results.title: Phylogenetically controlled life history trait meta-analysis in cetaceans reveals unexpected negative brain size and longevity correlation.

theories.name: Cognitive Buffer Hypothesis (CBH)

key_concepts.concept: Brain size as a survival buffer
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis posits that a larger brain provides individuals with enhanced cognitive abilities that help buffer against environmental challenges, thereby increasing survival rates.

key_concepts.concept: Longevity as a buffer for brain development costs
key_concepts.description: Longer lifespan is thought to offset the extended developmental costs associated with evolving and maintaining a larger brain, leading to an expected positive correlation between brain size and lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary correlation between brain size and lifespan
key_concepts.description: The CBH predicts a positive correlation between brain size and longevity across taxa, as seen in primates and other mammals, reflecting adaptive evolutionary pressures.

theories.evidence: Phylogenetic generalized least squares analysis of cetacean traits showing a negative correlation between brain size and lifespan, contrary to CBH predictions; comparative data with other mammalian taxa including primates and social carnivores.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable evolutionary mechanism explaining why brain size and lifespan co-evolve, offering a causal explanation for aging-related traits at the organismal level; the paper tests and discusses this theory in a new taxonomic context.

results.title: GnRH and Cognition.

theories.name: GnRH decline as a causal mechanism of age-related cognitive decline

key_concepts.concept: GnRH pulsatile secretion regulates brain function
key_concepts.description: GnRH, beyond its reproductive role, is involved in brain development and cognitive processes through its pulsatile secretion, which influences hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis and brain neuronal environment.

key_concepts.concept: Age-related decline in GnRH secretion contributes to cognitive decline
key_concepts.description: With aging, GnRH secretion declines along with the loss of gonadal steroid feedback, which is associated with disruptions in myelination, synaptic plasticity, and cognitive functions, linking GnRH decline to neurodegenerative disorders.

key_concepts.concept: Restoration of physiological GnRH levels can reverse cognitive decline
key_concepts.description: Therapeutic pulsatile GnRH administration can restore cognitive functions and sensory abilities in aged animals and humans, suggesting a causal role of GnRH in maintaining cognitive reserve and brain health during aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent studies showing GnRH involvement in brain development, cognitive function, age-related decline, and therapeutic reversal of cognitive deficits in animal models and human patients.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking GnRH decline to systemic cognitive aging, addresses broad aging-related cognitive decline, and discusses underlying biological mechanisms beyond reproduction.

results.title: Crassifolin A prolongs lifespan and healthspan in Caenorhabditis elegans via activating autophagy.

theories.name: Autophagy activation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Autophagy is a cellular process that maintains homeostasis by degrading and recycling damaged cellular components. Its activation is proposed to promote lifespan and healthspan by preventing accumulation of cellular damage, thus contributing to systemic aging delay.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of key aging-related signaling pathways
key_concepts.description: The theory involves the insulin/insulin-like signaling (IIS) pathway, dietary restriction (DR) pathway, and germline signaling pathway, which converge to activate transcription factors such as DAF-16/FOXO, SKN-1/NRF2, HSF-1, HLH-30/TFEB, and nuclear receptor DAF-12. These factors regulate autophagy and other longevity-associated processes.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from C. elegans survival analysis, aging phenotype assays, RT-qPCR, western blotting, and fluorescence quantification of transgenic reporter strains demonstrating lifespan and healthspan extension by Crassifolin A via activation of autophagy and related signaling pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (autophagy activation) underlying aging at the organismal level, supported by molecular pathways known to regulate aging broadly, not limited to a specific disease or organ.

results.title: Experiential diversity theory of adult development and aging in daily life.

theories.name: Experiential Diversity Theory of Adult Development and Aging

key_concepts.description: Experiential diversity is conceptualized as the richness and balance of different types of experiences across daily life domains such as activities, stressors, and emotions. It posits that having a wide and varied range of experiences contributes to healthy and resilient aging.

The theory links differences in experiential diversity to interactions between the individual and their environment, suggesting that these interactions influence the diversity of experiences one encounters and thus impact aging-related outcomes.

Experiential diversity is discussed in the context of developmental changes across the lifespan (ontogeny) and broader sociohistorical influences, indicating that both individual development and historical context shape experiential diversity and its effects on aging.

key_concepts.concept: Decline of Experiential Diversity with Age
key_concepts.description: Empirical evidence shows that the diversity of experiences tends to decline as people age, which may relate to changes in behavior, opportunities, and environmental interactions, influencing aging trajectories.

theories.evidence: The paper presents a conceptual framework and cites advances in empirical studies across three domains of daily experiences (activities, stressors, emotions) demonstrating age-related decline in experiential diversity. Methodological and theoretical considerations for future research are also provided.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining how aging occurs through changes in experiential diversity, linking person-environment interactions to aging outcomes. It offers a causal explanation by suggesting that reduced experiential diversity contributes to less healthy aging, addressing aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Evolution within the body: the rise and fall of somatic Darwinism in the late nineteenth century.

theories.name: Somatic Darwinism

key_concepts.concept: Struggle for existence between body parts
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that within an organism, different cells or body parts compete in a manner analogous to natural selection, influencing adaptive changes through population cell dynamics rather than a predefined harmonious design.

Elie Metchnikoff extended somatic Darwinism by proposing that immune cells, particularly phagocytes, mediate selection processes that drive adaptation, development, pathology, and senescence within the organism.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary vision of immunity and senescence
key_concepts.description: The theory frames immunity, development, pathology, and aging as outcomes of evolutionary processes occurring within the body, emphasizing internal cellular competition and selection as causal mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Historical analysis of the development and decline of the somatic Darwinism concept, referencing works of Ernst Haeckel, Wilhelm Preyer, Wilhelm Roux, and Elie Metchnikoff.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining aging and senescence at the organismal level through internal evolutionary processes; it addresses aging broadly and provides a mechanistic framework rather than narrow or descriptive findings.

results.title: Investigating Mechanisms of Ovarian Aging and Menopause Timing Using a Stochastic Approach.

theories.name: Stochastic multistage depletion theory of ovarian aging

key_concepts.concept: Follicle depletion as a multistage stochastic process
key_concepts.description: The theory models the decline in ovarian follicles through multiple stages, each governed by specific transition and death rates, capturing the probabilistic nature of follicle maturation and loss over time.

The narrow distribution of menopause timing across individuals is explained by synchronization effects that arise when transition rates between follicle stages become comparable, leading to coordinated depletion.

key_concepts.concept: Role of follicle death (atresia) in accelerating maturation
key_concepts.description: Follicle death is proposed to accelerate the maturation of remaining follicles, potentially explaining why females are born with an oversupply of follicles relative to reproductive needs.

key_concepts.concept: Time-dependent transition rates and acceleration of follicle depletion
key_concepts.description: Transition rates between follicle stages vary over time, and the model predicts a specific age at which follicle depletion accelerates, aligning with observed data on ovarian aging.

theories.evidence: Theoretical modeling supported by fitting to available empirical data on follicle depletion and menopause timing; no direct experimental data presented but model accounts well for observed distributions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining the timing and process of ovarian aging at the organism level, addressing a fundamental aging process (menopause) with mechanistic stochastic modeling.

results.title: Evolutionarily conserved transcription factors as regulators of longevity and targets for geroprotection.

theories.name: Transcriptional Regulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Certain transcription factors conserved across species regulate key transcriptional networks that control metabolic homeostasis and stress responses, which are early hallmarks of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Transcriptional network aberrations as aging drivers
key_concepts.description: Aberrations in transcriptional regulation disrupt cellular homeostasis and stress responses, contributing causally to aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation of longevity via transcription factors
key_concepts.description: Manipulating these conserved transcription factors can affect lifespan and healthspan across multiple model organisms, suggesting a fundamental mechanism underlying aging.
Targeting these transcription factors offers a strategy for interventions aimed at mitigating age-related diseases and potentially slowing aging itself.

theories.evidence: Citations and evidence from multiple multicellular model organisms (nematodes, flies, mice) showing lifespan and healthspan effects linked to conserved transcription factors; tentative links to human aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging at the organism level involving fundamental transcriptional regulation; addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases; discusses evolutionary conservation implying generality.

results.title: Social life results in social stress protection: a novel concept to explain individual life-history patterns in social insects.

theories.name: Social stress protection theory

key_concepts.description: A general concept proposing that social insects benefit from group-level defenses against a broad range of biotic and abiotic stressors, beyond the previously recognized social immunity against pathogens and parasites. This collective protection reduces individual stress exposure.

Because social groups can cooperatively mitigate environmental and biological stresses, individual members may evolve to invest less in their own direct defenses, optimizing their life-history traits such as longevity and aging plasticity.

The colonial lifestyle and social cooperation allow social insects like honey bees to exhibit exceptional aging plasticity and altered life expectancy patterns, potentially driven by the buffering effects of social stress protection.

theories.evidence: Conceptual reasoning supported by examples from honey bees and other social insects; references to established social immunity literature; discussion of how beekeeping practices disrupt social stress protection; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how social life influences aging and life-history patterns at the organismal level in social insects. It offers an organizing principle linking social behavior to aging plasticity, thus addressing why and how aging occurs differently in social species.

results.title: The Fallacy of the Longevity Elixir: Negligible Senescence May be Achieved, but Not by Using Something Physical.

theories.name: Evolutionary techno-cultural alignment theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Aging as an evolutionarily unnecessary process
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that human aging may become evolutionarily redundant due to future techno-cultural societal developments that alter evolutionary pressures and necessities.

Regenerative biotechnologies are argued to be fundamentally limited in their ability to counteract the stochastic, background process of aging due to disruption of complex organismal architecture and translational challenges.

key_concepts.concept: Distinction between age-related diseases and fundamental aging
key_concepts.description: The theory distinguishes between treating age-related degenerative diseases and addressing the underlying stochastic aging process, emphasizing that therapies effective for diseases may not impact the fundamental aging process.

theories.evidence: Conceptual reasoning and theoretical arguments presented; no experimental data cited in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain why aging occurs and how it might be rendered unnecessary through evolutionary and societal mechanisms; provides causal reasoning about limitations of physical interventions and evolutionary context.

results.title: Genetic and molecular basis for cellular senescence.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Normal human and rodent cells have a limited number of divisions in culture, after which they undergo morphological changes and stop proliferating, a process called cellular senescence or cellular aging.

Experimental evidence suggests that cellular senescence is controlled by genetic programs, as defects in senescence can be corrected by introducing specific chromosomes from normal cells into transformed cells.

Genes controlling the cell cycle, particularly those regulating entry into the DNA synthesis phase, are altered in senescent cells; phosphorylation changes in the retinoblastoma gene are implicated in this process.

key_concepts.concept: Link between cellular and organismal aging
key_concepts.description: Although not yet proven, it is proposed that aging at the cellular level contributes to the aging of the whole organism, suggesting cellular senescence may be a fundamental mechanism underlying organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental results showing correction of senescence defects by chromosome transfer, mapping of senescence genes to chromosomes, and molecular findings on cell cycle gene alterations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process (cellular senescence) with causal genetic and molecular mechanisms, proposes a generalizable mechanism potentially underlying organismal aging, and is not limited to a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Luck can explain the positive link between fecundity and longevity: The Matthew effect in social insects and beyond.
Beta-Hydroxybutyrate but not NMN supplementation mimics caloric restriction reducing early mortality in Daphnia.

theories.name: NAD+ Homeostasis and Caloric Restriction Mimicry Theory

key_concepts.concept: NAD+ homeostasis as a determinant of lifespan
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that maintaining NAD+ levels is crucial for lifespan regulation, with NAD+ abundance influencing aging processes and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Caloric restriction (CR) extends lifespan via NAD+ regulation
key_concepts.description: Caloric restriction is proposed to extend lifespan by modulating NAD+ metabolism, which in turn affects cellular and organismal aging mechanisms.
Beta-hydroxybutyrate (BHB), a ketone body, is hypothesized to regulate NAD+ levels and thereby reproduce some beneficial effects of caloric restriction on lifespan and mortality.

key_concepts.concept: Nicotinamide mononucleotide (NMN) as NAD+ precursor with differential effects
key_concepts.description: NMN, a precursor to NAD+, is tested for its ability to mimic CR effects, but findings suggest it does not reduce early mortality like BHB and may interfere with BHB’s benefits.

theories.evidence: Experimental lifespan assays in Daphnia under full diet, CR diet, and supplementation with BHB, NMN, and their combination; measurements of mortality, fecundity, lipofuscin accumulation, offspring lipid investment; RNAseq gene expression analysis comparing treatments.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (NAD+ homeostasis) underlying aging and lifespan regulation, linking it to caloric restriction and metabolic interventions with organism-wide implications.

results.title: [Mineral metabolism and aging.].

theories.name: Calciprotein Particle (CPP) Pro-aging Hypothesis

key_concepts.description: Phosphorus, present in blood mainly as phosphate ions and CPP, is identified as a factor that accelerates aging processes in mammals, based on mutant mouse models exhibiting accelerated aging.

CPP are colloidal particles composed of solid-phase calcium-phosphate and the serum protein fetuin-A. Their levels increase with age and decline in renal function, suggesting a systemic accumulation linked to aging.
CPP have the capacity to induce inflammation and calcification of vascular smooth muscle cells in vitro, implicating them as active pathogenic agents that may drive aging-related tissue dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of phosphate and CPP
key_concepts.description: Interventions aimed at reducing phosphate levels or CPP formation are proposed as potential anti-aging strategies, indicating a causal role of mineral metabolism dysregulation in aging.

theories.evidence: Identification of accelerated aging in mutant mice linked to phosphorus; in vitro studies showing CPP induce inflammation and vascular calcification; observed increase of CPP with age and renal decline.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging involving mineral metabolism and CPP accumulation, applicable at organism level, with mechanistic hypotheses explaining how aging is accelerated.

results.title: Polyphenism predicts actuarial senescence and lifespan in tiger salamanders.
LLMs and AI Life Models for Traditional Chinese Medicine-derived Geroprotector Formulation.
Senoinflammation as the underlying mechanism of aging and its modulation by calorie restriction.

theories.name: Senoinflammation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: A chronic, unresolved low-grade inflammatory state that affects multiple organs and systemic functions, contributing to aging and systemic degeneration.
A pro-inflammatory phenotype developed by senescent cells that secrete cytokines, chemokines, and other factors, driving metabolic dysregulation and inflammation during aging.
The theory posits that age-related inflammation (senoinflammation) is causally related to metabolic disturbances that exacerbate aging processes and age-related diseases.
Calorie restriction suppresses pro-inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, lipid accumulation, and SASP, thereby mitigating senoinflammation and its aging effects.

theories.evidence: Biochemical and molecular biology data supporting senoinflammation; experimental data from calorie restriction studies showing suppression of inflammatory markers and SASP.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining systemic aging via chronic inflammation linked to cellular senescence and metabolic dysregulation; addresses aging broadly; provides mechanistic explanation; supported by experimental data.

results.title: Getting together: Social contact frequency across the life span.
Decoding DNA repair regulation across human lifespan variability.

theories.name: DNA Repair and Longevity Theory

key_concepts.concept: DNA Repair as a Fundamental Aging Mechanism
key_concepts.description: DNA repair is an evolutionarily conserved process essential for maintaining genetic stability. Deficiencies or alterations in DNA repair capacity are implicated in aging and longevity, suggesting that the efficiency of DNA repair mechanisms influences the rate of biological aging.

key_concepts.concept: Variation in Human Lifespan Linked to DNA Repair
key_concepts.description: Human lifespan varies dramatically, from progeroid syndromes with very short lifespans to exceptional longevity over 120 years. This variability provides a natural framework to study how differences in DNA repair regulation may underlie lifespan differences across individuals.

key_concepts.concept: Targeted Modulation of DNA Repair Pathways to Promote Longevity
key_concepts.description: Understanding the molecular basis of DNA repair in humans with divergent aging trajectories opens avenues for targeted therapies. Precise modulation of DNA repair pathways could potentially promote longevity by enhancing genome maintenance.

theories.evidence: The paper integrates advances from human studies and comparative analyses of individuals with diverse aging trajectories, referencing prior evidence linking DNA repair to aging and longevity. It highlights challenges in translating animal model findings to humans.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging based on DNA repair mechanisms, addressing fundamental aging processes across the organism and lifespan variability. It is not limited to specific organs or diseases but frames DNA repair as a core aging mechanism.

results.title: Treating the aging brain: cortical reorganization and behavior.
Growth rate, evolutionary entropy and ageing across the tree of life.

theories.name: Evolutionary entropy theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary entropy as a fitness measure
key_concepts.description: Evolutionary entropy quantifies the diversity and variability in life history traits within a population and serves as a complementary measure to growth rate for assessing Darwinian fitness.

key_concepts.concept: Sensitivity of entropy and selection intensity
key_concepts.description: The sensitivity of evolutionary entropy to age is typically convex, indicating that natural selection acts more strongly on both younger and older age groups, which contrasts with the decreasing sensitivity of growth rate with age.
The theory suggests that evolutionary entropy captures a wider range of aging patterns, including phenomena like negative senescence, which are not well explained by growth rate sensitivity alone.

theories.evidence: Theoretical analysis of sensitivity functions of growth rate and evolutionary entropy across populations, with references to observed aging patterns such as negative senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging patterns based on evolutionary principles applicable across populations and species, addressing fundamental aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Time's up: Epigenetic clocks in plants.

theories.name: Epigenetic clock theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: DNA methylation as a biomarker of aging
key_concepts.description: Epigenetic clocks use DNA methylation patterns to predict the chronological age of an organism with high accuracy, reflecting underlying biological aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic changes as a measure of biological time
key_concepts.description: These clocks capture progressive, clock-like epigenetic modifications that correlate with aging, not only within an individual's lifespan but also across broader temporal scales such as circadian rhythms and evolutionary time.

key_concepts.concept: Differences between plant and animal epigenetic clocks
key_concepts.description: Plant epigenetic clocks differ from animal clocks in key aspects, including their ability to measure time beyond an individual organism's lifespan, reflecting unique biological and evolutionary aging processes in plants.

theories.evidence: Summary and classification of emerging evidence of epigenetic clocks in plants, comparison with animal epigenetic clocks, and discussion of biological bases; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (epigenetic changes) underlying biological aging across organisms, offers causal explanation (epigenetic modifications as drivers or markers of aging), and addresses aging broadly including organismal and evolutionary scales.

results.title: Clones of aging: When better fitness can be dangerous.

theories.name: Aberrant Clonal Expansion Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: With aging, certain cell clones with higher proliferative fitness expand abnormally within tissues. These expansions arise from normal cell turnover dynamics but become more prevalent due to changes in the tissue microenvironment.

key_concepts.concept: Aged tissue microenvironment favoring fitter clones
key_concepts.description: The decline in regenerative potential of surrounding cells in aged tissues creates a selective environment that favors clones with enhanced proliferative capacity, allowing them to outcompete normal cells.

key_concepts.concept: Growth pattern and tissue pattern formation defects
key_concepts.description: The combination of increased proliferative fitness and defects in tissue patterning may drive clonal expansions toward neoplastic transformation, linking clonal dynamics to cancer risk in aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references accumulating evidence and theoretical reasoning about clonal expansions and tissue microenvironment changes with age; no specific experimental data detailed in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism explaining how aging tissues change at the cellular level, affecting organismal aging and cancer risk. It addresses fundamental aging processes (clonal dynamics, tissue environment), proposes causal mechanisms (fitness advantage, regenerative decline), and is not limited to a single disease but connects to systemic aging.

results.title: Genetic and Genomic Insights into Planarian Biology.

theories.name: Regeneration-Linked Rejuvenation Theory

key_concepts.concept: Whole-body regeneration as a mechanism of biological rejuvenation
key_concepts.description: Planarians possess the ability to regenerate any lost tissue, and this regenerative capacity can reverse age-associated physiological decline, effectively making older planarians biologically younger. This suggests that regeneration processes can counteract aging at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Stem cell function in lifespan regulation and healthspan improvement
key_concepts.description: The theory implicates stem cells as central players in maintaining tissue homeostasis and enabling regeneration, which in turn regulates lifespan and improves healthspan by preventing or reversing aging-related deterioration.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic and genomic mechanisms underlying regeneration and aging
key_concepts.description: Advances in sequencing and genomic technologies have provided insights into the genetic basis of regeneration and age reversal, suggesting that specific genetic programs or pathways may orchestrate these processes, linking regeneration directly to aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: The abstract references recent experimental data showing regeneration in older planarians reverses physiological decline, and genomic studies that have transformed understanding of regeneration, aging, and rejuvenation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how biological aging can be reversed through regeneration, proposing underlying mechanisms involving stem cells and genetic regulation, thus meeting the criteria of generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope.

results.title: Does single-strand DNA break repair capacity influence oocyte maintenance and quality?

theories.name: DNA repair capacity theory of ovarian aging

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage and repair in oocyte maintenance
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the ability of oocytes to repair DNA damage, specifically single-strand DNA breaks, is critical for their survival and quality. Endogenous cellular processes cause DNA lesions, and efficient repair mechanisms are necessary to maintain oocyte function over time.

key_concepts.concept: Role of single-strand DNA break repair
key_concepts.description: While double-strand DNA break repair has been linked to ovarian aging, this theory extends the concept to single-strand DNA repair mechanisms, hypothesizing that they also play a fundamental role in oocyte maintenance and thus influence ovarian aging.

theories.evidence: References to human genome-wide association studies and animal model data linking DNA repair capacity to ovarian aging; hypothesis based on these findings
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (DNA repair capacity) underlying a fundamental aging process (ovarian aging), generalizable to organism-level reproductive aging, not limited to a narrow phenomenon, and attempts to explain why aging occurs in oocytes.

results.title: Life and Death without Telomerase: The Saccharomyces cerevisiae Model.

theories.name: Replicative Senescence as an Anticancer Mechanism

key_concepts.description: The absence of telomerase leads to changes in telomere length and structure, which affects cellular proliferative capacity and genome stability. These telomeric state transitions are critical in triggering replicative senescence.
Variability among cells in response to telomerase loss results in different cellular fates, including the potential evasion of senescence, which has implications for understanding cancer development.

key_concepts.concept: Inter-organelle Communication in Response to Telomerase Loss
key_concepts.description: The interplay between the nucleus and other organelles upon telomerase inactivation reveals complex cellular communication networks that influence aging and evolutionary processes.

theories.evidence: Insights derived from studies in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, a model organism, including molecular investigations of telomere biology, intracellular signaling, and organelle responses; references to foundational discoveries in cell cycle and DNA repair mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental aging process (replicative senescence) with causal mechanisms (telomere shortening due to telomerase absence), generalizable across eukaryotes, and connects cellular mechanisms to organism-level aging and cancer prevention.

results.title: DNA repair and the evolution of longevity: a critical analysis.

theories.name: DNA repair rate theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: DNA repair rates correlate with lifespan
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that species with higher DNA repair rates tend to have longer maximum lifespans, suggesting that efficient DNA repair mechanisms contribute causally to longevity by reducing accumulated genetic damage.

key_concepts.concept: Confounding effects of body size and phylogeny
key_concepts.description: The theory acknowledges that observed correlations between DNA repair rates and lifespan may be influenced or confounded by other factors such as body size and evolutionary relatedness among species, which must be accounted for to validate the causal link.

theories.evidence: Reanalysis of existing comparative data controlling for body size and phylogeny, showing little evidence supporting the direct relationship between DNA repair rates and lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging mechanism (DNA repair) with causal implications for lifespan differences across species, addressing general aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Endogenous retroviruses in multiple sclerosis: A network-based etiopathogenic model.

theories.name: Endogenous Retrovirus Activation as a Driver of System-Specific Aging

key_concepts.description: The activation of human endogenous retroviruses (HERVs) acts as a critical node in the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis and is proposed to contribute to aging-related neurodegeneration by disrupting cellular homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic Noise and Increased Epigenomic Entropy
key_concepts.description: Endogenous retroviruses contribute to epigenetic noise, which increases epigenomic entropy, leading to the proliferation of disorganized cellular subpopulations and accelerating system-specific aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammation and Aging as Interconnected Processes
key_concepts.description: Inflammation and aging are conceptualized as two sides of the same coin, representing plastic dis-adaptation to external stimuli that accelerates organ-specific aging and disrupts systemic communication, producing overlapping neurological symptoms.

theories.evidence: Review of preclinical, clinical, epidemiological, and evolutionary evidence linking endogenous retrovirus activation with multiple sclerosis and aging-related neurodegeneration; rationale for anti-retroviral therapy as disease-modifying strategy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking endogenous retrovirus activation to systemic aging processes beyond a single disease, explaining how epigenetic and inflammatory pathways drive aging at an organismal level.

results.title: Promoting health and survival through lowered body temperature.

theories.name: Lowered Body Temperature as a Longevity Mechanism

key_concepts.description: Lowering core body temperature (T_b) is associated with increased lifespan across species, suggesting a fundamental link between body temperature regulation and aging processes.

The theory challenges prior explanations that longevity effects of lowered T_b are solely due to slowed nonenzymatic chemical reactions, reduced mitochondrial reactive oxygen species, or lowered metabolic rate, proposing additional mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Molecular and Cellular Pathways Modulated by Temperature
key_concepts.description: Cold promotes longevity through specific pathways such as nutrient sensing and proteostasis, alters protein and nucleic acid thermodynamics affecting their structure and function, and modulates temperature-sensitive ion channels, dauer mutations, and RNA structures.

Lowered T_b influences the epigenetic signature and inflammation, potentially reshaping cellular environments through induction of RNA-binding cold shock proteins, activation of cold-sensitive kinases, and differential RNA splicing.

theories.evidence: Summarizes evidence from multiple species showing lifespan extension by lowered T_b, including links to calorie restriction effects; cites recent invertebrate studies revealing molecular pathways influenced by cold; discusses biochemical and epigenetic data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a general, organism-level aging mechanism (temperature regulation), proposes causal mechanisms beyond correlation, and addresses broad aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: The energy resistance principle.

theories.name: Energy Resistance Principle (ERP)

key_concepts.description: Energy resistance is described as a fundamental property in biological systems that enables the transformation of energy, converting the unformed energy potential from food-derived electrons into useful biological work.

key_concepts.concept: Excess energy resistance causes aging and disease
key_concepts.description: While necessary for life, excess energy resistance leads to reductive and oxidative stress, heat generation, inflammation, molecular damage, and information loss, which are hallmarks of aging and disease.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation of energy resistance influences health and aging
key_concepts.description: Factors such as disease-causing stressors increase energy resistance and circulating GDF15 levels, whereas restorative interventions like sleep and physical activity reduce energy resistance, promoting healing and healthy aging.

key_concepts.concept: ERP as a general bioenergetic framework
key_concepts.description: The ERP is proposed as a testable, general framework that explains bioenergetic forces shaping development, aging, and the continuum between health and disease, implying a causal mechanism for aging at the organismal level.

theories.evidence: The abstract references conceptual arguments linking energy resistance to known aging hallmarks and physiological markers such as GDF15, and mentions the principle is testable, but does not detail experimental data in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The ERP attempts to explain aging as a fundamental bioenergetic process applicable broadly to organisms, proposes a causal mechanism (energy resistance causing molecular damage and aging hallmarks), and connects to general aging rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: The role of Sestrins in the regulation of the aging process.

theories.name: Sestrin-mediated regulation of aging

key_concepts.description: Sestrins are stress-inducing proteins that help protect cells from damage by regulating antioxidant responses, thereby mitigating oxidative stress, which is a known contributor to aging.
Sestrins regulate autophagy, a cellular degradation and recycling process that maintains cellular homeostasis and is implicated in aging and longevity.
Sestrins influence nutritional perception and metabolic balance, which are critical for maintaining organismal health and lifespan, linking metabolic regulation to aging processes.
Sestrins play roles in immune function and have been shown to affect lifespan and health span, suggesting they contribute to systemic aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Summary of multiple studies showing involvement of Sestrins in aging-related processes such as metabolism, autophagy, immunity, and lifespan regulation; evolutionary conservation noted
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism involving Sestrins that regulate fundamental aging processes at the organismal level; not limited to a single organ or disease; discusses underlying mechanisms

results.title: Telomere Attrition in Human Lens Epithelial Cells Associated with Oxidative Stress Provide a New Therapeutic Target for the Treatment, Dissolving and Prevention of Cataract with N-Acetylcarnosine Lubricant Eye Drops. Kinetic, Pharmacological and Activity-Dependent Separation of Therapeutic Targeting: Transcorneal Penetration and Delivery of L-Carnosine in the Aqueous Humor and Hormone-Like Hypothalamic Antiaging Effects of the Instilled Ophthalmic Drug Through a Safe Eye Medication Technique.

theories.name: Telomere Attrition and Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere attrition as a causal driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres, protective DNA-protein structures at chromosome ends, shorten with each cell division and under oxidative stress, leading to cellular senescence and tissue aging. In lens epithelial cells, telomere shortening without telomerase activity triggers premature senescence contributing to cataractogenesis.

Reactive oxygen species and phospholipid hydroperoxides cause oxidative damage to lens epithelial cells, promoting telomere erosion and functional decline. This oxidative damage is a fundamental mechanism linking environmental and metabolic stress to cellular aging.

key_concepts.concept: Systemic neuroendocrine regulation of aging via hypothalamic pathways
key_concepts.description: The study suggests that N-acetylcarnosine eye drops may influence hypothalamic neuroendocrine pathways by delivering L-carnosine and its metabolites to the tuberomammillary nucleus, potentially modulating hormone-like antiaging effects and systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: The paper presents clinical data showing improved visual function in older adults treated with N-acetylcarnosine eye drops, biochemical rationale linking telomere shortening in lens cells to oxidative stress, and hypothesized neuroendocrine effects based on drug delivery to the hypothalamus.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (telomere attrition driven by oxidative stress) underlying aging at the cellular and organismal level, links cellular senescence to systemic aging and mortality, and discusses neuroendocrine regulation as a broader aging mechanism.

results.title: Multi-locus homozygosity promotes actuarial senescence in a wild mammal.

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of aging related to inbreeding depression and actuarial senescence

key_concepts.concept: Natural selection filters fitness costs to late life
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that deleterious effects of genomic homozygosity (e.g., from inbreeding) manifest primarily in late life because natural selection is weaker at older ages when reproductive value is lower. Thus, negative fitness impacts accumulate and become detectable as increased mortality or senescence.

Increased genome-wide homozygosity is associated with earlier onset and higher rates of actuarial senescence, indicating that genetic factors related to inbreeding contribute causally to aging-related mortality patterns.

key_concepts.concept: Interaction with disease amplifies aging effects
key_concepts.description: The presence of infection (bovine tuberculosis) further amplifies the association between homozygosity and actuarial senescence, suggesting that genetic vulnerability interacts with environmental stressors to influence aging.

theories.evidence: Bayesian analysis of life histories of wild European badgers, modeling Gompertz-Makeham mortality hazard function parameters in relation to multi-locus homozygosity, sex, disease status, and age-dependent mortality risks.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general evolutionary mechanism explaining why aging occurs (weaker selection in late life allows deleterious homozygosity effects to manifest), provides causal explanation linking genetic homozygosity to actuarial senescence, and addresses aging broadly at organismal level in a natural population.

results.title: Modeling the geometry of circadian synchronization and period across aging.

theories.name: Circadian Geometry Theory of Aging-Related Period Changes

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that changes in the freerunning circadian period across the lifespan arise from general properties of oscillator populations rather than specific localized mechanisms. It explains how the circadian period lengthens with age due to changes in coupling strength and variability.

key_concepts.concept: Role of coupling strength and period variability
key_concepts.description: Strong coupling among oscillators in early adulthood synchronizes the circadian period below the mean intrinsic period, while declining coupling and increased heterogeneity in intrinsic periods with aging lead to longer periods and reduced amplitude of rhythms.

The theory uses a Kuramoto model with time-dependent coupling and widening distribution of intrinsic periods to map synchronization geometry and macroscopic period changes, providing a parsimonious explanation for observed circadian dynamics across development and aging.

theories.evidence: Computational modeling results using Kuramoto oscillator framework; empirical data from C57BL/6 mice showing period changes and amplitude correlations; theoretical analysis of frequency distributions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how aging affects circadian period at the organismal level through oscillator coupling and variability dynamics. It addresses aging broadly by linking circadian rhythm changes to fundamental oscillator properties rather than a narrow organ-specific or disease-specific phenomenon.

results.title: Identification of genetic signatures of positive selection in apes linked to life-history trait adaptations.
A Binary siRNA-Loaded Tetrahedral DNA Nanobox for Synergetic Anti-Aging Therapy.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The accumulation of senescent cells in tissues contributes causally to organismal aging and age-related pathologies by promoting chronic inflammation and tissue dysfunction.
The mechanistic target of rapamycin complex 1 (mTORC1), particularly its component Raptor, regulates the conversion of cells into a senescent state, thus influencing aging progression.
Inhibiting mTORC1 signaling, for example by silencing Raptor expression via siRNA, can suppress cellular senescence and thereby delay aging and extend lifespan.

theories.evidence: Experimental results demonstrating that siRNA-loaded tetrahedral DNA nanostructures targeting Raptor inhibit mTORC1 signaling, reduce cellular senescence, attenuate inflammation, and extend lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (cellular senescence driven by mTORC1 signaling) underlying organismal aging, generalizable beyond specific tissues or diseases, and supported by intervention data.

results.title: Regulation of the Cilia as a Potential Treatment for Senescence and Tumors: A Review.

theories.name: Cilia-mediated regulation theory of aging and tumorigenesis

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the structural and functional integrity of primary cilia is closely linked to the development of diseases including progeria (a premature aging syndrome), tumorigenesis, and drug resistance. Changes in cilia phenotype may mediate key signaling pathways involved in these processes.

Primary cilia serve as critical mediators of signaling pathways, such as the Hedgehog pathway, which are implicated in both cancer progression and cellular senescence. Modulating these cilia-dependent signaling pathways can influence disease outcomes.

The hypothesis suggests that regulating cilia function or signaling could be a novel approach to treat senescence-related diseases, tumors, and ciliopathies. Anti-tumor and anti-aging drugs may exert effects through cilia-mediated mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Link between ciliopathies, aging, and metabolic disease
key_concepts.description: The theory connects ciliopathies with aging phenotypes and metabolic disorders such as obesity, suggesting that cilia dysfunction contributes broadly to systemic aging and related pathologies.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing literature linking primary cilia changes to progeria, tumorigenesis, drug resistance, and obesity; cites emerging use of Hedgehog inhibitors targeting cilia signaling; and discusses observed phenotypic overlaps between ciliopathies and aging/metabolic diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (cilia dysfunction and signaling disruption) underlying aging and tumorigenesis at the organismal level. It attempts to explain how aging and related diseases occur via cilia-mediated pathways, not limited to a single organ or disease. The paper hypothesizes a mechanistic role of cilia in systemic aging and tumor biology.

results.title: Development, regeneration and aging: a bizarre love triangle.
Should we Try to Alleviate Immunosenescence and Inflammaging - Why, How and to What Extent?

theories.name: Immunosenescence and Inflammaging as Aging Mechanisms

key_concepts.description: Aging-related decline in the immune system's ability to respond effectively to external and internal pathogens, leading to reduced immune surveillance and defense.
A chronic, low-grade inflammation state that develops with age due to immune system adaptations and regulatory changes, which may contribute to age-related pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Co-evolution of Immune System and Pathogens
key_concepts.description: The immune system evolved alongside pathogens, resulting in effective immunity but also built-in regulatory mechanisms (immune brakes) that change with age, influencing immunosenescence and inflammaging.

key_concepts.concept: Dual Role of Immunosenescence and Inflammaging
key_concepts.description: These processes can be detrimental by impairing immunity and promoting inflammation but may also have beneficial aspects, suggesting a complex balance in aging.

theories.evidence: Description of mechanisms underlying immune system aging, references to evolutionary context, and discussion of potential therapeutic interventions; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes causal mechanisms explaining why and how immune aging occurs at the organism level, discusses generalizable processes (immunosenescence and inflammaging) that affect systemic aging, and considers evolutionary and mechanistic bases.

results.title: Microbiome mediation of animal life histories via metabolites and insulin-like signalling.

theories.name: Microbiome-mediated modulation of aging via insulin-like signaling

key_concepts.concept: Gut microbiota influence on host life histories
key_concepts.description: Gut bacteria produce metabolites that can affect host development, growth, reproduction, and senescence by interacting with host metabolic and neuroendocrine pathways.

key_concepts.concept: Insulin-like growth factor (IGF) signaling pathway as a mediator
key_concepts.description: The IGF signaling pathway is a central regulatory network controlling development, growth, reproductive maturity, reproduction, and senescence, and is influenced by bacterially derived metabolites.

key_concepts.concept: Role of bacterial metabolites such as short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs)
key_concepts.description: SCFAs produced by bacterial fermentation act as signaling molecules that interface with the insulin-like signaling pathway and bind to receptors on neuroendocrine and peripheral nervous tissues, thereby modulating host life history traits.

theories.evidence: Citations of experimental studies showing SCFA increases affect circulating IGF-1 levels and are associated with development, growth, reproduction, and delayed senescence; references to -omics approaches for integrative testing.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism by which gut microbiota modulate fundamental aging processes via insulin-like signaling pathways, providing a causal explanation for how microbial metabolites influence systemic aging-related traits.

results.title: Mutual antagonism between aryl hydrocarbon receptor and hypoxia-inducible factor-1α (AhR/HIF-1α) signaling: Impact on the aging process.

theories.name: Antagonistic Signaling Theory of Aging via AhR and HIF-1α Pathways

key_concepts.description: The aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR) pathway is implicated in promoting age-related degenerative processes such as increased oxidative stress, inhibition of autophagy, promotion of cellular senescence, and extracellular matrix degeneration.

key_concepts.concept: HIF-1α signaling extends lifespan and counters aging
key_concepts.description: Hypoxia-inducible factor-1α (HIF-1α) signaling stimulates autophagy, inhibits cellular senescence, and enhances cell proliferation, thereby contributing to lifespan extension and maintenance of tissue homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Mutual antagonism between AhR and HIF-1α signaling
key_concepts.description: AhR and HIF-1α compete for the shared dimerization partner ARNT/HIF-1β, leading to competition for DNA binding and antagonistic regulation of downstream processes such as autophagy and senescence, which may drive the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary conservation and origin linked to multicellularity
key_concepts.description: Both AhR and HIF signaling systems are evolutionarily ancient and conserved, with roles in embryogenesis and multicellular organism evolution, suggesting their interplay may be fundamental to the evolutionary origin of aging.

theories.evidence: Citations to evolutionary conservation of AhR and HIF-1α, known effects of AhR on oxidative stress and senescence, known effects of HIF-1α on autophagy and proliferation, and molecular interactions such as competition for ARNT/HIF-1β and co-chaperone involvement.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: proposes a general, organism-level mechanism explaining aging as a balance between two conserved signaling pathways with antagonistic effects on cellular processes relevant to aging; provides causal explanations; addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Cold-inflammaging: When a state of homeostatic-imbalance associated with aging precedes the low-grade pro-inflammatory-state (inflammaging): Meaning, evolution, inflammaging phenotypes.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.description: Inflammaging is characterized by a persistent, low-grade increase in pro-inflammatory mediators in the plasma of elderly individuals, contributing to the pathogenesis of age-related chronic diseases.

Cold-inflammaging is a proposed early phase preceding overt inflammaging, marked by slight increases in cytokine levels that reflect homeostatic imbalance but remain below the threshold defining inflammaging. This phase represents an adaptive process aimed at restoring or achieving new homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Cytokines as drivers of homeostatic imbalance and inflammaging
key_concepts.description: Cytokines have a pleiotropic role as signal transducers; their dysregulated production by innate immunity initiates homeostatic imbalance (cold-inflammaging) and, if persistent, drives the transition to chronic inflammaging.

Cellular senescence with its senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), altered gut microbiota, and accumulation of endogenous molecular waste (termed Garb-aging) are important contributors to the inflammaging process.
Aging, inflammaging, and age-related diseases share fundamental biological mechanisms that converge on inflammaging, highlighting its central role in systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of Franceschi et al. (2000) and other established data showing increased pro-inflammatory mediators in elderly plasma; conceptual framework linking cytokine dynamics, cellular senescence, microbiota changes, and molecular waste accumulation to inflammaging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging at the organismal level by framing chronic inflammation as a fundamental aging mechanism; it addresses systemic aging rather than a narrow phenomenon; it integrates multiple biological drivers into a cohesive model.

results.title: Evolution of senescence: Alzheimer's disease and evolution.

theories.name: Evolutionary theories of senescence

key_concepts.description: The theory involves genetic variants, including common polymorphisms and rare mutations, that influence aging and senescence, suggesting that genetic diversity contributes to the aging process.

The theory is based on evolutionary principles explaining why senescence occurs, such as the decline in the force of natural selection with age, leading to accumulation of deleterious mutations or antagonistic pleiotropy.

theories.evidence: The abstract references genetic findings in Alzheimer's disease that align with the postulates of the two main evolutionary theories of senescence, implying genetic data supports these theories.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it addresses aging as a fundamental process at the organism level, proposes causal genetic mechanisms explaining why senescence occurs, and applies evolutionary logic broadly rather than focusing narrowly on Alzheimer's disease alone.

results.title: [Genetic mechanisms of longevity responses to dietary restriction].

theories.name: Dietary Restriction Longevity Mechanism

key_concepts.description: Dietary restriction (DR) is shown to effectively extend lifespan in mammals and reduce the incidence and progression of many age-dependent diseases, suggesting a fundamental role in modulating aging processes.

Recent advances have identified genetic bases related to energy sensing and life control across species (yeast, invertebrates, mammals), indicating conserved pathways that mediate the longevity response to dietary restriction.
Emerging evidence points to the brain as a principal sensor and regulator of dietary restriction signals, orchestrating systemic responses that lead to lifespan extension in metazoans.

theories.evidence: Citations and recent advances in genetic studies across multiple model organisms; evidence highlighting the brain's role in sensing dietary restriction.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how dietary restriction influences aging at the organismal level, involving genetic and nervous system regulation; addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Understanding Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Physical Fatigue Through the Perspective of Immunosenescence.

theories.name: Immunosenescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Immunosenescence refers to the progressive deterioration of the immune system associated with aging, leading to impaired immune responses and increased susceptibility to chronic inflammation.

key_concepts.concept: Chronic inflammation as a driver of systemic dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Aging immune cells promote persistent low-grade inflammation that disrupts normal cellular and tissue functions, contributing to metabolic and muscular impairments.
Interactions among immune, muscular, neuroendocrine, and vascular systems become dysregulated due to immunosenescence, sustaining pathological fatigue and systemic decline.
Chronic inflammation impairs mitochondrial ATP production, leading to energy deficits and muscle catabolism, which are central to fatigue symptoms.
Suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis and β2-adrenergic receptor dysfunction exacerbate immune dysregulation and metabolic imbalance.

theories.evidence: Synthesis of clinical and experimental data including biomarkers such as cytokines and exhaustion markers; discussion of cross-organ interactions and metabolic consequences.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining systemic aging-related immune decline and its impact on organismal fatigue, linking immune dysfunction to metabolic and neuroendocrine systems beyond a single disease context.

results.title: TMBIM-2 orchestrates systemic mitochondrial stress response via facilitating Ca2+ oscillations.

theories.name: Neuronal mitochondrial stress response theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Neuronal mitochondrial stress as a systemic signal
key_concepts.description: Prolonged mitochondrial stress in neurons triggers systemic responses that affect other tissues, such as the intestine, indicating a communication axis that influences organismal aging.
The transmembrane protein TMBIM-2 facilitates spatiotemporal calcium oscillations in neurons via the Ca2+ efflux pump MCA-3, which are critical for neurotransmitter release and downstream signaling.

key_concepts.concept: Activation of mitochondrial unfolded protein response (UPRmt)
key_concepts.description: Neuronal Ca2+ oscillations promote serotonin release that activates the neuronal-to-intestinal UPRmt, a conserved stress response pathway that modulates metabolism and aging.

TMBIM-2 expression decreases with age, correlating with functional decline, but its overexpression can counteract age-associated behavioral decline and extend lifespan, suggesting a causal role in aging regulation.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from Caenorhabditis elegans showing TMBIM-2-dependent Ca2+ oscillations, serotonin release, activation of UPRmt, behavioral assays of learning, and lifespan extension upon TMBIM-2 overexpression.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory proposes a generalizable mechanism linking neuronal mitochondrial stress to systemic aging processes via Ca2+ signaling and UPRmt activation; it provides a causal explanation for aging-related decline and lifespan regulation; and it addresses aging at the organismal level beyond a single tissue or disease.

results.title: Circular RNAs as multifaceted molecular regulators of vital activity and potential biomarkers of aging.

theories.name: Circular RNA accumulation and deregulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: CircRNAs are single-stranded covalently closed RNAs that accumulate with age in various species, including humans. Their stability and presence in biological fluids make them notable molecular entities whose levels change as organisms age.

key_concepts.concept: CircRNAs as regulators of biological processes linked to aging
key_concepts.description: CircRNAs regulate key biological processes such as genomic stability, metabolism, cell death, and signaling pathways. Their deregulation due to accumulation may contribute causally to the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: CircRNAs as epigenetic biomarkers and therapeutic targets
key_concepts.description: Certain circRNAs (e.g., circFOXO3, circRNA100783, circPVT1) have been identified as potential epigenetic biomarkers of aging, with the possibility that targeting circRNAs could offer therapeutic avenues for age-associated diseases.

theories.evidence: Analysis of scientific databases on circRNA expression during aging; examples of age-related differential expression of circRNAs in multiple species; references to known circRNAs linked to aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process by proposing that accumulation and deregulation of circRNAs drive aging through effects on genomic stability and metabolism, thus meeting generalizability and causal explanation criteria. The scope is broad, addressing systemic aging mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Geroscience: just another name or is there more to it?

theories.name: Geroscience theory

key_concepts.concept: Targeting aging to improve late-life health
key_concepts.description: Geroscience posits that aging is a malleable biological process and that interventions targeting aging mechanisms can improve health outcomes in late life, potentially offering a cost-effective approach to human healthspan extension.

key_concepts.concept: Malleability of aging in model organisms
key_concepts.description: The theory is supported by evidence from model organisms where aging processes can be modulated, suggesting conserved regulatory mechanisms that could be translated to humans.

Geroscience emphasizes moving from basic biological understanding of aging to translational and clinical applications, aiming to develop therapies that target aging itself rather than individual diseases.

theories.evidence: The abstract references the evolution of geroscience, its relationship to prior biogerontology and anti-aging medicine, and the progress in understanding aging regulation in model organisms; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The geroscience theory attempts to explain aging as a fundamental, malleable biological process with underlying regulatory mechanisms, proposes causal intervention targets, and addresses aging broadly at the organismal level. Thus, it meets the core criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: [Aging of prokaryotic organisms].

theories.name: Prokaryotic aging via asymmetric cell division and conditional senescence

key_concepts.concept: Asymmetric cell division leading to aging
key_concepts.description: In certain prokaryotes like Caulobacter crescentus, asymmetric cell division results in a gradual increase in the time required for new generation development, which is interpreted as a form of aging at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Inheritance of aging factors causing proliferative exhaustion
key_concepts.description: In Escherichia coli, the inheritance of specific cellular structures from the mother cell during division accelerates the exhaustion of proliferative capacity and leads to bacterial death, indicating a causal mechanism of aging.
A phenomenon termed 'conditional senescence' occurs during the stationary phase of bacterial growth in liquid cultures, where aging-like processes manifest under specific environmental conditions.

The paper discusses the evolutionary implications of aging in bacteria, suggesting that these aging mechanisms may have adaptive or selective roles, linking prokaryotic aging to broader biological aging theories.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent studies on Caulobacter crescentus and Escherichia coli demonstrating asymmetric division effects and conditional senescence; comparative discussion with eukaryotic cell aging phenomena.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes generalizable causal mechanisms explaining why and how aging occurs in prokaryotes, linking these mechanisms to evolutionary significance and drawing parallels to eukaryotic aging, thus addressing aging as a fundamental biological process.

results.title: The Fourth Age in Prospect.
How does the body know how old it is?

theories.name: Epigenetic Programmed Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Aging is controlled by genetic and epigenetic mechanisms, particularly DNA methylation patterns that change predictably over time, forming the basis of methylation clocks. These epigenetic changes act as a program that governs the timing of aging processes.

Due to the necessity of homeostasis in biological systems, aging is hypothesized to be regulated by several independent timekeepers rather than a single clock. These clocks coordinate signals that collectively determine the biological age of the organism.

Contrary to classical neo-Darwinian views that aging cannot be an adaptation, newer evolutionary theories propose selective mechanisms where aging may serve community-level benefits despite individual fitness costs, implying aging could be an evolved, programmed process.

Because aging is driven by signaling and epigenetic programming, it may be more feasible to medically intervene by modulating these signals or reprogramming epigenetics, rather than repairing accumulated molecular damage directly.

theories.evidence: References to the development of methylation clocks since 2013, evolutionary theory discussions, and observations of plasma-based rejuvenation successes are cited as supporting evidence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs at the organism level via epigenetic programming and evolutionary adaptation; it addresses aging broadly and not limited to specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Sex differences in antioxidant defence and the regulation of redox homeostasis in physiology and pathology.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: ROS are unstable compounds produced endogenously or from external sources. While low levels of ROS regulate cellular signaling and transcription, excessive ROS cause oxidative stress, damaging cells and contributing to aging and disease.
Cells possess antioxidant mechanisms evolved to maintain ROS at levels that allow signaling functions but prevent damage. The efficiency of these systems influences aging and disease progression.

Females generally have more proficient antioxidant defenses than males, which correlates with longer lifespan and lower incidence of chronic diseases, suggesting evolutionary and genetic determinants in redox homeostasis.

theories.evidence: Summary of recent literature on sex-related differences in redox regulation, molecular, genetic, and evolutionary determinants; references to studies linking oxidative stress to aging and disease.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (oxidative stress) underlying aging at the organism level, discusses evolutionary and genetic bases, and addresses systemic aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: The role of phagocytic cells in aging: insights from vertebrate and invertebrate models.

theories.name: Phagocytic scavenger cell involvement in aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the build-up of cellular and extracellular waste material contributes to the aging process. Phagocytic cells help prevent this accumulation by clearing waste, potentially influencing organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of phagocytic cells beyond pathogen elimination
key_concepts.description: Phagocytic scavenger cells not only neutralize pathogens but also maintain homeostasis by removing cellular debris and waste products, which may be linked to systemic aging mechanisms.
The theory considers the diversity and evolutionary relationships of phagocytic cells across vertebrate and invertebrate species to understand their conserved role in aging.

theories.mode: review, discuss, propose questions for further exploration
theories.evidence: Review of current knowledge from vertebrate and invertebrate models; no direct experimental evidence linking phagocytic function to aging is established yet.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain a general mechanism (waste clearance by phagocytes) potentially underlying aging; proposes a causal link between waste accumulation and aging; addresses aging broadly across species; however, direct causal mechanisms remain to be established.

results.title: Benefits of extended maternal care in a mass-provisioning bee at the cusp of sociality.
Longevity in the protozoa.

theories.name: Nuclear Differentiation and Partitioning Theory of Cellular Immortality and Senescence

key_concepts.concept: Partitioning of immortality and mortality in nuclear components
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that cellular immortality is not simply lost but partitioned between different nuclear segments, such as the macronucleus and reserve nucleus in ciliates. This partitioning allows for both senescence and evolutionary processes to occur in multicellular organisms.

key_concepts.concept: Role of sex in maintaining cellular longevity
key_concepts.description: Sexual reproduction is necessary to activate the reserve nucleus before deterioration occurs, providing access to a 'reserve account' that maintains life and proliferation potential. This mechanism is critical in species with limited macronuclear proliferation potential.

key_concepts.concept: Capital investment analogy for cellular maintenance
key_concepts.description: Cells are conceptualized as having 'capital investment' accounts—some invest in maintaining a reserve nucleus (reserve account) without losing original potential, while others accumulate 'debts' and require sexual activation to sustain life. Failure to maintain this reserve leads to cellular failure.

key_concepts.concept: Variability in lifespan potential among protozoa
key_concepts.description: Differences between species or cells with infinite versus finite lifespan potential may reflect critical determinants of longevity. Some colonial flagellates separate immortal and mortal cells, while others do not, indicating diverse strategies for managing cellular immortality.

key_concepts.concept: Senescence as both accident and design
key_concepts.description: Senescence may arise unintentionally or as a designed outcome of nuclear differentiation, suggesting that cells may retain a greater reserve for totipotency than previously assumed.

theories.evidence: Comparative observations of ciliates and colonial flagellates regarding nuclear proliferation potential, sexual reproduction roles, and lifespan partitioning; theoretical analogy to capital investment; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging/senescence at the organismal/cellular level, addressing fundamental mechanisms of how immortality and senescence arise through nuclear differentiation and sexual processes, applicable beyond a single species or organ.

results.title: Sex/gender-related differences in inflammaging.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.description: With aging, the innate immune system becomes chronically activated, leading to a persistent low-grade inflammatory state that contributes to tissue damage and functional decline.

Aging induces changes in adaptive immune responses, including altered lymphocyte function and reduced immune surveillance, which exacerbate chronic inflammation and impair the ability to resolve inflammation.

Senescent cells accumulate with age and secrete pro-inflammatory factors (senescence-associated secretory phenotype, SASP) that promote systemic inflammation and contribute to aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Extensive literature cited on inflammaging mechanisms and sex/gender differences; discussion of biomarkers showing sex-related differences; contextualization within COVID-19 outcomes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs via chronic inflammation driven by immune system changes and senescent cells; it is generalizable to organism-level aging and links to age-related diseases.

results.title: Adult dementia: history, biopsy, pathology.

theories.name: Alzheimer's disease as premature or accelerated aging

key_concepts.description: Alzheimer's disease is conceptualized as a form of aging that occurs earlier or progresses faster than normal aging, implying that the pathological changes seen in Alzheimer's reflect an acceleration of the normal aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Pathological correlates of aging in dementia
key_concepts.description: Neurofibrillary tangles, senile plaques, and amyloid deposition are considered hallmark pathological features that relate to aging processes, with amyloid being a key component both in plaques and congophilic angiopathy.

key_concepts.concept: Neuronal loss and enzymatic decline as mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Loss of neuronal cells and reduction in choline acetyltransferase activity are evaluated as pathogenic mechanisms underlying Alzheimer's disease, linking cellular and biochemical changes to aging-related neurodegeneration.

The theory posits that aging itself is a causal factor in Alzheimer's disease, but acknowledges that aging as an etiological agent must be clarified before Alzheimer's can be deemed an inevitable consequence of longevity.

theories.evidence: Historical review of Alzheimer's disease, pathological descriptions including electron microscopy and biochemical insights, evaluation of neuronal counts and enzyme loss, discussion of amyloid significance, and consideration of slow virus hypothesis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain why Alzheimer's disease occurs in the context of aging as a fundamental biological process, proposes mechanisms linking aging pathology to disease, and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing narrowly on a single organ or disease without generalization.

theories.name: Alzheimer's disease as a slow virus infection related to aging

key_concepts.description: The hypothesis that Alzheimer's disease may be caused by a slow virus infection, which interacts with aging processes and possibly an unknown immune defect, contributing to disease pathogenesis.
An unknown immune defect in aged individuals may predispose or allow slow virus infection to manifest as Alzheimer's disease, linking immune senescence or dysfunction with disease onset.

key_concepts.concept: Diagnostic and pathogenic implications of biopsy
key_concepts.description: Brain biopsy is used to explore the presence of slow virus infection and to understand pathogenic mechanisms, emphasizing the importance of careful handling due to infectious risk.

theories.evidence: Summary of polemic arguments, discussion of biopsy findings, and consideration of slow virus infection as an alternative or complementary explanation to aging alone.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism for Alzheimer's disease linked to aging, but the slow virus hypothesis is less established as a general aging theory and more disease-specific; however, it is framed in the context of aging-related immune defects.

results.title: Low-Molecular Weight Compounds that Extend the Chronological Lifespan of Yeasts, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, and Schizosaccharomyces pombe.

theories.name: Conserved intracellular signaling pathways regulating aging and lifespan

key_concepts.description: Intracellular factors and signaling pathways that control aging and lifespan are evolutionarily conserved from yeast to mammals, suggesting fundamental biological processes underlying aging across species.

key_concepts.concept: Regulation of aging via nutritional environment and genetic manipulation
key_concepts.description: Aging and lifespan can be modulated by adjusting the nutritional environment or through genetic manipulation, indicating that aging is a regulated biological process influenced by internal and external factors.

key_concepts.concept: Pharmacological intervention with low-molecular weight compounds
key_concepts.description: Drug treatment using low-molecular weight compounds can extend the chronological lifespan of yeast, providing a practical approach to modulate aging and potentially applicable to other organisms.

theories.evidence: Summary of studies identifying factors and signaling pathways in yeast; discussion of low-molecular weight compounds extending yeast lifespan; references to evolutionary conservation and application to other model organisms.
