theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes generalizable, causal mechanisms of aging conserved across species, addressing aging as a fundamental biological process; focuses on intracellular pathways and interventions that regulate aging broadly.

results.title: In-silico Comparative Analysis of TOP3B Protein Mammals Species with Emphasis on Heterocephalus glaber and Homo sapiens.

theories.name: Genomic Stability Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Genomic stability as a determinant of lifespan
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that maintaining the integrity and stability of the genome is crucial for preventing aging-related decline and extending lifespan. Mutations or structural variations in key proteins involved in DNA maintenance can influence genomic stability.

key_concepts.concept: Role of TOP3B protein in genomic maintenance
key_concepts.description: TOP3B, a DNA topoisomerase, is implicated in managing DNA topology during cellular processes. Variations and mutations in TOP3B may affect its function in genomic maintenance, thereby influencing aging and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Species-specific structural variations linked to longevity
key_concepts.description: Differences in TOP3B isoforms and mutations, particularly in the naked mole-rat, are hypothesized to contribute to enhanced genomic stability and exceptional lifespan, suggesting a molecular basis for species-specific aging rates.

theories.evidence: In-silico comparative analyses of TOP3B gene isoforms, conserved domain architectures, sequence mutations in naked mole-rat versus humans, evolutionary relationships, protein-protein interaction networks, pathway and molecular docking studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (genomic stability via TOP3B function) underlying aging and longevity at the organismal level, supported by comparative molecular data and linked to lifespan differences.

results.title: Cellular senescence: beneficial, harmful, and highly complex.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells as causal drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate in tissues over time and contribute to the aging process by impairing tissue function and promoting chronic inflammation.
Senescent cells secrete a complex mixture of pro-inflammatory cytokines, growth factors, and proteases that affect the tissue microenvironment and can promote aging and age-related pathologies.
Senescent cells have beneficial roles in normal physiology, such as tissue repair and tumor suppression, but also harmful effects by promoting aging and disease when they accumulate excessively.
Senescent cells communicate with other cells in the tissue microenvironment and potentially across organs through SASP factors, influencing systemic aging and disease progression.
Senolytics and senomorphics are emerging strategies to selectively eliminate senescent cells or modulate their secretory phenotype to mitigate aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Citations of multiple reviews and original research articles in the Special Issue; discussion of recent advances in identification, isolation, and functional studies of senescent cells; mention of experimental work on dietary macronutrients and senescence in mice; references to senolytic and senomorphic interventions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains aging as a fundamental process at organismal level via accumulation of senescent cells; proposes causal mechanisms (cellular senescence and SASP) driving aging; addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases; discusses evolutionary and physiological roles.

results.title: Telomeres and telomerase: active but complex players in life-history decisions.

theories.name: Telomere biology as an evolutionary life-history aging theory

key_concepts.description: Telomeres, the protective end caps of chromosomes, have been shown to significantly affect organismal lifespan and health, suggesting a role in aging processes.

The role and dynamics of telomeres vary across different animal taxa, indicating that telomere biology is not universally central to aging but depends on species-specific life history traits and complexity.

Telomere biology corresponds with fundamental life-history traits such as growth, body size, reproduction, and lifespan, implying that telomeres shape evolutionary strategies and life table parameters in a complex manner.

theories.evidence: Comparative data on telomere biology across a wide range of animal species with varying organismal complexity and life history strategies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation linking telomere biology to aging at the organismal level through evolutionary life-history trade-offs; it addresses aging broadly beyond single organs or diseases.

results.title: Cognitive impairments in chronic pain: a brain aging framework.

theories.name: Accelerated brain aging framework in chronic pain

key_concepts.description: The framework proposes that chronic pain leads to brain alterations that resemble or accelerate the normal aging process of the brain, thereby linking chronic pain to cognitive impairments and increased dementia risk.
Various factors related to chronic pain, either contributing to its onset or arising as consequences, influence brain aging through both linear and nonlinear mechanisms, affecting cognitive function.

key_concepts.concept: Use of neuroimaging and molecular brain atlases
key_concepts.description: Neuroimaging evidence and molecular brain atlases are leveraged to identify aging-related brain changes in chronic pain, supporting the biological basis of the framework and enabling development of cognitive risk indicators.

theories.evidence: Summarizes emerging findings and neuroimaging evidence; uses interpretable machine learning and molecular brain atlases to elucidate mechanisms and develop risk indicators.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal framework explaining how chronic pain accelerates brain aging, affecting cognition at the organism level; it addresses a fundamental aging process (brain aging) and its systemic consequences.

results.title: Brain physiological pulsations are linked to sleep architecture and cognitive performance in older adults.

theories.name: Glymphatic system decline theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The glymphatic system facilitates clearance of metabolic waste from the brain via cerebrospinal fluid movement along perivascular spaces, maintaining brain homeostasis.
Animal studies have shown that glymphatic clearance efficiency decreases with age, potentially leading to accumulation of waste products that contribute to brain aging and cognitive decline.

key_concepts.concept: Link between glymphatic decline, sleep quality, and cognition
key_concepts.description: Reduced glymphatic function in older adults is hypothesized to be associated with impaired sleep architecture and cognitive performance, suggesting a mechanistic pathway connecting aging, sleep disturbances, and cognitive decline.

theories.evidence: Correlations between brain physiological pulsations measured by MREG (reflecting glymphatic activity), sleep parameters from polysomnography, and cognitive test scores in older adults.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (glymphatic decline) underlying brain aging and cognitive decline, supported by physiological and cognitive data in humans, linking sleep and brain waste clearance to aging.

results.title: 27-hydroxycholesterol promotes oligodendrocyte maturation: Implications for hypercholesterolemia-associated brain white matter changes.
Aging is accompanied by T-cell stiffening and reduced interstitial migration through dysfunctional nuclear organization.

theories.name: Nuclear architecture and cell stiffness theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging causes alterations in the internal organization and structure of the cell nucleus, including changes in nuclear size and nuclear lamin B1 levels, which affect cellular mechanical properties.

key_concepts.concept: DNA hypomethylation as a driver of nuclear changes
key_concepts.description: Age-associated DNA hypomethylation contributes to changes in nuclear organization, influencing nuclear size and stiffness.

key_concepts.concept: Increased cell stiffness reduces T-cell migration
key_concepts.description: As nuclear size increases and nuclear architecture changes, T cells become stiffer, which impairs their ability to migrate through interstitial tissue, contributing to immunosenescence.

key_concepts.concept: Biophysical phenotype as a regulator of cellular function
key_concepts.description: The mechanical properties of cells, regulated by nuclear and cytoskeletal organization, are fundamental determinants of cellular function and change with age.

theories.evidence: Longitudinal analyses of 111 functional, biophysical, and biomolecular features of mouse CD4+ and CD8+ T cells; correlation and regression models linking nuclear changes to cell stiffness and migration; biomarker identification for age estimation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging alters cellular mechanical properties through nuclear changes, affecting systemic immune function; addresses aging broadly via cellular biophysics; provides mechanistic insight rather than mere correlation.

results.title: Reactivation of retrotransposable elements is associated with environmental stress and ageing.

theories.name: Retrotransposable Element Reactivation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: RTEs are repetitive DNA sequences that make up a large portion of eukaryotic genomes and have played a role in genome evolution, especially in mammals. Their activity is normally tightly controlled by epigenetic mechanisms to maintain genomic stability.

As cells age, the epigenetic control mechanisms that suppress RTE activity become compromised, leading to reactivation of these elements. This reactivation disrupts cellular function and homeostasis at the organ and organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Environmental stress as a trigger for RTE reactivation
key_concepts.description: Environmental stressors influence both aging phenotypes and the epigenetic regulation of RTEs. Evidence suggests that stress-induced RTE reactivation mediates the acceleration or onset of aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Causal role of RTE reactivation in aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that RTE reactivation is not merely a marker but a driver of aging processes, linking genomic instability caused by RTE activity to systemic aging and related pathologies.

theories.evidence: The abstract references accumulating evidence linking environmental stress, epigenetic dysregulation, and RTE reactivation to aging and age-related disease, implying citation of experimental and observational studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging at the organismal level, connecting epigenetic regulation, genome stability, and environmental stress to systemic aging processes.

results.title: Mitochondria-associated cellular senescence mechanisms: Biochemical and pharmacological perspectives.

theories.name: Mitochondrial Dysfunction Theory of Cellular Senescence

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the evolutionary adaptation of mitochondria as endosymbionts with other cellular compartments deteriorates with aging, leading to impaired communication and coordination between mitochondria and other organelles.

Aging causes deterioration in mitochondrial redox status, including disrupted redox signaling between organelles and inefficient activation of antioxidant response elements, which contributes to cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondria as Core Drivers of SASP
key_concepts.description: Dysfunctional mitochondria are proposed as central to the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), which promotes inflammatory and pathological changes associated with aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Link Between Mitochondrial Dysfunction, Immunity, and Age-Related Disease
key_concepts.description: Impaired mitochondrial redox control weakens immune function in the elderly, increasing susceptibility to age-related diseases, suggesting mitochondria play a causal role in systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known patterns of mitochondrial dysfunction in senescence, associations with SASP and immunity decline, and mentions senotherapeutic interventions targeting mitochondria, but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental mechanism of aging at the cellular and organismal level by proposing mitochondrial dysfunction as a causal driver of senescence and systemic aging. It addresses general aging processes beyond specific diseases and discusses underlying mechanisms, meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Cynaroside extends lifespan and improves the neurondegeneration diseases via insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathway in Caenorhabditis elegans.

theories.name: Insulin/IGF-1 Signaling Pathway Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This pathway is a fundamental biological signaling cascade conserved across species that regulates lifespan and aging processes. Modulation of this pathway influences aging and age-related diseases by affecting cellular metabolism, stress resistance, and gene expression.

key_concepts.concept: Inhibition of insulin/IGF-1 signaling extends lifespan
key_concepts.description: Reducing the activity of the insulin/IGF-1 pathway leads to activation of downstream transcription factors such as DAF-16/FOXO, which promote longevity and delay aging phenotypes. This mechanism has been demonstrated in multiple organisms including Caenorhabditis elegans.

key_concepts.concept: Link between insulin/IGF-1 signaling and neurodegeneration
key_concepts.description: The pathway not only regulates lifespan but also modulates the progression of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and polyglutamine diseases, suggesting a causal role in aging-related pathologies.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from Caenorhabditis elegans showing that Cynaroside treatment inhibits insulin/IGF-1 signaling via IGF-1 receptor DAF-2, activates DAF-16/FOXO, extends healthy lifespan, and improves neurodegeneration disease models.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It is a generalizable, causal biological theory explaining why and how aging occurs at the organism level, supported by mechanistic insights and evolutionary conservation. The paper tests and discusses this theory using pharmacological intervention and genetic analysis.

results.title: Aging as a loss of morphostatic information: A developmental bioelectricity perspective.

theories.name: Morphostasis Defect Theory of Aging via Bioelectric Signaling

key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized as a progressive loss of biophysical prepattern information that encodes anatomical setpoints necessary for maintaining dynamic tissue and organ homeostasis. This loss leads to failure in preserving anatomical order and function.

key_concepts.concept: Endogenous bioelectric signaling as physiological software
key_concepts.description: Bioelectric signals within cells and tissues act as a form of physiological software that orchestrates cell behavior to create and maintain complex multicellular structures. Disruption of this signaling impairs morphostasis and drives aging.

key_concepts.concept: Link between aging, regeneration, and cancer through bioelectricity
key_concepts.description: The theory posits homologies between developmental processes, aging, cancer, and regeneration mediated by bioelectric signaling pathways, suggesting that aging results from defects in the same bioelectric mechanisms that regulate tissue patterning and repair.
The concept of morphoceuticals is introduced as a potential therapeutic approach targeting bioelectric signaling to restore morphostasis, promote regeneration, and extend healthful longevity.

theories.evidence: The abstract references conceptual links between bioelectricity and life extension strategies, age-related diseases, and regeneration, but does not specify experimental data within the abstract. It suggests a research program and theoretical framework rather than presenting new empirical evidence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging at the organismal level, explaining aging as a failure of bioelectric morphostasis that underlies tissue and organ decline. It goes beyond describing patterns by hypothesizing a mechanistic driver (bioelectric signaling loss) and connects aging to development and regeneration, thus addressing broad aging processes.

results.title: Sex and death.

theories.name: Mating-induced death as an evolutionary aging mechanism

key_concepts.description: Sexual interactions, including mating, negatively impact health and lifespan across many animal species, suggesting a trade-off between reproduction and somatic maintenance.

Three major mechanisms underlie mating-induced killing: activation of the germline, transfer of seminal fluid, and male pheromone-mediated toxicity, each contributing to physiological decline after mating.

Key conserved signaling pathways such as DAF-9/DAF-12 steroid signaling, Insulin/IGF-1 signaling (IIS), and TOR signaling modulate the effects of mating on lifespan, linking reproduction to aging processes.
Mating-induced death may confer fitness benefits by coordinating reproduction and somatic longevity, reflecting sexual antagonism and evolutionary trade-offs shaping aging.

theories.evidence: Review of recent discoveries in C. elegans and other species, including phenotypic observations (shrinking, fat and glycogen loss), identification of molecular mechanisms, and genetic pathway analyses.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging linked to reproduction, involves conserved genetic pathways, and addresses aging at the organismal level from an evolutionary perspective.

results.title: Toward Systemic Lipofuscin Removal.

theories.name: Lipofuscin accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Lipofuscin is a type of cellular garbage that accumulates in autophagic vesicles and cytosol of postmitotic cells over time because it cannot be effectively degraded or removed.
Postmitotic cells, such as neurons, cannot dilute lipofuscin through cell division, leading to progressive accumulation that impairs lysosomal function and cellular health.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary link to memory and neuronal stability
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the evolution of stable synaptic connections and memory requires neurons to remain in place without dividing, which inadvertently causes lipofuscin buildup and contributes to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Lipofuscin accumulation as a major driver of aging and age-related disease
key_concepts.description: Accumulated lipofuscin impairs lysosomal degradation capacity, negatively affecting cell function and the microenvironment, potentially being a key factor in systemic aging and age-related pathologies.

theories.evidence: Citations of Drs. Brunk and Terman's postulation; mechanistic rationale regarding lysosomal impairment in postmitotic cells; discussion of evolutionary perspective; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at organismal level, linking cellular waste accumulation to systemic aging, with evolutionary rationale; not limited to specific disease or organ but focused on a fundamental aging process.

results.title: Sex differences in longevity are relative, not independent.

theories.name: Staying Alive Theory (SAT)

key_concepts.concept: Sex differences in survival and fitness
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that survival may be more fitness-enhancing for females than for males, implying differential selective pressures based on sex that influence longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Selective pressures on male and female traits
key_concepts.description: SAT considers whether independent selective pressures act on male and female traits, which could explain observed sex differences in mortality and longevity.
The theory uses historical data on sex differences in mortality to support or refute claims about differential survival advantages between sexes.

theories.evidence: The abstract references analysis of historical mortality records and questions the validity of claims within the SAT framework, though no specific experimental data is mentioned.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The SAT attempts to explain why sex differences in longevity exist by proposing evolutionary selective pressures, thus addressing a fundamental aging-related process at the organism level. It proposes causal mechanisms (selective pressures) and discusses generalizable patterns (sex differences in survival) rather than narrow phenomena. Therefore, it meets the criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Long live A(me)rica! An examination of the interplay between nationalistic-symbolic immortality striving and belief in life after death.
Male Reproductive Senescence in Mammals Is Pervasive and Aligned With the Slow-Fast Continuum.
Lessons from the life history of natural fertility societies on child growth and maturation.

theories.name: Predictive Adaptive Response via Energetic Cues in Life History Transitions

key_concepts.description: ICT is a life-history phase that acts as a predictive adaptive response to energetic cues, influencing adult height. This transition is modulated by environmental energy availability, which can delay or advance growth phases.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic Mechanisms in Energy Crisis Adaptation
key_concepts.description: Short-term evolutionary adaptations to energy scarcity use epigenetic regulation to defer ICT, resulting in shorter stature as an adaptive response to hostile environments.

key_concepts.concept: Transition from Juvenility to Adolescence and Longevity
key_concepts.description: This transition phase establishes key life-history traits such as longevity and age of fertility, linking developmental timing to reproductive fitness and survival.

key_concepts.concept: Adaptive Body Size and Reproductive Fitness
key_concepts.description: Body size is adaptively smaller in resource-poor or hostile environments, and this smaller somatic capital is tightly associated with reproductive fitness in natural fertility societies.

theories.evidence: Review and analysis of databases from natural fertility societies including life history data, population density, height, body mass, adolescence indices, and fertility parameters; confirmation of ICT model predictions and pubertal timing related to evolutionary fitness.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging-related developmental timing and body size adaptations linked to energy availability and evolutionary fitness. It addresses broad organism-level aging processes through life-history theory and epigenetic mechanisms.

results.title: Long COVID as a disease of accelerated biological aging: An opportunity to translate geroscience interventions.

theories.name: Geroscience theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Geroscience posits that aging is driven by fundamental biological mechanisms that underlie multiple age-associated conditions. Targeting these drivers can potentially prevent or ameliorate a broad spectrum of diseases linked to aging.

The theory suggests that certain conditions, such as long COVID, may induce a state of accelerated biological aging, where the biological processes typical of aging occur prematurely or at an increased rate.
By understanding long COVID as accelerated aging, geroscience provides a framework to translate aging biology insights into therapeutic interventions aimed at mitigating long COVID symptoms.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews symptom overlap between long COVID and aging, and leverages geroscience concepts to propose new research directions; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging-related symptoms in long COVID, linking systemic biological aging mechanisms to disease pathology and suggesting interventions targeting aging processes.

results.title: Origin of homochirality in peptides: The first milestone at the origin of life.
Stochastic analysis of human ovarian aging and menopause timing.

theories.name: Stochastic model of ovarian aging and menopause timing

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that menopause results from the depletion of the ovarian follicle reserve, which declines over time due to follicles transitioning through different developmental stages until exhaustion.
Follicles transition between stages in a probabilistic manner, and this stochastic process governs the dynamics of ovarian aging and the timing of menopause.

key_concepts.concept: Universal relation between initial reserve, depletion rate, and menopause threshold
key_concepts.description: The model suggests a universal quantitative relationship linking the initial number of follicles, their depletion rates, and a threshold follicle count that triggers menopause.

key_concepts.concept: Synchronization and regulation of follicle transitions
key_concepts.description: The narrow distribution of menopause timing across individuals is proposed to arise from precise regulatory mechanisms synchronizing follicle stage transitions.

theories.evidence: Model predictions consistent with experimental observations across diverse human populations; quantitative agreement with average menopause age; theoretical analysis of follicle dynamics.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining the biological aging process of the ovary leading to menopause, with a quantitative framework applicable to human populations broadly.

results.title: Aging through the lens of mitochondrial DNA mutations and inheritance paradoxes.

theories.name: Mitochondrial DNA Mutation-Driven Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial DNA mutations impair energy metabolism
key_concepts.description: Mutations in mitochondrial DNA disrupt the function of respiratory chain complexes, leading to compromised mitochondrial respiratory function and reduced cellular energy production, which affects overall cellular physiology.

key_concepts.concept: mtDNA mutations as a key driver of aging initiation and progression
key_concepts.description: The intrinsic vulnerability of mitochondrial DNA to mutations is proposed as a fundamental cause triggering the onset of aging and the development of age-related diseases, suggesting a causal role for mtDNA damage in systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Complex effects of oxidative stress and apoptosis on aging
key_concepts.description: Contrary to traditional views, oxidative stress and apoptosis induced by mtDNA mutations may not universally accelerate aging, indicating the need for nuanced understanding of these processes in the context of aging mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Role of mtDNA inheritance dynamics in propagating mutations
key_concepts.description: The patterns and mechanisms of mitochondrial DNA inheritance influence how pathogenic mutations are transmitted and accumulate, thereby affecting cellular senescence and systemic health decline during aging.

theories.evidence: Synthesis of recent insights and literature on mtDNA mutations, their physiological impact, and inheritance patterns; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging based on mitochondrial DNA mutation accumulation and inheritance dynamics, addressing systemic aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Male mating choices: The drive behind menopause?

theories.name: Male mate choice hypothesis for the evolution of menopause

key_concepts.concept: Male mating preference as evolutionary driver
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis proposes that ancestral males preferentially mating with younger females led to selection pressures that caused older females to lose fertility, resulting in menopause. This preference would allow deleterious mutations affecting fertility at older ages to accumulate.

key_concepts.concept: Evolution of menopause through mutation accumulation
key_concepts.description: Because older females were less likely to reproduce due to male preference, fertility-reducing mutations at older ages were not strongly selected against, leading to the evolution of a postmenopausal life stage.

The original hypothesis was tested using an agent-based model (ABM), and the current paper uses a mathematical model with ordinary differential equations (ODEs) to replicate and extend the analysis, including sensitivity to mating preference assumptions.

theories.evidence: Reproduction of previous ABM results with an ODE model; broader sensitivity analysis showing that slight deviations from exclusive male preference for younger females counteract menopause evolution; theoretical modeling and parameter exploration.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general evolutionary mechanism explaining why menopause evolved in humans, addressing a fundamental aging-related trait (postmenopausal infertility) at the organism level, with causal explanations via mutation accumulation driven by mating preferences.

results.title: Comprehensive study of W06A7.4 and TMEM144 mediated pathways in aging: insights from Caenorhabditis elegans to human.

theories.name: Conserved molecular pathway theory of aging involving W06A7.4/TMEM144

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that certain molecular pathways regulating aging are conserved across species, from C. elegans to humans, implying fundamental biological mechanisms underlying aging.

W06A7.4 in C. elegans and its human homolog TMEM144 regulate aging by modulating key pathways such as IIS (insulin/IGF-1 signaling), mTOR signaling, oxidative damage reduction, and mitochondrial function, which are known contributors to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Interaction with dietary restriction and mitochondrial maintenance
key_concepts.description: The pathway synergizes with dietary restriction to promote longevity, partly through maintaining mitochondrial membrane potential and reducing oxidative stress, linking metabolic regulation to aging.
Increased TMEM144 expression with age and Alzheimer's disease suggests that this pathway may connect aging mechanisms with neurodegeneration, highlighting a broader systemic impact.

theories.evidence: Genetic manipulation in C. elegans, analysis of human clinical samples showing age- and disease-related expression changes, and functional assays in cell lines demonstrating pathway effects on mitochondrial and metabolic functions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains aging as a fundamental conserved biological process, proposes causal mechanisms involving signaling pathways and mitochondrial function, and addresses aging broadly including systemic and neurodegenerative aspects.

results.title: The Idiosyncratic Physiological Traits of the Naked Mole-Rat; a Resilient Animal Model of Aging, Longevity, and Healthspan.

theories.name: Physiological Resilience and Low Metabolic Rate Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Low Basal Metabolic Activity as Protective Mechanism
key_concepts.description: Naked mole-rats maintain low body temperature, metabolic rate, cardiac output, and kidney concentrating ability under basal conditions, which reduces physiological stress and protects organs and cellular functions from damage, potentially slowing aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Ability to Rapidly Increase Physiological Functions
key_concepts.description: Despite low basal activity, naked mole-rats can rapidly ramp up metabolism and cardiac output 2-5 fold when needed, indicating a flexible physiological system that balances energy conservation with functional demands, contributing to resilience against age-related decline.

Naked mole-rats show negligible changes in lean and fat mass, bone quality, reproductive capacity, and demographic mortality even at ages far beyond expected lifespan, suggesting mechanisms that prevent typical age-associated physiological decline.

Their tolerance to hypoxia, hypercapnia, thermolability, and toxins may be linked to systemic protective mechanisms that also confer longevity and healthspan benefits, indicating an evolutionary adaptation that impacts aging.

theories.evidence: Review of physiological traits and demographic data showing negligible aging signs in naked mole-rats; references to their unusual tolerance to environmental stressors and stable physiological parameters with age.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging resistance based on physiological and metabolic mechanisms that affect the organism as a whole, not limited to a single organ or disease.

results.title: Dietary nitrate supplementation mitigates age-related changes at the neuromuscular junction in mice.

theories.name: Nitric oxide-mediated redox and synthetic pathway regulation theory of neuromuscular aging

key_concepts.concept: Nitric oxide (NO) bioavailability decline with age
key_concepts.description: NO levels decrease in aging muscle, leading to impaired signaling and transport mechanisms critical for neuromuscular junction (NMJ) stability.
Aging is associated with increased oxidative and nitrosative stress markers, such as protein carbonylation and 3-nitrotyrosine, which contribute to NMJ instability and muscle degeneration.
The Akt/mTOR pathway, crucial for protein synthesis and muscle maintenance, is downregulated with age, contributing to muscle fiber atrophy and fibrosis.

key_concepts.concept: NMJ instability and denervation as drivers of muscle aging
key_concepts.description: Age-related morphological changes at the NMJ, including fragmentation and reduced overlap, lead to denervation and muscle fiber loss, which are central to neuromuscular aging.
Supplementation with dietary nitrate restores NO bioavailability, improves redox balance, activates anabolic signaling, and stabilizes NMJ morphology, thereby mitigating neuromuscular decline.

theories.evidence: Experimental data comparing young, old, and nitrate-supplemented old mice showing biochemical, morphological, and molecular markers of NO signaling, oxidative stress, NMJ integrity, and muscle fiber characteristics.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism linking NO bioavailability, redox balance, and synthetic pathway regulation to systemic neuromuscular aging, supported by mechanistic evidence and intervention testing.

results.title: Cystathionine Gamma-Lyase: A Potential Longevity Gene Under Selection?

theories.name: Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S) Modulation of Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Role of H2S in physiological processes
key_concepts.description: Hydrogen sulfide acts as a signaling molecule involved in various physiological functions, including modulation of oxidative stress and maintenance of cellular health, which are critical factors influencing the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic selection on H2S-producing enzymes linked to longevity
key_concepts.description: Genes encoding enzymes responsible for endogenous H2S production, such as cystathionine-γ-lyase (CSE), may undergo evolutionary selection in long-lived species, suggesting that enhanced or altered H2S production contributes causally to lifespan extension.

Specific mutations in the CSE gene, particularly in the naked mole-rat, increase protein stability and cofactor binding affinity, potentially enhancing catalytic efficiency and H2S production, which may underlie unique longevity adaptations.

theories.evidence: Comparative codon-based evolutionary analyses across 114 mammalian species; detection of relaxation of purifying selection and positive selection signatures in CSE gene; identification of specific amino acid substitutions in naked mole-rat CSE linked to functional improvements.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking genetic and molecular adaptations in H2S biogenesis to aging and longevity at the organismal level; addresses fundamental aging processes rather than narrow disease or organ-specific phenomena.

results.title: Determinants of Social Cognitive Aging: Predicting Resilience and Risk.
Hypothalamic aging and hormones.

theories.name: Hypothalamic regulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Heterogeneous hypothalamic functional changes drive aging
key_concepts.description: Different hypothalamic nuclei undergo distinct aging-related changes that collectively determine the chronological sequence of mammalian aging. These changes shift the functional balance among hypothalamic systems toward aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Specific hypothalamic nuclei regulate systemic aging processes
key_concepts.description: The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) degeneration is linked to decreased slow-wave sleep possibly triggered by skin aging; the sexually dimorphic nucleus of the preoptic area (SDN-POA) degeneration is associated with increased body fat and hormonal changes; the paraventricular nucleus (PVN) remains stable in neuron number but regulates stress-related aging effects.

key_concepts.concept: Hypothalamic control of peripheral organ aging via hormonal axes
key_concepts.description: Aging of peripheral organs such as ovary, muscle, stomach, intestine, thymus, brain, cardiovascular system, bone, and kidney is regulated through hypothalamic nuclei via hormonal pathways including GH/IGF1, vasopressin, and stress hormones.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews hypotheses and observations linking hypothalamic nuclei changes to aging in various organs and systems, citing prior hypotheses (e.g., Cai, Cohen) and physiological pathways (GH/IGF1, vasopressin).
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging at the organismal level through hypothalamic regulation; it addresses broad aging processes and integrates multiple organ systems under a unifying mechanism.

results.title: Ageism, moral sensitivity and nursing students' intentions to work with older people - A cross-sectional study.
Error-prone protein synthesis recapitulates early symptoms of Alzheimer disease in aging mice.

theories.name: Protein misfolding accumulation theory of aging-related neurodegeneration

key_concepts.concept: Error-prone protein synthesis leads to random protein misfolding
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that increased errors during protein translation cause widespread misfolding of proteins, which disrupts cellular homeostasis. This misfolding is not limited to specific pathogenic proteins but is a general phenomenon contributing to aging-related dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Protein misfolding disrupts synaptic homeostasis and neuronal function
key_concepts.description: Misfolded proteins interfere with synaptic signaling pathways, including calcium signaling and mitochondrial function, leading to neuronal hyperexcitability and other dysfunctions that resemble early neurodegenerative disease symptoms.

key_concepts.concept: Random protein misfolding as a causal driver of neurodegenerative aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of misfolded proteins due to translational errors is proposed as a fundamental mechanism initiating age-related neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease, independent of specific rogue proteins like Aβ.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from mice expressing a ribosomal ambiguity mutation (Rps9 D95N) showing early Alzheimer-like symptoms including learning and memory deficits, disrupted synaptic homeostasis, altered calcium signaling, mitochondrial dysfunction, behavioral changes, and cerebral glucose hypometabolism.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging-related neurodegeneration at the organism level, explaining how random protein misfolding drives systemic neuronal aging phenotypes. It is not limited to a single protein or disease but suggests a broad underlying cause.

results.title: Altered Oxidative Status as a Cost of Reproduction in a Seabird with High Reproductive Costs.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) and Oxidative Damage
key_concepts.description: ROS are prooxidant molecules produced as byproducts of metabolism that can damage DNA, lipids, and proteins if not neutralized. This damage is proposed to contribute to cellular senescence and organismal aging.

Organisms possess enzymatic (e.g., superoxide dismutase, glutathione peroxidase, catalase) and nonenzymatic antioxidants to neutralize ROS and prevent oxidative damage, thereby modulating the rate of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Reproduction as a Source of Increased Oxidative Stress
key_concepts.description: Reproductive effort increases metabolic rate, potentially elevating ROS production and oxidative damage, which may impose a cost on survival and accelerate aging processes.

theories.evidence: Empirical data from a seabird species (thick-billed murres) measuring oxidative markers (TAC, UA, MDA) and antioxidant enzyme activities (SOD, GPx, CAT) across manipulated reproductive efforts and breeding seasons over multiple years.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (oxidative damage) underlying aging processes linked to reproduction, applicable at organismal level, with mechanistic explanations and empirical testing.

results.title: An in-silico approach to the dynamics of proliferation potential in stem cells and the study of different therapies in cases of ovarian dysfunction.

theories.name: Stem Cell Proliferation Potential and Telomerase Activity Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Proliferation potential as an indicator of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the mean proliferation potential of stem cell populations declines over time and can serve as a quantitative marker of cellular aging at the population level.

key_concepts.concept: Role of telomerase activity in maintaining proliferation potential
key_concepts.description: Telomerase activity modulates the ability of stem cells to maintain their proliferation potential by influencing telomere length, with insufficient telomerase leading to reduced proliferation and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Mathematical modeling of stem cell aging dynamics
key_concepts.description: Using discrete and continuous mathematical models, the theory formalizes how parameters such as mitosis rate, death rate, maximum proliferation potential, and telomerase activity interact to drive the temporal evolution of stem cell aging.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic modulation of telomerase to restore proliferation potential
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that activating telomerase expression through endogenous promoters, sexual steroids, or gene therapy can reverse or slow the decline in proliferation potential, thereby impacting aging-related dysfunctions such as primary ovarian insufficiency.

theories.evidence: Mathematical simulation results applying the model to hematopoietic stem cells with varying telomerase activity; references to empirical observations of telomerase activity in HSCs and granulosa cells; modeling of therapeutic interventions including sexual steroids and gene therapy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging at the stem cell population level, linking telomerase activity and proliferation potential to systemic aging processes; uses a formal mathematical framework to explain how aging dynamics emerge; addresses aging broadly beyond a single organ by focusing on stem cells as a fundamental aging driver.

results.title: CircadiOmic medicine and aging.

theories.name: Circadian rhythm disruption as a driver of aging and age-related diseases

key_concepts.description: Organisms have evolved ultradian, circadian, and infradian rhythms that synchronize biological functions with environmental cycles. These rhythms are maintained by precise clock machinery that regulates cellular, tissue, and organ functions.

key_concepts.concept: Robustness of circadian rhythms essential for health
key_concepts.description: The integrity and alignment of circadian rhythms are critical for normal physiological functions. Disruption or misalignment of these rhythms predisposes individuals to accelerated aging and various age-related diseases such as sleep disorders, cancer, diabetes, and neurodegenerative conditions.

Emerging fields like circadian and CircadiOmic medicine aim to leverage understanding of circadian biology to develop personalized therapeutic approaches that protect against aging and its associated diseases.

theories.evidence: The abstract references latest knowledge and emerging fields but does not specify experimental data; it is a review of existing literature linking circadian rhythm disruption to aging and disease.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (circadian rhythm disruption) influencing systemic aging and age-related diseases, discusses underlying biological clock mechanisms, and connects to organism-level aging processes.

results.title: Reproductive Strategies Affect Telomere Dynamics across the Life Course.

theories.name: Reproductive Trade-Off Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Genetic linkage of parental investment costs and benefits
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that because parental care has a heritable basis, the benefits of receiving increased parental provisioning early in life are genetically linked to the costs of providing increased parental care during adulthood. This linkage creates trade-offs that influence aging trajectories.

Different reproductive strategies, characterized by varying levels of parental investment, result in distinct cost-benefit syndromes across the life course that affect individual health and aging patterns.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere dynamics as a biomarker of somatic aging
key_concepts.description: Telomere length is used as an indicator of somatic state and aging, with reproductive strategies influencing telomere attrition rates at different life stages, particularly accelerated attrition in reproductively active adults with high parental investment.

theories.evidence: Artificial selection experiments in Japanese quail lines selected for low vs. high maternal investment showed differences in telomere length at birth, juvenile stages, and adulthood, indicating differential telomere attrition linked to reproductive strategy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking reproductive strategy (a fundamental life-history trait) to aging via telomere dynamics, addressing organism-level aging processes and providing mechanistic insight into aging trajectories.

results.title: Complex ontogeny of sexual size dimorphism in a female-larger gecko: Implications of determinate growth for lizard body size and life-history evolution.
Why should senescence evolve? An answer based on a simple demographic model.

theories.name: Evolutionary Demographic Model of Senescence

key_concepts.concept: Senescence evolution via trade-off between early-life advantage and late-life disadvantage
key_concepts.description: Senescence is expected to evolve if its negative effects on population growth rate are offset by an early-life beneficial trait. This reflects a nonadaptive perspective where natural selection favors traits that improve early survival or reproduction even if they cause deterioration later.

key_concepts.concept: Sudden death as a model for senescence
key_concepts.description: Senescence is modeled as a sudden death event occurring at a specific age, contrasting with random death. This simplification allows analysis of how sudden death influences population fitness and selection.

key_concepts.concept: Balance between presenescent mortality and senescence timing
key_concepts.description: The model shows that reductions in presenescent mortality can compensate for the introduction of senescence, and that natural selection can favor both increased longevity and senescence simultaneously, depending on survival curve shape and mortality rates.

key_concepts.concept: Selective neutrality and advantage in different mortality scenarios
key_concepts.description: Depending on how sudden death age and presenescent death rates balance, populations can be selectively neutral or have a selective advantage compared to nonsenescent populations, highlighting complex evolutionary dynamics of aging.

theories.evidence: Theoretical demographic modeling with references to prior evolutionary theories (Kirkwood 1985; Kirkwood and Cremer 1982; Medawar 1952; Weisman 1889). No new experimental data, but logical deductions from model scenarios.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a general evolutionary mechanism explaining why senescence evolves, offers causal explanations via demographic trade-offs, and addresses aging at the organismal population level rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Buried Treasure? Overlooked and Newly Discovered Evolutionary Contributions to Human Brain Diseases.

theories.name: Antagonistic pleiotropy theory

key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that certain genes or traits that are beneficial early in life for reproduction or survival may have deleterious effects later in life, contributing to aging and age-related diseases. The theory explains aging as a trade-off shaped by evolutionary pressures.

theories.evidence: The abstract references evolutionary concepts including antagonistic pleiotropy in the context of neurological diseases, suggesting a review or discussion of existing literature rather than new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general evolutionary mechanism explaining why aging occurs, with causal implications for brain aging and disease; it is generalizable beyond specific diseases and proposes an evolutionary logic for aging.

theories.name: Evolutionary exaptation in brain diseases

key_concepts.description: Exaptation refers to traits that evolved for one function but were co-opted for another, potentially contributing to vulnerabilities or diseases in the human brain. This concept explains how evolutionary history can leave residues that impact current brain health.

theories.evidence: The abstract mentions mechanisms of exaptation as part of the evolutionary framework for understanding neurological diseases, implying a conceptual discussion rather than new data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a causal evolutionary explanation for aging-related brain disease vulnerabilities, generalizable to human brain aging and disease mechanisms.

theories.name: Mismatch between biological and cultural evolution affecting human longevity

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that human longevity has increased due to cultural evolution outpacing biological evolution, leading to constraints and compensatory adaptations that influence aging and age-related diseases. It explains aging in the context of evolutionary dynamics between biology and culture.

theories.evidence: The abstract discusses human longevity and the outpacing of biological evolution by cultural evolution, suggesting a theoretical framework rather than empirical evidence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a broad evolutionary mechanism influencing aging and longevity, with causal implications for aging processes at the organism level.

results.title: Epitranscriptomics: new players in an old game.

theories.name: Epitranscriptomic regulation of aging theory

key_concepts.concept: RNA modifications as regulators of aging
key_concepts.description: More than 170 chemical modifications on coding and non-coding RNAs (the epitranscriptome) modulate RNA metabolism processes such as stability, translation, splicing, and processing, which in turn influence cellular functions relevant to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Mutations in RNA modifying enzymes affect lifespan
key_concepts.description: Studies in short-lived model organisms like yeast and worms show that mutations in enzymes responsible for RNA modifications can alter lifespan, suggesting a causal role of epitranscriptomic regulation in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Dysregulation of the epitranscriptome linked to aging hallmarks and diseases
key_concepts.description: In mammals, changes in RNA modifications and the expression of RNA modifying enzymes correlate with age-related diseases and recognized hallmarks of aging, implying a mechanistic connection.

key_concepts.concept: Potential regulation of other non-coding RNAs involved in aging
key_concepts.description: The theory hypothesizes that RNA modifications may regulate other non-coding RNAs, such as transposable elements and tRNA fragments, which play key roles in aging processes.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies in yeast and worms linking RNA modifying enzyme mutations to lifespan changes; transcriptome-wide analyses showing changes in mRNA modifications and RNA modifier expression with age; reanalysis of mouse tissue datasets showing dysregulation of RNA modification machinery during aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging involving epitranscriptomic regulation affecting organism-level aging processes; discusses underlying molecular mechanisms; connects to aging hallmarks and lifespan; not limited to a single organ or disease.

results.title: Polyphenols as Potential Geroprotectors.

theories.name: Geroprotection via Polyphenol-Mediated Molecular Mechanisms

key_concepts.description: Polyphenols induce a mild stress response that activates adaptive cellular pathways, enhancing the organism's resistance to more severe stress and contributing to longevity.
Polyphenols help regulate oxidative stress by balancing reactive oxygen species and antioxidant defenses, thereby reducing molecular damage associated with aging.
Polyphenols influence gene expression patterns through epigenetic modifications, potentially reversing or slowing age-related epigenetic changes that contribute to aging.
Polyphenols modulate cellular repair mechanisms and stress responses, helping to mitigate damage accumulation that drives aging.
Polyphenols affect metabolic pathways that influence energy balance and nutrient sensing, processes known to impact aging and lifespan.
Certain polyphenols reduce chronic inflammation and selectively eliminate senescent cells, both of which are key contributors to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Analysis of data from experimental animal models, clinical trials, and epidemiological studies demonstrating lifespan extension, improved aging biomarkers, and disease prevention effects linked to polyphenols.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes generalizable, causal mechanisms by which polyphenols influence fundamental aging processes at the organism level, supported by multiple lines of evidence and addressing broad aging phenomena.

results.title: An AMP Kinase-pathway dependent integrated stress response regulates ageing and longevity.

theories.name: AMP Kinase-dependent Integrated Stress Response (AMPK-ISR) theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: AMPK pathway as an integrated stress response system
key_concepts.description: The AMPK pathway functions as a conserved stress response mechanism that detects cellular energy status changes (AMP/ATP and NAD/NADH ratios) and the presence of toxins, triggering a protective transcriptional response. This response promotes health benefits and longevity by mitigating age-related decline.

A feedback loop within the AMPK pathway enables it to integrate multiple environmental and metabolic stress signals, coordinating a broad protective response that affects many organs and systems simultaneously.

The decline or inactivation of the AMPK pathway with age is proposed as a causal mechanism underlying the loss of various health benefits and the progression of aging, linking pathway activity directly to aging processes.

theories.evidence: The paper reports discovery of the feedback loop in the AMPK pathway and its conserved role in stress response; it links pathway activity to health benefits and longevity, referencing effects of exercise, drugs, and health ingredients known to activate AMPK and be impacted by aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs via decline in a fundamental stress response pathway affecting multiple organs and systemic aging; it addresses aging broadly and proposes an evolutionary conserved mechanism.

results.title: Circadian rhythm, hypoxia, and cellular senescence: From molecular mechanisms to targeted strategies.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence leads to a decline in physiological and metabolic functions, contributing to systemic aging by impairing tissue and organ performance and promoting inflammatory responses.

key_concepts.concept: Circadian rhythm regulation of cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: Circadian proteins, especially BMAL1, regulate homeostasis and mediate cellular responses to hypoxic stress, influencing the progression of cellular senescence.
Hypoxia-inducible factor-1α (HIF-1α) regulates oxygen homeostasis and gene transcription, impacting circadian rhythm and cellular senescence, either inducing or inhibiting senescence.

The interaction between HIF-1α and BMAL1 forms a heterodimer that may disrupt normal circadian and hypoxia signaling pathways, modulating cellular senescence and contributing to physiological dysfunction.

theories.evidence: Synthesis of diverse evidence from molecular studies on circadian proteins, hypoxia signaling, and cellular senescence; discussion of molecular mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses cellular senescence as a fundamental aging process with proposed molecular mechanisms involving circadian rhythm and hypoxia signaling, applicable broadly to organismal aging.

results.title: Why are whales big? Genes behind ocean giants.
A critical assessment of fasting to promote metabolic health and longevity.

theories.name: Caloric Restriction and Fasting as a Longevity Mechanism

key_concepts.description: This concept refers to evolved physiological mechanisms that allow organisms, including humans, to survive periods of food scarcity by adjusting metabolism and energy use. These mechanisms are considered adaptive in environments with intermittent famine.

Caloric restriction without overt starvation has been shown in model organisms to prolong lifespan, suggesting that reduced caloric intake triggers biological pathways that slow aging or reduce age-related damage.

key_concepts.concept: Mismatch Between Evolutionary Adaptations and Modern Environment
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that mechanisms evolved to survive famine may become maladaptive in modern contexts of caloric excess, contributing to obesity and metabolic disease, which are linked to aging and healthspan.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews data from model organisms demonstrating lifespan extension by caloric restriction, discusses evolutionary rationale, and examines clinical studies on fasting's metabolic effects and risks such as bone fragility.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging related to metabolic and evolutionary mechanisms; addresses aging broadly through metabolic health and longevity; and discusses underlying biological mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Aging: Lifespan and the evolution of somatic mutation rates.

theories.name: Evolutionary theory linking somatic mutation rates to lifespan

key_concepts.concept: Inverse correlation between lifespan and somatic mutation rate
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that species with longer lifespans have evolved lower rates of somatic mutations, suggesting a fundamental biological relationship between mutation accumulation and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary selection against noncancerous selfish cell lineages
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that natural selection acts to suppress the expansion of somatic cell lineages that behave selfishly but are not cancerous, which may influence aging and lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Somatic mutation rate as a causal factor in aging
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of somatic mutations is hypothesized to contribute causally to the aging process, linking molecular damage to organismal aging and lifespan evolution.

theories.evidence: Observational data showing an inverse correlation between mammalian lifespan and somatic mutation rates; evolutionary reasoning about selection pressures on somatic cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining aging at the organism level, grounded in evolutionary theory and molecular biology.

results.title: Ageing, metabolomics and palaeoanthropology: What can the fields learn from each other?
Aging and FGF23-klotho system.

theories.name: Phosphate toxicity-driven accelerated aging via the FGF23-Klotho endocrine system

key_concepts.concept: FGF23-Klotho endocrine system controls phosphate homeostasis
key_concepts.description: The bone secretes fibroblast growth factor-23 (FGF23) in response to phosphate intake, which acts on the kidney through the Klotho receptor to increase phosphate excretion, maintaining extracellular phosphate balance.

key_concepts.concept: Disruption of phosphate homeostasis causes accelerated aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Loss of Klotho or FGF23 leads to hyperphosphatemia and ectopic calcium phosphate precipitation, resulting in multiple organ atrophy, vascular calcification, sarcopenia, cognitive impairment, frailty, and shortened lifespan, resembling premature aging.

key_concepts.concept: Phosphate toxicity as a causal driver of systemic aging
key_concepts.description: Restoring phosphate balance by dietary phosphate restriction rescues aging-like phenotypes in deficient mice, indicating phosphate overload is causally linked to accelerated aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Calciprotein particles (CPPs) induce cell damage and inflammation contributing to aging
key_concepts.description: In chronic kidney disease (CKD), CPPs containing calcium phosphate circulate in blood, causing cellular damage and inflammation, which may underlie accelerated aging observed in CKD patients.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary constraint of calcium phosphate bone mineralization linked to aging
key_concepts.description: The evolution of calcium phosphate-based skeletons in vertebrates necessitates phosphate homeostasis mechanisms, but ectopic calcium phosphate deposition may predispose terrestrial vertebrates to aging.

theories.evidence: Mouse genetic models lacking Klotho or FGF23 showing premature aging phenotypes; rescue of phenotypes by low phosphate diet; observations in human CKD patients with CPPs and accelerated aging features; cited pathophysiological parallels between mice and humans.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (phosphate toxicity via FGF23-Klotho disruption) explaining systemic aging phenotypes across multiple organs and species; provides mechanistic insight linking mineral metabolism to aging; addresses organism-level aging rather than a narrow disease or organ.

results.title: Altruistic aging: The evolutionary dynamics balancing longevity and evolvability.

theories.name: Altruistic aging theory

key_concepts.description: Senescence, or age-related deterioration, is proposed to be altruistic because it benefits the population by potentially enhancing evolvability and adaptability during rapid environmental changes, despite being costly to the individual.

key_concepts.concept: Trade-off between longevity and population survival
key_concepts.description: Long-lived individuals can outcompete short-lived peers individually, but populations dominated by long-lived individuals are more prone to extinction when environments change rapidly, suggesting a balance between individual longevity and population-level adaptability.

key_concepts.concept: Stabilization of senescence through population structure
key_concepts.description: Similar to other cooperative behaviors, senescence can be stabilized in structured populations, implying that social or spatial organization influences the evolutionary dynamics of aging.

theories.evidence: Numerical simulations of an agent-based model demonstrating population dynamics under varying environmental conditions and population structures.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains why aging occurs (as an altruistic trait balancing longevity and evolvability), proposes causal evolutionary mechanisms, and addresses aging at the organism and population level with generalizable evolutionary logic.

results.title: The histone acylation reader ENL/AF9 regulates aging in Drosophila melanogaster.

theories.name: Histone crotonylation reader regulation of aging

key_concepts.description: Histone acylation, including crotonylation, modulates gene expression by altering chromatin structure and accessibility, which in turn affects cellular functions such as neurogenesis and response to signals.

key_concepts.concept: Role of YEATS domain proteins as histone crotonylation readers
key_concepts.description: YEATS domain-containing proteins (such as ENL/AF9) preferentially recognize crotonylated lysines on histones, acting as readers that translate this epigenetic mark into downstream gene regulatory effects.

Knockdown of neuronal ENL/AF9 in Drosophila extends lifespan and improves aging-related phenotypes like sleep and locomotion, suggesting a causal role of histone crotonylation reading in systemic aging regulation.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress modulation via gene regulation
key_concepts.description: Reduced ENL/AF9 activity upregulates catalase expression, decreases oxidative damage markers (MDA), and enhances oxidative stress tolerance, linking epigenetic regulation to aging-related oxidative stress mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Experimental knockdown of dENL/AF9 in Drosophila neurons with lifespan extension, improved fitness measures, gene expression changes (catalase upregulation), decreased oxidative damage (MDA levels), and increased oxidative stress tolerance.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking histone crotonylation reading to aging regulation at the organismal level, supported by mechanistic evidence and effects on lifespan and aging phenotypes.

results.title: Carving the senescent phenotype by the chemical reactivity of catecholamines: An integrative review.

theories.name: Catecholamine Chemical Reactivity Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Catecholamines (CA) undergo autoxidation producing toxic quinones and engage in Pictet-Spengler reactions with carbonyl compounds, generating mitochondrial toxins. This chemical reactivity is confined to specific cell types such as dopaminergic and noradrenergic neurons and their targets.

Reactive metabolites from CA cause covalent modifications of macromolecules that accumulate in slowly renewable biological components, compromising their function and contributing to aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Contribution to senescent phenotype and aging-associated disorders
key_concepts.description: The biochemical damage from CA reactivity leads to progressive functional decline in motor performance, cognition, emotional regulation, and neuroendocrine control, culminating in aging-associated diseases like Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, hypertension, sarcopenia, and menopause.
The theory explores how the paradox of CA's hazardous chemical properties coexisting with their biological importance may have evolved, suggesting a trade-off that impacts aging.

theories.evidence: The paper is an integrative review citing prior studies since the 1970s that link CA chemical reactivity to aging-associated diseases and phenotypes; it discusses biochemical mechanisms and evolutionary considerations but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (chemical reactivity of CA metabolites) contributing to systemic aging phenotypes and diseases, addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases, and discusses evolutionary logic underlying the mechanism.

results.title: Decoding Aging through iPSC Reprogramming: Advances and Challenges.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence and Epigenetic Reprogramming Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a hallmark and driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by the accumulation of senescent cells that contribute to tissue dysfunction and age-related diseases through mechanisms such as the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP).

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic clock resetting via partial reprogramming
key_concepts.description: Transient expression of reprogramming factors (OSKM) can reverse epigenetic aging markers, effectively 'resetting' the epigenetic clock and rejuvenating cells without full dedifferentiation.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress reversal
key_concepts.description: Reprogramming can restore mitochondrial function and reduce oxidative stress, which are key contributors to cellular aging and systemic decline.

key_concepts.concept: Use of iPSC technology to reverse aging hallmarks
key_concepts.description: Induced pluripotent stem cell technology demonstrates the potential to reverse multiple aging hallmarks, including telomere attrition and epigenetic alterations, suggesting a causal mechanism for aging that can be manipulated.

theories.evidence: Citations of lifespan extension in progeroid mouse models via partial reprogramming; references to experimental use of OSKM factors; mention of CRISPR-based epigenetic editing tools; discussion of mitochondrial and senescence markers.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging involving cellular senescence and epigenetic regulation, applicable at organismal level; discusses underlying causes and mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Oxidative distress in aging and age-related diseases: Spatiotemporal dysregulation of protein oxidation and degradation.

theories.name: Oxidative distress theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by an imbalance between oxidants and antioxidants leading to high concentrations of reactive species that cause biomolecular damage.
The generation, conversion, and removal of reactive species become compromised in both time and space, disrupting the redox landscape and increasing protein oxidation.
Oxidative damage to proteins, including irreversible modifications and cross-links, leads to protein fragmentation, misfolding, aggregation, and impaired function.

Dysfunction of key protein degradation pathways such as the 20S proteasome and autophagy-lysosome systems under oxidative distress contributes to the accumulation of damaged proteins and organismal aging.
The oxidative distress and resulting protein damage and degradation dysfunction are implicated in aging and age-related disorders including neurodegenerative, cardiovascular diseases, and diabetes.

theories.evidence: Data from cell cultures, animal models, and patient studies showing irreversible oxidation of redox-sensitive residues and various oxidative protein modifications; observations of impaired protein degradation pathways under oxidative distress conditions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs via oxidative damage and dysregulated protein homeostasis affecting the organism broadly; it is not limited to a single organ or disease but connects to systemic aging and multiple age-related diseases.

results.title: A mathematical model for the effects of grandmothering on human longevity.

theories.name: Grandmother hypothesis

key_concepts.description: Human females often live long beyond their reproductive years, unlike other great apes, suggesting that extended post-menopausal lifespan evolved due to selective advantages.
Post-menopausal females provide care for weaned infants, which allows mothers to reproduce again sooner without reducing offspring survival, thus enhancing inclusive fitness.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on population age structure and longevity
key_concepts.description: The caregiving behavior of grandmothers can increase adult life expectancy and alter steady-state age distributions in populations, supporting the evolution of longer lifespan.

theories.evidence: Mathematical modeling using ordinary differential equations simulating populations with and without grandmothering; numerical simulations showing increased adult life expectancy due to grandmother care.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general evolutionary mechanism explaining why humans evolved extended longevity beyond fertility, with causal explanations and population-level scope.

results.title: Microglial senescence.

theories.name: Microglial senescence theory of neurodegenerative disease

key_concepts.description: Microglial senescence refers to the aging-related decline in microglial function characterized by a state distinct from activation, potentially contributing to neurodegenerative disease pathogenesis. This concept suggests that senescent microglia may drive chronic neuroinflammation and neuronal dysfunction.

The theory emphasizes the difficulty in distinguishing between activated and senescent microglia, noting that previous models focusing solely on neuroinflammation may have conflated these states. Recognizing microglial senescence offers a refined framework to understand inflammatory processes in aging brains.

Microglial senescence is proposed as a better explanatory framework for the mechanisms underlying neurodegenerative diseases associated with aging, potentially replacing or complementing the traditional neuroinflammation hypothesis.

Understanding microglial senescence opens avenues for novel therapeutic strategies targeting senescent microglia to treat or prevent neurodegenerative diseases, differing fundamentally from approaches aimed at modulating neuroinflammation.

theories.evidence: Discussion of inconsistencies and caveats in neuroinflammation models of neurodegenerative disease; conceptual arguments rather than direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (microglial senescence) underlying aging-related neurodegeneration, addressing organism-level aging processes in the brain, and offers a mechanistic explanation beyond descriptive correlation. Although focused on microglia and neurodegeneration, it connects to systemic aging via brain aging and disease.

results.title: Biology of aging brain.

theories.name: Mitochondria-ROS-Calcium Metabolic Triad Theory of Neuronal Aging

key_concepts.description: A central concept proposing that the evolution of neuronal aging results from alterations in three interconnected metabolic components: mitochondria, reactive oxygen species (ROS), and intracellular calcium homeostasis. These components interact to maintain neuronal homeostasis, and their perturbation leads to aging-related decline.

With aging, neurons experience a reduced capacity to maintain physiological stability under stress due to metabolic and functional perturbations in the triad. Although aged neurons can maintain function under normal conditions, they become vulnerable to additional metabolic stressors such as ischemia or trauma.

The impaired metabolic state caused by disturbances in the triad predisposes neurons to degeneration, which may manifest clinically as cognitive dysfunction or dementia, often associated with protein aggregate accumulation disrupting metabolism.

theories.evidence: The paper cites experimental evidence supporting the role of the mitochondria-ROS-calcium triad in neuronal aging, including observations of modest neuron loss in specific brain regions, dendritic and axonal shrinkage, and metabolic dysregulation leading to vulnerability under stress.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining why neuronal aging occurs at the organismal level, linking metabolic dysfunction to systemic aging processes in the nervous system. It addresses broad aging mechanisms rather than narrow disease-specific phenomena.

results.title: Unravelling the nexus: Towards a unified model of development, ageing, and cancer.

theories.name: Driver Cell-Based Unified Model of Development, Ageing, and Cancer

key_concepts.description: The model posits the existence of driver cells distributed throughout the body, analogous to Spemann's organizers, which dynamically emerge from non-driver cells and reside in specialized niches. These cells orchestrate developmental and aging processes by inducing specific epigenetic gene activation patterns.

Development is viewed as a continuous process extending from conception through the entire lifespan, driven by the activity of driver cells. This challenges the traditional view that development ends at maturity, instead proposing that developmental-like processes persist and influence aging.

Events driven by driver cells before reproductive age are under strong evolutionary pressure and thus optimized, whereas events occurring after reproduction experience declining evolutionary pressure, resulting in 'pseudorandom' deterministic but erratic changes. These post-reproductive events contribute to benign aging traits and serious age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic Perturbations Leading to Disease and Cancer
