key_concepts.description: Some driver cell-induced events can disrupt epigenetic regulation of key pathways involved in driver cell activation and formation, potentially leading to cancer. This links aging and cancer mechanistically through the same driver cell-based framework.

theories.evidence: The abstract does not detail experimental data but references conceptual integration of embryogenesis, aging, and cancer, evolutionary theory regarding selection pressure, and epigenetic mechanisms. It suggests a novel theoretical framework rather than empirical validation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general, organism-level causal mechanism explaining aging as a continuation of developmental processes mediated by driver cells and epigenetic changes. It integrates evolutionary logic (declining selection pressure post-reproduction) and links aging to cancer, thus addressing broad aging phenomena beyond narrow contexts.

results.title: The Extension of Foundress Life Span and the Evolution of Eusociality in the Hymenoptera.

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of eusociality and lifespan extension in Hymenoptera

key_concepts.concept: Overlap of foundress and offspring lifespan
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the evolution of sterile worker castes in eusocial Hymenoptera requires that the foundress female's lifespan largely overlaps with that of her daughters, enabling reproductive division of labor.

key_concepts.concept: Increase in foundress lifespan with colony size
key_concepts.description: Foundress adult lifespan increases as colony size increases, while offspring development time decreases, leading to a higher ratio of foundress lifespan to worker lifespan, which supports the evolution of reproductive division of labor.

key_concepts.concept: Discrete lifespan increase at eusocial transition
key_concepts.description: There is a distinct increase in foundress lifespan when transitioning from solitary to eusocial species, independent of colony size, potentially driven by social factors such as multiple foundresses and progressive larval feeding.

key_concepts.concept: Plastic response to social status reducing senescence
key_concepts.description: Reduced senescence in dominant cofoundresses may be selected as a plastic response to social status, as subordinate cofoundresses perform high-risk tasks, lowering the dominant's extrinsic mortality.

key_concepts.concept: Role of haplodiploidy in eusocial evolution
key_concepts.description: Haplodiploidy favors multiple-foundress nests with reproductive skew among full sisters, possibly explaining the prevalence of eusociality in Hymenoptera.

theories.evidence: Phylogenetic analyses controlling for evolutionary relationships, life history character analyses, and comparative data on colony size, lifespan, and reproductive roles.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general evolutionary mechanism explaining why and how lifespan extension and eusociality evolve at the organismal level, addressing causal mechanisms and general principles beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: A comprehensive model for the biochemistry of ageing, senescence and longevity.

theories.name: Comprehensive biochemical signalling hubs model of aging

key_concepts.description: The model centers on three key biochemical signalling hubs: NFκB controlling the innate immune system, mTOR controlling cell growth, and the integrated stress response (ISR) controlling cellular homeostasis. These hubs interact to regulate aging processes at the biochemical level.

The model explains aging as involving chronic inflammation and cellular senescence, which arise from dysregulation within these signalling hubs, linking immune activation and stress responses to systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Advanced glycation end products (AGEs) as initiators
key_concepts.description: Aging is proposed to start with the spontaneous formation of AGEs, which trigger downstream effects on the signalling hubs, contributing to the aging phenotype.

key_concepts.concept: Gradual inhibition of AMPK-ISR determines maximal lifespan
key_concepts.description: The model suggests that the progressive inhibition of the AMPK-integrated stress response axis is a key determinant of maximal lifespan, highlighting a mechanistic link between energy sensing, stress responses, and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Hormetic dose response of anti-aging drugs
key_concepts.description: Based on the model, most anti-aging drugs are expected to show hormesis, meaning beneficial effects at low doses but potentially harmful effects at higher doses, complicating dose optimization.

theories.evidence: The model is based on integration of existing biochemical pathway data and literature; no new experimental data presented in abstract but references to totality of data underlying the model.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal biochemical mechanism for aging involving fundamental signalling hubs; explains systemic aging phenomena like inflammation and senescence; and integrates multiple pathways into a comprehensive framework.

results.title: Genome Instability and DNA Repair in Somatic and Reproductive Aging.

theories.name: DNA damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Genome instability as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of DNA damage over time leads to genome instability, which causally contributes to the aging process and aging-associated diseases such as cancer.

Diverse DNA repair pathways maintain genome integrity in somatic and germ cells, with somatic cells requiring maintenance only during the individual's lifespan, while germ cells maintain genetic information indefinitely.

key_concepts.concept: Cell fate changes triggered by DNA damage
key_concepts.description: DNA damage response can induce cellular outcomes such as apoptosis or cellular senescence, which are mechanisms linking DNA damage to aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary implications of germline DNA damage
key_concepts.description: Mutations caused by DNA damage in germ cells can lead to genetic diseases and influence species evolution, highlighting the importance of germline DNA repair in longevity and species fitness.

theories.evidence: Citations and discussion of DNA damage response pathways, cellular senescence, apoptosis, and the differential DNA repair in somatic versus germ cells; references to aging-associated diseases like cancer.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains aging as a fundamental process via genome instability and DNA repair mechanisms; proposes causal mechanisms linking DNA damage to aging; addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Male Adaptive Plasticity Can Explain the Evolution of Sexual Perception Costs.
Social Evolution: Big Benefits of BFFs.
Endocrine Regulation of Aging in the Fruit Fly Drosophila melanogaster.

theories.name: Endocrine Regulation of Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Endocrine signaling as a regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that hormones and endocrine pathways coordinate aging processes across tissues and cells, influencing lifespan and age-related physiological changes. Endocrine signals act as systemic regulators that integrate environmental and internal cues to modulate the pace of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic modulation of endocrine pathways affects lifespan
key_concepts.description: Mutations in single genes involved in endocrine signaling can extend or reduce lifespan, indicating that specific endocrine components have causal roles in aging regulation. These genetic alterations demonstrate that endocrine pathways are not merely correlated with aging but actively determine aging rates.

key_concepts.concept: Tissue- and cell-specific endocrine signaling impacts systemic aging
key_concepts.description: Changes in endocrine signaling localized to particular tissues or cells can influence overall organismal aging, highlighting the importance of inter-tissue communication mediated by hormones. This concept underscores the systemic nature of aging regulation via endocrine networks.

theories.evidence: Citations and synthesis of studies using Drosophila melanogaster demonstrating lifespan changes from mutations in endocrine genes and tissue-specific endocrine alterations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how endocrine signaling regulates aging at the organismal level, supported by evolutionary conservation and genetic evidence in a model organism.

results.title: Genetic approaches to aging in budding and fission yeasts: new connections and new opportunities.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction and nuclear silencing pathway in aging

key_concepts.description: Mutations causing defects in mitochondrial function alter aging-related processes, suggesting mitochondria play a causal role in aging. These defects affect nuclear silencing mechanisms, indicating cross-talk between mitochondria and nuclear gene regulation in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Nuclear silencing alterations independent of Rtg2p pathway
key_concepts.description: The study identifies changes in nuclear silencing that occur separately from the known Rtg2p-dependent retrograde signaling pathway, implying additional mitochondrial-to-nuclear communication pathways influence aging.

Mutations in ATP2, encoding a mitochondrial ATPase subunit conserved across prokaryotes and eukaryotes, reveal a lifespan-extending pathway, highlighting a conserved mitochondrial mechanism influencing organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Genetic screens in budding yeast isolating mutants affecting mitochondrial function and nuclear silencing; identification of ATP2 mutants twice in screens; development of chronological aging assays in fission yeast; isolation of long-lived mutants.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism linking mitochondrial dysfunction and nuclear gene regulation to aging, applicable across eukaryotes, supported by genetic evidence in model organisms.

results.title: Epigenetics and individuality: from concepts to causality across timescales.

theories.name: Epigenetic variation as a contributor to aging

key_concepts.description: Epigenetic changes refer to regulatory modifications that affect gene expression without altering the DNA sequence. These changes can persist through cell divisions and influence developmental differentiation.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic variation contributing to phenotypic differences
key_concepts.description: Variation in epigenetic states among individuals can lead to differences in phenotype, including susceptibility to diseases and aging-related traits, independent of genetic variation.
Some epigenetic modifications can be inherited across generations, potentially influencing evolutionary processes and phenotypic variation beyond classical genetic inheritance.

key_concepts.concept: Causal role of epigenetics in aging
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that epigenetic variation is not merely correlative but may causally contribute to aging processes by regulating gene expression patterns that affect organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Review of studies using new genomic approaches that measure and perturb epigenetic variation, highlighting advances in understanding epigenetic contributions to phenotypic differences and aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental mechanism (epigenetic regulation) underlying aging at the organismal level, proposes causal roles for epigenetic variation, and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

results.title: A mitochondrial DNA deletion in normally aging and in Alzheimer brain tissue.

theories.name: Mitochondrial DNA Deletion Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that specific deletions in mitochondrial DNA, such as the 4977 bp deletion, accumulate progressively in non-dividing cells like neurons as organisms age. These deletions are absent or negligible in rapidly dividing tissues and younger individuals but increase in older brain tissue.

The accumulation of mtDNA deletions leads to impaired mitochondrial function, specifically down-regulation of ATP production in neurons and other non-dividing cells. This energy deficit is proposed as a fundamental mechanism contributing to aging at the cellular and organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Common mechanism in aging and Alzheimer's disease
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that the mitochondrial DNA deletions contribute similarly to normal aging and Alzheimer's disease pathology, implying a shared underlying mechanism involving mitochondrial dysfunction.

theories.evidence: Quantitative PCR data showing absence of mtDNA deletions in young and rapidly dividing tissues, and presence at low levels (~0.13%) in aged brain tissue, with similar levels in Alzheimer’s patients and age-matched controls.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging based on mitochondrial DNA damage accumulation affecting cellular energy metabolism, applicable broadly to organismal aging and neurodegeneration.

results.title: Protection of the genome and the central exome by peripheral non-coding DNA against DNA damage in health, ageing and age-related diseases.

theories.name: Non-coding DNA protection theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Peripheral non-coding DNA as a protective buffer
key_concepts.description: Non-coding DNA, particularly peripheral heterochromatin regions, physically blocks DNA damage to the central exome and genome by acting as a shield against exogenous and endogenous assaults.

key_concepts.concept: Small non-coding RNAs inactivation of foreign nucleic acids
key_concepts.description: Non-coding DNA encodes small non-coding RNAs that function in the cytoplasm to inactivate foreign nucleic acids, thereby reducing DNA damage from external sources.

key_concepts.concept: Extrachromosomal circular DNA (eccDNA) removal of damaged DNA
key_concepts.description: Damage incurred by non-coding DNA during its protective role is excised and removed from the nucleus in the form of eccDNA via nuclear pore complexes, maintaining genome integrity.

With aging, the total amount of non-coding DNA and heterochromatin decreases, leading to reduced physical blockage and eccDNA-mediated damage removal, resulting in increased DNA damage accumulation in the genome and exome.

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage as proximate cause of aging and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of DNA damage due to diminished protection by non-coding DNA is proposed as a fundamental molecular driver of biological aging and age-associated genetic diseases.

theories.evidence: Summary of recent evidence supporting the protective role of non-coding DNA in healthy and pathological states; references to DNA damage accumulation and eccDNA mechanisms; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging at the organism level, explaining how DNA damage accumulates due to decline in non-coding DNA protection, addressing fundamental aging processes rather than specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Dietary polyphenols as geroprotective compounds: From Blue Zones to hallmarks of ageing.

theories.name: Geroprotective effects of dietary polyphenols via modulation of hallmarks of ageing

key_concepts.description: Polyphenols are a large family of plant-based compounds that may promote healthy ageing by influencing biological mechanisms underlying ageing. They are proposed to contribute to longevity by mitigating age-related diseases and promoting optimal healthspan.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation of evolutionarily conserved ageing mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Polyphenols may act on conserved molecular and cellular pathways associated with ageing, potentially impacting the hallmarks of ageing such as genomic instability, cellular senescence, and inflammation, thereby influencing systemic ageing processes.

key_concepts.concept: Dietary patterns in Blue Zones as models for healthy ageing
key_concepts.description: The dietary habits of long-lived populations in Blue Zones, characterized by high intake of polyphenol-rich foods, provide a natural model to study how nutrition influences longevity and the biological ageing process.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews epidemiological observations from Blue Zones, biochemical and biological studies on polyphenols, and their effects on hallmarks of ageing, highlighting existing evidence and knowledge gaps.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses mechanisms by which polyphenols may causally influence general ageing processes through conserved biological pathways, linking dietary factors to systemic ageing and longevity, thus meeting the criteria of a generalizable, causal, and broad-scope aging theory.

results.title: Interplay of transposable elements and ageing: epigenetic regulation and potential epitranscriptomic influence.

theories.name: Transposable Element Activation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Transposable elements (TEs) influence genomic stability and gene expression
key_concepts.description: TEs are mobile genetic elements whose activity can disrupt genome integrity and alter gene regulatory networks, potentially contributing to aging-related genomic instability.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic and epitranscriptomic regulation controls TE activity
key_concepts.description: TE activity is tightly regulated by chromatin state, DNA methylation, histone modifications, and RNA-based mechanisms, including emerging roles of epitranscriptomic modifications, which modulate TE expression and impact aging.

key_concepts.concept: TE activation is connected to physiological and pathological aging
key_concepts.description: Increased TE activity during aging may drive or exacerbate age-related molecular and cellular dysfunctions, suggesting a causal role in the aging process and age-associated diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews recent findings on TE regulation mechanisms and their dynamics during aging, citing studies on chromatin, DNA, RNA, and histone modifications, and emerging epitranscriptomic data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (TE activation regulated epigenetically) that causally contributes to aging at the organismal level, discusses underlying molecular mechanisms, and connects to systemic aging processes beyond narrow phenomena.

results.title: Genome-wide CRISPR screens identify ILF3 as a mediator of mTORC1-dependent amino acid sensing.

theories.name: mTORC1-dependent amino acid sensing as a regulator of aging

key_concepts.concept: mTORC1 as a central metabolic hub
key_concepts.description: mTORC1 integrates nutrient signals, particularly amino acids, to regulate cell growth and metabolism. Its activity is controlled by sensor proteins that relay amino acid availability to downstream complexes GATOR1 and GATOR2.

key_concepts.concept: ILF3 mediates mTORC1 amino acid sensing
key_concepts.description: ILF3 tethers the GATOR complexes to lysosomes, facilitating the regulation of mTORC1 activity in response to amino acid signals. This positioning is critical for proper mTORC1 signaling.

key_concepts.concept: Conserved role of ILF3 in aging modulation
key_concepts.description: ILF3’s function in controlling mTORC1 signaling and autophagy is evolutionarily conserved across species including humans, mice, and worms, and it modulates the aging process, suggesting a mechanistic link between nutrient sensing and systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Genome-wide CRISPR/Cas9 screens identifying ILF3 as a regulator, functional assays showing ILF3’s role in tethering GATOR complexes to lysosomes, and cross-species data implicating ILF3 in autophagy and aging modulation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism linking nutrient sensing via mTORC1 to aging regulation at the organismal level, supported by mechanistic insights and evolutionary conservation.

results.title: Quantification of Age-Related Decline in Transcriptional Homeostasis.
The Yin and Yang of replicative aging and rejuvenation.

theories.name: Replicative Aging and Rejuvenation in Budding Yeast

key_concepts.description: Budding yeast mother cells undergo aging as they divide asymmetrically, producing daughter cells. The mother cells progressively lose vitality and eventually die after a finite number of divisions, representing a fundamental aging process at the cellular level.

Daughter cells are born rejuvenated with nearly full lifespan potential, effectively resetting the aging clock despite the mother's age. This rejuvenation suggests mechanisms that segregate aging factors asymmetrically during cell division.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary Forces Shaping Aging and Rejuvenation
key_concepts.description: The paper discusses evolutionary pressures that may have led to the emergence of aging and rejuvenation strategies in yeast, proposing that these represent adaptive strategies with distinct benefits, implying an evolutionary rationale behind aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews recent findings on mechanisms of replicative aging and rejuvenation in yeast and discusses evolutionary perspectives; no new experimental data presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general biological aging process (replicative aging) with causal mechanisms (asymmetric division, rejuvenation), and discusses evolutionary forces, thus providing a generalizable and causal explanation of aging at the organismal/cellular level.

results.title: Phenotypic molecular features of long-lived animal species.

theories.name: Programmed Longevity Theory

key_concepts.concept: Longevity as a programmed biological property
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that longevity is not merely a byproduct of random damage or wear but is encoded as a species-specific, evolved program. This program involves adaptations at multiple biological levels, from metabolites to genome, regulated by signaling and regulatory networks.

Longevity differences among species arise from evolutionary processes that have shaped species-specific lifespan traits. The theory suggests that natural selection has optimized longevity through molecular and physiological adaptations.
Long-lived species exhibit coordinated structural and functional features across biological organization levels, implying an integrated regulatory system that supports extended lifespan.

theories.evidence: Comparative physiology studies across species with widely varying lifespans, highlighting molecular and systemic adaptations correlated with longevity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It attempts to explain why and how aging occurs at an organismal level, proposes a causal mechanism (programmed biological property), and addresses aging broadly across species rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

results.title: Six Drivers of Aging Identified Among Genes Differentially Expressed With Age.

theories.name: Gene expression drivers of aging theory

key_concepts.concept: Differential gene expression as causal drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: Certain genes that change expression levels with age are not merely markers but have causal roles in modulating lifespan and aging processes. Identifying these genes can reveal fundamental mechanisms driving aging.
Genes that show consistent differential expression with age across multiple mammalian species and whose orthologs affect lifespan in C. elegans suggest evolutionarily conserved aging drivers.

key_concepts.concept: Distinction between drivers and compensatory responses
key_concepts.description: Not all gene expression changes with age cause aging; some may be protective or downstream effects. The theory emphasizes the need to distinguish causal drivers from compensatory or incidental changes.

theories.evidence: Meta-analysis of 25 gene expression datasets from multiple mammalian tissues and species; RNA interference experiments targeting orthologous genes in C. elegans showing lifespan extension upon gene knockdown.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes causal mechanisms (specific genes) underlying aging at an organismal level, supported by cross-species data and functional testing; addresses aging broadly rather than a single organ or disease.

results.title: Non-complementary strand commutation as a fundamental alternative for information processing by DNA and gene regulation.
Life history tradeoffs in humans: increased life expectancy with sperm count reduction.

theories.name: Life History Tradeoff Theory

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that there is an inverse relationship between lifespan and reproductive output (fecundity). Organisms that live longer tend to have lower reproductive rates, which helps maintain species diversity and ecological balance.
The theory suggests that life history traits such as longevity and reproduction are balanced through evolutionary pressures to optimize survival and reproduction at the species level.

key_concepts.concept: Neuroendocrine regulation of spermatogenesis linked to longevity
key_concepts.description: The paper hypothesizes that the decline in sperm production in humans may be regulated by neuroendocrine mechanisms that also underlie increased human lifespan, suggesting a mechanistic link between reproductive decline and longevity.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from model organisms (Caenorhabditis elegans, Drosophila, rodents) showing lifespan extension associated with reduced fecundity; demographic data correlating fertility rates with infant mortality and life expectancy in humans.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging-related tradeoffs at the organism level, linking lifespan and reproductive capacity through evolutionary and physiological mechanisms.

results.title: [Whole-Genome Duplications in Evolution, Ontogeny, and Pathology: Complexity and Emergency Reserves].

theories.name: Whole-Genome Duplication (WGD) as an Adaptive Aging-Related Mechanism

key_concepts.description: Whole-genome duplication increases the amount of genetic material within cells, which can lead to increased complexity and adaptability at both organismal and cellular levels.

key_concepts.concept: WGD as a Driver of Evolution and Adaptation
key_concepts.description: WGD events contribute to speciation, increased organismal complexity, and adaptive potential by activating ancient evolutionary programs and regulatory networks.

key_concepts.concept: Somatic WGD in Aging and Pathology
key_concepts.description: Somatic cell polyploidy occurs in normal development, regeneration, aging, and pathological states such as cancer, suggesting a role in organismal aging processes and disease progression.

key_concepts.concept: Shift in Gene Regulation Prioritizing Cell Survival
key_concepts.description: Under stress, gene regulation may shift from organismal homeostasis to cell survival, potentially leading to aging-related diseases like cardiovascular conditions and carcinogenesis.
WGD may reactivate unicellularity-related pathways and morphogenetic programs that promote survival and life extension, linking genome duplication to aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Comparative whole-transcriptome data, molecular biology, genomics, and molecular medicine findings are integrated to identify common features of WGD in evolution, ontogeny, and pathology.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses WGD as a fundamental biological process influencing aging and adaptation at the organismal level, proposing mechanisms linking genome duplication to aging and disease, thus meeting the criteria of generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope.

results.title: Efficiency of mitochondrial functioning as the fundamental biological mechanism of general intelligence (g).

theories.name: Mitochondrial efficiency theory of aging and intelligence

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial functioning as a core biological mechanism
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the overall efficiency of mitochondrial functioning underlies general intelligence (g) and is a fundamental biological mechanism common to all brain and cognitive processes. This efficiency also contributes to the relationships observed among intelligence, health, and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of mitochondrial roles beyond oxidative stress
key_concepts.description: While oxidative stress and cell damage have been proposed as mechanisms linking mitochondria to aging, this theory expands the scope to include other important mitochondrial functions that affect brain development, neurological diseases, and general health.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary genetics of mitochondrial DNA and sex differences
key_concepts.description: The theory incorporates the maternal inheritance of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), the compensatory evolution of nuclear DNA, and the evolutionary inability to purge deleterious mtDNA mutations in males as factors that may explain sex differences in intelligence variability and cognitive domains.

theories.evidence: The proposal integrates existing research on intelligence, mitochondrial biology, brain development, neurological diseases, and health. It also references evolutionary genetics concepts related to mtDNA inheritance and nuclear DNA compensation. The abstract mentions generating testable predictions but does not describe new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging and cognitive decline based on mitochondrial efficiency, addressing aging broadly through fundamental biological mechanisms. It links mitochondrial function to systemic aging processes and cognitive aging, not limited to a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: The importance of reaction norms in dietary restriction and ageing research.
What is frustrating the search for treatment of dementia? Fraud or ideas?

theories.name: Evolutionary perspective on dementia-related molecular markers

key_concepts.concept: Evolution of molecular markers like peptide Aβ
key_concepts.description: This concept explores how molecular markers associated with dementia, such as amyloid-beta (Aβ), evolved because they provided some functional benefit to the individual, which allowed their persistence through natural selection.

key_concepts.concept: Delayability of dementia before diagnosis versus unstoppable progression after diagnosis
key_concepts.description: This concept addresses the paradox that dementia can be delayed before clinical diagnosis but becomes unstoppable afterward, suggesting underlying biological mechanisms that change disease dynamics at different stages.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses recent evidence of laboratory fraud affecting dementia research and uses evolutionary reasoning to question current assumptions about molecular markers; no new experimental data are presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain why dementia progresses in a particular way and why certain molecular markers exist from an evolutionary standpoint, addressing underlying causes and mechanisms at an organismal level. However, it is focused specifically on dementia rather than aging broadly, and the evolutionary framing is applied to dementia markers rather than general aging processes.

results.title: Mitochondria - Nucleus communication in neurodegenerative disease. Who talks first, who talks louder?

theories.name: Mitochondria-Nucleus Communication Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Bidirectional signaling between mitochondria and nucleus
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that mitochondria and the nucleus engage in a dynamic, two-way communication that regulates cellular homeostasis and stress responses. The dialogue involves feedback loops that integrate signals beyond these organelles, influencing cell survival or death decisions.

key_concepts.concept: Role of mitochondrial dysfunction in aging
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction triggers transcriptional responses aimed at protecting mitochondria and maintaining overall cellular homeostasis. This dysfunction accumulates with age, contributing to cellular stress and damage.

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage-induced stress pathways affecting mitochondria
key_concepts.description: DNA damage in the nucleus initiates stress signaling pathways that impact mitochondrial homeostasis, linking genotoxic stress to mitochondrial function and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Integrated organellar stress and communication failure in aging
key_concepts.description: With aging, both mitochondria and nucleus accumulate damage and stress, potentially disrupting their communication mechanisms. This interruption may exacerbate cellular dysfunction and contribute to neurodegenerative disease.

theories.evidence: Review of current literature on mitochondrial and nuclear signaling pathways, transcriptional responses to mitochondrial dysfunction, DNA damage stress pathways, and combined mitochondrial and genotoxic damage studies, with a focus on brain cells and neurodegenerative disease.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental cellular mechanism underlying aging by focusing on organelle communication and stress accumulation, which is generalizable beyond specific diseases. It proposes causal mechanisms linking mitochondrial and nuclear dysfunction to aging processes, especially in brain cells, thus meeting the core requirements of an aging theory.

results.title: [On the problems of the evolutionary optimization of life history. I. A Markov model of the Leslie life history and optimization of fertility].
Unraveling power-law scaling through exponential cell division dynamics.
Effects of development and parental care on Hamilton's force of selection.

theories.name: Hamilton's force of selection theory of senescence

key_concepts.concept: Force of selection decreases after reproduction onset
key_concepts.description: Hamilton's theory posits that the evolutionary force of natural selection weakens after an organism begins reproducing, which explains the emergence of senescence patterns as deleterious mutations accumulate in later life stages.

key_concepts.concept: Force of selection remains constant before reproduction
key_concepts.description: The theory assumes that prior to reproduction, the force of selection is stable because survival to reproductive age is critical for fitness, but this assumes offspring independence immediately after birth.

key_concepts.concept: Parental care and offspring dependence modify force of selection
key_concepts.description: This paper extends Hamilton's theory by modeling how offspring reliance on parental care delays offspring independence, thereby increasing the force of selection on offspring survival up to independence age and potentially explaining decreased early-life mortality.

key_concepts.concept: Gene activation patterns influence life history evolution
key_concepts.description: Genes expressed recurrently across life stages experience stronger selection than strictly age-specific genes, suggesting gene activation timing is important for understanding evolutionary aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Minimal mathematical model presented; theoretical analysis based on modifying assumptions of offspring independence; references to Hamilton's original theory.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains aging as a fundamental evolutionary process, proposes causal mechanisms for senescence patterns, addresses organism-level aging broadly, and extends existing evolutionary aging theory.

results.title: A cGAS-mediated mechanism in naked mole-rats potentiates DNA repair and delays aging.

theories.name: cGAS-mediated DNA repair enhancement theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Distinctive cGAS function in naked mole-rats
key_concepts.description: Naked mole-rat cGAS has evolved four amino acid changes that alter its function compared to human or mouse homologs, specifically losing its suppressive effect on homologous recombination DNA repair.
These amino acid changes weaken TRIM41-mediated ubiquitination and interaction with the segregase P97, allowing cGAS to remain bound to chromatin longer upon DNA damage, which facilitates DNA repair.
Prolonged cGAS binding promotes interaction between repair factors FANCI and RAD50, enhancing RAD50 recruitment to DNA damage sites and potentiating homologous recombination repair.

key_concepts.concept: Antagonism of cellular and tissue aging
key_concepts.description: The altered cGAS function contributes to delaying aging and extending lifespan in naked mole-rats, suggesting a causal mechanism linking enhanced DNA repair to longevity.

theories.evidence: Comparative molecular analysis of cGAS amino acid changes in naked mole-rats, functional assays showing altered ubiquitination and chromatin binding, interaction studies of repair factors, and lifespan/aging phenotype correlations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how enhanced DNA repair via altered cGAS function delays aging at the organismal level, supported by mechanistic insights and evolutionary context.

results.title: Pros and Cons of APOE4 Homozygosity and Effects on Neuroplasticity, Malnutrition, and Infections in Early Life Adversity, Alzheimer's Disease, and Alzheimer's Prevention.
From microbes to mammals: The experimental evolution of aging and longevity across species.

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of aging via experimental evolution

key_concepts.concept: Senescence as a pervasive biological phenomenon
key_concepts.description: Senescence is described as the functional deterioration of cells or organisms with age, observed broadly across species, indicating a fundamental aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Experimental evolution to test aging mechanisms
key_concepts.description: By imposing selection on age-specific fitness traits in populations, experimental evolution shifts aging patterns, allowing empirical investigation of the genetic and physiological bases of aging.
Whole-genome sequencing of experimentally evolved populations can identify candidate genomic variants associated with altered aging and longevity, linking genotype to phenotype.
Selection for longevity often involves trade-offs with reproductive timing and other phenotypic traits, reflecting evolutionary constraints and mechanisms underlying aging.

theories.evidence: Survey of experimental evolution studies across multiple species, phenotypic data on longevity and reproductive timing, genomic data from evolved populations, and complementary field studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses aging as a general biological process, proposes causal evolutionary mechanisms for aging, and discusses underlying genetic and physiological bases applicable across species.

results.title: Aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR) impairs circadian regulation: Impact on the aging process.

theories.name: Aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR) disruption of circadian regulation as a driver of aging

key_concepts.description: Circadian clocks regulate 24-hour sleep-wake cycles and metabolic rhythms conserved through evolution. Aging impairs circadian rhythmicity, which disrupts metabolism and physiological functions, contributing to age-related decline.

AhR, an evolutionarily conserved receptor originally for environmental defense, interacts with core circadian regulators (BMAL1/CLOCK) and epigenetic mechanisms, disrupting circadian gene expression and homeostasis.

AhR signaling inhibits autophagy, enhances cellular senescence, and disrupts extracellular matrix, processes linked to tissue degeneration during aging. These effects resemble those caused by chronic circadian disruption.

key_concepts.concept: Hypothesized causal link between AhR, circadian disruption, and aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that AhR signaling accelerates aging by impairing circadian homeostasis, thereby promoting tissue degeneration and functional decline.

theories.evidence: The abstract references robust evidence of AhR interaction with circadian regulators and its role in cellular senescence, autophagy inhibition, and extracellular matrix disruption. It also notes experimental evidence linking AhR signaling to age-related degeneration via circadian disruption, though causality is not fully established.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (how AhR-mediated circadian disruption drives systemic aging), proposes causal mechanisms (AhR interaction with circadian clock genes, autophagy inhibition, senescence), and addresses aging broadly rather than a single organ or disease.

results.title: Impact of Mitochondrial Architecture, Function, Redox Homeostasis, and Quality Control on Organismic Aging: Lessons from a Fungal Model System.

theories.name: Mitochondrial Quality Control and Redox Homeostasis Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The mQCS is a complex network of pathways that maintain mitochondrial function by balancing reactive oxygen species (ROS), degrading damaged proteins, and removing dysfunctional mitochondria. This system mitigates ROS-induced damage but has limited capacity, and overwhelming this capacity leads to mitochondrial dysfunction and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) as both source and target
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria generate ROS as byproducts of metabolism, which can damage mitochondrial components. ROS act as signaling molecules but excessive ROS cause oxidative damage, contributing to aging.

The structural organization of mitochondria and the regulation of mitochondrial lipids influence mitochondrial function and aging processes, suggesting that changes in mitochondrial morphology and membrane composition affect organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Limitations of current understanding and experimental models
key_concepts.description: Current knowledge of mQCS regulation and signaling pathways is incomplete, and most data come from controlled lab conditions that may not reflect natural environmental fluctuations, which are important for understanding aging as it evolved.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from the fungal model Podospora anserina demonstrating mitochondrial aging etiology, studies on mQCS branches, and observations on mitochondrial architecture and lipid homeostasis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism of aging centered on mitochondrial dysfunction and quality control failure, addressing fundamental biological aging processes at the organism level.

results.title: The evolution of cancer and ageing: a history of constraint.

theories.name: Evolutionary trade-off theory of cancer resistance and aging

key_concepts.concept: Cancer resistance as a constraint on lifespan evolution
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that natural selection favors mechanisms that suppress cancer early in life, which constrains the evolution of longer lifespans. Because cancer can affect young individuals, species evolve cancer resistance mechanisms that impact aging processes.
Mechanisms such as telomere shortening and cellular senescence that suppress tumor formation also limit cell proliferation and tissue regeneration, inadvertently promoting aging-related degeneration.

key_concepts.concept: Trade-offs between tumor suppression and tissue regeneration
key_concepts.description: Selection for tumor suppression impacts stem cell aging and the regenerative capacity of adult tissues, leading to functional decline and aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: The abstract references evolutionary logic and known biological mechanisms like telomere shortening and cellular senescence; it is a conceptual synthesis rather than new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable evolutionary mechanism explaining why aging occurs as a trade-off with cancer resistance, provides causal explanations linking tumor suppression to aging, and addresses aging broadly at the organismal level.

results.title: The role of senescence in cellular plasticity: Lessons from regeneration and development and implications for age-related diseases.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cell cycle arrest and proinflammatory phenotype
key_concepts.description: Senescence is characterized by a permanent cessation of cell division accompanied by the secretion of proinflammatory factors, which contribute to tissue dysfunction and organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Dual role in aging and regeneration
key_concepts.description: While traditionally linked to aging and age-related decline, senescent cells also play beneficial roles in tissue growth, regeneration, and development by influencing cellular plasticity.

key_concepts.concept: Senescence as a barrier and driver of plasticity
key_concepts.description: Senescence can act cell-autonomously to block cellular plasticity, but through paracrine signaling, it can also promote plasticity in neighboring cells, impacting tissue remodeling and disease processes.

theories.evidence: The paper integrates recent data on senescence roles in development, regeneration, and age-related diseases, citing emerging evidence of senescence's paradoxical functions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how cellular senescence contributes to organismal aging and age-related diseases, linking cellular processes to systemic aging phenomena.

results.title: How development affects evolution.

theories.name: Developmental constraints and pathways theory of evolution

key_concepts.description: While natural selection drives genotypic and phenotypic evolution toward fitness peaks, development constrains evolution to specific paths, causing evolutionary outcomes to occur at path peaks rather than the highest fitness landscape peaks.
Alterations in developmental processes can create new path peaks, triggering genotypic or phenotypic diversification even when the fitness landscape remains constant and unimodal.

key_concepts.concept: Role of phenotypic plasticity, niche construction, extra-genetic inheritance, and developmental bias
key_concepts.description: These factors influence the developmental constraints and thus alter the evolutionary path and outcomes, with extra-genetic inheritance having lasting evolutionary effects by modifying developmental constraints.
Phenotype construction that is biased in an adaptive direction can lead to either adaptive or maladaptive evolution depending on the nature of developmental constraints.

key_concepts.concept: Developmental propagation and evolution of negative senescence
key_concepts.description: Developmental effects that propagate phenotypically over age can enable the evolution of negative senescence, suggesting a developmental mechanism influencing aging patterns.

theories.evidence: Mathematical framework integrating development and evolution; theoretical analysis showing how development shapes evolutionary paths and outcomes; conceptual discussion of phenotypic plasticity, niche construction, and extra-genetic inheritance effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: This theory proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how development constrains and shapes evolutionary trajectories, including aging patterns such as negative senescence. It addresses aging broadly via developmental propagation of phenotypic effects over age, thus meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: Aging - What it is and how to measure it.
Somatic mutation as an explanation for epigenetic aging.

theories.name: Somatic mutation-driven epigenetic aging theory

key_concepts.concept: Coupling of somatic mutations and epigenetic changes
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that the accumulation of somatic mutations, particularly C-to-T mutations at methylated cytosines, drives widespread remodeling of DNA methylation patterns over time. This coupling suggests that epigenetic changes observed with age are a direct consequence of underlying mutation accumulation.

Somatic mutations at CpG sites not only alter methylation locally but also influence methylation patterns in a broader genomic region (±10 kb), enabling mutation-based models to predict biological age similarly to epigenetic clocks.

key_concepts.concept: Shared genomic loci as aging hotspots
key_concepts.description: Genomic regions where somatic mutations accumulate with age tend to have methylation patterns that are highly predictive of age, indicating these loci are key drivers of the aging methylome remodeling.

theories.evidence: Analysis of multimodal data from 9,331 human individuals showing correlation between CpG mutations and methylation changes, mutation-based age predictions aligning with epigenetic clocks, and identification of genomic loci with age-accumulating mutations linked to methylation patterns.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how biological aging occurs at the organism level through accumulation of somatic mutations driving epigenetic changes; it addresses aging broadly via methylation remodeling and mutation accumulation, not limited to specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Influence of telomerase activity and initial distribution on human follicular aging: Moving from a discrete to a continuum model.

theories.name: Telomere shortening and telomerase activity theory of cellular aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length as a biomarker and driver of cellular aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres shorten with each cell division, limiting the replicative capacity of cells and leading to senescence when a critical length is reached (Hayflick limit). This shortening is a fundamental mechanism underlying cellular aging.

key_concepts.concept: Asymmetric telomere length distribution during cell division
key_concepts.description: The model assumes that during cell division, one daughter cell inherits the same telomere length as the mother cell, while the other daughter cell inherits shorter telomeres, introducing heterogeneity in the cell population's aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of telomerase activity in modulating aging rate
key_concepts.description: Telomerase can elongate telomeres, thereby slowing the aging process of the cell population. Decreased telomerase activity leads to accelerated aging, while higher activity can maintain telomere length and delay senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Hayflick limit as a fundamental constraint on cell division
key_concepts.description: The Hayflick limit defines the maximum number of divisions a cell can undergo before becoming senescent, serving as a key parameter in the model that influences the aging rate of the cell population.

theories.mode: propose, formalize, test (via modeling and application to human follicular growth)
theories.evidence: Mathematical modeling (discrete and continuous), exact and numerical solutions of partial differential equations, application to human follicular growth data, analysis of aging rate dependence on telomerase activity, initial telomere distribution, and Hayflick limit.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (telomere shortening and telomerase activity) explaining cellular aging at organismal level; provides mechanistic explanation; addresses aging broadly through modeling of cell populations and senescence; connects to general aging theory via Hayflick limit and telomerase.

results.title: Senolytic therapy increases replicative capacity by eliminating senescent endothelial cells.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is a state of permanent cell cycle arrest induced by stressors such as DNA damage and telomere attrition. Senescent cells accumulate with age and contribute to tissue dysfunction and chronic inflammation, thereby driving organismal aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Senescent endothelial cells impair vascular function
key_concepts.description: Senescent endothelial cells negatively impact vascular health by promoting inflammation and reducing regenerative capacity, which contributes to cardiovascular disease progression, a major age-related pathology.

key_concepts.concept: Senolytic clearance of senescent cells can rejuvenate tissue function
key_concepts.description: Senolytic drugs selectively eliminate senescent cells, potentially restoring proliferative capacity and reducing markers of cellular aging such as DNA damage and telomere dysfunction, thus mitigating aging phenotypes at the cellular and tissue level.

theories.evidence: Experimental treatment of replicative senescent human endothelial cells with senolytics Talabostat and Navitoclax showed reduction in senescent cell burden and increased proliferation. Talabostat also reduced DNA damage markers and telomere dysfunction, while Navitoclax increased oxidative stress.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging via accumulation of senescent cells affecting organismal aging, tests interventions targeting this mechanism, and links cellular senescence to systemic aging-related phenotypes.

results.title: PMMA nanoplastics induce gastric epithelial cellular senescence and cGAS-STING-mediated inflammation via ROS overproduction and NHEJ suppression.

theories.name: Cellular senescence and DNA damage-driven aging theory

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that accumulation of senescent cells, characterized by markers such as senescence-associated β-galactosidase activity and cell cycle arrest, contributes causally to organismal aging by impairing tissue function and promoting inflammation.

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage and impaired repair mechanisms
key_concepts.description: DNA damage accumulation, particularly due to reactive oxygen species (ROS) overproduction, and suppression of DNA repair pathways like nonhomologous end-joining (NHEJ), leads to genomic instability that drives cellular dysfunction and aging.

Activation of the cGAS-STING signaling pathway by cytosolic DNA fragments resulting from DNA damage triggers chronic inflammation, which is a hallmark and causal contributor to aging and age-related phenotypes.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing PMMA nanoplastics induce ROS overproduction, DNA damage, inhibition of NHEJ repair, increased senescence markers in gastric epithelial cells, chromosomal aberrations, micronuclei formation, and activation of cGAS-STING pathway; correlated with aging-related inflammation and behavioral changes in mice.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a general causal mechanism of aging (cellular senescence, DNA damage, inflammation) applicable beyond a specific organ or disease; proposes underlying mechanisms (ROS, DNA repair suppression, cGAS-STING activation); connects cellular events to organism-level aging processes.

results.title: Taking flight: An ecological, evolutionary and genomic perspective on bat telomeres.

theories.name: Telomere maintenance theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres, the protective end caps of chromosomes, shorten with each cell division, leading to cellular senescence and organismal aging. This concept posits that the rate and extent of telomere shortening influence lifespan and healthspan.

key_concepts.concept: Telomerase expression and alternative telomere maintenance mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Telomerase is an enzyme that can elongate telomeres, potentially counteracting shortening. Some species, including certain bats, may have evolved alternative mechanisms to maintain telomere length, contributing to extended longevity.

Comparative genomic and phylogenomic analyses suggest that telomere maintenance strategies have evolved in response to ecological and life-history pressures, influencing species-specific longevity patterns.

theories.evidence: Comparative genomic analyses, patterns of telomere shortening and telomerase expression across bat species, and phylogenomic studies cited; however, functional causative studies are noted as still required.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging mechanism (telomere dynamics) with causal implications for organismal aging and longevity across species, not limited to a single organ or disease.

results.title: Adult age-related changes in the specificity of episodic memory representations: A review and theoretical framework.
Immunity and lifespan: answering long-standing questions with comparative genomics.

theories.name: Immunity-longevity coevolution theory

key_concepts.concept: Role of immune system in lifespan evolution
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that the ability of organisms to defend against pathogens over extended periods is a key factor influencing lifespan. The immune system's efficiency and specificity, particularly the balance between innate and adaptive immunity, are proposed to affect longevity.

Adaptive immunity, characterized by high specificity and long-lasting immunological memory, is hypothesized to support extended lifespans by providing effective pathogen defense with minimal self-damage, unlike the more nonspecific innate immunity.

key_concepts.concept: Comparative immunogenomics as a tool to study aging
key_concepts.description: Advances in whole genome assemblies enable comparative genomic analyses across species, allowing researchers to disentangle the coevolution of longevity and immune traits, thereby testing the relationship between immune system characteristics and lifespan evolution.

theories.mode: discuss, propose new theoretical framework enabled by comparative genomics
theories.evidence: The paper references recent improvements in whole genome assemblies and comparative immunogenomic analyses as emerging tools to investigate the coevolution of immunity and longevity, though no direct experimental data or results are presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain why and how lifespan (a general aging trait) is influenced by immune system evolution, proposing a causal mechanism linking immune specificity and memory to longevity. It addresses aging broadly at the organism level and is not limited to a specific disease or organ. Thus, it meets the core criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Multi-omic underpinnings of heterogeneous aging across multiple organ systems.
Systems Age: a single blood methylation test to quantify aging heterogeneity across 11 physiological systems.
Cell membrane asymmetries and cellular aging.

theories.name: Asymmetric cell division and membrane asymmetry theory of replicative aging

key_concepts.description: In budding yeast, mother cells divide asymmetrically to produce smaller daughter cells. This process allows the daughter cells to inherit a full replicative lifespan potential, effectively resetting aging in the daughter despite the mother cell aging over successive divisions.

The capacity of mother cells to produce daughters with full lifespan depends critically on membrane-associated processes that ensure asymmetric distribution of aging factors, such as damaged proteins or organelles, thereby protecting the daughter cell from inheriting aging-related damage.

key_concepts.concept: Role of asymmetrically distributed membrane proteins in aging
key_concepts.description: Numerous membrane proteins are asymmetrically distributed during cell division, and these proteins play roles in replicative aging. However, a comprehensive understanding of their specific functions and how membrane asymmetry mechanistically contributes to cellular aging remains incomplete.

theories.evidence: The paper synthesizes extensive prior studies in Saccharomyces cerevisiae on asymmetric cell division and membrane protein distribution related to replicative aging. It compiles known asymmetrically distributed membrane proteins and discusses their roles, highlighting gaps in current knowledge.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining how aging is reset in daughter cells via asymmetric inheritance of aging factors mediated by membrane asymmetry. It addresses causal mechanisms of aging at the cellular level with implications for organismal aging, not limited to a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Strategic outline of interventions targeting extracellular matrix for promoting healthy longevity.
Entropy, Assessed by Homeostatic Dysregulation on Electrocardiograms Predicts Fracture and Mortality.

theories.name: Entropy-based Homeostatic Dysregulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Entropy as a measure of biological aging
key_concepts.description: Entropy represents increased disorder and loss of homeostasis across biological systems, reflecting the progressive decline in physiological regulation with age.

key_concepts.concept: Homeostatic dysregulation (HD) quantified by Mahalanobis distance
key_concepts.description: HD is operationalized as the dispersion of physiological measurements from a youthful normal reference, measured here by Mahalanobis distance of ECG parameters, indicating systemic physiological dysregulation.
Dysregulation measured in one system (cardiac electrophysiology via ECG) reflects broader systemic aging processes, including musculoskeletal decline, which manifests as increased fracture risk.

key_concepts.concept: Predictive association with mortality and morbidity
key_concepts.description: Higher entropy/HD correlates with increased risk of fractures and all-cause mortality independent of traditional risk factors, suggesting it captures fundamental aging-related physiological decline.

theories.evidence: Analysis of a large cohort (7738 individuals) with ECG-based HD measures correlated with age, fracture incidence, and mortality risk over 5.5 years; statistical adjustments for confounders including bone mineral density and clinical risk factors.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging as systemic homeostatic dysregulation (entropy increase), supported by empirical data linking physiological dysregulation to aging outcomes; addresses aging broadly beyond single organ or disease.

results.title: Exponential dynamics of DNA methylation with age.

theories.name: DNA methylation exponential dynamics theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: DNA methylation dynamics as exponential convergence
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that DNA methylation levels at individual CpG sites start out of equilibrium at birth and approach a steady-state equilibrium exponentially with age. This suggests a nonlinear dynamic process underlying methylation changes over the lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Heterogeneity of timescales across methylation sites
key_concepts.description: Different CpG sites exhibit different rates (timescales) of exponential convergence to their steady-state methylation levels, indicating site-specific dynamics that collectively shape the overall methylation aging trajectory.

key_concepts.concept: Modeling methylation as a system approaching equilibrium
key_concepts.description: By modeling methylation changes as a system moving toward equilibrium, the theory provides a mechanistic framework for understanding age-related methylation patterns beyond descriptive or predictive models.

key_concepts.concept: Link between methylation dynamics and exponential aging risk
key_concepts.description: The exponential nature of methylation changes parallels the exponential increase in mortality risk with age, suggesting a fundamental connection between methylation dynamics and the biological aging process.

theories.evidence: Fitting the theoretical model to empirical DNA methylation data from brain tissue spanning birth to old age; simulations of methylation changes using empirical distributions of timescales; comparison of modeled dynamics to observed exponential trajectories.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanistic model explaining how a fundamental biological process (DNA methylation) changes with age at the organismal level; it addresses aging broadly by linking methylation dynamics to systemic aging risk; it is not limited to a single disease or organ without broader implications.

results.title: Three-Dimensional Regulation of Ferroptosis at the Intersection of Iron, Sulfur, and Oxygen Executing Scrap and Build Toward Evolution.

theories.name: Ferroptosis as a regulated cell death mechanism influencing aging

key_concepts.description: A form of regulated necrotic cell death dependent on catalytic Fe(II) and characterized by lipid peroxidation. It is implicated in various physiological and pathological processes including aging, neurodegeneration, and cancer.

key_concepts.concept: Three-dimensional regulation by iron, sulfur, and oxygen
key_concepts.description: Ferroptosis is controlled by the interplay of iron (oxidants), sulfur compounds (antioxidants), and oxygen (affecting membrane fluidity and susceptibility to lipid peroxidation), which together determine cell susceptibility to ferroptosis.
Ferroptosis is involved in aging processes, potentially contributing to cellular and organismal aging through iron-dependent oxidative damage and regulated cell death pathways.

key_concepts.concept: Cancer as ferroptosis resistance and iron addiction
key_concepts.description: Carcinogenesis is described as a process where cells develop resistance to ferroptosis and become addicted to iron, based on rodent studies, linking ferroptosis regulation to cancer and aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent research linking ferroptosis to aging, neurodegeneration, embryonic erythropoiesis, and cancer; rodent animal studies on cancer ferroptosis resistance; conceptual framework of iron, sulfur, and oxygen regulation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper proposes a mechanistic explanation of a regulated cell death pathway (ferroptosis) that impacts aging at a general organismal level through iron-dependent oxidative damage and lipid peroxidation. It addresses causal mechanisms and is generalizable beyond specific diseases, linking to aging broadly.

results.title: Muller's genetic load/species extinction hypothesis.

theories.name: Muller's genetic load hypothesis

key_concepts.description: The hypothesis proposes that ionizing radiation exposure causes the accumulation of harmful recessive mutations in a population over generations, increasing genetic load.

key_concepts.concept: Species extinction risk due to genetic load
key_concepts.description: Muller suggested that the buildup of genetic load could threaten species survival, potentially leading to species extinction, including humans.
The hypothesis assumes a linear relationship between radiation dose and mutation induction, with no safe threshold, implying even minimal radiation can cause cumulative genetic damage.

theories.evidence: Long-term mouse radiation studies over 82 generations (~2500 human years) showed no significant effects on reproductive fitness or longevity; worldwide data from multiple labs failed to support the hypothesis; recent data on dominant mutations contradict LNT and cumulative assumptions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging-related decline at the species level via genetic mutation accumulation; it attempts to explain why species might deteriorate or go extinct due to genetic damage, thus addressing fundamental aging processes at the organism/population level.

results.title: Chemistry of the Joint Origin and Evolution of Life, Death, and Aging.

theories.name: Chemical Origin of Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Aging emerges concomitantly with life due to inherent chemical properties of small molecules involved in the origin of life. These molecules have 'excessive' potencies that enable them to form covalent adducts with proteins and nucleic acids, leading to accumulation of damaged macromolecules that reduce viability over time.

key_concepts.concept: Kinetics of molecular disintegration and mortality
key_concepts.description: The exponential increase in mortality with age (Gompertz law) arises from the kinetics of molecular disintegration following the Arrhenius equation. This chemical kinetic principle, originally temperature-dependent, is inherited by the viability decline of protocells, linking chemical decay rates to organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Aging as an independent factor from biological evolution
key_concepts.description: Aging is proposed not to be a product of biological evolution or programmed processes but an independent chemical factor that effectively eliminates old living objects without requiring evolved aging programs.

Oxygen is not the primary cause of aging but modifies the chemical driving forces of aging. It enabled the evolution of multicellular organisms with unrenewable cell populations and the capacity to accumulate and recognize chemical damage, thus influencing aging complexity.
While aging is chemically inevitable, the abstract suggests that the satisfactory solution to the problem of aging awareness in humans is mental rather than chemical, physical, or pharmacological.

theories.evidence: Review of published chemical concepts related to origin of life molecules, theoretical linkage of chemical kinetics (Arrhenius equation) to mortality patterns (Gompertz law), and logical argumentation about oxygen's role and evolutionary implications.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general, fundamental chemical mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organism level, offers causal explanations linking molecular damage and mortality kinetics, and addresses aging broadly as a universal process independent of evolved programs.

results.title: Sexual dimorphism in liver cell cycle and senescence signalling pathways in young and old rats.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as initiator and consequence of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence involves permanent cell cycle arrest and changes in cellular function, which both trigger and result from the aging process at the organismal level.
The aging process and its molecular pathways, including senescence signaling, differ between males and females, indicating sex-dependent mechanisms in systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Cell cycle arrest regulation in aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with altered expression of genes regulating cell cycle progression and arrest, such as increased expression of inhibitors (p15, p21, p57) and decreased expression of cell cycle promoters (Cdk2, Cdk4), contributing to reduced cellular proliferation capacity.

theories.evidence: RNA-seq data from liver tissue of male and female rats at young (110 days) and old (650 days) ages showing differential gene and protein expression in cell cycle and senescence pathways, with sex-specific patterns.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes causal molecular mechanisms (cell cycle arrest and senescence signaling) underlying general biological aging at the organ and organism level, with evolutionary and physiological relevance via sexual dimorphism.

results.title: The Origins of Aging: Evidence that Aging is an Adaptive Phenotype.

theories.name: Adaptive Aging Program Theory

key_concepts.concept: Aging as an adaptive developmental program
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that aging is not merely a consequence of damage accumulation but an evolved, species-specific program that serves adaptive functions at the organismal and ecological levels.

Aging and death programs regulate species population densities within ecosystems, balancing the optimal functioning of both individual species and the ecosystem as a whole through multilevel selection.

In complex multicellular organisms, cellular aging mechanisms such as senescence, autophagy, and apoptosis act as altruistic processes benefiting the organism by supporting morphogenesis, tissue repair, and maintenance.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary transition from single-cell to multicellularity
key_concepts.description: The theory traces aging origins from replicative arrest in single-cell organisms to stem cell decline and programmed cellular death in multicellular organisms, highlighting aging as an evolved biological strategy.

Humans possess a second inheritance system—culture—that has expanded ecological niches and altered evolutionary pressures, suggesting that future aging and lifespan evolution will be influenced by urban ecosystems and cultural practices.

theories.evidence: Review of published data on cellular aging programs in single-cell and multicellular organisms; discussion of evolutionary biology concepts including multilevel selection; ecological and evolutionary theory applied to aging; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging as an adaptive, evolved program affecting the whole organism and species populations, grounded in evolutionary and ecological theory.

results.title: Platelet Factor 4 and Longevity of Patients with Essential Thromobocythemia: An Example of Antagonistic Pathogenic Pleiotropy.

theories.name: Antagonistic Pathogenic Pleiotropy

key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that certain pathological abnormalities can simultaneously cause specific diseases while also reducing other morbidities through unrelated mechanisms. This dual effect results in an overall morbidity or mortality that is less severe than expected from the pathology alone.

key_concepts.concept: Balance between harmful and protective effects
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that the negative impact of a disease-causing abnormality may be offset by beneficial effects mediated by factors produced as a consequence of the abnormality, leading to a net neutral or even positive effect on longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Example of essential thrombocythemia and platelet factor 4
key_concepts.description: In essential thrombocythemia, elevated platelets increase platelet factor 4 (PF4) levels, which may reduce age-associated decline in immune and cognitive functions, potentially balancing the increased thrombotic risk and preserving life expectancy.

theories.evidence: The paper uses clinical observations of essential thrombocythemia patients who do not show reduced life expectancy despite elevated thrombotic risk, and references experimental findings in mice where PF4 reduces age-related decline in immune and cognitive functions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how a pathological abnormality can influence aging and longevity at the organismal level, addressing underlying causes and balancing effects relevant to systemic aging.

results.title: Seed production determines the entrance to dormancy of the inflorescence meristem of Pisum sativum and the end of the flowering period.
Asymmetric Stem Cell Division and Germline Immortality.

theories.name: Germline Immortality via Asymmetric Stem Cell Division

key_concepts.description: The concept that germ cells can perpetually transmit genetic information across generations without aging, maintaining an 'eternal cycle' of cellular youth and function.

A mechanism by which stem cells divide to produce one daughter cell that retains stem cell properties and another that differentiates, potentially segregating damaged cellular components to maintain germline cell youth.
Processes during gametogenesis and asymmetric division that reset or rejuvenate cellular age markers, effectively reversing or preventing the accumulation of aging-related damage in germ cells.

theories.evidence: Citations and extensive studies in yeast models demonstrating asymmetric cell division and gametogenesis as mechanisms for cellular age resetting; parallels drawn between unicellular and multicellular organisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining how biological aging is avoided in germ cells, addressing causal mechanisms (asymmetric division and age resetting) relevant to organismal aging and reproduction.

results.title: Stem cell-mediated development, regeneration, chimerism, and aging in the colonial chordate Botryllus schlosseri.
Influence of oxidative stress on women's fertility: A model with a generational age Caputo's fractional derivative.

theories.name: Telomere shortening and oxidative stress theory of cellular aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening as a driver of cellular aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres shorten with each cell division due to the end-replication problem, leading to a gradual loss of proliferative potential and cellular aging. This shortening is a fundamental mechanism underlying cellular senescence and organismal aging.
Oxidative stress causes damage that leads to a more rapid loss of telomeric repeats beyond the natural shortening from cell division, thereby accelerating cellular aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Mathematical modeling of aging dynamics using fractional derivatives
key_concepts.description: The paper proposes a continuum mathematical model incorporating Caputo's fractional derivative to capture the stochastic effects of oxidative stress on telomere shortening and cellular generational aging, linking molecular damage to aging at the cell population level.

key_concepts.concept: Interaction between oxidative stress and telomerase activity
key_concepts.description: The model suggests that antioxidants and telomerase activity can mitigate the accelerated aging effects caused by oxidative stress, indicating a potential intervention point for reducing cellular aging.

theories.evidence: Mathematical modeling applied to human follicular growth data comparing young and older women; simulation results showing effects of oxidative stress and telomerase activity on granulosa cell generational age.
