theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (telomere shortening accelerated by oxidative stress) explaining cellular aging relevant to organismal fertility decline; uses a mathematical model to formalize the mechanism; connects molecular damage to systemic aging effects in female reproductive cells.

results.title: Chrysophanol delays aging via insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathway.

theories.name: Insulin/IGF-1 Signaling Pathway Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathway is a highly conserved molecular cascade across species that regulates lifespan and aging processes. Modulation of this pathway influences longevity and healthspan by affecting metabolic and stress response mechanisms.

In model organisms like Caenorhabditis elegans, the insulin receptor homolog DAF-2 negatively regulates the FOXO transcription factor DAF-16. Reduced signaling through DAF-2 activates DAF-16, which promotes expression of genes involved in stress resistance, metabolism, and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Regulation of senescence and antioxidant defenses
key_concepts.description: Activation of the insulin/IGF-1 pathway influences cellular senescence-associated secretory phenotypes (SASPs) and enhances antioxidant gene expression, thereby contributing to delayed aging and improved cellular homeostasis.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing chrysophanol extends lifespan and healthspan in C. elegans and multiple mouse models by activating the insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathway; observations of changes in SASPs and antioxidant gene expression.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging that is evolutionarily conserved and supported by experimental intervention across species, addressing systemic aging rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: The role of chondrocyte senescence in the pathogenesis of osteoarthritis and in limiting cartilage repair.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Cells, such as chondrocytes, undergo progressive senescence characterized by increased expression of senescence markers (e.g., beta-galactosidase), decreased mitotic activity, and telomere shortening, which collectively reduce their functional capacity.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on tissue function and repair
key_concepts.description: Senescent chondrocytes synthesize less functional extracellular matrix components and respond poorly to anabolic stimuli, leading to diminished tissue maintenance and repair, contributing to age-related diseases such as osteoarthritis.
Introduction of telomerase (hTERT) and oncogenes (E6 and E7) can extend the replicative lifespan of chondrocytes, suggesting that cellular senescence is not an inevitable, irreversible process.

theories.evidence: Measurement of senescence markers (beta-galactosidase, mitotic activity, telomere length) in human chondrocytes across ages; correlation of mitochondrial dysfunction with senescence; creation of immortalized chondrocyte cell lines via hTERT and oncogene transfection.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process (cellular senescence) with causal mechanisms (telomere shortening, mitochondrial dysfunction) that affect organism-level aging (cartilage aging and osteoarthritis prevalence). The theory is generalizable beyond chondrocytes to systemic aging mechanisms.

results.title: Loss of Earth's old, wise, and large animals.
Loss of α-gal during primate evolution enhanced antibody-effector function and resistance to bacterial sepsis.

theories.name: Evolutionary trade-off theory of aging via pathogen-driven selection

key_concepts.description: Old World primates, including humans, have lost the functional GGTA1 gene, which encodes the enzyme synthesizing α-gal. This mutation leads to absence of α-gal glycans and presumably arose due to natural selection pressures.

key_concepts.concept: Enhanced immune effector function due to α-gal loss
key_concepts.description: Loss of α-gal from IgG-associated glycans increases IgG effector function by enhancing IgG-Fc gamma receptor binding, which improves resistance to bacterial sepsis independently of α-gal-specific immunity.

key_concepts.concept: Trade-off between pathogen resistance and accelerated reproductive senescence
key_concepts.description: While loss of GGTA1 confers survival advantage against sepsis, it also causes accelerated reproductive senescence in mice, suggesting an evolutionary trade-off between immunity and aging.

Modeling indicates that high exposure to virulent pathogens could exert sufficient selective pressure to fix GGTA1 loss-of-function mutations, linking pathogen-driven selection to aging-related trade-offs.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from Ggta1-deleted mice showing increased resistance to bacterial sepsis and accelerated reproductive senescence; mathematical modeling supporting evolutionary selection pressure.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable evolutionary mechanism explaining aging-related trade-offs at organism level, with causal explanation linking pathogen exposure to accelerated senescence; scope is broad, connecting immune function and systemic aging.

results.title: Antioxidant and prooxidant modulation of lipid peroxidation by integral membrane proteins.

theories.name: Lipid peroxidation as a universal driver of biological aging

key_concepts.concept: Lipid peroxidation as a fundamental aging mechanism
key_concepts.description: Lipid peroxidation is proposed as a key universal driver of biological aging, involving free radical chain reactions that damage cellular membranes and contribute to aging processes at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Role of membrane proteins in modulating lipid peroxidation
key_concepts.description: Integral membrane proteins containing redox-active amino acid residues influence the course and extent of lipid peroxidation, either promoting or inhibiting the chain reaction, thus affecting aging-related damage.

key_concepts.concept: Specific amino acid residues as modulators
key_concepts.description: Tyrosine and tryptophan act as chain-breaking antioxidants terminating lipid peroxidation, cysteine accelerates propagation as a chain-transfer catalyst, and methionine may interfere with initiation, reflecting evolutionary adaptations to oxidative stress.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews experimental, genetic, and comparative data supporting the roles of specific amino acid residues in lipid peroxidation and evolutionary pressures shaping their presence in membrane proteins.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain aging as a fundamental biological process through the mechanism of lipid peroxidation and its modulation by membrane proteins, providing causal explanations and evolutionary context applicable broadly to organismal aging.

results.title: Selection on age-specific survival: Constant versus fluctuating environment.

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of aging based on age-specific survival selection

key_concepts.description: The classic evolutionary biodemography result states that natural selection pressure on survival decreases as reproductive age increases, implying that traits affecting survival late in life are less strongly selected against.

key_concepts.concept: Effect of environmental fluctuation on selection
key_concepts.description: This paper examines how fluctuating environments, as opposed to constant environments, influence the pattern of selection on age-specific survival, showing that the decline in selection with age may not always hold under environmental variability.

The mathematics underlying the classic result reflect a general property of the genetics of populations with age structure, applicable in both constant and fluctuating environments, suggesting robustness of evolutionary principles governing aging.

theories.evidence: Mathematical analysis of selection on age-specific survival under different environmental scenarios; theoretical modeling rather than empirical data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it addresses a general evolutionary mechanism explaining why aging occurs via declining selection pressure with age, proposes causal evolutionary explanations, and applies broadly to organism-level aging processes.

results.title: Mechanisms of SIRT3 Regulation of Aging and Aging-Related Diseases and Advances in Drug Therapy.

theories.name: SIRT3-mediated mitochondrial regulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: SIRT3 enhances mitophagy through p53 deacetylation, which promotes the removal of damaged mitochondria, thereby maintaining mitochondrial integrity and function, a key factor in slowing cellular senescence and systemic aging.

SIRT3 activates antioxidant enzymes such as SOD2 and IDH2, which reduce oxidative stress by neutralizing reactive oxygen species, thus protecting cells from oxidative damage that contributes to aging.
SIRT3 coordinates fatty acid β-oxidation and glucose metabolism to maintain energy balance and metabolic health, which are critical for delaying age-related metabolic decline and diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews multiple lines of evidence including molecular pathways (p53 deacetylation, SOD2/IDH2 activation), disease models (neurodegeneration, cardiovascular, metabolic disorders), and therapeutic interventions (natural compounds targeting SIRT3).
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism of aging centered on mitochondrial regulation by SIRT3, addressing systemic aging processes and age-related diseases, not limited to a single organ or disease.

results.title: Termite queen physogastry and associated mechanisms shaping a high lifetime fecundity.
Life, Death and Energy: What Does Nature Select?

theories.name: Equal Fitness Paradigm (EFP)

key_concepts.concept: Energetic basis of survival and reproduction
key_concepts.description: The EFP posits that natural selection maximizes energetic fitness, quantified as the conversion of biomass into surviving offspring, emphasizing energy as the fundamental currency driving survival and reproductive success.

key_concepts.concept: Mass-specific rate of cohort biomass production
key_concepts.description: This parameter represents the rate at which biomass is produced per unit mass in a cohort, serving as a key factor in determining energetic fitness and how organisms allocate energy to growth and reproduction.

key_concepts.concept: Steady-state replacement of parents by offspring
key_concepts.description: At steady state, parents replace themselves with offspring of equal mass-specific energy content and biomass, indicating a balance in energy flow across generations that natural selection maintains.

key_concepts.concept: No intrinsic fitness advantage for higher metabolic or life history traits
key_concepts.description: The paradigm explains why traits such as higher metabolic power, faster growth rates, greater fecundity, longevity, or resource use efficiency do not inherently confer fitness advantages, as energy allocation is balanced by natural selection.

theories.evidence: Mathematical formulation of energetic fitness (E = P_coh * G * F * Q), empirical constants for energy and biomass replacement, and theoretical arguments based on natural selection and energy use across diverse life histories.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging and life history traits based on energy allocation and natural selection, applicable broadly across organisms, and addresses fundamental mechanisms underlying aging and reproduction.

results.title: [Sestrins are Gatekeepers in the Way from Stress to Aging and Disease].

theories.name: Sestrin-mediated stress response theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Sestrins are evolutionarily conserved proteins present across animal species that are activated in response to various stress stimuli, acting as gatekeepers in cellular stress adaptation.

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic regulation via AMPK and mTOR pathways
key_concepts.description: Activated sestrins regulate key metabolic signaling pathways, specifically AMPK and mTOR kinases, to promote antioxidant responses and autophagy, facilitating cell survival under stress.

key_concepts.concept: Dual role in aging and disease
key_concepts.description: While sestrins contribute to protection against stress and support organismal health during activities like physical exercise, their prolonged activation under chronic stress conditions may contribute to the development of age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The abstract references evolutionary conservation of sestrins, their activation by stress stimuli, and their regulatory roles in AMPK and mTOR signaling pathways, with implications for cell survival and age-related disease development. No direct experimental data is presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how a conserved molecular mechanism (sestrins) mediates cellular stress responses that impact aging and age-related diseases, proposing a causal mechanism linking stress adaptation to aging processes at the organismal level. It is generalizable beyond specific organs or diseases and addresses fundamental aging mechanisms.

results.title: Inflammation and DNA damage: cause, effect or both.

theories.name: DNA Damage-Induced Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Chronic Inflammation as a Driver of DNA Damage
key_concepts.description: Chronic unresolved inflammation leads to sustained secretion of cytokines and redox stress, which causes mitochondrial and nuclear DNA damage. This persistent damage acts as a trigger for downstream aging mechanisms.
DNA damage activates the DDR pathway orchestrated by ATM and ATR kinases, which alter gene expression and metabolism to induce cellular senescence, a state of permanent cell cycle arrest.

Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory cytokines and other factors (SASP) that reinforce inflammation and promote a vicious cycle between inflammation and senescence, contributing to tissue dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionarily Conserved Circuitry for Mutation Prevention
key_concepts.description: The cycle of inflammation, DNA damage, DDR, and senescence is an evolutionarily conserved mechanism to arrest the cell cycle and reduce mutation accumulation during oxidative stress caused by infection or inflammation.

key_concepts.concept: Link to Organ Dysfunction and Age-Related Diseases
key_concepts.description: DNA damage-induced senescence and inflammation contribute to dysfunction in multiple organs and are implicated in diverse diseases of autoimmune, rheumatic, degenerative, and vascular origin, connecting cellular mechanisms to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references molecular pathways (ATM/ATR kinases, p53, p16, p21), cytokine secretion profiles, and associations with organ dysfunction in various diseases, suggesting a synthesis of experimental and literature evidence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental, organism-level aging process via a causal mechanism (DNA damage leading to senescence and inflammation), generalizable beyond specific diseases, and proposes an organizing principle (vicious cycle of inflammation and senescence).

results.title: Identification of a longevity gene through evolutionary rate covariation of insect mito-nuclear genomes.

theories.name: Mito-nuclear coevolution and longevity regulation theory

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that coordinated evolution and functional interaction between mitochondrial and nuclear genes are fundamental to regulating organismal longevity. This includes not only mitochondrial-targeted nuclear genes but also other nuclear genes that evolutionarily covary with mitochondrial genes.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary rate covariation (ERC) as a tool to identify longevity genes
key_concepts.description: ERC analysis across species can reveal nuclear genes that coevolve with mitochondrial genes, suggesting functional interactions that impact aging and lifespan regulation.

key_concepts.concept: Role of CG11837/DIMT1 in lifespan regulation
key_concepts.description: The gene CG11837 (putative ortholog of human DIMT1) modulates lifespan across diverse species by influencing oxidative phosphorylation and protecting against cellular senescence, indicating a conserved mechanism linking mito-nuclear interactions to aging.

theories.evidence: Comparative genomic ERC analysis of 472 insect species; functional knockdown and overexpression experiments in multiple insect species and C. elegans showing lifespan effects; cellular assays in human cells demonstrating protection from senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how mito-nuclear gene interactions regulate aging across species, supported by mechanistic experiments and evolutionary analysis.

results.title: Facing healthy and pathological aging: A systematic review of fMRI task-based studies to understand the neural mechanisms of cognitive reserve.

theories.name: Cognitive Reserve Theory

key_concepts.description: CR explains individual differences in susceptibility to cognitive decline despite brain aging or pathology. It is often operationalized through socio-behavioral proxies such as education, occupation, and engagement in mentally stimulating activities that modulate cognitive performance.

Neural reserve refers to the efficiency and capacity of existing brain networks that support cognitive function. Higher neural reserve is associated with reduced brain activity during tasks, indicating more efficient processing.

Neural compensation involves the recruitment of additional or alternative brain regions to maintain cognitive performance when primary networks are compromised by aging or pathology. It is often observed during difficult tasks or in pathological aging.

theories.evidence: Systematic review of fMRI task-based studies in young, healthy, and pathological elderly individuals showing patterns of brain activity related to neural reserve and compensation; observations of increased task-related activity with age and compensation in pathology; effects of socio-behavioral proxies on neural mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for variability in cognitive aging at the organism level, linking socio-behavioral factors to neural mechanisms that modulate aging-related cognitive decline. It addresses broad cognitive aging rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific phenomenon.

results.title: Evolution of asymmetric damage segregation : a modelling approach.

theories.name: Asymmetric Damage Segregation Theory of Cellular Aging

key_concepts.description: In certain unicellular organisms like budding yeast, damaged proteins and cellular components are preferentially retained in the mother cell during cell division, leading to mother cell-specific aging while the daughter cell is rejuvenated.

The theory proposes that the degree of asymmetry in damage segregation is shaped by evolutionary selective forces balancing costs and benefits, including trade-offs between reproduction and maintenance, and energy requirements.

key_concepts.concept: Trade-offs between reproductive investment and maintenance
key_concepts.description: The model incorporates physiological trade-offs where investment in damage repair and maintenance competes with reproductive output, influencing the evolutionarily optimal strategy for damage segregation.
The theory uniquely considers potential cellular costs that accompany evolving asymmetric damage segregation, which may influence whether symmetry or asymmetry is favored in different organisms.

theories.evidence: Mathematical modeling incorporating protein synthesis, damage accumulation, and degradation processes; incorporation of ecological and physiological trade-offs; comparative discussion of different yeast species with varying segregation asymmetry.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal evolutionary mechanism explaining why asymmetric damage segregation occurs as a fundamental aging process at the cellular level, with implications for organismal aging; it addresses underlying causes and evolutionary logic beyond a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Evolutionary ecology of telomeres: a review.

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of telomere dynamics

key_concepts.description: Telomere-associated disease risks can shorten reproductive lifespan and reduce relative fitness among individuals, thereby influencing natural selection. This suggests telomere length and maintenance may be under evolutionary pressure.

key_concepts.concept: Heritability and variation of telomere traits
key_concepts.description: Telomere length shows wide variation in heritability across taxa, gender, ethnicity, age, and disease status, ranging from zero to one. This complexity challenges traditional quantitative genetic models and indicates diverse evolutionary dynamics.

key_concepts.concept: Taxonomic variation in telomere maintenance mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Rates of telomere attrition and elongation vary among taxa, with some coherence but notable exceptions, such as somatic telomerase activity in inbred mice, beavers, and many ectotherms. This diversity complicates simplistic views of telomere biology and its evolutionary role.

theories.evidence: Citations of observed variation in telomere heritability and length among populations, differences in telomerase activity across species, and evolutionary divergence in telomere traits.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain why telomere dynamics influence aging and fitness at the organismal level, proposes evolutionary mechanisms underlying aging-related telomere changes, and addresses general aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Pharmacological frontiers in senescence: Transforming senescence with drug repurposing.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence refers to the irreversible growth arrest of cells in response to various stressors, which contributes causally to aging and age-related diseases by promoting tissue dysfunction and chronic inflammation.

Pharmacological interventions can modulate senescence by selectively eliminating senescent cells (senolytics), modifying their secretory phenotype (senomorphics), blocking senescence induction (senoblockers), or reversing senescence (senoreversers), thereby potentially mitigating systemic aging effects.

key_concepts.concept: Drug repurposing as a strategy for senescence intervention
key_concepts.description: Using existing drugs with known safety and pharmacokinetics to target senescence accelerates clinical translation and offers a pragmatic approach to extend healthspan and treat aging-related dysfunction.

theories.evidence: Comprehensive classification of senotherapeutics, discussion of molecular targets and mechanisms, and evaluation of pharmacological strategies bridging preclinical and clinical applications.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental biological aging mechanism (cellular senescence) with causal explanation, generalizable to organismal aging, and discusses pharmacological interventions targeting this mechanism.

results.title: Termites and other social insects as emerging model organisms of ageing research: how to achieve a long lifespan and a high fecundity.

theories.name: TI-J-LiFe network theory of ageing and life-history trade-offs

key_concepts.description: A universal mechanistic framework involving the TOR/IIS (Target of Rapamycin/Insulin/Insulin-like Signaling), juvenile hormone (JH), and lifespan/fecundity regulatory axes that underlie ageing and life-history trade-offs in insects. This network integrates nutrient sensing, hormonal regulation, and downstream ageing processes.

In social insects, pathways that typically link high fecundity to shortened lifespan in solitary insects have been uncoupled. For example, in honeybees and ants, vitellogenesis (egg yolk production) is uncoupled from life-shortening high juvenile hormone titres and IIS activity, allowing queens to achieve both long lifespan and high fecundity.

Despite upstream uncoupling, downstream processes causing ageing such as oxidative stress, transposable element activity, and telomere attrition still vary between species and environments, indicating that the ultimate ageing mechanisms remain conserved but modulated.

theories.evidence: Summary of current data from social insect models (termites, ants, honeybees) showing molecular uncoupling of fecundity and lifespan pathways; comparative evolutionary insights; references to conserved downstream ageing mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: provides a generalizable mechanistic framework explaining how ageing and life-history trade-offs are regulated at an organismal level; proposes causal mechanisms involving conserved signaling and hormonal pathways; addresses broad ageing processes beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: LONG-TERM LABORATORY EVOLUTION OF A GENETIC LIFE-HISTORY TRADE-OFF IN DROSOPHILA MELANOGASTER. 1. THE ROLE OF GENOTYPE-BY-ENVIRONMENT INTERACTION.
Coevolution of non-homologous end joining efficiency and encephalization.

theories.name: Coevolution of DNA double-strand break repair efficiency and encephalization theory

key_concepts.description: NHEJ is a primary DNA repair mechanism for double-strand breaks, especially important in postmitotic cells such as neurons. The theory posits that enhanced NHEJ efficiency evolved in species with greater encephalization to maintain genomic integrity in the brain.

The relative expansion of brain size compared to body mass, a distinctive trait in primates. The theory suggests that increased brain size imposed selective pressure for improved DNA repair mechanisms to protect long-lived, non-dividing neural cells.

key_concepts.concept: Correlation between DNA repair pathways and longevity/encephalization
key_concepts.description: The theory differentiates the roles of two DNA repair pathways: homologous recombination (HR) correlates better with longevity, while NHEJ correlates more strongly with encephalization, implying distinct evolutionary pressures on these pathways.

theories.mode: discuss, analyze existing data, propose evolutionary linkage
theories.evidence: Analysis of transcriptome data from 34 mammalian species showing correlations between gene expression of NHEJ components and encephalization, and HR gene expression with longevity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking DNA repair efficiency (NHEJ) with a fundamental organism-level trait (encephalization), explaining part of the aging process in the brain and its evolutionary context.

results.title: The emerging roles of tRNAs and tRNA-derived fragments during aging: Lessons from studies on model organisms.

theories.name: tRNA-associated regulation of aging and lifespan

key_concepts.description: tRNAs, traditionally known for their role in translation, are now recognized to have broader roles in physiological and pathological processes, including aging. Alterations in tRNA metabolism may influence cellular functions that contribute to lifespan regulation.
Chemical modifications on tRNAs (epitranscriptome) affect their stability and function, potentially impacting aging processes by modulating protein synthesis and cellular stress responses.
Fragments derived from tRNAs have emerged as novel regulatory molecules that may influence aging and lifespan by affecting gene expression, stress responses, or signaling pathways.

theories.evidence: Summary and synthesis of studies from model organisms including yeast, C. elegans, flies, and mice showing conserved longevity genes and emerging roles of tRNA-related processes in aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (tRNA metabolism and derived fragments) influencing aging at an organismal level, discusses causal roles in lifespan regulation, and is not limited to a single organ or disease.

results.title: Interspecific interactions and aging: Prediction of gerogenic bacteria and critical human protein targets of microbial infections.

theories.name: Gerogenic bacteria theory

key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that certain bacteria, termed 'gerogenic,' can induce aging processes in their human hosts by interacting with human proteins associated with aging and cellular senescence. These bacteria act as 'age-distorters' by molecularly hijacking host proteins, potentially accelerating biological aging.

The theory emphasizes that bacterial proteins can interact specifically with human aging-related proteins, disrupting normal cellular functions and promoting senescence. The use of bipartite networks to predict these interspecific protein interactions highlights a mechanistic basis for microbial influence on systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary convergence of microbial age-distorting proteins
key_concepts.description: An observed convergence where both bacterial and viral proteins target a common set of human aging-associated proteins, suggesting a shared evolutionary strategy among pathogens to influence host aging pathways.

theories.evidence: Predictions based on bipartite network analyses of protein interactions, supported by published experimental evidence and transcriptomic data; identification of specific bacterial genera (Salmonella, Escherichia, Shigella) with higher potential to interact with human aging proteins; references to common targeting of 14 human aging proteins by both bacteria and viruses.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism by which microbial infections may drive systemic aging through molecular interactions affecting cellular senescence. It addresses aging broadly at the organism level by implicating common pathogens in the aging process and suggests underlying mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Inverse Lansing Effect: Maternal Age and Provisioning Affecting Daughters' Longevity and Male Offspring Production.

theories.name: Lansing effect and inverse Lansing effect

key_concepts.concept: Maternal age effect on offspring longevity
key_concepts.description: The Lansing effect describes the phenomenon where offspring of older mothers typically have reduced life expectancy. This concept suggests that maternal age influences the aging and lifespan of the next generation.

An observed phenomenon where offspring of older mothers exhibit increased longevity, contrary to the traditional Lansing effect. This is hypothesized to result from age-specific maternal provisioning, such as lipid content, affecting offspring development and lifespan.

The amount and quality of lipids provided by mothers to embryos vary with maternal age and influence offspring life history traits, including longevity and reproductive traits. Lipid provisioning may create a caloric restriction-like environment during embryonic development, potentially extending offspring lifespan.

Higher mitochondrial membrane potential in neural tissues of offspring from older mothers may be linked to increased longevity, suggesting a physiological mechanism underlying the inverse Lansing effect.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from several Daphnia magna clones showing clone-specific maternal age effects on offspring longevity and male offspring production; lipid content measurements; mitochondrial membrane potential assays; a maternal age reversal treatment demonstrating intermediate lifespan and lipid content.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general aging-related phenomenon (maternal age effects on offspring aging), proposes causal mechanisms (maternal lipid provisioning affecting offspring lifespan), and discusses organism-level aging processes beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: Homeostasis and evolution in relation to regeneration and repair.

theories.name: Homeostasis and Homeodynamic Regulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Homeostasis as a fundamental physiological process
key_concepts.description: Homeostasis refers to self-regulating processes that maintain internal stability in response to external changes. It reduces internal entropy and is proposed as a driving force behind evolution, implying a fundamental role in organismal aging.

Mechanisms such as homeodynamics, allostasis, hormesis, and homeorhesis represent different stable stationary states that organisms can reach to maintain or restore equilibrium. These processes regulate tissue regeneration and repair, which are central to aging.

Regeneration involves restoring tissue structure and function through cell proliferation, differentiation, and death, controlled by hormesis. Repair leads to a new stable state with decreased functionality and fibrosis, reflecting aging-related decline.

The variation in regenerative and reparative capacities across species, tissues, and developmental stages—including aging—is shaped by evolutionary constraints that limit stem cell proliferation in unfavorable environments to prevent tumor development.

theories.evidence: The abstract references physiological concepts, evolutionary theory, and cellular mechanisms such as immune cell balance, redox state, and signaling pathways involved in regeneration and repair. It also mentions attempts to manipulate these processes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain aging as a fundamental organism-level process through homeostatic regulation and its failure or shift from regeneration to repair. It proposes causal mechanisms linking homeostasis, regeneration, repair, and evolutionary constraints to aging, thus meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Hallmarks of stem cell aging.

theories.name: Stem Cell Aging Hallmarks Theory

key_concepts.concept: Progressive functional decline of somatic stem cells
key_concepts.description: As organisms age, somatic stem cells gradually lose their capacity to maintain tissue homeostasis and support regeneration, which contributes to overall organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Intrinsic and extrinsic stressors affecting stem cells
key_concepts.description: Stem cells, although somewhat protected compared to differentiated cells, remain vulnerable to various internal and external stress factors that drive their aging and functional deterioration.

key_concepts.concept: Five cardinal features characterizing aged stem cells
key_concepts.description: The theory identifies five key hallmarks or features that define aged stem cells, which collectively explain their decline and impact on tissue aging.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of stem cell aging hallmarks
key_concepts.description: These hallmarks not only provide mechanistic insight into aging but also highlight potential intervention points to rejuvenate stem cell function and extend tissue health span.

theories.evidence: Synthesis of existing studies on stem cell compartments and their aging features; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging at the organismal level through stem cell functional decline, linking intrinsic/extrinsic mechanisms to systemic aging.

results.title: Adipose tissue senescence: Biological changes, hallmarks and therapeutic approaches.

theories.name: Adipose Tissue Senescence Theory

key_concepts.description: Adipose tissue cells undergo senescence characterized by permanent cell cycle arrest, contributing to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging effects.

Seven hallmarks are proposed as characteristic features of adipose tissue senescence: telomere attrition, epigenetic alterations, genomic instability, mitochondrial dysfunction, disabled macroautophagy, cellular senescence, and chronic inflammation. These interconnected processes drive aging-related changes in adipose tissue.

With aging, adipose tissue undergoes redistribution with visceral fat expansion and peripheral subcutaneous fat reduction, alongside impaired adipogenesis, reduced stem cell proliferation/differentiation, diminished thermogenic capacity, and immune dysregulation, which collectively contribute to systemic metabolic aging.

theories.evidence: The paper synthesizes existing knowledge and proposes seven hallmarks of adipose tissue senescence based on biological changes observed during aging; it discusses these hallmarks and their interconnections, referencing known cellular and molecular aging mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how adipose tissue senescence contributes to systemic aging, integrates multiple aging hallmarks, and addresses organism-level metabolic aging rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Hallmarks of cardiovascular ageing.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Cardiovascular Ageing Theory

key_concepts.description: A decline in the cellular process responsible for degrading and recycling cellular components, leading to accumulation of damaged organelles and proteins, which contributes to cardiovascular ageing.
The failure to maintain the proper folding, function, and turnover of proteins, resulting in protein aggregation and cellular dysfunction in cardiovascular tissues.
Accumulation of DNA damage and mutations, including clonal haematopoiesis of indeterminate potential, which impairs cardiovascular cell function and promotes ageing.
Changes in DNA methylation, histone modification, and chromatin remodeling that alter gene expression patterns contributing to cardiovascular ageing.
Decline in mitochondrial function leading to reduced energy production and increased reactive oxygen species, driving cardiovascular ageing.
The accumulation of senescent cells that secrete pro-inflammatory factors, impair tissue regeneration, and promote cardiovascular ageing.
Alterations in hormonal and nervous system signals that disrupt cardiovascular homeostasis and contribute to ageing-related decline.
Chronic low-grade inflammation that exacerbates tissue damage and dysfunction in the cardiovascular system during ageing.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews molecular hallmarks supported by existing literature and proposes a hierarchical order distinguishing primary from downstream hallmarks; therapeutic targeting is discussed but no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of cardiovascular ageing as a fundamental ageing process with broad organismal relevance; it integrates multiple mechanisms into a hierarchical model; it is not limited to a single disease or organ dysfunction but connects cardiovascular ageing to systemic ageing and healthspan.

results.title: Morphological Analysis of Aging Hallmarks in the Central Nervous System of the Fast-Aging African Turquoise Killifish.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Framework

key_concepts.description: Accumulation of DNA damage and mutations over time that impair cellular function and contribute to aging phenotypes.
Decline in mitochondrial function leads to increased production of reactive oxygen species, causing oxidative damage to cells and tissues.
Permanent cell cycle arrest of damaged or stressed cells that secrete pro-inflammatory factors, contributing to tissue dysfunction and aging.
Decline in the regenerative capacity of stem cells, leading to impaired tissue maintenance and repair during aging.
Changes in signaling between cells, including increased inflammation and disrupted homeostasis, which drive aging processes.

theories.mode: discuss, apply, and provide methodological approaches to investigate
theories.evidence: Immunohistochemical, molecular, and biochemical analyses of aging hallmarks in the killifish central nervous system tissues (retina, optic tectum, telencephalon).
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses fundamental, generalizable biological mechanisms underlying aging at the organismal level, proposes causal mechanisms, and is not limited to a single organ or disease.

results.title: Hallmarks of lens aging and cataractogenesis.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) and Oxidative Damage
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging results from the accumulation of damage caused by reactive oxygen species, which are byproducts of cellular metabolism. In the lens, a pro-oxidant shift due to impaired repair systems leads to cumulative damage to biomolecules, causing cellular dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Breakdown of Oxidative Stress Repair Systems
key_concepts.description: Aging involves a progressive failure of the cellular antioxidant defenses and repair mechanisms that normally maintain redox homeostasis. This breakdown results in increased oxidative stress and damage, contributing to aging phenotypes and pathologies such as cataracts.

theories.evidence: Overview of current understanding of lens ROS sources and antioxidative defenses; proposal of hallmarks based on literature synthesis; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (oxidative damage accumulation) underlying aging at the organismal level, here exemplified in lens aging but with broader applicability. It explains why aging occurs via failure of redox homeostasis.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence as a Driver of Aging

key_concepts.description: The accumulation of senescent cells contributes to aging by impairing tissue function and promoting inflammation. In the lens, senescence is identified as one of the hallmarks linking cellular aging to cataractogenesis.

theories.evidence: Mentioned as one of eight candidate hallmarks of lens aging and cataractogenesis, based on literature synthesis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as cellular senescence is a broadly recognized causal mechanism contributing to systemic aging, not limited to lens tissue.

theories.name: Loss of Proteostasis Theory

key_concepts.description: Aging involves the failure of protein homeostasis mechanisms, leading to accumulation of damaged or misfolded proteins. This contributes to cellular dysfunction and age-related diseases such as cataracts.

theories.evidence: Listed as one of the eight candidate hallmarks linking aging and cataractogenesis, based on current understanding.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as loss of proteostasis is a general aging mechanism implicated across tissues and organisms, explaining how aging occurs at a molecular and cellular level.

results.title: Lipids and the hallmarks of ageing: From pathology to interventions.

theories.name: Impaired lipid metabolism as a driver of aging

key_concepts.concept: Lipids as regulators of aging hallmarks
key_concepts.description: Lipids influence multiple fundamental aging processes including cellular senescence, chronic inflammation, gut dysbiosis, telomere attrition, genome instability, proteostasis, autophagy, epigenetic alterations, and stem cell dysfunction. Changes in lipid metabolism can modulate these hallmarks, thereby affecting organismal aging.

With aging, systemic lipid profiles alter in characteristic ways that correlate with the aging phenotype. These inherent deficiencies in lipid metabolism contribute causally to the progression of aging and age-related pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Dietary lipids as modulators of aging
key_concepts.description: The type and quantity of lipids consumed in the diet significantly influence lipid metabolism and its effects on aging. Dietary lipids can either exacerbate or ameliorate age-related changes, making them important modulators of the aging process.

theories.evidence: Comprehensive review of current literature linking lipid metabolism alterations to the hallmarks of aging; correlations between systemic lipid profile changes and aging phenotypes; discussion of dietary lipid impact on aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism by which impaired lipid metabolism drives fundamental aging processes across the organism. It addresses broad aging hallmarks rather than narrow phenomena and discusses underlying mechanisms.

results.title: The role of dietary strategies in the modulation of hallmarks of aging.

theories.name: Dietary restriction modulation of hallmarks of aging

key_concepts.concept: Dietary restriction as a modulator of aging mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Dietary restriction (DR), typically involving reduced caloric intake, is proposed to influence fundamental aging processes by modulating key hallmarks such as genomic instability, loss of proteostasis, deregulated nutrient sensing, cellular senescence, and altered intercellular communication. This suggests DR acts on core biological pathways that drive systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Hallmarks of aging as interconnected mechanisms
key_concepts.description: The hallmarks of aging represent a network of basic biological mechanisms that collectively contribute to the aging process. These include genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, loss of proteostasis, mitochondrial dysfunction, cellular senescence, and altered intercellular communication, among others. The theory posits these hallmarks are fundamental drivers of organismal aging.

Specific dietary patterns such as the Mediterranean diet, plant-based diets, and ketogenic diet may also modulate several hallmarks of aging, including genomic instability, epigenetic changes, mitochondrial function, and intercellular communication. This expands the concept of nutritional influence on aging beyond simple caloric reduction.

theories.evidence: Narrative review of studies in preclinical models and humans showing effects of dietary restriction and dietary patterns on hallmarks of aging; citations of experimental and observational data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses generalizable, organism-level aging mechanisms (hallmarks of aging) and proposes dietary strategies as causal modulators of these mechanisms, thus explaining how aging can be influenced. The hallmarks framework is a broadly accepted aging theory, and dietary modulation is discussed as a mechanism influencing these fundamental processes.

results.title: The impact of opioids on the hallmarks of ageing.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Ageing Framework

key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction refers to the decline in mitochondrial performance and efficiency, leading to impaired energy production and increased reactive oxygen species, which contribute to cellular damage and aging.
Genomic instability involves the accumulation of DNA damage and mutations over time, undermining cellular function and promoting aging and age-related diseases.
Telomere shortening is the progressive loss of protective DNA sequences at chromosome ends during cell division, which limits cellular replicative capacity and contributes to aging.
Cellular senescence is a state of permanent cell cycle arrest triggered by damage or stress, which accumulates with age and contributes to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Loss of Proteostasis and Nutrient Sensing
key_concepts.description: Loss of proteostasis refers to the decline in protein homeostasis mechanisms, leading to protein aggregation and cellular dysfunction; nutrient sensing pathways regulate metabolism and aging, but their alteration by opioids remains less understood.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews recent advances and accumulating evidence linking opioid use to early onset of mitochondrial dysfunction, genomic instability, and telomere shortening, citing studies that associate chronic opioid use with these hallmarks. It notes limited data on other hallmarks like nutrient sensing and proteostasis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it discusses a general, organism-level framework explaining mechanisms underlying biological aging, proposing causal links between opioid exposure and acceleration of fundamental aging processes. The hallmarks framework is broadly applicable and mechanistic.

results.title: Effects of nanomaterial exposure on telomere dysfunction, hallmarks of mammalian and zebrafish cell senescence, and zebrafish mortality.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Telomeres shorten with each cell division, leading to telomere dysfunction that triggers cellular senescence. This shortening is considered a hallmark and causal mechanism of biological aging at the cellular and organismal level.
Markers such as senescence-associated β-galactosidase, p21, and p16 indicate the presence of senescent cells, which accumulate with age and contribute to aging phenotypes and functional decline.

Telomerase (TERT) and shelterin components (TRF1, TRF2, POT1) regulate telomere maintenance. Changes in their expression affect telomere stability and cellular senescence, linking molecular mechanisms to aging.

theories.evidence: Meta-analysis of 35 studies showing nanomaterial exposure leads to telomere shortening, altered telomerase activity, increased senescence biomarkers, and increased mortality in zebrafish models.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental biological aging mechanism (cellular senescence via telomere dysfunction), proposes causal mechanisms, and generalizes beyond specific diseases or organs to organismal aging.

results.title: Cytosolic DNA sensor IFI16 proteins: Potential molecular integrators of interactions among the aging hallmarks.

theories.name: IFI16-mediated integration of aging hallmarks theory

key_concepts.concept: Integration of aging hallmarks via IFI16 proteins
key_concepts.description: IFI16 proteins act as molecular integrators that link multiple aging hallmarks such as genomic instability, telomere attrition, epigenetic alterations, mitochondrial dysfunction, cellular senescence, and altered intercellular communications. This integration suggests a unifying mechanism coordinating these diverse aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Activation of cGAS-STING pathway and inflammaging
key_concepts.description: IFI16 proteins are essential for cytosolic DNA-induced activation of the cGAS-STING pathway, which leads to type I interferon (IFN-β) expression. This pathway is implicated in aging-related chronic inflammation, known as inflammaging, a key contributor to systemic aging.

Increased IFI16 protein levels enhance the cell growth inhibitory functions of tumor suppressors p53 and pRb, linking IFI16 to cellular senescence and growth arrest mechanisms that contribute to aging.

theories.evidence: Citations to studies indicating IFI16 involvement in cGAS-STING activation, interactions with p53 and pRb, and necessity for multiple aging hallmarks; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism linking multiple fundamental aging hallmarks at the molecular level, applicable broadly to organismal aging rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: The brain-body energy conservation model of aging.

theories.name: Brain-Body Energy Conservation (BEC) Model of Aging

key_concepts.description: As somatic cells accumulate molecular damage, they activate costly intracellular stress responses, leading to increased cellular energy expenditure and secretion of cytokines signaling hypermetabolism.

key_concepts.concept: Brain as mediator of organismal energy economy
key_concepts.description: The brain perceives increased energy demand from senescent cells and acts as a broker to manage the whole-body energy budget, which remains stable or decreases with age despite cellular hypermetabolism.

key_concepts.concept: Energy conservation responses by the brain
key_concepts.description: To cope with a shrinking energy budget, the brain suppresses low-priority physiological processes, resulting in fatigue, reduced physical activity, sensory decline, immune changes, and endocrine deficits, which manifest as aging phenotypes.

The model proposes energetic principles explaining how aging trajectories can be altered by stressors and geroscience interventions through their impact on energy allocation and brain-mediated responses.

theories.evidence: The abstract presents a conceptual framework integrating known phenomena such as cellular damage accumulation, cytokine secretion, brain energy management, and systemic aging phenotypes; specific experimental data are not detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a general, organism-level causal mechanism explaining why and how aging occurs via energy metabolism and brain-mediated energy allocation; it is not limited to a single organ or disease and offers an organizing principle for aging.

results.title: Telomeres as hallmarks of iPSC aging: A review on telomere dynamics during stemness and cellular reprogramming.

theories.name: Telomere Shortening Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening as a cause of aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres, the protective ends of chromosomes, progressively shorten with cell division, leading to cellular senescence or dysfunction, which contributes to organismal aging and age-related disorders.

key_concepts.concept: Telomerase activity in tissue regeneration and aging
key_concepts.description: Telomerase enzyme can extend telomeres, supporting stem cell self-renewal and pluripotency, which are essential for tissue repair and regeneration; insufficient telomerase activity leads to telomere shortening and aging, while excessive activity may promote transformation.

key_concepts.concept: Resetting telomere length during cellular reprogramming
key_concepts.description: During the generation of induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs), telomere length is reset through telomerase activation, enhancing regenerative potential; incomplete telomerase activation can cause genomic instability and impaired cell function.

theories.evidence: Review of recent bibliography linking telomere dynamics, stemness, and cellular reprogramming; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging at the organismal level (telomere shortening and telomerase activity), discusses underlying causes and mechanisms, and connects cellular processes to systemic aging and regeneration.

results.title: Wild capuchin monkeys as a model system for investigating the social and ecological determinants of ageing.
Mild hyperoxia shortens telomeres and inhibits proliferation of fibroblasts: a model for senescence?

theories.name: Oxidative stress-induced telomere shortening theory of cellular senescence

key_concepts.description: Exposure to mild hyperoxia (40% oxygen) increases oxidative stress in human fibroblasts, which accelerates the rate of telomere shortening per population doubling from about 90 bp to over 500 bp. This suggests oxidative damage as a key driver of telomere attrition.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length as a signal for cell cycle exit and senescence
key_concepts.description: Cell proliferation is irreversibly blocked when telomeres reach a critical cutoff length (~4 kb), indicating that telomere shortening provides a causal signal for the onset of cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of single-strand breaks in telomeres contributes to shortening
key_concepts.description: Single-strand breaks accumulate in telomeric DNA, especially under oxidative stress, potentially causing loss of distal single-stranded fragments during replication. This mechanism may be more important than incomplete replication in driving telomere shortening.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from culturing human WI-38 fibroblasts under normoxic and hyperoxic conditions; measurements of proliferation, morphology, lipofuscin accumulation, DNA content by flow cytometry, Southern blotting of telomere length, and S1 nuclease sensitivity assays.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (oxidative stress causing telomere shortening) explaining why cellular senescence occurs, which is a fundamental aging process at the cellular level. It links telomere dynamics to proliferation arrest, a key aging hallmark, and discusses mechanisms applicable beyond a single disease or organ.

results.title: Sesamin suppresses aging phenotypes in adult muscular and nervous systems and intestines in a Drosophila senescence-accelerated model.

theories.name: Oxidative damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging results from the accumulation of oxidative damage caused by reactive oxygen species, which impair cellular and tissue function over time.

key_concepts.concept: Damage to proteins, DNA, and cells
key_concepts.description: Oxidative stress leads to the buildup of damaged proteins and DNA lesions, contributing to functional decline in multiple tissues including muscle, brain, and intestine.

key_concepts.concept: Antioxidative defense and DNA repair mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Upregulation of antioxidative enzymes and DNA repair pathways can mitigate oxidative damage, thereby slowing aging phenotypes and extending lifespan.

theories.evidence: The paper presents experimental evidence from Drosophila senescence-accelerated models showing that sesamin feeding reduces ROS accumulation, decreases damaged protein buildup, protects dopaminergic neurons, suppresses DNA damage and intestinal stem cell hyperproliferation, and upregulates antioxidative and DNA repair genes, resulting in lifespan extension.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (oxidative damage accumulation) underlying general aging processes across multiple tissues, supported by intervention and mechanistic data in a model organism.

results.title: Extracellular matrix glycation epigenetically regulates brain aging and neurodegeneration in the in vitro aged neurovascular model.

theories.name: Extracellular Matrix Glycation-Induced Epigenetic Regulation of Brain Aging

key_concepts.description: AGEs accumulate in brain tissue with age and co-localize with pathological proteins such as amyloid β and tau, suggesting a role in brain aging and neurodegeneration.
AGE incorporation into the extracellular matrix leads to brain endothelial dysfunction and microglial activation, which promote neuroinflammation and neurodegeneration, key features of brain aging.

AGE effects on neurons are mediated through epigenetic mechanisms involving the histone-modifying enzyme KMT2A, linking extracellular matrix glycation to gene expression changes that drive brain aging.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of AGE and its receptor
key_concepts.description: Intervention targeting AGE and its receptor can attenuate neurovascular dysfunction, indicating a causal role of AGE in brain aging and suggesting potential anti-aging strategies.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from an in vitro neurovascular model incorporating AGE-anchored matrix, observations of endothelial dysfunction and microglial activation, epigenetic enzyme involvement, and alignment with aged and Alzheimer's disease mouse model findings.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking extracellular matrix glycation to brain aging and neurodegeneration through epigenetic regulation, addressing systemic brain aging rather than a narrow disease focus.

results.title: ER stress in cardiac aging, a current view on the D-galactose model.

theories.name: D-galactose-induced aging model

key_concepts.description: Chronic exposure to D-galactose induces oxidative stress, which mimics the accumulation of reactive oxygen species and related damage observed in natural aging.
D-galactose treatment leads to impaired mitochondrial function, a hallmark of aging cells, contributing to decreased energy production and increased cellular damage.
The model shows increased levels of AGEs, which are proteins or lipids that become glycated after exposure to sugars, contributing to tissue stiffness and dysfunction during aging.
D-galactose induces inflammatory responses and SASP, a pro-inflammatory phenotype of senescent cells that contributes to aging-related tissue dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress and unfolded protein response (UPR)
key_concepts.description: The review highlights the less understood role of ER stress and UPR in the D-galactose model, suggesting these pathways affect cardiac aging by disrupting protein homeostasis.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews current literature on cellular and molecular mechanisms in the D-galactose model, including oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, AGEs, inflammation, SASP, and ER stress/UPR, with a focus on cardiac aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The D-galactose model is a widely used experimental paradigm that attempts to replicate fundamental aging processes at the cellular level, including oxidative damage, inflammation, and senescence, which are generalizable mechanisms underlying organismal aging. It proposes causal mechanisms (oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, ER stress) that contribute to aging phenotypes, thus meeting the criteria for an aging theory-related model.

results.title: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: A Metabolic Model of Accelerated Aging - Multi-Organ Mechanisms and Intervention Approaches.

theories.name: Metabolism-Inflammation-Aging Network in Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus

key_concepts.description: Chronic high blood sugar and insulin resistance in T2DM cause oxidative stress, which damages mitochondria. Dysfunctional mitochondria then contribute to downstream aging processes such as epigenetic changes, telomere shortening, and cellular senescence.

Four axes are proposed to explain accelerated aging in T2DM: glucose toxicity, toxicity of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs), immunoinflammatory aging, and protein amyloidosis. These axes represent distinct but interconnected pathways by which diabetes accelerates systemic aging.

The four diabetes-specific aging axes are integrated into a broader network linking metabolic dysfunction, chronic inflammation, and aging mechanisms. This network provides a systemic framework for understanding how T2DM accelerates organismal aging.

theories.mode: review, synthesize, propose (integration of diabetes-specific aging axes into a general metabolism-inflammation-aging network), provide new insights into interventions
theories.evidence: Synthesis of epidemiological and clinical research findings across multiple organs; discussion of molecular mechanisms such as oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, epigenetic regulation, telomere shortening, and cellular senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for accelerated aging in T2DM, connecting metabolic and inflammatory mechanisms to systemic aging processes. It addresses aging broadly through multiple organs and mechanisms, not limited to a single tissue or disease narrowly. The theory integrates known aging mechanisms (oxidative stress, senescence) into a diabetes-specific context but with general aging implications.

results.title: Regulatory Mechanisms of Aging Through the Nutritional and Metabolic Control of Amino Acid Signaling in Model Organisms.

theories.name: Nutrient Signaling Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Dietary restriction without malnutrition has been shown to extend lifespan across multiple model organisms, suggesting a conserved mechanism linking nutrient availability to aging processes.
Mutations in the insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathway influence aging and longevity, indicating that nutrient sensing and metabolic signaling pathways regulate lifespan.
Specific amino acids act as signals that modulate metabolic pathways affecting aging, with their sensing, transduction, and metabolism playing critical roles in lifespan regulation.
Factors such as life stage, sex, and genetic background influence how nutritional and metabolic signaling pathways affect aging, highlighting the complexity of nutrient-aging interactions.

theories.evidence: Citations and summaries of genetic and nutritional studies in model organisms ranging from yeast to mammals, focusing on dietary restriction, insulin signaling mutations, and amino acid metabolism.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging through nutrient and metabolic signaling pathways affecting organismal aging broadly, supported by evolutionary and mechanistic insights.

results.title: Baicalein May Act as a Caloric Restriction Mimetic Candidate to Improve the Antioxidant Profile in a Natural Rodent Model of Aging.

theories.name: Caloric Restriction Mimetic (CRM) Theory

key_concepts.concept: Caloric Restriction (CR) as a lifespan extender
key_concepts.description: CR is recognized as the most effective intervention to extend lifespan across vertebrate and invertebrate models by inducing biochemical, hormonal, and physiological changes that slow aging.

CRMs are compounds, either synthetic or natural, that mimic the beneficial effects of CR without the need to reduce caloric intake, aiming to reproduce CR's antiaging benefits through similar molecular and cellular pathways.

Baicalein, a plant-derived polyphenol with antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and autophagy-inducing properties, is proposed to mimic CR effects by improving antioxidant profiles, modulating membrane transporters, and reducing eryptosis, thereby maintaining redox homeostasis during aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from supplementation of Baicalein in male Wistar rats showing alleviation of pro-oxidant markers, improvement in antioxidant profiles, correction of age-induced alterations in erythrocyte membrane transporters, and reduction in eryptosis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable mechanism (CR mimetics) explaining how aging can be modulated systemically via biochemical pathways; it provides causal explanations linking oxidative stress and redox homeostasis to aging; and it addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

results.title: In vivo anti-aging effects of naringin, a bioflavonoid: insights from the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae as a model organism.

theories.name: Nutrient sensing TORC1 signaling pathway modulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: TORC1 signaling pathway as a regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: The TORC1 (Target of Rapamycin Complex 1) pathway senses nutrient availability and regulates cellular growth and metabolism. Modulation of TORC1 activity influences lifespan by affecting processes such as autophagy, stress resistance, and metabolic adaptation, thereby playing a causal role in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Antioxidant and stress mitigation as anti-aging mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Oxidative and apoptotic stress contribute to cellular aging. Agents that reduce oxidative damage and apoptosis can enhance cell viability and lifespan, suggesting that managing cellular stress is a key mechanism in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic regulation of aging via SIR2 and ATG1
key_concepts.description: Genes such as SIR2 (a sirtuin involved in chromatin silencing and longevity) and ATG1 (a key autophagy regulator) are implicated in aging processes. Their expression levels influence lifespan, linking genetic regulation and nutrient signaling pathways to aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from yeast chronological lifespan assays showing increased viability with naringin treatment; gene expression analysis indicating altered TORC1 pathway and anti-aging gene expression; mutant yeast strains lacking antioxidant enzymes or signaling genes showing differential responses; metabolomic profiling revealing changes in metabolites related to aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism involving nutrient sensing and stress pathways that regulate organismal aging; uses yeast as a model but aims to explain fundamental aging processes; addresses broad aging mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Optimal Cut-Off Point for Self-Rated Successful Aging Based on the Rowe and Kahn's Model.

theories.name: Rowe and Kahn's Successful Aging Model

key_concepts.description: The model defines successful aging based on multiple criteria including low probability of disease and disability, high cognitive and physical functional capacity, and active engagement with life. It conceptualizes aging success as a multidimensional construct beyond mere absence of disease.

SRSA is a subjective evaluation by individuals of their own aging success, which the study attempts to quantify and validate against Rowe and Kahn's objective criteria. The model links subjective perceptions with objective measures to better understand aging outcomes.

theories.evidence: The study uses a sample of 478 older adults assessed via SRSA and scales measuring Rowe and Kahn's criteria, applying receiver-operating characteristic analysis to identify optimal SRSA cut-off points for discriminating successful aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal framework explaining why some individuals age successfully, addressing aging broadly at the organism level with underlying organizing principles.

results.title: Dietary stress remodels the genetic architecture of lifespan variation in outbred Drosophila.

theories.name: Evolutionary mismatch hypothesis in lifespan genetics

key_concepts.description: Despite evolutionary theory predicting purging of alleles that reduce lifespan, such alleles persist in populations, suggesting additional factors influence their maintenance.
Alleles regulating lifespan may have effects that depend on environmental context, such as diet, leading to variable impacts on lifespan under different conditions.

key_concepts.concept: Recently derived alleles with environment-dependent effects
key_concepts.description: Lifespan-reducing alleles are often recently evolved, have stronger negative effects under high-sugar diets, and show signs of selection, consistent with a mismatch between current environments and evolutionary history.

theories.evidence: Genome-wide association data from over 10,000 outbred Drosophila exposed to control and high-sugar diets, tracking allele frequency changes over lifespan; identification of thousands of lifespan-associated alleles with environment-dependent effects; signatures of selection in wild populations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general evolutionary mechanism explaining why lifespan-reducing alleles persist, addressing causal explanations via genotype-environment interactions and evolutionary mismatch, applicable broadly to organismal aging.

results.title: A gerophysiology perspective on healthy ageing.

theories.name: Gerophysiology perspective on aging as accumulation of scarring

key_concepts.description: Aging is viewed through the lens of homeostasis (robustness) and allostasis (fragility), where optimal organ structure and function maintain homeostasis, but repeated repair processes lead to allostasis and frailty.

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of scar healing as a driver of biological aging
key_concepts.description: Successive repair after daily injuries and infections causes accumulation of scarring, which leads to progressive tissue degeneration and systemic aging at the whole organism level.

key_concepts.concept: SIM triptych (mesenchymal stroma cells, immunity, metabolism) as central regulators
key_concepts.description: The interplay of mesenchymal stroma cells, immune system, and metabolism drives tissue and organ fate, regulating age-related functional decline and providing a mechanistic basis for the gerophysiology perspective.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review proposing a conceptual framework integrating existing knowledge from geroscience and biomolecular hallmarks of aging; no new experimental data presented but references to established concepts in repair, immunity, and metabolism.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general, organism-level causal mechanism explaining aging as accumulation of scarring affecting homeostasis, integrates molecular and physiological processes, and aims to explain systemic aging rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Support for Y-compensation of mother's curse affecting lifespan in Drosophila melanogaster.

theories.name: Mother's Curse and Y-Chromosome Compensation Theory

key_concepts.description: This concept refers to the accumulation of male-biased deleterious mutations on mitochondria due to their strict maternal inheritance, which can negatively impact male fitness and lifespan.

The hypothesis that males may compensate for the deleterious mitochondrial mutations through mutations on the Y-chromosome, which is strictly paternally inherited, potentially mitigating the negative effects on male lifespan.

The idea that Y-chromosome compensation may require coevolved autosomal backgrounds to effectively ameliorate mitochondrial mutations, suggesting a complex genetic interaction rather than direct Y-mitochondria compensation alone.

theories.evidence: Experimental comparison of lifespan among males with coevolved and non-coevolved Y-mitochondria pairs placed alongside coevolved or non-coevolved autosomal backgrounds in three disparate Drosophila melanogaster populations, showing lower mortality risk in coevolved pairs only when autosomes were coevolved.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining male lifespan variation through genetic interactions involving mitochondrial mutations and Y-chromosome compensation, addressing fundamental aging processes at the organism level.

results.title: Accuracy of tRNA charging and codon: anticodon recognition; relative importance for cellular stability.

theories.name: Translation fidelity and cellular stability theory

key_concepts.concept: Accurate tRNA charging by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the accuracy of aminoacylation of tRNAs by synthetases is critical for maintaining cellular homeostasis and long-term cellular stability. Errors in this step can lead to accumulation of faulty proteins, which may cause progressive cellular deterioration.

This concept involves the fidelity of ribosomal decoding of mRNA codons by tRNA anticodons. Although errors here occur, the processive nature of ribosomes limits error propagation because error-prone ribosomes mainly produce inactive proteins that do not exacerbate translation errors.

key_concepts.concept: Processivity of ribosomes and error propagation
key_concepts.description: The model incorporates the processive character of ribosomes, suggesting that ribosomal errors are less detrimental to cellular stability compared to tRNA charging errors, as they do not significantly propagate errors within the translation machinery.

theories.evidence: The paper develops a new computational/modeling framework describing subreactions of translation, comparing the relative impact of tRNA charging versus codon:anticodon recognition on cellular stability. It builds on and extends previous models.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental cellular process (protein synthesis fidelity) as a causal mechanism underlying cellular stability and progressive deterioration, which relates to aging at the cellular level. It proposes mechanisms (translation fidelity steps) that could causally influence aging processes, thus meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: Blocking PD-L1-PD-1 improves senescence surveillance and ageing phenotypes.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate with age in tissues and contribute causally to age-related inflammation and diseases. Their presence is a hallmark of aging and is implicated as a driver of systemic aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Immune surveillance and clearance of senescent cells
key_concepts.description: The immune system, particularly T cells, surveils and eliminates senescent cells to maintain tissue homeostasis. Failure or evasion of this clearance leads to senescent cell accumulation and exacerbates aging.

key_concepts.concept: PD-L1 mediated immune evasion by senescent cells
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells heterogeneously express PD-L1, an immune checkpoint protein that inhibits T cell-mediated clearance. PD-L1+ senescent cells resist immune surveillance, promoting their accumulation and driving age-associated inflammation.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of immune checkpoints to reduce senescent cells
key_concepts.description: Blocking the PD-1/PD-L1 pathway enhances immune clearance of senescent cells, reducing their burden and ameliorating aging phenotypes. This suggests immune checkpoint blockade as a potential anti-aging intervention.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from naturally aging mice and disease models showing PD-L1+ senescent cell accumulation; single-cell analysis correlating PD-L1 with SASP; treatment with PD-1 antibody reducing senescent cell numbers and improving aging phenotypes in vivo in a CD8+ T cell-dependent manner.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism for aging at the organismal level via senescent cell accumulation and immune evasion; explains why senescent cells accumulate with age; connects molecular mechanisms (PD-L1 expression) to systemic aging and inflammation; supported by experimental intervention data.

results.title: Phenoptosis and the Various Types of Natural Selection.

theories.name: Phenoptosis as an evolutionary aging mechanism

key_concepts.description: Phenoptosis refers to genetically programmed death of an individual organism, where the organism sacrifices its own life based on genetic mechanisms. This concept challenges the classical view of natural selection focused solely on individual survival and reproduction.

The theory expands natural selection beyond the individual level to include kin selection, group selection, gene-level selection, and interactions within holobionts and ecosystems. These levels of selection can favor traits that promote cooperation or sacrifice at the individual level for the benefit of the group or species.
