key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary basis of aging and death
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that aging and death can be understood as adaptive traits shaped by natural selection acting at multiple levels, including programmed death (phenoptosis) that benefits kin or the group, rather than solely as byproducts of individual-level selection.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known phenomena of genetically determined individual sacrifice and various forms of natural selection documented in evolutionary biology literature, but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging and death as evolutionary adaptations (phenoptosis) shaped by multilevel natural selection, addressing aging as a fundamental biological process beyond individual survival.

results.title: Changing ROS, NAD and AMP: A path to longevity via mitochondrial therapeutics.

theories.name: Mitochondrial ROS and Metabolite Modulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Mitochondria generate reactive oxygen species (ROS), which act as metabolites influencing lifespan and function as a kind of biological clock, linking mitochondrial function to aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: NAD+ and AMP as metabolic signaling molecules
key_concepts.description: Oxidized nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and adenosine monophosphate (AMP) are key metabolic intermediates that regulate signaling pathways involved in gene silencing, nutrient allocation, cell regeneration, and programmed cell death, thereby influencing aging.

Targeting mitochondria with specific drugs or enzymes to modulate levels of ROS, NAD+, and AMP can influence aging and lifespan, suggesting a causal mechanism linking mitochondrial metabolism to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: References to known substances like metformin affecting NAD+ and AMP levels, mitochondrially targeted ubiquinone derivatives interacting with ROS, and allotopic expression of enzymes influencing mitochondrial metabolites; discussion of these as innovative approaches to lifespan extension.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging based on mitochondrial metabolism and signaling molecules affecting systemic aging processes; not limited to specific diseases or organs but addresses fundamental aging mechanisms.

results.title: SkQ1 as a Tool for Controlling Accelerated Senescence Program: Experiments with OXYS Rats.

theories.name: Phenoptosis (Programmed Death) Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is conceptualized as a special case of programmed death of the organism, termed phenoptosis, implying that aging is an active, genetically regulated process rather than a passive accumulation of damage.

Enhanced generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in mitochondria is proposed as a key mechanism triggering phenoptosis, linking mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress to the aging program.
Use of the mitochondrial-targeted antioxidant SkQ1 can inhibit phenoptosis by suppressing mitochondrial ROS production, thereby preventing or delaying aging and age-related diseases.
The model of OXYS rats demonstrates accelerated aging due to genetic predisposition, manifested as early onset of multiple age-related diseases, which can be mitigated by SkQ1 treatment.

key_concepts.concept: Restoration of mitochondrial structure and function
key_concepts.description: SkQ1's beneficial effects are linked to restoration of mitochondrial structural and functional parameters, impacting multiple signaling pathways involved in aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of numerous studies confirming SkQ1's ability to inhibit physiological aging; experimental results showing SkQ1 suppresses accelerated senescence manifestations in OXYS rats, including cataracts, retinopathy, osteoporosis, and Alzheimer's-like signs; association with mitochondrial dysfunction and signaling pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general, organism-level causal mechanism for aging (phenoptosis as programmed death), links mitochondrial ROS as a causal driver, and tests intervention (SkQ1) that modulates this mechanism. The theory is generalizable beyond specific diseases and addresses aging broadly.

results.title: The Immune System and Cellular Senescence: A Complex Interplay in Aging and Disease.

theories.name: Immunosenescence Theory

key_concepts.description: The immune system undergoes gradual deterioration with age, including thymic involution, T-cell dysfunction, B-cell aging, and reduced immune cell diversity.
A persistent low-grade inflammatory state driven by immune dysfunction and senescent cell secretions that contributes to age-related diseases.
Age-related changes in immune cell metabolism impair immune responses and contribute to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Summarizes established hallmarks of immunosenescence and their impact on aging and disease, supported by literature citations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it explains a fundamental aging process at the organism level with proposed mechanisms and systemic consequences.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cells enter a stable cell cycle arrest in response to stress or damage, which accumulates with age and contributes to tissue dysfunction and aging phenotypes.
Senescent cells interact with the immune system, influencing immune surveillance and clearance mechanisms, and their accumulation can exacerbate age-related immune decline.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews known features of cellular senescence and its interplay with immune cells, citing recent advances in understanding immune-senescent cell interactions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging at the organism level involving accumulation of senescent cells and their systemic effects.

results.title: Biological Clocks: Why We Need Them, Why We Cannot Trust Them, How They Might Be Improved.

theories.name: Phenoptosis via Epigenetic Changes Theory

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that late-life aging involves a programmed self-destruction process called phenoptosis, which is implemented through specific epigenetic changes. This suggests aging is not merely damage accumulation but involves an active, genetically encoded program.

There are two distinct types of epigenetic changes: type (1) changes that implement phenoptosis (programmed aging), and type (2) changes that occur in response to accumulated damage as a survival mechanism. These two types have opposite effects on lifespan when reversed.

Current epigenetic clocks do not distinguish between type (1) and type (2) changes, leading to misleading interpretations of biological age and intervention effects. The theory argues that separating these changes is necessary for reliable aging measurement.
While epigenetic changes mediate phenoptosis, they are not the primary biological clock. The actual timekeeping mechanism may be partially located in the hypothalamus, but remains to be discovered.

theories.evidence: Conceptual arguments based on epigenetic clock performance and lifespan effects; proposed new experiments to separate epigenetic change types; references to recent epigenetic clock research.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains why aging occurs via programmed phenoptosis (causal explanation), generalizable to organism-level aging, addresses broad aging mechanisms beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: [Mechanisms of aging and programmed death of erythrocytes].

theories.name: Eryptosis as a programmed cell death mechanism in erythrocytes

key_concepts.description: Eryptosis is a form of suicidal death in erythrocytes characterized by a regulated cascade of molecular events leading to cell clearance. It is analogous to apoptosis in nucleated cells but occurs in anucleate erythrocytes lacking nuclei and mitochondria.

Increased cytosolic Ca(2+) activity is the main trigger of eryptosis. Elevated Ca(2+) activates Ca(2+)-sensitive K(+) channels, scramblase, calpain, and other proteases, initiating the molecular cascade that results in erythrocyte death.

Eryptosis is tightly regulated by multiple molecular participants and signaling pathways, including the roles of ceramide and membrane blebbing, which contribute to the aging and clearance of erythrocytes.

key_concepts.concept: Erythrocytes as a model for aging
key_concepts.description: Because erythrocytes undergo programmed aging and death, they serve as a model to study aging mechanisms, potentially providing insights into the suicidal death of nucleated cells and broader aging processes.

theories.evidence: The abstract references molecular events, signaling pathways, and factors such as Ca(2+) and ceramide involved in eryptosis, citing recent findings and summarizing current knowledge; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory proposes a general mechanism explaining how erythrocytes undergo programmed aging and death, which is a fundamental biological aging process at the cellular level. It offers causal explanations involving signaling pathways and molecular triggers. Although focused on erythrocytes, the paper links this mechanism to general aging and programmed cell death, suggesting broader relevance. Thus, it meets the criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Systematic mapping of organism-scale gene-regulatory networks in aging using population asynchrony.
Does female resistance to mating select for live-fast-die-young strategies in males? A comparative analysis in the genus Drosophila.
More effective transposon regulation in fertile, long-lived termite queens than in sterile workers.

theories.name: Transposable Element Regulation as a Mechanism for Longevity and Genome Integrity

key_concepts.description: TEs are mobile genetic sequences that can cause genomic damage accumulation over an organism's lifetime, potentially contributing to aging by compromising genome integrity.
The piRNA pathway is a molecular mechanism that suppresses TE activity, particularly in the germ-line, to protect genome integrity and prevent mutation transmission to offspring.

key_concepts.concept: Caste- and Age-Specific TE Regulation in Eusocial Insects
key_concepts.description: In eusocial termites, reproductive castes (queens) exhibit stronger regulation of TEs via upregulated piRNA pathways compared to sterile workers, correlating with their extreme longevity and sustained reproductive output.

key_concepts.concept: Genome Integrity as a Driver of Longevity
key_concepts.description: Efficient TE regulation in termite queens' somatic tissue (fat body) likely preserves genome integrity, which supports their long lifespan and high reproductive fitness, suggesting a causal mechanism linking TE control to aging.

theories.evidence: Comparative transcriptomic analysis of TE expression and piRNA-pathway gene expression across termite castes and queen ages; observed higher TE activity in short-lived workers versus reproductives; stable TE expression with age in long-lived queens despite increased overall gene expression.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (TE regulation via piRNA pathway) influencing organismal aging and longevity, supported by comparative data in a model with distinct lifespan phenotypes; addresses aging broadly via genome integrity maintenance; not limited to a single disease or organ.

results.title: Lysosomes signal through the epigenome to regulate longevity across generations.

theories.name: Lysosome-epigenome signaling theory of transgenerational longevity

key_concepts.description: Lysosomes sense metabolic inputs and act as signaling centers that regulate longevity by modulating downstream epigenetic mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic regulation via histone H3.3 and H3K79 methylation
key_concepts.description: Activation of lysosomal lipid signaling and AMPK or reduction of lysosomal mTOR signaling increases expression of histone variant H3.3 and its methylation at lysine 79, which promotes lifespan extension.

Signals originating from lysosomes in somatic tissues influence the germline epigenome through intestine-to-germline transport of histone H3.3 and germline-specific methyltransferase activity, enabling longevity effects to be inherited across generations.

theories.evidence: Experimental data in Caenorhabditis elegans showing that manipulation of lysosomal signaling pathways affects histone modifications and lifespan across multiple generations; overexpression of H3.3 or H3K79 methyltransferase recapitulates longevity effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking metabolic sensing by lysosomes to epigenetic regulation of aging and longevity at the organismal level, including transgenerational effects; it explains how aging is regulated beyond single organs or diseases.

results.title: Multi-Omic Data Analysis Supporting the Plausibility of Human Aging Sperm-Mediated Epigenetic Inheritance.

theories.name: Epigenetic inheritance theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Sperm DNA methylation changes with age
key_concepts.description: As males age, their sperm exhibit differential DNA methylation patterns, which are changes in the chemical modifications of DNA that can regulate gene expression without altering the DNA sequence itself.

These age-related methylation changes in sperm are proposed to be transmitted to offspring, potentially influencing early embryonic gene expression and development, thereby affecting health and disease risk in subsequent generations.

key_concepts.concept: Reestablishment of methylation marks and developmental consequences
key_concepts.description: The inherited methylation marks may lead to reprogramming events in the embryo and primordial germ cells, causing developmental anomalies and the inheritance of disease phenotypes, linking paternal aging to offspring health outcomes.

theories.evidence: Analysis of publicly available human multi-omic data showing overlap of differentially methylated CpGs in aging sperm and aging/disease soma, enrichment of these CpGs in regulatory regions of developmental genes, and association with genes expressed during early embryonic development and primordial germ cell reprogramming.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how biological aging (paternal aging) can influence offspring aging and disease risk via epigenetic inheritance, addressing organism-level aging processes beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: Early menopause results from instead of causes premature general ageing.

theories.name: DNA damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: DNA repair gene involvement in aging
key_concepts.description: Genes involved in menopause overlap with those responsible for double-strand break repair and mismatch and base excision repair of DNA, indicating a mechanistic link between DNA repair capacity and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Cumulative DNA damage leads to cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: Accumulation of DNA damage over time causes cells to enter senescence, which exhausts somatic cell renewal capacity, leads to cellular dysfunction, and accelerates cell death, driving the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Germline genome erosion parallels somatic aging
key_concepts.description: Similar DNA damage accumulation occurs in germ cells within the ovaries, contributing to ovarian aging and dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Systemic survival response suppresses sex-steroid hormone output
key_concepts.description: As DNA damage accumulates with age, a systemic response reduces sex-steroid hormone production, which contributes to ovarian silencing and the onset of menopause.

key_concepts.concept: Menopause as a consequence, not cause, of systemic aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that menopause results from systemic aging processes driven by DNA damage accumulation rather than causing premature aging itself.

theories.evidence: References to recent genome-wide association studies linking menopause genes to DNA repair pathways; conceptual linkage of DNA damage accumulation to cellular senescence and systemic aging; logical inference connecting ovarian aging to systemic aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (DNA damage accumulation) explaining aging at the organismal level, links cellular senescence to systemic aging, and frames menopause as a manifestation of systemic aging rather than an isolated phenomenon.

results.title: Impact of coffee intake on human aging: Epidemiology and cellular mechanisms.

theories.name: Damage Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The accumulation of DNA damage and mutations over time contributes to the aging process by impairing cellular function and increasing the risk of age-related diseases.
Damage to proteins, lipids, and other macromolecules accumulates with age, leading to cellular dysfunction and systemic decline.
Aging involves disruptions in metabolic processes and protein homeostasis, which reduce the ability of cells to maintain function and respond to stress.

key_concepts.concept: Control of stress adaptation and inflammation
key_concepts.description: Effective regulation of cellular stress responses and inflammation is critical in modulating aging, with coffee components showing robust effects in these areas.

theories.evidence: Epidemiological data from over 50 studies showing reduced all-cause mortality with coffee consumption; studies in humans and human tissues demonstrating preservation of biological mechanisms related to aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses fundamental biological mechanisms underlying aging at the organism level, proposes causal mechanisms (damage accumulation and impaired stress responses), and links these to general aging rather than specific diseases alone.

results.title: Targeting aging mechanisms: pharmacological perspectives.

theories.name: Geroprotector Mechanism Classification Theory

key_concepts.description: This concept involves pharmacological agents that reduce oxidative damage, a form of molecular damage thought to accumulate with age and contribute to aging processes.
Maintaining protein homeostasis by regulating protein folding, degradation, and synthesis to prevent accumulation of damaged or misfolded proteins that impair cellular function during aging.
Interventions aimed at reducing DNA damage and maintaining genome integrity, which is critical as accumulated genomic instability is a hallmark and driver of aging.
Drugs that modify epigenetic marks to restore youthful gene expression patterns or counteract age-associated epigenetic drift, potentially influencing aging trajectories.
Pharmacological strategies to maintain mitochondrial health and bioenergetics, as mitochondrial dysfunction is a key contributor to systemic aging.
Targeting pathways such as mTOR, insulin/IGF-1 signaling, or others known to regulate lifespan and aging processes.
Compounds that selectively eliminate senescent cells or suppress their harmful secretions, addressing cellular senescence as a causal driver of aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews hundreds of compounds shown to extend lifespan in model organisms and classifies them by their mechanisms; clinical studies are noted as rare.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses multiple mechanisms that underlie aging and pharmacological interventions targeting them, thus addressing generalizable causal explanations of aging processes at the organism level.

results.title: Pathological mechanisms of kidney disease in ageing.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Accumulation of DNA damage and mutations over time leads to cellular dysfunction and contributes to the aging process at the organismal level.
Progressive shortening of telomeres with each cell division limits cellular replicative capacity, promoting senescence and aging.
Chronic, low-grade inflammation ('inflammaging') drives tissue damage and functional decline, playing a causal role in systemic aging.
Decline in autophagic processes impairs cellular quality control, leading to accumulation of damaged proteins and organelles, accelerating aging.
Age-related mitochondrial decline reduces energy production and increases reactive oxygen species, contributing to cellular and organismal aging.
These pathways regulate metabolism, stress resistance, and longevity; their dysregulation is implicated in aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Citations and synthesis of molecular mechanisms recognized as regulators of lifespan and kidney aging; discussion of their roles in systemic aging and kidney disease.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it addresses fundamental, generalizable mechanisms causally linked to aging across the organism, not limited to kidney but applied to systemic aging; proposes underlying causes and organizing principles of aging.

results.title: Hallmarks of ovarian aging.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Ovarian Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Accumulation of DNA damage and mutations in ovarian cells over time contributes to the decline in ovarian function and aging.
Progressive shortening of telomeres in ovarian cells leads to cellular senescence and reduced regenerative capacity, driving ovarian aging.
Changes in DNA methylation, histone modification, and chromatin remodeling affect gene expression patterns in ovarian cells, influencing aging processes.
Decline in the cellular process that removes damaged organelles and proteins results in accumulation of cellular damage, promoting ovarian aging.
Permanent cell cycle arrest of ovarian cells contributes to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging effects.
Alterations in pathways that sense and respond to nutrient availability (e.g., mTOR, AMPK) disrupt metabolic homeostasis in ovarian cells.
Decline in mitochondrial function leads to reduced energy production and increased reactive oxygen species, accelerating ovarian aging.
Excessive reactive oxygen species cause damage to DNA, proteins, and lipids in ovarian cells, contributing to aging.
Persistent low-grade inflammation in ovarian tissue exacerbates cellular damage and functional decline.

theories.evidence: Synthesis of existing literature identifying nine common features (hallmarks) of ovarian aging; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal framework explaining ovarian aging mechanisms that are linked to systemic aging processes; addresses fundamental biological aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: How calorie restriction slows aging: an epigenetic perspective.

theories.name: Epigenetic alteration theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is influenced by genomic instability and alterations in epigenetic markers such as DNA methylation and heterochromatin structure. These changes lead to abnormal gene expression and contribute to aging-related diseases and cellular dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Role of heterochromatin loss and DNA methylation decline
key_concepts.description: Age-related loss of heterochromatin and decreased global DNA methylation disrupt chromatin organization, which impairs genomic integrity and cellular identity, accelerating the aging process.

Caloric restriction acts as a key effector that promotes longevity by modulating epigenetic modifications and maintaining chromatin-based barriers, thereby preserving genomic stability and cellular identity.

theories.evidence: Citations of numerous studies across species (rodents to primates) demonstrating caloric restriction's effects on longevity and epigenetic modifications; discussion of molecular mechanisms linking caloric restriction to chromatin and genomic stability.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how epigenetic changes drive aging at the organismal level and how caloric restriction modulates these processes to slow aging.

results.title: LINE-1 transposable element renaissance in aging and age-related diseases.

theories.name: LINE-1 transposable element involvement in aging theory

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the reactivation or 'resurrection' of LINE-1 transposable elements occurs during aging and age-related diseases, which may contribute to the aging process at a systemic level.
LINE-1 activity is implicated in causing genomic instability, a hallmark of aging, by disrupting genome integrity through insertional mutagenesis and DNA damage.

Loss of heterochromatin and changes in DNA methylation patterns associated with aging may be driven or exacerbated by LINE-1 activity, contributing to altered gene expression and cellular dysfunction.
LINE-1 elements may influence or promote the SASP, a pro-inflammatory state of senescent cells that drives systemic aging and age-related pathologies.

theories.evidence: Citations of numerous studies verifying LINE-1 resurrection in aging, cancer, and age-related diseases; functional insights into mechanisms underlying LINE-1 activity; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (LINE-1 activity) underlying fundamental aging processes such as genomic instability, epigenetic changes, and cellular senescence, applicable broadly beyond specific diseases.

results.title: Aging and Susceptibility to Pulmonary Disease.

theories.name: Damage Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging results from random molecular damage that is unrepaired and accumulates over time, leading to cellular defects and tissue dysfunction.

The aging process is advanced by the failure of cellular processes such as stem cell exhaustion, genomic instability, telomere attrition, epigenetic alterations, loss of proteostasis, deregulated nutrient sensing, mitochondrial dysfunction, cellular senescence, altered intercellular communication, and extracellular matrix changes.

theories.evidence: The abstract cites known cellular mechanisms and their breakdown as contributors to aging, referencing established hallmarks of aging and linking them to pulmonary aging and disease.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal explanation for aging based on damage accumulation and cellular mechanism failure, applicable broadly beyond pulmonary system, addressing fundamental aging processes.

theories.name: Immunosenescence and Inflammaging Theory

key_concepts.description: Age-related changes in the innate and adaptive immune systems lead to dysregulation and decreased immune effectiveness.
A chronic, low-level inflammatory state driven by immunosenescence that contributes to aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The abstract references the decline in immune function and the presence of chronic inflammation with age, linking these to pulmonary aging and disease susceptibility.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a mechanistic explanation for systemic aging effects via immune system decline and chronic inflammation, applicable broadly to organismal aging.

results.title: The impact of carnosine on biological ageing - A geroscience approach.

theories.name: Geroscience framework of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by a gradual decline in physiological function and resilience, involving molecular, cellular, and systemic changes across multiple organ systems.
Key biological processes such as genomic instability, inflammation, and telomere attrition contribute causally to aging and age-related diseases like cardiovascular disease and neurodegeneration.
Identifying and targeting aging pathways with geroprotectors (e.g., resveratrol, metformin) can extend healthspan by mitigating fundamental aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Summary of existing literature on hallmarks of aging and geroprotectors; citations implied though not detailed in abstract
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes generalizable, causal mechanisms underlying aging at organismal level and discusses interventions targeting these mechanisms.

theories.name: Carnosine as a geroprotector theory

key_concepts.description: Carnosine acts as an antioxidant, reducing oxidative stress which is a key driver of molecular damage in aging.
Carnosine reduces inflammation and prevents protein glycation, processes implicated in aging and age-related functional decline.

key_concepts.concept: Functional benefits on muscle and cognition
key_concepts.description: Carnosine supplementation improves muscle function, exercise performance, and cognitive health, suggesting systemic benefits relevant to healthy aging.

theories.evidence: Summarizes evidence from studies showing carnosine’s effects on physiological functions and oxidative stress-related pathologies; specific studies not detailed in abstract
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it discusses a compound targeting general aging mechanisms (oxidative stress, inflammation) with systemic effects, though it is more focused on intervention than proposing a new aging theory.

results.title: Hematopoietic loss of Y chromosome activates immune checkpoints and contributes to impaired senescent cell clearance and renal disease.

theories.name: Cellular senescence clearance impairment theory

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cell accumulation as a driver of aging-related pathology
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the buildup of senescent cells contributes causally to morbidity and mortality associated with aging by promoting tissue dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Hematopoietic loss of Y chromosome (LOY) impairs immune-mediated clearance of senescent cells
key_concepts.description: LOY in blood cells leads to upregulation of immune checkpoint proteins that inhibit immune clearance mechanisms, resulting in accumulation of senescent cells.

key_concepts.concept: Impaired senescent cell clearance exacerbates age-related kidney disease
key_concepts.description: The failure to clear senescent cells due to LOY-induced immune checkpoint activation contributes to renal dysfunction and pathology in aging and injury contexts.

theories.evidence: Prospective cohort study linking LOY in blood with increased kidney disease incidence; transcriptional analyses showing immune cell LOY enrichment and senescence in human kidneys; mouse models with LOY bone marrow exhibiting renal dysfunction and senescent cell accumulation; senolytic treatment reducing renal dysfunction; immune checkpoint blockade rescuing pathology.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism linking a common somatic mutation (LOY) to impaired immune clearance of senescent cells, thereby explaining a fundamental aging process (senescent cell accumulation) with systemic consequences (renal aging/disease). It addresses general aging mechanisms beyond a single organ by implicating hematopoietic immune function in senescence regulation.

results.title: Systems modelling predicts chronic inflammation and genomic instability prevent effective mitochondrial regulation during biological ageing.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging mediated by impaired AMPK-NAD+-PGC1α-SIRT1 signaling

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial turnover regulation via AMPK-NAD+-PGC1α-SIRT1 pathway
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial quality control and turnover are regulated through a signaling pathway involving AMPK, NAD+, PGC1α, and SIRT1, which responds to cellular stress to maintain mitochondrial function.

key_concepts.concept: Impact of genomic instability and chronic inflammation on NAD+ degradation
key_concepts.description: Genomic instability and chronic inflammation increase NAD+ degradation through enzymes PARP1 and CD38, respectively, reducing NAD+ availability and impairing the signaling pathway.

key_concepts.concept: Age-related decline in pathway responsiveness leading to mitochondrial dysfunction
key_concepts.description: With aging, the AMPK-NAD+-PGC1α-SIRT1 pathway becomes less responsive, which primes cells for accumulation of dysfunctional mitochondria, contributing to biological aging.

theories.evidence: Computational modeling calibrated and validated against experimental data; simulation studies of mitochondrial turnover under stress and aging conditions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging impairs mitochondrial regulation via a key signaling pathway affected by genomic instability and inflammation, thus linking molecular damage to systemic aging.

results.title: Genetic mechanisms of aging in plants: What can we learn from them?

theories.name: Programmed aging via meristematic activity and phytohormones

key_concepts.description: The continuous activity of meristems and their maintenance is proposed as a mechanism to extend lifespan.
Phytohormones regulate growth and developmental processes, and their continuous activity may modulate aging and longevity in plants.
Duplication of genes provides redundancy that may protect against deleterious mutations, contributing to longevity.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses these mechanisms as adaptive strategies plants use to increase lifespan, based on literature.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes organism-level mechanisms that regulate aging and longevity.

theories.name: Genomic instability and telomere depletion theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The shortening or loss of telomeres, protective caps at the ends of chromosomes, contributes to cellular aging by limiting cell division and genomic stability.
Accumulation of DNA damage and chromosomal abnormalities over time leads to loss of cellular function and organismal aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews published data on telomere depletion and genomic instability as factors in plant aging, drawing parallels to animal aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes underlying causal mechanisms (telomere shortening, genomic instability) that contribute broadly to aging processes beyond specific organs or diseases.

theories.name: Loss of proteostasis theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The decline in the ability to maintain protein folding, repair, and degradation leads to accumulation of damaged or misfolded proteins, contributing to cellular dysfunction and aging.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses loss of proteostasis as one of the factors causing plant aging, referencing existing studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental mechanism of aging applicable at the organism level.

theories.name: Epigenetic changes theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Changes in DNA methylation, histone modification, and chromatin remodeling alter gene expression patterns over time, driving aging processes.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews epigenetic changes as a factor influencing plant aging and longevity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria by proposing a general mechanism affecting aging at the organismal level.

results.title: Linker Histones Maintain Genome Stability and Drive the Process of Cellular Ageing.

theories.name: Chromatin organization and genome stability theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Chromatin structural organization as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the spatial organization of nuclear DNA into chromatin is fundamental for regulating gene activity, and changes in chromatin structure during aging lead to cellular deterioration. Chromatin acts as the interface where genetic information and environmental factors interact, influencing the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Role of linker histones in higher-order chromatin organization
key_concepts.description: Linker histones are proposed to have a unique and critical role in maintaining higher-order chromatin structure, which is essential for genome stability. Their function extends beyond traditional architectural roles to actively influence cellular aging and genome integrity.

key_concepts.concept: Genomic instability as a causal link between aging and cancer
key_concepts.description: Disruption in genome regulation and increased genomic instability are seen as central mechanisms connecting aging and cancer development. The loss of chromatin organization, partly mediated by changes in linker histones, contributes to this instability and drives the aging process.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses recent data and emerging evidence highlighting the role of linker histones in chromatin organization and genome stability, linking these to cellular aging and cancer. It references known hallmarks of cellular aging and molecular-level changes but does not present new experimental data in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (chromatin and genome stability) underlying aging at the cellular and organismal level, provides a causal explanation (disruption of chromatin structure and genomic instability), and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a single disease or organ.

results.title: Stem Cell Therapies and Ageing: Unlocking the Potential of Regenerative Medicine.

theories.name: Damage Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by the gradual accumulation of damage to macromolecules such as DNA, proteins, and lipids, which impairs cellular function and contributes to organismal decline.
Instability in the genome, including mutations and chromosomal aberrations, increases with age and undermines cellular integrity and function, promoting aging phenotypes.
Age-related changes include the loss of heterochromatin structure, which affects gene regulation and genome stability, further driving the aging process.
The cumulative damage and genomic instability lead to stem cell exhaustion or fatigue, reducing their regenerative capacity and contributing to tissue degeneration.

theories.evidence: Citations from Campisi et al. (Nature 571:183-192, 2019) describing molecular hallmarks of aging; conceptual linkage to stem cell exhaustion and regenerative decline.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organismal level through damage accumulation and its impact on stem cells, connecting molecular damage to systemic aging.

theories.name: Stem Cell Exhaustion Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging involves a reduction in the number and functional capacity of stem cells, which impairs tissue maintenance and repair.
The diminished ability of stem cells to proliferate and differentiate leads to decreased tissue regeneration and contributes to age-related functional decline.
Stem cell therapies aim to reverse stem cell fatigue by rejuvenating these cells, restoring their proliferative and differentiation potential to counteract aging effects.

theories.evidence: Discussion of stem cell therapies as interventions to mitigate aging-related degeneration; conceptual framework linking stem cell function to systemic aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a causal explanation for aging based on stem cell dynamics, generalizable across tissues and organs, and linked to organismal aging.

results.title: What Can Biologic Aging Tell Us About the Effects of Mental Stress on Vascular Health.

theories.name: Vascular Aging as a Driver of Systemic Aging

key_concepts.description: Chronic inflammation contributes to the deterioration of vascular function and structure, promoting aging-related cardiovascular disease.
Accumulation of reactive oxygen species damages vascular cells and tissues, leading to impaired vascular health and aging.
Decline in mitochondrial function within vascular cells reduces energy production and increases cellular damage, accelerating vascular aging.
DNA damage and mutations accumulate in vascular cells, contributing to aging-related vascular pathology.
Changes in DNA methylation and other epigenetic marks affect gene expression in vascular cells, influencing aging processes.
Pathways that sense and respond to nutrient availability modulate vascular aging and may be targets for intervention.

theories.evidence: Summary of current understanding and literature on biological mechanisms of vascular aging including inflammation, oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, genomic instability, epigenetic changes, and nutrient signaling.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses vascular aging as a fundamental biological aging process with causal mechanisms that contribute to systemic aging and cardiovascular disease. It connects organ-specific aging (vascular) to general aging mechanisms and discusses underlying causes.

theories.name: Mental Stress as a Risk Factor Influencing Biological Aging Mechanisms

key_concepts.description: Mental stress triggers biological changes that negatively impact vascular health, potentially accelerating aging-related cardiovascular disease.
Mental stress and aging share common cellular and molecular pathways such as inflammation and oxidative stress that impair vascular function.
Indicators of biological aging affected by mental stress could be used to develop prognostic markers and therapeutic strategies.

theories.evidence: Review of literature linking mental stress to vascular aging mechanisms and cardiovascular disease risk.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it discusses mental stress as a factor influencing biological aging mechanisms, but mental stress itself is not a general aging theory; rather, it is a risk factor modulating aging processes.

results.title: Telomere Shortening and Fusions: A Link to Aneuploidy in Early Human Embryo Development.

theories.name: Telomere Shortening and Dysfunction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening as a marker and driver of cellular aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres, protective DNA-protein structures at chromosome ends, shorten with each cell division and with age, leading to genomic instability. This shortening is linked to decreased cellular function and increased risk of chromosomal abnormalities such as aneuploidy.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere dysfunction causing genomic instability and aneuploidy
key_concepts.description: Telomere shortening and fusion events can lead to chromosomal mis-segregation and aneuploidy, particularly in early embryonic development, which may contribute to developmental failure and age-related reproductive decline.

key_concepts.concept: Association of telomere length with reproductive aging and outcomes
key_concepts.description: Shorter telomeres in oocytes and related cells correlate with poor reproductive outcomes such as miscarriage, trisomy 21, ovarian insufficiency, and reduced success in assisted reproductive technologies, linking telomere dynamics to organism-level aging processes.

theories.evidence: Review of current literature showing correlations between telomere length in oocytes, embryos, and reproductive cells with aging and reproductive outcomes; associations with aneuploidy, DNA damage, and reactive oxygen species; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (telomere shortening and dysfunction) underlying aging-related decline in reproductive capacity and embryonic development, connecting cellular-level processes to organism-level aging phenomena.

results.title: Whole genome sequencing reveals telomere associated genomic differences between healthy and unhealthy aging in a Korean population.

theories.name: Genomic Instability and Telomere Attrition Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Genomic instability as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of DNA damage and impaired DNA repair mechanisms lead to genomic instability, which is a fundamental cause of aging. This instability results in cellular dysfunction and contributes to the aging phenotype.

Telomeres shorten with age, and their attrition limits cellular replicative capacity, promoting cellular senescence and organismal aging. The rate of telomere shortening is linked to health status during aging.
Oxidative stress causes molecular damage contributing to aging, while upregulation of antioxidant enzymes (such as SOD1 and SOD2) can mitigate this damage, promoting healthier aging.

theories.evidence: Whole genome sequencing comparing healthy and unhealthy agers, telomere length measurements (TelSeq and Computel), germline variant burden analysis, pathway enrichment for oxidative stress mutations, and functional validation using GTEx dataset.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains fundamental aging processes (genomic instability, telomere attrition) with causal mechanisms, supported by organism-level data, and connects molecular damage to systemic aging differences.

results.title: Alteration in the chromatin landscape during the DNA damage response: Continuous rotation of the gear driving cellular senescence and aging.

theories.name: DNA Damage Response-Induced Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: DDR is a complex biological mechanism involving signaling pathways that detect and process DNA lesions to maintain cellular homeostasis. Failure or perturbation in DDR leads to DNA repair failure and genomic instability.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular Senescence as a Consequence of Persistent DDR
key_concepts.description: Persistent activation of DDR causes irreversible cell cycle arrest known as cellular senescence, which accumulates with age and contributes to organismal aging.
Continuous DDR activation exerts pressure on chromatin dynamics, leading to altered chromatin structure and epigenetic dysregulation, which are closely linked to cellular senescence and aging.

Sustained DDR and heterochromatin changes promote SASP, a pro-inflammatory secretory phenotype that drives aging-related diseases and cancer development, linking cellular senescence to systemic aging pathology.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews diverse mechanisms and evidence from prior studies linking DDR to chromatin remodeling, cellular senescence, SASP, and aging-related pathologies; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how persistent DNA damage and DDR signaling drive cellular senescence and systemic aging processes via chromatin and epigenetic changes. It addresses aging broadly at the organismal level through cellular senescence and SASP.

results.title: DNA damage signals from somatic uterine tissue arrest oogenesis through activated DAF-16.
Oxidative stress, aging, antioxidant supplementation and their impact on human health: An overview.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress and Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Oxidative stress results from an imbalance between reactive oxygen species production and antioxidant defenses, leading to cellular damage. This damage contributes to cellular senescence and increased frailty, which are central to the aging process.
Accumulation of DNA damage and progressive shortening of telomeres impair cellular function and promote senescence, thereby contributing to organismal aging.
Decline in mitochondrial function leads to reduced energy production and increased generation of reactive oxygen species, exacerbating oxidative damage and metabolic dysregulation during aging.
Alterations in nutrient sensing mechanisms affect metabolic homeostasis and cellular maintenance, influencing aging and lifespan.

theories.evidence: The abstract references multiple well-known aging hallmarks and mechanisms supported by existing literature, including genomic instability, telomere shortening, epigenetic changes, and mitochondrial dysfunction. It also mentions dietary interventions like antioxidant intake and caloric restriction as modulators.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory attempts to explain why and how aging occurs at a general organismal level through oxidative stress and related cellular mechanisms; it proposes causal mechanisms; and it addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

theories.name: Nutritional Modulation of Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Dietary antioxidants as modulators of aging
key_concepts.description: Intake of antioxidants through diet can reduce oxidative damage, potentially slowing cellular senescence and age-related functional decline.
Reducing caloric intake without malnutrition influences nutrient sensing pathways and metabolic processes, which can delay aging and increase lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Mediterranean diet as a protective factor
key_concepts.description: The Mediterranean diet, rich in antioxidants and healthy nutrients, may modulate aging processes and reduce risk of age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The abstract cites dietary habits and nutritional approaches as potential modulators of aging, referencing known interventions like caloric restriction and antioxidant supplementation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria: while it discusses mechanisms that influence aging broadly, it is more focused on modulation and intervention rather than proposing a fundamental causal theory of aging itself. However, it is connected to general aging mechanisms.

results.title: Relationship between lifespan and somatic mutation in D. melanogaster after treatment with chlorophyllin.

theories.name: Damage accumulation theory (genetic damage and oxidative stress)

key_concepts.concept: Genetic damage as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that accumulation of genetic mutations and damage in somatic cells contributes causally to aging and lifespan limitation. Reducing mutation frequency can delay aging and extend lifespan.
Antioxidants like sodium copper chlorophyllin (SCC) can inhibit genetic damage by neutralizing oxidative stress, thereby potentially delaying aging processes and extending lifespan.
Individuals with higher somatic mutation loads die earlier, suggesting a causal link between accumulated genetic damage and organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing SCC treatment reduces mutation frequency and extends lifespan in Drosophila melanogaster, especially after gamma ray-induced damage; correlation between mutation load and mortality rates.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (genetic damage accumulation) underlying aging, generalizable beyond specific organs or diseases, and addresses aging as a fundamental biological process.

results.title: Delayed complications of sulfur mustard poisoning: a focus on inflammation and telomere footprint.

theories.name: Telomere Attrition Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Telomeres, the protective end caps of chromosomes, progressively shorten with cell division and stress, leading to cellular senescence or dysfunction. The paper highlights telomere shortening as a molecular indicator of sulfur mustard-induced aging and cellular damage.

TERRA molecules regulate telomere maintenance and genome stability. Dysregulation of TERRA is proposed to contribute to telomere dysfunction and cellular aging processes in the context of sulfur mustard exposure.

key_concepts.concept: Link between Telomere Dynamics and Chronic Inflammation
key_concepts.description: The theory integrates telomere attrition with inflammatory signaling pathways such as NF-κB and TGF-β, suggesting a feedback loop where telomere dysfunction perpetuates chronic inflammation and fibrosis, driving systemic aging-related pathology.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing evidence linking oxidative stress, inflammation, and telomere biology in sulfur mustard exposure, citing molecular indicators like telomere shortening and TERRA dysregulation, and signaling pathways NF-κB and TGF-β.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking telomere biology and inflammation to systemic aging processes induced by toxic exposure, addressing fundamental aging mechanisms beyond specific diseases.

results.title: [Postnatal epigenome-mediated aging control and global trends].

theories.name: Epigenome-mediated aging theory

key_concepts.description: The epigenome controls the on/off states of genes in response to environmental factors and stress through mechanisms such as DNA methylation, histone modifications, and chromatin remodeling. These epigenetic changes influence cellular identity and function.

With aging, the epigenome undergoes changes that lead to the loss of cell-specific epigenetic identity, resulting in tissue functional decline. These changes are dynamic and influenced by metabolic diseases, social stress, infectious diseases, and DNA damage.

DNA methylation patterns serve as biomarkers of biological age, forming the basis of epigenetic aging clocks. These clocks reflect the progression of aging and can be modulated by interventions such as calorie restriction.

key_concepts.concept: Reversibility and control of epigenomic aging
key_concepts.description: Postnatal epigenomic changes are reversible, as demonstrated by factors like Yamanaka factors (OKSM and OSK), which can reprogram cells and potentially rejuvenate tissues. Emerging modalities including mRNA, artificial peptides, and genome editing aim to control aging via epigenomic mechanisms.

The epigenome interacts closely with other aging hallmarks such as inflammation, stem cell function, metabolism, genomic instability, and autophagy, suggesting a central role in orchestrating systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent observations of epigenomic changes with age, gene expression analyses in aging mice, references to calorie restriction effects, mention of Yamanaka factors and emerging biotech interventions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining how aging occurs via epigenomic regulation and alterations; it provides causal explanations linking epigenomic changes to tissue and organismal aging; it addresses aging broadly at organismal and cellular levels; and it integrates with known aging hallmarks.

results.title: Molecular mechanisms of proliferative senescence and genomic instability in Werner syndrome and the WRN gene network.

theories.name: Cellular senescence and genomic instability theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Proliferative senescence as a model of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that cellular proliferative senescence, characterized by irreversible growth arrest of diploid cells, is a fundamental mechanism underlying organismal aging. Werner syndrome cells exhibit an extreme form of this senescence, linking cellular aging processes to systemic aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Genomic instability as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Genomic instability, including chromosomal translocations, deletions, and telomere crises, contributes causally to aging by compromising genome integrity. In Werner syndrome, defects in the WRN gene lead to increased genomic instability, which accelerates cellular senescence and aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: WRN protein’s role in DNA repair and maintenance
key_concepts.description: The WRN protein, with helicase and exonuclease activities, interacts with multiple DNA damage response pathways (NHEJ, homologous recombination, base excision repair) and telomere maintenance mechanisms. Its dysfunction disrupts genome stability and cell cycle progression, linking molecular defects to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Multifactorial nature of aging involving gene networks
key_concepts.description: Aging is proposed as a multifactorial process involving complex gene networks, as evidenced by the involvement of WRN in multiple pathways and the identification of other gene variants (LMNA, POLD1, etc.) in atypical Werner syndrome. This supports a broad, integrative view of aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Experimental observations of Werner syndrome cells showing extreme proliferative senescence, variegated translocation mosaicism, S phase arrest; molecular characterization of WRN protein interactions with DNA repair pathways; genetic findings in atypical Werner syndrome patients.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes causal mechanisms (genomic instability, cellular senescence) underlying general aging processes, supported by molecular and genetic data; theory is generalizable beyond Werner syndrome to aging broadly; addresses fundamental causes rather than narrow disease description.

results.title: Can iPSCs Turn Back Time? Prospects and Pitfalls in Age Reversal.

theories.name: Epigenetic Reprogramming Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The process by which induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) reset their biological age through extensive epigenetic remodeling, effectively reversing age-associated epigenetic and transcriptional changes.

A method involving transient or cyclic expression of Yamanaka factors (OSKM) that reverses aging hallmarks such as gene expression profiles, DNA methylation patterns, and mitochondrial function without fully erasing cellular identity.
Maintaining the differentiated state of cells during partial reprogramming to avoid dedifferentiation and tumorigenesis, which is a major challenge for safe age reversal.

theories.evidence: Summarizes findings from multiple studies showing restoration of youthful gene expression, DNA methylation, mitochondrial function, and reduction of senescence markers; also discusses safety concerns like genomic instability and tumorigenesis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging based on epigenetic changes and their reversal at the organismal level; addresses fundamental aging processes rather than narrow phenomena; discusses mechanisms underlying aging and rejuvenation.

results.title: Taurine and Berberine: Nutritional Interventions Targeting Cellular Mechanisms of Aging and Longevity.

theories.name: Cellular senescence and mitochondrial dysfunction as drivers of aging

key_concepts.description: Cells enter a state of permanent growth arrest contributing to aging by impairing tissue function and promoting inflammation. The paper links taurine deficiency to increased cellular senescence, suggesting a causal role in aging.

Mitochondria lose efficiency and produce more reactive oxygen species with age, leading to cellular damage. Taurine is implicated in protecting mitochondrial function, thus mitigating aging-related decline.

Aging involves depletion or dysfunction of stem cells, reducing tissue regeneration capacity. Taurine deficiency is associated with stem cell exhaustion, connecting nutrient status to aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Citations of emerging research linking taurine deficiency to cellular senescence, mitochondrial dysfunction, and stem cell exhaustion; animal studies showing health span and lifespan effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses general aging mechanisms (cellular senescence, mitochondrial dysfunction, stem cell exhaustion) with causal explanations and broad organism-level relevance.

theories.name: Metabolic signaling modulation by berberine affecting aging pathways

key_concepts.description: Berberine modulates the AMPK and mTOR pathways, which are central regulators of cellular metabolism, growth, and aging. This modulation is proposed to promote longevity by enhancing stress resistance and metabolic homeostasis.
Berberine influences sirtuin 1, a NAD+-dependent deacetylase involved in lifespan regulation and cellular stress responses, linking it to aging control mechanisms.
Berberine promotes mild mitochondrial stress that triggers adaptive beneficial responses, enhancing cellular resilience and longevity.

theories.evidence: References to molecular studies on berberine's effects on signaling pathways and animal studies demonstrating lifespan extension.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria by proposing causal mechanisms (signaling pathways) that broadly affect aging processes at the organism level.

results.title: Knockout of Shelterin subunit genes in zebrafish results in distinct outcomes.

theories.name: Telomere damage and genomic instability theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Shelterin complex role in telomere maintenance
key_concepts.description: The Shelterin complex is essential for maintaining telomere structure by interacting with telomerase and the CST complex, thereby protecting chromosome ends from damage.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere damage leads to genomic instability
key_concepts.description: Perturbation or deficiency of Shelterin subunits causes telomere damage, which results in genomic instability, a key driver of cellular dysfunction and organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere dysfunction as a causal mechanism of aging
key_concepts.description: Damage to telomeres triggers cellular and organismal aging phenotypes, such as reduced lifespan, sterility, and cachectic dwarfism, indicating telomere integrity is causally linked to aging processes.

theories.evidence: Generation of zebrafish knockout models for Shelterin subunit genes (acd, pot1, tinf2, terf1, pinx1) using CRISPR/Cas9; observation of premature aging-like phenotypes in acd mutants including male sterility, cachectic dwarfism, and reduced lifespan; differential survival outcomes depending on which Shelterin gene is knocked out.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains a fundamental aging mechanism (telomere damage leading to aging), proposes causal mechanisms (Shelterin dysfunction causes telomere damage and genomic instability), and addresses aging broadly at the organismal level through telomere biology.

results.title: Defective DNA repair: a putative nexus linking immunological diseases, neurodegenerative disorders, and cancer.

theories.name: DNA damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Cells accumulate DNA damage from internal and external sources, and inadequate repair leads to genomic instability, which impairs cellular function and physiological processes.

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage response (DDR) pathways as central regulators
key_concepts.description: DDR genes and pathways maintain genomic integrity by repairing DNA damage; alterations in these pathways are linked to multiple diseases and aging, suggesting DDR as a nexus connecting aging and disease.

key_concepts.concept: Shared genetic variants in DDR genes across diseases
key_concepts.description: Single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in DDR genes are associated with cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, and immunological disorders, indicating that DNA repair defects contribute broadly to aging-related pathologies.

theories.evidence: Analysis of GWAS summary statistics identifying thousands of SNPs associated with cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, and immunological disorders, including SNPs in DDR genes ATM, CUX2, WNT3, and RAD51B.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (DNA damage accumulation and repair defects) underlying aging and multiple age-related diseases, with broad organism-level implications and evolutionary relevance.

results.title: Circular RNAs accumulate in aging human placental tissue and in stillbirth, leading to DNA damage and cellular senescence.

theories.name: Circular RNA-induced placental aging theory

key_concepts.description: Circular RNAs are enzyme-resistant RNA molecules that accumulate in aging tissues, including the placenta, and their levels increase with gestational age and in stillbirth cases.
Circular RNAs can bind directly to genomic DNA, forming RNA:DNA complexes that induce DNA breaks and genomic instability, contributing to cellular damage.
The accumulation of circular RNAs and their interaction with DNA leads to increased DNA damage and triggers cellular senescence in placental tissue, which is a hallmark of aging.

RNase H1 degrades RNA in RNA:DNA hybrids; decreased RNase H1 abundance in stillbirth placentae may prevent circular RNA degradation, facilitating their accumulation and the formation of damaging complexes.
Accelerated aging in the placenta, characterized by shortened telomeres, DNA damage, and senescence driven by circular RNA accumulation, is associated with unexplained stillbirth.

theories.evidence: Quantification of circular RNAs and linear transcripts in placental samples across gestational ages and stillbirths; DNA:RNA immunoprecipitation confirming circular RNA binding to DNA; telomere length measurements; siRNA knockdown of circ_0000284 reducing DNA damage and senescence markers; measurement of circular RNAs in maternal blood predicting stillbirth risk.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining why placental aging occurs via circular RNA accumulation and DNA damage, linking molecular events to organism-level outcomes (stillbirth). It addresses aging broadly in placental tissue as a fundamental process, not limited to a narrow phenomenon, and proposes a mechanistic explanation involving RNA:DNA interactions and senescence.

results.title: Cells from ERCC1-deficient mice show increased genome instability and a reduced frequency of S-phase-dependent illegitimate chromosome exchange but a normal frequency of homologous recombination.

theories.name: DNA damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Spontaneously occurring DNA lesions accumulate in cells due to deficiencies in DNA repair mechanisms, leading to genomic instability and increased mutation frequency.
Specifically, the deficiency in ERCC1 impairs nucleotide excision repair and a form of illegitimate recombination, causing unrepaired lesions and double strand breaks to accumulate.

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage-induced cell cycle arrest and senescence
key_concepts.description: Accumulated DNA damage triggers the p53 response and G2 cell cycle arrest mediated by p21, leading to growth arrest and early cellular senescence, which contribute to organismal aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from ERCC1-deficient mouse and hamster cells showing increased mutation frequency, genomic instability, reduced illegitimate recombination, and cell cycle arrest; phenotypic observations of ERCC1-deficient mice with premature aging-like features.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how DNA repair deficiency leads to accumulation of damage, triggering cellular senescence and organismal aging; it addresses aging broadly via genome instability and cell cycle arrest mechanisms.

results.title: Identification and structural basis of C-terminal cyclic imides as natural degrons for cereblon.
Protein Tyrosine Nitration: Role in Aging.

theories.name: Reactive Nitrogen Species (RNS)-Induced Protein Damage Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Role of Reactive Nitrogen Species in Aging
key_concepts.description: Reactive Nitrogen Species (RNS), like Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS), are generated during aerobic metabolism and can cause covalent modifications to proteins, such as tyrosine nitration. These modifications alter protein function and contribute to physiological aging across multiple organs.

key_concepts.concept: Protein Tyrosine Nitration as a Molecular Mechanism
key_concepts.description: Tyrosine nitration is a post-translational modification induced by RNS that affects protein structure and function. This biochemical modification is linked to functional decline in tissues such as skeletal muscle, heart, brain, and liver during aging.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative and Nitrosative Stress as Fundamental Aging Drivers
key_concepts.description: Oxidative stress has been widely implicated in aging, and this theory extends the concept to include nitrosative stress via RNS. The accumulation of protein damage by RNS is proposed as a causal mechanism underlying systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: Critical review and evaluation of published studies demonstrating protein tyrosine nitration in various organs and its association with age-related functional alterations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (RNS-induced protein damage) explaining aging at the organismal level, discusses biochemical pathways underlying aging, and links molecular damage to systemic functional decline.

results.title: Protein oxidation and proteolytic signalling in aging.

theories.name: Protein Oxidation and Proteolytic System Dysfunction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative Stress and Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS)
key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with increased levels of reactive oxygen species due to a permanent flux of free radicals and oxidants in aerobic organisms. Limited antioxidant and repair mechanisms lead to accumulation of oxidative damage over time.

Elevated ROS cause damage to proteins, impairing their function and leading to cellular malfunction in aged cells. Protein oxidation contributes to senescence-associated alterations and neurodegenerative diseases.

The proteasomal and lysosomal (autophagy) systems degrade damaged proteins to maintain cellular function. Aging and cellular differentiation induce changes in these proteolytic systems, reducing their efficiency and allowing accumulation of damaged and aggregated proteins.

key_concepts.concept: Feedback Between Protein Aggregates and Proteolytic Dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Highly modified and undegradable protein aggregates can impair intracellular proteolytic systems, creating a vicious cycle that exacerbates protein damage and cellular aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of multiple studies linking longevity, oxidative stress, protein damage, and proteolytic system changes; references to cellular and molecular observations of protein oxidation and proteolytic activity alterations during aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how oxidative damage to proteins and dysfunction of proteolytic systems contribute to organismal aging. It addresses fundamental aging processes, not limited to specific diseases or organs, and proposes mechanistic links between oxidative stress, protein damage, and aging.

results.title: Structural basis for L-isoaspartyl-containing protein recognition by the human PCMTD1 cullin-RING E3 ubiquitin ligase.

theories.name: Protein damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: With aging, proteins accumulate spontaneous damage such as the formation of L-isoaspartyl residues, which cause structural kinks in polypeptide chains and impair proteome stability.

Organisms have evolved mechanisms to mitigate protein damage, including enzymatic repair by PCMT1 through methylation and degradation pathways involving ubiquitin ligases like PCMTD1 to maintain proteome integrity and promote organismal survival.

The PCMTD1 cullin-RING E3 ubiquitin ligase complex recognizes L-isoaspartyl residues as signals for ubiquitylation, targeting damaged proteins for proteasomal degradation, representing an alternative or complementary pathway to enzymatic repair.

theories.evidence: Structural data from cryo-EM, native mass spectrometry, and biochemical assays demonstrating PCMTD1 CRL complex binding specificity to L-isoaspartyl residues and its role in ubiquitylation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how spontaneous protein damage accumulates with age and how cellular systems mitigate this damage to influence aging at the organismal level.

results.title: CD300f immune receptor contributes to healthy aging by regulating inflammaging, metabolism, and cognitive decline.

theories.name: Immune receptor regulation of systemic aging via inflammaging and metabolic modulation

key_concepts.concept: Immune receptor CD300f as a regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: CD300f is a lipid-sensing immune receptor that integrates activating and inhibitory signaling pathways, modulating inflammation, efferocytosis, and microglial metabolic fitness. It is proposed to regulate systemic aging-related processes and contribute to healthy lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammaging as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Chronic low-grade inflammation (inflammaging) is implicated as a causal mechanism in aging. The absence of CD300f leads to systemic inflammaging, suggesting that CD300f normally acts to restrain inflammatory processes that contribute to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic and cognitive decline linked to immune regulation
key_concepts.description: Loss of CD300f results in reduced brain glucose uptake, altered macrophage immunometabolic phenotype, and increased cognitive decline, linking immune receptor function to metabolic and neurological aspects of aging.
CD300f deficiency is associated with increased cellular senescence and proteostasis disruption, which are recognized mechanisms contributing to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Longitudinal study of CD300f knockout and wild-type mice over 30 months showing reduced lifespan and healthspan in knockouts, systemic inflammaging, cognitive decline, altered brain glucose uptake via 18FDG PET, microglial aging phenotypes, proteostasis alterations, senescence markers, frailty, and sex-dependent metabolic changes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking immune receptor signaling to systemic aging processes including inflammation, metabolism, and cognitive decline; supported by experimental evidence in a mammalian model; addresses aging broadly rather than a single organ or disease.

results.title: A biomimetic natural sciences approach to understanding the mechanisms of ageing in burden of lifestyle diseases.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction leads to impaired energy production and increased reactive oxygen species, contributing to cellular damage and aging.
Telomere shortening limits cellular replication capacity, leading to senescence and organismal aging.
Changes in DNA methylation and histone modification patterns alter gene expression profiles during aging.
The decline in protein homeostasis results in accumulation of damaged or misfolded proteins, impairing cellular function.
Alterations in nutrient sensing pathways (e.g., insulin/IGF-1 signaling) affect metabolism and longevity.
Reduction in stem cell regenerative capacity diminishes tissue maintenance and repair.
Chronic low-grade inflammation and immune system decline contribute to aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Citations of multiple hallmarks common across taxa; comparative analysis of species with different lifespans and metabolic profiles.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes generalizable, causal mechanisms underlying aging at organismal level, integrating multiple fundamental processes.

theories.name: Biomimetic Comparative Aging Approach

key_concepts.description: Studying diverse species with varying lifespans and metabolic adaptations to uncover fundamental aging mechanisms.
Using natural models from the wild rather than genetically homogenous lab animals to better translate findings to humans.
Combining ecological, physiological, and molecular data to gain holistic insights into aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Discussion of species with unique longevity traits and metabolic profiles; proposal of new research avenues based on natural models.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Proposes a generalizable framework to understand aging mechanisms by leveraging natural diversity, thus meeting criteria for a theory-related approach.

results.title: Introduction: Progression of the Science of Ageing.

theories.name: Macromolecular Damage Accumulation Theory

key_concepts.concept: Damage to nuclear and mitochondrial DNA
key_concepts.description: Accumulation of DNA damage impairs cellular function and genome stability, driving aging processes.
Alterations in epigenetic marks and protein damage (e.g., aggregation, misfolding) contribute to cellular dysfunction and aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies on DNA damage, epigenetic changes, and protein damage in aging cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism of aging through cumulative molecular damage affecting organismal function.

theories.name: Calorie Restriction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Reducing calorie intake without malnutrition slows aging processes and extends lifespan in various organisms, suggesting a fundamental mechanism linking metabolism and aging.
Calorie restriction induces changes in metabolic pathways and stress response systems that reduce damage accumulation and improve cellular maintenance.

theories.evidence: Historical and recent studies highlighting calorie restriction effects on lifespan and healthspan in model organisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging applicable across species and links metabolic regulation to aging processes.

theories.name: Replicative Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cells have a finite number of divisions before entering a senescent state, contributing to tissue dysfunction and organismal aging.
Progressive shortening of telomeres during cell division signals replicative senescence, linking chromosomal integrity to aging.

theories.evidence: Presentation of cellular studies on replicative senescence and telomere biology in aging research history.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it explains a fundamental cellular mechanism that contributes causally to organism-level aging.

theories.name: Inflammaging Theory

key_concepts.description: Aging is accompanied by a persistent, systemic inflammatory state that contributes to tissue degeneration and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Inflammation is not just a consequence but a causal factor accelerating aging and functional decline.

theories.evidence: Emerging recognition and studies highlighting the role of inflammation in aging processes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria by proposing a systemic mechanism contributing causally to aging at the organismal level.

theories.name: Sirtuin-Mediated Aging Regulation Theory
