key_concepts.description: Sirtuins are NAD+-dependent enzymes that regulate metabolism, stress resistance, and genomic stability, influencing aging.
Mutations affecting sirtuin activity can alter lifespan, suggesting a programmed or regulated component of aging.

theories.evidence: References to genetic studies and pharmaceutical interventions targeting sirtuins.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a conserved molecular mechanism influencing aging broadly across organisms.

results.title: A stem cell aging framework, from mechanisms to interventions.

theories.name: Stem Cell Aging Framework

key_concepts.description: This concept involves alterations in the epigenetic landscape of somatic stem cells during aging, which affect gene expression patterns and contribute to functional decline.
Aging stem cells experience disruptions in protein quality control mechanisms, leading to accumulation of damaged or misfolded proteins that impair cellular function.
Chronic inflammation, circadian rhythm dysregulation, and metabolic disorders act as systemic factors that negatively impact stem cell function and contribute to organismal aging.
Interventions targeting stem cell aging mechanisms hold potential to promote healthy aging and combat age-related diseases by restoring or preserving stem cell function.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing decades of scientific research, including recent technological advances that dissect mechanisms of stem cell aging and therapeutic developments.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable framework explaining how stem cell decline contributes causally to organismal aging, discusses underlying mechanisms, and addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Signaling pathways and effectors of aging.

theories.name: Signaling Pathways Dysregulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Certain signaling pathways such as AMPK, sirtuins, FOX proteins, and NAD+ biosynthesis via Nampt promote longevity by maintaining metabolic homeostasis, DNA repair, and autophagy, which are essential for cellular health and lifespan extension.

key_concepts.concept: Loss of protective factors accelerates aging
key_concepts.description: Loss of factors like Klotho, which modulates insulin sensitivity and suppresses oxidative stress and inflammation, leads to premature aging, indicating that these molecules play a causal role in regulating organismal aging.

Aging is associated with imbalanced activation of multiple signaling pathways including p53, insulin/IGF, PI3K/AKT, mTOR, and NFkB, which disrupt cellular metabolism, autophagy, and promote inflammaging, immunosenescence, stem cell exhaustion, senescence, apoptosis, or cancer.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known pro-longevity factors (AMPK, sirtuins, FOX proteins, Nampt, Klotho) and pathways (p53, insulin/IGF, mTOR, NFkB) with citations to their roles in metabolism, DNA repair, inflammation, and aging phenotypes, including premature aging in mouse models.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation of aging based on dysregulation of conserved signaling pathways affecting organismal aging processes broadly, not limited to specific organs or diseases.

results.title: From genoprotection to rejuvenation.

theories.name: Nutrient Sensing Network Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is regulated by a network of nutrient sensors including AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK), mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR), insulin/insulin-like growth factor signaling pathway (IIS), sirtuins, NFkB, and FOXO. These sensors integrate metabolic and environmental signals to modulate cellular and organismal aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Intervention via dietary and pharmacological modulation
key_concepts.description: Calorie restriction, dietary restriction, and administration of NAD+ precursors (NAM, NMN, NR) and antioxidants can delay aging by modulating the activity of these nutrient sensors, thereby extending lifespan and healthspan.

theories.evidence: Citations and references to multiple interventions (calorie restriction, NAD+ precursors, antioxidants) that target nutrient sensors; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs via nutrient sensing pathways affecting organism-level aging; it addresses fundamental aging processes and interventions that modulate these pathways.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence and Senotherapeutics Theory

key_concepts.description: Accumulation of senescent cells contributes to age-related decline in tissue homeostasis and function, promoting systemic aging.

Therapeutic strategies including senolytics (which eliminate senescent cells) and senomorphics (which modulate senescent cell phenotype) can mitigate aging-associated tissue dysfunction and inflammation.

theories.evidence: References to senotherapeutics, senolytics, and anti-inflammaging strategies as measures to counteract aging-related tissue decline; no new data in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general causal mechanism (cellular senescence) driving systemic aging and discusses interventions targeting this mechanism.

theories.name: Epigenetic Reprogramming Theory of Aging Reversal

key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with changes in epigenetic marks that alter gene expression and cellular function, contributing to organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Reversal of aging by epigenetic reprogramming
key_concepts.description: Emerging interventions that reset epigenetic states can erase signs of aging and potentially reverse aging processes at the cellular and organismal level.

theories.evidence: Mention of epigenetic reprogramming as a possibility to reverse aging; no experimental details provided in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism underlying aging and potential reversal strategies applicable at organismal level.

results.title: Oxysterols are potential physiological regulators of ageing.

theories.name: Oxysterol regulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxysterols as regulators of aging processes
key_concepts.description: Oxysterols, oxidized derivatives of cholesterol, are proposed to act as physiological regulators influencing multiple biological processes involved in aging. Their effects vary depending on their chemical structure and concentration, exhibiting either deleterious or beneficial impacts on inflammation, oxidative stress, and cell survival.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation of key aging hallmarks by oxysterols
key_concepts.description: Oxysterols modulate critical aging-related mechanisms including stem cell differentiation, epigenetic changes, cellular senescence, and proteostasis. This suggests that the profile of oxysterols ('oxysterome') influences the aging process at a systemic level.

key_concepts.concept: Cholesterol metabolic pathway as a target for anti-aging interventions
key_concepts.description: Given the regulatory role of oxysterols in aging, the cholesterol metabolic pathway is proposed as a promising target for developing innovative anti-aging strategies aimed at delaying or reversing aging and associated diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing existing studies that link oxysterols with inflammation, oxidative stress, stem cell function, epigenetics, senescence, and proteostasis in the context of aging. It cites data supporting both harmful and beneficial roles of oxysterols depending on context.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (oxysterols as systemic regulators) explaining how aging occurs through modulation of fundamental biological processes. It provides a causal explanation by linking oxysterol profiles to aging hallmarks and suggests evolutionary/physiological regulatory roles. The scope is broad, addressing organism-level aging mechanisms rather than narrow disease or organ-specific phenomena.

results.title: Aging in chronic lung disease: Will anti-aging therapy be the key to the cure?

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells as drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate with age and induce pathological changes in tissues by secreting pro-inflammatory factors and disrupting normal cellular functions. In chronic lung disease, senescent cells contribute to immune dysfunction, airway remodeling, oxidative stress, and impaired tissue regeneration.

Key aging hallmarks such as blocked proliferation, telomere attrition, mitochondrial dysfunction, epigenetic alterations, altered nutrient sensing, and stem cell exhaustion collectively contribute to the decline in tissue function and the development of chronic lung disease.
Targeting aging mechanisms, particularly cellular senescence, may offer novel therapeutic avenues to prevent or treat chronic lung diseases by restoring tissue homeostasis and function.

theories.evidence: The abstract references multiple aging-related phenotypes and their pathological consequences in chronic lung disease, citing known hallmarks of aging and their involvement in disease progression. It discusses the potential of anti-aging therapies based on these mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (cellular senescence and aging hallmarks) underlying systemic aging processes that contribute to chronic lung disease. It addresses fundamental aging processes rather than a narrow phenomenon and discusses causal mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Dietary Restriction Delays But Cannot Heal Irradiation-Induced Hair Graying by Preserving Hair Follicle Stem Cells in Quiescence.

theories.name: DNA damage-driven stem cell exhaustion theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage as intrinsic cause of stem cell aging
key_concepts.description: DNA damage accumulates in stem cells, leading to their functional decline and eventual exhaustion. This damage triggers differentiation-induced removal of damaged stem cells, contributing to tissue aging.

key_concepts.concept: Stem cell quiescence as a protective mechanism
key_concepts.description: Prolonging the quiescent (resting) phase of hair follicle stem cells (HFSCs) can delay their depletion by reducing activation and differentiation, thereby slowing aging-related loss of stem cells.

key_concepts.concept: Trade-off between quiescence and DNA repair
key_concepts.description: While quiescence preserves stem cells by preventing their activation, it also suppresses DNA repair mechanisms, which eventually leads to irreversible damage accumulation and loss of melanoblasts, causing hair graying.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing dietary restriction extends time to hair graying after γ-irradiation in mice by prolonging HFSC quiescence; observations of suppressed DNA repair and eventual melanoblast loss despite quiescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (DNA damage-driven stem cell exhaustion) explaining aging at the organismal level, supported by mechanistic insights into stem cell quiescence and DNA repair trade-offs.

results.title: Detailing the biomedical aspects of geroscience by molecular data and large-scale "deep" bioinformatics analyses.
Sirt1 Protects Subventricular Zone-Derived Neural Stem Cells from DNA Double-Strand Breaks and Contributes to Olfactory Function Maintenance in Aging Mice.

theories.name: DNA damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of DNA damage in stem cells
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that DNA damage, particularly double-strand breaks, accumulates in stem cells over time, impairing their function and contributing to organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Stem cell exhaustion as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The inability of stem cells to maintain tissue homeostasis due to accumulated damage leads to functional decline and aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Adaptive DNA repair mechanisms mitigate aging
key_concepts.description: Upregulation of DNA repair pathways, such as non-homologous end joining mediated by Sirt1, can reduce DNA damage accumulation and protect stem cells, potentially slowing aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing reduced DNA double-strand breaks in aged SVZ-derived neural stem cells due to upregulated Sirt1 and NHEJ repair; Sirt1 deficiency leads to stem cell exhaustion, olfactory memory decline, and accelerated aging in mice.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (DNA damage accumulation and repair) underlying aging at the organismal level, with evidence linking stem cell maintenance to systemic aging phenotypes.

results.title: Primary cilia shape hallmarks of health and aging.

theories.name: Primary cilia dysfunction as a modulator of aging

key_concepts.description: Primary cilia are specialized cellular organelles that detect changes in the extracellular environment, playing a crucial role in cellular signaling and homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Role of primary cilia in aging hallmarks
key_concepts.description: Malfunction of primary cilia is linked to the modulation of key hallmarks of aging at tissue and cellular levels, potentially accelerating the aging process and contributing to age-related disorders.
Primary cilia dysfunction is associated with a range of age-related diseases including cancer, neurodegenerative, and metabolic disorders, suggesting a broader impact on organismal aging.
Pharmacological targeting of primary cilia dysfunction is proposed as a strategy to promote healthy aging and treat age-related diseases, although molecular pathways remain incompletely understood.

theories.evidence: Review of existing literature linking primary cilia dysfunction to aging hallmarks and age-related diseases; discussion of limited molecular pathway understanding and therapeutic approaches.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (primary cilia dysfunction) influencing systemic aging processes and age-related diseases, offers causal explanations linking cilia malfunction to aging hallmarks, and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a single disease or organ.

results.title: Periodontitis and Accelerated Biological Aging: A Geroscience Approach.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cells enter a state of permanent growth arrest called senescence, which accumulates with age and contributes to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging. Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory factors that impair tissue homeostasis and promote age-related pathologies.

Senescent cells accumulate in periodontal tissues, such as osteocytes and gingival cells, impairing their function and contributing to alveolar bone resorption and barrier dysfunction, which exacerbates periodontitis.

Targeting senescent cells with senolytic drugs, cell therapy, and lifestyle interventions (e.g., exercise, intermittent fasting) can rejuvenate periodontal tissues and potentially delay aging-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Meta-epidemiological data linking periodontitis with aging-related diseases; observations of shortened telomeres in severe periodontitis; cellular and molecular studies showing senescence induced by bacterial lipopolysaccharides and chronic hyperglycemia; recent advances in senotherapy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process (cellular senescence) with causal mechanisms; links local periodontal aging to systemic biological aging; discusses interventions targeting aging mechanisms.

theories.name: Biological Aging Biomarker Theory

key_concepts.description: Biological age, estimated by composite biomarker signatures, reflects an individual's functional status and aging rate better than chronological age. Discrepancies between biological and chronological age indicate accelerated or decelerated aging.
Higher biological age correlates with increased prevalence of periodontitis and tooth loss, suggesting that periodontitis is both a marker and a contributor to accelerated biological aging.

theories.evidence: Use of composite biomarker age estimators showing increased periodontitis in subjects with higher biological age; telomere length measurements.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria: proposes a generalizable concept of biological aging beyond chronological age and links it to disease; however, it is more a framework for measuring aging rather than a mechanistic theory explaining why aging occurs.

theories.name: Inflammaging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as aging driver
key_concepts.description: Aging is accompanied by a persistent, systemic, low-grade inflammatory state termed inflammaging, which contributes to tissue dysfunction and age-related diseases.
Chronic infection and inflammation from periodontitis elevate systemic inflammatory burden, accelerating biological aging and increasing risk for age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Meta-epidemiological data linking periodontitis-related inflammation to aging diseases and mortality; molecular evidence of inflammation-induced senescence in periodontal tissues.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (chronic inflammation) driving systemic aging and links local periodontal inflammation to general aging processes.

results.title: Ameliorating TIMM50 Loss Slows Senescence by Improving Mitochondrial Structure and Function.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction is characterized by increased mitochondrial volume, reduced ATP production, and elevated reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation, which are key features observed in cellular senescence and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic regulation of mitochondrial dysfunction via TIMM50
key_concepts.description: Downregulation of the mitochondrial protein TIMM50 triggers senescence by impairing mitochondrial function, suggesting a genetic regulatory mechanism underlying mitochondrial dysfunction in aging.

TIMM50 loss is mediated by sirtuin1-dependent downregulation of CCAAT enhancer binding protein alpha (CEBPα), a transcription activator of TIMM50, linking mitochondrial dysfunction to specific genetic regulatory pathways.
Compounds such as verapamil and MitoTEMPO that stabilize TIMM50 and reduce mitochondrial ROS can delay senescence, supporting the causal role of mitochondrial dysfunction in aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from several senescence models showing that TIMM50 downregulation triggers senescence; pathway analysis identifying sirtuin1-CEBPα regulation; screening of anti-aging compounds demonstrating TIMM50 stabilization and senescence delay.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process (mitochondrial dysfunction) at organismal level, proposes causal genetic and biochemical mechanisms, addresses general aging beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Relationship between metabolic rate, free radicals, differentiation and aging: a unified theory.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic rate as determinant of aging rate
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that metabolic rate governs the rate of aging, with higher metabolic rates leading to faster aging and shorter lifespan. This is supported by observations across homeotherms and poikilotherms, where metabolic potential is a species-specific characteristic influencing longevity.

Metabolism produces oxygen-free radicals that induce molecular damage, evidenced by accumulation of lipofuscin granules and other molecular markers. This damage accumulates with age and contributes causally to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Dynamic equilibrium between free radical generation and antioxidant defenses
key_concepts.description: A balance exists between the rate of free radical production and the antioxidant defense system, which declines with age. Loss of this equilibrium leads to dysdifferentiation, aging, and cancer, linking oxidative damage to cellular differentiation states.

theories.evidence: Citations of biochemical markers such as lipofuscin, Schiff-base-like fluorescent material, thiobarbituric acid-reactants, and pentane exhalation as indicators of free radical damage; comparative metabolic data across species.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs across species based on metabolic rate and oxidative damage, addressing organism-level aging processes.

results.title: ELN regulates cellular senescence: Emerging hypothesis for a non-canonical role.

theories.name: ELN regulation of cellular senescence via mitochondrial function

key_concepts.description: The ELN gene encodes tropoelastin, the main component of elastic fibers, which are essential extracellular matrix components providing elasticity to tissues. Elastic fibers decrease with aging, and this decline is proposed to contribute to the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate with aging; these cells cease proliferation and influence their microenvironment, thereby promoting aging. Cellular senescence is considered a causal driver of systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Non-canonical role of ELN in regulating mitochondrial respiratory chain activity
key_concepts.description: Beyond its structural role, ELN may regulate mitochondrial respiratory chain activity, which controls oxidative stress levels within cells. This regulation could modulate cellular senescence, linking ELN function directly to aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: The paper comments on and extends recent results supporting ELN's protective role against cellular senescence and hypothesizes mechanisms involving mitochondrial regulation; specific experimental details are not provided in the abstract but reference recent findings.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking ELN function to cellular senescence, a known driver of systemic aging. It addresses aging broadly through molecular and cellular processes, not limited to a single organ or disease.

results.title: Aging in the Perspective of Integrative Medicine, Psychoneuroendocrineimmunology and Hormesis.

theories.name: Psychoneuroendocrineimmunology (PNEI) theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Integration of psychological, neurological, endocrine, and immune systems
key_concepts.description: PNEI posits that aging results from complex interactions among the nervous, endocrine, and immune systems, which collectively influence organismal homeodynamics and resilience. Dysregulation in these interconnected systems contributes to aging-related decline.

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation and chronic stress as drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory highlights chronic low-grade cellular inflammation and persistent stress as general, interlinked factors that induce aging by causing biochemical, cellular, and multi-organ derangements.
Aging is characterized as a progressive decrease in homeodynamics, reflecting reduced psycho-biological resilience, which is central to the organism's ability to maintain stability and function.

theories.evidence: Narrative review of literature including pathophysiology of cell senescence, chronic degenerative diseases, and interventions targeting PNEI pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging involving systemic interactions and mechanisms beyond single organs or diseases, addressing fundamental aging processes.

theories.name: Hormesis theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Hormesis theory suggests that exposure to low doses of stressors (e.g., calorie restriction, exercise, fasting) activates cellular defense mechanisms that enhance resilience and delay aging processes.
Mild stress triggers pathways such as improved autophagy, antioxidant defenses, and metabolic adaptations that counteract age-related damage and promote longevity.

theories.evidence: Literature describing longevity-targeting interventions like calorie restriction, exercise, fasting, and nutraceuticals that induce hormetic effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a mechanistic explanation for aging modulation via stress-induced adaptive responses applicable at the organism level.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by mitochondrial DNA damage and metabolic dysfunction, leading to impaired energy production and increased generation of reactive oxygen species.
Accumulation of oxidative damage from reactive oxygen species contributes to cellular degeneration and aging-related decline.

key_concepts.concept: Impairment of autophagy and proteasome function
key_concepts.description: Dysfunction in cellular quality control systems such as autophagy and proteasome degradation leads to accumulation of damaged proteins and organelles, exacerbating aging.
Genomic instability and mutations accumulate over time, further driving cellular senescence and organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Summary of literature on cell degenerative processes related to aging including mitochondrial dysfunction, oxidative stress, and genome alterations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it explains fundamental biological mechanisms causing aging at the cellular and organismal level.

results.title: Are there Different Kinds of Aging?

theories.name: Biochemical hypothesis of aging

key_concepts.description: The hypothesis proposes that certain biochemical reactions become less stimulated and diminish over time, leading to a reduction in cellular functions.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on cellular energy and synthesis
key_concepts.description: This decline affects not only specific biochemical functions but also cellular energy production, which in turn reduces the cell's capacity for synthesis and maintenance.

The hypothesis is used to interpret the mechanisms underlying accelerated aging syndromes such as Werner syndrome and Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome, linking genetic mutations affecting DNA repair and nuclear envelope proteins to broader aging processes.

theories.evidence: Critical analysis of accelerated aging syndromes (Werner syndrome, HGPS) and their molecular defects; comparison with normal aging processes; theoretical reasoning based on biochemical reaction dynamics.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the cellular and organismal level, linking molecular defects to systemic aging processes beyond specific diseases.

results.title: Mitochondrial respiration is controlled by Allostery, Subunit Composition and Phosphorylation Sites of Cytochrome c Oxidase: A trailblazer's tale - Bernhard Kadenbach.

theories.name: Allosteric Feedback Inhibition Theory of Cytochrome c Oxidase in Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that cytochrome c oxidase (CytOx) activity is regulated by allosteric feedback inhibition at high mitochondrial ATP/ADP ratios, which is essential for maintaining healthy mitochondrial function and preventing oxidative stress.

Under stress conditions, CytOx undergoes reversible dephosphorylation, which disrupts its normal regulation and leads to increased production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), contributing to oxidative damage.

key_concepts.concept: Excessive reactive oxygen species trigger degenerative diseases and aging
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of ROS due to impaired CytOx regulation is proposed as a causal mechanism driving oxidative stress, cellular damage, and ultimately aging and associated degenerative diseases.

theories.evidence: The theory is supported by observations of defective CytOx activity with increasing age in human muscle and neuronal cells, and by biochemical studies on CytOx regulation and phosphorylation states.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how mitochondrial dysfunction via CytOx regulation leads to oxidative stress and aging at the organismal level. It addresses a fundamental biological aging process, not limited to a single disease or organ, and offers mechanistic insight into aging.

results.title: Immune Aging and Its Implication for Age-Related Disease Progression.

theories.name: Immune Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Immune system compositional and functional changes
key_concepts.description: Aging induces alterations in both innate and adaptive immune cells, leading to impaired immune responses. These changes contribute broadly to systemic aging processes by affecting the organism's ability to control infections, cancer, and maintain tissue homeostasis.

A chronic, low-grade systemic inflammation that develops with age, driven in part by immune aging. Inflammaging is implicated as a causal mechanism linking immune system decline to the pathogenesis of multiple age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Tertiary lymphoid structures (TLS) as hallmarks of immune aging
key_concepts.description: TLS formation is associated with aged immune systems and contributes to local inflammation and tissue damage. TLS represent a structural and functional manifestation of immune aging with potential roles in disease progression and therapeutic targeting.

theories.evidence: The article synthesizes emerging evidence from multiple studies linking immune aging to age-related diseases, including kidney and autoimmune diseases, and discusses TLS as a novel hallmark based on recent research findings.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging at the organism level through immune system decline and inflammaging, addressing systemic aging mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Limits to sustained energy intake. XXXIV. Can the heat dissipation limit (HDL) theory explain reproductive aging?

theories.name: Heat Dissipation Limit (HDL) Theory

key_concepts.concept: Heat dissipation as a limiting factor
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that reproductive performance is limited by an organism's capacity to dissipate excess metabolic heat generated during high energy expenditure activities such as lactation.

key_concepts.concept: Age-related decline in heat dissipation capacity
key_concepts.description: The theory hypothesizes that the decline in reproductive performance with age is due to a decrease in the ability to dissipate heat, which becomes a physiological constraint.
The theory suggests that animals with higher metabolic rates experience more severe limitations in reproductive performance due to heat dissipation constraints.

theories.evidence: Experimental study on bank voles selected for high metabolic rate and controls, comparing reproductive performance and metabolic rates across age groups and with manipulation of heat dissipation capacity by shaving.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining why reproductive aging occurs, linking thermoregulatory capacity to systemic aging effects on reproduction. It attempts to explain aging at an organismal level and tests mechanistic hypotheses.

results.title: Genome reorganization during aging of dividing cells.

theories.name: Genome reorganization theory of cellular aging

key_concepts.concept: Self-limiting genome reorganization during cell division
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that long-term proliferation of fibroblasts depends on the genome's capacity to reorganize during cell division, but this reorganization potential is self-limiting. With each division, residual quantitative and qualitative changes accumulate in chromatin, progressively limiting the ability for further genome rearrangements.

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of chromatin and DNA alterations
key_concepts.description: At each population doubling, errors such as unequal DNA distribution between sister cells, chromosome assembly and segregation mistakes, DNA loss, replication errors, and multiple rounds of replication at single origins accumulate. These changes lead to increased chromatin instability and structural alterations that impair cell function.

key_concepts.concept: Chromatin structural degradation as an aging marker
key_concepts.description: With aging, chromatin fibers become spaced and shorter, nucleosome organization is lost, and DNA fragmentation occurs. These changes are more pronounced toward the end of the fibroblast lifespan and are present early in cells from aged adults and Werner syndrome patients, suggesting a link between chromatin reorganization defects and cellular aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of transposable elements in aging genome instability
key_concepts.description: Short, unbeaded DNA fragments, possibly transposable elements, detach during division and fail to reintegrate due to age-related chromatin changes. This may contribute to genome instability and cellular aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental observations of fibroblast populations exposed to low dose ionizing radiation; measurements of DNA distribution errors, chromatin alkali- and thermo-lability, ultrastructural chromatin changes, and presence of DNA fragments in normal and Werner syndrome fibroblasts.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining cellular aging through genome reorganization limits, supported by mechanistic evidence and applicable to organism-level aging processes via cellular senescence and genome stability.

results.title: A health economic theory of occupational choice, aging, and longevity.
Type 2 Deiodinase Thr92Ala Polymorphism and Aging Are Associated with a Decreased Pituitary Sensitivity to Thyroid Hormone.
Combining rejuvenation interventions in rodents: a milestone in biomedical gerontology whose time has come.

theories.name: Rejuvenation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Rejuvenation focuses on reducing biological age by reversing or repairing inert changes in tissue structure and composition, rather than merely slowing the progression of aging.
Effective rejuvenation requires simultaneous interventions targeting multiple categories of aging-related damage, addressing the complex and multifactorial nature of aging.

Rejuvenation is proposed as an easier and more direct approach than slowing aging because it deals with accumulated damage rather than the underlying processes that both cause damage and sustain life.

theories.evidence: Discussion of in vivo studies in rodents and other model organisms showing effects on lifespan and age-related decline; references to accelerated disease models and therapeutic strategies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging by focusing on damage repair and biological age reduction at the organismal level; it addresses fundamental aging mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Enhanced ROS Production in Mitochondria from Prematurely Aging mtDNA Mutator Mice.

theories.name: Mitochondrial hypothesis of aging

key_concepts.description: Accumulation of mutations in mitochondrial DNA leads to defective mitochondria, which contributes to the aging phenotype by impairing cellular energy production and function.

key_concepts.concept: Increased mitochondrial ROS production drives aging
key_concepts.description: Mutated mitochondria produce elevated levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which cause oxidative damage to cellular components, thereby accelerating the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: ROS production depends on mitochondrial electron flow conditions
key_concepts.description: ROS generation varies with the metabolic state of mitochondria; under physiological forward electron flow conditions, ROS production is increased in mtDNA-mutator mitochondria, supporting the hypothesis.

theories.evidence: Experimental measurements of ROS production rates in mitochondria isolated from mtDNA-mutator mice under different substrate and electron flow conditions; comparison with wildtype mitochondria.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining aging at the organismal level via mitochondrial dysfunction and ROS; it addresses fundamental aging processes rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Sex-dependent selection, ageing, and implications for "staying alive".

theories.name: Sex-dependent selection theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that higher extrinsic mortality in males reduces the strength of natural selection against aging-related diseases and behaviors that promote self-preservation, leading to higher intrinsic mortality in males.
Due to weaker selection in males, traits promoting longevity may incidentally become more prevalent or pronounced in females, resulting in female-biased longevity.

The theory suggests that the observed sex differences in aging and longevity may be disentangled from adaptive self-preservation mechanisms, implying a complex interplay between evolutionary pressures and aging processes.

theories.evidence: The abstract references theoretical insights from aging biology and proposes the hypothesis based on evolutionary logic; no direct experimental data are presented, but it calls for rigorous testing.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable evolutionary mechanism explaining sex differences in aging at the organismal level, offers causal explanations related to selection pressures, and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Endogenous and exogenous viral reactivation as a driver of epigenetic drift and mitophagy failure in aging.

theories.name: Virome Pressure Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Progressive Reactivation of Endogenous and Exogenous Viruses
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that human endogenous retroviruses (HERVs) and latent viral infections acquired throughout life progressively reactivate with age, placing increasing stress on cellular regulatory systems.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic Silencing Mechanisms and Their Decline
key_concepts.description: Continuous silencing of viral elements is maintained by DNA methylation, histone deacetylation, and NAD⁺-dependent pathways, which deteriorate over time, leading to loss of control over viral reactivation.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on Mitochondrial Quality Control and Immune Activation
key_concepts.description: Reactivation of viral elements disrupts key mitochondrial quality control genes, impairs mitophagy, and activates innate immune responses, contributing to aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of Virology, Epigenetics, and Mitochondrial Biology
key_concepts.description: The model synthesizes multiple biological domains to explain aging as a multifactorial process driven by viral reactivation-induced epigenetic drift and mitochondrial dysfunction.

theories.evidence: The abstract presents a unifying hypothesis integrating existing knowledge from virology, epigenetics, and mitochondrial biology, but does not detail new experimental data within the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining aging at the organism level by linking viral reactivation to epigenetic and mitochondrial dysfunction, addressing fundamental aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Immune Aging in Rheumatoid Arthritis.

theories.name: Immune aging as a causal driver of autoimmunity in rheumatoid arthritis

key_concepts.description: Premature immune aging refers to the accelerated aging phenotype observed in immune cells, particularly CD4+ T cells, in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). This aging process occurs before clinical joint inflammation and is characterized by molecular and functional changes that predispose these cells to become pathogenic effectors.

Malfunction of organelles such as mitochondria, lysosomes, lipid droplets, and the endoplasmic reticulum in T cells leads to altered cellular metabolism and behavior. These organelle dysfunctions contribute to hypermobility, tissue invasiveness, and dysregulated signaling pathways like mTORC1 activation, promoting proinflammatory states.

Clonal hematopoiesis drives aging in myeloid cells, producing aged monocytes and hypermetabolic macrophages that sustain chronic low-grade inflammation (inflammaging). This systemic inflammatory environment supports the progression of immune aging and autoimmunity.

key_concepts.concept: Age-associated B cells and autoantibody production
key_concepts.description: Age-associated B cells accumulate with immune aging and specialize in producing autoantibodies, contributing to the autoimmune pathology observed in RA.

theories.evidence: The paper references molecular immunology and functional genomics data linking immune aging signatures in CD4+ T cells and other immune cells to RA pathogenesis. It also notes observations in healthy individuals with genetic risk alleles and describes cellular and molecular dysfunctions associated with aging immune cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory meets all criteria: it provides a generalizable explanation for aging-related susceptibility to RA by proposing immune aging as a fundamental causal mechanism. It addresses systemic immune aging processes rather than a narrow phenomenon, proposes mechanisms (organelle dysfunction, clonal hematopoiesis, inflammaging), and links these to disease development, thus explaining how aging contributes to autoimmunity.

results.title: Cellular clones and transgenic mice overexpressing copper-zinc superoxide dismutase: models for the study of free radical metabolism and aging.

theories.name: Free Radical Damage Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that an imbalance in the production and detoxification of oxygen-derived free radicals, such as superoxide and hydrogen peroxide, leads to oxidative damage accumulation in cells, which contributes to aging and age-related pathologies.

CuZnSOD is an enzyme that converts superoxide radicals into hydrogen peroxide. Overexpression of CuZnSOD, as seen in Down's Syndrome due to gene dosage effects, may cause excess hydrogen peroxide production, which can promote peroxidative cellular damage.

The accumulation of oxidative damage, particularly lipid peroxidation in brain tissues, is proposed to accelerate aging processes and contribute to neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease.

theories.evidence: Data from cellular clones and transgenic mice overexpressing human CuZnSOD show increased Se-GPx activity and elevated peroxidation in brain tissue, mimicking the biochemical environment of Down's Syndrome and supporting the hypothesis of oxidative imbalance driving aging-related damage.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains a fundamental aging mechanism (oxidative damage accumulation) with generalizability beyond a single disease, proposes a causal mechanism (ROS imbalance leading to damage), and addresses systemic aging processes including neurodegeneration.

results.title: Proposed role for a combination of citric acid and ascorbic acid in the production of dietary iron overload: a fundamental cause of disease.

theories.name: Dietary Iron Overload Theory of Aging-Related Disease

key_concepts.concept: Iron overload as a fundamental cause of aging-related diseases
key_concepts.description: Excess dietary iron accumulation contributes causally to multiple age-associated diseases such as heart disease, cancer, diabetes, osteoporosis, and arthritis by promoting oxidative damage.

key_concepts.concept: Synergistic enhancement of iron absorption by citric acid and ascorbic acid
key_concepts.description: The combination of citric acid and ascorbic acid acts synergistically to increase iron absorption from the diet, leading to elevated systemic iron levels particularly in aging populations.

key_concepts.concept: Age-related dietary trends increasing iron load
key_concepts.description: Changes in dietary patterns with age, including increased intake of iron absorption enhancers, contribute to progressive iron overload, which may underlie worsening disease statistics in older adults.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative damage mediated by iron overload
key_concepts.description: Iron catalyzes oxidative reactions that damage biomolecules, and decreased plasma antioxidants in disease states reflect this oxidative stress, linking iron overload mechanistically to aging-related pathology.

theories.evidence: Review of literature linking iron overload to multiple diseases; analysis of antioxidant depletion in disease; evaluation of dietary trends and iron absorption factors; proposal of experiments to test hypothesis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (iron overload) underlying multiple aging-related diseases, linking dietary factors to systemic aging processes via oxidative damage; it attempts to explain why aging-related disease incidence increases and offers a mechanistic basis applicable organism-wide.

results.title: Anecdotal Evidence Elucidates the Aging Process.

theories.name: Reversibility of Aging via Young Plasma Factors

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that factors present in the plasma of young organisms can reverse aging processes in older organisms, suggesting aging is not strictly unidirectional and may be modifiable by systemic circulating factors.

The paper suggests that anecdotal evidence has clarified the underlying mechanisms of aging and rejuvenation, implying a biological process that can be influenced or reversed, potentially involving systemic signals or factors.

Building on historical research involving heterochronic parabiosis (joining circulatory systems of young and old animals), this theory extends the concept by identifying specific plasma fractions that mediate rejuvenation effects.

theories.evidence: Several experiments by the authors' group demonstrating reversibility of aging with young plasma fraction; anecdotal evidence clarifying aging mechanisms; references to historical heterochronic parabiosis research.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging and rejuvenation at the organism level, addressing fundamental aging processes beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Songbirds avoid the oxidative stress costs of high blood glucose levels: a comparative study.

theories.name: Adaptation to avoid oxidative stress costs of high blood glucose

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress as a mediator of hyperglycaemia-induced aging
key_concepts.description: High blood glucose levels can lead to elevated oxidative stress, which is implicated in aging-related pathologies and reduced lifespan at the individual level.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary adaptation in birds to decouple glycaemia and lifespan
key_concepts.description: Despite high blood glucose levels, birds do not show the expected oxidative damage or reduced lifespan, suggesting they have evolved physiological adaptations that prevent oxidative costs associated with hyperglycaemia.

The study uses comparative data across 51 songbird species to test whether blood glucose levels correlate with oxidative stress markers, controlling for phylogeny and life-history traits, to infer evolutionary adaptations.

theories.evidence: Comparative analyses of blood glucose and oxidative stress markers (uric acid, total antioxidants, glutathione, malondialdehyde) in 51 songbird species; no clear correlation found between glucose levels and oxidative damage; moderate evidence for lower antioxidant investment in species with stronger glucose stress response.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable evolutionary adaptation mechanism explaining how birds avoid oxidative damage from high glucose, addressing causal mechanisms of aging-related oxidative stress at organismal and macroevolutionary scales.

results.title: Oxidative stress and aging.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging (Oxidative Stress Theory)

key_concepts.concept: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) as damaging agents
key_concepts.description: ROS are constantly generated in living tissues and can damage DNA, proteins, and lipids. Excessive ROS leads to oxidative stress, which is proposed to cause cumulative molecular damage contributing to aging.

ROS also act as physiological signaling molecules. Abnormally high ROS levels can dysregulate redox-sensitive signaling pathways by oxidizing cysteine residues in signaling proteins, altering their function and contributing to aging-related cellular dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Intracellular and extracellular redox status shifts
key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with an oxidative shift in the intracellular glutathione redox status (REDST) and extracellular plasma REDST, which correlates with cellular dysfunction and aging-related pathophysiological processes.

theories.evidence: Citations of genetic studies in C. elegans, Drosophila, and mice supporting the role of ROS in aging; cell culture and animal studies showing oxidative shifts linked to dysfunction; human studies correlating plasma redox changes with aging pathologies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental, generalizable mechanism (oxidative damage and redox signaling dysregulation) underlying aging; proposes causal mechanisms; addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Inflammaging as a target for healthy ageing.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic systemic inflammation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Inflammaging refers to the chronic, low-grade systemic inflammation that increases with advancing age. This persistent inflammatory state contributes causally to the development of multiple chronic diseases and general decline in health during aging.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammaging as a mechanistic link to age-associated diseases
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that inflammaging is a fundamental biological process underlying the increased risk of chronic diseases in older adults, thus connecting inflammation to the broader aging process rather than isolated pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Targeting inflammaging to promote healthy aging
key_concepts.description: Interventions aimed at reducing inflammaging, including non-pharmacological strategies (diet, physical activity, microbiome therapies) and pharmacological approaches (caloric restriction mimetics, p38 MAP kinase inhibitors, senolytics), are proposed to modulate the aging process and extend healthy lifespan.

theories.evidence: Review of recent literature and hypotheses; discussion of intervention strategies and pharmacological agents targeting inflammaging; references to emerging therapies such as senolytics.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism (chronic inflammation) underlying systemic aging and age-related diseases, with broad organism-level implications and evolutionary relevance. It is not limited to a single disease or organ and includes mechanistic explanations and intervention strategies.

results.title: Telomere shortening is associated with cell division in vitro and in vivo.

theories.name: Telomere Shortening Theory of Cellular Aging

key_concepts.description: The inability of DNA replication machinery to fully replicate the ends of linear chromosomes leads to progressive shortening of telomeric DNA with each cell division.

key_concepts.concept: Lack of Telomerase Activity in Somatic Cells
key_concepts.description: Most somatic cells do not express telomerase, the enzyme that can add telomeric repeats de novo, resulting in irreversible telomere shortening during replication.

Telomere length decreases primarily as a function of cell division rather than chronological time, as demonstrated by differences in telomere shortening rates between dividing and quiescent cells both in vitro and in vivo.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere Length as a Biomarker of Replicative Capacity
key_concepts.description: Because telomere shortening correlates with the number of cell divisions, telomere length can serve as a biomarker indicating the replicative history and potential of cells.

theories.evidence: Experimental measurements of telomere length in dividing versus quiescent human diploid fibroblasts in vitro, and in mitotically active versus quiescent brain tissue in vivo, showing statistically significant telomere shortening only in dividing cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a general causal mechanism (end replication problem and lack of telomerase) explaining why aging occurs at the cellular level, applicable broadly to somatic cells, with causal explanation tied to cell division; not limited to a single disease or organ but relevant to organismal aging.

results.title: [The role of social representations on embodied and situated cognitive aging: The example of the transition to retirement].

theories.name: Stereotype Embodiment Theory

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that individuals gradually internalize societal representations and stereotypes about aging over time, which then influence their own behaviors and self-perceptions.
The internalized stereotypes lead to repeated behavioral changes that can physically and cognitively manifest, contributing to observed changes in aging individuals.

Unlike other stigmatized groups, the elderly social group is not clearly defined or static; the transition to retirement acts as a key social marker that catalyzes the impact of aging stereotypes on cognition.

theories.evidence: The abstract references existing studies on stereotype embodiment theory and proposes the transition to retirement as a unique context to study its effects, but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general psychosocial aging theory explaining how social representations causally influence aging cognition at an organism-level scale; it addresses broad aging processes beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Calculating Aging: Analysis of Survival Curves in the Norm and Pathology, Fluctuations in Mortality Dynamics, Characteristics of Lifespan Distribution, and Indicators of Lifespan Variation.

theories.name: Multiple Pathways of Aging (Chronic Phenoptosis) Theory

key_concepts.concept: Multiple molecular pathways leading to aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging results from various distinct molecular and cellular pathways, including DNA metabolism (repair, transcription, replication), oxidative stress protection via Nrf2, and regulation of cell proliferation. Each pathway uniquely contributes to aging but converges on a common organismal outcome.

key_concepts.concept: Accelerated cellular senescence as a unifying mechanism
key_concepts.description: Despite different mutations affecting diverse pathways, they all accelerate aging by either reducing cell lifespan or hastening the transition of cells into a senescent state. This cellular senescence acts as a causal driver of systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Temporal scaling and survival curve analysis as tools to distinguish aging dynamics
key_concepts.description: Using models like the accelerated failure time (AFT) model and coefficient of variation of lifespan (CV_LS), the theory incorporates quantitative and qualitative differences in aging dynamics, including accelerated aging without changing survival curve shape, supporting the concept of multiple aging pathways.

theories.evidence: Analysis of survival curves using AFT and Gompertz models; comparison of mutations affecting DNA metabolism, oxidative stress, and proliferation; references to empirical data on survival curve shapes and mortality fluctuations; citations of prior work by Skulachev and others.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging at the organism level, integrating multiple molecular pathways into a unified aging mechanism involving cellular senescence and phenoptosis. It addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Using attribute amnesia to test the limits of hyper-binding and associative deficits in working memory.
Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated Receptor Gamma (PPARγ)-targeted Gel/Mg/Lip@Gigantol nanoplatform attenuates skin barrier disruption-associated aging in mice via NLRP3 suppression.

theories.name: Barrier-Skin-Systemic Aging Axis

key_concepts.description: Disruption of the skin's epidermal barrier initiates a cascade that accelerates aging processes, linking local skin damage to systemic aging effects.

key_concepts.concept: PPARγ suppression as central mechanistic hub
key_concepts.description: Suppression of Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated Receptor Gamma (PPARγ) due to barrier disruption triggers downstream aging mechanisms, positioning PPARγ as a key regulator of aging pathways.

key_concepts.concept: NLRP3 inflammasome activation and SASP amplification
key_concepts.description: PPARγ suppression leads to activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome, which amplifies the Senescence-Associated Secretory Phenotype (SASP), promoting systemic inflammation and oxidative stress that drive aging.

key_concepts.concept: Systemic oxidative stress as aging driver
key_concepts.description: The cascade initiated by barrier disruption and PPARγ suppression culminates in systemic oxidative stress, which contributes broadly to organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental evidence includes identification of Gigantol as a high-affinity PPARγ agonist, development of a delivery system enhancing PPARγ targeting, and in vivo mouse studies showing delayed skin aging, restored barrier microstructure, suppressed systemic inflammation, and reduced aging markers such as P21.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking skin barrier integrity, PPARγ signaling, inflammasome activation, and systemic aging processes. It explains how aging occurs at an organismal level via inflammatory and oxidative stress pathways, not limited to skin alone.

results.title: Sperm production is negatively associated with muscle and sperm telomere length in a species subjected to strong sperm competition.

theories.name: Reproduction-Associated Telomere Attrition Theory

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that increased reproductive investment, particularly in sexually selected traits such as sperm production, leads to accelerated deterioration of both somatic and germinal cells. This is due to enhanced telomere attrition, reflecting a cost of reproduction that impacts organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length as a biomarker of aging and reproductive cost
key_concepts.description: Telomere length in somatic and germinal tissues is used as an indicator of cellular aging and damage. Shorter telomeres are associated with higher reproductive effort, suggesting that reproductive allocation influences biological aging processes.

Based on life-history theory, aging is viewed as a consequence of resource allocation trade-offs, where investment in reproduction reduces resources available for somatic maintenance, thereby accelerating aging.

theories.evidence: Empirical measurements of telomere length in somatic and sperm cells of guppies across lifespan; correlation analysis showing negative association between sperm production and telomere length; longitudinal data showing telomere lengthening with age in somatic tissue but no age effect in sperm cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking reproductive investment to aging via telomere dynamics, addressing organism-level aging processes and trade-offs; it is not limited to a single organ or disease and provides mechanistic insight into aging.

results.title: Epigenetic factors Polycomb (Pc) and Suppressor of zeste (Su(z)2) negatively regulate longevity in Drosophila melanogaster.

theories.name: Epigenetic regulation of aging via Polycomb group proteins

key_concepts.description: Epigenetic factors such as Polycomb (PcG) and trithorax (trxG) protein complexes regulate gene expression profiles that influence aging and lifespan. These complexes maintain developmental gene expression and cellular processes that impact aging rates.

key_concepts.concept: Polycomb repressive complex 1 (PRC1) components influence lifespan
key_concepts.description: Mutations in PRC1 components Pc and Su(z)2 increase survival and retard aging in Drosophila, suggesting these proteins negatively regulate longevity. This indicates a causal role of epigenetic repression in aging.
Knockdown of Pc and Su(z)2 in the fat body, but not muscle or brain, enhances lifespan, implying that epigenetic regulation of aging is tissue-specific and may involve distinct pathways.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic regulators affect oxidative stress response
key_concepts.description: Pc and Su(z)2 influence lifespan potentially through pathways independent of canonical PRC1 functions, with distinct effects on oxidative stress response, linking epigenetic regulation to a known aging-related mechanism.

theories.evidence: Genetic mutations and inducible knockdown experiments in Drosophila demonstrating increased lifespan and altered aging rates; tissue-specific knockdown experiments; observations on oxidative stress response.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (epigenetic regulation by PcG proteins) underlying aging at the organism level, supported by experimental evidence in a model organism, and addresses fundamental aging processes rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific effect.

results.title: The role of mitochondria in cytokine and chemokine signalling during ageing.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria lose efficiency and quality control with age, leading to impaired cellular function and contributing to systemic aging processes.
Dysfunctional mitochondria promote chronic low-level inflammation by regulating the production of cytokines and chemokines, which drive age-related immune activation.
Age-related decline in mitochondrial biogenesis, dynamics, mitophagy, and mitochondrial unfolded protein response (UPRmt) exacerbates mitochondrial dysfunction and inflammation.

key_concepts.concept: Interaction between mitochondrial dysfunction and cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction influences cellular senescence, which in turn regulates secretion of pro-inflammatory molecules, linking mitochondrial health to systemic aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Review of molecular mechanisms involving mitochondrial components (mtDNA, ROS, metabolites, etc.), mitochondrial quality control pathways, and their roles in inflammageing and cellular senescence; citations of studies linking mitochondrial dysfunction to age-related diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how mitochondrial dysfunction drives systemic aging via inflammation and senescence; addresses fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases; provides mechanistic insights into aging.

results.title: Aging and proteolysis of oxidized proteins.

theories.name: Damage accumulation theory of aging (oxidative damage and proteolysis decline)

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging is driven by the accumulation of oxidatively damaged proteins in tissues, which impairs cellular function and contributes to organismal aging.
A proposed mechanism is that aging involves a decline in the activity of proteases responsible for degrading oxidized proteins, leading to their accumulation and further cellular dysfunction.

The theory acknowledges that the decline in proteolytic activity and accumulation of oxidized proteins may vary between tissues and species, suggesting a complex interplay between damage production and clearance.

theories.evidence: Experimental measurements of alkaline protease activity in housefly and rat tissues at different ages, showing no decline in some tissues/species and significant decline in others, correlated with oxidized protein levels.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (damage accumulation and proteolysis decline) explaining why aging occurs at the organismal level, supported by cross-species and tissue data.

results.title: Self-percepts of control in middle and later adulthood: buffering losses by rescaling goals.
Nonuniversality of inflammaging across human populations.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Inflammaging refers to the age-associated increase in chronic systemic inflammation, which is proposed to contribute causally to the aging process and age-related diseases.
The theory posits that inflammaging can be quantified by analyzing patterns or axes of circulating inflammatory cytokines, which reflect systemic inflammatory status linked to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Environmental and population variability in inflammaging
key_concepts.description: The theory implies inflammaging is a generalizable aging mechanism, but this paper challenges that by showing inflammaging signatures vary markedly across populations and environments, suggesting it may not be universal.

theories.evidence: Comparative analysis of cytokine profiles from four human populations (two industrialized and two indigenous nonindustrialized) showing differences in inflammaging axis structure and associations with age and health outcomes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (chronic inflammation) with proposed causal mechanisms (inflammatory cytokines), addresses aging broadly, and tests generalizability across populations.

results.title: Epigenetic rejuvenation by partial reprogramming.

theories.name: Epigenetic Rejuvenation via Partial Cellular Reprogramming

key_concepts.concept: Reprogramming to pluripotency reverses cellular aging markers
key_concepts.description: Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) generation resets age-associated molecular features such as telomere length, epigenetic clocks, transcriptomic profiles, and replicative senescence, effectively rejuvenating cells at a molecular level.

key_concepts.concept: Partial reprogramming as a rejuvenation strategy
key_concepts.description: Limited exposure to reprogramming factors can reset epigenetic aging clocks while preserving cellular identity, potentially avoiding the risks of full de-differentiation and teratoma formation associated with complete reprogramming.

key_concepts.concept: Link between aging and cell fate determination
key_concepts.description: The theory explores whether the rejuvenation program can be separated from the pluripotency program or if aging processes are inherently tied to mechanisms controlling cell identity and differentiation state.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent studies demonstrating reversal of aging markers by iPSC reprogramming and partial reprogramming; discussion of molecular features such as telomere elongation and epigenetic clock resetting.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism explaining how biological aging can be reversed or modulated at the cellular level via epigenetic reprogramming, addressing fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Apparent "mild depolarization of the inner mitochondrial membrane" as a result of a possible generation of the outer membrane potential.

theories.name: Mitochondrial membrane potential modulation theory in aging

key_concepts.concept: Kinase-linked mild depolarization of mitochondrial inner membrane
key_concepts.description: A proposed mechanism where kinase activity induces a mild depolarization of the mitochondrial inner membrane potential (IMP), which prevents reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation and is lost in aging tissues, suggesting a role in mitochondrial anti-aging programs.

The hypothesis that a positive potential can be generated across the mitochondrial outer membrane by kinase-linked VDAC complexes, which contributes to the total measured membrane potential and may have been previously overlooked in aging studies.

key_concepts.concept: VDAC voltage gating regulated by kinase-linked OMP
key_concepts.description: Voltage-dependent anion channels (VDAC) on the outer membrane may be gated by the metabolically dependent OMP, influencing cell energy metabolism, cell death resistance, and potentially playing a role in the genetic aging program.

theories.evidence: Computational analysis suggesting OMP generation; reinterpretation of experimental data involving fluorescent probes and mitochondrial potential measurements; literature data on mitochondrial hyperpolarization and VDAC knockdowns in cancer cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental mitochondrial mechanism potentially underlying aging processes at the organismal level by proposing a novel component (OMP) affecting mitochondrial function and aging. It provides a causal explanation for changes in mitochondrial membrane potential linked to aging and integrates metabolic regulation and genetic aging programs. Although focused on mitochondria, the mechanism is proposed as a general aging-related process, not limited to a specific disease or organ.

results.title: Carotid Body-Mediated Chemoreflex Function in Aging and the Role of Receptor-Interacting Protein Kinase.

theories.name: RIPK3-mediated necroptosis as a driver of aging-related carotid body dysfunction

key_concepts.description: Necroptosis is a form of programmed cell death distinct from apoptosis, involving receptor-interacting protein kinase-3 (RIPK3). It can be triggered by molecular pathways associated with low-grade inflammation, a hallmark of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Carotid body degeneration and ventilatory impairment
key_concepts.description: Aging leads to degeneration of the carotid body (CB) and reduction in CB chemoreceptor cells, which impairs ventilatory responses to hypoxia and hypercapnia, contributing to breathing disorders.

key_concepts.concept: Role of RIPK3 in CB dysfunction
key_concepts.description: RIPK3-dependent necroptosis contributes causally to CB degeneration and dysfunction during aging, as genetic deletion of RIPK3 in mice prevents age-related ventilatory impairments and breathing disorders.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from adult and aged wild type and RIPK3 knockout mice showing that aged RIPK3-/- mice maintain normal ventilatory responses and lack breathing disorders seen in aged wild type mice.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it proposes a causal mechanism (RIPK3-mediated necroptosis) explaining a fundamental aging-related decline (carotid body dysfunction) that affects organism-level physiology (ventilatory control). It links a molecular pathway to a general aging hallmark (inflammation) and systemic functional decline.

results.title: Unlocking the therapeutic potential of natural stilbene: Exploring pterostilbene as a powerful ally against aging and cognitive decline.

theories.name: Cellular senescence and oxidative damage theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The accumulation of oxidative damage to cellular components such as DNA, proteins, and lipids contributes to the functional decline associated with aging. This damage arises from reactive oxygen species generated during metabolism and leads to cellular dysfunction.

Cells enter a state of permanent growth arrest in response to stress or damage, contributing to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging. Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory factors that exacerbate aging phenotypes.
Progressive shortening of telomeres during cell division limits cellular replicative capacity, triggering senescence and contributing to organismal aging.
Chronic low-grade inflammation, often called 'inflammaging,' is driven by senescent cells and oxidative stress, promoting age-related tissue damage and disease.
Sirtuin proteins regulate cellular resilience, longevity, and metabolic homeostasis by modulating stress responses, DNA repair, and mitochondrial function, thereby influencing aging processes.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews preclinical studies demonstrating pterostilbene's effects on oxidative damage, inflammation, telomere maintenance, cellular senescence, and sirtuin activation, as well as its neuroprotective effects in models of cognitive decline and Alzheimer's disease.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory addresses fundamental aging mechanisms (oxidative damage, senescence, telomere attrition, inflammation) that are broadly applicable to organismal aging, proposes causal mechanisms, and links molecular pathways to systemic aging and cognitive decline.

results.title: Telomere shortening is a sole mechanism of aging in mammals.

theories.name: Telomere Shortening Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening as the sole mechanism of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that the progressive shortening of telomeres during cell division is the fundamental cause of biological aging and lifespan limitation in mammals. This shortening occurs inevitably with each mitotic cycle due to the DNA replication mechanism.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening explains aging phenomena better than oxidative damage
key_concepts.description: The theory argues that oxidative damage cannot fully explain key aging-related phenomena such as malignant tumor growth or why children start aging from a 'zero' baseline rather than inheriting aged cellular states. Telomere shortening provides a more comprehensive causal explanation.

key_concepts.concept: Telomerase activity prevents aging and senescence
key_concepts.description: Cells with active telomerase, such as transformed (cancer) cells, maintain telomere length and thus do not undergo senescence or aging despite high oxidative stress, supporting the causal role of telomere shortening in aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references logical explanations resolving contradictions in telomere length correlations with age, contrasts with oxidative theory limitations, and observations of transformed cells with active telomerase showing no senescence despite oxidative damage.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging applicable at the organism level; it addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases or organs; and it provides an explanatory framework rather than mere correlation or prediction.

results.title: Inflamm-aging as a diverse and context-dependent process: from species and population differences to individual trajectories.

theories.name: Inflamm-aging as a context-dependent eco-evolutionary process

key_concepts.concept: Inflamm-aging as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Inflamm-aging refers to the increase in inflammatory activity associated with aging, traditionally considered a universal feature of the aging process.

The theory emphasizes that inflamm-aging is not universal in a fixed form but varies depending on species, population evolutionary histories, environmental exposures, and individual trajectories, reflecting a norm of reaction rather than a fixed signature.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of inflammatory mechanisms as flexible stress responses
key_concepts.description: Inflammation is viewed as a suite of stress responses that are integrated and regulated differently across biological contexts, shaped by eco-evolutionary factors.

Increased inflammation in aging may reflect mismatches between evolved human biology and modern industrialized environments, including lifestyle factors such as sedentary behavior and cardiometabolic disease prevalence.

The inflammatory aging profile is a norm of reaction, with phenotypic expression modulated by genotype and environment, implying no universal inflamm-aging signature but rather population- and individual-specific patterns.

theories.evidence: Draws on mechanistic, evolutionary, comparative, anthropological, genetic, and environmental studies, including data from non-industrialized populations and eco-evolutionary theory.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal, and broad explanation for aging-related inflammation as a fundamental aging process modulated by evolutionary and environmental factors, addressing systemic aging rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Dissipative scaling of development and aging in multicellular organisms.

theories.name: Dissipation theory of development and aging

key_concepts.description: Organisms undergo dynamic, irreversible processes such as evolution, self-replication, and ontogenesis that dissipate energy. This dissipation is self-regulated and facilitates exponential growth through hierarchical, entropy-lowering self-organization.

Geometric constraints impose ceilings on energy expenditures, promoting thermal optimality during development. This leads to a dissipative scaling across organisms consistent with ecological scaling laws that combine isometric and allometric terms.

key_concepts.concept: Damage tolerance via new dissipative structures
key_concepts.description: Growing organisms can tolerate damage by continuously extending and producing new dissipative structures that are low in entropy, effectively managing internal entropy during growth phases.

When organisms reduce cell division rates and reach a steady adult state, they become thermodynamically unstable, leading to increased internal entropy through damage accumulation, which manifests as aging.

theories.evidence: The paper derives a general theoretical framework based on thermodynamics and ecological scaling laws; no direct experimental data is mentioned in the abstract, but the theory is consistent with known ecological scaling and thermodynamic principles.
