theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a general, organism-level causal mechanism explaining why and how aging occurs based on thermodynamic principles and energy dissipation. It is generalizable, causal, and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a specific organ or disease.

results.title: [The age-related positivity effect: forgetting the negative and/or remembering the positive? An inter-task study].

theories.name: Socioemotional Selectivity Theory

key_concepts.description: Older adults tend to remember positive information better than negative information, reflecting a shift in emotional processing with age.
Older adults reduce processing of negative stimuli, possibly through cognitively costly mechanisms, leading to decreased negativity preference.
The theory posits that as perceived time horizons shrink with age, individuals prioritize emotionally meaningful goals, influencing memory and attention.

theories.evidence: Behavioral data from immediate and delayed free recall and recognition tasks comparing young and older adults' memory for positive, negative, and neutral words.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general psychosocial aging theory explaining why older adults show altered emotional memory patterns, linking cognitive and emotional aging mechanisms at an organismal level.

results.title: Reactive Species in Progeroid Syndromes and Aging-Related Processes.

theories.name: Reactive Species Hormesis Theory in Aging

key_concepts.description: Reactive species can have a dual role depending on their levels: beneficial effects at moderate levels and harmful effects when exceeding certain thresholds. This hormesis varies across different cell types and organisms, indicating a complex regulatory role rather than a simple damaging agent.

key_concepts.concept: Reactive species as modulators of gene expression
key_concepts.description: Beyond their traditional damaging or signaling roles, reactive species influence gene expression patterns, suggesting they participate in regulatory networks that affect aging and degenerative processes.

Studies of progeroid syndromes such as Cockayne syndrome reveal that reactive species contribute to aging-related degeneration in ways that challenge the classical view of reactive species solely causing damage, indicating a more nuanced and multifaceted role.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses recent advances and critical issues, referencing studies on progeroid syndromes (e.g., Cockayne syndrome) and the evolving understanding of reactive species roles, including hormesis and gene expression modulation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how reactive species contribute causally to aging processes at a general organismal level, moving beyond narrow damage descriptions to a broader mechanistic framework involving hormesis and gene regulation. It addresses aging broadly, including accelerated aging syndromes, and proposes underlying mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: The cost of reproduction in women: Reproductive effort and oxidative stress in premenopausal and postmenopausal American women.

theories.name: Life History Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Life history theory posits that organisms allocate limited resources between reproduction and somatic maintenance. Increased reproductive effort may reduce investment in maintenance, potentially accelerating aging and senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative Stress as a Mechanism of Aging
key_concepts.description: Oxidative stress, caused by reactive oxygen species damaging cellular components such as DNA, is proposed as a causal physiological mechanism contributing to accelerated aging and mediating the trade-off between reproduction and somatic maintenance.

theories.evidence: The study measured oxidative damage biomarkers (8-OHdG) and oxidative defense (Cu/Zn-SOD) in serum samples from premenopausal and postmenopausal women, correlating these with reproductive effort indicators such as parity and number of sons.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain why aging occurs through a fundamental trade-off between reproduction and maintenance, proposing oxidative stress as a causal mechanism. It is generalizable beyond a single organ or disease and addresses aging broadly. The paper tests this theory by examining physiological markers linked to aging and reproduction.

results.title: Partial hippocampal inactivation: effects on spatial memory performance in aged and young rats.
Recent Advancement in Elimination Strategies and Potential Rejuvenation Targets of Senescence.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cells enter a state of permanent cell cycle arrest, resist apoptosis, and undergo phenotypic changes. Senescent cells accumulate with age and contribute to aging-related decline.

Senescent cells secrete a complex mixture of pro-inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, matrix metalloproteinases, interleukins, and extracellular matrix molecules that alter the tissue microenvironment and promote inflammation.
SASP factors induce paracrine signaling that can convert neighboring proliferating cells into senescent cells, amplifying the accumulation of senescent cells in tissues.

Senescence has beneficial roles in early development and wound healing where senescent cells are cleared by the immune system, but detrimental effects arise from accumulation of senescent cells during aging.

theories.evidence: Summary of recent studies demonstrating accumulation of senescent cells with age, characterization of SASP, and effects of senescent cell clearance on age-related disorders.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging at the organism level via accumulation of senescent cells and their secretions affecting tissue function and systemic inflammation. It addresses aging broadly, not limited to specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Age differences and the identity negative priming effect: an updated meta-analysis.

theories.name: Inhibitory-based theories of cognitive aging

key_concepts.description: Negative priming refers to the phenomenon where processing of a stimulus is slowed down if it was previously ignored, reflecting inhibitory control mechanisms in cognition.
These theories propose that aging leads to reduced efficiency in inhibitory processes, which manifests as a diminished negative priming effect in older adults compared to younger adults.

theories.evidence: Updated meta-analysis comparing negative priming effects between young and old adults, showing no significant difference, contrasting with earlier findings.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism (inhibitory decline) explaining cognitive aging broadly, with causal implications for why cognitive aging occurs; it is not limited to a narrow phenomenon or specific disease.

results.title: Perceptions of task difficulty predict cognitive effort for older adults.

theories.name: Selective Engagement Theory

key_concepts.description: Older adults perceive higher cognitive costs when engaging in difficult tasks, which leads to reduced motivation to invest effort in those tasks.

key_concepts.concept: Effort allocation based on task difficulty
key_concepts.description: Older adults selectively allocate cognitive effort, disengaging from tasks they perceive as highly difficult, as indexed by physiological measures such as systolic blood pressure response.

theories.evidence: Empirical data from a study comparing younger and older adults performing memory tests, with subjective difficulty ratings and systolic blood pressure response as an index of effort.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a psychosocial mechanism explaining why older adults reduce cognitive effort with increasing task difficulty, addressing a general aging-related change in motivation and effort allocation. It explains a causal mechanism (perceived costs leading to disengagement) relevant to aging at the organismal level.

results.title: Religiosity and social support in Polish older adults: the mediating role of wisdom. Perspectives on Lars Tornstam's theory of gerotranscendence.

theories.name: Gerotranscendence theory

key_concepts.concept: Wisdom as a mediator in aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that wisdom develops as a key psychological resource in late adulthood, mediating complex relationships between religious meaning systems and social support. Wisdom facilitates mature coping mechanisms and personal growth during aging.
Religiousness provides a framework of meaning that interacts with social support and wisdom, influencing how older adults experience and adapt to aging challenges.
Multiple dimensions of social support (perceived, received, protective buffering) are influenced by wisdom and religious meaning, highlighting the psychosocial complexity of aging.

theories.evidence: Empirical data from 466 older adults using validated scales (RMSS, 3D-WS, BSSS) showing mediation effects of wisdom between religious meaning and social support dimensions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a psychosocial aging theory explaining how aging occurs at a general psychosocial level, proposing mechanisms (wisdom mediating religious meaning and social support) relevant to aging processes broadly, not limited to specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Resurrection of endogenous retroviruses during aging reinforces senescence.

theories.name: Endogenous Retrovirus Reactivation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Endogenous retroviruses (ERVs), normally dormant viral elements in the genome, become reactivated during aging, leading to transcription of viral genes and production of retrovirus-like particles (RVLPs). This reactivation is proposed to be a causal factor driving cellular senescence and tissue aging.

The retrovirus-like particles produced by reactivated ERVs act as transmissible signals that induce senescence phenotypes in neighboring young cells, suggesting a mechanism by which aging signals propagate within tissues.

key_concepts.concept: Repression of ERVs Alleviates Aging Phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Suppressing ERV activity reduces cellular senescence and tissue degeneration, indicating that ERV reactivation is not merely a marker but a functional contributor to aging processes.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing HERVK (HML-2) activation in human senescent cells, detection of ERV activation in aged primate and mouse organs, and human elderly tissues and serum; functional blocking of RVLPs with neutralizing antibodies reduces senescence; repression of ERVs alleviates aging phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs at the organismal level via ERV reactivation driving cellular senescence and tissue aging. It is not limited to a single organ or disease and provides mechanistic insight into aging processes.

results.title: Redox modifications in synaptic components as biomarkers of cognitive status, in brain aging and disease.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging (Harman's Theory)

key_concepts.description: Aging results from the progressive accumulation of oxidative modifications caused by reactive oxygen and nitrogen species, which damage cellular components over time.
Oxidative stress contributes to the development and progression of neurodegenerative diseases by impairing neuronal function.
Specific oxidative modifications of neuronal proteins and changes in microRNA expression can serve as biomarkers for brain aging and cognitive decline.

theories.evidence: Citations of Harman's theory, discussion of redox modifications in neuronal proteins, microRNA regulation, and antioxidant effects on cognition.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (oxidative damage) explaining aging broadly, including neurodegeneration, and discusses underlying biochemical processes affecting organism-level aging.

results.title: The killifish germline regulates longevity and somatic repair in a sex-specific manner.

theories.name: Evolutionary tradeoff theory of aging

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that resources allocated to reproduction reduce those available for somatic maintenance and repair, leading to aging. The theory suggests an evolutionary balance where investment in reproduction comes at the cost of lifespan.

The germline may regulate aging by modulating somatic repair and longevity, with different effects depending on sex. Manipulating germline development can alter lifespan and damage repair, indicating a causal role of germline in systemic aging.

The theory incorporates sex-specific differences in how germline depletion affects lifespan and repair mechanisms, implying that evolutionary tradeoffs and aging pathways operate differently in males and females.

theories.evidence: Genetic germline arrest experiments in turquoise killifish showing lifespan extension and enhanced damage repair in a sex-specific manner; single-cell gonadal atlas for cell-type markers; transcriptomic analyses revealing pro-longevity pathways enriched in germline-depleted males; functional conservation demonstrated in Caenorhabditis elegans.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental, organism-level aging mechanism (germline-soma tradeoffs), proposes causal mechanisms (germline regulation of somatic repair and longevity), and discusses evolutionary logic underlying aging.

results.title: Human cells and the finite lifespan theory.

theories.name: Commitment theory of cellular aging

key_concepts.description: Cells start as uncommitted and potentially immortal, but at each cell division, daughter cells have a fixed probability of becoming irreversibly committed to senescence, which leads to eventual cell death after a set number of divisions.

key_concepts.concept: Finite lifespan of diploid fibroblast cultures
key_concepts.description: The finite lifespan of human diploid fibroblast cultures arises because committed cells accumulate and eventually dominate, causing culture senescence, whereas uncommitted cells dilute committed ones and can be lost during subculturing.

key_concepts.concept: Population size effects on culture lifespan
key_concepts.description: Culture lifespan can be decreased by drastic reduction in population size due to loss of uncommitted cells, and conversely, may be extended indefinitely by maintaining large culture sizes or selectively isolating uncommitted cells.

theories.evidence: The theory explains observed properties of human diploid fibroblast cultures including finite lifespan, heterogeneity in growth potential, variation in parallel cultures, and predicts behavior of mixed cultures and effects of population size.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining why cellular aging occurs at the organismal cell population level, addressing fundamental aging processes beyond a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Telomere Dynamics in Cardiovascular Aging: From Molecular Mechanisms to Precision Medicine.

theories.name: Telomere attrition theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening as a driver of cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: Telomeres progressively shorten with cell division and stress, leading to cellular senescence and dysfunction in key cardiovascular cell types such as endothelial cells, cardiomyocytes, and vascular smooth muscle cells.

key_concepts.concept: Molecular mechanisms linking telomere shortening to aging
key_concepts.description: Telomere attrition is mechanistically connected to oxidative stress via the NOX2/PRDX1 axis, epigenetic dysregulation including subtelomeric methylation changes and loss of H3K9me3, and mitochondrial dysfunction, all contributing to aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length as a biomarker for cardiovascular aging
key_concepts.description: Leukocyte telomere length and telomere-associated proteins (e.g., TRF2, POT1) serve as predictive biomarkers for cardiovascular diseases such as coronary artery disease, heart failure, and hypertension, linking telomere dynamics to systemic aging.

Interventions including telomerase activation, senolytic drugs, and CRISPR-based gene editing are explored as strategies to counteract telomere shortening and its downstream effects, aiming to rejuvenate vascular tissues and mitigate aging-related cardiovascular decline.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews molecular pathways (NOX2/PRDX1, epigenetics, mitochondrial dysfunction), clinical biomarker studies (telomere length in leukocytes), and therapeutic approaches (telomerase activators, senolytics, CRISPR editing) with references to experimental and clinical data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining aging at the organismal level via telomere dynamics; it addresses broad aging processes beyond specific diseases; and it integrates molecular, cellular, and clinical evidence.

results.title: Changing landscape of hematopoietic and mesenchymal cells and their interactions during aging and in age-related skeletal pathologies.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Cells enter an irreversible growth arrest state characterized by the secretion of pro-inflammatory factors known as the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP). This state impairs regenerative potential and contributes to tissue dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Senescence-driven functional decline in stem cells
key_concepts.description: Skeletal stem cells (SSCs) and hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) undergo senescence with age, leading to altered lineage commitment, reduced self-renewal, and impaired function, which collectively contribute to systemic aging phenotypes such as osteoporosis and immune decline.
The accumulation of senescent cells and their SASP factors alter the bone marrow microenvironment, disrupting homeostasis and promoting age-related skeletal and hematopoietic pathologies.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews cellular and molecular changes in SSCs and HSCs during aging, highlighting senescence markers, lineage skewing, and functional impairments supported by cited studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (cellular senescence) explaining systemic aging processes affecting multiple stem cell types and their contribution to organismal aging.

results.title: The effect of age and fluid intelligence on working memory in different modalities among elderly individuals: a moderated mediation analysis.

theories.name: Dedifferentiation theory of cognitive aging

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that as certain cognitive abilities decline with age, other cognitive functions compensate to maintain overall cognitive performance. This compensation reflects a dedifferentiation or reduced specialization among cognitive domains in older adults.

Dedifferentiation suggests that different cognitive modalities (e.g., verbal, visuospatial, tactile) become more interrelated or less distinct in aging, allowing one modality to support or compensate for declines in another.
Fluid intelligence is posited to mediate the relationship between different working memory tasks, acting as a compensatory mechanism that becomes more significant as age increases.

theories.evidence: Empirical data from 106 healthy older adults performing forward and backward recall tasks across verbal, visuospatial, and tactile modalities, along with fluid intelligence assessment via Raven Colored Progressive Matrices; statistical analyses including moderated mediation models showing modality-specific effects and mediation by fluid intelligence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining cognitive aging at the organism level, offers a causal explanation (compensation via fluid intelligence), and addresses broad cognitive aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: No Evidence That Life History Strategies Shape Within-Body Mosaics of Ageing.
Unveiling the role of chronic inflammation in ovarian aging: insights into mechanisms and clinical implications.

theories.name: Chronic Inflammation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Chronic Inflammation as a Hallmark of Aging
key_concepts.description: Chronic inflammation is characterized by a prolonged and sustained inflammatory response that persists over time, causing detrimental effects on tissues and organs. It is proposed as a novel hallmark contributing to the aging process by promoting tissue dysfunction and decline.

Chronic inflammation is implicated in the decline of ovarian function and fertility by affecting the oocyte reserve and quality. It interacts with genetic, hormonal, and environmental factors to drive the complex process of ovarian aging.

The theory suggests that chronic inflammation mechanistically contributes to aging by inducing cellular and tissue damage, thereby accelerating functional decline in the ovary and potentially other organs.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review that synthesizes existing literature on chronic inflammation as a hallmark of aging, focusing on ovarian aging. It discusses clinical symptoms and underlying mechanisms but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (chronic inflammation) underlying aging processes, addresses aging broadly (ovarian aging as a model for systemic aging mechanisms), and discusses mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Fetal origin of sex-bias brain aging.

theories.name: Fetal programming of brain aging via epigenetic mechanisms

key_concepts.description: The epigenetic clock (epiclock) measures DNA methylation patterns that correlate with biological age. This concept posits that epigenetic states established during fetal development influence the trajectory of brain aging later in life.
The theory suggests that male and female brains age differently due to sex-specific DNA methylation patterns established in fetal development, which are predictive of epigenetic age in old age.

Methylation patterns shared between the placenta and fetal brain, especially involving genes in the gonadotropin-releasing hormone receptor (GnRHR) pathway, indicate that placental epigenetic regulation may program sex differences in brain aging.

theories.evidence: Mouse epigenetic clock profiling at fetal, postnatal, and aged stages; neural network predictive modeling of methylation; transcriptomic analysis showing coordinated gene expression changes; whole-genome bisulfite sequencing identifying sex-specific methylation sites in placenta and fetal brain; identification of GnRHR pathway involvement.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how biological aging of the brain is programmed early in development via epigenetic modifications, with implications for sex differences in aging. It addresses organism-level aging processes through epigenetic programming rather than focusing on a narrow disease or organ-specific pathology.

results.title: The cycling and aging mouse female reproductive tract at single-cell resolution.

theories.name: Recurrent remodeling-driven fibrosis and chronic inflammation theory of female reproductive tract aging

key_concepts.description: The female reproductive tract undergoes repeated cycles of remodeling during reproductive cycling, including phases of estrous cycle and pregnancy, which are necessary for reproductive function.
Fibroblasts play a central and organ-specific role in orchestrating extracellular matrix reorganization and inflammation during the remodeling processes.

key_concepts.concept: Cumulative remodeling leads to aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: The repeated remodeling events over the reproductive lifespan drive gradual age-related accumulation of fibrosis and chronic inflammation in the female reproductive tract.

key_concepts.concept: Causal link between cycling and aging
key_concepts.description: Chemical ablation of cycling reduces fibrotic accumulation during aging, supporting the hypothesis that recurrent remodeling causally contributes to aging-related tissue changes.

theories.evidence: Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data characterizing gene expression and morphological changes across estrous cycle phases and aging; chemical ablation experiments reducing fibrosis accumulation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how repeated physiological remodeling drives aging-related fibrosis and inflammation in an organ system, with experimental testing supporting causality. While focused on the female reproductive tract, the theory suggests a broader principle of how recurrent physiological remodeling can drive aging.

results.title: "Stereotype embodiment theory"-based intervention to reduce ageism in Japan: Integration with interventions to encourage life planning among younger people.
Age-related changes in older adults' anger and sadness: The role of perceived control.
Coordination of metabolic activity and stress resistance in yeast longevity.

theories.name: Metabolic control and stress resistance theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The regulation of metabolic pathways influences longevity by modulating cellular energy states and biochemical processes that affect aging. Proper metabolic control can extend lifespan by optimizing resource allocation and reducing metabolic damage.

Increased resistance to various stresses (oxidative, environmental, etc.) contributes to longevity by protecting cells from damage accumulation. Stress resistance mechanisms help maintain cellular integrity and function during aging.

key_concepts.concept: Coordination of metabolic control and stress resistance
key_concepts.description: These two physiological processes are interconnected and coordinated, potentially through genetic factors such as the yeast RAS genes, which integrate signals to regulate both metabolism and stress responses, thereby influencing aging.

theories.evidence: Genetic analysis in yeast showing roles of metabolic control and stress resistance; molecular mechanisms emerging; involvement of yeast RAS genes; comparative correlations with aging processes in C. elegans, Drosophila, and dietary restriction in mammals.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain why and how aging occurs through fundamental processes (metabolism and stress resistance) that are generalizable across organisms; proposes causal mechanisms coordinated by genetic factors; addresses aging broadly beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: Fullerenes as Anti-Aging Antioxidants.

theories.name: Antioxidant and mitochondrial uncoupling theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Fullerenes and their derivatives can scavenge reactive oxygen species, reducing oxidative damage, which is a major proposed cause of aging according to damage accumulation theories.

Fullerenes may act as mild mitochondrial uncouplers by functioning as protonophores, which can reduce mitochondrial ROS production and improve mitochondrial function, thereby potentially slowing aging processes.

Theoretical modeling and simulations suggest that fullerenes and their derivatives can penetrate lipid bilayer membranes, enabling their antioxidant and uncoupling actions within mitochondria and cells.

theories.mode: review, discuss, propose hypothesis, theoretical modeling, synthesis
theories.evidence: Review of literature up to 2016, confrontation of experimental data and theoretical modeling, own research results including simulations of fullerene transport and mitochondrial membrane interactions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging related to oxidative damage and mitochondrial function, applicable at organism level; it discusses underlying causes (ROS damage, mitochondrial uncoupling) and integrates experimental and theoretical data.

results.title: Novel neuroendocrine and metabolic mechanism provides the patented platform for important rejuvenation therapies: targeted therapy of telomere attrition and lifestyle changes of telomerase activity with the timing of neuron-specific imidazole-containing dipeptide-dominant pharmaconutrition provision.

theories.name: Telomere Attrition and Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length as a biomarker and causal factor of aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres are repetitive DNA-protein structures at chromosome ends that protect genomic integrity. Their length shortens with cell division and oxidative stress, and this shortening is associated with cellular senescence, a state of irreversible growth arrest contributing to organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence driven by telomere shortening
key_concepts.description: Telomere attrition triggers cellular senescence, which is implicated in age-related disorders and systemic aging processes. Senescent cells accumulate and contribute to tissue dysfunction and chronic inflammation.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic modulation of telomerase activity and telomere maintenance
key_concepts.description: Interventions aimed at slowing telomere shortening or activating telomerase can potentially delay aging and age-related diseases. The paper discusses pharmacological and nutritional approaches, including neuron-specific imidazole-containing dipeptides, to regulate telomere dynamics and cellular senescence.

theories.evidence: Review of recent patents and preliminary longitudinal studies associating longer telomeres with better survival; discussion of neuron-specific imidazole-containing dipeptides (carnosine, carcinine) regulating telomere length and telomerase activity; references to associations between telomere length and multiple age-related diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains a fundamental biological aging mechanism (telomere attrition leading to cellular senescence), proposes causal mechanisms, and addresses aging broadly across multiple tissues and diseases. The paper discusses therapeutic modulation of this mechanism, indicating engagement with the theory beyond description.

results.title: The aging of emotional words processing in implicit and explicit emotion task: an ERP study.

theories.name: Socioemotional Selectivity Theory

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that as people age, their perception of time changes, leading to a prioritization of emotionally meaningful goals and experiences over information-seeking or future-oriented goals.
Older adults tend to focus more on positive emotional information and show a bias toward processing positive over negative stimuli, which contrasts with younger adults who may show a negativity bias.
The theory suggests that older adults engage distinct cognitive and neural mechanisms, including both bottom-up and top-down processes, to regulate emotional experience and attention.

theories.evidence: Behavioral data showing older adults' positivity bias in explicit emotion tasks and ERP data revealing distinct early and late emotion effects in young versus older adults during implicit and explicit tasks.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a generalizable psychosocial aging theory explaining why emotional processing changes with age, proposes mechanisms involving motivational and cognitive shifts, and addresses aging at the organismal level.

results.title: Evolution of Human Susceptibility to Alzheimer's Disease: A Review of Hypotheses and Comparative Evidence.

theories.name: Evolutionary susceptibility theory of Alzheimer's disease

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that humans have evolved unique susceptibilities to Alzheimer's disease that are not observed in other nonhuman primates, suggesting evolutionary changes in the human lineage that increase AD risk.

Differences in brain structure and molecular pathways between humans and other primates may underlie the distinct susceptibility to AD, indicating that evolutionary modifications in these systems contribute to disease vulnerability.

Some primate species may have evolved protective mechanisms against AD, and understanding these adaptations can shed light on why humans lack similar protections, highlighting evolutionary trade-offs.

theories.evidence: Comparative neuroanatomical and molecular studies cited; evolutionary hypotheses reviewed; discussion of recent evidence for protective changes in primates.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain why aging-related neurodegeneration (AD) occurs specifically in humans from an evolutionary perspective, proposing causal evolutionary mechanisms underlying general organism-level aging vulnerability.

results.title: Streptozotocin and L-Buthionine-Sulfoximine Decrease Neuron Membrane Lipid Packing and Alter Insulin Signaling.

theories.name: Membrane aging hypothesis

key_concepts.concept: Membrane composition and fluidity as drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis posits that changes in the lipid composition, permeability, and fluidity of cell membranes contribute fundamentally to aging processes and aging-related diseases, including neurodegeneration.

key_concepts.concept: Membrane environment influences membrane protein function
key_concepts.description: Membrane proteins such as the insulin receptor require an optimal membrane lipid environment for proper partitioning and signaling functionality, linking membrane aging to systemic cellular dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Alterations in membrane lipids induce insulin resistance
key_concepts.description: Changes in cholesterol and sphingomyelin content and membrane packing can disrupt insulin signaling pathways, suggesting a mechanistic link between membrane aging and metabolic dysfunction.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from neuro-2a cells treated with STZ and BSO showing altered cholesterol and sphingomyelin levels, changes in membrane packing measured by Laurdan probe, gene expression changes (Srebf2, Cyp46a1), and insulin signaling impairment.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging at the cellular membrane level affecting systemic aging processes such as insulin resistance; it is not limited to a single disease but addresses a fundamental aging-related cellular change.

results.title: Large-scale chromatin reorganization reactivates placenta-specific genes that drive cellular aging.

theories.name: Epigenomic landscape reorganization theory of cellular aging

key_concepts.concept: Chromatin reorganization as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that large-scale changes in chromatin structure, including heterochromatin loss and euchromatin weakening, disrupt nuclear architecture and epigenetic regulation, thereby driving cellular aging processes.
A gradual increase in epigenetic entropy reflects loss of ordered chromatin states, leading to deregulation of gene expression patterns that contribute to aging phenotypes.

De-repression of specific gene clusters, such as placenta-specific beta-1 glycoprotein (PSG) genes, occurs due to chromatin changes and these genes exacerbate cellular aging, serving as potential biomarkers and mechanistic drivers.
Switching between topological compartments in the genome alters the spatial organization of chromatin, influencing gene expression and epigenetic states that underlie aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Large-scale epigenomic analyses comparing isogenic young, senescent, and progeroid human mesenchymal progenitor cells; identification of chromatin state changes and gene expression alterations linked to aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining cellular aging through chromatin and epigenetic reorganization, applicable beyond a single tissue or disease, addressing fundamental aging processes.

results.title: SUAG/on across the adult lifespan.
Longitudinal evidence for immunosenescence and inflammaging in free-living great tits.

theories.name: Immunosenescence and Inflammaging Theory

key_concepts.description: Refers to the age-related decline in immune function, characterized by changes such as a peak and subsequent decline in cellular oxidative burst responsiveness, indicating reduced acute immune responses in older individuals.

Describes the chronic, low-grade inflammation that increases with age, evidenced by elevated levels of inflammatory mediators like leukotriene B4 (LTB4) and granulocyte counts, contributing to systemic aging and age-related pathologies.

Links between inflammation and oxidative damage are highlighted by the positive association of LTB4 with oxidative damage markers and negative association with antioxidant enzyme activity, suggesting that chronic inflammation disrupts redox homeostasis during aging.

theories.evidence: Longitudinal tracking of inflammatory parameters, oxidative burst responsiveness, LTB4 levels, granulocyte counts, and oxidative stress markers in 54 free-living great tits over three years; statistical analysis showing age-dependent trends consistent with immunosenescence and inflammaging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses general aging mechanisms (immune system aging) with causal explanations (chronic inflammation and immune decline) applicable at organism level, supported by longitudinal data in a natural population.

results.title: The putative roles of FSH and AMH in the regulation of oocyte developmental competence: from fertility prognosis to mechanisms underlying age-related subfertility.
Systems biology of human aging: A Fibonacci time series model.

theories.name: Fibonacci fractal dynamics theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that human aging can be modeled as a fractal time series, where temporal fractals govern the progression of aging processes at a macro scale, extending beyond previously studied micro scales.

key_concepts.concept: Intrinsic aging rates shaped by entropy
key_concepts.description: Aging rates are influenced by entropy, suggesting that the increase in disorder or energy dispersal within biological systems is a fundamental driver of aging dynamics.

key_concepts.concept: Fibonacci fractal dynamics as organizing principle
key_concepts.description: The model posits that Fibonacci sequence-based fractal patterns underlie the timing and emergence of key life cycle traits, implying an intrinsic biological rhythm or structure to aging.

theories.evidence: Supported by research findings cited in the paper, though specific experiments or data are not detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging based on fractal and entropy dynamics, applicable at the organismal level, and offers an organizing principle for aging processes.

results.title: Novel insights into reproductive ageing and menopause from genomics.

theories.name: Programmed reproductive aging theory

key_concepts.description: Menopause is triggered by a physiological timer dependent on a threshold number of ovarian follicles, suggesting a programmed mechanism rather than simple chronological aging.

key_concepts.concept: Decoupling of reproductive senescence from chronological age
key_concepts.description: Reproductive aging is thought to be governed by physiological aging processes distinct from chronological age, indicating an intrinsic biological program regulating reproductive lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Molecular pathways linking external menopause triggers to oocyte chromosome segregation
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that specific molecular pathways connect the external signals that initiate menopause to the internal mechanisms controlling meiotic errors in oocytes, which affect fertility outcomes.

theories.evidence: Insights from large-scale genomics studies, animal models, molecular targets identified via next-generation sequencing and systems biology approaches.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for reproductive aging as a programmed biological process with organism-level implications, supported by molecular and genomic data.

theories.name: Epigenetic age acceleration models in reproductive aging

key_concepts.concept: Use of epigenetic clocks to predict menopause onset
key_concepts.description: Epigenetic age acceleration models may provide biomarkers that predict the timing of menopause, linking epigenetic changes to reproductive aging mechanisms.
Combining genomics data with epigenetic models offers a predictive toolkit for understanding and potentially modulating reproductive lifespan.

theories.evidence: Preliminary genomics and epigenetic studies suggesting correlations between epigenetic age and menopause timing.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it links epigenetic mechanisms to reproductive aging broadly, but evidence and mechanistic details remain incipient.

results.title: Circadian clock communication during homeostasis and ageing.

theories.name: Circadian clock communication theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Circadian clocks are endogenous timekeeping mechanisms present in almost all cell types that regulate physiological processes to anticipate daily environmental rhythms, thereby maintaining organismal homeostasis.

Circadian clocks in different tissues communicate through systemic and local signals, with the central clock in the hypothalamus coordinating peripheral clocks to synchronize physiological functions across the organism.
The mechanisms of circadian clock communication deteriorate with aging, leading to impaired homeostasis and contributing to aging-related morbidities.

key_concepts.concept: Interventions targeting circadian clocks to improve healthspan
key_concepts.description: Dietary, behavioral, and pharmacological interventions may restore or compensate for the decline in circadian clock communication during aging, potentially improving healthspan.

theories.evidence: The abstract references growing evidence linking decay of clock communication with aging-related morbidities and mentions interventions, implying citation of experimental and observational studies, though no specific data or experiments are detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process by proposing that the decay of circadian clock communication drives systemic aging-related decline, thus meeting generalizability and causal explanation criteria. It addresses aging broadly at the organismal level rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

results.title: Deciphering the physical properties of cell fate decision making in mTOR signaling.

theories.name: mTOR signaling dynamics theory of cellular aging and fate decisions

key_concepts.concept: mTOR signaling as a regulator of cell fate
key_concepts.description: The mTOR pathway integrates nutrient signals to regulate metabolic homeostasis and influences cellular states including normal, tumor, prosurvival, and aging. Its signaling dynamics determine transitions between these states.

key_concepts.concept: Indirect negative feedback between mTORC1 and mTORC2
key_concepts.description: A key mechanism generating biphasic behaviors in mTOR signaling is the indirect negative feedback of mTORC1 on mTORC2, which modulates the pathway’s activity and influences cell fate transitions.

key_concepts.concept: Nonequilibrium physical dynamics governing state transitions
key_concepts.description: Cellular state transitions are driven by nonequilibrium forces including gradient and curl forces, with transitions occurring via dominant kinetic paths that are irreversible and involve crossing energy barriers, such as the aging state barrier that inhibits tumor formation.

key_concepts.concept: Potential landscape and entropy production framework
key_concepts.description: The theory applies potential landscape theory and entropy production to quantify the stability and transitions of cellular states, providing a physical perspective on how mTOR signaling controls aging and tumorigenesis.

theories.evidence: Mathematical modeling of insulin-induced mTOR signaling, analysis of biphasic behaviors, potential landscape and entropy calculations, kinetic path analysis revealing transition irreversibility and barriers.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how mTOR signaling dynamics causally regulate cellular aging and fate decisions at a general organismal level, proposing mechanisms of state transitions and feedback loops. It addresses aging broadly through a fundamental signaling pathway and integrates physical principles to explain aging-related processes, meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Is anger, but not sadness, associated with chronic inflammation and illness in older adulthood?
Individual Cell Longevity, 'Life's Timekeeper', and Metazoan Evolution.

theories.name: Life's Timekeeper oscillator theory of metazoan aging and evolution

key_concepts.description: A fundamental intracellular oscillator, termed 'Life's Timekeeper', evolved in the ancestor of metazoans to regulate and extend the longevity of individual cells. This oscillator modulates the frequency of cellular processes, thereby influencing how long cells can survive before senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Coordination of development and aging via oscillator synchronization
key_concepts.description: In multicellular organisms, the oscillator remains synchronized across all cells, coordinating cell-cell signaling and timing developmental processes as well as aging and senescence. This synchronization controls organismal lifespan by regulating when cells become senescent and how they are replaced.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary role in enabling specialized cell types and complex traits
key_concepts.description: Slower oscillator frequencies allowed for extended cell longevity, which enabled the evolution of many specialized terminally differentiated cells. This reduced the need for continual stem cell replacement and allowed long-lived cells like neurons to persist, facilitating the evolution of brains, complex behavior, and intelligence.

key_concepts.concept: Influence on morphological evolution and life history traits
key_concepts.description: The oscillator influences morphological evolution by altering developmental timing, affecting size and shape changes. It also mediates correlations between life history traits, acting as a key internal variable alongside environmental selection pressures.

theories.evidence: The abstract presents a theoretical proposal based on evolutionary reasoning and conceptual synthesis; no direct experimental data or citations are mentioned in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general, organism-level causal mechanism explaining how aging and lifespan are regulated via an intracellular oscillator. It addresses fundamental aging processes, links cellular longevity to organismal aging, and integrates evolutionary perspectives, thus fulfilling generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope requirements.

results.title: Effect of haemodialysis on the brain and heart assessed using multiparametric MRI.
The Role of Epigenetics in Accelerated Aging: A Reconsideration of Later-Life Visual Loss After Early Optic Neuropathy.

theories.name: Epigenetic Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic mechanisms as drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that changes in epigenetic markers, such as DNA methylation and histone modifications, contribute causally to the aging process by altering gene expression patterns that regulate cellular function and organismal aging.

Neuronal injury can promote accelerated epigenetic aging, leading to earlier or more severe functional decline than expected from chronological age alone. This is supported by observations in diseases like multiple sclerosis and postpolio syndrome.

key_concepts.concept: Partial epigenetic reprogramming as a rejuvenation strategy
key_concepts.description: Experimental evidence suggests that partial reversal of epigenetic aging marks can enhance neuronal survival and improve function, indicating that epigenetic aging is not only a marker but a modifiable causal mechanism of aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of prior clinical observations of late-life vision loss after early neuronal injury, references to studies in mice and nonhuman primates demonstrating partial reversal of cellular aging and improved neuronal survival and function after epigenetic reprogramming.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (epigenetic changes) explaining how aging occurs at the organismal level, links injury to acceleration of systemic aging processes, and discusses potential for intervention. It is not limited to a single organ or disease but frames neuronal injury effects within broader aging mechanisms.

results.title: Inhibition and aging: similarities between younger and older adults as revealed by the processing of unattended auditory information.
A novel information theoretic approach reveals loss of effective biomolecular communication in aging muscle cells.

theories.name: Biomolecular Communication Decline Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging leads to deterioration in the communication between transcription factors (TFs) and their target genes (TGs), resulting in disrupted information flow necessary for maintaining organismal function.

key_concepts.concept: Increased Biological Noise and Reduced Channel Capacity
key_concepts.description: The decline in communication efficiency is attributed to escalating biological noise and a loss of precision in TF regulation of TGs, which reduces the channel capacity of the biomolecular communication system.

key_concepts.concept: Selective Preservation and Loss of Communication Channels
key_concepts.description: Certain TF:TG pairs, such as those involved in fatty acid oxidation, show the greatest loss of communication with aging, whereas communication related to essential functions like RNA synthesis is relatively preserved, suggesting resource reallocation during aging.

theories.evidence: Analysis of skeletal muscle single cell RNA-seq data from young, middle-aged, and aged animals using information theory metrics such as mutual information and channel capacity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging disrupts fundamental biomolecular communication processes at the organismal level, supported by mechanistic quantification and applicable beyond a single narrow phenomenon.

results.title: The "common cause hypothesis" of cognitive aging: evidence for not only a common factor but also specific associations of age with vision and grip strength in a cross-sectional analysis.
The longevity bottleneck hypothesis: Could dinosaurs have shaped ageing in present-day mammals?

theories.name: Longevity Bottleneck Hypothesis

key_concepts.description: The hypothesis proposes that the dominance of dinosaurs for over 100 million years imposed evolutionary pressures on early mammals, which were small, nocturnal, and short-lived. This long period favored rapid reproduction over longevity, shaping mammalian aging patterns.

key_concepts.concept: Loss or inactivation of longevity-associated genes and pathways
key_concepts.description: Due to the evolutionary pressure for rapid reproduction during the dinosaur era, mammals lost or inactivated genes and biological pathways that would otherwise support long lifespans and regenerative traits.

key_concepts.concept: Legacy effects on present-day mammalian aging
key_concepts.description: Although some mammals, including humans, have evolved longer lifespans, their aging processes remain constrained by genetic and evolutionary legacies originating from the dinosaur-dominated period.

theories.evidence: The hypothesis is supported by comparative observations that reptiles and amphibians exhibit slower or negligible aging phenotypes and regenerative traits absent in mammals; evolutionary reasoning about mammalian life history during dinosaur dominance is used as indirect evidence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The hypothesis attempts to explain why mammals age faster compared to some other vertebrates by proposing an evolutionary mechanism affecting fundamental aging processes at the organismal level. It provides a causal explanation linking evolutionary history to genetic and physiological aging traits, thus meeting the criteria for a generalizable aging theory.

results.title: PRDM16 Reduces Cellular Senescence by Upregulating GSTM1.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a causal driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of senescent cells (SnCs) in tissues contributes to the aging process and aging-related organ dysfunction. Senescent cells promote tissue deterioration and functional decline, thereby driving systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative DNA damage as a trigger of senescence
key_concepts.description: Oxidative stress leads to DNA damage, which acts as a key driver of cellular senescence. Reducing oxidative DNA damage can attenuate senescence and delay aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Regulation of senescence by transcriptional factors
key_concepts.description: PRDM16, a transcriptional regulator, modulates cellular senescence by upregulating genes involved in antioxidant defense, such as GSTM1, thereby reducing oxidative damage and senescence.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing PRDM16 levels decline with age in multiple organs; global and tissue-specific Prdm16 deletion accelerates senescence and aging-related organ injury; lentiviral PRDM16 delivery reduces senescence; mechanistic evidence that PRDM16 upregulates GSTM1 and improves glutathione metabolism to inhibit oxidative DNA damage.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process (cellular senescence) with causal mechanisms (oxidative DNA damage, transcriptional regulation), generalizable across multiple organs and systemic aging, not limited to a specific disease or organ.

results.title: In vivo DNA replication dynamics unveil aging-dependent replication stress.
Telomere dynamics and reproduction.

theories.name: Telomere theory of reproductive aging

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that oocyte aging results from two main factors: first, oocytes in older women have undergone more cell cycles during fetal oogenesis, leading to telomere shortening; second, oocytes accumulate oxidative damage over the woman's lifetime, further compromising telomere integrity.

Telomeres shorten with each cell division due to the end replication problem, providing a molecular clock that tracks cellular aging. This shortening is especially relevant in oocytes that have undergone many divisions during fetal development.

key_concepts.concept: Sensitivity of telomeres to oxidative damage
key_concepts.description: Telomeres contain guanine-rich sequences that are particularly vulnerable to oxidative stress, which can cause damage even in postmitotic cells like oocytes, contributing to aging.

Telomerase, which can maintain or elongate telomeres, is largely inactive during oogenesis and early development, resulting in oocytes having short telomeres that approach a critical threshold for viability.

key_concepts.concept: Consequences of telomere attrition on fertility
key_concepts.description: Shortened telomeres and telomeropathy are linked to diminished ovarian reserve, abnormal embryo development, and infertility, supporting the causal role of telomere dynamics in reproductive aging.

theories.evidence: The theory is supported by observations in mice with induced telomere attrition and women with natural telomeropathies showing reproductive deficits; also, comparative telomere dynamics in sperm and embryos are discussed.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain why reproductive aging occurs at the organismal level by proposing telomere shortening and oxidative damage as causal mechanisms. It generalizes beyond a narrow phenomenon by linking telomere dynamics to fundamental aging processes in female germ cells. Thus, it meets the criteria of generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope within reproductive aging as a component of organismal aging.

results.title: An account of a century of ATP research.
Constant and continuous growth reduction as a possible cause of ageing.

theories.name: Growth Equilibrium Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Post-embryonic growth involves a continuous decrease in certain growth parameters relative to others, observed consistently across species such as chickens, rats, and nematodes, suggesting a generalizable growth pattern.

key_concepts.concept: Shared regulation of growth and aging by growth promoters and inhibitors
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the same substances that promote and inhibit growth also regulate aging processes, implying a mechanistic link between growth regulation and aging.
Aging results from a constantly changing balance between growth-promoting and growth-inhibiting factors, where shifts in this equilibrium drive the aging process.

theories.evidence: Comparative growth pattern analysis across chickens, rats, and nematodes demonstrating identical growth reduction patterns; theoretical reasoning linking growth regulators to aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, organism-level mechanism explaining how aging occurs via shifts in growth regulatory balance, providing a causal explanation beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Energy Metabolism Focused Analysis of Sexual Dimorphism in Biological Aging and Hypothesized Sex-specificity in Sirtuin Dependency.

theories.name: Sex-specific sirtuin dependency theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Sirtuins are a family of regulatory proteins that mediate a molecular circuit balancing survival and proliferation, which influences senescence and aging processes.

Biological aging exhibits significant sex differences in onset, mechanisms, and effects, involving genetic, cellular, metabolic, endocrine, and epigenetic factors that differ between males and females.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary decoupling of female longevity from sirtuin dependency
key_concepts.description: After reproductive maturity, females may have evolved a sex-limited decoupling of longevity from sirtuin-driven metabolic networks, meaning female lifespan extension is less dependent on sirtuin activity compared to males.

key_concepts.concept: Energy homeostasis as a central link between aging, sex, and reproduction
key_concepts.description: Aging, sex, and reproduction are evolutionarily intertwined through systemic energy homeostasis, which is regulated differently in males and females, influencing aging trajectories.

theories.evidence: The paper interrogates existing literature on sexual dimorphism in genetic, cellular, metabolic, endocrine, and epigenetic aging processes and synthesizes these findings to propose the hypothesis of sex-limited sirtuin dependency decoupling. It also outlines considerations for experimental testing.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory attempts to explain why and how biological aging occurs with a generalizable mechanism involving sirtuin regulation and sexual dimorphism; it proposes causal mechanisms linking energy metabolism, sex differences, and aging; and it addresses systemic aging rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Cellular mechanisms in brain aging: Focus on physiological and pathological aging.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress and Cellular Damage Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) causes damage to cellular components such as lipids, proteins, and DNA, leading to functional decline in cells and tissues. This process is proposed as a central driver of aging, especially in metabolically active tissues like the brain.

Cells enter a state of permanent growth arrest in response to damage or stress, contributing to tissue dysfunction and chronic inflammation. Senescent cells accumulate with age and are implicated as causal contributors to organismal aging.
Chronic low-grade inflammation, often termed 'inflammaging,' results from persistent cellular damage and senescence, exacerbating tissue deterioration and functional decline during aging.
Progressive accumulation of DNA lesions impairs cellular function and genome integrity, promoting aging phenotypes and increasing vulnerability to pathological conditions.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews cellular processes such as oxidative stress, senescence, inflammation, and DNA damage, citing cumulative evidence including the beneficial effects of antioxidant and anti-inflammatory supplements on cognitive decline.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a general causal explanation for aging as a fundamental biological process, discusses mechanisms applicable at the organism level (especially brain aging), and links cellular damage accumulation to physiological and pathological aging.

results.title: Adrenergic regulation of astroglial aerobic glycolysis and lipid metabolism: Towards a noradrenergic hypothesis of neurodegeneration.

theories.name: Noradrenergic hypothesis of cognitive decline and neurodegeneration

key_concepts.concept: Role of noradrenergic system in brain energy metabolism
key_concepts.description: Noradrenaline released from locus coeruleus neurons regulates astroglial aerobic glycolysis and lipid metabolism, which are critical for maintaining neural network viability and energy balance necessary for cognitive functions such as learning and memory.

key_concepts.concept: Astrocyte dysfunction as a primary driver of neurodegeneration
key_concepts.description: Neurodegeneration and cognitive decline in Alzheimer's disease may arise from a primary failure of astrocytes, which are essential for ionic balance, neurotransmitter turnover, synaptic connectivity, and energy homeostasis in the CNS.

key_concepts.concept: Link between locus coeruleus degeneration and hypometabolic CNS state
key_concepts.description: The loss of locus coeruleus neurons leads to impaired noradrenaline release, causing a hypometabolic state in the brain that contributes to cognitive decline and Alzheimer's disease pathology.

key_concepts.concept: Dual role of astroglial metabolism in neuroprotection and neurodegeneration
key_concepts.description: Adrenergic control of astroglial glycolysis and lipid droplet metabolism can be protective but under certain conditions may promote neurodegeneration, suggesting a complex regulatory mechanism influencing aging-related cognitive decline.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review that compiles evidence linking noradrenergic system impairment, astrocyte dysfunction, and metabolic changes in the CNS to Alzheimer's disease and cognitive decline, citing clinical observations of locus coeruleus degeneration and hypometabolism.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging-related cognitive decline and neurodegeneration at the organismal brain level, linking cellular metabolism and neurotransmitter systems to systemic aging processes in the CNS.

results.title: Identification of the redox-stress signaling threshold (RST): Increased RST helps to delay aging in C. elegans.

theories.name: Redox-stress Signaling Threshold (RST) theory

key_concepts.concept: Dual role of Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS)
key_concepts.description: ROS can have both beneficial and harmful effects on living organisms depending on their concentration. At lower concentrations, ROS act advantageously, while at higher concentrations, they become detrimental.
RST is defined as the maximum level of ROS below which redox stress confers beneficial effects. This threshold determines the transition point between advantageous and harmful ROS effects.

The RST is not fixed and can be increased by adaptive responses such as early-life starvation, heat stress, or exercise, which enhance the organism's capacity to tolerate higher ROS levels beneficially.
Raising the RST improves Redox-stress Response Capacity (RRC) and healthspan, suggesting that expanding the beneficial ROS range through early stimulation can delay aging processes.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from C. elegans showing lifespan effects under different paraquat-induced oxidative challenges; observations that early-life stressors increase RST and improve healthspan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how redox stress modulates aging at the organismal level, with adaptive modulation of a threshold influencing aging rate.

results.title: Mitochondrial dysfunction drives cellular senescence: Molecular mechanisms of inter-organelle communication.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction-driven cellular senescence theory

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a driver of cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial impairment leads to cellular senescence, which is a fundamental hallmark of aging. Dysfunctional mitochondria contribute to aging by disrupting cellular homeostasis and promoting senescence pathways.

The theory emphasizes the role of functional crosstalk between mitochondria and other organelles such as the endoplasmic reticulum, lysosomes, and peroxisomes. This communication regulates key processes including calcium signaling, lipid metabolism, inflammatory responses, nutrient sensing, mitophagy, redox balance, and lipid homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Organelle network dysfunction as a unified framework for aging
key_concepts.description: Defects in the dynamic interactions among organelles propagate mitochondrial damage and trigger cellular senescence, suggesting that aging can be understood as integrated organelle network dysfunction rather than isolated mitochondrial failure.

theories.mode: review, synthesize, propose (novel paradigm emphasizing inter-organelle communication)
theories.evidence: Systematic dissection of molecular mechanisms and regulatory hubs such as mitochondria-associated ER membranes (MAMs); discussion of pathways involving lysosomal and peroxisomal coordination; citations of established and emerging research in mitochondrial and organelle biology.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how mitochondrial dysfunction and inter-organelle communication drive cellular senescence, a core aging hallmark, thus addressing aging at the organismal level through fundamental cellular processes.

results.title: Re: JP-TR-2024-286891 'The ageing brain: Cortical overactivation - How does it evolve?'.

theories.name: Compensation-to-Maladaptation Developmental Theory of Brain Aging

key_concepts.description: Older adults show increased cortical activity during motor and motor-cognitive tasks, which initially serves as a compensatory mechanism to maintain performance despite age-related neural decline.

key_concepts.concept: Progression from Compensation to Negative Overcompensation
key_concepts.description: Over time, the compensatory cortical overactivation can become excessive and maladaptive, leading to inefficient brain activation patterns that impair rather than support function.

key_concepts.concept: Dedifferentiation and Desegregation of Brain Networks
key_concepts.description: With aging, brain network activity becomes less distinct and less segregated, reflecting a loss of specialized and lateralized activation patterns, which is linked to the maladaptive overcompensation process.

key_concepts.concept: Relative Task Difficulty and Neural Strategy Utilization
key_concepts.description: Older adults experience increased relative task difficulty even when absolute task difficulty is constant, prompting the use of neural strategies such as increased cortical activation and reduced inhibitory control, similar to young adults under high task demands.

theories.evidence: Review of existing literature showing age-related cortical overactivation, changes in brain network segregation, behavioral correlations with motor performance, and comparison with young adults under increased task difficulty.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal developmental mechanism explaining how brain aging evolves over time at the organismal level, linking neural activation changes to functional outcomes and aging progression.

theories.name: Static Compensation vs. Dedifferentiation Theories of Brain Aging

key_concepts.description: Theories that interpret increased brain activity in older adults as a beneficial adaptation to counteract neural decline.
Theories that view increased and less selective brain activation as inefficient and non-specific, reflecting neural decline and loss of functional specialization.

theories.evidence: Citations of prior research supporting both compensatory and dedifferentiation interpretations of cortical overactivation in aging brains.
theories.criteria_reasoning: These are established theories explaining brain aging mechanisms but are critiqued here for being static and not accounting for progression over time.

results.title: Autophagy as an Anti-senescent in Aging Neurocytes.

theories.name: Autophagy Dysfunction Theory of Neurocyte Aging

key_concepts.concept: Autophagy as a regulator of cell homeostasis and longevity
key_concepts.description: Autophagy is a cellular process responsible for the turnover of aberrant intracellular components, which is fundamental to maintaining neuron homeostasis and preventing cellular aging.

Neurocyte aging is characterized by impaired autophagy, including downregulation of autophagy-related genes (e.g., ATG5-ATG12, Beclin-1) and altered autophagy markers (LC3-II/LC3-I ratio, p62), leading to metabolic stress and accelerated aging.

key_concepts.concept: Molecular loss and cellular identity decline
key_concepts.description: Aging neurocytes lose cell identity through molecular changes such as epigenetic, transcriptomic, proteomic alterations, and autophagy dysfunction, which collectively contribute to the aging phenotype.

key_concepts.concept: Autophagy modulation as an anti-senescent intervention
key_concepts.description: Targeting autophagy pathways, including key molecules like mTOR, AMPK, and Sirtuins, can slow or reverse neurocyte aging and improve outcomes in neurodegenerative diseases.

theories.evidence: The abstract references gene expression changes, molecular markers of autophagy dysfunction, and the involvement of known regulatory molecules (mTOR, AMPK, Sirtuins). It also mentions therapeutic potential based on these mechanisms, implying citation of experimental and clinical data though not detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (autophagy dysfunction) explaining why neurocytes age, links cellular changes to organism-level aging processes (neurodegeneration), and discusses underlying molecular pathways and potential interventions.

results.title: DNA Instability in Neurons: Lifespan Clock and Driver of Evolution.

theories.name: Neuronal DNA Instability Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Neuronal DNA as the initial substrate of aging
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that the instability and damage accumulation in neuronal DNA is a fundamental cause of aging, positioning neuronal DNA damage as the primary substrate from which aging processes originate.

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of DNA damage in specific genome regions
key_concepts.description: The theory explores how neuronal DNA accumulates damage over time, focusing on which genome regions are most affected and how this contributes to aging and lifespan determination.

key_concepts.concept: Trade-off between neuronal plasticity and DNA instability
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that evolutionary adaptations such as sleep, increased neuron numbers, adult neurogenesis, somatic polyploidy, and RNA editing represent biological strategies to balance the benefits of neuronal plasticity against the costs of DNA instability.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent experimental data supporting the hypothesis; reference to Olovnikov's 2003 proposal; discussion of evolutionary and biological processes linked to neuronal DNA instability.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining aging at the organism level through neuronal DNA damage accumulation, discusses underlying causes and evolutionary logic, and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a narrow disease or organ-specific phenomenon.

results.title: Interferon regulatory factor 7 impairs cellular metabolism in aging adipose-derived stromal cells.

theories.name: Sterile activation of cell-autonomous self-defense pathway theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging involves the activation of immune-related pathways in the absence of infection ('sterile'), indicating that intrinsic cellular mechanisms trigger immune responses as a part of the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Role of IRF7 as a driver of metabolic dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Interferon regulatory factor 7 (IRF7) expression increases with age in adipose-derived stromal cells, leading to impaired mitochondrial function, altered amino acid biogenesis, and reduced degradation of branched-chain amino acids, which collectively contribute to metabolic dysfunction during aging.

key_concepts.concept: Link between dysregulated immunity and metabolic dysfunction in aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes a causal connection between immune dysregulation and metabolic decline as fundamental hallmarks of aging, mediated by cell-autonomous pathways involving IRF7.

theories.evidence: Multi-omics and functional analyses of adipose-derived stromal cells from young and midlife mice showing increased IRF7 expression correlating with mitochondrial impairment and altered amino acid metabolism.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism linking immune pathway activation to metabolic dysfunction as a fundamental aging process at the organismal level, not limited to a single disease or organ.

results.title: Growth differentiation factor 11: A proangiogenic drug as a potential antiaging regulating molecule.

theories.name: Circulating proyouthful factor theory (GDF11 as a rejuvenation factor)

key_concepts.description: Aging is influenced by the balance of circulating factors in the blood, some promoting aging ('proaging') and others promoting youthfulness ('proyouthful'). The presence of these factors systemically affects multiple organs and tissues.

key_concepts.concept: GDF11 as a critical rejuvenation factor
key_concepts.description: Growth differentiation factor 11 (GDF11), a member of the TGFβ superfamily, is proposed as a key circulating molecule in young blood that can rejuvenate aging organs by promoting vascular and neural plasticity, thus improving regenerative capacity.

GDF11 exerts its effects by binding to specific receptor complexes and activating intracellular signaling via the TGFβ-Smad and BMP-Smad pathways, which mediate its proangiogenic and proneurogenic functions.

Parabiosis experiments linking young and old mice circulations identified GDF11 as an antihypertrophic factor that rejuvenates the aging heart, supporting the systemic role of circulating factors in aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of parabiosis experiments in mice, biochemical characterization of GDF11 signaling pathways, and observed effects on vascular, neural, cardiovascular, and wound healing functions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for systemic aging involving circulating factors that influence multiple tissues and organs. It addresses aging broadly and proposes underlying molecular pathways.

results.title: Beneficial death: A substantial element of evolution?

theories.name: Beneficial death theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that a shorter lifespan, including premature death due to aging, can be evolutionarily advantageous by increasing relative fitness under certain conditions.
Shorter-lived individuals reproduce more frequently, allowing faster generational turnover, which accelerates adaptation and can outcompete longer-lived individuals.

key_concepts.concept: Optimal lifespan as an evolved trait
key_concepts.description: Simulations suggest that natural selection can establish an optimal lifespan that balances survival and reproductive success, even in challenging environments.

theories.evidence: Simulations modeling evolutionary dynamics showing that shorter lifespan can confer fitness benefits and promote continuous evolution.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable evolutionary mechanism explaining why aging (shortened lifespan) occurs, offers a causal explanation for aging as an adaptive trait, and addresses aging at the organismal and evolutionary level.

results.title: Resetting the aging clock through epigenetic reprogramming: Insights from natural products.

theories.name: Epigenetic aging clock theory

key_concepts.description: Epigenetic changes such as DNA methylation, histone modifications, chromatin remodeling, and RNA modifications regulate gene expression patterns that change with age, influencing biological aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic reprogramming as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Disordered or imbalanced epigenetic modifications accumulate during aging and contribute causally to the aging phenotype, making epigenetic reprogramming a key mechanism underlying biological age beyond chronological age.

key_concepts.concept: Aging clock based on epigenetic marks
key_concepts.description: The epigenetic clock uses patterns of epigenetic modifications to differentiate biological age from chronological age, serving as a biomarker and mechanistic indicator of systemic aging.

Natural products can potentially restore balanced epigenetic states, thereby resetting the aging clock and alleviating age-related dysfunctions, suggesting a causal role of epigenetic dysregulation in aging.
