key_concepts.description: This theory posits that aging causes a broad, general slowing down of all cognitive processes, which impacts various cognitive tasks including word retrieval.

theories.evidence: The study measured reaction times in a covert naming task and found that overall reaction time for word retrieval, controlling for psychomotor slowing, was the best predictor of spontaneous word-finding difficulty and executive function decline.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (processing speed decline) explaining cognitive aging broadly, not limited to specific organs or diseases.

theories.name: Transmission Deficit Hypothesis (TDH)

key_concepts.description: TDH posits that aging leads to a specific breakdown in the transmission of activation from semantic representations (lemmas) to phonological word forms, causing word-finding difficulties.

theories.evidence: Strong support was found for TDH in picture-word interference effects, showing increased semantic interference and decreased phonological facilitation with age.
theories.criteria_reasoning: While it addresses a specific cognitive mechanism, it is focused on language production and word retrieval, which may be somewhat narrow but still connected to general cognitive aging processes.

theories.name: Inhibitory Deficit Hypothesis (IDH)

key_concepts.description: The IDH suggests that aging impairs the ability to inhibit or suppress irrelevant information, leading to cognitive difficulties such as increased interference during word retrieval.

theories.evidence: The study found limited support for IDH, with some increase in semantic interference across the lifespan but no strong association with word-finding difficulty in connected speech.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general cognitive mechanism (inhibitory control decline) underlying aging-related cognitive changes.

results.title: mTORC1-Induced Bone Marrow-Derived Mesenchymal Stem Cell Exhaustion Contributes to the Bone Abnormalities in Klotho-Deficient Mice of Premature Aging.

theories.name: Stem cell exhaustion theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by the decline in the functional capacity and number of adult stem cells, leading to impaired tissue maintenance and regeneration. This exhaustion contributes to systemic aging phenotypes, including bone abnormalities.

Increased activity of the mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1 (mTORC1) in bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells leads to decreased autophagy and disrupted stem cell homeostasis, driving stem cell functional decline and exhaustion.

key_concepts.concept: Klotho deficiency as an aging model
key_concepts.description: Deficiency of the Klotho protein in mice induces premature aging phenotypes, including bone abnormalities, by promoting stem cell dysfunction via mTORC1 activation, linking genetic regulation to aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from Klotho-deficient mice showing hyperproliferation but functional decline of BMSCs, elevated mTORC1 activity, decreased autophagy, rescue of stem cell function by soluble Klotho protein and mTORC1 inhibitor rapamycin, and improved bone phenotype and lifespan upon rapamycin treatment.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains a fundamental aging process (stem cell exhaustion) with causal mechanisms (mTORC1 activation and autophagy suppression), is generalizable to organismal aging beyond bone, and is supported by mechanistic experimental evidence.

results.title: Pro-Angiogenesis Therapy and Aging: A Mini-Review.

theories.name: Angiogenesis hypothesis of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with a reduction in capillary density throughout the body, leading to diminished microcirculation. This decline contributes to common age-related symptoms such as muscle weakness, cold intolerance, and slow wound healing.

key_concepts.concept: Reduced levels of angiogenic growth factors (AGFs)
key_concepts.description: The decrease in capillary density is attributed to declining systemic levels of angiogenic growth factors during old age. These growth factors, such as vascular endothelial growth factor, are critical for maintaining and promoting blood vessel formation.

key_concepts.concept: Old age as a deficiency state of AGFs
key_concepts.description: Old age is conceptualized as a deficiency state similar to hormonal declines, where reduced AGFs lead to impaired angiogenesis and consequent physiological decline.
Based on the hypothesis, pro-angiogenesis therapy using recombinant AGFs is proposed as a treatment to alleviate age-related symptoms by restoring microcirculation.

theories.evidence: Citations of over 40 papers documenting reduced capillary density in aged humans and animals, 7 reports showing declining AGF levels, and references to animal experiments and short-term clinical trials using recombinant AGFs.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging at the organism level (decline in angiogenesis), explains why aging symptoms occur systemically, and suggests an underlying biological cause rather than describing isolated phenomena.

results.title: To aggregate or not to aggregate - Is it a matter of the ribosome?

theories.name: Ribosomal Infidelity-Induced Proteostasis Decline Theory

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that errors during translation at the ribosome, which is the most error-prone step in gene expression, lead to the production of misfolded proteins. These errors expose hydrophobic residues, causing proteins to aggregate.

Misfolded proteins with exposed hydrophobic residues aggregate intracellularly and extracellularly, overwhelming cellular clearance mechanisms. This aggregation is toxic and drives neuronal cell loss, particularly in neurodegenerative diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Age-Related Decline in Cellular Buffering Capacity
key_concepts.description: Aging reduces the cell's ability to buffer and manage proteostasis, making cells more vulnerable to the effects of translational errors and protein aggregation, which may explain the late onset of neurodegenerative diseases.

The theory suggests a two-hit model where the first hit is the age-related decline in cellular proteostasis capacity, and the second hit is the increased translational errors leading to protein misfolding and aggregation, driving neurodegeneration.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent evidence showing that manipulating ribosomal accuracy affects lifespan in model organisms and that reduced translational accuracy correlates with neurodegeneration.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how aging-related decline in proteostasis and ribosomal fidelity contribute to systemic aging processes, particularly neurodegeneration. It addresses fundamental aging mechanisms (protein homeostasis and translational fidelity) with organism-level implications.

results.title: Unique Patterns in Amino Acid Sequences of Aging-Related Proteins.
From gestational chronodisruption to noncommunicable diseases: Pathophysiological mechanisms of programming of adult diseases, and the potential therapeutic role of melatonin.

theories.name: Developmental Origins of Health and Disease (DOHaD) theory

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that exposures and environmental conditions during critical periods of development, such as gestation, can program physiological systems in ways that influence disease susceptibility in adulthood.

Disruption of maternal-fetal circadian rhythms during gestation due to factors like light pollution and shift work leads to desynchronization that adversely affects fetal development and increases risk for noncommunicable diseases later in life.
Maintaining healthy circadian rhythms throughout life is important to mitigate the programmed risks from early-life chronodisruption and to prevent or reduce the burden of adult diseases.

theories.evidence: Associations between gestational chronodisruption and adverse cardiovascular, neurodevelopmental, metabolic, and endocrine outcomes are cited; the paper references ongoing research into melatonin supplementation as a potential intervention.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how early-life environmental factors program aging-related disease susceptibility at the organism level, addressing broad aging-related health outcomes beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Differential effects of lifespan-extending genetic manipulations in an animal model of MJD/SCA3.

theories.name: Insulin/IGF-1 Signaling Pathway in Aging and Neuroprotection

key_concepts.description: Reduction in insulin/IGF-1 signaling is known to increase lifespan in multiple organisms by altering nutrient sensing and metabolic pathways, which modulate aging processes at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Neuroprotection via modulation of proteostasis and stress responses
key_concepts.description: Downregulation of insulin/IGF-1 signaling activates cellular stress responses such as the heat shock response, which helps maintain protein homeostasis and reduces toxic protein aggregation, thereby protecting neurons in neurodegenerative disease models.

Not all lifespan-extending genetic manipulations confer equal neuroprotection; specifically, interventions targeting insulin/IGF-1 and related nutrient-sensing pathways improve motor phenotypes in a C. elegans model of SCA3/MJD, while others like mitochondrial dysfunction or germline ablation do not.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from a C. elegans neuronal model of SCA3/MJD showing that genetic mutations reducing insulin/IGF-1 signaling and eat-2 signaling extend lifespan and improve motor function; chronic treatment with an insulin/IGF-1 signaling inhibitor also demonstrated therapeutic benefit.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (nutrient sensing via insulin/IGF-1 signaling) underlying aging and links it causally to neurodegeneration, addressing aging broadly beyond a single disease and proposing mechanistic explanations.

results.title: Long-COVID-19 autonomic dysfunction: An integrated view in the framework of inflammaging.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Inflammaging refers to the persistent, systemic, low-grade inflammation that develops with age and contributes to the pathogenesis of age-related diseases. This chronic inflammatory state is proposed as a fundamental mechanism underlying biological aging.

A proinflammatory sympathetic overdrive combined with decreased anti-inflammatory vagal parasympathetic activity disrupts neuro-immune-endocrine homeostasis. This imbalance promotes chronic inflammation and accelerates aging processes.

Reduced hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis activity and impaired cholinergic anti-inflammatory pathway (CAP) diminish anti-inflammatory responses, further fueling inflammaging and increasing vulnerability to age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Observations of autonomic dysfunction, low cortisol levels, increased pro-inflammatory markers, and neurotransmitter alterations in Long COVID patients; prior literature linking ANS imbalance to aging-related inflammation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how systemic chronic inflammation driven by ANS imbalance contributes to aging and age-related diseases, connecting viral infection sequelae (Long COVID) to fundamental aging processes.

results.title: Cell clocks and neuronal networks: neuron ticking and synchronization in aging and aging-related neurodegenerative disease.

theories.name: Circadian clock disruption theory of aging-related neurodegeneration

key_concepts.description: Cells possess endogenous molecular clocks based on clock genes that form interconnected, self-sustained transcriptional/translational feedback loops regulating biological rhythms.

The master circadian pacemaker in the hypothalamic suprachiasmatic nucleus and other brain regions involved in learning and memory exhibit circadian oscillatory behavior, which is crucial for cognitive function and neural network information processing.

key_concepts.concept: Disruption of circadian rhythms in aging and neurodegeneration
key_concepts.description: Aging-dependent neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s disease involve disturbances in intracellular clock signaling and intercellular synchronization of brain clocks, contributing to cognitive decline and disease pathology.

theories.evidence: Review of recent data implicating circadian regulation in disease susceptibility, longevity, cognitive performance, molecular pathways under circadian control, clinical disturbances of circadian rhythms in neurodegenerative diseases, and animal model data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (circadian clock disruption) underlying aging-related neurodegeneration, offers causal explanations linking molecular clock dysfunction to aging phenotypes, and addresses aging broadly through brain and systemic rhythmic regulation.

results.title: Contribution of metamemory beliefs to age-related differences in the effect of emotion on judgments of learning.

theories.name: Socioemotional Selectivity Theory

key_concepts.description: Older adults tend to focus more on positive information and memories, showing a bias toward positive emotional content in cognitive processes such as judgments of learning.
Younger adults demonstrate a bias toward emotionally salient information, regardless of valence, which influences their judgments of learning differently compared to older adults.
Individuals hold beliefs about how emotion affects memory, which differ by age group and contribute to age-related differences in cognitive judgments related to learning and memory.

theories.evidence: Three experiments with Chinese participants showing age-related differences in emotional effects on judgments of learning and corresponding metamemory beliefs.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it explains a general psychosocial aging process (emotional and cognitive changes with age) with causal mechanisms (metamemory beliefs influencing cognitive biases), applicable broadly to aging populations.

results.title: Intrinsic amyloid deposition following proteostasis impairment in osteoarthritic chondrocytes: Insights and therapeutic approaches.

theories.name: Proteostasis impairment and amyloid deposition theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Proteostasis involves cellular mechanisms such as autophagy, the unfolded protein response, and the ubiquitin-proteasome system that maintain protein homeostasis. Impairment of these systems leads to accumulation of misfolded proteins and amyloid fibrils, which are linked to aging tissues.

key_concepts.concept: Amyloid deposition as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Amyloid fibrils accumulate intrinsically in aged cells, here specifically in osteoarthritic chondrocytes, suggesting that amyloidosis is a consequence of proteostasis failure and contributes to tissue degeneration during aging.

key_concepts.concept: Proteostasis failure as a causal mechanism of aging
key_concepts.description: The failure of proteostasis is proposed as a fundamental aging mechanism that drives cellular dysfunction and disease progression, such as osteoarthritis, by allowing toxic protein aggregates to accumulate.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing amyloid fibrils in ex vivo cartilage samples from OA patients; in vitro induction of ER stress and autophagy blockage in chondrocytes leading to amyloid deposition; mitigation of effects by polyphenols.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (proteostasis failure) underlying aging-related tissue degeneration, supported by mechanistic experiments, and links to a hallmark of aging. Although focused on OA chondrocytes, the theory is framed as a general aging process applicable to organismal aging.

results.title: HSF1, Aging, and Neurodegeneration.

theories.name: Proteostasis Decline Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Heat Shock Factor 1 (HSF1) as a Master Regulator
key_concepts.description: HSF1 regulates the induction of heat shock protein chaperones that maintain protein quality control (QC) and proteostasis, which are critical for cellular protection against stress.

key_concepts.concept: Age-Dependent Deterioration of Protein Quality Control
key_concepts.description: With aging, the function of HSF1 and the proteostasis network declines, leading to impaired protein QC and increased vulnerability to protein misfolding and aggregation.

key_concepts.concept: Role of Intrinsically Disordered Proteins in Aging
key_concepts.description: Proteins with intrinsically disordered regions are sensitive to cellular environmental changes that occur during aging, contributing to dysfunction in protein organization and signaling pathways.

key_concepts.concept: Link Between Proteostasis Decline and Neurodegenerative Diseases
key_concepts.description: The dysfunction of HSF1 and accumulation of disease-related protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases are proposed as manifestations of age-related proteostasis collapse.

theories.evidence: Overview of HSF1 structural, functional, and energetic properties; discussion of age-related decline in HSF1 function; correlation with neurodegenerative disease protein aggregation; literature citations implied though not detailed in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (proteostasis decline via HSF1 dysfunction) explaining why aging occurs at the organismal level, linking molecular QC failure to systemic aging and disease vulnerability.

results.title: Molecular genetic approaches to the study of cellular senescence.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a terminal proliferative arrest
key_concepts.description: Cells lose the ability to synthesize DNA and divide, resulting in a permanent cessation of proliferation while maintaining basic metabolic functions. This state is proposed as a fundamental cellular model for aging.

Senescence is considered a dominant active process controlled by specific genes or gene pathways, rather than a passive deterioration. The identification of multiple complementation groups suggests at least four genes or pathways involved in regulating senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Molecular mechanisms involving gene expression and cell-cycle regulation
key_concepts.description: Changes in gene expression and cell-cycle-associated products, including the active production of DNA synthesis inhibitors, are key steps in the cascade leading to senescence, indicating a regulated molecular mechanism.
Studying immortal cells that have bypassed senescence provides insights into the genes and pathways that govern the senescence program, highlighting the genetic control of this aging-related process.

theories.evidence: Summarizes experimental evidence supporting senescence as an active process, differences between young and senescent cells, gene expression changes, identification of complementation groups, and chromosome transfer studies locating senescence genes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental, generalizable biological aging process at the cellular level; proposes causal genetic and molecular mechanisms; addresses aging broadly as cellular senescence is widely considered a driver of organismal aging.

results.title: Sex differences in adult lifespan and aging rate across mammals: A test of the 'Mother Curse hypothesis'.

theories.name: Mother Curse hypothesis

key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited exclusively from the mother, which can lead to sex-specific evolutionary pressures on mtDNA mutations.
Because mtDNA is maternally inherited, deleterious mutations that affect males but not females can accumulate over generations, potentially causing reduced male lifespan and faster aging.

key_concepts.concept: Sex differences in lifespan and aging rate
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis proposes that the accumulation of male-harming mtDNA mutations explains why males often have shorter lifespans and faster aging rates compared to females across species.

theories.evidence: Empirical analysis of 128 mammalian populations (104 species) comparing adult lifespan and aging rates with mtDNA neutral substitution rates in wild and captive conditions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining sex differences in aging at the organism level, with evolutionary logic and broad applicability across mammals.

results.title: Telomere Length Is a Driving Hallmark for Aging-Related Biochemical Hallmarks: Evidence From the Shared Genetic Effect and Causal Inference.

theories.name: Telomere Shortening as a Driving Hallmark of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere Length as a Biomarker and Driver
key_concepts.description: Telomere length (TL) shortens with age and is considered both a marker and a causal factor influencing aging-related biochemical changes. Shortened telomeres contribute to cellular senescence and organismal aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Shared Genetic Components Linking TL and Aging Hallmarks
key_concepts.description: Genetic analyses reveal that telomere length shares genetic correlations with multiple aging-related biochemical markers, suggesting common molecular pathways underlying aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Causal Effects of Telomere Length on Biochemical Hallmarks
key_concepts.description: Using bidirectional Mendelian randomization, the study infers that telomere length causally influences levels of several biochemical markers related to aging, such as GDF15, IGF-1, sex hormone binding globulin, testosterone, fasting insulin, and blood cell counts.

theories.evidence: Comprehensive genetic analyses including shared genetic analysis, pleiotropic analysis, gene enrichment analysis, and bidirectional Mendelian randomization analyses demonstrating genetic correlations and causal effects between telomere length and aging-related biochemical hallmarks.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory explains a fundamental aging process (telomere shortening) with generalizability to organism-level aging, proposes causal mechanisms linking telomere length to systemic aging hallmarks, and addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Making sense of the ageing methylome.

theories.name: Epigenetic aging theory

key_concepts.concept: DNA methylation changes as aging markers
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that changes in DNA methylation patterns, including differential and variable methylation at individual CpG sites, accumulate over time and reflect biological aging processes.
At the whole methylome level, increased entropy and altered correlation networks represent a loss of epigenetic information fidelity, which may causally contribute to aging phenotypes.
Modulating DNA methylation patterns and the enzymes responsible for methylation can influence healthspan and lifespan, suggesting a mechanistic role for epigenetic regulation in aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews various age-related DNA methylation changes, statistical tools for quantification, evidence linking methylation to aging phenotypes, and longevity interventions targeting methylation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process (epigenetic changes) with proposed causal mechanisms (methylation damage and entropy) and links to organism-level aging phenotypes and longevity interventions, meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Polyphenols and Diets as Current and Potential Nutrition Senotherapeutics in Alzheimer's Disease: Findings from Clinical Trials.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence refers to the state where cells irreversibly stop dividing and develop a distinctive phenotype that contributes to aging and age-related diseases. It is considered a fundamental biological process underlying organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells contribute causally to age-related diseases such as Alzheimer's disease
key_concepts.description: Accumulation of senescent cells and their secretory phenotype (SASP) can promote tissue dysfunction and chronic inflammation, thereby driving the onset and progression of neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's disease.

key_concepts.concept: Targeting senescent cells (senotherapy) as an intervention strategy
key_concepts.description: Therapeutic approaches aimed at selectively eliminating senescent cells or modulating their phenotype may delay aging processes and age-related pathologies, representing a causal intervention based on the senescence theory.

theories.evidence: Summary of preclinical studies showing neuroprotective effects of senotherapeutic polyphenols (quercetin, resveratrol, EGCG, curcumin, fisetin); limited and inconclusive human trials; calls for further mechanistic studies and clinical trials.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: generalizable to organismal aging, proposes causal mechanism (cellular senescence driving aging and disease), addresses broad aging process beyond a single disease by linking senescence to systemic aging and AD.

results.title: Testing for age- and sex-specific mitonuclear epistasis in Drosophila.

theories.name: Mother's Curse Hypothesis

key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial DNA is inherited exclusively from the mother, which can lead to the accumulation of mutations that are deleterious to males but neutral or less harmful to females.
Because of maternal inheritance, mutations harmful to males may persist and accumulate, potentially causing reduced male fitness, especially with aging.
The cooperation between mitochondrial and nuclear genomes is essential for efficient ATP production, and mismatches between these genomes can lead to fitness consequences.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from fertility measurements of males and females at different ages in 27 mitonuclear populations of Drosophila melanogaster with matched or mismatched mitonuclear genomes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining sex-specific aging effects due to mitochondrial inheritance and mitonuclear genome interactions, addressing organism-level aging processes.

results.title: Aging and inhibition: Introduction to the special issue.
Delirium and frailty in older adults: Clinical overlap and biological underpinnings.

theories.name: Frailty and Delirium as Manifestations of Accelerated Biological Aging

key_concepts.concept: Frailty as a Risk Factor for Delirium
key_concepts.description: Frailty, a geriatric syndrome characterized by decreased physiological reserves and increased vulnerability, is proposed to increase the risk of developing delirium. This concept suggests a causal link where the presence of frailty predisposes older adults to acute cognitive disturbances.

Both frailty and delirium share underlying biological mechanisms including inflammation, neurodegeneration, metabolic insufficiency, and vascular burden. These common pathways suggest that the two syndromes may represent overlapping or interconnected processes within the biology of aging.

There is some evidence supporting that delirium episodes may accelerate the progression of frailty, indicating a bidirectional relationship. This concept implies that delirium might not only be a consequence but also a driver of biological aging processes manifested as frailty.

The review highlights the geroscience approach, which integrates aging biology to understand and target multiple age-related conditions simultaneously. This framework supports the idea that frailty and delirium are interconnected manifestations of systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: Systematic literature review of 118 articles from PubMed, expert content synthesis highlighting overlapping clinical and biological features, and identification of common mechanisms from existing studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging-related syndromes (frailty and delirium) through shared biological aging mechanisms, addressing organism-level aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: High Investment in Reproduction Is Associated with Reduced Life Span in Dogs.

theories.name: Life History Trade-Off Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that organisms allocate limited resources between reproduction and bodily maintenance. High investment in reproduction reduces resources available for self-maintenance, leading to accelerated aging and shorter lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary fitness maximization over lifespan maximization
key_concepts.description: Natural selection favors traits that maximize reproductive success rather than longevity. This explains why organisms may evolve to prioritize reproduction at the cost of reduced lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Influence of body size and growth rate on lifespan
key_concepts.description: Faster growth and larger adult size are associated with shorter lifespans, reflecting an underlying life history strategy where rapid development and reproduction come at the expense of longevity.

theories.evidence: Empirical data from domestic dog breeds showing that reproductive investment negatively correlates with lifespan, controlling for ancestry and gene flow; larger breeds show stronger negative effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it provides a generalizable evolutionary explanation for aging based on resource allocation trade-offs, proposes causal mechanisms linking reproduction and lifespan, and addresses aging at the organismal level.

results.title: Insights into age-related osteoporosis from senescence-based preclinical models and human accelerated aging paradigms.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging is driven by the buildup of senescent cells in tissues, which cease to divide and accumulate over time, contributing to functional decline.

Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory cytokines, proteases, and growth factors (SASP) that have deleterious local and systemic effects, promoting tissue dysfunction and age-related pathologies such as osteoporosis.
Targeting and removing senescent cells genetically or pharmacologically can mitigate aging phenotypes, supporting the causal role of senescence in aging processes.

theories.evidence: Preclinical animal models based on telomere dysfunction and focal radiation to induce senescence; genetic and pharmacological removal of senescent cells; human accelerated aging paradigms with bone loss phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains aging as a fundamental process via senescent cell accumulation and SASP effects; proposes causal mechanisms; addresses systemic aging beyond bone alone.

theories.name: Mitochondrial Dysfunction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Age-related decline in mitochondrial function, including defects in respiratory chain complexes, contributes to cellular dysfunction and aging phenotypes.
Mutations in the mitochondrial DNA polymerase gamma gene (Polg) cause accumulation of mtDNA mutations leading to mitochondrial dysfunction, which models accelerated aging and osteoporosis in mice.
Mitochondrial dysfunction is implicated in multiple age-related diseases including osteoporosis, suggesting a systemic role in aging.

theories.evidence: Mouse models with Polg knock-in mutations recapitulating respiratory chain defects; correlation with osteoporosis phenotypes; references to human accelerated aging syndromes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria by proposing a fundamental causal mechanism (mitochondrial dysfunction) underlying systemic aging and age-related diseases.

theories.name: Lineage Switching and Wnt Signaling Inhibition in Aging Bone

key_concepts.description: With aging, bone marrow stromal cells shift differentiation from osteoblasts to adipocytes, contributing to bone loss.
Wnt signaling, critical for osteoblast differentiation and bone formation, is inhibited in aging and accelerated aging syndromes, exacerbating bone loss.
Aging and progeroid conditions increase osteoclast formation and activity, leading to enhanced bone resorption.

theories.evidence: Clinical observations in premature aging syndromes with bone loss; mechanistic links to signaling pathways and cell lineage changes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it addresses mechanisms contributing to systemic aging phenotypes (bone loss) but is more focused on bone-specific processes; however, linked to general aging via accelerated aging syndromes.

results.title: T cell control of inflammaging.

theories.name: Inflammaging driven by T cell dysregulation

key_concepts.description: With aging, T cells undergo functional alterations including dysregulated cytokine and chemokine production and impaired cytotoxicity. These changes affect the immune system's ability to maintain homeostasis and respond appropriately to stimuli.

The altered T cell functions contribute to the development and persistence of low-grade systemic inflammation, termed inflammaging, which is a hallmark of biological aging and is implicated in various age-related physiological dysregulations.

key_concepts.concept: Mechanistic link between T cell aging and systemic physiological outcomes
key_concepts.description: Age-related changes in T cells are proposed to drive abnormal physiological outcomes through mechanisms that sustain or exacerbate inflammaging, thereby influencing the aging process at the organismal level.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing existing knowledge on T cell changes with age and their role in inflammaging, citing prior studies on cytokine dysregulation, immune senescence, and inflammation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (inflammaging) at the organismal level by proposing causal mechanisms involving T cell functional decline and its systemic effects. It is generalizable beyond a single disease or organ and addresses a core aging hallmark.

results.title: Stem Cell Rejuvenation by Restoration of Youthful Metabolic Compartmentalization.

theories.name: Epigenetic alteration-driven stem cell aging theory

key_concepts.description: Mild mitochondrial stress occurring with aging leads to lysosomal-mediated decreases in the mitochondrial citrate transporter (CiC) in mesenchymal stem cells, disrupting metabolic compartmentalization.

key_concepts.concept: Nuclear acetyl-CoA deficit and histone hypoacetylation
key_concepts.description: Reduced CiC causes a deficit of acetyl-CoA in the nucleus, resulting in hypoacetylation of histones, which alters the epigenome and affects gene expression patterns related to stem cell function.
The epigenetic changes favor adipogenesis over osteogenesis in MSCs, impairing their ability to maintain bone tissue integrity, a hallmark of aging-related stem cell dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Rejuvenation via restoration of nuclear acetyl-CoA
key_concepts.description: Restoring nuclear acetyl-CoA levels by ectopic expression of CiC or acetate supplementation rejuvenates aged MSCs, restoring their osteogenic differentiation potential.

theories.mode: discuss, propose (mechanistic link between metabolism, epigenetics, and stem cell aging), suggest intervention
theories.evidence: Citations of recent reports demonstrating mitochondrial stress effects on CiC, experimental restoration of CiC or acetate supplementation rejuvenating MSC differentiation; reference to lifespan extension by citrate in Drosophila.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking mitochondrial metabolic changes to epigenetic alterations driving stem cell aging, which is a fundamental aging process affecting organismal aging.

results.title: "Inner clocks" of glass-forming liquids.
Processing speed mediates the relationship between brain structure and semantic fluency in aging.

theories.name: Processing Speed Theory of Cognitive Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that a general slowing of cognitive processing speed is a fundamental cause of age-related declines in various cognitive functions, including semantic fluency.

Processing speed is proposed to mediate the relationship between structural brain changes (such as reductions in gray matter volume and white matter integrity) and cognitive performance decline, suggesting that slower processing speed explains how brain aging impacts cognition.

Age-related reductions in gray matter volume and white matter integrity in fronto-temporal regions and connecting tracts are linked to declines in semantic fluency, with processing speed acting as the key mechanism connecting these brain changes to cognitive outcomes.

theories.evidence: Empirical data from younger and older healthy participants performing semantic fluency and digit symbol tests, combined with diffusion tensor imaging showing brain structural differences; hierarchical regression analyses demonstrating processing speed fully mediates the effect of brain structure on semantic fluency.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (processing speed decline) explaining broad cognitive aging effects, supported by brain structural correlates; it addresses aging at the organism-level cognitive function and proposes a causal mediator rather than mere correlation.

results.title: Dedifferentiation of brain functional gradient captures cognition performance and stroke occurrence: A UK Biobank study.
Hypothesis: functional age and onset of autosomal dominant genetic prion disease.

theories.name: Functional Age-Dependent Onset Hypothesis for Genetic Prion Disease

key_concepts.concept: Age-related onset variability in genetic prion disease
key_concepts.description: Genetic prion disease caused by PRNP mutations typically manifests at or after middle age, but the exact age of onset varies widely even among individuals with the same mutation, suggesting factors beyond the mutation itself influence disease timing.

key_concepts.concept: Proportionality of disease onset to species lifespan
key_concepts.description: Mouse models of genetic prion disease develop symptoms within months, whereas humans develop symptoms after decades, indicating that the time to disease onset scales with the species' lifespan, implying a link between aging processes and disease initiation.

key_concepts.concept: Functional aging as a driver of disease initiation
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis proposes that the initiation of genetic prion disease is strongly influenced by the biological aging process, such that disease onset correlates with an organism’s functional age rather than chronological age alone.

key_concepts.concept: Potential for aging suppression to delay disease
key_concepts.description: If aging processes causally influence prion disease onset, then interventions that suppress or slow aging could potentially delay the onset of genetic prion disease.

theories.evidence: Comparative observations of disease onset timing in humans versus mouse models; variability in onset age among humans with identical mutations; logical inference relating disease onset to species lifespan and aging processes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism linking aging (functional age) to disease onset timing, attempts to explain why aging influences disease manifestation at an organismal level, and suggests underlying principles connecting aging and genetic prion disease onset.

results.title: Alexey Olovnikov: theoretical biology beyond the margins.

theories.name: Marginotomy hypothesis (telomere theory of aging)

key_concepts.description: The hypothesis identifies the inability of DNA polymerases to fully replicate the ends of linear chromosomes (telomeres), leading to progressive shortening of telomeres with each cell division.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening as a driver of cellular aging
key_concepts.description: Telomere attrition limits the replicative capacity of cells, causing cellular senescence or apoptosis, which contributes to organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Link between molecular mechanisms and aging
key_concepts.description: The theory connects a fundamental molecular mechanism (telomere shortening) to the broader biological process of aging, suggesting a causal role in systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Historical theoretical discovery by Olovnikov, later experimental confirmation of telomere shortening and its role in cell aging, citations to molecular biology and gerontology literature.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: generalizable to organism-level aging, proposes a causal mechanism (telomere shortening), addresses broad aging process beyond specific diseases or organs.

theories.name: Olovnikov's later theoretical landscape linking ontogenesis and aging

key_concepts.concept: Integration of aging with all stages of ontogenesis
key_concepts.description: Olovnikov expanded his theoretical framework beyond telomeres to encompass molecular mechanisms that connect development (ontogenesis) and aging as a continuous process.

key_concepts.concept: Reevaluation of telomere role in aging
key_concepts.description: He reconsidered the primacy of telomeres in aging, suggesting a more complex, multifactorial theoretical model that includes other molecular and developmental factors.

theories.evidence: Biographical and theoretical analysis of Olovnikov's evolving ideas, no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Appears to propose a broader theoretical framework linking development and aging, which could meet criteria if fully elaborated; however, details are limited in abstract.

results.title: Review on ginseng and its potential active substance G-Rg2 against age-related diseases: Traditional efficacy and mechanism.
Multiple deletions in mitochondrial DNA are present in senescent mouse brain.

theories.name: Mitochondrial DNA deletion accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of mtDNA deletions with age
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that deletions in mitochondrial DNA accumulate progressively in tissues such as the brain during aging, contributing to cellular dysfunction and organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of direct repeats in deletion formation
key_concepts.description: Direct repeat sequences in mtDNA are hypothesized to facilitate the formation of deletions by promoting misalignment or recombination events, thus initiating the accumulation of deletions associated with aging.

theories.evidence: Detection of multiple large mtDNA deletions (3726-, 3867-, and 4236-bp) in aged mouse brain but not in young mice, sequencing of deletion junctions revealing direct repeats of 13-15 bp.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (mtDNA deletions initiated by direct repeats) underlying a fundamental aging process (mitochondrial dysfunction contributing to aging), with generalizability beyond a single disease or organ, addressing systemic aging.

results.title: Telomeres in ecology and evolution: A review and classification of hypotheses.

theories.name: Telomere-related hypotheses in ecology and evolution

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length and shortening as causal factors
key_concepts.description: Some hypotheses propose that telomere length or the rate of telomere shortening causally influence organismal performance, life-history traits, and fitness, implying a mechanistic role of telomeres in aging or senescence processes.
These hypotheses explore how changes in telomere length affect physiological functions or organismal viability, potentially linking telomere biology to aging and life-history evolution.

The review identifies multiple, sometimes contradictory, hypotheses regarding telomeres, reflecting different assumptions about causality and functional impact, highlighting the complexity and diversity of theoretical perspectives in telomere research.

theories.evidence: Synthesis and classification of existing hypotheses from ecology and evolution literature; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper reviews multiple hypotheses related to telomeres that attempt to explain mechanisms underlying aging and life-history traits at an organismal level, discussing causality and functional consequences, thus meeting the criteria for aging theories.

results.title: [Anti-aging traditional Chinese medicine： potential mechanisms involving AMPK pathway and calorie restriction based on "medicine-food homology" theory].

theories.name: AMPK pathway as a causal mechanism of aging

key_concepts.description: AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) acts as a key sensor and regulator of cellular energy status, modulating metabolic pathways to maintain energy homeostasis.

Experimental evidence shows that overexpression or pharmacological activation of AMPK (e.g., by metformin) extends lifespan in model organisms such as nematodes and Drosophila, suggesting a conserved role in aging regulation.
AMPK influences aging through downstream signaling pathways including TOR/S6K, FOXO transcription factors, and CRTC, which regulate growth, stress resistance, and metabolism.

theories.evidence: Citations of lifespan extension in nematodes and Drosophila via AMPK overexpression or activation; network pharmacology analysis identifying TCM compounds targeting AMPK; references to known downstream pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal biological mechanism explaining how aging can be modulated via energy metabolism pathways, applicable across organisms; not limited to a specific disease or organ.

theories.name: "Medicine-food homology" theory in traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) as an anti-aging framework

key_concepts.concept: Disease prevention via food and medicine integration
key_concepts.description: The TCM concept of 'medicine-food homology' posits that certain substances can serve both as food and medicine, promoting health and longevity by preventing disease and improving bodily function.

key_concepts.concept: Activation of AMPK by TCM compounds
key_concepts.description: Certain TCM herbs and compounds (e.g., berberine, curcumin, resveratrol) may activate AMPK, linking traditional practices to modern molecular aging mechanisms.
The approach emphasizes improving systemic health and energy metabolism to delay aging, reflecting a general organism-level perspective consistent with aging theory.

theories.evidence: Survey of frequently used TCM herbs in 'medicine-food homology' formulations; network pharmacology analysis showing interaction of TCM compounds with AMPK pathway proteins.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it proposes a general anti-aging framework integrating traditional knowledge with molecular mechanisms; however, it is more of a conceptual framework linked to AMPK rather than an independently detailed mechanistic theory.

results.title: Mitophagy in aging and longevity.

theories.name: Mitophagy as a pro-longevity mechanism

key_concepts.description: Mitophagy is the selective autophagic clearance of damaged or unwanted mitochondria, serving as a mitochondrial quality control mechanism essential for cellular homeostasis, metabolism, and development.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial quality control and organismal health
key_concepts.description: Proper removal of dysfunctional mitochondria through mitophagy maintains mitochondrial function, which is critical for organismal fitness, healthspan, and lifespan by preventing cellular damage and dysfunction.

Mitophagy influences multiple aging-related cellular processes including cellular senescence, stem cell function, inflammation, mitochondrial unfolded protein response (mtUPR), and bioenergetics, linking mitochondrial health to systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic evidence supporting mitophagy in longevity
key_concepts.description: Genetic studies indicate that enhanced mitophagy correlates with increased lifespan and protection against age-related degenerative diseases, suggesting mitophagy is a causal mechanism promoting longevity.

theories.evidence: Summary of recent mechanistic understanding and genetic evidence linking mitophagy to longevity and aging-related diseases; citations of studies associating mitophagy defects with Parkinson’s, Alzheimer’s, cancer, and degenerative disorders.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (mitophagy) explaining how mitochondrial quality control influences organismal aging and longevity, addressing systemic aging processes beyond specific diseases.

results.title: [Aging: Some theories, genetic, epigenetic and environmental considerations].

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a common outcome
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that cellular senescence, a state of irreversible cell cycle arrest, is a central mechanism driving the aging process. Various aging-related molecular and cellular changes converge on this outcome, which contributes to organismal aging.

theories.evidence: The paper references studies associating senescence with epigenetic-mediated chromatin condensation changes and links senescence to molecular changes at genetic and epigenetic levels.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain a general causal mechanism underlying aging at the organismal level, not limited to a specific organ or disease.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This theory suggests that reactive oxygen species (free radicals) generated during metabolism cause progressive molecular damage, which accumulates over time and leads to aging and age-related disorders.
Alterations in mitochondrial homeostasis exacerbate free radical production and damage, further accelerating the aging process through damage accumulation.

theories.evidence: The abstract mentions studies supporting free radicals as a useful mechanism to explain aging and age-related disorders, linked with mitochondrial homeostasis alterations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining aging as damage accumulation affecting the whole organism.

theories.name: Epigenetic Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This theory proposes that molecular changes at the epigenetic level, such as chromatin condensation alterations, contribute causally to aging by affecting gene expression and cellular function over time.

theories.evidence: The abstract cites studies associating senescence with epigenetic-mediated chromatin condensation changes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain aging through fundamental molecular mechanisms applicable broadly across tissues and organisms.

results.title: C‑X‑C Motif Chemokine 10/C-X‑C Motif Chemokine Receptor 3 Signaling Induces Neural Senescence and Cognitive Impairments.

theories.name: Neural senescence induced by CXCL10/CXCR3 signaling

key_concepts.concept: Chemokine signaling as a driver of neural senescence
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that increased CXCL10 chemokine and its receptor CXCR3 signaling in the brain contribute causally to neural cell senescence, which is a key mechanism underlying brain aging.
CXCL10 is considered a component of the SASP, a pro-inflammatory secretory profile of senescent cells, which may perpetuate and exacerbate aging processes in the central nervous system.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on cognitive decline via neural senescence
key_concepts.description: The signaling pathway leads to increased expression of senescence markers (p16INK4a, p21Cip1, p53) and decreased pRB, resulting in impaired cognitive functions such as learning and memory deficits.
CXCL10/CXCR3 signaling reduces autophagy in neurons and impairs glutamate signaling, linking cellular senescence mechanisms to functional neuronal decline.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from aged mice showing increased CXCL10/CXCR3 expression; chronic intracerebroventricular infusion of CXCL10 inducing senescence markers and cognitive deficits; blockade of effects by CXCR3 antagonist; in vitro primary neuron experiments demonstrating CXCL10-induced senescence and autophagy attenuation; reporter assays showing impaired glutamate signaling.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (chemokine signaling-induced neural senescence) explaining brain aging and cognitive decline, supported by mechanistic evidence and applicable to organism-level CNS aging rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific phenomenon.

results.title: Relationships between endogenous circadian period, physiological and cognitive parameters and sex in aged gray mouse lemurs (Microcebus murinus).

theories.name: Circadian resonance theory

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that an organism's lifespan is reduced when its endogenous circadian period (tau) deviates significantly from the 24-hour environmental day-night cycle. This mismatch is thought to impose physiological costs that accumulate over time, accelerating aging.

Daily resetting of the circadian clock to align with the external 24-hour photoperiod may induce marginal physiological costs. These costs, although small each day, accumulate over the organism's lifetime, contributing to aging and reduced fitness.

The theory suggests that deviations in tau correlate with biomarkers of aging such as oxidative stress, IGF-1 concentrations, and cognitive performance, indicating a mechanistic connection between circadian rhythm regulation and systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: The study measured endogenous circadian period (tau), oxidative stress levels, IGF-1 concentrations, and cognitive performance in aged gray mouse lemurs. It found that males with tau far from 24 h had increased oxidative stress and that tau positively correlated with IGF-1 and learning performance in both sexes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The circadian resonance theory attempts to explain why aging occurs by proposing a fundamental mechanism linking circadian rhythm alignment to lifespan and aging biomarkers, thus meeting the criteria of generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope.

results.title: NFκB dynamics-dependent epigenetic changes modulate inflammatory gene expression and induce cellular senescence.

theories.name: NFκB dynamics-dependent cellular senescence theory

key_concepts.concept: NFκB signaling upregulation as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that increased activity of the nuclear factor κB (NFκB) signaling pathway is a fundamental feature of aging, contributing to chronic inflammation associated with age.

key_concepts.concept: Alteration of NFκB nuclear dynamics from oscillatory to sustained activity
key_concepts.description: A shift in NFκB nuclear dynamics, specifically from oscillatory to sustained activation due to depletion of its negative regulator IκBα, leads to enhanced inflammatory gene expression and promotes cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic changes mediated by NFκB dynamics
key_concepts.description: Sustained NFκB activity increases NFκB-DNA binding at transcription start sites of age-associated genes, inducing epigenetic modifications that drive inflammatory gene expression and senescence progression.

key_concepts.concept: Role of IκBα protein decrease under stress and aging
key_concepts.description: The reduction of IκBα protein levels under replicative or oxidative stress and in aged tissues facilitates sustained NFκB activity, linking stress responses to aging-related cellular senescence.

theories.evidence: Experimental manipulation of NFκB dynamics by depleting IκBα in presence of TNFα induced cellular senescence; observed decreased IκBα and increased NFκB-DNA binding in aged mouse hearts; in vitro data showing IκBα decrease under stress conditions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how altered NFκB signaling dynamics drive cellular senescence, a key aging process; links molecular signaling changes to organism-level aging phenomena; provides mechanistic insight into inflammatory gene regulation and senescence induction.

results.title: Mitochondrial stress orchestrates chromatin remodeling and longevity via phosphoregulation of the NuRD component LIN-40.

theories.name: Mitochondrial stress-induced chromatin remodeling theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as an aging hallmark
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction is recognized as a fundamental feature of aging that triggers adaptive nuclear responses to maintain cellular homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Phosphoregulation of NuRD complex component LIN-40
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial stress induces dephosphorylation of LIN-40, a NuRD complex component, which enhances its interaction with transcription factor DVE-1, leading to activation of mitochondrial unfolded protein response (UPRmt) and chromatin remodeling.
Phosphorylation of LIN-40 is controlled by p38 MAPK/PMK-3 kinase and reversed by PP1c/GSP-2 phosphatase, linking mitochondrial stress signaling to chromatin remodeling.

key_concepts.concept: Link between mitochondrial stress response and organismal longevity
key_concepts.description: The phosphorylation state of LIN-40 influences lifespan extension under mitochondrial stress, as shown by the LIN-40(T654D) variant abolishing this lifespan extension, indicating a causal mechanism connecting mitochondrial stress signaling, chromatin remodeling, and longevity.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from Caenorhabditis elegans demonstrating phosphorylation-dependent regulation of LIN-40, interaction with DVE-1, activation of UPRmt, and effects on lifespan extension; genetic variant LIN-40(T654D) abolishing lifespan extension under mitochondrial stress.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking mitochondrial dysfunction (a known aging hallmark) to chromatin remodeling and longevity at the organismal level, explaining how mitochondrial stress signaling orchestrates aging-related processes.

results.title: Aging in bacteria, immortality or not-a critical review.

theories.name: Replicative Aging (RA) in Bacteria

key_concepts.concept: Asymmetric cell division and old pole inheritance
key_concepts.description: Bacteria divide by binary fission, but the daughter cell inheriting the 'old' pole from the mother cell shows a progressive decline in proliferative capacity, indicating a form of replicative aging despite initial assumptions of bacterial immortality.

Contrary to the traditional view of bacterial immortality, bacteria exhibit a limited number of divisions under favorable growth conditions, demonstrating a bona fide aging process at the cellular level.
The daughter cells that do not inherit the old pole are considered rejuvenated, effectively resetting their biological clock and maintaining population viability.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent studies describing replicative aging in bacteria, phenotypic observations of proliferative decline in old pole cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining why bacterial cells age (decline in replicative capacity linked to old pole inheritance), offers a causal explanation, and addresses aging broadly at the cellular organismal level in bacteria.

theories.name: Bacterial Aging as a Communitarian Adaptive Strategy

key_concepts.description: Bacterial aging phenomena are interpreted within an ecological and social context, suggesting that aging may serve as an adaptive bet-hedging strategy to generate phenotypic diversity within populations.

Aging in bacteria may function to produce a range of phenotypes that enhance population survival under environmental stresses, implying an evolved, adaptive role for aging rather than purely detrimental effects.
The paper calls for a unified theory that integrates molecular, ecological, and evolutionary perspectives to explain the reasons behind bacterial aging.

theories.evidence: Conceptual arguments supported by ecological and evolutionary reasoning; no direct experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes an evolutionary and ecological causal explanation for bacterial aging applicable at the population level, linking aging to survival strategies and sociality.

theories.name: Conditional Senescence (CS) in Bacteria

key_concepts.concept: Decline in viability in growth-arrested populations
key_concepts.description: CS is characterized by a decrease in cellular viability observed in bacterial populations that have stopped growing, distinct from replicative aging occurring during active growth.
Unlike RA, CS occurs under arrested growth conditions and is not directly related to the replicative history of the cells, suggesting a different aging mechanism.

theories.evidence: References to observed declines in viability in non-dividing bacterial populations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism for aging in bacteria under specific conditions, generalizable to bacterial populations, and addresses aging beyond replicative decline.

results.title: Importance and Meaning of TERRA Sequences for Aging Mechanisms.

theories.name: Subtelomere-Telomere Theory of Adaptive Aging

key_concepts.description: Each telomere is covered by a 'hood' formed in the first cell of an organism, which maintains its size through cell divisions. Telomere shortening causes this hood to slide onto the subtelomere region, repressing it via the telomeric position effect.

The theory postulates the existence of subtelomeric regulatory sequences whose progressive repression by the telomeric hood leads to cellular alterations. These sequences correspond to TElomeric Repeat-containing RNA (TERRA), whose repression affects gene regulation and cellular functions.

Repression of TERRA sequences increases the probability of activating the cell senescence program, causing replication arrest and functional alterations. Partial repression leads to reversible cellular dysfunctions that can be mitigated by telomerase activation.

key_concepts.concept: Adaptive Evolutionary Role of Telomeric Location
key_concepts.description: The evolutionary placement of these regulatory sequences in subtelomeric regions, vulnerable to repression by the telomeric hood, is argued to be adaptive, serving the specific function of determining aging at the cellular and organismal level.

theories.evidence: The theory references documented characteristics of TERRA sequences and their regulatory roles; it builds on known telomere biology and telomerase regulation; evolutionary reasoning is used to argue adaptiveness.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a general, organism-level mechanism explaining how aging occurs via telomere dynamics and subtelomeric repression; it provides a causal mechanism linking telomere shortening to cellular senescence and organismal aging; it addresses aging broadly and includes evolutionary logic.

results.title: Chromosome ends and the theory of marginotomy: implications for reproduction.

theories.name: Theory of Marginotomy (Telomere Theory of Aging)

key_concepts.description: Telomeres, protective chromosome end structures, cannot be fully replicated during DNA replication, leading to progressive shortening. This shortening limits the number of times a cell can divide, linking telomere length to cellular lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length as a determinant of organismal aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that telomere shortening at the cellular level contributes to the overall aging process and lifespan limitation of the organism, connecting cellular replicative capacity with organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Telomerase and telomere lengthening as anti-aging mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Telomerase enzyme can counteract telomere shortening, being active in germ, stem, and cancer cells but mostly inactive in adult somatic cells. The theory suggests potential anti-aging interventions through telomere lengthening.

theories.evidence: Historical theoretical proposal by Olovnikov; confirmation of proliferative telomere shortening impact on life expectancy; observations of telomerase activity patterns; associations between telomere length and fertility outcomes; citations of empirical studies on telomere dynamics and reproductive aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it is a generalizable biological aging theory explaining a fundamental mechanism (telomere shortening) causing aging at the organismal level, proposes causal mechanisms, and addresses broad aging processes beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Senescence of skeletal stem cells and their contribution to age-related bone loss.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the accumulation of senescent cells in tissues contributes causally to the aging process by impairing tissue function and regeneration.
Skeletal stem cells, which are the progenitors of bone-forming osteoblastic cells, undergo senescence with age, leading to defective bone formation and contributing to systemic bone loss.
Senescent skeletal stem cells alter the bone microenvironment, which further exacerbates age-related bone fragility and increased fracture risk.

theories.evidence: The paper provides a detailed discussion of the hypothesis linking skeletal stem cell senescence to bone aging and reviews potential therapeutic strategies targeting cellular senescence to treat age-related bone loss.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (cellular senescence) explaining a fundamental aging process (bone aging) with implications for organismal aging; it is not limited to a narrow phenomenon but connects stem cell senescence to systemic aging effects.

results.title: Meiosis as a mechanism for epigenetic reprogramming and cellular rejuvenation.

theories.name: Meiosis as a cellular rejuvenation mechanism opposing aging

key_concepts.description: Cellular aging is caused by the accumulation of defective organelles and proteins as well as epigenetic modifications such as DNA methylation and histone modifications that alter chromatin structure and function.

Meiosis functions not only for genetic recombination but also to reset or oppose the cellular aging that accumulates through successive mitotic divisions, effectively rejuvenating the germline and enabling the transition to a new life cycle.
Meiosis involves extensive epigenetic reprogramming, which may erase age-associated epigenetic marks, thereby restoring youthful chromatin states in gametes.
Beyond recombination, meiosis evolved as a fundamental biological mechanism to counteract aging at the cellular level, ensuring the continuity of life cycles across diverse eukaryotes.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews recent findings supporting the hypothesis, including comparative life cycle data from animals, yeast, flowering plants, and bryophytes, and references the original proposal by Robin Holliday from 40 years ago.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining why meiosis evolved as a fundamental process to counteract cellular aging, addressing aging broadly at the organismal life cycle level. It is not limited to a specific organ or disease and provides an organizing principle for aging and rejuvenation.

results.title: Adult neurogenesis in the central nervous system of teleost fish: from stem cells to function and evolution.

theories.name: Numerical Matching Hypothesis of Adult Neurogenesis

key_concepts.concept: Neurogenesis driven by peripheral tissue growth
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that adult neurogenesis in the central nervous system is regulated by the continued growth of peripheral tissues such as muscle fibers and sensory receptor cells. The hypothesis suggests that neurogenesis ensures a constant ratio between peripheral and central nervous system elements, maintaining functional integration.

key_concepts.concept: Link between body growth patterns and stem cell attrition
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis connects the presence or absence of stem cell attrition during aging to the organism's growth pattern—determinate versus indeterminate growth. Fish with determinate growth show stem cell attrition with aging, while those with indeterminate growth do not, implying a causal relationship between growth dynamics and neurogenic capacity.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary explanation for cessation of neurogenesis in mammals
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis offers an evolutionary rationale for why adult neurogenesis has largely ceased in mammals, which exhibit determinate growth. It suggests that because peripheral tissues stop growing, the need for additive neurogenesis to maintain peripheral-central ratios diminishes, leading to the evolutionary loss of widespread adult neurogenesis.

theories.evidence: Observations of neurogenic sites in teleost fish brains, comparative data on stem cell attrition linked to growth patterns, and mathematical/computational modeling identifying factors critical for tissue growth (symmetric stem cell division, cell death, cell drift).
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why adult neurogenesis occurs and declines in relation to organismal growth and aging, with evolutionary implications. It addresses aging broadly via stem cell dynamics and tissue growth regulation, not limited to a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Aging and attention: Meaningfulness may be more important than valence.
A life span model of successful aging.

Maternal age and gonadotrophin elevation cooperatively decrease viable ovulated oocytes and increase ootoxicity, chromosome-, and spindle-misalignments: '2-Hit' and 'FSH-OoToxicity' mechanisms as new reproductive aging hypotheses.

theories.name: FSH OOToxicity Hypothesis

key_concepts.description: High levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) are proposed to be directly toxic to ovulatory oocytes, reducing their viability and quality. This toxicity contributes to decreased pregnancy success rates in women with elevated FSH, such as those undergoing controlled ovarian stimulation or naturally cycling women with diminished ovarian reserve.

key_concepts.concept: Root cause of infertility linked to FSH
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis suggests that FSH ootoxicity is a fundamental mechanism underlying low fertility outcomes associated with high FSH levels, beyond the effects of maternal age alone.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from a mouse model showing that treatment with an FSH analog (eCG) induces ootoxicity and chromosome/spindle misalignments, especially pronounced in midlife mice compared to young mice.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism explaining how elevated FSH contributes to reproductive aging at the organismal level, linking hormonal changes to oocyte quality decline and infertility, thus addressing a general aging-related reproductive process.

theories.name: 2-Hit Hypothesis of Reproductive Aging

key_concepts.description: Advanced maternal age (AMA) increases the vulnerability of oocytes to damage caused by elevated FSH levels, leading to greater ootoxicity and chromosomal abnormalities.

The hypothesis posits a two-step process where aging primes oocytes for damage, and elevated FSH acts as a second hit that exacerbates oocyte quality decline and aneuploidy, jointly contributing to infertility.

theories.evidence: Mouse model experiments showing that midlife mice exhibit more severe oocyte damage and reduced viability under elevated FSH conditions than young mice, indicating an interaction between age and FSH effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a mechanistic explanation for how aging and hormonal changes interact to cause reproductive aging, addressing general organism-level reproductive aging processes.

results.title: Insights and Interventions in Age-Associated Inflammation.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic inflammation as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is accompanied by a persistent, low-grade inflammatory state that contributes to the progressive decline in physiological function and increased risk of chronic diseases.

The chronic inflammatory state arises from diverse stimuli including external pathogens, internal cellular debris, metabolic dysregulation, and chronic stress, which collectively drive systemic inflammation.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Rather than being a mere consequence, chronic inflammation actively promotes aging processes and age-associated pathologies, making it a causal mechanism in systemic aging.

theories.evidence: The paper examines recent mechanistic advances and anti-inflammatory strategies, referencing current research progress though specific studies are not detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs systemically, addressing broad aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Mammal Aging is Controlled by an Evolvability-Based Adaptive Program.

theories.name: Evolvability-Based Programmed Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Programmed Aging as an Adaptive Trait
key_concepts.description: Aging is proposed to be a genetically specified program that purposely causes aging in mammals. Contrary to earlier beliefs that aging could not be programmed due to evolutionary constraints, this theory suggests aging evolved because it provides population-level advantages, such as reducing the probability of extinction.

The theory incorporates modern evolutionary mechanics concepts like group selection and evolvability, which allow individually adverse traits like aging to be favored if they enhance the survival or adaptability of the population as a whole.

Rather than a fixed biological clock, the aging program is controlled by an adaptive mechanism that senses local or temporary environmental or physiological conditions and adjusts the aging process accordingly to optimize outcomes.

theories.evidence: The paper references evolutionary mechanics concepts (group selection, evolvability) and genetic discoveries supporting population advantages of aging. It also presents theoretical arguments and some unspecified evidence for adaptive control mechanisms in aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organism level, grounded in evolutionary theory and genetic programming. It addresses aging broadly as a fundamental biological process, not limited to specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Associative memory in older adults: Making sense of associative memory deficits and hyperbinding effects.

theories.name: Associative Deficit Hypothesis

key_concepts.concept: Decline in forming and retrieving associations
key_concepts.description: This hypothesis posits that older adults experience a decline in their ability to form and retrieve associations between arbitrary pieces of information, leading to deficits in associative memory.

theories.evidence: Overview of theoretical framework and associated experimental paradigms; synthesis of existing literature supporting the hypothesis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal explanation for a fundamental cognitive aging process (associative memory decline) with generalizability to organism-level cognitive aging, not limited to a specific disease or organ.

theories.name: Inhibitory Deficit Hypothesis

key_concepts.description: This hypothesis suggests that older adults tend to bind more information together than intended, including irrelevant associations, and have difficulty inhibiting or ignoring these irrelevant associations, which impairs associative memory.

theories.evidence: Overview of theoretical framework and associated experimental paradigms; synthesis of existing literature supporting the hypothesis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (inhibitory control decline) underlying a general cognitive aging phenomenon (associative memory changes), applicable broadly to aging cognition.

results.title: Microplastics/nanoplastics contribute to aging and age-related diseases: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a crucial role.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction refers to the decline in mitochondrial performance, including impaired energy production and increased generation of reactive oxygen species, which contributes to cellular and organismal aging processes.
Exposure to microplastics and nanoplastics can cause mitochondrial damage, which may accelerate mitochondrial dysfunction and thereby promote aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Environmental pollutants as contributors to aging
key_concepts.description: Emerging pollutants like microplastics and nanoplastics are proposed as novel environmental factors that exacerbate mitochondrial dysfunction, linking environmental exposure to the biological aging process.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent research demonstrating MPs/NPs contribution to mitochondrial damage and aging; examination of distribution and pathways of MPs/NPs in human tissues; theoretical framework linking MPs/NPs to mitochondrial dysfunction and aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general biological aging mechanism (mitochondrial dysfunction) at the organismal level, proposes a causal link between environmental pollutants and aging, and discusses underlying mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena.
