results.title: The mitochondrial and cytoplasmic superoxide anion imbalance trigger the expression of certain cellular aging markers in HaCaT keratinocytes.

theories.name: Cellular aging triggered by superoxide anion imbalance

key_concepts.description: The hypothesis that endogenous signals, termed cellular aging triggers, induce cellular aging events. These triggers act as causal factors initiating biological changes associated with cellular aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of superoxide anion (O2⁻) as a CAT
key_concepts.description: Superoxide anion, continuously produced by eukaryotic cells, is proposed as a prime candidate for a cellular aging trigger. Imbalances in mitochondrial and cytoplasmic O2⁻ levels can induce cellular aging markers.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial and cytoplasmic oxidative imbalance causing aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Induction of O2⁻ imbalance via mitochondrial complex I inhibition or redox cycling leads to reduced proliferation, increased senescence markers (β-Galactosidase, TGF-β), nuclear alterations, oxidative stress markers, and SASP factors, linking oxidative imbalance causally to cellular aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from HaCaT keratinocytes treated with rotenone and paraquat showing reduced proliferation, increased β-Galactosidase, TGF-β, nuclear alterations, oxidative markers, and interleukin 1β levels.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (oxidative imbalance via superoxide anion) underlying cellular aging processes, with experimental testing in a cell model. While focused on cellular aging, the concepts relate to fundamental aging mechanisms involving oxidative stress, which are broadly relevant to organismal aging.

results.title: The role of theories of cognitive aging: comment on Salthouse.
Intermittent time-restricted eating may increase autophagic flux in humans: an exploratory analysis.

theories.name: Autophagy as a causal mechanism in biological aging

key_concepts.description: Autophagy is a cellular process that removes damaged components and maintains cellular homeostasis, thereby slowing the progression of age-related pathologies.

In animal models, nutrient restriction such as calorie restriction or intermittent fasting has been shown to increase autophagic flux, which is proposed to contribute to lifespan extension and delay of age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Autophagy dysfunction contributes to age-related disease
key_concepts.description: Impairment or decline in autophagic activity is implicated in the development of multiple age-related diseases, suggesting that maintaining or enhancing autophagy could be a mechanism to slow aging.

theories.evidence: Randomized controlled trial in 121 humans with obesity comparing standard care, calorie restriction, and intermittent time-restricted eating over 6 months; measurement of autophagic flux in peripheral blood mononuclear cells; statistical analysis showing significant difference in autophagic flux change between iTRE and control groups at 6 months; correlation analysis with blood triglycerides.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (autophagy) underlying biological aging at the organism level, supported by intervention data in humans; addresses a fundamental aging process rather than a narrow phenomenon; links nutrient restriction to modulation of a primary hallmark of aging.

results.title: Ovulation suppression protects against chromosomal abnormalities in mouse eggs at advanced maternal age.

theories.name: Ovulation Frequency-Dependent Oocyte Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Ovulation frequency as a determinant of oocyte aging
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that the number of ovulations an organism undergoes influences the physiological aging of oocytes, particularly their ability to segregate chromosomes accurately and produce euploid eggs. Reducing ovulation frequency is hypothesized to delay the aging process of oocytes.

key_concepts.concept: Role of Rec8-cohesin in maintaining chromatid cohesion
key_concepts.description: Rec8-cohesin complexes maintain sister chromatid cohesion during meiosis, which is critical for accurate chromosome segregation. Loss of Rec8 with age leads to increased chromosomal abnormalities, and ovulation suppression helps retain Rec8, thereby preserving chromatid cohesion.

key_concepts.concept: 3D chromatin structure deterioration in aging oocytes
key_concepts.description: Aging oocytes exhibit deterioration in their 3D chromatin architecture, including increased extruded loop sizes. This structural change is linked to loss of cohesin complexes, which normally restrict loop extrusion, suggesting a mechanistic connection between chromatin structure and oocyte aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental interventions reducing ovulation frequency (successive pregnancies, hormonal contraception, pre-pubertal knockout mouse model) showed decreased chromosomal abnormalities in aged mouse eggs. Single-nucleus Hi-C data revealed changes in 3D chromatin structure, and artificial cleavage of Rec8 increased loop sizes, supporting the mechanistic link.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (oocyte aging) with a causal mechanism (ovulation frequency affecting cohesin retention and chromatin structure), applicable at the organismal reproductive level. It proposes underlying causes and mechanisms for age-related chromosomal abnormalities, thus meeting all core criteria.

results.title: "When did you see it?" The effect of emotional valence on temporal source memory in aging.

theories.name: Socio-Emotional Selectivity Theory

key_concepts.concept: Emotional valence influences memory processing in aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that as people age, their motivational priorities shift towards emotionally meaningful goals, which affects how they process and remember emotional information. Older adults tend to prioritize positive over negative information, known as the positivity effect.

key_concepts.concept: Temporal source memory affected by emotional valence
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that emotional valence modulates how older adults remember the timing of events, with positive stimuli being remembered as more recent and negative stimuli being temporally displaced.
The theory accounts for differences in how younger and older adults process and recall temporal information, with older adults showing distinct patterns influenced by emotional content.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from temporal source memory tasks with younger, old, and old-old adults viewing emotional pictures and recalling the session in which they were seen; observed patterns consistent with the theory's predictions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general psychosocial aging theory explaining why emotional processing and memory change with age, addressing broad aging-related cognitive changes with causal mechanisms related to motivational shifts.

results.title: Treat more than heat-New therapeutic implications of Cimicifuga racemosa through AMPK-dependent metabolic effects.

theories.name: Menopause as a manifestation of general aging with metabolic impairment

key_concepts.description: Menopause is proposed not merely as a reproductive phase but as part of the broader aging process, involving systemic changes that go beyond reproductive hormone decline.
Age-related metabolic dysfunctions, exacerbated by estrogen depletion and neurotransmitter dysregulation, contribute to the severity of menopausal symptoms such as hot flushes.

key_concepts.concept: AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) as a metabolic regulator
key_concepts.description: AMPK is identified as a key metabolic regulator modulated by Cimicifuga racemosa extracts, which may mitigate menopausal symptoms and potentially influence the aging process itself.

theories.evidence: Comprehensive literature survey citing studies on CRE effects, menopause pathophysiology, and AMPK-related metabolic pathways; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain aging-related metabolic changes underlying menopause, proposes a causal mechanism involving AMPK, and connects menopause symptoms to systemic aging processes.

results.title: Advancing theory-driven research in the psychological science of adult development and aging.
The metabolic and endocrine impact of diet-derived gut microbiota metabolites on ageing and longevity.

theories.name: Gut microbiota-metabolite influence on systemic aging theory

key_concepts.concept: Gut dysbiosis as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging is associated with a shift in gut microbiota composition, characterized by depletion of beneficial bacteria producing metabolites like short-chain fatty acids (SCFA) and indole derivatives, and enrichment of pathobionts producing harmful metabolites.

key_concepts.concept: Metabolite-mediated modulation of host metabolic health
key_concepts.description: Beneficial metabolites such as SCFA and indole-3-propionic acid improve host glycemic control, insulin sensitivity, and secretion, thereby promoting healthy aging, while detrimental metabolites like imidazole propionate, phenols, and trimethylamine promote insulin resistance and atherosclerosis, contributing to unhealthy aging.

key_concepts.concept: Distinct gut microbiota signatures in longevity
key_concepts.description: Longevity is associated with a unique gut microbiota profile enriched in bacteria producing beneficial metabolites, suggesting a causal role of microbiota-derived metabolites in promoting lifespan and healthy aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent research on gut microbiota composition changes with aging and longevity, metabolic effects of specific microbial metabolites, and associations between microbiota profiles and health outcomes in aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism linking gut microbiota-derived metabolites to systemic aging processes and longevity, addressing aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Oxidative Stress Promotes Axonal Atrophy through Alterations in Microtubules and EB1 Function.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress-Induced Microtubule Dysfunction Theory of Neuronal Aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) increase with age and cause oxidative stress, which is a hallmark of aging and age-related diseases. This oxidative stress is proposed to causally contribute to neuronal aging by damaging cellular components.

Oxidative stress leads to changes in the microtubule cytoskeleton within axons and synapses, including defects in microtubule structure and function, which contribute to axonal and synaptic decay during aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of microtubule plus end-binding protein 1 (EB1)
key_concepts.description: ROS sensitizes EB1, a protein that binds to the growing ends of microtubules, causing microtubule defects that impair neuronal integrity. Manipulating EB1 function can mitigate aging-related axonal deterioration.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic potential of targeting microtubule dynamics
key_concepts.description: Enhancing microtubule plus-end physiology by modulating EB1 function offers a strategy to improve axonal resilience and prevent aging hallmarks exacerbated by oxidative stress.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from Drosophila primary neuronal cultures and in vivo neuronal aging models showing increased ROS leads to axonal swellings, microtubule alterations, and morphological changes; manipulation of EB1 rescues these phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism linking oxidative stress (a fundamental aging hallmark) to neuronal aging via microtubule dysfunction, applicable to organism-level neuronal aging, with mechanistic explanations and therapeutic implications.

results.title: Coevolution of Brain, Culture, and Lifespan: Insights from Computer Simulations.

theories.name: Cultural Drive Theory of Aging and Lifespan Evolution

key_concepts.concept: Coevolution of brain, culture, and lifespan
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that human traits such as large brain size, culture, language, and extended lifespan coevolved through mutual feedback loops. Culture and brain development influence lifespan evolution, and extended lifespan in turn enhances cultural development.

key_concepts.concept: Impact of between-group competition (BGC) on lifespan
key_concepts.description: In the absence of culture, strong between-group competition favors shorter lifespans. However, culture can override this effect by favoring genetic evolution of longer lifespans even under strong competition.

key_concepts.concept: Cultural versus genetic evolution of lifespan
key_concepts.description: Cultural evolution involves the accumulation and transmission of survival-enhancing or survival-impairing knowledge ('memes') that can spread independently of genetic benefits. This leads to longer lifespans culturally than genetically evolved lifespans.

key_concepts.concept: Role of post-reproductive lifespan in group competitiveness
key_concepts.description: The presence of knowledgeable long-lived individuals can increase group competitiveness, promoting genetic evolution of a long post-reproductive period.

theories.evidence: Computer simulations using the TribeSim model exploring autocatalytic coevolution dynamics; simulation results showing effects of culture and BGC on lifespan evolution and post-reproductive period.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains why and how aging and lifespan evolve at the organismal level through cultural and genetic mechanisms; it proposes causal mechanisms involving cultural and genetic interactions; it addresses aging broadly in humans, not limited to specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Exercise-induced angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis: A potential therapeutic tool to fight aging and disease.

theories.name: Exercise-induced angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis as anti-aging mechanisms

key_concepts.description: The formation of new blood vessels (angiogenesis) plays a crucial role in maintaining tissue health and function during aging. Enhancing angiogenesis can mitigate vascular decline, which is a common feature of aging and contributes to decreased organ function.

The formation of new lymphatic vessels (lymphangiogenesis) is important for immune system regulation and tissue repair. Modulating lymphangiogenic pathways may help counteract immune dysfunction associated with aging.

Physical exercise induces both angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis, thereby improving physiological functions across multiple organ systems. This endogenous stimulation represents a potential therapeutic strategy to combat age-related functional decline and diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing current knowledge on exercise-induced angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis, including underlying mechanisms and effects in different organs, supported by citations of existing studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis) underlying systemic aging processes, offers causal explanations linking vascular and immune system decline to aging, and discusses exercise as a modulator of these processes. The focus is on broad organism-level aging mechanisms rather than narrow disease or organ-specific phenomena.

results.title: Internalization or Dissociation? Negative Age Stereotypes Make You Feel Younger Now But Make You Feel Older Later.
The impact of Internet use on cognitive function in older adults: Based on the cognitive reserve hypothesis.

theories.name: Cognitive Reserve Theory

key_concepts.description: Cognitive reserve refers to the brain's resilience to neuropathological damage, allowing some individuals to maintain cognitive function despite aging or brain pathology. It is built up through life experiences such as education, occupational complexity, and engaging activities that stimulate the brain.
Using the internet provides cognitive stimulation and social interaction opportunities, which may enhance or maintain cognitive function in older adults by contributing to cognitive reserve.

Social interaction, including social support, social networks, and social participation, partially mediates the positive effect of internet use on cognitive function, suggesting social factors are integral to cognitive reserve.

theories.evidence: Empirical analysis of 2020 China Longitudinal Aging Social Survey data showing significant positive correlation between internet use and cognitive function, with mediation analysis of social interaction factors.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism explaining how cognitive aging can be mitigated through cognitive reserve built by life experiences and activities, including internet use. It addresses aging broadly at the organism level (cognitive function), proposes causal pathways (cognitive stimulation and social interaction), and is generalizable beyond specific diseases or organs.

theories.name: Active Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Active aging theory emphasizes maintaining physical, social, and mental activities to promote health and well-being in older adults, thereby delaying or reducing age-related decline.
Internet use is seen as a means to support active aging by facilitating social participation and cognitive engagement, which can help maintain cognitive function.

theories.evidence: The study references active aging theory as a framework supporting the observed positive effects of internet use on cognitive function and social interaction.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a psychosocial framework explaining how engagement in activities influences aging outcomes broadly. However, it is less mechanistic than cognitive reserve theory and more focused on behavioral aspects.

results.title: Is generativity Erikson's answer to human ageing in the neoliberal world?
Racial inequities in the incidence of major adverse cardiovascular events in ELSA-Brasil cohort: the mediating role of weathering.

theories.name: Weathering hypothesis

key_concepts.concept: Chronic social disadvantage accelerates biological aging
key_concepts.description: The weathering hypothesis proposes that prolonged exposure to social stressors such as racism and socioeconomic disadvantage leads to accelerated biological aging, which in turn increases vulnerability to age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Biological age as a mediator of health disparities
key_concepts.description: Biological age, estimated through biomarkers, can diverge from chronological age due to environmental and social stressors, mediating the relationship between social determinants (e.g., race) and health outcomes like cardiovascular disease.

key_concepts.concept: Racial disparities in aging-related disease incidence
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis explains observed racial inequities in the incidence of major adverse cardiovascular events by linking social disadvantage to earlier onset of biological aging and disease.

theories.evidence: Analysis of 10,983 Brazilian adults free from cardiovascular disease at baseline, using self-reported race as a proxy for social disadvantage, biological age calculated from nine biomarkers, and longitudinal incidence data on major adverse cardiovascular events; statistical modeling showing mediation of racial disparities in cardiovascular events by accelerated biological aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how social disadvantage leads to accelerated biological aging and increased disease risk at the organism level; addresses aging broadly through biological age acceleration; provides a causal explanation linking social factors to aging-related disease.

results.title: Ageing drop by drop: Disturbance of the membrane-less organelle biogenesis as an aging hallmark.

theories.name: Membrane-less Organelle Dysfunction as an Aging Hallmark

key_concepts.concept: Membrane-less organelles (MLOs) and liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS)
key_concepts.description: MLOs are cellular compartments formed without membranes, driven by scaffold proteins with intrinsic disorder through LLPS. This process organizes cellular biochemistry dynamically and reversibly, crucial for normal cell function.

key_concepts.concept: Dysfunction of MLOs as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Aberrant behavior or dysfunction of MLOs disrupts cellular homeostasis and is linked to aging phenotypes. This dysfunction is proposed as a new hallmark of aging, contributing broadly to organismal aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Interconnectivity between aging-related proteins and MLO proteins
key_concepts.description: Bioinformatics analysis reveals significant overlap between aging-related proteins (Ageome) and proteins involved in MLOs (Granulome), indicating a molecular network (Intersectome) that connects MLO dysfunction with aging mechanisms.
Proteins involved in MLOs also relate to established aging hallmarks, suggesting that MLO dysfunction integrates with other aging pathways and mechanisms, reinforcing its role in systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Bioinformatics analysis of large protein datasets (Granulome and Ageome), statistical enrichment of overlapping proteins (Intersectome), functional annotation of proteins in representative MLOs, and literature linking MLO dysfunction to neurodegenerative diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism underlying aging at the organism level by implicating MLO dysfunction as a fundamental aging hallmark. It connects molecular mechanisms (LLPS, scaffold proteins) to systemic aging processes and integrates with known aging hallmarks.

results.title: [Old age and attachment theory, a systematic review of attachment typology, continuity, prevalence and association with psychological and health variables in older adults].

theories.name: Attachment theory in psychosocial aging

key_concepts.description: Attachment theory categorizes individuals into types such as secure and avoidant attachment. This theory examines how these attachment styles manifest and vary in prevalence among older adults compared to younger populations.

key_concepts.concept: Attachment as an explanatory and mediating variable
key_concepts.description: Attachment styles influence psychological and health outcomes in old age, mediating relationships with depression, life satisfaction, physical illness, and loneliness. This suggests attachment patterns play a causal role in psychosocial aging processes.

Various instruments are used to evaluate attachment in older adults, though there is no consensus on the best methods. The theory involves understanding how attachment can be reliably measured to study its impact on aging.

theories.evidence: Systematic review of 17 studies involving 7118 older adults, comparing prevalence of attachment types and associations with psychosocial and health variables.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general psychosocial aging theory explaining how attachment styles causally influence aging-related psychological and health outcomes at the organism-level scale. It is generalizable beyond specific diseases or organs and provides causal explanations rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Establishing evidence for immune surveillance of β-cell senescence.

theories.name: Cellular senescence immune surveillance theory

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a programmed state
key_concepts.description: Cells enter a programmed state of permanent cell cycle arrest characterized by a complex immunogenic secretome that signals their presence to the immune system.

key_concepts.concept: Immune surveillance and clearance of senescent cells
key_concepts.description: The immune system recognizes and clears senescent cells, preventing their accumulation and potential detrimental effects on tissue function.

key_concepts.concept: Role of immune surveillance in limiting senescent β-cell accumulation during aging
key_concepts.description: Immune surveillance mechanisms normally restrict the buildup of senescent pancreatic β-cells as organisms age, maintaining tissue homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Breakdown of immune surveillance as a driver of senescent cell accumulation in diabetes
key_concepts.description: Failure or impairment of immune surveillance leads to the pathological accumulation of senescent β-cells, contributing to diabetes progression.

theories.evidence: The article is an opinion piece advancing a hypothesis based on recent work showing β-cell senescence in diabetes; no new experimental data presented but references to existing literature.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how immune surveillance of senescent cells influences organismal aging and disease; it addresses cellular senescence as a causal driver of systemic aging processes and links immune system function to aging-related β-cell dysfunction.

results.title: Mitochondria as a sensor, a central hub and a biological clock in psychological stress-accelerated aging.

theories.name: Mitochondrial Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative damage by mitochondrial free radicals
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated by mitochondria cause cumulative oxidative damage to cellular components, which drives the aging process at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondria as stress sensors and central hubs
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria dynamically respond to psychological stress by acting as sensitive sensors and integrators of hormonal, mechanical, and immune signals, thereby influencing molecular pathways that accelerate aging.

key_concepts.concept: Distinction between normal and accelerated aging
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that mitochondrial responses to psychological stress can differentiate normal aging from accelerated aging, highlighting mitochondria’s role in modulating aging rates.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing literature on mitochondrial oxidative damage and psychological stress effects, discusses mitochondrial functions as hormonal, mechanosensitive, and immune suborganelles, and cites studies linking mitochondria to accelerated aging and interventions like exercise and mitochondria-targeted therapies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (mitochondrial oxidative damage and stress sensing) explaining how biological aging occurs systemically, not limited to specific organs or diseases. It addresses why aging accelerates under psychological stress, linking molecular mechanisms to organism-level aging.

results.title: When and how perceived control buffers against cognitive declines: A moderated mediation analysis.
Biochemical correlates of longevity in two closely related rodent species.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress as a cause of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging results from cumulative damage caused by reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as superoxide (O2.-) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), generated primarily by mitochondria. This oxidative damage affects cellular components, leading to functional decline and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial ROS generation rates correlate with lifespan
key_concepts.description: Species with lower mitochondrial production of ROS tend to have longer lifespans, suggesting that reduced oxidative damage contributes to longevity.
Higher activities of antioxidant enzymes like catalase and glutathione peroxidase reduce oxidative damage, thereby potentially extending lifespan.

theories.evidence: Comparative biochemical analysis between two rodent species with differing lifespans showed that the longer-lived species had lower mitochondrial ROS generation, higher antioxidant enzyme activities, and reduced protein oxidative damage, supporting the oxidative stress role in aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a general causal mechanism for aging (oxidative damage accumulation), is applicable across species, and addresses aging as a fundamental biological process rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: The Somatic Impact on Inheritance and the Germline Control of the Soma.

theories.name: Germplasm Theory and Epigenetic Inheritance in Aging

key_concepts.description: Proposed by August Weismann, this theory posits that genetic inheritance is exclusively mediated by germ cells, which protect heritable germline genomes from influences arising from an individual's life history, thus separating soma and germline in heredity.

Recent studies show that epigenetic variations can be inherited, suggesting that somatic experiences or environmental factors may influence germline genomes, thereby challenging the strict separation of soma and germline and opening new perspectives on molecular inheritance mechanisms.

Emerging research focuses on the interactions between somatic cells and germline cells, particularly how these circuits control the integrity of heritable genomes and their implications for both somatic and reproductive aging, suggesting a mechanistic link between inheritance and aging processes.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent studies on epigenetic inheritance and soma-germline interactions; theoretical discussion of molecular mechanisms and implications for aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental biological mechanism explaining how aging and inheritance are interconnected at the organismal level, proposes causal mechanisms involving epigenetic inheritance and soma-germline communication, and discusses implications for systemic aging rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Diets, genes, and drugs that increase lifespan and delay age-related diseases: Role of nutrient-sensing neurons and Creb-binding protein.

theories.name: Neuronal regulation of aging via nutrient-sensing neurons

key_concepts.concept: Role of nutrient-sensing neurons in lifespan regulation
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that specific neurons that sense nutrient status play a determinative role in controlling organismal lifespan and the onset of age-related diseases, beyond cell-autonomous mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Neuronal signaling mediates effects of dietary restriction and insulin-like signaling
key_concepts.description: Protective effects of dietary restriction and reduced insulin-like signaling on lifespan and disease delay depend on signaling pathways involving Creb-binding protein in GABA neurons and Nrf2/Skn1 in nutrient-sensing neurons, indicating a central neuronal mechanism.

Nutrient-sensing neurons influence lifespan by regulating metabolic pathways, particularly the balance between glycolysis and alternative metabolic routes such as ketone and lipid metabolism, which affects systemic aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Neuroactive drugs as modulators of aging
key_concepts.description: Drugs that act on neuronal signaling pathways can delay pathology in models of age-related diseases (e.g., Alzheimer's) and inhibit cytokine production implicated in aging, suggesting neurons as therapeutic targets for aging interventions.

theories.evidence: Citations of genetic interventions in C. elegans (Creb-binding protein, Nrf2/Skn1), drug screening results showing neuroactive compounds extend lifespan and delay pathology, and mechanistic hypotheses on metabolic regulation by neurons.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging at the organismal level involving neuronal regulation of metabolism and lifespan; it addresses aging broadly and is not limited to a single organ or disease.

results.title: Kinetics of in vitro ageing of mouse embryo fibroblasts.

theories.name: Mortalization theory of Shall & Stein

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the reproductive potential of cells declines smoothly over time rather than abruptly, describing aging as a continuous process of decreasing cell division capacity.

Gamma quantifies the rate at which the doubling time of the culture increases and represents the number of generations at which half of the newborn cells become reproductively sterile, serving as a key metric for aging kinetics in cell populations.

The theory explains that the fraction of dividing cells decreases gradually throughout the lifespan of the cell strain, leading to a progressive reduction in growth rate rather than catastrophic or linear changes.

theories.evidence: Experimental data on mouse embryo fibroblast cultures showing non-exponential growth, constant cell cycle duration, and a smooth decline in growth fraction; estimation of gamma parameter consistent across lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of cellular aging dynamics at the population level, addressing fundamental aging processes beyond a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: REM phase: An ingenious mechanism to enhance clearance of metabolic waste from the retina.

theories.name: REM sleep glymphatic clearance hypothesis

key_concepts.concept: REM sleep as a mechanism for metabolic waste clearance in the retina
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis proposes that the REM phase of sleep facilitates enhanced clearance of metabolic waste from the retina, analogous to glymphatic clearance in the brain. This clearance is critical because the outer retinal layers lack direct blood supply, making waste removal essential for retinal health.

A para-vascular transport system, similar to the brain's glymphatic system, is proposed to exist in the eye. This system promotes elimination of interstitial solutes through para-vascular channels, and its function increases during sleep, particularly during REM, driven by a 'vitreous pump' mechanism.

key_concepts.concept: Link between impaired clearance and aging-related retinal diseases
key_concepts.description: Impairment of this REM-associated clearance mechanism may contribute to retinal degenerations such as age-related macular degeneration and chronic open-angle glaucoma, diseases that share similarities with Alzheimer's disease in terms of metabolic waste accumulation and aging pathology.

theories.evidence: The paper references prior hypotheses (Maurice 1998), recent research on brain glymphatic systems, analogies to ocular physiology, and observed similarities between Alzheimer's and retinal degenerations. However, direct experimental evidence within the paper is not detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging-related metabolic waste clearance in the retina occurs and how its impairment could drive aging-related retinal dysfunction. It addresses a fundamental physiological process linked to aging, not limited to a narrow disease or organ without broader implications.

results.title: The role of vascular cell senescence in atherosclerosis: antisenescence as a novel therapeutic strategy for vascular aging.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cells have a finite replicative lifespan and enter an irreversible growth arrest known as cellular senescence. Senescent cells accumulate with age and contribute to tissue dysfunction and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Senescent vascular cells contribute to vascular aging and atherosclerosis
key_concepts.description: Senescent vascular cells are found in atherosclerotic lesions but not in healthy vessels, expressing proinflammatory molecules and reduced endothelial nitric oxide synthase, which promotes vascular inflammation and dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere attrition as a mechanism of vascular cell senescence
key_concepts.description: Telomere shortening leads to vascular cell senescence and dysfunction, promoting atherogenesis. Conversely, telomere lengthening can extend cell lifespan and protect against vascular aging.
Other mechanisms such as activation of Ras signaling can induce vascular cell senescence and inflammation independent of telomere status, suggesting multiple pathways contribute to vascular aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies showing senescent vascular cells in human atherosclerotic lesions, telomere attrition associated with vascular aging, and experimental data on Ras activation inducing senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains aging as a fundamental process at organism level through cellular senescence; proposes causal mechanisms (telomere attrition, Ras activation); addresses broad aging-related vascular dysfunction linked to systemic aging.

results.title: Senescence-associated microvascular endothelial dysfunction: A focus on the blood-brain and blood-retinal barriers.

theories.name: Vascular Senescence Hypothesis of Age-Related Neurodegenerative Disorders

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that senescence of microvascular endothelial cells, which form the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and blood-retinal barrier (BRB), leads to dysfunction of these critical barriers. This dysfunction results in increased permeability and leakage, contributing to vascular and parenchymal damage associated with aging.

key_concepts.concept: Barrier Dysfunction as a Driver of Systemic Aging
key_concepts.description: The breakdown of BBB and BRB due to endothelial senescence is proposed to be a fundamental mechanism underlying age-related neurodegenerative disorders (ARND) such as Alzheimer's disease and age-related macular degeneration. This links local vascular aging to systemic aging processes affecting the brain and retina.

The hypothesis suggests that interventions aimed at reducing or reversing endothelial senescence (senotherapeutics) could restore barrier integrity and mitigate progression of ARND, providing a mechanistic basis for therapeutic development.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing recent discoveries regarding endothelial senescence pathways implicated in BBB and BRB breakdown, and discusses their relevance to ARND. It references associations between barrier permeability and aging as well as neurodegenerative disease, but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism (endothelial senescence causing barrier dysfunction) explaining systemic aging effects in neurodegeneration. It addresses aging broadly beyond a single organ by linking vascular aging to organism-level neurodegenerative outcomes.

results.title: The association between ambient particulate matter exposure and the telomere-mitochondrial axis of aging in newborns.

theories.name: Telomere-Mitochondrial Axis of Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Telomeres are protective DNA-protein structures at chromosome ends whose length shortens with cellular replication and stress, serving as a biomarker and potential causal factor in biological aging.
Mitochondrial DNA content reflects mitochondrial health and biogenesis, which are critical for cellular energy metabolism and implicated in aging processes through mitochondrial dysfunction.

The tumor suppressor p53 and the mitochondrial biogenesis regulator PGC-1α represent key molecular components linking telomere dynamics and mitochondrial function, forming a core axis that influences aging mechanisms.

Exposure to ambient particulate matter (PM2.5) during prenatal development affects telomere length, mitochondrial DNA content, and core-axis proteins, suggesting environmental factors can modulate fundamental aging pathways from early life.
Telomere length mediates the relationship between particulate matter exposure and mitochondrial DNA content as well as p53 protein levels, indicating a mechanistic link within the core-axis of aging.

theories.evidence: Epidemiological data from 556 mother-newborn pairs measuring placental and cord blood telomere length, mitochondrial DNA content, and protein levels of p53 and PGC-1α, correlated with prenatal PM2.5 exposure using statistical models and mediation analysis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism linking environmental exposure to fundamental aging processes via telomere and mitochondrial pathways, addressing organism-level aging markers and underlying molecular mediators.

results.title: Inflammation, Oxidative Stress, Vascular Aging and Atherosclerotic Ischemic Stroke.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.description: Inflammaging refers to the age-associated increase in systemic pro-inflammatory status characterized by a chronic, low-grade inflammatory state that contributes to the aging process and age-related diseases.
With aging, there is a reduced capacity to manage various stressors, which exacerbates the pro-inflammatory environment and promotes tissue dysfunction and damage.

key_concepts.concept: Link to vascular aging and disease
key_concepts.description: Inflammaging is implicated in vascular aging by promoting endothelial dysfunction, arterial stiffness, and atherosclerosis, thereby increasing the risk of ischemic stroke.

theories.evidence: Citations and synthesis of existing literature linking inflammation, oxidative stress, and vascular aging to ischemic stroke risk.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism explaining how aging occurs via chronic inflammation affecting systemic vascular function, with causal implications for aging-related vascular pathology.

results.title: Relations among CRFR1 and FKBP5 genotype, cortisol, and cognitive function in aging humans: A Project FRONTIER study.

theories.name: Glucocorticoid cascade hypothesis

key_concepts.concept: Role of baseline cortisol in cognitive aging
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis posits that elevated baseline cortisol levels contribute causally to cognitive decline during aging by affecting brain function and structure over time.

Specific genotypes at CRFR1 and FKBP5 loci are proposed to influence individual susceptibility to cortisol-related cognitive decline, suggesting a genetic basis for variability in aging-related cognitive outcomes.

theories.evidence: Longitudinal cognitive data over 3 years in non-demented rural Americans, genotype analysis of CRFR1 and FKBP5 SNPs, and cortisol measurements; results showed mixed support with some contradictory findings.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (cortisol dysregulation) underlying cognitive aging, with genetic factors modulating this process; the theory addresses aging broadly at the organismal cognitive function level.

results.title: Defective mitochondrial quality control in the aging of skeletal muscle.

theories.name: Mitochondrial quality control theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a central aging mechanism
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria not only produce ATP but also regulate redox signaling, calcium handling, and apoptotic pathways. With aging, these functions become compromised due to chronic oxidative stress and defective quality control, leading to muscle decline.

Quality control systems such as mitochondrial biogenesis, dynamics (fusion/fission), mitophagy (selective degradation of damaged mitochondria), and vesicle trafficking are critical for maintaining mitochondrial and muscle cell integrity. Their deterioration with age contributes to systemic muscle aging.

key_concepts.concept: Dynamic mitochondrial signaling and stress adaptability
key_concepts.description: The shift from viewing mitochondrial decline as static damage to understanding it as a failure in dynamic signaling networks and adaptability to stress highlights the complexity of mitochondrial involvement in aging.

theories.evidence: High-resolution respirometry data showing intrinsic declines in mitochondrial respiratory capacity independent of lifestyle; large-scale phenotyping and transcriptomic profiling linking mitochondrial integrity to physical performance and mobility.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining aging at the organismal level (skeletal muscle aging as part of systemic aging), discusses underlying causes (mitochondrial dysfunction and quality control failure), and addresses broad aging processes rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific phenomenon.

results.title: Analyzing different aging theories in the context of the brain: DNA damage, inflammation, redox imbalance, and neurodevelopment intertwine.

theories.name: DNA Damage Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging results from the progressive accumulation of DNA damage over time, impairing cellular functions and contributing to organismal aging.
Neurons efficiently repair learning-induced DNA damage despite having fewer repair pathways, indicating a specialized mechanism influencing brain aging.

theories.evidence: Reference to neuronal efficiency in repairing DNA damage and the role of DNA damage response factors like PARP1 and RELA.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria by proposing a fundamental causal mechanism (DNA damage accumulation) with organism-level implications, especially in brain aging.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The neuronal tissue shows unique resilience to oxidative stress caused by reactive oxygen and nitrogen species, suggesting specialized protective mechanisms in brain aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of reactive species in aging
key_concepts.description: Free radicals cause cumulative damage to cellular components, contributing to aging; the brain's response to these species is a key factor in its aging process.

theories.evidence: Discussion of neuronal tissue resilience to oxidative stress and references to reactive oxygen and nitrogen species effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (damage accumulation by free radicals) explaining aging at organismal level, with brain-specific nuances.

theories.name: Inflammaging Theory

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by persistent, systemic low-grade inflammation that contributes to tissue dysfunction and age-related diseases.
Molecules like TLR9 and NFκB link inflammatory pathways with memory processes, highlighting inflammation's role in brain aging.

theories.evidence: Discussion of inflammatory pathways in the brain, involvement of TLR9, NFκB, and RELA in inflammation and aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it explains a general aging mechanism (inflammation) with causal links to aging processes, including brain-specific aspects.

theories.name: Programmed Developmental Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Aging as continuation of developmental programs
key_concepts.description: Aging results from programmed biological processes that extend from development into later life, influencing aging trajectories.
RELA links developmental processes between skin and brain, integrating DNA damage response and inflammation control as part of programmed aging.

theories.evidence: Mention of RELA's role connecting development, DNA damage response, and inflammation; conceptual framing of aging as programmed developmental process.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria by proposing a programmed mechanism underlying aging at organismal level, integrating multiple pathways.

results.title: Understanding the Impact of Obesity on Ageing in the Radiance of DNA Metabolism.

theories.name: DNA damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by the progressive accumulation of DNA damage and mutations in the genome over time, which impairs cellular function and contributes to organismal aging.
The inability to effectively repair DNA damage leads to genomic instability, which accelerates aging and increases susceptibility to age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Link between DNA damage and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: DNA damage accumulation is a dominant mechanism contributing not only to aging but also to the development of neurodegeneration, cardiovascular disease, cancer, and other chronic conditions.

theories.evidence: Citations of observed higher DNA damage loads in obese individuals and known associations between DNA damage and aging phenotypes; references to molecular, cellular, and physiological aging features linked to DNA metabolism.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental, organism-level aging process with causal mechanisms (DNA damage accumulation and repair failure), broadly applicable beyond specific organs or diseases, and proposes underlying causes of aging.

theories.name: Obesity-accelerated aging hypothesis via DNA metabolism disruption

key_concepts.concept: Obesity as a driver of accelerated aging
key_concepts.description: Obesity induces phenotypes similar to aging, including decreased life expectancy and increased risk of age-related diseases, suggesting it accelerates the aging process.
Higher levels of DNA damage are observed in the genomes of obese individuals, implying that obesity may exacerbate genomic instability.

key_concepts.concept: Shared molecular mechanisms between obesity and aging
key_concepts.description: The inability to repair DNA damage effectively may be a common mechanistic link between obesity, aging, and cancer predisposition.

theories.evidence: Observational data on DNA damage loads in obese people; known health impacts of obesity overlapping with aging phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria: proposes a mechanism linking obesity to accelerated aging via DNA damage, which is a general aging mechanism; however, it is more of a hypothesis linking a condition (obesity) to aging rather than a standalone aging theory.

results.title: Cellular and Molecular Mechanisms of Action of Mitochondria-Targeted Antioxidants.

theories.name: Mitochondrial ROS Damage and Programmed Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) as Aging Drivers
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria generate reactive oxygen species that cause damage to mitochondrial and cellular components, contributing to dysfunction underlying aging and degenerative diseases.

Contrary to the classical view of aging as gradual accumulation of random damage, evidence suggests that ROS-induced damage is programmed, implying regulated processes rather than purely stochastic events.
Aging and many pathologies arise from disrupted ROS signaling and regulatory mechanisms, not just from oxidative damage per se.
Chain reactions of cardiolipin peroxidation initiated by mitochondrial ROS are key drivers of degenerative processes linked to aging.
Antioxidants targeted specifically to mitochondria (e.g., MitoQ, SkQ) can abolish cardiolipin peroxidation and potentially slow aging and treat related diseases.

theories.evidence: Citations of extensive in vitro, in vivo, and clinical trial studies of mitochondria-targeted antioxidants; molecular mechanism insights; recent progress in the field.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism of aging involving mitochondrial ROS and programmed damage, applicable broadly beyond specific diseases, with mechanistic explanations and evolutionary implications.

results.title: Is Human Aging a Form of Phenoptosis?

theories.name: Phenoptosis theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Aging as a genetically programmed, regulated process
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that aging is not merely the accumulation of damage but an ordered, genetically determined phenomenon shaped by natural selection, akin to phenoptosis—programmed death of an organism.

key_concepts.concept: Phenoptosis as an adaptive evolutionary strategy
key_concepts.description: Phenoptosis refers to programmed organismal death that may have adaptive value; aging is hypothesized to be a form of phenoptosis, implying that aging evolved as a regulated process rather than a byproduct of wear and tear.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews theoretical arguments and empirical data supporting aging as phenoptosis, highlighting recent interpretations of TERRA sequences and subtelomere-telomere theory mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging as a programmed process at the organismal level, addressing fundamental mechanisms and evolutionary logic.

theories.name: Subtelomere-telomere theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere and subtelomere regions regulate aging
key_concepts.description: This theory suggests that specific mechanisms involving telomeres and subtelomeric regions, including TERRA sequences, control aging processes through genetic and epigenetic regulation.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic modifications and cell senescence linked to telomeric structures
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that epigenetic changes, limits on cell replication, and the fixed size of telomeric heterochromatin contribute to gradual cellular senescence and organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Evidence includes recent interpretations of TERRA sequences and compatibility of epigenetic and cellular senescence phenomena with the theory's mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a mechanistic, generalizable explanation for aging involving fundamental cellular and molecular processes linked to telomeres, applicable organism-wide.

results.title: Entropy Meets Physiology: Should We Translate Aging as Disorder?

theories.name: Entropy Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Entropy as a metaphor for biological aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes a parallelism between the thermodynamic concept of entropy, which measures disorder in irreversible systems, and biological aging. It suggests that aging can be understood as an increase in biological disorder and irreversible damage at the organismal level.
Aging is characterized as a process that leads to irreversible physiological and molecular changes, similar to how entropy increases in closed systems, leading to disorder that cannot be reversed.

key_concepts.concept: Role of cellular senescence and stem cell dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is considered a response to accumulated damage, contributing to tissue dysfunction. The decline in mesenchymal stromal/stem cells (MSCs) self-renewal, differentiation, and immunomodulatory functions exacerbates tissue degradation and metabolic decline, linking cellular-level changes to systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammation as a key player in age-related syndromes
key_concepts.description: Inflammation is highlighted as a central mechanism that interacts with cellular senescence and stem cell dysfunction, promoting the progression of aging-related tissue damage and systemic decline.

theories.evidence: The paper is a concise review summarizing existing scientific research on MSCs aging, cellular senescence, and inflammation, and speculates on the analogy with entropy; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain why and how aging occurs at a general organismal level by proposing a fundamental organizing principle (entropy/disorder) linking cellular damage, senescence, and systemic decline. It provides a causal framework rather than mere description and connects cellular mechanisms to organismal aging.

results.title: Inflammaging in domestic dogs: basal level concentrations of IL-6, IL-1β, and TNF-α in serum of healthy dogs of different body sizes and ages.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Inflammaging refers to the progressive, chronic increase in proinflammatory status in mammals as they age, which is considered a fundamental aging process linked to multiple age-related diseases such as cardiovascular disease, arthritis, and cancer.
Key cytokines such as IL-6, IL-1β, and TNF-α mediate the inflammatory state associated with aging, and their serum concentrations can reflect the degree of inflammaging in an organism.

key_concepts.concept: Sex and reproductive status influence on inflammaging
key_concepts.description: Sex hormones, particularly estrogen in intact females, may modulate inflammatory pathways, potentially affecting the inflammaging process and aging rates, as indicated by differences in cytokine levels between intact and sterilized dogs.

theories.evidence: Measurement of serum IL-6, IL-1β, and TNF-α concentrations in healthy dogs of various ages and body sizes; statistical analysis (four-way ANOVA) showing age-related changes in IL-6 and interactions between sex, sterilization status, and IL-1β levels.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (chronic inflammation) underlying aging at the organism level, supported by mechanistic biomarkers (cytokines), and addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Long-term consumption of green tea EGCG enhances murine health span by mitigating multiple aspects of cellular senescence in mitotic and post-mitotic tissues, gut dysbiosis, and immunosenescence.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence involves the permanent cessation of cell division and the acquisition of a senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) that contributes to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage response and cell cycle inhibitors
key_concepts.description: Accumulation of DNA damage activates cell cycle inhibitors, which enforce senescence and contribute to aging-related tissue decline.
Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory cytokines and other factors that promote chronic inflammation (inflamm-aging) and disrupt tissue homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on multiple tissues including mitotic and post-mitotic
key_concepts.description: Senescence affects both dividing (mitotic) and non-dividing (post-mitotic) tissues such as visceral adipose and intestinal tissues, contributing broadly to organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Profiling of cellular senescence markers in multiple organs of mice at different ages; measurement of DNA damage response, cell cycle inhibitors, SASP regulators; assessment of immunosenescence and gut microbiome changes; intervention with EGCG showing attenuation of senescence markers and inflamm-aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (cellular senescence) underlying systemic aging, is generalizable across tissues and organismal aging, and is tested via intervention and longitudinal profiling.

theories.name: Inflamm-aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is accompanied by increased systemic levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as TNF-α and IL-1β, which contribute to tissue dysfunction and age-related decline.
Changes in immune cell populations, including altered CD4/CD8 T cell ratios and decreased NK cells, exacerbate inflamm-aging and impair immune surveillance.

theories.evidence: Measurement of inflamm-aging markers and immune cell populations in aging mice; observation that EGCG consumption reduces inflammatory cytokines and improves immune parameters.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a causal explanation for systemic aging processes via chronic inflammation and immune system changes, applicable organism-wide.

theories.name: Gut Microbiome Dysbiosis Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with reduced diversity of gut microbial species, which negatively impacts host metabolism and immune function.
An increase in harmful bacteria contributes to systemic inflammation and tissue dysfunction, promoting aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: Metagenomic analyses showing decreased microbial diversity and increased pathogenic bacteria with age; EGCG treatment preserves microbial diversity and suppresses pathogens.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it links gut dysbiosis causally to systemic aging processes, though the theory is emerging and less established than cellular senescence or inflamm-aging.

results.title: Aging, dementia and calcium metabolism.

theories.name: Disturbed neuronal calcium metabolism theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging and dementia are linked to disturbances in calcium metabolism within neurons, which may lead to neuronal dysfunction and degeneration.
Calcium imbalance in neurons is proposed as a fundamental causal mechanism driving aging-related cognitive decline and dementia, including vascular and Alzheimer's dementia.

theories.evidence: Overview of clinical studies with nimodipine treatment in vascular and Alzheimer's dementia is presented, suggesting therapeutic targeting of calcium metabolism.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (calcium metabolism disturbance) explaining aging-related neuronal decline and dementia, with organism-level implications beyond a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Gerotranscendence as a Life Perspective Among Nursing Home Residents: A Qualitative Study Into Positive Ageing While Dependent on 24/7 Care.

theories.name: Gerotranscendence theory

key_concepts.description: Gerotranscendence involves a shift from a materialistic and rational worldview to a cosmic and transcendent life perspective, reflecting a deeper understanding of existence in old age.
This shift is associated with enhanced life satisfaction, peace of mind, and acceptance of life's paradoxes, contributing to positive psychosocial aging.
Older adults develop insight, contextualism, relativism, and the ability to 'let go,' which are seen as markers of gerotranscendence and psychological growth in late life.

theories.evidence: Qualitative interviews with 20 nursing home residents aged 77-105, analyzed using Tornstam's Gerotranscendence Scale; narrative hermeneutical approach revealing recognition of gerotranscendence characteristics.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria for a psychosocial aging theory as it proposes a general mechanism explaining why and how psychosocial aging occurs at an organism-level scale, focusing on a broad life perspective shift and increased life satisfaction; however, it is psychosocial rather than biological.

results.title: Targeting macro- and micro-nutrient regulation of H<sub>2</sub>S signaling for the aging brain.

theories.name: Redox Homeostasis Dysfunction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging is driven by dysfunctions in redox homeostasis, where increased oxidative stress and diminished thiol-mediated protections lead to macromolecular damage. This damage accumulates over time, causing tissue failure, especially in organs like the brain.

H2S is highlighted as a critical gasotransmitter involved in redox regulation. Its metabolism and signaling pathways contribute to maintaining redox balance, and disruptions in these pathways may underlie aging processes.

Dietary restriction and iron status influence the enzymatic and non-enzymatic production and metabolism of H2S, thereby affecting redox homeostasis. These nutritional factors modulate aging-related redox dysfunction and may offer therapeutic avenues.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing literature on redox homeostasis, H2S metabolism, dietary restriction, and iron status, and their links to brain aging, glioblastoma, and neurodegeneration.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging mechanism (redox imbalance) with causal implications (oxidative stress causing macromolecular damage) and is generalizable to organismal aging, particularly brain aging. It is not limited to a single disease but connects to broad aging-related disorders.

results.title: Acquired Piezo2 Channelopathy is One Principal Gateway to Pathophysiology.

theories.name: Acquired Piezo2 Channelopathy Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Piezo2 channel microdamage as root cause of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that acquired microdamage to Piezo2 mechanosensory ion channels at proprioceptive somatosensory terminals under allostatic stress acts as a principal gateway to pathophysiology and is coined as the primary damage or root cause of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Proton affinity and ultrafast proton-based long-range signaling
key_concepts.description: Piezo2 channels are theorized to have a unique low-frequency semiconductor Schottky barrier diode-like feature that enables proton handling for quantum tunneling and ultrafast long-range signaling to the hippocampus, which is critical for proper synchronization and function.

key_concepts.concept: Impairment of Piezo2-initiated signaling leads to aging-related dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Acquired Piezo2 channelopathy impairs the ultrafast proton-based signaling and synchronization to the hippocampus, contributing to systemic pathophysiology and aging processes.
The microdamage to Piezo2 channels is interpreted within a novel quad-phasic non-contact injury model, providing a new mechanistic perspective on aging and related pathophysiology.

theories.evidence: The abstract references prior identification of Piezo2 channels, theoretical proposals of microdamage under allostatic stress, and the novel interpretation of proton-based signaling mechanisms; it also mentions potential diagnostic and treatment approaches (heart rate variability detection, paired-associative electromagnetic stimulation) but does not present direct experimental data within the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging at the organism level, linking molecular channel microdamage to systemic aging processes via novel signaling pathways. It is not limited to a single organ or disease but suggests a fundamental aging cause. The theory explains how aging occurs mechanistically through channelopathy and signaling impairment.

results.title: Daily temperature cycles prolong lifespan and have sex-specific effects on peripheral clock gene expression in Drosophila melanogaster.
Reactivation of senescence-associated endogenous retroviruses by ATF3 drives interferon signaling in aging.

theories.name: Senescence-associated endogenous retrovirus (SA-ERV) reactivation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Reactivation of endogenous retroviruses in senescent cells
key_concepts.description: A subclass of endogenous retroviruses (ERVs), termed senescence-associated ERVs (SA-ERVs), become transcriptionally reactivated specifically in senescent cells, suggesting a link between ERV activity and cellular aging.

key_concepts.concept: ATF3-mediated bidirectional transcription and dsRNA generation
key_concepts.description: The activating transcription factor 3 (ATF3) drives bidirectional transcription of SA-ERVs, producing double-stranded RNAs (dsRNAs) that serve as signaling molecules within senescent cells.

key_concepts.concept: Activation of innate immune signaling via RIG-I/MDA5-MAVS pathway
key_concepts.description: The dsRNAs derived from SA-ERVs activate the RIG-I/MDA5-MAVS signaling cascade, which triggers a type I interferon (IFN-I) response, linking retroviral reactivation to inflammatory signaling associated with aging.

key_concepts.concept: Systemic relevance and hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Increased expression of ATF3, SA-ERVs, and IFN-I response are observed in multiple tissues of aged individuals and progeria patients, along with elevated dsRNAs and IFNβ in blood, indicating a systemic role of this mechanism in organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental identification of SA-ERV reactivation in senescent fibroblasts; demonstration of ATF3-driven bidirectional transcription; activation of RIG-I/MDA5-MAVS pathway and IFN-I response; expression analyses in tissues from aged humans and progeria patients; detection of dsRNAs and IFNβ in aged individuals' blood.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism linking cellular senescence, retroviral reactivation, innate immune activation, and systemic aging processes. It addresses aging broadly beyond a single tissue or disease and provides mechanistic insight into why aging-associated inflammation occurs.

results.title: Dismantling Anti-Ageing Medicine: Why Age-Relatedness of Cardiovascular Disease is Proof of Robustness Rather Than of Ageing-Associated Vulnerability.
A biochemical marker for differentiation is present in an in vitro aging cell system.

theories.name: Cellular aging as differentiation and programmed cell death theory

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that cellular aging is not merely degenerative but is closely related to the process of cellular differentiation, implying that aging cells undergo changes similar to those seen in differentiation.

key_concepts.concept: Programmed cell death as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is suggested to result from programmed cell death mechanisms rather than random degeneration, indicating an intrinsic, regulated process contributing to aging at the cellular level.

key_concepts.concept: Histone variant ratio as a biochemical marker
key_concepts.description: The ratio of histone variants H2A.1 to H2A.2 decreases linearly with cumulative population doublings in human diploid fibroblasts, paralleling changes observed during differentiation, serving as a marker linking differentiation and aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing a linear decrease in the H2A.1/H2A.2 histone variant ratio in an in vitro aging system of human diploid fibroblasts; this ratio is known to decrease during differentiation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for cellular aging linked to differentiation and programmed cell death, addressing fundamental aging processes beyond a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Prepubertal gonad investment modulates thymus function: evidence in a teleost fish.
The shared molecular mechanisms underlying aging of the brain, major depressive disorder, and Alzheimer's disease: The role of circadian rhythm disturbances.

theories.name: Circadian Rhythm Disturbance Theory of Aging and Neuropsychiatric Disease

key_concepts.concept: Circadian clock dysfunction as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that disruptions in the circadian clock contribute fundamentally to the biological aging process by altering physiological rhythms that regulate cellular and systemic homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Shared molecular mechanisms linking aging, major depressive disorder (MDD), and Alzheimer's disease (AD)
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that circadian rhythm disturbances underlie common pathophysiological pathways in aging, MDD, and AD, implying that these conditions are interconnected through dysregulated biological clocks.

Nitro-oxidative stress is proposed as a key molecular mechanism that both contributes to aging and is associated with circadian clock disturbances, linking oxidative damage to the pathogenesis of AD and MDD.

theories.evidence: The paper cites clinical and preclinical studies showing associations between circadian rhythm disruption and mood regulation, dysregulation of clock genes in rodent depression models, and links between NOS, aging, AD, and MDD.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (circadian rhythm disturbances) underlying aging and related neuropsychiatric diseases, addressing systemic aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Microvascular Ageing Links Metabolic Disease to Age-Related Disorders: The Role of Oxidative Stress and Inflammation in Promoting Microvascular Dysfunction.

theories.name: Inflammation-driven microvascular aging theory

key_concepts.concept: Microvascular dysfunction as a marker of aging
key_concepts.description: Microvascular dysfunction, involving changes in endothelial function and vessel wall structure, is proposed as a superior indicator of biological aging compared to chronological age. It is implicated in multiple chronic age-associated diseases, linking vascular health to systemic aging.

Persistent low-grade inflammation driven by factors such as older age, hypertension, nutrient excess, and hyperglycemia promotes microvascular damage. This chronic inflammatory state is central to the aging process and the progression of metabolic and cardiovascular diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress and reactive oxygen species (ROS)
key_concepts.description: Increased local generation of ROS due to inflammation further impairs endothelial function and exacerbates inflammatory responses, creating a vicious cycle that accelerates microvascular aging and dysfunction.

Alterations in mitochondrial function contribute to irreversible structural changes in the microvasculature and are a hallmark of many age-related diseases, linking cellular energy metabolism to vascular aging.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing existing literature on microvascular dysfunction, inflammation, oxidative stress, and mitochondrial dysfunction in aging and metabolic diseases. It cites evidence linking inhibition of inflammatory pathways to reduced risk of age-related cardiovascular diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking chronic inflammation and oxidative stress to systemic aging via microvascular dysfunction. It addresses fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases and discusses underlying biological mechanisms.

results.title: Exploring the Impact of Microplastics and Nanoplastics on Macromolecular Structure and Functions.

theories.name: Oxidative Epigenetic Feedback Loop Theory of Cellular Aging Induced by Microplastics

key_concepts.description: Microplastics and nanoplastics induce oxidative stress by generating reactive oxygen species that damage cellular components, leading to impaired cell function and contributing to aging processes.

Exposure to microplastics triggers epigenetic modifications, such as DNA methylation or histone modification, which can alter gene expression patterns relevant to aging and may be heritable across generations.

key_concepts.concept: Feedback Loop Between Oxidative Stress and Epigenetics
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes a mechanistic feedback loop where oxidative stress induces epigenetic changes that further exacerbate oxidative damage, creating a self-reinforcing cycle that accelerates cellular aging.

key_concepts.concept: Size-Dependent Organelle Targeting and Pollutant Corona Effects
key_concepts.description: The impact of micro- and nanoplastics varies with particle size, influencing which organelles are targeted and how pollutant coronas (layers of adsorbed molecules) modify their biological interactions, affecting aging-related cellular damage.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review that integrates existing mechanistic studies on oxidative stress, epigenetic alterations, protein misfolding, and other molecular damages caused by microplastics, proposing a unifying hypothesis; it cites experimental and ecological data but does not present new experiments.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it proposes a general mechanistic explanation for how microplastic-induced molecular damage can drive cellular aging processes at the organismal level, connecting oxidative stress and epigenetic regulation in a feedback loop relevant beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Telomerase as a possible key to bypass reproductive cost.

theories.name: Telomere biology and somatic telomerase activity as a determinant of aging rate linked to reproductive strategy

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length as determinant of replicative aging
key_concepts.description: Telomere length is proposed to limit the number of cell divisions, thereby influencing cellular aging and potentially organismal aging by restricting regenerative capacity.

key_concepts.concept: Somatic telomerase activity supports proliferative capacity and organismal lifespan
key_concepts.description: Telomerase activity in somatic cells maintains telomere length, enabling continued cell division and tissue regeneration, which may extend organismal lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Telomerase activity as a trade-off with tumor suppression
key_concepts.description: The absence of telomerase activity in somatic cells acts as a tumor suppression mechanism by limiting uncontrolled cell proliferation, suggesting a balance between aging, regeneration, and cancer risk.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere biology reflects aging rate from species reproductive strategy perspective
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis proposes that variation in telomere biology and somatic telomerase activity among species correlates with their reproductive strategies, influencing aging rates as an adaptive trait rather than a simple cellular limit.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses numerous examples from invertebrate and vertebrate species to challenge existing assumptions and support the novel hypothesis linking telomere biology with reproductive strategy and aging rate.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain aging as a fundamental process by linking telomere biology and telomerase activity to organismal aging and lifespan through reproductive strategy, providing a causal mechanism and evolutionary logic applicable broadly across species.

results.title: Telomerase-Mediated Anti-Ageing Interventions.

theories.name: Telomere Shortening and Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening as a cause of aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres, repetitive DNA-protein complexes at chromosome ends, shorten progressively with each cell division due to the end-replication problem. This shortening limits cellular replicative capacity and is proposed as a fundamental mechanism driving biological aging.
