Aging involves cycles of homeostasis disruption and repair, where hormesis facilitates improved maintenance and repair mechanisms to counteract aging-related damage.

theories.evidence: Discussion of caloric restriction, exercise, nutrition as hormetic interventions supported by biomolecular markers and physiological outcomes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a generalizable, causal framework explaining how biological aging can be modulated through adaptive stress responses affecting the whole organism.

results.title: The Role of Ginseng and Its Bioactive Compounds in Aging: Cells and Animal Studies.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Framework

key_concepts.description: Aging involves a progressive decline in physiological functions, leading to increased vulnerability to stressors and diseases.

A set of interconnected biological processes that collectively drive aging, including genomic instability, telomere attrition, epigenetic alterations, loss of proteostasis, deregulated nutrient sensing, mitochondrial dysfunction, cellular senescence, stem cell exhaustion, and altered intercellular communication.
Natural compounds such as ginsenosides can modulate these hallmarks, potentially delaying aging and mitigating age-related diseases by targeting fundamental aging processes.

theories.evidence: Summary of cellular and animal studies on ginseng and its bioactive compounds affecting aging hallmarks; references to pharmacological functions and bioconversion processes enhancing bioactivity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses general aging mechanisms through the hallmarks framework, proposes causal biological processes underlying aging, and discusses interventions targeting these mechanisms at the organismal level.

results.title: Modeling the dynamics of energy imbalance: The free radical theory of aging and frailty revisited.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative Stress as a Driver of Aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the accumulation of oxidative damage caused by free radicals to biological molecules (DNA, proteins, lipids) is a fundamental cause of aging. This damage impairs cellular and tissue function over time, leading to systemic decline.

Aging is associated with an imbalance between energy production and consumption, exacerbated by oxidative stress, which impairs the organism's ability to maintain homeostasis. This imbalance contributes to frailty, characterized by reduced capacity to cope with stressors.

key_concepts.concept: Frailty as a Manifestation of Aging Processes
key_concepts.description: Frailty is conceptualized as a geriatric syndrome reflecting the cumulative effect of oxidative damage and energy imbalance, leading to decreased resilience and functional decline. It links molecular damage to organism-level vulnerability.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review discussing existing literature on oxidative stress and frailty, citing pharmacological and behavioral approaches, but notes the lack of effective interventions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (oxidative damage) explaining aging at the organism level, linking molecular damage to systemic decline and frailty. It addresses aging broadly, not limited to specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Molecular basis of cell fate plasticity - insights from the privileged cells.

theories.name: Cell fate plasticity and partial reprogramming theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The ability of somatic cells to change their differentiated state, moving not only downward along Waddington's landscape but also upward or sideways, indicating a dynamic and reversible cell identity. This plasticity underlies regenerative potential observed in some organisms and may be present in mammals.

key_concepts.concept: Partial reprogramming by Yamanaka factors reverses aging hallmarks
key_concepts.description: Expression of Yamanaka factors can partially reprogram cells, reversing many molecular and cellular hallmarks of aging without full dedifferentiation, suggesting a mechanism to rejuvenate cells and tissues.

key_concepts.concept: Senescence, aging, and malignancy as distinct cell states
key_concepts.description: These are proposed as definable biochemical and biophysical states of cells, implying that aging is not just a passive decline but a regulated cell state that can be potentially manipulated.

theories.evidence: Citations of partial reprogramming studies (e.g., reference [76]) showing reversal of aging hallmarks; conceptual synthesis of molecular insights from privileged cells that reprogram non-stochastically.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining how aging might be reversed or modulated at the cellular level, addressing causal mechanisms of aging through cell state plasticity and reprogramming, with implications for organism-level aging and rejuvenation.

results.title: Nuclear envelope disruption triggers hallmarks of aging in lung alveolar macrophages

theories.name: Nuclear envelope rupture-induced genomic instability theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Nuclear envelope rupture as a source of DNA damage
key_concepts.description: Cells migrating through confined spaces experience mechanical forces that cause transient ruptures in the nuclear envelope, leading to DNA damage. This damage contributes to genomic instability, a hallmark of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of Lamin A/C in protecting nuclear integrity
key_concepts.description: Lamin A/C is a nuclear envelope protein that limits nuclear envelope rupture events. Its deficiency leads to increased nuclear envelope rupture, DNA damage, and cellular senescence, particularly in lung alveolar macrophages.

key_concepts.concept: Genomic instability driving cellular senescence and immune dysfunction
key_concepts.description: DNA damage from nuclear envelope rupture activates p53-dependent senescence pathways in alveolar macrophages, contributing to immune dysfunction and increased susceptibility to infections, which are features of aging.
Upregulation of lysosomal markers such as CD63 in aged and Lamin A/C-deficient macrophages suggests a mechanism for clearing damaged DNA, linking cellular maintenance pathways to aging processes.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing Lamin A/C ablation causes nuclear envelope rupture, DNA damage, p53-dependent senescence, depletion of alveolar macrophages, and increased infection susceptibility; in vivo observations of macrophage migration causing nuclear envelope rupture; shared lysosomal signatures in aged and Lamin A/C-deficient macrophages; requirement of CD63 for damaged DNA clearance.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (nuclear envelope rupture-induced genomic instability) underlying aging at the organismal immune system level; explains how mechanical forces and nuclear envelope integrity contribute to aging; links cellular senescence and immune dysfunction to a fundamental aging process; not limited to a narrow disease but addresses immune aging broadly.

results.title: Nuclear mitochondrial DNA transfer revisited: From genomic noise to hallmark of aging.

theories.name: NUMT accumulation as a hallmark of aging

key_concepts.description: NUMTs are mitochondrial DNA fragments inserted into the nuclear genome, originating from the ancient endosymbiotic relationship between mitochondria and host cells. These insertions are evolutionarily conserved and can modulate nuclear architecture and cellular function.

Mitochondrial damage caused by cellular stress leads to the release of mtDNA, which integrates into nuclear DNA via non-homologous end joining. This process, termed NUMTogenesis, is ongoing and may be exacerbated in aging tissues.

key_concepts.concept: NUMTs intersecting with biological hallmarks of aging
key_concepts.description: Accumulation of NUMTs correlates with aging phenotypes such as cognitive decline and reduced lifespan, suggesting a causal role in biological aging. NUMTs may influence mitochondrial-nuclear communication, promote inflammation, affect telomere dynamics, and contribute to cellular senescence.

theories.evidence: Citations of whole-genome sequencing studies showing NUMT diversity and polymorphisms; observations of NUMT accumulation correlating with cognitive decline and lifespan reduction; mechanistic insights into mtDNA release and nuclear integration; links to inflammation, telomere dynamics, and senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (NUMT accumulation) contributing causally to aging processes at the organismal level, linking mitochondrial damage to nuclear genome changes and systemic aging hallmarks.

results.title: COVID-19 and Crosstalk With the Hallmarks of Aging

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: The gradual deterioration of the immune system associated with aging, leading to reduced ability to respond to infections and increased susceptibility to diseases.
Chronic low-grade inflammation that increases with age, often driven by inflammasomes, which contributes to tissue damage and age-related pathologies.
Accumulation of DNA damage and mutations over time that impair cellular function and contribute to aging and age-related diseases.
Decline in mitochondrial function leading to reduced energy production and increased reactive oxygen species, which exacerbate cellular aging.
Progressive shortening of telomeres with each cell division, eventually leading to cellular senescence or apoptosis.
Changes in DNA methylation, histone modification, and chromatin remodeling that affect gene expression patterns during aging.
Decline in the cellular process that removes damaged organelles and proteins, leading to accumulation of cellular debris and dysfunction.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing literature on the hallmarks of aging and their interaction with SARS-CoV-2 infection, citing known mechanisms and observed clinical outcomes in older adults.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses general biological aging mechanisms (hallmarks of aging) that explain why aging occurs and how it impacts systemic responses, including immunity. It proposes causal mechanisms and is broadly applicable to organismal aging beyond specific diseases.

results.title: Neurotropic Viruses as Acute and Insidious Drivers of Aging

theories.name: Viral-Induced Accelerated Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Viral Pathogenesis as a Driver of Aging
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that both active and latent viral infections contribute to aging by inducing cellular stresses that disrupt homeostasis, leading to irreversible damage and age-related pathologies such as neurodegeneration.

key_concepts.concept: Stress Response Pathways Activation by Viruses
key_concepts.description: Viruses trigger multiple stress pathways including dysregulation of protein quality control, DNA damage via integration and epigenetic changes, immune-mediated oxidative stress, immune exhaustion, and energy depletion, which collectively accelerate aging processes.

The theory integrates viral effects with established hallmarks of aging, suggesting that viral infections exacerbate these fundamental aging mechanisms, thereby promoting premature aging and age-associated diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews epidemiological correlations between viral infections and neurodegenerative diseases, and contextualizes findings from multiple basic science studies on viral impacts on cellular stress pathways and aging hallmarks.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking viral infections to systemic aging processes, discusses underlying biological pathways, and connects to organism-level aging outcomes.

results.title: Dog Life Spans and the Evolution of Aging.

theories.name: Disposable Soma Theory of the Evolution of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that organisms allocate limited resources between reproduction and somatic maintenance, optimizing life history traits such as growth and lifespan to maximize fitness. Aging results from a trade-off where investment in somatic maintenance is insufficient to prevent damage accumulation, leading to senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Mutation Accumulation vs. Life History Optimization
key_concepts.description: The theory is contrasted with mutation accumulation, which attributes aging to the buildup of deleterious mutations with late-life effects. The disposable soma theory emphasizes adaptive resource allocation rather than passive mutation buildup as the primary driver of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Cancer as a Cause of Age-Dependent Mortality
key_concepts.description: The theory incorporates the idea that increased body size leads to higher age-dependent mortality primarily due to cancer, suggesting that somatic defenses against cancer have not evolved rapidly enough to match recent increases in body size in dog breeds.

theories.evidence: Empirical data confirming the inverse relationship between lifespan and body size across dog breeds after controlling for phylogeny; analysis showing that extrinsic mortality differences do not explain lifespan variation; correlation of increased early growth rate and body size with higher age-dependent mortality mainly due to cancer.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it provides a generalizable evolutionary explanation for aging at the organism level, proposes causal mechanisms (resource allocation trade-offs and cancer defense evolution), and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

theories.name: Mutation Accumulation Theory

key_concepts.description: This theory suggests that aging results from the buildup of mutations that have deleterious effects manifesting late in life, when natural selection is weaker, leading to senescence.

theories.evidence: The paper attempts to evaluate the relative influence of mutation accumulation versus life history optimization by analyzing lifespan and body size relationships in dog breeds.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it is a general evolutionary theory explaining aging causally and broadly, though the paper finds less support for it in this context.

results.title: The Conglomerate Theory of Oncogenesis: A Unified Biophysical Framework for Understanding Cancer Through Bioaccumulation

theories.name: Conglomerate Theory of Oncogenesis

key_concepts.concept: Extension of aging damage mechanisms to cancer
key_concepts.description: This theory extends the Conglomerate Theory of Aging to explain cancer development as a localized acceleration of the same molecular damage processes, specifically transition metal bioaccumulation and AGE/ALE formation.

Unlike systemic aging, cancer arises from localized microenvironments where autocatalytic feedback loops of molecular damage promote cellular transformation, tumor progression, metastasis, and therapeutic resistance.
The theory provides a mechanistic framework linking molecular damage accumulation to oncogenesis, suggesting multi-targeted therapeutic strategies aimed at upstream drivers of cancer.

theories.evidence: The abstract outlines the theoretical framework and mechanistic rationale; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism for cancer development linked to fundamental molecular damage processes that also drive aging, thus addressing a general biological process beyond a single disease.

theories.name: Conglomerate Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging is driven by universal biochemical processes initiated by reactive species, including transition metal bioaccumulation and formation of advanced glycation and lipoxidation end products. These processes contribute to molecular damage that accumulates over time.

The accumulation of transition metals, AGEs, ALEs, and their hybrid complexes creates self-reinforcing feedback loops that accelerate molecular damage, leading to systemic decline characteristic of aging.

theories.evidence: Referenced as foundational principles underlying the proposed oncogenesis theory; presumably based on prior literature though not detailed in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain aging as a fundamental, organism-level process driven by biochemical damage accumulation mechanisms with causal explanations.

results.title: Influence of a diet with potential geroprotectors on blood biochemistry and aging-associated markers in domestic cats: a pilot study.

theories.name: Dietary modulation of molecular hallmarks of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that chronic inflammation contributes causally to aging and age-related decline. Markers such as NF-κB and IL-1β are key mediators of inflammatory pathways that drive cellular and systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate with age and promote tissue dysfunction via secretion of pro-inflammatory factors. The marker p16 is used as an indicator of senescent cell burden, linking senescence to organismal aging.

Proteins such as SIRT1 and Klotho regulate metabolic and stress response pathways that influence aging rate and healthspan. Upregulation of these factors is associated with protective effects against age-related molecular damage.

key_concepts.concept: Receptor for advanced glycation end products (RAGE) in aging
key_concepts.description: RAGE mediates cellular responses to damage-associated molecular patterns and advanced glycation end products, contributing to chronic inflammation and aging-related tissue damage.

Plant-based extracts (e.g., silymarin, green tea, grape seed, curcumin, grapefruit seed) can influence molecular hallmarks of aging by reducing inflammation and senescence markers and enhancing protective metabolic regulators.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from a randomized controlled pilot study in domestic cats showing changes in blood biochemistry and expression of aging-associated markers (NF-κB, IL-1β, p16, SIRT1, Klotho, RAGE) after dietary intervention with geroprotective compounds.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses fundamental aging mechanisms (inflammation, senescence, metabolic regulation) with causal implications, proposes dietary modulation as a mechanism influencing systemic aging processes, and is applicable broadly beyond the specific species studied.

results.title: Periodontitis-induced Systemic Multi-organ Aging Mediated by the NF-κB Signalling Pathway.

theories.name: NF-κB-mediated cellular senescence theory of systemic aging

key_concepts.concept: Periodontitis as a systemic aging inducer
key_concepts.description: Periodontitis, a localized inflammatory disease, can induce aging phenotypes in multiple distal organs, suggesting that local chronic inflammation can drive systemic biological aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: NF-κB signaling pathway as a mediator
key_concepts.description: The NF-κB signaling pathway plays a critical causal role in mediating the systemic aging effects induced by periodontitis by regulating cellular senescence and the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP).

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence and SASP as aging drivers
key_concepts.description: Markers of cellular senescence such as p16^INK4a, p21^CIP1/WAF1, β-galactosidase, and SASP regulatory genes (Il1b, Il6, Mmp13) are upregulated in multiple organs, linking cellular senescence mechanistically to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from a ligature-induced periodontitis mouse model showing increased senescence markers and SASP gene expression in multiple organs; intervention with NF-κB inhibitor BAY 11-7082 attenuated these aging markers.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (NF-κB-mediated cellular senescence) explaining systemic aging induced by chronic inflammation; addresses aging broadly across multiple organs; provides mechanistic insight rather than mere correlation.

results.title: Metabolaging: a new geroscience perspective linking aging pathologies and metabolic dysfunction.

theories.name: Metabolaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic dysfunction as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that age-related alterations in metabolic systems contribute fundamentally to the aging process by disrupting homeostasis and leading to systemic decline. It emphasizes that metabolic imbalances are not just consequences but active contributors to aging pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Interaction of metabolically active organs and nutrient-sensing pathways
key_concepts.description: The theory highlights the role of key organs such as adipose tissue and their interaction with nutrient-sensing pathways (e.g., insulin/IGF signaling, mTOR) in orchestrating systemic metabolic changes that underlie aging. This organ-pathway crosstalk is central to understanding how metabolic decline propagates aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Link between metabolic aging and stress response
key_concepts.description: Metabolaging posits that metabolic dysfunction with age impairs the organism’s ability to respond to acute physiological stressors, such as trauma or burn injuries, thereby connecting metabolic aging to resilience and survival mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Conceptual framework introduced in the abstract; references to hallmarks of aging and metabolic organ function; discussion of metabolic disturbances influencing stress responses; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging centered on metabolic dysfunction affecting systemic aging processes. It addresses broad organism-level mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena, linking metabolic pathways and organ function to aging and stress resilience.

results.title: Oxidation of biological molecules with age and induced oxidative stress in different growth phases of Saccharomyces cerevisiae.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging results from the accumulation of oxidative damage to biological molecules such as lipids and proteins caused by reactive oxygen species (ROS). This damage impairs cellular function and contributes to the decline associated with aging.

Different strains or cells may vary in their ability to withstand oxidative stress, which correlates with differences in lifespan. Cells or organisms with better oxidative stress defenses are proposed to age more slowly.

key_concepts.concept: Protein and lipid oxidation as aging markers
key_concepts.description: Oxidative modifications of proteins (e.g., carbonylation) and lipids (e.g., TBARS) increase with age and under induced oxidative stress, serving as measurable indicators of oxidative damage linked to aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data measuring lipid peroxidation (TBARS), protein carbonylation, and protein oxidation in four strains of Saccharomyces cerevisiae at different growth phases and under induced oxidative stress conditions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it addresses a general biological aging mechanism (oxidative damage accumulation) with causal explanation, supported by experimental data in a model organism, and attempts to link oxidative stress resistance to lifespan differences.

results.title: From adaptation to exhaustion: defining exposure-related malnutrition as a bioenergetic phenotype of aging.

theories.name: Exposure-Related Malnutrition (ERM) as a Bioenergetic Phenotype of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Bioenergetic constraint and unresolved physiological adaptation
key_concepts.description: Aging is framed as the cumulative cost of unresolved physiological adaptation under limited bioenergetic resources, rather than passive molecular damage accumulation. This concept emphasizes energy availability as a critical factor in determining aging trajectories.

ERM is introduced as a mechanistically grounded phenotype characterized by subtle multisystem declines (fatigue, cognitive slowing, immune dysregulation, anabolic resistance) arising from sustained metabolic strain during chronic stress exposure. It is distinct from classical malnutrition and represents an early maladaptive state preceding frailty and chronic disease.

A unifying model describing the trajectory of stress response and resolution, highlighting that insufficient metabolic substrates lead to failed resolution and a trade-off state prioritizing immediate survival over long-term maintenance, which underlies ERM.

Interconnected mechanisms such as neuroendocrine activation, immune reprogramming, skeletal muscle catabolism, translational suppression, and mitochondrial distress create a feedback loop that sustains maladaptive adaptation and bioenergetic failure.

ERM is proposed as a reversible condition detectable by dynamic biomarkers and functional assessments, with potential for intervention through circadian-aligned lifestyle strategies to restore resilience and extend healthspan.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review that synthesizes existing knowledge on mechanisms (neuroendocrine, immune, mitochondrial), maps ERM onto hallmarks of aging, and proposes a staging model and clinical strategies. No new experimental data is presented but multiple mechanistic pathways and clinical features are cited.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging as a bioenergetic failure of adaptive resolution, addressing systemic aging processes beyond single organs or diseases. It offers an organizing principle linking metabolic stress, energy availability, and aging phenotypes.

results.title: From Adaptation to Exhaustion: Defining Exposure-Related Malnutrition as a Bioenergetic Phenotype of Aging

theories.name: Exposure-Related Malnutrition (ERM) as a Bioenergetic Phenotype of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is framed as the cumulative cost of unresolved physiological adaptation under limited bioenergetic resources. Chronic metabolic strain during sustained stress leads to maladaptive states rather than passive damage accumulation.

ERM is introduced as a mechanistically grounded phenotype characterized by subtle multisystem declines (fatigue, cognitive slowing, immune dysregulation, anabolic resistance) that occur without overt weight loss or classical malnutrition signs. It represents an early, reversible energy-constrained maladaptive state preceding frailty and chronic disease.

A unifying model describing the trajectory of stress response where bioenergetic availability determines whether the system successfully resolves stress or defaults to a trade-off prioritizing immediate survival over long-term maintenance, leading to ERM.

Interconnected mechanisms such as neuroendocrine activation, immune reprogramming, muscle catabolism, translational suppression, and mitochondrial distress create a feedback loop that sustains maladaptation and bioenergetic failure.

key_concepts.concept: Mapping ERM onto hallmarks of aging and clinical implications
key_concepts.description: ERM is linked to established hallmarks of aging and staged multidimensionally, with clinical strategies proposed for early detection and reversal through biomarkers, functional assessments, and lifestyle interventions aligned with circadian biology.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review proposing a new framework supported by synthesis of existing knowledge on neuroendocrine, immune, metabolic, and mitochondrial mechanisms; clinical observations of subtle multisystem decline; and mapping to hallmarks of aging. No new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, organism-level causal explanation for aging as a failure of adaptive resolution under bioenergetic constraints, linking multiple systems and mechanisms. It addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases and offers mechanistic insight rather than mere description.

results.title: The biphasic and age-dependent impact of Klotho on hallmarks of aging and skeletal muscle function

theories.name: Entropy-based molecular disorder theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by the buildup of molecular errors that disrupt the flow of biological information, leading to increased disorder within cellular and tissue systems.

key_concepts.concept: Network entropy as a measure of aging
key_concepts.description: Entropy, a concept from statistical physics, is used to quantify the level of disorder in gene networks associated with the hallmarks of aging, reflecting the systemic decline in molecular order with age.

There exists an inflection point in the progression of entropy increase at a certain age (old age, 22-24 months in mice), beyond which the disorder accelerates or becomes irreversible, marking a critical phase in aging.

theories.evidence: Use of statistical physics to estimate entropy from gene expression data related to hallmarks of aging; observation of entropy inflection point in old mice; experimental overexpression of α-Klotho protein to modulate gene networks and assess functional outcomes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism (molecular disorder accumulation quantified by entropy) explaining aging at the organismal level; connects molecular changes to functional decline (sarcopenia); uses a mechanistic framework rather than descriptive or disease-specific focus.

theories.name: Klotho-mediated modulation of aging hallmarks theory

key_concepts.concept: Longevity protein α-Klotho as an aging modulator
key_concepts.description: α-Klotho is proposed to influence aging by modulating gene expression across all hallmarks of aging, potentially restoring molecular order and improving tissue function.

The beneficial effects of Klotho overexpression on muscle strength and molecular hallmarks are observed in old mice but not in oldest-old mice, suggesting a biphasic and age-dependent impact with a limit beyond the entropic tipping point.

theories.evidence: Experimental overexpression of α-Klotho in old and oldest-old mice; measurement of gene expression changes across aging hallmarks; functional assessment of muscle strength improvements in old but not oldest-old mice.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general aging mechanism (modulation of hallmarks of aging by Klotho) with causal implications; links molecular intervention to systemic aging phenotypes; discusses limits of intervention related to aging progression.

results.title: MoMA: Large scale network model of Microbes, Metabolites and Aging hallmarks

theories.name: Microbiome-mediated modulation of aging hallmarks theory

key_concepts.concept: Gut microbiome as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The gut microbiome influences age-related health decline by modulating biological processes that contribute to aging. It acts both as a marker and an active modulator of systemic aging mechanisms.
Metabolites produced by gut microbes interact with and regulate the hallmarks of aging, suggesting a causal role of microbial metabolic activity in the aging process at a systems level.

The structure and connectivity of microbial-metabolite-aging hallmark interactions in a large-scale network influence how aging hallmarks are differentially regulated, highlighting complex systemic effects.

theories.evidence: Development of a Microbiome Metabolite Aging (MMA) fusion network with 238 metabolite-aging hallmark interactions and identification of 249 microbes affecting aging hallmarks; references to prior studies on microbiome's role in aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism by which the gut microbiome and its metabolites modulate fundamental aging hallmarks at the organismal level, thus explaining how aging occurs systemically.

results.title: Liquid-liquid phase separation in aging: Novel insights in the pathogenesis and therapeutics.

theories.name: Liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) in aging

key_concepts.concept: LLPS as a mechanism for membraneless organelle formation
key_concepts.description: LLPS is a reversible biophysical process by which biomolecules self-assemble into distinct, membraneless compartments within cells, such as Cajal bodies and RNA transport granules. This organization is crucial for maintaining cellular functions and coordinating biochemical reactions.

key_concepts.concept: LLPS involvement in physiological and pathological processes
key_concepts.description: LLPS has been implicated in diverse biological contexts including immune responses and tumorigenesis, suggesting it plays a broad role in cellular regulation and disease states.

key_concepts.concept: Interaction between LLPS and hallmarks of aging
key_concepts.description: The paper explores how LLPS mechanisms relate to the twelve hallmarks of aging, proposing that LLPS contributes to the molecular and cellular changes underlying aging processes, potentially influencing aging pathogenesis and therapeutic strategies.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews recent advances linking LLPS to aging hallmarks, referencing the updated framework of aging hallmarks and molecular studies on LLPS in cellular compartments; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental cellular mechanism (LLPS) that may causally contribute to aging by affecting cellular organization and function broadly, linking to general aging hallmarks. It proposes an underlying mechanism rather than describing narrow phenomena, thus meeting the core criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: De Novo Design of Anti-Aging Peptides

theories.name: Information Theory of Aging (ITOA)

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that aging is driven by a gradual decline in the fidelity and integrity of epigenetic information, which is crucial for maintaining cellular identity and function. This loss leads to systemic deterioration characteristic of aging.

theories.evidence: The paper references the ITOA as a foundational concept and tests anti-aging peptides designed via computational methods that demonstrate delaying cellular senescence and restoring cellular functions in vitro, as well as improving locomotor activity in aged C. elegans.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it explains a fundamental, organism-level aging mechanism (epigenetic information loss), proposes a causal mechanism, and addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Aging, cellular senescence and Parkinson's disease.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: With advancing age, senescent cells accumulate in tissues, including the brain. These cells cease to divide and alter tissue function, contributing to aging phenotypes and age-related diseases.
Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, and proteases that can disrupt tissue microenvironments, promote chronic inflammation, and exacerbate neurodegeneration.
Cellular senescence in brain cells may drive or exacerbate neuropathological processes in Parkinson’s disease by interacting with mitochondrial dysfunction, oxidative stress, and neuroinflammation.

theories.evidence: Review of studies examining cellular senescence hallmarks in PD, including mitochondrial dysfunction, loss of proteostasis, genomic instability, telomere attrition, and direct studies of senescence in PD models.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (cellular senescence) contributing to systemic aging and age-related neurodegeneration, with broad applicability beyond PD alone.

results.title: The tumor suppression theory of aging.

theories.name: Tumor Suppression Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Somatic mutation as proximal cause of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that somatic mutations are the immediate cause of aging, but the critical consequences are not functional impairment per se, but oncogenic transformation and clonal expansion of mutated cells.
Many aging phenotypes are interpreted as evolved tumor-suppressive mechanisms that limit malignant growth, which is the dominant cause of death in early and middle life for many mammals.

key_concepts.concept: Cell proliferation as mutation driver influenced by obesity and caloric restriction
key_concepts.description: The rate of aging is modulated by factors affecting cell proliferation, such as obesity accelerating and caloric restriction decelerating aging, since most mutations arise during cell division.

Cellular senescence, apoptosis, and differentiation induced by oncogenes, telomere shortening, or DNA damage evolved as secondary defenses to limit tumorigenic potential of expanding clones, but accumulation of senescent cells and associated phenotypes contribute to tissue dysfunction and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Peto's paradox and mutation as a fundamental limit on longevity
key_concepts.description: The conservation of cancer as a dominant cause of death across species (Peto's paradox) supports the idea that somatic mutation imposes a fundamental, hard limit on mammalian lifespan.

theories.evidence: The abstract references evolutionary logic (Peto's paradox), known cellular mechanisms (senescence, apoptosis), and epidemiological observations (effects of obesity and caloric restriction) to support the theory; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging as a fundamental organism-level process, linking somatic mutation and tumor suppression mechanisms to systemic aging phenotypes and lifespan limits.

results.title: Past and Future Directions for Research on Cellular Senescence.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cells enter a state of permanent growth arrest after repeated replication or stress, preventing further cell division. This arrest is a hallmark of cellular senescence and contributes to aging by limiting tissue regeneration.

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells as fundamental pillars of aging
key_concepts.description: Accumulation of senescent cells in tissues over time drives aging phenotypes and functional decline. These cells secrete pro-inflammatory factors that disrupt tissue homeostasis and promote age-related pathologies.

Interventions aimed at selectively eliminating or modulating senescent cells to improve healthspan and potentially delay aging-related decline. This therapeutic approach is based on the causal role of senescent cells in systemic aging.

theories.mode: review, discuss, point to future directions
theories.evidence: Historical description from Hayflick and Moorehead, recognition of senescence as a fundamental aging pillar, mention of senotherapeutics development as applied research in the field
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental, organism-level aging mechanism (cellular senescence), proposes causal mechanisms (cell-cycle arrest, secretory phenotype), and addresses systemic aging rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: The damage-independent evolution of ageing by selective destruction

theories.name: Selective Destruction Theory of Ageing

key_concepts.description: A proposed biological mechanism that specifically removes faster-growing aberrant cells from tissues to prevent morbidity and mortality risks associated with these cells. This mechanism acts as a counterselection process to control cell population dynamics.

The survival advantage conferred by selective destruction allows slower-growing mutant cells to outcompete both fast mutants and wildtype cells, leading to their spread within tissues. This shift in cell population dynamics induces ageing as a metabolic slowdown.

Ageing arises not from the accumulation of molecular damage, as in the disposable soma theory, but from evolutionary selection pressures acting on cell growth rates mediated by selective destruction. This theory suggests ageing can evolve independently of energetic maintenance costs.
Negligible senescence is redefined as increased basal mortality rather than absence of ageing, providing a new perspective on ageing patterns in organisms with minimal senescence.

theories.evidence: Agent-based modelling simulations supporting the plausibility of selective destruction driving ageing independently of damage accumulation; consistency with gene expression hallmarks of ageing is suggested.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining ageing at the organismal level; addresses ageing broadly beyond specific organs or diseases; offers an evolutionary and mechanistic explanation distinct from damage accumulation theories.

theories.name: Disposable Soma Theory (DST)

key_concepts.description: Ageing results from the accumulation of molecular damage due to limited energetic resources allocated to maintenance and repair, leading to gradual deterioration.

theories.evidence: Referenced as the current prevailing theory contrasted with the proposed selective destruction theory.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Widely accepted biological ageing theory meeting all criteria, but only discussed as background context rather than the main focus.

results.title: Aging in the vascular system: lessons from mechanobiology, computational approaches, and oxidative stress.

theories.name: Vascular theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Vascular aging as a primary driver of systemic aging
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that aging in the vascular system is the initiating factor that triggers or accelerates aging processes in multiple organs, thus positioning vascular aging as a fundamental cause of organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Mechanical properties of arteries and their nonlinear behavior
key_concepts.description: The theory emphasizes the importance of arterial stiffness and pressure relationships, which are complex and nonlinear, affecting how vascular aging manifests and influences overall aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of oxidative stress and cellular senescence in vascular aging
key_concepts.description: Oxidative stress and the accumulation of senescent cells within the vascular system are proposed as key molecular and cellular mechanisms driving vascular aging and thereby contributing to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews clinical observations, molecular and cellular studies, computational biomechanics approaches, and human studies linking accelerated arterial aging to cognitive impairment and functional decline.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The vascular theory of aging attempts to explain why and how aging occurs at the organismal level by proposing vascular aging as a causal driver of systemic aging. It addresses general aging processes beyond a single organ by linking vascular changes to multiorgan aging and functional decline. The theory proposes mechanisms including oxidative stress and cellular senescence, fulfilling the causal explanation criterion.

results.title: A tale as old as time - the importance of accelerated lung aging in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

theories.name: Accelerated Aging Theory in COPD

key_concepts.description: COPD patients exhibit an accelerated form of the normal aging process in the lungs, characterized by faster decline in lung function and structural deterioration compared to typical aging.
Genomic damage contributes to structural defects and cellular dysfunction in the lungs, which are hallmarks of aging that are exacerbated in COPD.

key_concepts.concept: Hallmarks of aging potentiated by environmental exposures
key_concepts.description: Primary, antagonistic, and integrative hallmarks of aging are accelerated in COPD, driven by cumulative injury from repeated environmental exposures (e.g., smoking) and comorbidities.
Epigenetic profiles unique to COPD subpopulations reflect cellular processes that advance biological age, indicating epigenetic abnormalities contribute to accelerated aging in COPD.

theories.evidence: Citations and discussion of genomic damage, epigenetic profiles, and hallmarks of aging in COPD patients; references to biomarkers and environmental risk factors.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for accelerated aging in COPD lungs, linking genomic and epigenetic mechanisms to systemic aging processes; addresses aging broadly through hallmarks of aging framework.

results.title: Inhalation of concentrated ambient PM2.5 promotes inactivation of telomerase reverse transcriptase, telomere shortening, and senescence of multiple cell types in mice.

theories.name: Telomere attrition and cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Telomeres are protective DNA-protein structures at chromosome ends that shorten with cell division and stress, leading to cellular aging. This shortening is proposed as a fundamental mechanism driving cellular senescence and organismal aging.

Telomerase, particularly its catalytic subunit Tert, maintains telomere length. Attenuation of Tert activity leads to accelerated telomere shortening, promoting senescence and aging phenotypes in multiple cell types.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence and senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP)
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells exhibit increased β-galactosidase activity and secrete pro-inflammatory factors (SASP) that contribute to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging. This phenotype is a causal driver of aging processes.

theories.evidence: Experimental exposure of mice to concentrated ambient PM2.5 showed telomere shortening and increased senescence markers in multiple cell types; antioxidant treatment mitigated telomere attrition; recovery experiments showed partial reversibility.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging mechanism (telomere shortening and senescence) with causal explanation (attenuated Tert activity), generalizable across multiple cell types, and connected to systemic aging processes.

results.title: Systemic aging and aging-related diseases.

theories.name: Systemic aging driven by organ-organ crosstalk and senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP)

key_concepts.concept: Systemic aging as a multi-organ process
key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized as a systemic biological process involving dysfunction across multiple organs rather than isolated organ decline. This systemic perspective emphasizes the interconnectedness of organ aging and its contribution to overall organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Organ-organ communication via metabolites and inflammatory mediators
key_concepts.description: Aged organs communicate through metabolites such as lipids, glucose, short-chain fatty acids, inflammatory cytokines, and exosomes. This crosstalk accelerates aging processes in other organs, suggesting a networked mechanism underlying systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) and inflammation
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells release SASP factors that promote inflammation and further senescence in multiple organs. This feedback loop exacerbates systemic aging and contributes to the progression of age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic disorders as accelerators of aging
key_concepts.description: Chronic metabolic disturbances such as hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinemia, and hypercholesterolemia accelerate hallmarks of aging, linking systemic metabolic health to the aging process.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing current understanding and citing multiple studies on organ crosstalk, metabolic disorders, SASP, and inflammation in systemic aging and age-related diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging as a systemic process involving inter-organ communication and senescence mechanisms. It addresses aging broadly beyond single organs or diseases and discusses underlying mechanisms driving aging.

results.title: How evolution makes us age: Introducing the evolvable soma theory of ageing.

theories.name: Evolvable Soma Theory of Ageing

key_concepts.concept: Ageing as cumulative effect of evolutionary experiments
key_concepts.description: Ageing results from the accumulation of mostly unsuccessful random changes (experiments) introduced by evolution to improve species design. These changes tend to be harmful and cause bodily decline leading to death.
Nature tends to add innovations at the end of development, meaning that evolutionary changes affecting later life stages accumulate, contributing to ageing.

Ageing is advantageous because it allows evolution to test new innovations during a life phase where their impact on reproductive fitness is present but less critical, thus contributing to the system’s ability to evolve by regularizing the fitness landscape.

theories.evidence: The abstract presents a conceptual hypothesis consistent with the terminal addition concept and evolutionary optimization principles; no direct experimental data cited.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a general, organism-level evolutionary mechanism explaining why ageing occurs (causal explanation), is broadly applicable as a fundamental aging theory, and connects ageing to evolutionary optimization and fitness landscapes.

results.title: Hallmarks of aging in age-related macular degeneration and age-related neurological disorders: novel insights into common mechanisms and clinical relevance.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Biological Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: This concept refers to the decline in the cellular mechanisms that maintain protein folding, repair, and degradation, leading to accumulation of damaged or misfolded proteins that impair cellular function and contribute to aging.

Macroautophagy is a cellular degradation pathway that removes damaged organelles and proteins. Its impairment leads to cellular dysfunction and accumulation of cellular debris, which is implicated in aging and age-related diseases.

Mitochondria are critical for energy production and cellular metabolism. Dysfunction in mitochondria leads to reduced energy output and increased production of reactive oxygen species, contributing to cellular damage and aging.
Chronic low-grade inflammation, often termed 'inflammaging,' is a hallmark of aging that promotes tissue damage and dysfunction, playing a causal role in the progression of age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper integrates knowledge from aging research literature identifying these hallmarks as common denominators in biological aging and their role in neurodegenerative diseases, citing associations between AMD and neurological disorders.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses fundamental, generalizable mechanisms underlying biological aging across organ systems, proposes causal mechanisms, and links these to systemic aging and disease progression.

results.title: Reduction of DNA Topoisomerase Top2 reprograms the epigenetic landscape and extends health and life span across species

theories.name: Epigenetic reprogramming theory of aging via DNA topoisomerase modulation

key_concepts.concept: Role of DNA topoisomerases in aging
key_concepts.description: DNA topoisomerases, particularly Top2 and its mammalian homolog Top2b, are enzymes that regulate DNA topology during replication and transcription. Their activity influences the epigenetic landscape and cellular functions linked to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic landscape alteration as a mechanism of aging
key_concepts.description: Reduction of Top2b leads to significant changes in the epigenetic landscape of various tissues, shifting gene expression patterns toward those observed in young animals. This suggests epigenetic regulation is a causal mechanism in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Attenuation of aging hallmarks by Top2b reduction
key_concepts.description: Lowering Top2b levels reduces key aging hallmarks such as cellular senescence, deregulated nutrient sensing, epigenetic alterations, and lysosomal biogenesis, indicating a broad impact on fundamental aging processes.
The longevity and health span extension effects of Top2/Top2b reduction are observed in yeast, nematodes, and mice, supporting a generalizable and conserved aging mechanism.

theories.evidence: Experimental knockdown of Top2/Top2b in S. cerevisiae, C. elegans, and mice showing increased lifespan and healthspan; molecular analyses demonstrating changes in epigenetic markers and aging hallmarks.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: proposes a causal mechanism (epigenetic reprogramming via Top2b reduction) explaining aging broadly across species; addresses fundamental aging processes and hallmarks; supported by cross-species experimental data.

results.title: Exposing the core genetic drivers of chronological aging in yeast cells

theories.name: Conserved Hallmarks of Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging across eukaryotic organisms is driven by a set of conserved cellular and molecular hallmarks, such as genomic instability, mitochondrial dysfunction, and deregulated nutrient sensing, which collectively underlie the aging process.

Specific genes and pathways regulate lifespan and aging phenotypes, and these genetic factors are conserved across species, indicating fundamental mechanisms that govern aging at the organismal level.

Multiple aging-related pathways interact and compensate for each other, such as the interplay between transcriptional regulators like Tec1 and mitochondrial function, suggesting a network of mechanisms that collectively influence aging.

theories.evidence: Meta-analysis of large-scale gene-deletion screens in yeast; identification of consistent genetic factors enriched in replicative lifespan genes and orthologs in other organisms; functional analyses linking these factors to universal aging hallmarks; lifespan-epistasis screen demonstrating interaction between TEC1 and mitochondrial machinery.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory attempts to explain aging as a fundamental, organism-level process with conserved genetic and cellular mechanisms; it proposes causal explanations involving genetic regulators and cellular pathways; it addresses aging broadly beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: Status, despair, and epigenetic age acceleration: Chains of risk?
A motivational framework of personality development in late adulthood.
Dietary restriction and ageing: Recent evolutionary perspectives.

theories.name: Resource Reallocation Theory of Dietary Restriction

key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that dietary restriction redirects metabolic resources away from reproduction and towards somatic maintenance, thereby promoting longevity. The trade-off implies a balance between investing energy in reproduction versus maintaining the body to extend lifespan.
Dietary restriction acts as a proximate mechanism that induces a physiological state favoring longevity by enhancing somatic maintenance processes at the expense of reproductive output.

The theory is grounded in evolutionary life history theory, which posits that organisms allocate limited resources between growth, reproduction, and maintenance in ways that maximize fitness, with dietary restriction shifting this allocation.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing evidence both supporting and challenging the resource reallocation model, including findings where reproduction and lifespan trade-offs are not always observed and where nutrient-specific effects can uncouple this relationship.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it proposes a generalizable evolutionary mechanism explaining why dietary restriction affects aging at the organismal level, offering a causal explanation for lifespan extension via resource allocation trade-offs, and addressing aging broadly rather than a narrow phenomenon.

theories.name: Alternative Evolutionary Models of Dietary Restriction Effects on Aging

key_concepts.concept: Decoupling of reproduction and somatic maintenance
key_concepts.description: Emerging evidence suggests that the classical trade-off between reproduction and lifespan may be uncoupled under certain dietary conditions, indicating that other mechanisms may underlie the lifespan extension seen with dietary restriction.
The inclusion or removal of specific nutrients can modulate the relationship between reproduction and somatic maintenance, suggesting a more complex interaction than simple resource reallocation.

key_concepts.concept: Re-evaluation of life history theory linkage
key_concepts.description: The paper discusses the need to re-explore and potentially revise the connection between dietary restriction and evolutionary life history theory to accommodate new findings that challenge the traditional resource reallocation framework.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses recent empirical findings that challenge the classical model and presents alternative theoretical perspectives, though no new experimental data are presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses general aging mechanisms through evolutionary theory and proposes alternative causal explanations for dietary restriction effects on aging, thus relevant to organism-level aging processes.

results.title: Distinguishing between driver and passenger mechanisms of aging.

theories.name: Driver and passenger mechanisms of aging

key_concepts.description: These are molecular and cellular changes that causally contribute to the aging process, such as alterations in the genome, telomeres, mitochondria, epigenome, proteins, stem cells, immune system, and accumulation of senescent cells.
These are aging-associated changes that occur alongside aging but do not causally drive the aging process. Distinguishing these from drivers is critical to understanding the mechanisms of aging.

The approach of using animal models and human genetic studies to empirically determine which aging-related changes are causal drivers versus passengers, addressing the challenge of identifying true mechanisms behind aging.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses empirical approaches including animal models and human genetic studies used to infer causality, but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain why and how biological aging occurs at a general organismal level by focusing on causal mechanisms distinguishing drivers from passengers. It addresses broad aging mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Evaluation of reproductive profiles, epigenetic aging, and mortality in post-menopausal women.

theories.name: Evolutionary trade-off theory of aging

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that there is an evolutionary trade-off between reproductive effort and lifespan, where resources allocated to reproduction may reduce investment in maintenance and repair, thereby accelerating aging.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic aging as a biomarker of biological aging
key_concepts.description: Epigenetic clocks such as PhenoAge, GrimAge, and DunedinPoAm are used to estimate biological age and the pace of aging, reflecting underlying biological processes that contribute to healthspan and mortality risk.

key_concepts.concept: Impact of reproductive profiles on aging trajectories
key_concepts.description: Variations in reproductive history, such as premature menopause, can influence epigenetic aging rates and mortality, suggesting that reproductive factors modulate biological aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Analysis of reproductive profiles and epigenetic aging markers in a cohort of 770 post-menopausal women; latent profile analysis identified reproductive classes; statistical associations found between premature menopause, accelerated DunedinPoAm pace of aging, and increased mortality; mediation analysis showed partial mediation of mortality risk by accelerated aging pace.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general aging mechanism (evolutionary trade-offs), proposes causal explanations linking reproduction to aging pace, and uses epigenetic aging as a mechanistic biomarker; the study tests theoretical predictions in a human population.

results.title: Delayed Reproduction as a Driver of Longevity

theories.name: Delayed Reproduction as a Driver of Longevity

key_concepts.concept: Reproductive timing influences selection on longevity
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that delayed reproduction intensifies natural selection on alleles that promote survival and reproductive success later in life, thereby shaping the evolution of lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Feedback dynamics between reproduction and longevity
key_concepts.description: There is a proposed feedback loop where delayed reproduction favors increased longevity, which in turn enables further delay in reproduction, potentially reinforcing selection for longer lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Extension and complement to classical evolutionary aging theories
key_concepts.description: This framework complements foundational aging theories (mutation accumulation, antagonistic pleiotropy, disposable soma) by adding reproductive timing as an active driver influencing the direction and strength of selection on aging traits.

theories.evidence: Conceptual models and comparative life history data are presented to support the hypothesis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable evolutionary mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organism level, offers causal explanations via selection dynamics, and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Sex-specific patterns of senescence in artificial insect populations varying in sex-ratio to manipulate reproductive effort

theories.name: Disposable Soma Theory of Ageing

key_concepts.concept: Resource Trade-off Between Reproduction and Longevity
key_concepts.description: Organisms allocate limited resources optimally between reproduction and somatic maintenance to maximize fitness. Investment in early reproduction reduces resources available for somatic protection, leading to accelerated aging.

Differences in reproductive strategies between males and females lead to distinct aging patterns. Males may experience accelerated senescence due to sexual competition and mating effort, while females face trade-offs primarily through reproductive effort.

key_concepts.concept: Impact of Reproductive Effort on Immunity and Survival
key_concepts.description: High reproductive effort can negatively affect longevity and immune function, with sex-specific effects. For example, female mortality increases with reproductive effort, while male longevity and immunity are influenced by mating investment.

theories.evidence: Experimental manipulation of sex-ratio in artificial populations of Tenebrio molitor beetles to vary reproductive effort and sexual competition; measurement of lifetime reproduction, survival, and immunity; observed sex-specific trade-offs consistent with theory predictions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains why aging occurs via resource allocation trade-offs at organismal level; proposes causal mechanisms linking reproduction and somatic maintenance; addresses general aging processes with sex-specific nuances.

results.title: Parental age at death is associated with age at first birth in offspring.

theories.name: Evolutionary theories of aging

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that there is an evolutionary balance between the timing and investment in reproduction and the rate of aging. Resources allocated to early reproduction may come at the cost of longevity, reflecting antagonistic pleiotropy or disposable soma principles.
The idea that aging rates are partly heritable and passed from parents to offspring, influencing lifespan and potentially other life history traits such as age at first reproduction.

theories.evidence: Analysis of a large Swedish birth cohort (92,359 individuals) using parental age at death as a proxy for inherited aging rates, and statistical modeling showing association between parental lifespan and offspring age at first birth.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general, organism-level aging process with a causal evolutionary explanation (trade-off between reproduction and aging), supported by empirical data linking inherited aging rates to life history traits.

results.title: The hallmarks of aging in Ataxia-Telangiectasia.

theories.name: DNA damage response and genome instability theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the accumulation of DNA damage and the efficiency of cellular DNA repair mechanisms are central to aging. ATM kinase is a key regulator of DDR, and its absence leads to genome instability, which contributes to aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Genome instability as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Genome instability caused by defective ATM function leads to cellular dysfunction and senescence, promoting systemic aging processes. This instability is linked to increased cancer risk and tissue degeneration.
ATM also regulates mitochondrial function and redox balance, and its loss disrupts these processes, contributing to cellular damage accumulation and aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews molecular and cellular signatures of aging in Ataxia-Telangiectasia, a disease caused by ATM deficiency, highlighting links between ATM loss, genome instability, and premature aging phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (DNA damage response and genome instability) explaining systemic aging processes, supported by a disease model that reflects broader aging mechanisms.

results.title: Metformin inhibits nuclear egress of chromatin fragments in senescence and aging

theories.name: Chromatin Fragment Nuclear Egress Theory of Senescence-Associated Inflammation

key_concepts.description: Senescent cells and aged tissues release chromatin fragments into the cytoplasm, which activate the cGAS-STING pathway, driving chronic inflammation, a hallmark of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Nuclear Egress as a Mechanism for CCF Export
key_concepts.description: Chromatin fragments exit the nucleus via nuclear egress, a membrane trafficking process involving the nuclear envelope and ESCRT-III/Torsin proteins, allowing large complexes to shuttle from nucleus to cytoplasm.

Nutrient sensing pathways, particularly AMPK activation by glucose limitation or metformin treatment, inhibit nuclear egress by promoting autophagic degradation of ESCRT-III component ALIX, thereby reducing CCF cytoplasmic presence and inflammation.

The theory connects nutrient sensing and chronic inflammation mechanisms, suggesting that metabolic interventions can modulate a fundamental aging process by controlling nuclear egress of chromatin fragments.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing that inactivation of nuclear egress proteins leads to accumulation of chromatin fragments at the nuclear membrane and impaired cGAS-STING activation; metformin treatment reduces ALIX protein levels and chronic inflammation in aged mice intestines.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism linking chromatin fragment nuclear egress to systemic chronic inflammation, a hallmark of aging, and connects metabolism to aging processes. It addresses a fundamental aging mechanism beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: The damage-independent evolution of ageing by selective destruction

theories.name: Selective Destruction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: A proposed biological process that removes faster-growing mutant cells from tissues to prevent morbidity and mortality risks associated with these cells. This mechanism acts as a counterselection pressure favoring slower-growing cells.
The spread of slower-growing cells due to selective destruction leads to a systemic metabolic slowdown, which manifests as aging, independent of molecular damage accumulation.
Contrary to the disposable soma theory, this theory suggests aging can evolve and be positively selected without reliance on energetic costs or accumulation of molecular damage.
The theory posits that selective destruction provides a survival advantage by controlling fast-growing mutants, thus shaping aging as an adaptive process rather than a passive damage accumulation.

theories.evidence: Agent-based modeling simulations supporting the plausibility of selective destruction driving aging; consistency with gene expression hallmarks of aging cited.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general, organism-level causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs, offers an evolutionary rationale, and addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases.

theories.name: Disposable Soma Theory (DST)

key_concepts.description: Aging results from the accumulation of molecular damage due to limited energetic resources allocated to somatic maintenance, leading to gradual decline.
Molecular damage accumulates over time because organisms prioritize reproduction over perfect maintenance, causing aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: Referenced as the prevailing theory contrasted with the newly proposed selective destruction theory.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Widely accepted aging theory meeting all criteria; included here as a comparative framework rather than the main focus.

results.title: Young and old adult brains experience opposite effects of acute sleep restriction on the functional connectivity network

theories.name: Compensation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: This theory posits that older adults exhibit compensatory neural mechanisms that counteract age-related declines, allowing them to maintain cognitive function despite physiological challenges such as sleep loss.

The theory predicts that older adults respond differently to acute stressors like sleep restriction compared to younger adults, showing resilience or altered brain network activity rather than simple decline.

key_concepts.concept: Fundamental shift in brain network dynamics
key_concepts.description: Rather than a uniform dampening of effects seen in younger adults, older adults experience opposite or distinct changes in functional connectivity, reflecting a reorganization or compensation in brain networks.

theories.evidence: Functional connectivity analyses showing strengthened subnetworks in younger adults but weakened in older adults after sleep restriction; crossover interactions in connectivity degree, modularity, and dynamic functional connectivity state fractional occupancy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for age-related differences in brain function under stress (sleep loss), addressing systemic aging-related neural compensation mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Targeting the molecular & cellular pillars of human aging with exercise.

theories.name: Seven Biological Pillars of Aging

key_concepts.description: The seven biological pillars represent fundamental aging pathways that are conserved across diverse model organisms, suggesting common underlying mechanisms driving aging at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Molecular and Cellular Drivers of Aging
key_concepts.description: These pillars encompass key molecular and cellular processes that contribute causally to biological aging and age-related functional decline, forming a framework to understand how aging leads to chronic diseases.

Regular physical exercise can influence these pillars by modulating their activity or impact, thereby potentially delaying the onset of age-associated chronic diseases and preserving functional capacity.

theories.evidence: Consensus review from NIA-sponsored meeting in 2014, literature on conserved aging pathways in model organisms, and studies on exercise effects on aging-related processes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general, organism-level framework explaining why and how biological aging occurs through fundamental conserved pathways; it addresses causal mechanisms and is broadly applicable beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: HMGB1, an evolving pleiotropic protein critical for cellular and tissue homeostasis: Role in aging and age-related diseases.

theories.name: HMGB1 pleiotropic protein role in aging theory

key_concepts.concept: HMGB1 as a DNA chaperone and gene transcription regulator
key_concepts.description: HMGB1 is a non-histone chromatin-associated protein that influences DNA structure and gene expression, thereby affecting cellular homeostasis and function.

HMGB1 can move from the nucleus to the cytoplasm to regulate processes such as autophagy, or be secreted extracellularly where it acts as a damage-associated molecular pattern (DAMP) molecule with both inflammatory and regenerative roles.

Lower intracellular HMGB1 levels and increased extracellular release are associated with age-related traits, suggesting HMGB1’s involvement in the aging process and its potential as a universal biomarker of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary perspective on HMGB1 functional pleiotropy
key_concepts.description: The protein’s multiple roles may have evolved to balance cellular maintenance, damage signaling, and regeneration, linking its functions to aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Review of molecular and cellular mechanisms, associations of HMGB1 expression patterns with age-related traits, evolutionary considerations, and literature citations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses HMGB1’s role as a fundamental molecular player influencing general aging processes through mechanisms affecting cellular homeostasis, damage signaling, and regeneration, thus meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Chemical reprogramming ameliorates cellular hallmarks of aging and extends lifespan

theories.name: Cellular reprogramming theory of aging reversal

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that reverting somatic cells to a pluripotent state through reprogramming can reverse molecular hallmarks of aging, effectively rejuvenating cells at a fundamental level.

Partial reprogramming can improve key aging drivers such as genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, cellular senescence, and oxidative stress, which are central mechanisms contributing to organismal aging.
Using small molecule cocktails to induce partial reprogramming offers a translational approach to mitigate aging phenotypes and extend lifespan, demonstrated here in human cells and C. elegans.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing partial chemical reprogramming improves genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, cellular senescence, oxidative stress in aged human cells, and extends lifespan in C. elegans.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging can be reversed at the cellular level, addressing fundamental aging drivers and demonstrating organism-level lifespan extension.

results.title: Efficiency of DNA repair mechanisms of domestic dog primary fibroblasts isolated from small and large breeds of different ages in response to double stranded breaks (DSB).

theories.name: DNA damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Genomic instability as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with increased genomic instability, primarily due to the accumulation of DNA damage over time. This instability contributes to functional decline and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Impaired DNA repair mechanisms with age
key_concepts.description: The efficiency of DNA repair pathways, particularly those repairing double-strand breaks (DSBs), declines with age, leading to accumulation of unrepaired DNA damage.

Two main pathways repair DSBs: the fast non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) and the slower homologous recombination (HR). Aging affects these pathways differently, with HR being more deficient in older, larger breeds.

key_concepts.concept: Species and size-related variation in DNA repair
key_concepts.description: Larger mammalian species tend to have more robust DNA repair systems, which correlates with longer lifespans. Within a species (dogs), breed size and age influence DNA repair efficiency.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from primary fibroblast cells of small and large breed dogs at different ages treated with etoposide to induce DSBs; measurement of γ-H2AX foci at 2 and 24 hours post-treatment to assess repair efficiency.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging (DNA damage accumulation and repair decline), is generalizable across organisms (mammals, with intraspecies variation), and addresses fundamental aging processes rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Population level mitogenomics of the long-lived Greater Mouse-eared bat,Myotis myotis, reveals dynamic heteroplasmy and challenges the Free Radical Theory of Ageing

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Ageing (FRTA)

key_concepts.concept: High metabolic rate leads to mitochondrial damage
key_concepts.description: The FRTA posits that organisms with high metabolic rates produce more reactive oxygen species (ROS), which cause oxidative damage to mitochondrial DNA, leading to mitochondrial heteroplasmy and progressive aging.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial heteroplasmy as a marker of aging
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of mutations in mitochondrial DNA (heteroplasmy) is considered a key mechanism driving aging, as it impairs mitochondrial function and cellular energy production.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress as a primary cause of heteroplasmy
key_concepts.description: Oxidative mutations caused by ROS are thought to be the main source of mitochondrial heteroplasmy, linking metabolic rate directly to aging.

theories.evidence: Targeted deep sequencing of mitogenomes from 195 wild Myotis myotis bats aged <1 to 6+ years showed that most heteroplasmies were low frequency transitions, oxidative mutations were rare, and heteroplasmy increased with age but dynamically and not uniformly. This challenges the FRTA prediction that high metabolic rate causes inevitable accumulation of oxidative mitochondrial damage.
