theories.name: Mitochondria-Telomere Vicious Circle Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that dysfunctional mitochondria and telomeres interact in a feedback loop that exacerbates cellular damage. Dysfunctional mitochondria increase oxidative stress, which damages telomeres, while damaged telomeres further impair mitochondrial function, together reducing cell fitness and promoting cellular aging.

Oxidative stress generated by dysfunctional mitochondria is a key damaging agent that affects telomere integrity. This stress leads to telomere shortening and dysfunction, which are central to the aging process at the cellular level.

key_concepts.concept: Telomerase Shuttling Between Nucleus and Mitochondria
key_concepts.description: Telomerase, traditionally known for maintaining telomere length in the nucleus, also shuttles to mitochondria where it may influence mitochondrial function and integrity. This dual localization suggests a mechanistic link between telomere biology and mitochondrial health.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial Genome Influence on Telomere Length Inheritance
key_concepts.description: Variants in mitochondrial genes may affect the inheritance and maintenance of telomere length in humans, indicating a genetic and functional connection between mitochondrial genome variation and telomere biology relevant to aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing evidence linking oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction to telomere damage, discusses the role of telomerase shuttling, and elaborates on mitochondrial genome variants affecting telomere length inheritance. Specific experimental data are not detailed in the abstract but prior studies are cited.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how mitochondrial and telomere dysfunction drive cellular and organismal aging through a feedback loop. It addresses fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases or organs and discusses underlying mechanisms.

results.title: Mitochondrion: A bridge linking aging and degenerative diseases.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that progressive decline in mitochondrial function contributes causally to the aging process by impairing cellular energy metabolism, increasing oxidative stress, and promoting cellular damage.

Restoring mitochondrial function and promoting mitochondrial biogenesis can have beneficial effects on lifespan extension and healthy aging, suggesting that mitochondrial health is a modifiable factor influencing aging.

key_concepts.concept: Link between mitochondrial dysfunction and degenerative diseases
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction is implicated not only in aging but also in aging-related degenerative diseases such as neurodegenerative diseases, osteoarthritis, metabolic diseases, and cardiovascular diseases, indicating a systemic role in organismal aging.

theories.evidence: The paper summarizes accumulating evidence from various studies linking mitochondrial dysfunction to aging and degenerative diseases, and discusses therapeutic approaches targeting mitochondria to promote healthy aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain why aging occurs at an organismal level by proposing mitochondrial dysfunction as a fundamental causal mechanism; it is generalizable beyond specific diseases and addresses aging broadly; it proposes causal mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Cellular senescence and premature aging in Down Syndrome.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: A state of irreversible cell cycle arrest that cells enter in response to various stressors, contributing to aging and age-related diseases by impairing tissue function and promoting inflammation.

Cellular senescence is proposed as a key mechanism driving the premature aging phenotypes observed in Down Syndrome, linking senescent cell accumulation to multi-organ dysfunction and cognitive decline.

Targeting cellular senescence may offer potential interventions to alleviate age-related pathologies in Down Syndrome, highlighting senescence as a causal driver rather than a mere correlate of aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references emerging evidence and current knowledge on cellular senescence in DS, including its association with cognitive impairment and multi-organ dysfunction, but does not specify new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (cellular senescence) explaining why accelerated aging occurs in DS, which is connected to systemic aging processes and age-related diseases.

results.title: Chronic D-galactose administration induces natural aging characteristics, in rat's brain and heart.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Framework

key_concepts.description: This concept involves the disruption of cellular pathways that detect and respond to nutrient availability, which is critical for maintaining metabolic homeostasis and influences aging processes.

Mitochondrial dysfunction refers to the decline in mitochondrial performance and efficiency, leading to increased reactive oxygen species production and impaired energy metabolism, contributing to aging.
Cellular senescence is the process by which cells irreversibly stop dividing and secrete pro-inflammatory factors, which accumulate with age and drive tissue dysfunction.
Stem cell exhaustion describes the decline in the regenerative capacity of stem cells over time, reducing tissue repair and maintenance, thereby promoting aging.
This concept involves changes in signaling between cells, including increased inflammation and impaired signaling networks, which contribute to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from chronic D-galactose administration in rats showing mimicry of natural aging characteristics in brain and heart tissues, including multiple hallmarks of aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it addresses general aging mechanisms at the organismal level, proposes causal mechanisms underlying aging (hallmarks), and is not limited to a specific disease or organ alone but rather systemic aging processes.

results.title: Pentadecanoic Acid (C15:0), an Essential Fatty Acid, Shares Clinically Relevant Cell-Based Activities with Leading Longevity-Enhancing Compounds
Multigenerational downregulation of insulin/IGF-1 signalling in adulthood improves lineage survival, reproduction, and fitness inC. eleganssupporting the developmental theory of ageing

theories.name: Developmental Theory of Ageing

key_concepts.concept: Decline in the force of natural selection with age
key_concepts.description: This theory posits that the strength of natural selection decreases as organisms age, leading to less effective regulation of gene expression in adulthood compared to development. Consequently, gene expression in adulthood may become suboptimal or deleterious, contributing to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Poorly regulated gene expression in adulthood
key_concepts.description: Because selection pressure weakens after reproductive maturity, genes that are beneficial during development may be misregulated or harmful when expressed in adulthood, causing aging-related decline.

key_concepts.concept: Trade-off between somatic maintenance and reproduction mediated by IIS
key_concepts.description: The insulin/IGF-1 signalling pathway regulates resource allocation between somatic maintenance and reproduction, and its downregulation in adulthood can increase lifespan without reproductive cost, supporting the developmental theory's framework.

theories.evidence: The study performed a 40-generation mutation accumulation experiment in C. elegans, downregulating IIS via daf-2 RNAi in adulthood only. Results showed reduced extinction rates and increased fitness under stress in lines with reduced IIS, supporting the theory's prediction about gene regulation effects in adulthood. Functional hrde-1 was required for these benefits, linking epigenetic inheritance mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal explanation for aging based on evolutionary decline in selection pressure and gene regulation, applicable broadly beyond specific organs or diseases. It addresses fundamental aging mechanisms via IIS pathway modulation and evolutionary logic.

results.title: Cost-free lifespan extension via optimisation of gene expression in adulthood supports the developmental theory of ageing

theories.name: Developmental Theory of Ageing (DTA)

key_concepts.concept: Decline in selection gradients with age
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that natural selection pressure decreases as organisms age, leading to less optimized gene expression in adulthood and consequently to organismal senescence.

Senescence arises because gene expression patterns that are beneficial during development become detrimental when they continue unchecked in adulthood, causing physiological hyper-function that harms survival.

Adjusting gene expression specifically during adulthood can improve survival and fitness without incurring the typical trade-offs between reproduction and somatic maintenance predicted by classic energy trade-off theories.

theories.evidence: Experimental RNAi knockdown of five longevity-related genes (age-1, raga-1, ifg-1, ife-2, nuo-6) in Caenorhabditis elegans at different life stages showed improved survival with adult or post-reproductive downregulation and little evidence of reproduction-lifespan trade-offs.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains why aging occurs at an organismal level by proposing a causal mechanism (dysregulated gene expression due to declining selection), is generalizable beyond specific organs or diseases, and addresses fundamental aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Epigenetic aging in adult neurogenesis.

theories.name: Epigenetic dysregulation theory of aging in neural stem cells

key_concepts.description: Epigenetic regulators control gene expression programs that govern neural stem cell (NSC) quiescence, proliferation, and differentiation, which are critical for maintaining adult neurogenesis.
With aging, the epigenetic landscape specific to NSCs deteriorates, leading to increased NSC quiescence and reduced proliferation, which contributes to the decline in adult hippocampal neurogenesis.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic alterations as hallmarks of aging
key_concepts.description: Epigenetic changes are recognized as central hallmarks of aging, suggesting that epigenetic dysregulation is a fundamental mechanism driving age-related functional decline in NSCs and possibly systemic aging.

theories.mode: review, propose perspectives for future research
theories.evidence: Summary of recently accumulating evidence from multiple studies linking epigenetic dysregulation to NSC aging; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (epigenetic dysregulation) explaining why biological aging occurs at the organismal level via NSC decline; connects epigenetic aging to systemic aging processes; not limited to a narrow phenomenon but addresses a fundamental aging hallmark.

results.title: Age-related changes in human skeletal muscle transcriptome and proteome are more affected by chronic inflammation and physical inactivity than primary aging

theories.name: Primary versus Secondary Aging Theory in Skeletal Muscle

key_concepts.description: Refers to intrinsic, time-dependent biological aging processes that affect gene expression related to nuclear proteins involved in DNA repair, RNA processing, transcription, mitochondrial respiratory enzymes, mitochondrial complex assembly, cristae formation, reactive oxygen species production, and proteostasis regulators.

Refers to aging effects driven by external or environmental factors such as chronic inflammation and physical inactivity, which have a larger impact on transcriptomic and proteomic changes in skeletal muscle, affecting thousands of genes related to mitochondrial function, proteostasis, cell membrane, secretory, and immune responses.
Proteins associated with aging are mainly regulated at the post-transcriptional level, indicating complex regulation beyond gene expression changes.
Identification of primary aging genes and their transcriptional regulators provides a resource to study the role of these genes in the development of cellular senescence.

theories.evidence: Comparative transcriptomic and proteomic analysis of skeletal muscle samples from young healthy individuals, young and older patients with osteoarthritis (a model of chronic inflammation and inactivity), showing differential gene expression patterns attributable to primary aging versus secondary aging factors.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain mechanisms underlying biological aging at the organismal level by distinguishing intrinsic aging processes from secondary influences like inflammation and inactivity, proposes causal mechanisms, and addresses aging broadly through molecular hallmarks in skeletal muscle connected to systemic aging.

results.title: Programmed versus non-programmed evolution of aging. What is the evidence?

theories.name: Programmed Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Programmed aging as an evolutionary trait
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that aging is a genetically programmed process shaped by evolution, implying that longevity and senescence are determined by specific molecular mechanisms encoded in the genome.
The theory suggests that longevity is controlled by basic molecular pathways that actively regulate aging, rather than being a passive accumulation of damage.
Programmed aging is hypothesized to have an adaptive evolutionary role, potentially benefiting the species or population by regulating lifespan.

theories.evidence: The paper examines a broad range of observational and experimental data from both field and laboratory studies accumulated over recent decades that support programmed aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it attempts to explain why aging occurs as a fundamental, organism-level process with proposed molecular and evolutionary mechanisms; it addresses aging broadly and discusses causal explanations.

theories.name: Non-Programmed Aging Theory (Antagonistic Pleiotropy)

key_concepts.concept: Aging as a byproduct of genes with beneficial early-life effects
key_concepts.description: This theory posits that certain genes have beneficial effects early in life but detrimental effects later, leading to aging as a non-adaptive consequence.
Aging results from the accumulation of damage or deleterious effects that natural selection does not eliminate because of the trade-off with reproductive success.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses data that are compatible with non-programmed aging and the role of antagonistic pleiotropy in some cases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a causal evolutionary explanation for aging as a fundamental organism-level process, not limited to specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Cognitive aging and the life course: A new look at the Scaffolding theory.

theories.name: Scaffolding Theory of Aging and Cognition

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that throughout life, the brain engages adaptive and compensatory mechanisms—referred to as scaffolding—to meet neurocognitive challenges caused by environmental demands and changes in brain circuitry, whether developmental or degenerative.

key_concepts.concept: Influence of enriching and depleting factors across the life course
key_concepts.description: The theory emphasizes that factors which either enrich or deplete brain health exert their effects at different points during the life course, impacting the brain's scaffolding capacity and thus cognitive function and decline.

key_concepts.concept: Reciprocal influences on cognitive function and decline
key_concepts.description: The model considers that scaffolding and brain health factors interact reciprocally to influence both the current level of cognitive function and the rate of cognitive decline in later life.

theories.evidence: Review of recent brain imaging studies, longitudinal datasets, and analytic advances that provide new evidence on life course influences on brain health and scaffolding.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal model explaining how neurocognitive aging occurs via adaptive scaffolding mechanisms acting across the organism's lifespan, addressing broad cognitive aging rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Epigenetic Clocks and Programmatic Aging

theories.name: Programmatic Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Methylation clocks track biological age and are linked to developmental genes such as Hox and polycomb, suggesting that aging is a continuation of developmental programming rather than random damage accumulation.

key_concepts.concept: Evolution of aging through developmental mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Aging evolves as part of a conserved developmental sequence that spans ontogenesis, adult development, and aging, implying that aging is constrained and determined by developmental biology.
Polycomb group proteins regulate a trade-off between early developmental fidelity and later developmental plasticity, influencing the progression of aging and susceptibility to late-life diseases.
An interdisciplinary framework combining evolutionary biology, biogerontology, and developmental biology to understand aging as a programmed developmental process.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent advances in programmatic theories, observations of methylation clock CpG sites near developmental genes, and evolutionary biology concepts; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging as a programmed developmental process applicable at the organismal level, integrating evolutionary and developmental mechanisms.

results.title: TFEB is a central regulator of the aging process and age-related diseases.

theories.name: TFEB-centered regulatory theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: TFEB as a master regulator of aging hallmarks
key_concepts.description: TFEB activity influences multiple fundamental aging processes, including DNA damage inhibition, epigenetic modifications, autophagy induction, proteostasis maintenance, mitochondrial quality control, nutrient sensing, energy metabolism, inflammation regulation, senescence inhibition, and cell regeneration.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of lifestyle and pharmacological interventions via TFEB
key_concepts.description: Common anti-aging interventions such as caloric restriction, intermittent fasting, exercise, and certain drugs induce TFEB and autophagy, suggesting TFEB mediates their beneficial effects on aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: TFEB activation as a therapeutic strategy
key_concepts.description: Activating TFEB has potential to delay normal aging and ameliorate tissue-specific age-related diseases including neurodegeneration, immune dysfunction, muscle and metabolic decline, bone remodeling, and cancer.

theories.evidence: Summary of emerging discoveries and literature linking TFEB activity to multiple aging hallmarks and age-related diseases; references to lifestyle and pharmacological interventions that induce TFEB; assessment of therapeutic impacts in various tissues and diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal regulatory mechanism underlying aging processes at the organismal level, integrating multiple aging hallmarks and linking molecular regulation to systemic aging and disease.

results.title: Under the shadow: Old-biased genes are subject to weak purifying selection at both the tissue and cell type-specific levels

theories.name: Mutation Accumulation Theory

key_concepts.concept: Weak purifying selection at old age
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that deleterious genetic variants that act late in life accumulate because natural selection is weaker at older ages, allowing these variants to persist in the population.
Aging results from the buildup of harmful mutations expressed predominantly in old age, which negatively affect organismal function and survival.
Genes that are more highly expressed in old individuals (old-biased genes) show weaker sequence conservation, indicating relaxed selection pressure on these genes compared to young-biased genes.

theories.evidence: Analysis of bulk tissue and cell type-specific RNA sequencing data from multiple species (mammals, non-mammalian vertebrates, invertebrates) showing consistent patterns of decreased conservation in old-biased genes; single-cell transcriptome analysis in mice confirming the trend across diverse cell types.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It is a generalizable evolutionary theory explaining why aging occurs due to accumulation of late-acting deleterious mutations; it proposes a causal mechanism (weak purifying selection at old age); and it addresses aging broadly across tissues, cell types, and species.

results.title: Senotherapeutic Drugs: A New Avenue for Skincare?

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate progressively in tissues over time, contributing causally to the aging process by impairing tissue function and promoting inflammation.

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells as drivers of systemic aging
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells are not only markers but active drivers of aging, influencing organismal aging through their secretory phenotype and disruption of tissue homeostasis.

Interventions such as senolytics (selective removal of senescent cells) and senomorphics (modulation of senescent cell function) are emerging strategies to mitigate aging effects by targeting cellular senescence.

theories.evidence: The abstract references the well-studied role of cellular senescence as a hallmark of aging and discusses emerging senotherapeutic interventions under investigation, implying citation of existing literature and ongoing research.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it explains a fundamental, organism-level aging process (senescent cell accumulation), proposes causal mechanisms (senescent cells drive aging), and discusses interventions targeting these mechanisms, thus addressing general aging beyond specific organs or diseases.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Framework

key_concepts.concept: Basic health maintenance mechanisms failing over time
key_concepts.description: Aging results from the progressive failure of fundamental cellular and molecular processes that maintain organismal health, collectively termed the hallmarks of aging.
The hallmarks framework integrates various aging mechanisms, including cellular senescence, to provide a comprehensive explanation of aging at the organismal level.

theories.evidence: The abstract references the hallmarks of aging as a conceptual framework underlying skin aging and systemic aging processes, suggesting reliance on established literature.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a generalizable, causal explanation of aging processes at the organism level, not limited to specific tissues or diseases.

theories.name: Dysregulated mRNA Processing as a Hallmark of Aging

key_concepts.description: A newly identified hallmark of aging involving disruptions in the normal processing of mRNA, which may contribute to cellular dysfunction and aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Targeting mRNA processing for senomorphic effects
key_concepts.description: Interventions aimed at correcting or modulating mRNA processing can have rejuvenating effects on cells, representing a novel therapeutic avenue in aging research.
A new modality to manipulate disrupted mRNA processing using oligonucleotide-based drugs, potentially restoring normal cellular function and mitigating aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract mentions this as a newly discovered hallmark and discusses therapeutic targeting, implying recent research findings though no direct experimental data is presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Potentially meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism contributing to aging and therapeutic targeting; however, as a newly discovered hallmark, the causal role may still be under investigation.

results.title: Age pigment lipofuscin causes oxidative stress, lysosomal dysfunction, and pyroptotic cell death

theories.name: Lysosomal-Mitochondrial Axis Theory of Aging and Cell Death

key_concepts.description: Lipofuscin is an age pigment that accumulates ubiquitously during aging. It is composed of aggregates containing elevated levels of proline and metals such as calcium and iron, which are implicated in cellular dysfunction.
Lipofuscin promotes mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, contributing to oxidative stress, which is a key driver of cellular damage and aging.
Lipofuscin causes lysosomal membrane permeabilization, leading to reduced lysosome quantity and impaired activity of lysosomal enzymes such as cathepsin D, disrupting cellular waste processing.
At low concentrations, lipofuscin induces cell death through a pyroptosis-like pathway, linking lysosomal and mitochondrial dysfunction to programmed inflammatory cell death mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Experimental isolation of authentic lipofuscin from human and equine cardiac tissue; incorporation into fibroblasts; measurement of cell death (LC50 = 5.0 µg/mL); assays showing increased mitochondrial ROS, lysosomal membrane permeabilization, reduced lysosome number, and decreased cathepsin D activity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how accumulation of lipofuscin contributes to aging at the cellular and organismal level via oxidative stress and lysosomal dysfunction, linking to cell death pathways. It addresses fundamental aging processes rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: DNA methylation in genes associated with the evolution of ageing and disease: A critical review.

theories.name: Evolutionary theories of ageing

key_concepts.description: This theory proposes that deleterious mutations that affect individuals later in life accumulate in the genome because natural selection is weaker at older ages, leading to ageing and age-related decline.

This theory suggests that organisms allocate limited resources between reproduction and maintenance of the soma (body), leading to gradual accumulation of damage and ageing as a trade-off for reproductive success.
These theories propose that ageing is regulated by genetic or epigenetic programs, such as DNA methylation changes, which actively drive the ageing process and age-related diseases.
This concept involves alleles that have beneficial effects on fitness early in life but detrimental effects later, contributing to ageing and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews recent genetic evidence of pleiotropic alleles affecting fitness at different ages, discusses DNA methylation changes associated with ageing and caloric restriction, and links these to evolutionary ageing theories.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper addresses general biological ageing mechanisms at the organismal level by discussing evolutionary theories that explain why ageing occurs, including causal mechanisms like pleiotropy and resource allocation. It links epigenetic changes (DNA methylation) to these theories, thus meeting the criteria for generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope.

results.title: Association of Obstructive Sleep Apnea with the Aging Process.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Framework

key_concepts.description: This concept involves changes in the signaling between cells that affect tissue and organismal homeostasis, often leading to chronic inflammation and impaired function, which are characteristic of aging.

This refers to the impaired ability of cells and organisms to properly sense and respond to nutrient availability, which affects metabolic pathways such as insulin signaling and is linked to aging and age-related diseases.
The progressive shortening of telomeres, the protective caps at the ends of chromosomes, which limits cellular replicative capacity and contributes to cellular senescence and organismal aging.
Decline in mitochondrial function, including reduced mitochondrial DNA copy number and impaired energy production, which leads to increased oxidative stress and cellular damage associated with aging.
Accumulation of DNA damage and mutations over time, leading to impaired cellular function and increased risk of age-related pathologies.

theories.evidence: Observational prospective study of 599 patients with suspected OSA measuring five hallmarks of aging (CRP, insulin resistance, leukocyte telomere length, mitochondrial DNA copy number, urinary 8-hydroxy-2-deoxyguanosine) and correlating these with OSA severity and age groups.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses fundamental aging processes (hallmarks) with causal mechanisms (cellular communication, nutrient sensing, telomere attrition, mitochondrial dysfunction, genomic instability) and tests association with OSA as a factor influencing aging; generalizable beyond OSA alone.

results.title: LFMD: detecting low-frequency mutations in high-depth genome sequencing data without molecular tags

theories.name: Mitochondrial Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative damage as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: This theory posits that reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated by mitochondria cause cumulative damage to mitochondrial DNA and other cellular components, leading to functional decline and aging at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial DNA mutations accumulate with age
key_concepts.description: Mutations in mitochondrial DNA, particularly those caused by oxidative damage, increase over time and contribute to cellular dysfunction and aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Link between mitochondrial damage and neurodegenerative diseases
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that oxidative damage-induced mitochondrial mutations contribute to aging-related diseases such as Alzheimer’s Disease by impairing brain cell function.

theories.evidence: Mitochondrial heterogeneity analysis of 28 human brain samples across different stages of Alzheimer’s Disease showed increased oxidative damage-related mutations (C:G>A:T) in mid-stage AD, consistent with the theory.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging (oxidative damage accumulation in mitochondria) applicable at the organismal level and links to systemic aging and disease.

results.title: Necroptosis inhibition counteracts neurodegeneration, memory decline and key hallmarks of aging, promoting brain rejuvenation

theories.name: Necroptosis as a causal driver of brain aging and neurodegeneration

key_concepts.description: Necroptosis is a programmed form of necrotic cell death that mediates degeneration of injured axons, contributing to early pathological events in the aged brain preceding neuronal dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Necroptosis triggers neurodegeneration and cognitive decline
key_concepts.description: Activation of necroptosis leads to neuroinflammation, synaptic transmission decrease, and memory impairment during aging, suggesting it as a causal mechanism underlying brain aging.

key_concepts.concept: Inhibition of necroptosis promotes brain rejuvenation
key_concepts.description: Genetic loss or pharmacological inhibition of necroptosis effectors (e.g., Mlkl) delays age-associated axonal degeneration, reduces neuroinflammation, restores hippocampal function, and improves cognitive performance, indicating a potential geroprotective intervention.

theories.evidence: Genetic knockout of Mlkl in aged mice delays axonal degeneration and cognitive decline; pharmacological inhibition reverses hippocampal impairments; quantitative proteomics shows improved hippocampal proteome linked to brain rejuvenation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (necroptosis) underlying a fundamental aging process (brain aging and cognitive decline), with evidence from multiple species and interventions, addressing systemic aging effects on the brain.

results.title: [Progerin and Its Role in Accelerated and Natural Aging].

theories.name: Progerin accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Progerin accumulation in the nuclear envelope
key_concepts.description: Progerin is a defective precursor of lamin A protein that abnormally retains a hydrophobic oligoisoprene chain, causing it to attach to the inner nuclear membrane. This accumulation disrupts nuclear morphology and nuclear matrix structure.

key_concepts.concept: Nuclear structural distortions leading to metabolic defects
key_concepts.description: As progerin accumulates, it pushes away nuclear matrix fibrils and chromatin, altering nuclear envelope properties and nuclear pore complexes. This impairs nuclear-cytoplasmic transport and causes defects such as oxidative stress, DNA lesions, telomere exhaustion, and epigenetic distortions.

The metabolic defects caused by progerin accumulation increase cell death and contribute to organismal aging. This mechanism is demonstrated in Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome (HGPS) and is proposed to also play a role in natural aging at lower progerin levels.
A point mutation in the LMNA gene causes abnormal splicing and mass production of progerin, leading to rapid aging in HGPS patients.
Strategies include preventing progerin formation or promoting its clearance via autophagy activation (e.g., rapamycin), which may reduce aging rate and have potential applications in natural aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of known HGPS genetic mutation and phenotype, mechanistic description of progerin effects on nuclear structure, references to experimental approaches using rapamycin and autophagy activation, and observations of progerin presence in normal aging individuals.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging based on progerin accumulation affecting nuclear integrity and cell metabolism, applicable to both accelerated and natural aging, with a mechanistic explanation and evolutionary/genetic basis.

results.title: Association between driving frequency and well-being among older adults.

theories.name: Activity theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that maintaining active participation in social and productive activities leads to higher well-being and successful aging. It emphasizes that older adults who remain active experience better psychosocial outcomes.
Driving is conceptualized as a form of independence that facilitates social engagement and access to resources, which in turn supports well-being in older adults.
Not just participation but the frequency of engagement in activities (such as driving) is important for enhancing well-being among older adults.

theories.evidence: Analysis of data from the 2018 National Health and Aging Trends Study using logistic regression to associate driving frequency with well-being measures.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a psychosocial aging theory explaining how and why aging individuals' well-being is influenced by activity levels, with generalizability to older adults broadly and causal implications about activity affecting aging outcomes.

results.title: Survival costs and benefits of reproduction: A register-based study in 20th century Estonia.

theories.name: Antagonistic pleiotropy theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Age-dependent trade-offs between reproduction and survival
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that certain genes or traits that enhance reproductive success early in life may have detrimental effects on survival or health later in life, leading to aging. This explains why traits beneficial in youth can cause increased mortality risks at older ages.

key_concepts.concept: Reversal of survival-parity association with age
key_concepts.description: The theory predicts that the relationship between reproductive output (parity) and survival changes with age, such that higher parity may be associated with better survival during reproductive ages but worse survival at older ages due to accumulated costs.

theories.evidence: Analysis of survival and parity data from a large Estonian cohort showed that fathers with many children had better survival during reproductive age but worse survival after age 70, consistent with the theory's prediction of age-dependent trade-offs.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a generalizable, causal evolutionary explanation for aging at the organism level, addressing broad aging mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Potential Synergistic Supplementation of NAD+ Promoting Compounds as a Strategy for Increasing Healthspan

theories.name: NAD+ Decline and CD38/NAD+/SIRT1 Axis Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) levels decrease as organisms age, leading to disrupted biological functions that contribute to aging and age-related diseases. This decline is considered a fundamental process influencing systemic aging.

CD38 is an enzyme that degrades NAD+, and its increased activity with age contributes to the reduction of NAD+ levels. Inhibiting CD38 can prevent NAD+ degradation, thereby potentially restoring NAD+ levels and mitigating aging effects.

key_concepts.concept: SIRT1 Activation and Downstream Protective Effects
key_concepts.description: SIRT1 is a NAD+-dependent deacetylase that promotes cellular health and longevity. Maintaining NAD+ levels supports SIRT1 activity, which in turn activates protective pathways that counteract aging-related damage.

Administering NAD+ precursors such as nicotinamide mononucleotide (NMN) or nicotinamide riboside (NR) can restore NAD+ levels in aged organisms, potentially improving healthspan by reversing or slowing aging processes.

Combining NAD+ precursors with other geroprotective compounds may enhance the efficacy of NAD+ restoration and provide additional health benefits, forming a multi-targeted approach to delay aging and reduce age-related disease risk.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing literature on NAD+ decline, CD38 inhibition, SIRT1 activation, and supplementation with NMN/NR, citing studies on geroprotectors and senolytics; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining systemic aging through NAD+ metabolism and its regulation; addresses fundamental aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: RNA binding proteins in senescence: A potential common linker for age-related diseases?

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence refers to the state in which cells irreversibly stop dividing and undergo distinctive phenotypic alterations. This process contributes to aging by promoting tissue dysfunction and chronic inflammation, thereby driving systemic aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Role of RNA binding proteins (RBPs) in regulating senescence
key_concepts.description: RBPs regulate gene expression post-transcriptionally, influencing mRNA maturation, stability, and translation. Their dysregulation can promote cellular senescence, linking molecular mechanisms to aging phenotypes and age-related pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: RBPs as molecular links between senescence and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: RBPs are implicated in the pathogenesis and progression of multiple aging-related diseases by modulating cellular senescence and other aging hallmarks, suggesting they may serve as diagnostic markers or therapeutic targets to delay aging processes.

theories.evidence: The paper summarizes accumulating evidence from various studies showing RBPs' involvement in cellular senescence and aging-related diseases; it is a review article without new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it addresses a general aging mechanism (cellular senescence) with causal explanations involving RBPs, connects molecular mechanisms to systemic aging and diseases, and discusses underlying principles applicable broadly.

results.title: Is Evidence Supporting the Subtelomere-Telomere Theory of Aging?

theories.name: Subtelomere-Telomere Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Role of subtelomeric DNA in aging
key_concepts.description: This theory emphasizes that aging mechanisms are not solely due to telomere shortening but critically involve subtelomeric DNA, which regulates epigenetic modifications and cellular aging processes.

Aging and cellular senescence are controlled by epigenetic modifications governed by the subtelomere-telomere-telomeric hood-telomerase system, suggesting aging is a genetically programmed and regulated process rather than random degeneration.

The theory proposes aging as a phenoptotic (programmed organismal death) phenomenon, which is modifiable and reversible, opposing the view that aging results from random, inevitable damage accumulation.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of telomere protection and heterochromatin structure
key_concepts.description: The subtelomeric region and telomeric heterochromatin structures play essential roles in protecting telomeres and regulating gradual cell senescence, linking chromatin state to organismal aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews and investigates experimental results related to epigenetic modifications, oxidation, inflammation, telomere protection, telomeric heterochromatin, cell senescence, and organismal decline with telomere shortening, showing compatibility with the theory's assumptions and implications.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a general, organism-level causal mechanism for aging involving genetic and epigenetic regulation; it explains why and how aging occurs; it is not limited to a single organ or disease but addresses systemic aging; and it contrasts programmed aging with damage accumulation theories.

results.title: Gene co-expression network reveals highly conserved, well-regulated anti-ageing mechanisms in old ant queens

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of ageing with reduced selection shadow

key_concepts.description: The concept that the force of natural selection declines with age due to extrinsic mortality reducing the effective population size of older individuals, leading to accumulation of deleterious effects and ageing.

key_concepts.concept: Reduced extrinsic mortality in ant queens
key_concepts.description: Ant queens experience low extrinsic mortality because they are protected within the nest by workers and soldiers, which reduces the selection shadow acting on them and allows stronger purifying selection at old age.

key_concepts.concept: Strong purifying selection on old-biased genes
key_concepts.description: Genes upregulated in old queens are under strong purifying selection, indicating evolutionary maintenance of gene function at old age, counter to expectations of deteriorating regulation.
Old queens show increased transcriptional regulation and maintenance of proteostasis and stress response, suggesting molecular mechanisms that prevent typical ageing deterioration.

theories.evidence: Comparative gene expression analysis in young and old ant queens; gene co-expression network analysis showing higher connectivity and upregulated anti-ageing modules in old queens; evolutionary analysis showing strong purifying selection on old-biased genes and hub genes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it addresses a general evolutionary mechanism explaining why ageing occurs or is mitigated, proposes causal mechanisms (selection shadow reduction leading to maintained gene regulation and anti-ageing processes), and is generalizable beyond a single organ or disease, applying to organism-level ageing.

results.title: Lipodystrophy-associated progeroid syndromes.

theories.name: Genomic instability as a hallmark of aging

key_concepts.description: Genomic instability refers to the increased frequency of mutations within the genome, often caused by impaired nuclear organization, chromatin structure alterations, and defective DNA repair mechanisms. This instability contributes to cellular dysfunction and is proposed as a fundamental driver of aging processes.

Changes in epigenetic marks such as DNA methylation and histone modifications disrupt normal gene expression patterns, leading to cellular aging and dysfunction. Epigenetic dysregulation is considered a key mechanism linking genetic defects to aging phenotypes.

Mitochondrial dysfunction involves impaired energy production and increased generation of reactive oxygen species, which can damage cellular components and promote aging. It is a widely recognized contributor to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews clinical features and molecular bases of lipodystrophy-associated progeroid syndromes, citing genomic instability, epigenetic dysregulation, and mitochondrial dysfunction as pathogenic mechanisms. It attempts to map these to López-Otín's hallmarks of aging, a widely accepted aging framework.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it addresses fundamental mechanisms (genomic instability, epigenetic changes, mitochondrial dysfunction) that causally contribute to systemic aging, not limited to a single organ or disease, and connects rare progeroid syndromes to general aging hallmarks.

results.title: DNA Methylation Age Mediates Effect of Metabolic Profile on Cardiovascular and General Aging.

theories.name: Epigenetic clock theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: DNA methylation age as a biomarker and mediator of aging
key_concepts.description: DNA methylation patterns change predictably with age and can be quantified by epigenetic clocks. These clocks not only correlate with chronological age but also reflect biological aging processes, potentially mediating the effects of metabolic factors on aging outcomes.

key_concepts.concept: Different generations of epigenetic clocks reflect distinct aging mechanisms
key_concepts.description: First-generation clocks (Horvath, Hannum, Li) are associated with cardiovascular aging risk, while second-generation clocks (GrimAge, PhenoAge) better capture general aging and frailty. This suggests multiple epigenomic mechanisms underlie different aspects of systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic profiles influence aging through epigenomic modifications
key_concepts.description: Circulating metabolites such as lipids, fatty acids, glucose, and inflammatory biomarkers affect DNA methylation age acceleration, which in turn mediates the risk of cardiovascular disease and frailty, indicating a causal pathway linking metabolism, epigenetics, and aging.

theories.evidence: Prospective cohort data from 988 participants with DNA methylation measured by EPIC BeadChip; metabolomic profiling by NMR; incident cardiovascular disease and frailty outcomes tracked over ~9.5 years; statistical mediation analyses showing DNA methylation age acceleration mediates metabolite associations with aging outcomes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how epigenomic changes mediate systemic aging processes influenced by metabolism; addresses broad aging outcomes (cardiovascular disease and frailty); provides mechanistic insight beyond correlation.

results.title: The role of mitochondria and mitophagy in cell senescence.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging with mitochondrial dysfunction

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is characterized by a permanent cell cycle arrest and is considered a hallmark of aging. It contributes to the loss of tissue function and health decline associated with aging.

During cellular senescence, dysfunctional mitochondria accumulate, leading to decreased efficiency of oxidative phosphorylation and increased production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which further promote aging processes.

Mitophagy, the selective degradation of damaged mitochondria, is perturbed during senescence, resulting in mitochondrial accumulation, impaired mitochondrial biogenesis, and contributing to aging and age-related diseases.

Cellular senescence has a dual nature, being both beneficial (e.g., tumor suppression, wound healing) and detrimental (e.g., chronic inflammation, tissue dysfunction), depending on context and timing.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondria as central hubs in aging
key_concepts.description: The theory emphasizes mitochondria as central players in aging, suggesting that targeting mitochondrial quality control mechanisms could mitigate negative effects of senescence and promote healthy lifespan.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known hallmarks of aging, mitochondrial dysfunction, ROS production, mitophagy impairment, and multiple signaling pathways, indicating a synthesis of existing literature rather than new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how mitochondrial dysfunction and impaired mitophagy drive cellular senescence, which in turn contributes to organismal aging. It addresses fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Aging as a Consequence of the Adaptation-Maladaptation Dilemma.

theories.name: Adaptation-Maladaptation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging results from the organism's inability to effectively counteract harmful influences over time, framing aging as a failure in adaptation to a set of aging stimuli.

Adaptation mechanisms such as adaptive transcription, epigenetic remodeling, and metabolic plasticity, while initially protective, progressively drive dysfunction themselves through maladaptation, contributing to aging-related disorders like cancer and metabolic dysregulation.

The core dilemma is that the very adaptation mechanisms used to handle stressors act as stressors themselves and cannot be fully counteracted, creating a paradox where protective processes also cause damage.

To reduce maladaptation, the organism may progressively downregulate adaptive cascades (e.g., via genomic methylation), which leads to decreased physiological adaptation capacity and aging syndromes such as frailty, immunosenescence, and cognitive decline.
Certain biological mechanisms can simultaneously protect against aging and drive aging, suggesting that longevity may depend on uncoupling adaptation from maladaptation.

theories.evidence: The abstract presents a conceptual framework without specific experimental data but references known biological processes (adaptive transcription, epigenetic remodeling, metabolic plasticity) and aging syndromes (cancer, metabolic dysregulation, frailty, immunosenescence, cognitive decline) to support the theory.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organism level, addressing fundamental adaptation processes and their paradoxical role in aging. It is not limited to a single organ or disease and explains aging broadly.

results.title: Pleiotropic fitness effects across sexes and ages in the Drosophila genome and transcriptome.

theories.name: Mutation Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This theory posits that mutations with deleterious effects that manifest later in life accumulate in populations because natural selection is weaker at older ages, allowing these mutations to persist and contribute to senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Decline in selection strength with age
key_concepts.description: Selection pressure decreases as organisms age, so mutations harmful in late life are less effectively purged, leading to an accumulation of late-acting deleterious alleles that cause aging.

theories.evidence: Quantitative genetic and transcriptomic analyses in Drosophila showed a negative correlation between the load of deleterious mutations and fitness across genotypes, supporting mutation accumulation; no support was found for antagonistic pleiotropy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organismal level through accumulation of late-acting deleterious mutations; it is generalizable beyond specific organs or diseases and provides causal explanation.

theories.name: Antagonistic Pleiotropy Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This theory suggests that some genes have beneficial effects early in life but deleterious effects later, leading to aging as a trade-off shaped by natural selection favoring early-life benefits.
Natural selection favors traits that enhance early reproductive success even if they cause deterioration in later life, explaining senescence as an evolutionary compromise.

theories.evidence: The study found little evidence supporting antagonistic pleiotropy in the Drosophila genome and transcriptome data, despite testing for it.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Although the theory is a valid aging theory, in this paper it is only tested and found unsupported; the paper engages with it but does not propose or develop it.

results.title: Why death and aging ? All memories are imperfect.

theories.name: Imperfect Cellular Memory Theory of Aging and Death

key_concepts.description: Cells collectively measure environmental cues to improve the validity of information, enabling natural cellular engineering through collaborative decision-making and problem-solving in response to environmental stresses.
All biological information at the cellular level is inherently ambiguous, leading to imperfect cellular memories—acquired patterns of response to environmental stressors that accumulate over time.

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of Imperfect Memories Leading to Senescence
key_concepts.description: As cells continuously learn and adapt, the buildup of imperfect memories reduces cellular flexibility, impairing the ability to respond effectively to new stresses and maintain homeorhetic balance, resulting in gradual functional decline.
The age-dependent accumulation of imperfect memories culminates in a breakdown of cell-cell communication and environmental information processing, causing systemic senescence and ultimately death.

This theory is presented as a novel framework that integrates and is compatible with existing aging theories, suggesting that previous approaches highlight different cellular signatures within this overarching process.

theories.evidence: The abstract references recent papers emphasizing cellular information management and evolutionary development; however, no direct experimental data or specific citations are detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain why and how biological aging occurs at a general organismal level by proposing a fundamental mechanism based on imperfect cellular memory accumulation affecting cellular decision-making and communication. It is generalizable, causal, and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Sex differences in markers of oxidation and inflammation. Implications for ageing.

theories.name: Oxidative-inflammatory theory of ageing

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress as a driver of ageing
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that ageing results from the establishment of oxidative stress, which causes molecular and cellular damage over time, contributing to functional decline.

key_concepts.concept: Interplay between oxidative stress and inflammation
key_concepts.description: Oxidative stress interacts with the immune system to induce inflammatory stress, creating a feedback loop that exacerbates damage and accelerates ageing.

key_concepts.concept: Sexual dimorphism in oxidative and inflammatory markers
key_concepts.description: Differences between males and females in levels of oxidation and basal inflammation may explain sex differences in lifespan, with males generally exhibiting higher oxidative and inflammatory stress.

key_concepts.concept: Circulating cell-free DNA as a marker and mediator
key_concepts.description: Cell-free DNA in circulation is proposed as both a marker of oxidative damage and an inducer of inflammation, linking the two processes and potentially serving as a useful biomarker of ageing.

theories.evidence: Presentation of sex differences in oxidative and inflammatory markers; discussion of circulating cell-free DNA roles; references to existing literature on oxidative-inflammatory theory.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining why and how ageing occurs through oxidative and inflammatory processes, applicable at the organism level and addressing lifespan differences; it is not limited to a specific organ or disease.

results.title: Mitochondrial cristae architecture protects against mtDNA release and inflammation.

theories.name: Mitochondrial cristae disorganization-induced inflammation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial cristae architecture as a protective mechanism
key_concepts.description: The structural organization of mitochondrial cristae, maintained by specific protein complexes and lipids, prevents the release of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) into the cytosol, thereby avoiding activation of inflammatory pathways.

key_concepts.concept: mtDNA release triggers innate immune response
key_concepts.description: Damage to mitochondria that disrupts cristae architecture leads to mtDNA release, which activates the cGAS-STING pathway, inducing a type I interferon (IFN-I) response and promoting inflammation.

key_concepts.concept: Link between mitochondrial damage, inflammation, and aging
key_concepts.description: Chronic mtDNA-induced inflammation is implicated as a driver of aging and aging-related degenerative diseases, suggesting that mitochondrial cristae integrity is a key factor in systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: A mitochondria-targeted CRISPR knockout screen identified key cristae architecture regulators whose disruption induces mtDNA release and IFN-I response; knockout of MTX2, linked to human progeria, induced STING-dependent inflammation in mouse liver.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking mitochondrial structural integrity to systemic inflammation and aging; addresses aging broadly through inflammation as a hallmark; provides mechanistic insights beyond narrow organ-specific or disease-specific phenomena.

results.title: Role of Mitochondria in Environmentally and Dietary Modulated Age-Associated Diseases.

theories.name: Mitochondrial Damage Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by the gradual build-up of damage within mitochondrial components, including mitochondrial DNA, proteins, and membranes, which impairs mitochondrial function over time.

key_concepts.concept: Decline in physiological functions due to mitochondrial dysfunction
key_concepts.description: As mitochondrial damage accumulates, cellular energy production declines, leading to reduced physiological capacity and increased vulnerability to age-associated diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Environmental and dietary modulation of mitochondrial aging
key_concepts.description: External factors such as environmental exposures and diet influence the rate and extent of mitochondrial damage, thereby modulating the aging process and related disease development.

theories.evidence: The abstract references the role of mitochondria in age-associated diseases and the impact of environmental and dietary factors, implying synthesis of existing literature rather than new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism (mitochondrial damage accumulation) explaining aging at the organismal level, linking environmental and dietary factors to systemic aging and disease.

results.title: Zbp1 gene: a modulator of multiple aging hallmarks as potential therapeutic target for age-related diseases.

theories.name: Cellular senescence as a causal driver of systemic aging

key_concepts.concept: Regulation of cellular senescence by Zbp1
key_concepts.description: Zbp1 controls the onset and progression of cellular senescence by modulating the expression of key senescence markers such as p16INK4a and p21CIP1/WAF1, which are critical regulators of cell cycle arrest and senescence phenotype.

Zbp1 promotes the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-6 and IL-1β through activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome, linking it to inflammaging, a hallmark of aging characterized by persistent low-grade inflammation.

Zbp1 regulates the cellular response to DNA damage by influencing the expression of genes such as p53 and ATM, which are central to DNA repair and maintenance of genomic stability, processes that decline with age.
Zbp1 modulates mitochondrial function, essential for energy production and cellular homeostasis, implicating it in the mitochondrial dysfunction hallmark of aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of multiple studies reporting Zbp1's role in regulating aging hallmarks including cellular senescence, inflammation, DNA damage response, and mitochondrial dysfunction; molecular mechanisms discussed in the review.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory addresses general aging mechanisms (cellular senescence, inflammation, DNA damage, mitochondrial dysfunction) at organismal level; proposes causal roles of Zbp1 in these processes; connects multiple hallmarks of aging; and suggests therapeutic interventions targeting aging broadly.

results.title: Redox Systems, Antioxidants and Sarcopenia.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative Stress as a Driver of Aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the accumulation of oxidative damage caused by reactive oxygen species (ROS) leads to structural and functional alterations in cellular components, which contribute to the aging process and age-related conditions.

key_concepts.concept: Decline in Antioxidant Defense with Age
key_concepts.description: Innate antioxidant defenses exist to limit oxidative damage, but their efficiency diminishes with aging, resulting in an imbalance favoring pro-oxidant species and increased cellular damage.

Maintaining a balance between oxidant production and antioxidant protection is critical for organismal homeostasis, and disruption of this balance may underlie the pathophysiology of aging and related phenotypes such as sarcopenia.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews literature on oxidative stress and antioxidant systems, discusses their role in sarcopenia and aging, and notes the lack of clear evidence supporting antioxidant supplementation benefits.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (oxidative damage) underlying aging at the organismal level, discusses evolutionary and biochemical bases, and connects to systemic aging phenotypes (e.g., sarcopenia).

results.title: Does oxidative stress shorten telomeres in vivo? A meta-analysis.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that reactive oxygen species and oxidative damage cause accelerated shortening of telomeres, which are protective caps on chromosomes, thereby contributing to cellular aging and organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere attrition as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Telomere shortening is considered a fundamental biological marker and driver of aging, linking molecular damage to the aging process at the cellular and organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress as a causal mechanism in aging
key_concepts.description: Oxidative stress is proposed as a proximate cause of aging by damaging cellular components, including DNA, proteins, and lipids, which leads to functional decline and aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: Meta-analysis of 37 studies with 4969 individuals and 18,677 correlational measurements; additional meta-analysis of 7 interventional studies manipulating oxidative stress; statistical correlations and effect sizes reported.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (telomere attrition linked to oxidative stress) with causal mechanisms, is generalizable across taxa and life phases, and addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Does oxidative stress shorten telomeres in vivo? A meta-analysis

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that reactive oxygen species and oxidative damage accelerate the shortening of telomeres, which are protective caps on chromosomes. This telomere attrition is considered a hallmark of biological aging, linking oxidative stress directly to the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere attrition as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Telomere shortening is a fundamental biological marker of aging, reflecting cellular senescence and organismal aging. The theory suggests that oxidative stress is a proximate cause driving this telomere shortening, thereby contributing causally to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Variation in oxidative stress effects across species and life phases
key_concepts.description: The impact of oxidative stress on telomere dynamics may vary depending on species lifespan and life stage, with stronger correlations observed in short-lived species and during adult life phases when aging phenotypes become apparent.

theories.evidence: Meta-analysis of 37 studies involving 4,834 individuals and 18,590 correlational measurements showed an overall correlation indistinguishable from zero between oxidative stress markers and telomere dynamics in vivo, but interventional studies (n=7) manipulating oxidative stress showed significant effects on telomere dynamics.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental biological aging mechanism (oxidative stress causing telomere attrition), proposes a causal explanation for aging at the organismal level, and is generalizable across taxa and life phases. The paper tests and synthesizes evidence related to this theory.

results.title: The role of protein oxidation in ageing & disease

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Ageing

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that reactive oxygen species (free radicals) cause damage to cellular components such as proteins, lipids, and DNA. This cumulative oxidative damage impairs tissue function and contributes to the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Protein oxidation as a driver of tissue aging
key_concepts.description: Specifically, oxidative modifications to muscle proteins are implicated in the deterioration of muscle function with age, linking molecular damage to systemic aging phenotypes like sarcopenia.

theories.evidence: The study uses advanced mass spectrometry and western blotting to detect and quantify oxidative modifications in muscle proteins from aged and obese mice, providing molecular data on oxidative damage patterns.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (oxidative damage) underlying aging at the organismal level, supported by mechanistic investigation of protein oxidation in muscle aging, a systemic aging phenotype.

results.title: Age-dependent aggregation of ribosomal RNA-binding proteins links deterioration in chromatin stability with loss of proteostasis

theories.name: Chromatin instability-proteostasis decline linkage theory

key_concepts.concept: Chromatin instability as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that instability at the ribosomal DNA (rDNA) region leads to aging-related cellular decline. This instability disrupts chromatin structure, which is a fundamental aspect of genome maintenance and cellular function.

key_concepts.concept: Proteostasis decline linked to chromatin instability
key_concepts.description: Loss of protein homeostasis (proteostasis) occurs specifically in cells exhibiting decreased rDNA stability. The decline in proteostasis is caused by aggregation of ribosomal RNA-binding proteins, which is triggered by aberrant overproduction of rRNAs due to chromatin instability.

key_concepts.concept: Interconnection between chromatin instability and proteostasis as a mechanism of aging
key_concepts.description: The aggregation of rRNA-binding proteins negatively impacts nucleolar integrity and global proteostasis, thereby limiting cellular lifespan. This mechanism explains how two major hallmarks of aging—chromatin instability and proteostasis loss—are causally linked at the cellular level.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from microfluidics and single-cell imaging in replicative aging yeast (S. cerevisiae), screening of 170 RNA-binding proteins showing enrichment of rRNA-binding proteins aggregating upon rDNA instability, and observations of nucleolar integrity and proteostasis decline associated with these aggregates.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking chromatin instability and proteostasis decline as fundamental aging processes at the organismal (cellular) level. It explains why and how aging occurs through molecular mechanisms affecting genome stability and protein homeostasis, not limited to a narrow phenomenon or specific disease.

results.title: Frentizole derivatives with mTOR inhibiting and senomorphic properties.

theories.name: mTOR signaling pathway theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) signaling pathway regulates cell growth, metabolism, and aging. Inhibition of mTOR by drugs like rapamycin is associated with lifespan extension and anti-aging effects, possibly by modulating cellular senescence and metabolic processes.

key_concepts.concept: mTOR as a central aging regulator
key_concepts.description: mTOR integrates environmental and cellular signals to control anabolic and catabolic processes, and its dysregulation contributes to aging and age-related diseases. Targeting mTOR can thus influence systemic aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: The paper performs docking studies of frentizole derivatives into the FKBP-rapamycin-binding domain of mTOR, molecular dynamics simulations, and in vitro assays measuring mTOR inhibitory and anti-senescence effects, followed by in vivo safety studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (mTOR signaling) underlying aging, supported by mechanistic studies and links to lifespan extension.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Accumulation of senescent cells contributes to aging and age-related decline by secreting pro-inflammatory factors and impairing tissue function.
Drugs that modulate senescence phenotypes (senomorphics) or selectively eliminate senescent cells (senolytics) can ameliorate aging phenotypes and extend healthspan.

theories.evidence: The paper evaluates frentizole derivatives for in vitro anti-senescence effects, including senolytic and senomorphic activities, linking these to mTOR inhibition and lifespan extension.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general causal mechanism of aging (cellular senescence) and tests interventions targeting this process.

theories.name: Mitochondrial free radical theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial toxicity and free radical damage drive aging
key_concepts.description: Accumulation of mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative damage from free radicals contributes to cellular and organismal aging. Disrupting toxic interactions in mitochondria, such as amyloid β binding to ABAD, may reduce mitochondrial toxicity and slow aging.

key_concepts.concept: Link between mitochondrial dysfunction and neurodegeneration
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial toxicity is implicated in Alzheimer’s disease pathology, suggesting a connection between mitochondrial aging mechanisms and neurodegenerative processes.

theories.evidence: The paper references frentizole’s ability to disrupt amyloid β-ABAD interaction in mitochondria and attempts to interlink this mitochondrial free radical-centric theory with mTOR signaling through docking studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental aging mechanism (mitochondrial damage) with causal implications for systemic aging and neurodegeneration.

results.title: Proteostasis and Energetics as Proteome Hallmarks of Aging and Influenza Challenge in Pulmonary Disease

theories.name: Proteostasis Collapse Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging leads to a maladaptive collapse of the proteostasis network, which is responsible for maintaining protein folding, quality control, and degradation. This collapse results in an excessive folding burden on cells, impairing their ability to maintain protein homeostasis.

Age-associated changes in mitochondrial pathways cause an imbalance that contributes to cellular stress and dysfunction. This mitochondrial imbalance exacerbates the proteostatic collapse and impacts cellular energetics.

Specific alterations in chaperone proteins such as Hsp70 co-chaperones (involved in protein folding) and Hsp90 co-chaperones (important for stress signaling) reduce the cell’s capacity to manage proteotoxic stress, especially under acute challenges like influenza infection.

theories.evidence: Proteomic analysis of alveolar macrophages and type 2 cells from young and old mice, both naïve and influenza A exposed, showing proteostasis network collapse and mitochondrial pathway changes with aging and infection.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (proteostasis collapse and mitochondrial dysfunction) underlying aging at the cellular and organismal level, supported by mechanistic proteomic data, and linked to systemic aging-related vulnerability.

results.title: On the Aging and Reproductive Consequences of Biological Complexity

theories.name: Complex Systems Dynamics Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Distributed and Complex Evolution of Aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is viewed not as the result of a few isolated causal factors but as a distributed process involving complex interactions and dynamics across multiple systems. This concept emphasizes the multifactorial and interconnected nature of aging rather than linear or single-cause explanations.

key_concepts.concept: Motivated Objectives and Principles Behind Aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that aging is driven by underlying objectives and principles related to growth, decay, and alternative biological routes such as reproduction. This implies that aging is not random but follows certain evolutionary or systemic goals.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of Techniques from Complex Systems Science
key_concepts.description: The model incorporates methodologies and analytical tools from fields that study complex systems dynamics to characterize and predict aging processes. This approach aims to capture the nonlinear, emergent, and systemic properties of aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract mentions a new theoretical model incorporating techniques from other fields but does not specify empirical data or experiments.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging at the organismal level, addressing why and how aging occurs through complex system dynamics and motivated biological principles.

results.title: Heterochronic parabiosis reprograms the mouse brain transcriptome by shifting aging signatures in multiple cell types

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Aging involves characteristic changes in gene expression profiles across multiple cell types, reflecting underlying molecular and cellular deterioration.

key_concepts.concept: Modifiability and reversibility of aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Interventions such as heterochronic parabiosis can alter or reverse aging-associated transcriptomic signatures, suggesting aging is not a fixed, irreversible process.
Different brain cell types, notably endothelial cells, show distinct aging signatures and responsiveness to rejuvenation interventions, indicating heterogeneity in aging processes within an organ.

theories.evidence: Single-cell transcriptomic profiling of young and old mouse brains after heterochronic parabiosis, identifying gene expression changes, pathway alterations, transcriptional networks, ligand-receptor interactions, and senescence status.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses aging broadly at the organismal level through molecular mechanisms, proposes causal mechanisms (hallmarks of aging), and tests the modifiability of aging signatures, thus explaining how aging occurs and can be reversed.

results.title: Chaotic aging: Intrinsically disordered proteins in aging-related processes

theories.name: Intrinsically Disordered Proteins (IDPs) Role in Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: IDPs as configurable hubs in signaling cascades
key_concepts.description: Intrinsically disordered proteins and regions lack stable tertiary structure, allowing them flexibility to act as dynamic hubs that regulate multiple cellular signaling pathways, including those involved in aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: IDPs involvement in genome regulation and aging hallmarks
key_concepts.description: IDPs are enriched in aging-associated processes, particularly those related to genome regulation such as genomic instability, telomere attrition, epigenetic alterations, and stem cell exhaustion, suggesting a central role in the molecular mechanisms underlying aging.

key_concepts.concept: IDP aggregation and toxicity as causal aging mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Aggregation of IDPs, especially those with high liquid-liquid phase separation propensity, can lead to loss-of-function and cellular toxicity, potentially driving aging-related cellular dysfunction and damage.
