theories.evidence: Analysis of a dataset of 1624 aging-related proteins showing 36% IDP content; Gene Ontology and protein-protein interaction network analyses revealing IDP enrichment in aging pathways; identification of IDPs with high LLPS propensity and predicted aggregation risk.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging at the molecular level involving IDPs affecting multiple aging hallmarks and cellular functions; it addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Comparative veterinary geroscience: mechanism of molecular, cellular, and tissue aging in humans, laboratory animal models, and companion dogs and cats.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by a set of complex but comprehensible biological processes that are highly conserved across species, indicating fundamental underlying mechanisms common to many organisms.
Key mechanisms of aging occur at the cellular and molecular levels, affecting tissues such as musculoskeletal, adipose, and brain, which manifest as age-related decline and dysfunction.
Identifying consistent aging patterns across species highlights potential targets for interventions aimed at mitigating negative health impacts, extending lifespan, and improving healthspan.

theories.evidence: Comparative descriptions of aging mechanisms in humans, laboratory animals, and companion dogs and cats; references to conserved hallmarks of aging; comparative analysis across species.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes generalizable, causal mechanisms of aging conserved across species, addresses aging broadly at organismal level, and discusses underlying biological processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Biomolecular Markers of Brain Aging.

theories.name: Damage Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging results from the time-dependent accumulation of cellular damage caused by vital activities, leading to loss of physiological integrity and impaired function.
Mitochondrial function declines with age, increasing oxidative stress which contributes to cellular damage and aging processes.
The failure to maintain protein homeostasis through autophagy and protein turnover leads to accumulation of damaged proteins, contributing to aging.
Signaling pathways such as insulin/IGF and TOR are altered during aging, affecting metabolism and cellular maintenance mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular Senescence and Stem Cell Exhaustion
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of senescent cells and decline in stem cell function reduce tissue regeneration and contribute to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references multiple well-known aging markers and conserved mechanisms such as mitochondrial dysfunction, oxidative stress, autophagy, insulin/IGF signaling, TOR signaling, and sirtuin function, citing their roles in aging generally and in brain aging specifically.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains aging as a fundamental process via damage accumulation mechanisms; proposes causal explanations; addresses aging broadly including brain aging as a special case.

theories.name: Programmed Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Aging is proposed as a genetically programmed process, implying that aging is regulated by genetic and epigenetic programs rather than solely by random damage.

theories.evidence: The abstract mentions this theory as one of two main categories of aging theories but does not elaborate experimental evidence or detailed mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain aging as a fundamental, organism-level process with causal genetic programming, though details are limited in the abstract.

results.title: An Antagonistically Pleiotropic Gene Regulates Vertebrate Growth, Maturity and Aging

theories.name: Antagonistic Pleiotropy Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Functional trade-offs between early-life and late-life fitness
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that certain genes or mechanisms that enhance fitness or reproductive success early in life may have detrimental effects later in life, contributing to aging and age-related decline.
Genes such as vgll3 can regulate traits like growth and sexual maturity, influencing the timing and balance of developmental processes that affect lifespan and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Late-life costs manifesting as disease and increased mortality
key_concepts.description: Early-life benefits conferred by certain gene variants may lead to increased risks of diseases such as tumors and higher mortality rates in later life stages.

theories.evidence: Experimental disruption of vgll3 isoforms in turquoise killifish showed accelerated growth and reproductive development (early-life benefits) but also melanoma-like tumors and increased late-life mortality, supported by transplantation experiments in immunodeficient rag2 models.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory explains why aging occurs via genetic trade-offs affecting organism-level life history; it proposes a causal mechanism (pleiotropic gene effects) with broad organismal implications; evidence is presented testing the theory in a vertebrate model.

results.title: Population size shapes the evolution of lifespan

theories.name: Mutation Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This theory posits that mutations with deleterious effects that manifest late in life accumulate in the genome because natural selection is weaker at older ages, allowing these mutations to persist and contribute to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Impact of population size on selection efficacy
key_concepts.description: The paper highlights that larger population sizes enable more effective purifying selection against deleterious germline variants, reducing both age-independent and age-dependent mortality, thereby influencing lifespan evolution.

theories.evidence: Numerical modeling results showing how population size affects mortality patterns under mutation accumulation assumptions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it explains a fundamental evolutionary mechanism underlying biological aging, proposes causal mechanisms, and addresses aging broadly at the organismal level.

theories.name: Antagonistic Pleiotropy Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Trade-off between early-life benefits and late-life costs
key_concepts.description: Gene variants that enhance survival or reproduction early in life can have detrimental effects later, leading to increased mortality post-maturation, which contributes to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of population size in selection dynamics
key_concepts.description: The study finds that larger population sizes facilitate stronger positive selection on gene variants that improve early-life survival, even if these variants increase late-life mortality, thereby shaping lifespan evolution.

theories.evidence: Numerical simulations demonstrating how population size influences lifespan evolution under antagonistic pleiotropy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Satisfies criteria by providing a causal evolutionary explanation for aging applicable at the organismal level and integrating population genetics factors.

results.title: Blood pressure variability: A potential marker of aging.

theories.name: Blood Pressure Variability as a Marker Linked to Hallmarks of Aging

key_concepts.description: BPV increases with age due to alterations in neuro-cardiovascular regulatory mechanisms, reflecting impaired physiological variability and homeostatic dysregulation typical of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Shared Molecular Mechanisms Between BPV and Aging
key_concepts.description: BPV and aging share molecular pathways including subclinical inflammation, endothelial dysfunction, increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, arterial stiffness, and autonomic dysfunction, which contribute to systemic aging phenotypes.

BPV is linked to fundamental aging hallmarks such as genomic instability, epigenetic modifications, and mitochondrial oxidative damage, suggesting it may reflect underlying causal mechanisms of biological aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of repeated evidence associating increased BPV with organ damage and multiple age-related health outcomes; references to molecular mechanisms common to aging and BPV; mention of Geroscience findings relating BPV to aging hallmarks.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses BPV as a systemic marker connected to fundamental aging mechanisms, proposing underlying causal links through shared molecular pathways and hallmarks of aging, thus meeting the criteria of generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope.

results.title: Improving intestinal inflammaging to delay aging? A new perspective.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The inflammaging theory proposes that persistent, systemic, low-level inflammation contributes causally to the aging process and age-related functional decline across multiple tissues and organs.

key_concepts.concept: Gut as a key site of inflammaging
key_concepts.description: The aging gut experiences changes such as microbiome dysbiosis, impaired immune function, and compromised barrier integrity, which promote chronic inflammation that in turn accelerates systemic aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Bidirectional relationship between inflammation and aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Inflammaging not only results from aging-related gut changes but also drives further aging-like phenotypes such as microbiota imbalance and intestinal barrier dysfunction through inflammatory mediators.

theories.mode: discuss, demonstrate mechanisms, explore intervention potential
theories.evidence: Citations of numerous studies linking gut microbiome, immune function, and barrier integrity to inflammaging; mechanistic discussion of inflammatory mediators; conceptual exploration of improving gut inflammaging to negate aging-like phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (chronic inflammation) underlying systemic aging, is broadly applicable beyond a single organ or disease, and explains how aging occurs at organismal level via inflammatory processes.

results.title: Free Radical Timer of Aging: from Chemistry of Free Radicals to Systems Theory of Reliability.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging integrated with Systems Theory of Reliability

key_concepts.description: Proposed by Denham Harman, this theory suggests that aging results from stochastic damage caused by free radicals, particularly oxygen anion-radicals (O2•-), which are by-products of mitochondrial respiration. These radicals induce oxidative stress leading to biomolecular damage and cellular dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Systems Theory of Reliability applied to Aging
key_concepts.description: This approach unites programmed aging and stochastic aging by modeling aging as a reliability problem of biomolecular constructs. It explains universal aging features such as exponential mortality increase and links longevity to species-specific metabolic rates, framing aging as a decline in system reliability due to stochastic failures.

Stochastic malfunctions in mitochondrial electron transport nanoreactors produce oxygen anion-radicals that disrupt redox balance (NAD(P)H/NAD(P)+ ratio), affecting sirtuin activity and slowing biomolecular renewal, which leads to accumulation of oxidative damage and triggers autophagy or apoptosis contributing to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Free-Radical Redox Timer as a Stochastic Mechanism
key_concepts.description: The free-radical redox timer acts as a stochastic mechanism that realizes a programmed decline in biomolecular reliability, effectively timing aging processes through oxidative stress accumulation and metabolic regulation.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews historical and contemporary concepts, integrates them via systems theory, and provides theoretical estimates (e.g., potential human brain longevity up to 250 years with perfect antioxidant defense). It cites known biochemical pathways (mitochondrial ROS production, sirtuin regulation) and mortality patterns.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging at the organism level by integrating stochastic damage (free radicals) with programmed reliability decline, addresses broad aging phenomena (mortality rates, metabolism), and synthesizes evolutionary and biochemical mechanisms.

results.title: Membrane Lipids and Maximum Lifespan in Clownfish

theories.name: Longevity-Homeoviscous Adaptation (LHA) Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Membrane lipid composition linked to lifespan
key_concepts.description: The LHA theory posits that the composition of cell membrane lipids influences metabolic rate and maximum lifespan. Specifically, the types and saturation levels of phospholipid fatty acids affect membrane fluidity and susceptibility to peroxidation, which in turn impacts aging.

key_concepts.concept: Membrane peroxidation index as a biomarker
key_concepts.description: The theory uses the membrane peroxidation index (PIn), derived from phospholipid fatty acid composition, as an indicator of membrane susceptibility to oxidative damage. Lower PIn values are associated with longer maximum lifespan, reflecting reduced oxidative damage to membranes.

Originally demonstrated in mammals and birds, the theory suggests a generalizable mechanism linking membrane lipid composition to longevity across vertebrates, including fish, although this study finds mixed support in fish species.

theories.evidence: Lipid analyses of brain, liver, and skeletal muscle phospholipids from two clownfish species and one damselfish species with different maximum lifespans; correlation analysis between membrane peroxidation index and lifespan; comparison with previous fish studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs via membrane lipid composition affecting metabolic rate and oxidative damage; addresses organism-level lifespan differences; tests theory predictions in fish models.

results.title: The evolution of ageing in cooperative breeders

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of ageing in cooperative breeders

key_concepts.concept: Delayed onset of senescence due to reproductive queueing
key_concepts.description: In cooperative breeders, natural selection favors a delayed start of aging processes because individuals reproduce later due to waiting in a reproductive queue. This delay in reproduction shifts the timing of senescence to older ages compared to solitary breeders.

When reproductive queueing depends on age, cooperative breeders evolve especially long lifespans. This mechanism links social structure and age-related reproductive opportunities to the evolution of longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Kin selection and genetic relatedness influence lifespan evolution
key_concepts.description: Lower genetic relatedness among group members leads to longer evolved lifespans because selection against mortality is weaker when death reduces competition between relatives. This integrates kin selection theory with aging evolution.

theories.evidence: Theoretical evolutionary modeling results demonstrating how cooperative breeding and kin structure affect lifespan and senescence timing.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable evolutionary mechanism explaining why aging occurs differently in cooperative breeders versus solitary breeders, provides causal explanations linking reproduction timing and kin selection to aging, and addresses aging broadly at the organismal and evolutionary level.

results.title: A Multidisciplinary Approach to Explain Biological Aging and Longevity

theories.name: Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Nonequilibrium thermodynamics governs biomolecular degradation and renewal
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that nonequilibrium thermodynamics controls the dynamic balance between molecular degradation and renewal within biomolecular ensembles, which leads to inevitable loss of fidelity in biological systems over time.

key_concepts.concept: Fidelity loss as a fundamental driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that the unavoidable decline in molecular fidelity due to thermodynamic principles underlies the aging process, providing a mechanistic basis for aging that transcends specific molecular damage types.

key_concepts.concept: Explanation of species longevity trends and paradoxes
key_concepts.description: The model accounts for observed longevity patterns across species, including paradoxical findings such as high damage levels in young individuals of long-lived species like the naked mole-rat, which are not well explained by existing theories.

key_concepts.concept: Challenges to declining selective pressure and disposable soma theory
key_concepts.description: This framework questions the primacy of declining selective pressure as the main driver of aging and challenges key assumptions of the disposable soma theory, suggesting alternative organizing principles.

theories.evidence: The abstract references theoretical modeling and comparative species observations (e.g., naked mole-rat damage levels) but does not detail experimental data; it also critiques existing theories such as disposable soma.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a general, organism-level causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs; it addresses broad aging phenomena including species longevity trends; it provides a causal explanation based on thermodynamics rather than mere description.

results.title: The role of nicotinamide mononucleotide (NMN) in anti-aging, longevity, and its potential for treating chronic conditions.

theories.name: NAD+ Decline and Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: NAD+ levels decrease across multiple tissues as organisms age, which is associated with the hallmarks of aging. This decline is proposed as a fundamental aging mechanism affecting organismal homeostasis.

NAD+ influences key cellular functions such as metabolic pathways, DNA repair, and immune cell activity. These processes are critical for maintaining cellular and tissue homeostasis, and their impairment contributes to aging.

Restoring NAD+ levels through supplementation with intermediates like nicotinamide mononucleotide (NMN) can delay or reverse age-related disorders, suggesting a causal role of NAD+ depletion in aging and age-associated diseases.

theories.evidence: References to recent studies in mice and humans targeting NAD+ metabolism with NAD+ intermediates, including clinical trial findings on NMN's effects on age-related chronic conditions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging (NAD+ decline) affecting multiple tissues and fundamental cellular processes, with implications for organism-level aging and longevity.

results.title: Epigenetic information loss is a common feature of multiple diseases and aging

theories.name: Epigenetic Information Loss Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging is driven by the loss of epigenetic information, specifically the erosion of tissue-unique DNA methylation patterns. This loss leads to a regression of these patterns toward a mean state, reducing the distinct epigenetic identity of tissues.

In aging and disease, methylation patterns that are unique to specific tissues degrade, causing these tissues to lose their epigenetic uniqueness. This degradation is observed as a convergence toward a common methylation profile across tissues.

The loss of epigenetic information is not only a feature of aging but also common across multiple diseases, suggesting a shared underlying mechanism linking epigenetic erosion to pathological conditions and organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Analysis of tissue-unique methylation patterns in healthy versus diseased organs showing regression toward mean methylation states; observation of age-related erosion of unique methylation patterns in some tissues and cells; ability to distinguish patients from healthy controls based on methylation pattern changes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs at the organism level via epigenetic information loss; it addresses aging broadly and links to disease states; it provides a mechanistic explanation rather than mere correlation.

results.title: Molecular and cognitive signatures of ageing partially restored through synthetic delivery of IL2 to the brain

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.description: Inflammaging refers to the progressive increase in basal, low-grade inflammation observed during aging, which is implicated as a central factor linking aging to various age-related diseases.
In the aging brain, increased infiltration of peripheral immune cells such as T cells contributes to amplification of inflammatory cascades, disrupting the neurogenic niche and neuronal function.

key_concepts.concept: Regulatory T cells and IL2-mediated immune modulation
key_concepts.description: A small resident population of regulatory T cells in the brain can be expanded by IL2 delivery, which may counteract neuroinflammation and partially restore molecular and cognitive aging signatures.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from aging mice treated with brain-specific IL2 delivery showing partial restoration of molecular aging hallmarks in glial cells and prevention of spatial learning decline.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (chronic inflammation) underlying aging at the organismal level, supported by mechanistic insights into immune cell roles and intervention effects.

results.title: A Multi-Omics Longitudinal Aging Dataset in Primary Human Fibroblasts with Mitochondrial Perturbations

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Framework

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial Metabolism as a Hallmark of Aging
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction is considered one of the central biological processes driving aging. This concept posits that changes in mitochondrial bioenergetics, including oxidative phosphorylation efficiency and mitochondrial DNA integrity, contribute causally to cellular and organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of Multi-Omics Data to Understand Aging Mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Combining diverse biological data types such as DNA methylation, gene expression, telomere length, and mitochondrial mutations allows for a comprehensive understanding of the mechanistic underpinnings of aging. This approach aims to link molecular changes to functional decline.

key_concepts.concept: Experimental Perturbation of Cellular Energetics to Test Aging Mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Manipulating pathways like oxidative phosphorylation, glycolysis, and glucocorticoid signaling in human fibroblasts provides a means to experimentally test how energy metabolism influences cellular aging processes, potentially validating causal roles.

theories.evidence: Longitudinal multi-omic dataset from primary human fibroblasts including healthy and mitochondrial disease donors; experimental manipulations targeting mitochondrial and metabolic pathways; publicly available data enabling further analysis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses general biological aging mechanisms (hallmarks of aging), proposes causal links via mitochondrial metabolism, and uses experimental data to test these mechanisms at the cellular level. The focus on mitochondrial metabolism connects to systemic aging processes beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: Eusocial insect queens show costs of reproduction and transcriptomic signatures of reduced longevity

theories.name: Costs of reproduction theory in eusocial insects

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that reproduction incurs physiological or survival costs that can reduce longevity. In eusocial insect queens, these costs may be latent or masked, leading to a positive correlation between fecundity and longevity under normal conditions.
Increasing reproductive effort (e.g., egg-laying rate) is hypothesized to reduce lifespan due to resource allocation trade-offs, consistent with classical evolutionary aging theories.

key_concepts.concept: Remodeling of genetic pathways during eusocial evolution
key_concepts.description: The genetic and transcriptomic profiles related to aging may be altered in eusocial insect queens, potentially explaining how costs of reproduction manifest differently compared to solitary organisms.

theories.evidence: Experimental manipulation of bumblebee queens by egg removal increased egg-laying rate and reduced longevity; mRNA-seq data showed differences in age-related gene expression between treatment and control queens, particularly with respect to relative age.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general evolutionary aging theory (costs of reproduction) with causal mechanisms (resource trade-offs affecting longevity), tested experimentally in eusocial insects, and connects gene expression changes to aging processes at the organismal level.

results.title: Defining the age-dependent and tissue-specific circadian transcriptome in male mice

theories.name: Circadian clock dysfunction as a driver of aging

key_concepts.concept: Circadian clocks regulate daily transcriptional programs
key_concepts.description: Cellular circadian clocks orchestrate rhythmic gene expression that supports physiological homeostasis and resilience by timing biological processes within a 24-hour cycle.
With aging, the number of rhythmically expressed genes (REGs) declines across multiple tissues, indicating a loss of robust circadian regulation which may contribute to systemic aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Tissue-specific and adaptive changes in rhythmic gene expression
key_concepts.description: Some genes gain rhythmicity in aged tissues, suggesting an adaptive or compensatory response to aging-related circadian disruption, which varies by tissue type.

key_concepts.concept: Link between circadian rhythmicity and hallmarks of aging
key_concepts.description: REGs in young mice are enriched for genes associated with established aging hallmarks, implying that circadian regulation intersects with fundamental aging mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Increased gene expression variability with age
key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with greater daily variability in gene expression across tissues, reflecting loss of transcriptional homeostasis and possibly contributing to aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: Transcriptomic profiling of circadian gene expression across six tissues in male mice at three different ages, showing quantitative and qualitative changes in rhythmic genes and gene expression variability.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism linking circadian clock dysfunction to systemic aging processes, supported by multi-tissue data and connection to aging hallmarks.

results.title: Investigating mitochondrial gene expression patterns inDrosophila melanogasterusing network analysis to understand aging mechanisms

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that progressive impairment of mitochondrial function leads to decreased cellular energy production and increased generation of reactive oxygen species, which contribute to the decline in physiological functions associated with aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of mitochondrial gene expression changes in aging
key_concepts.description: Alterations in the expression patterns of mitochondrial genes affect mitochondrial performance and cellular metabolism, thereby influencing the aging process and the development of age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Use of gene co-expression network analysis
key_concepts.description: Applying graph theory to analyze gene co-expression networks allows identification of modules enriched in mitochondrial genes, providing insights into the coordinated regulation of mitochondrial function during aging.

theories.evidence: Gene co-expression network analysis in Drosophila melanogaster at various developmental stages identified modules enriched in mitochondrial genes implicated in aging and age-related diseases, including UQCR-C1, ND-B17.2, ND-20, and Pdhb.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process (mitochondrial dysfunction) with causal mechanisms (gene expression changes affecting mitochondrial function) and is generalizable beyond a single organ or disease. The paper engages with this theory by analyzing mitochondrial gene expression patterns and their relationship to aging in a model organism.

results.title: Expanded bioinformatic analysis of Oximouse dataset reveals key putative processes involved in brain aging and cognitive decline.

theories.name: Redox Signaling Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Contrary to purely damaging roles, ROS reversibly oxidize cysteine residues in proteins, modulating their function and regulating cellular processes.

key_concepts.concept: Selective cysteine oxidation changes with age
key_concepts.description: Aging involves specific, targeted changes in cysteine oxidation states in key proteins rather than a global increase in oxidative damage.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on pathways linked to aging
key_concepts.description: Redox modifications affect pathways such as ubiquitin-proteasome system, one-carbon metabolism, mitochondrial transition pore regulation, and synaptic calcium homeostasis, which are implicated in brain aging and cognitive decline.

theories.evidence: Comprehensive bioinformatics analysis of cysteine oxidation in mouse brain aging using Oximouse dataset; identification of hundreds of putative redox switches in aging-related pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a mechanistic, generalizable explanation for aging involving redox regulation at the proteome level, with implications for systemic brain aging.

theories.name: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) Damage Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that reactive oxygen species generated by oxidative metabolism cause cumulative damage to biomolecules, leading to aging and functional decline.
ROS induce irreversible oxidative modifications in proteins, impairing their function and contributing to cellular and tissue aging.

theories.evidence: The paper references historical dominance of this theory in geroscience and contrasts it with newer evidence about ROS roles in signaling.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it is a generalizable, causal explanation of aging mechanisms at organismal level, addressing fundamental aging processes.

results.title: Age-specific effects of deletions: implications for aging theories.

theories.name: Mutation accumulation and antagonistic pleiotropy theories of aging

key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that aging evolves because mutations with deleterious effects manifest late in life when natural selection is weak, allowing these mutations to accumulate in the genome.
This theory suggests that some mutations have beneficial effects early in life but deleterious effects later, leading to aging as a trade-off shaped by natural selection favoring early-life benefits.

key_concepts.concept: Age-specific deleterious effects with progressive worsening
key_concepts.description: An extension or alternative to classic theories where mutations start as mildly harmful early in life and their negative effects progressively worsen with age, contributing to aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental measurement of genomic deletions for their heterozygous effects on juvenile performance, fecundity at multiple ages, and adult survival; data showing most deletions have age-specific effects that are commonly harmful late in life; analysis indicating many deletions fit a scenario of progressively worsening negative effects with age.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the paper addresses general aging mechanisms via mutation effects across life stages, proposes causal explanations for aging through mutation effects and their age-specificity, and discusses evolutionary theories of aging applicable at the organismal level.

results.title: A Cellular Senescence-Centric Integrated Approach to Understanding Organismal Aging.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence-Centric Integrated Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence refers to the irreversible growth arrest of cells in response to various stressors, which contributes causally to organismal aging by promoting tissue dysfunction and chronic inflammation.

Immunosenescence is the age-associated decline in immune system function, which is proposed to be interconnected with cellular senescence, thereby exacerbating systemic aging and increasing vulnerability to diseases.

Gut microbiota dysbiosis involves the imbalance of microbial communities in the gut, which is linked to aging processes and is hypothesized to interact with cellular senescence and immunosenescence to influence organismal aging.

The theory emphasizes an integrative view that connects cellular senescence with immunosenescence and gut microbiota dysbiosis, proposing a consolidated framework to understand the multifactorial nature of biological aging and identify therapeutic targets.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses emerging evidence linking cellular senescence, immunosenescence, and gut microbiota dysbiosis, citing recent research findings and conceptual interconnections, though no new experimental data is presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it attempts to explain aging as a fundamental organism-level process by proposing an integrative mechanism involving cellular senescence and related systemic modulators; it provides causal explanations linking these processes to aging; and it addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

results.title: Cellular senescence-an aging hallmark in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease pathogenesis.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cells undergo irreversible growth arrest and develop a senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), which contributes to tissue dysfunction and aging. Accumulation of senescent cells in tissues is implicated as a causal mechanism underlying aging and age-related diseases.

Exposure to cigarette smoke induces oxidative modifications to cellular components, accelerating cellular senescence by damaging macromolecules. This links environmental stressors to the causal mechanisms of aging via senescence.
Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory cytokines and other factors that disrupt tissue homeostasis and promote chronic inflammation, thereby driving aging-related pathology.

theories.evidence: Citations to studies showing increased cellular senescence in COPD tissues, effects of cigarette smoke on senescence induction, and the role of SASP in disease pathogenesis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes cellular senescence as a fundamental, causal mechanism driving organism-level aging and age-related disease, with generalizable principles beyond COPD.

theories.name: Proteostasis Loss and Autophagy Decline Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Autophagy, a conserved lysosomal degradation pathway that maintains proteostasis, diminishes during aging, leading to accumulation of damaged proteins and organelles that contribute to cellular dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Proteostasis loss as an aging hallmark
key_concepts.description: Failure to maintain protein homeostasis is a core hallmark of aging, which exacerbates cellular senescence and tissue degeneration.

key_concepts.concept: Dual role of autophagy in aging and disease
key_concepts.description: While insufficient autophagy promotes senescence and aging, excessive autophagy can induce regulated cell death, indicating a complex balance in autophagy’s role in aging and pathology.

theories.evidence: Reports from the authors and cited literature on autophagy insufficiency in COPD and its modulation of cellular senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental aging mechanism (proteostasis loss via autophagy decline) with causal implications for organismal aging and disease.

results.title: H<sub>2</sub>S contributed from CSE during cellular senescence suppresses inflammation and nitrosative stress.

theories.name: Cellular senescence as a regulator of systemic aging via redox and inflammatory modulation

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as an aging hallmark
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence involves permanent cell cycle arrest accompanied by increased reactive oxygen/nitrogen species (ROS/RNS), inflammatory gene expression, and senescence-associated beta-galactosidase activity, which are recognized hallmarks of aging at the cellular level.

key_concepts.concept: Role of gasotransmitters in redox homeostasis during senescence
key_concepts.description: Gasotransmitters such as hydrogen sulfide (H2S), nitric oxide (NO), and carbon monoxide (CO) modulate redox balance during cellular senescence, influencing oxidative and nitrosative stress levels.

key_concepts.concept: H2S produced by cystathionine gamma-lyase (CSE) modulates inflammation and nitrosative stress
key_concepts.description: H2S levels increase during senescence due to upregulation of CSE, leading to reduced phosphorylation of NF-κB components (IκBα and p65), thereby suppressing inflammatory gene expression and lowering NO-mediated nitrosative stress.

theories.evidence: Direct measurements of intracellular H2S using fluorescent reporter dye (WSP-5), protein sulfhydration analysis, lentiviral shRNA-mediated knockdown of CSE, and gene expression profiling demonstrating altered inflammatory pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory addresses aging broadly by linking cellular senescence mechanisms to systemic aging processes through redox and inflammatory regulation; it proposes causal mechanisms involving gasotransmitter signaling; and it generalizes beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: Aging, Senescence, and Dementia.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence refers to the process where cells cease to divide and undergo distinctive phenotypic alterations, including secretion of pro-inflammatory factors. It is recognized as a fundamental biological change that occurs broadly in aging tissues and contributes to organismal aging.

Senescent cells secrete a variety of pro-inflammatory cytokines, growth factors, and proteases (e.g., IL-6, IGFBP, TGF-β, MMP-10) that can disrupt tissue function and promote chronic inflammation, termed inflammaging, which is implicated in systemic aging and age-related diseases.

Senescence occurs not only in dividing cells but also in brain-resident cells such as microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. The accumulation of senescent cells in the brain is proposed to contribute causally to neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's disease, linking cellular senescence to systemic aging and disease pathology.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic risk factors linked to senescence
key_concepts.description: Genome-wide association studies have identified that genetic variants associated with Alzheimer's disease overlap with genes involved in senescence pathways (e.g., ADAM10, ADAMTS4, BIN1), suggesting a genetic underpinning connecting senescence mechanisms to aging-related neurodegeneration.

Senolytic compounds that selectively eliminate senescent cells have shown promising results in experimental models, supporting the idea that targeting senescence could modify aging processes and treat age-related diseases, thus providing a mechanistic intervention approach.

theories.evidence: Review of literature including cellular studies showing senescence in brain cells, detection of SASP factors in patient samples, genetic association studies linking senescence genes to Alzheimer's disease, and experimental data on senolytic compounds.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory explains aging as a fundamental biological process involving cellular senescence with causal mechanisms (SASP, cell cycle arrest), is generalizable across tissues and organismal aging, and connects to systemic aging and neurodegeneration.

results.title: Age Differences in Economic Preferences: Cumulative meta-analyses of risk, time, social, and effort preferences
Transposable elements and their role in aging.

theories.name: Transposable Element-Mediated Aging Hypothesis

key_concepts.description: The activity of transposable elements (TEs) in somatic cells contributes to aging by causing DNA damage, genome instability, and alterations in gene regulation, which cumulatively affect cellular and tissue function over time.

key_concepts.concept: Balance Between TE Activity and Repression
key_concepts.description: TEs maintain a dynamic balance between their transposition activity and cellular repression mechanisms; disruption of this balance with age leads to increased TE activity, contributing to age-related genomic and epigenetic changes.

key_concepts.concept: TEs as Drivers of Genome and Epigenome Modifications
key_concepts.description: TEs influence aging through their interactions with recombination, replication, repair, and chromosomal regulation processes, as well as by generating new genes and regulatory RNAs, thereby modifying regulatory networks that impact organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Species-Specific TE Composition Influences Aging Dynamics
key_concepts.description: Differences in the number, composition, and distribution of TEs among species may underlie variations in aging dynamics and longevity, suggesting a genomic basis for species-specific aging patterns.

key_concepts.concept: Dual Role of TE Activity Under Stress
key_concepts.description: TE activation under stress can have adaptive evolutionary benefits at the population level by generating genetic diversity, but at the individual level, it may reduce longevity and stress tolerance, linking TE activity to aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Review of published data on TE interactions with cellular processes, somatic mutations in human and animal tissues, correlations between TE activation and heterochromatin maintenance proteins, and analysis of species-specific TE features.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The hypothesis attempts to explain aging as a fundamental biological process via TE activity and its genomic/epigenetic consequences (generalizability); proposes causal mechanisms linking TE derepression and genome instability to aging (causal explanation); addresses aging broadly across organisms and tissues, not limited to specific diseases or organs (scope).

results.title: A new insight into cell biological and biochemical changes through aging.

theories.name: mTORC1 Hyperactivation Theory

key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that hyperactivation of the mTORC1 pathway in aging cells drives cellular and organismal aging processes by disrupting normal cell metabolism and growth regulation.

theories.evidence: Identified as the most important signaling pathway contributing to aging; no novel experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a mechanistic, causal pathway influencing aging broadly at the cellular and organismal level.

theories.name: Immunosenescence and Inflammaging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Shift in immune cell lineage and chronic inflammation
key_concepts.description: Aging involves a shift from lymphoid to myeloid lineage production and increased pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, TNF-α), causing systemic inflammation and contributing to age-related decline.

theories.evidence: Describes immune system changes with aging and their consequences; no new data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria by linking immune system remodeling and inflammation as causal contributors to systemic aging.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Accumulation Theory

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by the buildup of senescent cells that no longer divide but secrete pro-inflammatory factors, contributing to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Referenced as an existing theory; no new data or testing presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a causal explanation for aging involving cellular mechanisms with organism-wide implications.

theories.name: Neuro-Endocrine Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This theory posits that aging results from dysregulation of neuroendocrine systems, leading to altered hormone levels and systemic physiological decline.

theories.evidence: Mentioned as one of the theories explaining aging; no new evidence provided.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria by proposing a systemic causal mechanism affecting organism-level aging.

theories.name: Stem Cell Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that aging results from the progressive loss of stem cell function, leading to reduced tissue regeneration and repair capacity across the organism.

theories.evidence: Mentioned as one of several existing theories; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain a fundamental aging process at the organism level by implicating stem cell decline as a causal mechanism.

results.title: Early onset of senescence and imbalanced epidermal homeostasis across the decades in photoexposed human skin: Fingerprints of inflammaging.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that persistent, low-grade inflammation over time causes cellular dysfunction and contributes to premature aging of tissues. This chronic inflammation is a fundamental driver of biological aging processes.

Inflammaging disrupts the balance of tissue maintenance and repair, leading to altered cellular states such as senescence and impaired differentiation, which cumulatively manifest as aging phenotypes in the organism.
External factors like solar radiation induce or exacerbate inflammaging, especially in skin, which acts as a frontline defense and is thus particularly susceptible to inflammation-driven aging.

theories.evidence: The paper presents system biology analyses including histology, transcriptomics, proteomics, and biomarker measurements from human skin biopsies across ages and photoexposure conditions. Findings include elevated inflammatory SASP biomarkers (IL-8, IL-1RA/IL1-α), increased DNA damage response markers, accelerated epigenetic aging, and changes in gene/protein expression related to senescence, differentiation, hypoxia, and glycolysis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a general causal mechanism (chronic inflammation) underlying aging at the organismal tissue level (skin as a model but with implications for systemic aging), explains how aging occurs via cellular dysfunction induced by inflammation, and is not limited to a narrow phenomenon or disease.

results.title: Antifragility and antiinflammaging: Can they play a role for a healthy longevity?

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as aging driver
key_concepts.description: This theory proposes that a persistent, subclinical, systemic inflammatory state develops with age, termed 'inflammaging', which acts as a major risk factor for common age-related diseases and mortality.

key_concepts.concept: Balance between pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory responses
key_concepts.description: Healthy aging and longevity are associated with the ability to upregulate antiinflammaging responses that counteract inflammaging, allowing better coping with chronic inflammation.
A genetic predisposition for strong antiinflammatory responses and the capacity to remodel metabolic pathways to handle diverse stressors and antigens contribute to healthy lifespan extension.

theories.evidence: Citations of multiple studies on long-lived individuals, especially centenarians, showing correlations between antiinflammaging responses and healthy longevity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process (systemic inflammation), proposes causal mechanisms (inflammatory balance), and applies broadly to organism-level aging and age-related diseases.

theories.name: Antifragility concept applied to aging

key_concepts.concept: Antifragility as performance improvement under stress
key_concepts.description: Originally from business and risk analysis, antifragility describes systems that improve their function when exposed to stressors, rather than merely resisting damage.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic modulation in response to stress
key_concepts.description: Some individuals may modulate their epigenome more rapidly or effectively in response to diverse life stressors, potentially influencing inflammatory and anti-inflammatory pathways.
Antifragility and antiinflammaging may share mechanisms that regulate inflammatory responses, jointly contributing to healthy aging trajectories.

theories.evidence: Conceptual proposal linking antifragility theory from other fields to aging biology; no direct experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria: proposes a general mechanism (stress-induced improvement), links to epigenetic and inflammatory regulation, but antifragility is a borrowed concept not yet fully formalized as an aging theory.

results.title: Pan-tissue methylation aging clock: Recalibrated and a method to analyze and interpret the selected features.

theories.name: Antagonistic pleiotropy theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Genes or biological pathways have multiple effects, some beneficial early in life but detrimental later, leading to aging-related decline.
Certain genetic traits that enhance reproductive success or fitness in early life may cause damage or reduced function in later life, driving aging.
Aging arises because natural selection favors traits that improve early-life fitness even if they have negative effects in old age, explaining aging as an evolutionary trade-off.

theories.evidence: Analysis of selected DNA methylation probes from the pan-tissue methylation aging clock showed features supporting the antagonistic pleiotropy theory.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes an evolutionary causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organism level, generalizable beyond specific tissues or diseases.

results.title: Circulatory systems and mortality rates

theories.name: Mesoscopic aging theory combining network connectivity and biophysical transport

key_concepts.description: This concept models aging as influenced by the connectivity structure within an organism, where the pattern and strength of connections between components affect the aging process and mortality rates.

This concept emphasizes the biophysical transport of cooperative and antagonistic factors between cells, where the balance and kinetics of these factors influence cell death and thus organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Diversity of mortality curves explained by mesoscopic factors
key_concepts.description: By varying parameters such as factor ratios, reaction kinetics, diffusion, and flow, the model accounts for the observed diversity in aging patterns across different lifeforms, linking microscopic failures and macroscopic aging outcomes.

theories.evidence: The paper presents two theoretical models (network theoretic and convection-diffusion) and explores their implications on mortality curves, supported by model simulations and biophysical reasoning.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging mechanisms at a mesoscopic scale, linking microscopic processes and macroscopic aging patterns applicable to organisms broadly.

results.title: On How, and Why, and When, We Grow Old

theories.name: Universal Mitotic Fraction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is linked to a reduction in the fraction of cells that are dividing. This decline in cell division fraction follows a simple universal mathematical expression, termed the Universal Mitotic Fraction Equation.

Lifespan correlates with the age at which fewer than one-in-a-thousand cells are dividing, reflecting a failure of cellular rejuvenation. This failure occurs because cells are no longer diluted with new materials nor is DNA adequately repaired during mitosis.
Growth and aging are causally linked through the dynamics of cell division rates, suggesting that the processes are not independent but governed by shared cellular mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Mathematical modeling of growth and lifespan in terms of cell numbers (Cellular Phylodynamics), correlation of lifespan with mitotic fraction thresholds, citations of prior work on cell division and DNA repair mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining aging at the organismal level based on fundamental cellular processes; it links growth and aging universally across animals; it is not limited to a specific organ or disease.

results.title: Global Age-Specific Patterns of Cyclic Gene Expression Revealed by Tunicate Transcriptome Atlas

theories.name: Circadian Clock Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Circadian gene expression changes with age
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the expression levels of circadian clock genes, which regulate daily rhythms of behavior and physiology, alter systematically as organisms age, affecting organism-wide biological functions.

key_concepts.concept: Age-specific amplitudes and frequencies of clock gene oscillations
key_concepts.description: Circadian clock and clock-controlled genes oscillate with daily rhythms whose amplitude and frequency vary depending on the age of the organism, suggesting a dynamic regulation of circadian rhythms during aging.

key_concepts.concept: Link between circadian gene expression and aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Changes in cyclic gene expression at the tissue level correlate with morphological and cellular aging phenotypes, indicating that circadian dysregulation may be a key regulator or driver of systemic aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Circadian regulation intersects with known and novel aging pathways
key_concepts.description: Hundreds of pathways associated with established hallmarks of aging, as well as previously unlinked pathways, show age-related cyclical expression differences, suggesting circadian rhythms influence broad aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Transcriptome sequencing data from the colonial chordate Botryllus schlosseri showing organism-wide and tissue-specific age-related changes in circadian gene expression; correlation with morphological and cellular aging phenotypes; identification of affected pathways linked to aging hallmarks.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, organism-level mechanism explaining how aging occurs via systemic changes in circadian gene expression; provides causal explanation linking circadian regulation to aging phenotypes; addresses aging broadly beyond specific tissues or diseases.

results.title: Developmental diet alters the fecundity-longevity relationship and age-related gene expression inDrosophila melanogaster

theories.name: Standard evolutionary theory of ageing

key_concepts.description: This theory predicts a negative relationship between reproductive output (fecundity) and lifespan (longevity), based on the idea that resources invested in reproduction reduce those available for maintenance and survival.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation by mutations and resource availability
key_concepts.description: The theory acknowledges that this trade-off can be altered or reversed by longevity-enhancing mutations or unequal resource distribution among individuals.
In eusocial insects, reproductive queens can live longer than non-reproductive workers, representing a notable exception to the typical trade-off predicted by the theory.

theories.evidence: Experimental manipulation of larval diet in Drosophila melanogaster showing that developmental diet alters the directionality of fecundity-longevity relationships; gene expression profiling linked to aging genes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain why aging occurs at an organismal level through evolutionary trade-offs, proposes causal mechanisms (resource allocation and mutations), and addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Proper control of R-loop homeostasis is required for maintenance of gene expression and neuronal function during aging
Bioenergetics and mitochondrial dysfunction in aging: recent insights for a therapeutical approach.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Mitochondria are the primary cellular source of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are chemically reactive molecules containing oxygen. These ROS can cause indiscriminate damage to cellular macromolecules such as DNA, proteins, and lipids.
The oxidative damage caused by ROS accumulates over time, leading to a progressive decline in biological function and contributing to the aging process at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial Dysfunction as a Driver of Aging
key_concepts.description: Defects in mitochondrial function, including impaired electron transport chain activity, exacerbate ROS production and cellular energy deficits, which are linked to aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Citations of several years of research demonstrating the role of mitochondria in aging and the association of oxidative stress with age-dependent functional decline; discussion of novel mitochondria-targeted therapies and antioxidant strategies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs (ROS-induced damage from mitochondria), addresses aging broadly at the organismal level, and discusses underlying biological processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: [Unifying theory of aging].

theories.name: Unifying Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This theory aims to organize previously proposed aging theories, which each focus on limited elements of senescence, into a comprehensive and interconnected framework that explains aging as a complex, multifactorial process.

key_concepts.concept: Aging as a drift from developmental differentiation
key_concepts.description: Aging is described as a gradual deviation of the biological system from its developmentally differentiated state, leading to a progressive loss of the organism's ability to cope with environmental entropy and deterioration.

key_concepts.concept: Inevitability of aging due to information limits
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the current level of biological information in the human system restricts lifespan, making aging unavoidable and incurable under present conditions, although lifespan extension is possible without fundamentally altering this information.

theories.evidence: The abstract does not present experimental data but discusses conceptual synthesis of existing theories and general biological principles related to entropy and system information.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it attempts to explain why aging occurs at an organismal level by proposing an organizing principle (drift from developmental state and entropy), provides a causal explanation (loss of coping capacity due to information limits), and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

results.title: Sex-specific body mass ageing trajectories in adult Asian elephants

theories.name: Classical theory of ageing

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that differences in life-history traits between sexes, such as reproductive strategies and intrasexual competition, influence the timing and rate of ageing. In species with marked sexual dimorphism and stronger competition in one sex, that sex is expected to age earlier or faster.

key_concepts.concept: Trade-offs between growth, reproduction, and maintenance
key_concepts.description: The classical theory suggests that energy and resources allocated to growth and reproduction may come at the cost of somatic maintenance, leading to ageing and decline in physiological functions over time.

theories.evidence: Longitudinal dataset of semi-captive Asian elephants showing sex-specific body mass ageing trajectories, with males gaining weight until mid-life then declining, and females gaining weight until late life with decline only near death.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain why ageing occurs differently between sexes at an organismal level, proposes causal mechanisms related to life-history trade-offs and sexual competition, and addresses ageing broadly rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Increased juvenile survival may not be universally linked to longevity: ecological, social and life-history drivers of age-specific mortality in birds

theories.name: Traditional Evolutionary Theories of Ageing (tETA)

key_concepts.concept: Positive correlation between juvenile survival and longevity
key_concepts.description: The theory predicts that species with higher survival rates early in life should also exhibit greater longevity, based on evolutionary trade-offs and life-history strategies.
tETA posits that aging and lifespan are shaped by evolutionary pressures balancing reproduction and survival, where investment in early-life survival influences later-life longevity.

theories.evidence: Comparative study of 204 bird species analyzing juvenile survival, longevity, and their combinations; identification of both concordant (positive JS-L combinations) and discordant (JS-L mismatches) patterns; correlation with life-history, ecological, and social traits.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general, organism-level evolutionary theory explaining why aging occurs, proposes causal mechanisms (evolutionary trade-offs), and is broadly applicable beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Kidney-specific methylation patterns correlate with kidney function and are lost upon kidney disease progression

theories.name: Information Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that aging involves the progressive loss of unique tissue identity, as reflected by specific DNA methylation patterns that define tissue function. The loss of this epigenetic information leads to functional decline in tissues.

key_concepts.concept: Guided regression towards a baseline methylation pattern
key_concepts.description: Rather than random epigenetic drift, the loss of methylation patterns in aging tissues follows a non-random, locus-dependent trajectory towards a common baseline methylation state observed in other tissues.

key_concepts.concept: Correlation between methylation changes and gene expression
key_concepts.description: Changes in methylation patterns at specific genomic sites are accompanied by altered gene expression, linking epigenetic information loss to functional deterioration in aging organs such as the kidney.

theories.evidence: Identification of kidney-specific methylation sites whose methylation levels correlate with kidney function and disease progression; observation that methylation patterns regress towards a common baseline in chronic kidney disease; enrichment of transcription-factor binding sites at these loci; correlation of methylation changes with gene expression changes in patient samples.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs at the tissue and organism level through loss of epigenetic information, supported by mechanistic insights and linked to functional decline.

results.title: DNA Break-Induced Epigenetic Drift as a Cause of Mammalian Aging

theories.name: DNA Break-Induced Epigenetic Drift Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by progressive changes in the epigenome, particularly alterations in DNA methylation patterns, which accumulate over time and can be measured by epigenetic clocks.

key_concepts.concept: DNA Double-Strand Breaks (DSBs) as a Trigger
key_concepts.description: Non-mutagenic DNA double-strand breaks cause a reorganization of the epigenome, leading to epigenetic drift. This genomic instability acts as a causal mechanism initiating aging-related epigenetic changes.
The mechanism linking DNA damage to epigenetic changes and aging is conserved from budding yeast to mammals, suggesting a fundamental, generalizable aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Acceleration of Physiological and Cognitive Aging
key_concepts.description: Induced epigenetic changes driven by DNA breaks accelerate multiple aging phenotypes, including physiological decline, cognitive impairment, and molecular aging markers.

theories.evidence: Experimental evidence from a transgenic mouse model (ICE system) showing that inducible DNA double-strand breaks cause epigenomic reorganization and accelerate aging phenotypes and epigenetic clock advancement.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging at the organism level, links DNA damage to epigenetic changes as an underlying cause, and addresses broad aging phenomena beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Voluntary wheel running has no impact on brain and liver mitochondrial DNA copy number or mutation measures in the PolG mouse model of aging

theories.name: Mitochondrial theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial DNA damage as a cause of aging
key_concepts.description: This theory proposes that accumulation of mutations and damage in mitochondrial DNA leads to mitochondrial dysfunction, which in turn drives the aging process and associated phenotypes at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Role of mitochondrial DNA mutations in premature aging
key_concepts.description: Mutations in mitochondrial DNA, such as those caused by defective polymerase gamma proofreading in PolG mice, result in accelerated aging symptoms including hair loss, weight loss, organ damage, and early death.

key_concepts.concept: Exercise as a modulator of mitochondrial DNA mutations
key_concepts.description: Exercise has been reported to reduce mitochondrial DNA mutations and normalize protein levels in some tissues, suggesting a potential intervention that might influence aging via mitochondrial mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from PolG mutant mice showing accumulation of mtDNA mutations causing premature aging; exercise intervention tested for effects on mtDNA mutations and copy number in brain and liver; novel mtDNA extraction and mutation measurement methods implemented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: generalizable as it addresses a fundamental biological aging mechanism applicable organism-wide; proposes a causal mechanism (mtDNA damage causing aging); scope is broad, linking mitochondrial dysfunction to systemic aging phenotypes.

results.title: Plausible Links Between Metabolic Networks, Stem Cells, and Longevity.

theories.name: Stem Cell Aging and Longevity Regulation Theory

key_concepts.description: The theory incorporates major cellular hallmarks such as genomic instability, telomere attrition, epigenetic alterations, and stem cell exhaustion, which collectively contribute to the decline in tissue and organ function with age.
Hormonal and endocrine factors modulate aging processes by influencing stem cell compartments and systemic aging, suggesting that endocrine signals can regulate the rate of aging and longevity.

Age-associated changes in epigenetic marks affect gene expression patterns in stem cells and other tissues, impacting cellular function and organismal aging, and potentially serving as targets for antiaging interventions.

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic Networks and Stem Cell Function
key_concepts.description: Metabolic pathways and networks interact with stem cell biology to influence longevity, implying that metabolic regulation is a key mechanism underlying aging processes.

theories.evidence: The abstract references recent discoveries in genetic pathways and biochemical processes controlling aging rate, discusses stem cell biology and endocrine regulation, and overviews epigenetic modifications and antiaging modalities, indicating a synthesis of current research findings.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain aging as a fundamental process involving stem cell biology, endocrine regulation, and epigenetic mechanisms, proposing causal pathways that affect organismal aging and longevity. It is generalizable beyond specific diseases or organs and addresses mechanisms underlying aging.

results.title: Towards a network theory of ageing: a model combining the free radical theory and the protein error theory.

theories.name: Network Theory of Ageing

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that ageing results from a network of interacting maintenance processes rather than a single cause. It emphasizes that multiple molecular and cellular processes operate in parallel to influence ageing and longevity.
This component describes how free radicals, antioxidants, and proteolytic enzymes interact, with free radicals causing damage that can destabilize cellular systems if not adequately neutralized.
This part focuses on error propagation loops within the cellular translation machinery, where errors in protein synthesis accumulate and contribute to ageing.

The theory links the system’s ability to maintain homeostasis through energy-consuming maintenance processes to lifespan, suggesting a positive correlation between maintenance energy expenditure and longevity.
The model supports the idea that caloric restriction prolongs life by reducing the generation of free radicals, thereby stabilizing the translation system and reducing damage accumulation.

theories.evidence: Theoretical model simulations integrating free radical and protein error theories; simulation results showing destabilization of translation system by radicals; correlation between maintenance energy and lifespan; support for caloric restriction effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of ageing as a network of interacting processes affecting organismal homeostasis; integrates established biological theories into a broader framework; addresses ageing broadly rather than narrowly.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Ageing

key_concepts.description: Free radicals cause molecular damage that accumulates over time, leading to cellular dysfunction and ageing.
Antioxidants and proteolytic enzymes mitigate free radical damage by neutralizing radicals and degrading damaged proteins, respectively.

theories.evidence: Incorporated into the network model; simulations show increased radical production or insufficient protection destabilizes translation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: A well-established general ageing theory explaining causal mechanisms of damage accumulation; here integrated into a broader network model.

theories.name: Protein Error Theory of Ageing

key_concepts.description: Errors in the cellular translation machinery accumulate and propagate, leading to dysfunctional proteins and contributing to ageing.
Error propagation loops create a feedback mechanism that exacerbates protein errors and cellular dysfunction over time.

theories.evidence: Incorporated into the network model; simulations show interaction with free radical damage affects system stability.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Provides a causal mechanism for ageing at the molecular level; integrated here into a broader network framework.

results.title: Rodent diet aids and the fallacy of caloric restriction.

theories.name: Tumor Suppression Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Aging delay via tumor suppression mechanisms
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that caloric restriction (CR) delays aging primarily by reducing obesity-related tumorigenesis, implying that the anti-aging effects of CR are mediated through enhanced tumor suppression rather than a direct slowing of intrinsic aging processes.

The health and lifespan benefits of CR depend on the baseline metabolic state of the organism, particularly obesity status; CR extends lifespan mainly when control animals are obese, suggesting that CR acts by mitigating obesity-related damage rather than universally slowing aging.

key_concepts.concept: Pharmacologic lifespan extension linked to weight reduction
key_concepts.description: Drugs like resveratrol, rapamycin, nicotinamide mononucleotide, and metformin extend lifespan partly by reducing body weight, supporting the idea that interventions improving health span may function as diet aids that reduce obesity-associated risks rather than directly targeting aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Comparative observations in rodents and primates showing that CR benefits are prominent only when control groups are obese; pharmacologic interventions that extend lifespan also reduce body weight; human epidemiological data indicating optimal survival at normal BMI without CR.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how aging delay occurs (via tumor suppression linked to obesity reduction), is generalizable beyond specific diseases, and addresses aging broadly at the organism level.

results.title: Eusociality and the Evolution of Aging in Superorganisms.

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of aging in eusocial superorganisms

key_concepts.description: In eusocial colonies, reproductive roles are monopolized by queens (and kings in termites), which leads natural selection to favor longer queen lifespans compared to workers, independent of extrinsic mortality risks.

Despite sharing genomes, queens and workers exhibit dramatically different lifespans, with queens living much longer. This divergence is influenced more by reproductive roles and colony structure than by differences in external hazards.

Contrary to classical evolutionary aging theory, caste-specific extrinsic hazards (e.g., exposure to external risks) are neither necessary nor sufficient to explain lifespan differences between queens and workers.

key_concepts.concept: Impact of reproductive skew and colony structure
key_concepts.description: Factors reducing reproductive skew, such as polygyny and worker reproduction, decrease lifespan divergence between castes, highlighting the evolutionary importance of reproductive dynamics in aging.

theories.evidence: Quantitative mathematical models developed and analyzed to explain caste-specific aging patterns; challenges classical verbal evolutionary aging explanations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: provides a generalizable evolutionary aging theory explaining why eusocial insect queens live longer than workers; proposes causal mechanisms based on reproductive monopolization and colony structure; addresses aging at organismal and colony levels.

results.title: Epigenetic clocks provide clues to the mystery of uterine ageing.

theories.name: Information Theory of Ageing

key_concepts.concept: Genomic Instability and Epigenetic Landscape Erosion
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that aging is driven by the loss of genomic integrity and the progressive smoothing or erosion of the epigenetic landscape, which leads to a decline in cellular and tissue functionality.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic Clocks as Measures of Biological Aging
key_concepts.description: Epigenetic clocks, based on DNA methylation patterns, serve as biomarkers that reflect the biological age of tissues by measuring the 'ticking' or progression of epigenetic changes associated with aging.

key_concepts.concept: Age-Related Functional Decline Linked to Epigenetic Changes
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that the functional decline of tissues, including the uterus, is causally linked to changes in the epigenetic landscape, which can be quantified and potentially modulated.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews data from epigenetic clock applications (Horvath, DNAm PhenoAge, Zang, AltumAge) in uterine/endometrial tissues, highlighting correlations with chronological age and functional decline, and discusses strategies to improve clock accuracy and potential interventions to slow or reverse epigenetic aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining aging at the organismal level through epigenetic information loss, addresses broad aging processes beyond a single organ, and discusses mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: The variability of expression of many genes and most functional pathways is observed to increase with age in brain transcriptome data

theories.name: Stochastic damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Aging as a non-programmed stochastic process
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging is not driven by a genetic program but results from random, dynamic stochastic events that accumulate over time, leading to functional decline.

key_concepts.concept: Increase in transcriptional noise with age
key_concepts.description: A key mechanism proposed is that molecular-level stochasticity, such as variability in gene expression (transcriptional noise), increases with age, reflecting underlying random damage or dysregulation.

key_concepts.concept: Transcriptome heterogeneity as a marker of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that increased heterogeneity in gene expression across cells or individuals is a hallmark of aging, indicating loss of regulatory precision and increased biological variability.

theories.evidence: Analysis of human brain transcriptome data showing a reproducible, transcriptome-wide increase in gene expression heterogeneity with age, independent of analysis method and affecting many functional pathways.
