theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it attempts to explain why aging occurs (stochastic accumulation of damage/noise), is generalizable to organism-level aging (transcriptome-wide, multiple pathways), and proposes causal mechanisms (increased transcriptional noise as driver of aging).

results.title: C. eleganshermaphrodites undergo semelparous reproductive death

theories.name: Semelparous reproductive death theory

key_concepts.description: Semelparous organisms reproduce only once in their lifetime, investing massive resources into a single reproductive episode that leads to rapid death. This reproductive death is characterized by extensive biomass repurposing and organ degeneration, as seen in species like Pacific salmon and monocarpic plants.

In C. elegans hermaphrodites, intestinal biomass is converted into yolk post-reproduction, causing intestinal atrophy and yolk steatosis. This process supports larval growth via yolk milk but leads to severe senescent pathology and early death.

key_concepts.concept: Germline removal suppresses reproductive death and extends lifespan
key_concepts.description: Removal of the germline in C. elegans and Pacific salmon suppresses semelparous reproductive death, resulting in lifespan extension. This indicates a causal link between reproductive effort and aging-related death.

key_concepts.concept: Programmatic mechanisms underlying reproductive death and aging
key_concepts.description: Reproductive death is viewed as an exaggerated form of programmatic aging mechanisms that also contribute to aging in non-semelparous species. Thus, mechanisms driving reproductive death in C. elegans may inform general aging biology.

theories.evidence: Comparative analysis of three Caenorhabditis sibling species pairs showing lactation and early pathology only in hermaphrodites; lifespan extension upon germline removal; citations of prior studies on reproductive death and germline removal effects in C. elegans and Pacific salmon.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains why aging occurs in C. elegans as a fundamental process linked to reproductive strategy; proposes causal mechanisms (biomass repurposing, germline influence); addresses aging broadly by connecting semelparous reproductive death to general aging mechanisms.

results.title: The Impact of Vitamin C on Different System Models of Werner Syndrome.

theories.name: Werner Syndrome as a Model of Accelerated Aging via DNA Repair and Telomere Maintenance Defects

key_concepts.concept: Genetic instability and defective WRN protein
key_concepts.description: Werner syndrome is caused by mutations in the WRN gene encoding a helicase/exonuclease involved in DNA replication, repair, transcription, and telomere maintenance. This defect leads to genomic instability, a hallmark of aging.
WS individuals exhibit increased oxidative stress and inflammation, which are recognized contributors to aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Hallmarks of aging recapitulated in WS models
key_concepts.description: Biological models of WS (mouse, C. elegans, human iPSCs) show cellular phenotypes that overlap with general aging hallmarks, suggesting WS models reflect systemic aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Citations and descriptions of multiple WS biological models (mouse, worm, human iPSCs) demonstrating aging-related anomalies; references to molecular pathways involving WRN protein.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism of aging (DNA repair and telomere dysfunction) that explains systemic aging phenotypes, supported by multiple model systems.

theories.name: Vitamin C as a Modulator of Aging Phenotypes via Antioxidant and Enzymatic Cofactor Roles

key_concepts.concept: Vitamin C counteracts age-related cellular phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Vitamin C supplementation reverses aging-related cellular defects observed in WS models, indicating a potential causal role in modulating aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Vitamin C as a cofactor for hydroxylases and oxygenases
key_concepts.description: Beyond antioxidant properties, vitamin C acts as a cofactor for enzymes involved in epigenetic regulation and other molecular pathways, adding complexity to its role in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Uncertainty about clinical efficacy in WS patients
key_concepts.description: It remains unclear whether vitamin C supplementation benefits human WS patients long-term, highlighting the need for further mechanistic and clinical studies.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from WS cellular and animal models showing reversal of aging phenotypes with vitamin C; biochemical knowledge of vitamin C enzymatic roles.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it discusses a potential causal intervention affecting systemic aging phenotypes, but the exact mechanisms and generalizability remain to be fully elucidated.

results.title: Male reproductive strategy and decreased longevity.

theories.name: Disposable Soma Theory of Ageing

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that organisms allocate limited resources between reproduction and somatic maintenance. Investment in reproduction reduces resources available for maintaining the body, leading to aging and decreased longevity.
Higher investment in somatic maintenance promotes longevity by preserving bodily functions, whereas reduced maintenance accelerates aging and mortality.
Aging results from evolutionary trade-offs where natural selection favors reproductive success over long-term maintenance, explaining why organisms age.

theories.evidence: The paper uses the concept of r-K selection theory applied to gender differences, citing higher male reproductive rates and riskier behaviors as reasons for lower somatic maintenance and longevity in males, consistent with disposable soma theory predictions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains aging as a fundamental process with evolutionary logic, proposes causal mechanisms (resource allocation trade-offs), and addresses aging broadly at the organism level through gender differences in reproductive strategy.

theories.name: r-K Selection Theory Applied to Aging

key_concepts.description: r-selected organisms prioritize high reproductive rates with less investment in individual offspring and somatic maintenance, leading to shorter lifespan. K-selected organisms invest more in fewer offspring and somatic maintenance, promoting longevity.

Males are characterized as r-selected with risky, variable reproductive behavior and less somatic maintenance, while females are K-selected with steady reproductive investment linked to somatic maintenance.
The reproductive strategy influences longevity through differential investment in body maintenance, explaining inter-gender lifespan differences.

theories.evidence: The paper applies r-K selection theory to explain observed gender differences in metabolic rates, mortality, and reproductive behavior, linking these to somatic maintenance and longevity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a generalizable evolutionary framework explaining aging-related differences in lifespan through reproductive strategies, with causal implications for somatic maintenance and aging.

results.title: Inflammaging in human photoexposed skin: Early onset of senescence and imbalanced epidermal homeostasis across the decades

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that persistent, low-grade inflammation over time causes cellular dysfunction and contributes to premature aging of tissues. This chronic inflammation is a fundamental driver of aging processes at the organismal level.
Inflammaging leads to an imbalance in tissue homeostasis, disrupting normal cellular functions such as differentiation and repair, which accelerates aging phenotypes in affected tissues.
In tissues like skin, environmental factors such as solar radiation exacerbate inflammaging by inducing inflammatory responses, DNA damage, and epigenetic changes that promote premature aging.

theories.evidence: The paper presents histological, transcriptomic, proteomic, and biomarker data from human skin biopsies across ages 20s to 70s, showing elevated inflammatory markers (IL-8, IL-1RA/IL1-α), DNA damage response markers (53BP1), accelerated epigenetic aging, and changes in gene/protein expression related to senescence, differentiation, hypoxia, and glycolysis in photoexposed skin.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a general causal mechanism (chronic inflammation) underlying biological aging at the tissue and organismal level, supported by molecular and cellular evidence. It is not limited to a specific disease or organ but addresses aging broadly, with skin as a model system illustrating systemic aging processes.

results.title: The biology and t heories of aging.

theories.name: Damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging results from the accumulation of damage to molecules such as proteins and DNA over time, leading to irreversible changes at cellular and tissue levels.
The accumulation of damage disrupts the body's ability to maintain internal stability, reducing stress resistance and increasing vulnerability to diseases.
Aging is driven by multiple mechanisms, both genetic and acquired, that collectively contribute to the aging process rather than a single cause.

theories.evidence: The abstract references cumulative damage to proteins and DNA and discusses multiple mechanisms contributing to aging, citing the complexity and multifactorial nature of the process.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging at the organism level involving fundamental biological damage mechanisms.

results.title: Lifelong Cytomegalovirus and Early-Life Irradiation Synergistically Potentiate Age-Related Defects in Response to Vaccination and Infection

theories.name: DNA-damage theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Unrepaired DNA damage leads to cellular and organismal senescence
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that accumulation of DNA damage that is not properly repaired causes cells to enter senescence, which contributes to the aging process at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage as a fundamental cause of immune aging
key_concepts.description: Exposure to whole-body irradiation causes DNA damage and hematopoietic repopulation stress, which are linked to hallmarks of immune aging, suggesting DNA damage drives systemic aging effects.
The theory is extended by examining how DNA damage from irradiation synergizes with lifelong latent cytomegalovirus infection to potentiate age-related immune defects and mortality.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from murine models showing that early-life sub-lethal whole-body irradiation combined with lifelong latent MCMV infection leads to increased mortality and immune dysfunction in old age, especially after vaccination and viral challenge. Observations include MCMV reactivation and immune activation correlating with mortality.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a general causal mechanism (DNA damage causing aging via senescence), is broadly applicable to organismal aging (immune system aging as a systemic aging hallmark), and is tested experimentally in a model relevant to human aging.

results.title: Evolution favors aging in populations with assortative mating and strong pathogen pressure

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of aging with assortative mating and pathogen pressure

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that aging individuals can outcompete non-aging individuals under certain conditions such as higher initial fertility, assortative mating patterns, and strong pathogen pressure. This suggests that aging may confer a selective advantage in specific ecological and reproductive contexts.

Assortative mating, where individuals preferentially mate with similar phenotypes, can promote the prevalence of aging phenotypes in a population by influencing reproductive success and genetic structure.
Strong pathogen pressure favors aging phenotypes, possibly because aging may facilitate faster generational turnover, enhancing population adaptability to pathogens.

Populations with dimorphic sexual reproduction (separate sexes) show a greater tendency for aging phenotypes to dominate or resist non-aging phenotypes compared to hermaphroditic populations, indicating reproductive system structure influences aging evolution.

key_concepts.concept: Bridging classical and programmed aging theories
key_concepts.description: The findings align with both classical evolutionary theories (e.g., mutation accumulation, antagonistic pleiotropy) and programmed aging theories, suggesting aging evolution may involve a combination of mechanisms rather than a single explanation.

theories.evidence: Mathematical modeling simulating evolution in sexually reproducing populations with aging and non-aging individuals, analyzing effects of fertility, mating patterns, pathogen pressure, and reproductive system type.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory is generalizable to organism-level aging evolution, provides causal explanations for why aging evolves, and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Dietary restriction improves fitness of ageing parents but reduces fitness of their offspring

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Trade-off between somatic maintenance and reproduction
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that organisms allocate limited resources between maintaining their own body (soma) and reproduction. Increased investment in somatic maintenance can extend lifespan but often comes at the cost of reduced reproductive output.

Extending parental lifespan through dietary restriction may reduce offspring fitness, indicating that benefits to parents can have costs for their progeny, which may explain missing costs of longevity in evolutionary terms.

Recent findings suggesting dietary restriction can extend lifespan without apparent costs challenge a central tenet of the evolutionary theory, which assumes longevity gains must come with trade-offs.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from Caenorhabditis remanei showing that dietary restriction by fasting increased female lifespan, fecundity, and stress resistance, but offspring of DR mothers had reduced fecundity, slower growth, and smaller body size.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental, organism-level aging process with causal explanations involving resource allocation trade-offs and evolutionary logic; it is not limited to a single organ or disease and discusses mechanisms underlying aging.

results.title: Senescence: Still an Unsolved Problem of Biology

theories.name: Classical Evolutionary Theories of Senescence

key_concepts.description: These theories propose that senescence, characterized by increasing mortality risk and declining reproduction with age, is an unavoidable outcome of evolutionary processes after maturity.

key_concepts.concept: Universality of senescence in species with germ-soma separation
key_concepts.description: Theories predict that species possessing a clear germ-soma barrier inevitably exhibit senescence, reflecting a fundamental biological constraint.

theories.evidence: Demographic data from 308 multicellular species showing age-based mortality and reproduction trajectories that contradict predictions of classical theories; evidence that senescence is not universal and that mortality and reproduction patterns can diverge.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain why aging occurs at an organismal level with causal evolutionary mechanisms; the paper critiques these theories based on broad comparative data.

theories.name: Expanded Multidimensional Theories of Senescence

key_concepts.description: Proposes that classical theories focusing solely on chronological age are insufficient to explain senescence patterns; other factors must be considered.

key_concepts.concept: Role of life history traits, size, ecology, and kin selection
key_concepts.description: Suggests that traits such as organism size, ecological context, and kin selection dynamics play integral roles in shaping senescence outcomes, potentially explaining observed deviations from classical theory predictions.

theories.evidence: Based on observed discrepancies between classical theory predictions and empirical data across many species, the authors propose widening theoretical frameworks to include additional biological and ecological factors.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a broader causal framework for aging that attempts to explain why and how senescence varies across species at an organismal level.

results.title: KMT1/Suv39 methyltransferase family regulates peripheral heterochromatin tethering via histone and non-histone protein methylations

theories.name: Epigenetic regulation of aging via heterochromatin organization

key_concepts.description: EHMTs (euchromatic histone methyltransferases) methylate the non-histone protein LaminB1, stabilizing it and facilitating its association with peripheral heterochromatin marked by H3K9me2. This methylation is crucial for anchoring heterochromatin to the nuclear periphery.

key_concepts.concept: Loss of EHMT function leads to heterochromatin disorganization
key_concepts.description: Loss of EHMTs or LMNB1 methylation disrupts heterochromatin anchorage at the nuclear periphery, causing altered nuclear morphology and epigenetic changes such as global reduction of H3K27 methylation, which are hallmarks of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Correlation of EHMT depletion with aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: A gradual depletion of EHMTs correlates with loss of methylated LMNB1 and peripheral heterochromatin in aging human fibroblasts, suggesting a mechanistic link between EHMT activity, chromatin organization, and intrinsic aging processes.

Restoration of EHMT expression in aged cells reverts defects in peripheral heterochromatin organization, indicating that EHMT-mediated methylation pathways may causally influence aging-related chromatin changes.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing EHMT methylation of LaminB1, loss of heterochromatin anchorage upon EHMT or LMNB1 methylation loss, observation of EHMT depletion in aging fibroblasts, and rescue of chromatin defects by EHMT restoration.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general epigenetic mechanism explaining how chromatin organization changes contribute causally to intrinsic aging at the cellular and organismal level. It addresses fundamental aging processes beyond a single tissue or disease and provides mechanistic insight into aging-related nuclear architecture changes.

results.title: Free radical theory of aging: history.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Free radical reactions as causal agents
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that aging is caused by free radical reactions, which are chemical reactions involving highly reactive molecules with unpaired electrons. These reactions damage cellular components and accumulate over time, leading to the functional decline associated with aging.

key_concepts.concept: Modifiability by genetic and environmental factors
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that the aging process driven by free radicals is modifiable through genetic predispositions and environmental influences, implying that interventions could potentially alter the rate or extent of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Unified explanation for aging and disease
key_concepts.description: Free radical reactions are implicated not only in intrinsic aging but also in environmental and disease-related changes, providing a common mechanistic basis linking aging with increased disease risk and mortality.

theories.evidence: The abstract references multiple lines of evidence supporting the theory, including studies on the origin of life and evolution, effects of ionizing radiation, dietary manipulations affecting endogenous free radical reactions, explanations of aging phenomena, and studies implicating free radicals in disease pathogenesis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging applicable at the organism level, addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases or organs, and provides an organizing principle for aging and related diseases.

results.title: Genetic basis of longevity and age-related diseases : evidence from genetic association studies

theories.name: Genetic basis of longevity and aging theory

key_concepts.description: Genetic makeup influences the style of growth, metabolism, and adaptation to the environment, which in turn affects aging and longevity. Genetic variation among species and individuals shapes metabolic pathways and phenotypes related to aging.

Aging is a complex, multifactorial phenotype influenced by both biological and non-biological factors. Genetic factors play a prime role but interact with other influences such as diet and environment.

The clustering of centenarians in families and lifespan plasticity observed in model organisms through genetic manipulation and dietary interventions support the idea that aging is modulated by genetic factors.

theories.evidence: Citations of genetic association studies, observations of familial clustering of longevity, experimental data from genetic manipulations and diet in model organisms
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging based on genetic mechanisms affecting organism-level aging processes. It addresses aging broadly, not limited to specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Effect of resveratrol and pterostilbene on aging and longevity.

theories.name: Polyphenol modulation of aging hallmarks theory

key_concepts.description: Resveratrol and pterostilbene act as antioxidants that reduce oxidative stress, a key contributor to cellular and molecular damage during aging.
These polyphenols have anti-inflammatory effects that may counteract chronic low-grade inflammation, which is implicated in aging and age-related diseases.
Resveratrol and pterostilbene may help maintain telomere length or reduce telomere shortening, thereby potentially delaying cellular senescence and organismal aging.
The compounds influence cellular senescence processes, which are causal drivers of aging and age-related pathologies.

theories.evidence: Summary of multiple studies showing beneficial effects of resveratrol and pterostilbene on oxidative stress, inflammation, telomere attrition, cellular senescence, lifespan extension, and age-related diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses mechanisms by which these compounds modulate fundamental aging hallmarks that are broadly implicated in organismal aging, thus addressing causal explanations and generalizable aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: [Advances in three important signaling pathways related to aging in Drosophila melanogaster and screening of anti-aging traditional Chinese medicine].

theories.name: AMP-Activated Protein Kinase (AMPK) Pathway Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: AMPK as an energy sensor influencing aging
key_concepts.description: AMPK is a cellular energy sensor that activates catabolic pathways and inhibits anabolic processes under low energy conditions. It is proposed to promote longevity by enhancing metabolic homeostasis, stress resistance, and autophagy, thereby modulating aging at the organismal level.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews data from Drosophila studies demonstrating the role of AMPK signaling in aging regulation and its potential as a target for anti-aging interventions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets the aging theory criteria by explaining a fundamental, causal mechanism of aging related to energy metabolism and systemic regulation.

theories.name: Insulin/Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IIS) Signaling Pathway Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: IIS pathway as a regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: The IIS pathway involves insulin and IGF-1 signaling that influences cellular metabolism, growth, and survival. It is proposed to modulate lifespan by regulating nutrient sensing and stress resistance mechanisms, thereby affecting the aging process at the organismal level.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews studies using Drosophila melanogaster as a model organism to understand the IIS pathway's role in aging, citing modern research linking this pathway to molecular mechanisms of aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining aging at the organism level through nutrient signaling pathways; it is broadly applicable beyond specific diseases or organs.

theories.name: mTOR Signaling Pathway Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: mTOR pathway as a central regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: The mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway integrates signals from nutrients, growth factors, and energy status to regulate cell growth, proliferation, and autophagy. Its modulation is proposed to influence aging by balancing anabolic and catabolic processes, affecting cellular and organismal longevity.

theories.evidence: The paper summarizes recent findings in Drosophila models that link mTOR signaling to aging mechanisms, highlighting its importance in the molecular regulation of lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Satisfies the criteria by providing a general, causal explanation of aging through a conserved signaling pathway affecting systemic aging processes.

results.title: Eusociality and the evolution of aging in superorganisms

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of caste-specific aging in eusocial insects

key_concepts.description: In eusocial colonies, queens monopolize reproduction, which leads natural selection to favor longer queen lifespans compared to workers. This reproductive skew creates differential selective pressures on lifespan between castes.
The timing of sexual offspring production in highly social colonies influences selection on lifespan, favoring queens that live longer to maximize reproductive output over time.

Traditional explanations emphasize that queens experience lower extrinsic mortality risks than workers, but this paper quantitatively shows that such risk differences are neither necessary nor sufficient alone to explain lifespan divergence.

Factors reducing reproductive skew, such as polygyny (multiple queens) and worker reproduction, diminish the lifespan divergence between queens and workers, highlighting the role of social organization in aging evolution.

theories.evidence: Quantitative mathematical models developed and analyzed to test classical verbal evolutionary aging theory explanations; comparison of effects of mortality risks and reproductive monopolization on lifespan divergence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general evolutionary mechanism explaining why and how aging patterns diverge in eusocial organisms, addressing fundamental aging processes at the organismal and colony level with causal explanations and broad scope.

results.title: Free radical theory of aging: view against the reliability theory.

theories.name: Reliability free radical theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Structural and functional hierarchy of living systems
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that living organisms have a hierarchical organization with a finite number of critical structures, termed supervisors, which are essential for system reliability and function.

key_concepts.concept: Stochastic age-related changes in supervisors due to free radicals
key_concepts.description: Age-related damage occurs randomly in these supervisors, primarily caused by oxygen free radicals produced as by-products of normal oxidative metabolism.

key_concepts.concept: Threshold values of reliability parameters and cooperativity
key_concepts.description: Biological systems exhibit cooperative interactions among processes, leading to threshold effects in the reliability of supervisors, which influence aging dynamics.

key_concepts.concept: Linking free radical damage accumulation to mortality kinetics
key_concepts.description: The theory explains how linear accumulation of free radical damage in supervisors can produce exponential increases in mortality rates with age, consistent with the Gompertz law.

The theory accounts for empirical correlations between maximum lifespan and metabolic factors across species and estimates potential lifespan limits, such as a 250-year potential for primates absent free radical damage.

key_concepts.concept: Chromosomes of neural postmitotic cells as supervisors
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that chromosomes in non-dividing neural cells act as critical supervisors whose damage accumulation drives aging.

theories.evidence: Theoretical reasoning linking free radical damage kinetics to mortality data patterns (Gompertz law), interspecies lifespan-metabolism correlations, and lifespan potential estimates; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining aging at organism level; connects free radical damage accumulation to systemic aging and mortality patterns; addresses broad aging phenomena beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Epigenetic Clock: Just a Convenient Marker or an Active Driver of Aging?

theories.name: Epigenetic Clock Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: A stochastic process involving global DNA hypomethylation, especially in highly methylated repeat sequences such as transposable elements, leading to random changes in DNA methylation patterns during aging.
Age-related hypermethylation of promoter CpG islands and hypomethylation of CpG-poor genes, which alter gene expression patterns and contribute to aging phenotypes.
Specific CpG methylation patterns correlate strongly with chronological age and can be used to predict biological age and mortality risk, reflecting underlying aging processes.

The epigenome undergoes gradual degradation due to genome damage and stress, but unlike DNA mutations, age-related epigenetic changes can be partially or fully reversed to a youthful state, suggesting a dynamic aging mechanism.

key_concepts.concept: Causal Role of Epigenetic Changes in Aging
key_concepts.description: Random and specific methylation changes increase transcriptional noise and alter gene expression, impairing tissue function and contributing causally to organismal aging and decline.

theories.evidence: Citations of strong evidence from various organisms showing epigenetic systems contribute to lifespan control; correlations of methylation patterns with age and mortality; mechanistic links between methylation changes and tissue dysfunction.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental, organism-level aging process via epigenetic mechanisms; proposes causal mechanisms (epigenetic drift and site-specific methylation changes) affecting aging; addresses broad aging phenomena beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Modeling long lifespans in eusocial insect populations

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of aging in eusocial insects

key_concepts.concept: Reduced extrinsic mortality in eusocial queens
key_concepts.description: The colony structure of eusocial insects protects the queen from external threats, lowering her extrinsic mortality risk, which classical evolutionary aging theories predict leads to increased lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Link between eusociality and longevity evolution
key_concepts.description: The evolution of eusocial behavior, characterized by division of labor and reproductive specialization, is closely connected to the evolution of extended lifespan, particularly in queens.

key_concepts.concept: Population structure effects on lifespan evolution
key_concepts.description: Different population structures (solitary, monogynous eusocial, polygynous eusocial) influence the evolution of lifespan, with eusocial structures favoring longer lifespans under certain migration and group benefit parameters.
The relative fitness of solitary versus eusocial strategies depends on progeny migration probabilities, with eusocial strategies dominating at intermediate migration rates and longer lifespans.

theories.evidence: Agent-based simulations and evolutionary modeling comparing fitness outcomes across solitary, monogynous eusocial, and polygynous eusocial population structures under varying parameters.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable evolutionary mechanism explaining why eusocial queens have extended lifespans, offers causal explanations linking extrinsic mortality and social structure to aging, and addresses aging at the organismal level in the context of evolutionary theory.

results.title: Comparative analysis of epigenetic aging clocks from CpG characteristics to functional associations

theories.name: Epigenetic clock theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: DNA methylation as a biomarker of biological aging
key_concepts.description: Epigenetic clocks use DNA methylation patterns at specific CpG sites to estimate biological age, reflecting the cumulative effect of aging processes across tissues and cells.
Different epigenetic clocks vary in their CpG site composition and show weak correlations with each other, indicating that they may capture distinct aspects or mechanisms of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Link between epigenetic alterations and mitochondrial dysfunction
key_concepts.description: The study finds co-expression modules related to mitochondrial function and shows that mitochondrial DNA depletion accelerates epigenetic age, suggesting a mechanistic connection between epigenetic changes and mitochondrial aging.

theories.evidence: Comparative analysis of 11 epigenetic clocks across multiple tissues and cells; transcriptional profiling in CD14+ monocytes; network analysis identifying co-expression modules; experimental data showing increased epigenetic age in mtDNA-depleted 143B cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general, organism-level aging mechanism (epigenetic changes), proposes causal links (epigenetic alterations linked to mitochondrial dysfunction), and synthesizes multiple clocks to understand aging broadly.

results.title: Experimentally reduced insulin/IGF-1 signalling in adulthood extends lifespan of parents and improves Darwinian fitness of their offspring

theories.name: Hyperfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that aging evolves because genes that promote reproduction and growth in early life become deleteriously overactive in late life, causing excessive biosynthesis and physiological hyperfunction that leads to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Suboptimal gene expression in late adulthood
key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by gene expression patterns that are optimized for early-life functions but become maladaptive when running at high levels in late adulthood, causing cellular and organismal dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Nutrient-sensing signaling pathways as modulators of aging
key_concepts.description: The insulin/IGF-1 nutrient-sensing pathway is evolutionarily conserved and its downregulation in adulthood can postpone aging and simultaneously improve Darwinian fitness, supporting the idea that excessive signaling contributes to aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental reduction of insulin/IGF-1 signaling via daf-2 RNAi in adult Caenorhabditis elegans extended lifespan, improved late-life reproduction, and increased offspring Darwinian fitness across multiple genotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging applicable at the organism level, explains why aging occurs via hyperfunction rather than damage accumulation, and is supported by experimental evidence testing its predictions.

theories.name: Classical energy trade-off theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Energy trade-offs between reproduction and survival
key_concepts.description: Aging evolves because organisms allocate limited energy resources between reproduction and somatic maintenance, leading to accumulation of unrepaired cellular damage over time.

key_concepts.concept: Damage accumulation as cause of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging results from the gradual build-up of unrepaired molecular and cellular damage due to insufficient maintenance caused by energy allocation trade-offs.

theories.evidence: The paper contrasts this classical theory with the hyperfunction theory and presents experimental data that contradict the classical theory’s prediction that energy trade-offs universally cause senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Although classical theory is a well-established aging theory, in this paper it is discussed mainly to contrast with the hyperfunction theory and is not the primary focus or newly tested mechanism.

results.title: Clownfishes are a genetic model of exceptional longevity and reveal molecular convergence in the evolution of lifespan

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of aging via extrinsic mortality

key_concepts.concept: Reduced extrinsic mortality leads to evolution of longevity
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that species experiencing lower rates of death from external causes (e.g., predation) tend to evolve longer lifespans because natural selection favors traits that enhance survival and reproduction over extended periods.

Clownfishes live in symbiosis with sea anemones that protect them from predators, effectively lowering their extrinsic mortality and thus providing an ecological context for the evolution of their exceptional longevity.

theories.evidence: Survey identifying clownfish species with lifespans over 20 years; genetic analyses comparing positively-selected genes in clownfishes, mole rats, and killifishes; evidence of convergent evolution in mitochondrial biogenesis pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general evolutionary mechanism explaining why longevity evolves in response to extrinsic mortality, proposes causal mechanisms, and applies broadly to organismal aging.

theories.name: Mito-nuclear balance theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial biogenesis and mito-nuclear interactions influence lifespan
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that coordination between mitochondrial and nuclear genomes (mito-nuclear balance) is crucial for cellular energy homeostasis and longevity, with disruptions contributing to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Positive selection on mitochondrial transcription termination factor (MTERF1)
key_concepts.description: MTERF1, involved in mitochondrial gene expression regulation, shows signs of positive selection in long- and short-lived species, indicating its role in lifespan evolution via mitochondrial function.

key_concepts.concept: Positive selection on Glutathione S-Transferase Kappa 1 (GSTK1)
key_concepts.description: GSTK1, an enzyme involved in detoxification and oxidative stress response, is under positive selection in multiple clades, suggesting its enzymatic function is important in lifespan modulation.

theories.evidence: Comparative transcriptome sequencing and positive selection scans in clownfishes, mole rats, and killifishes; homology modeling indicating enzymatic residues under selection.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a mechanistic explanation for aging related to mitochondrial function and genetic regulation, applicable broadly across species.

results.title: Protection from oxidative stress by enhanced glycolysis; a possible mechanism of cellular immortalization.

theories.name: Warburg Effect as a Mechanism Linking Metabolism and Aging

key_concepts.description: The Warburg effect describes the preference of cancer cells for glycolysis over oxidative phosphorylation even in the presence of oxygen, leading to metabolic reprogramming.

key_concepts.concept: Glycolysis Modulating Oxidative Stress and Cellular Lifespan
key_concepts.description: Enhanced glycolysis can reduce oxidative stress levels, thereby modulating cellular lifespan and potentially protecting cells from senescence.
The tumor suppressor p53 post-transcriptionally regulates phosphoglycerate mutase (PGM), linking metabolic control to cellular aging and stress responses.

theories.evidence: Experimental findings reported by the authors showing enhanced glycolysis reduces oxidative stress and modulates cellular lifespan; connection to p53 regulation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it proposes a metabolic mechanism influencing aging broadly via oxidative stress modulation, linking cancer metabolism to aging processes; however, it is somewhat novel and specific but framed as a general mechanism.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) and Oxidative Stress
key_concepts.description: ROS are chemically reactive molecules containing oxygen that can cause cellular damage. Oxidative stress occurs when ROS production exceeds the capacity of antioxidant defenses, leading to damage of cellular components, which contributes to aging and senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Causal Role of Oxidative Stress in Aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that accumulation of oxidative damage from ROS is a fundamental cause of biological aging at the organismal level, leading to cellular senescence and functional decline.

theories.evidence: The paper cites Harman's original free radical theory and recent findings supporting that protection from oxidative stress can increase lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a generalizable, causal explanation of aging mechanisms applicable at the organism level, addressing oxidative damage as a fundamental aging cause.

results.title: Modulation of cell death in age-related diseases.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging results from the gradual accumulation of damage caused by reactive oxygen species, which are chemically reactive molecules containing oxygen. These ROS cause irreversible damage to DNA, proteins, and lipids over time, impairing cellular function.
As ROS accumulate, cells lose their ability to maintain homeostasis due to oxidative damage, which overwhelms the antioxidant defense systems designed to neutralize ROS.
The accrued molecular damage can trigger programmed cell death pathways such as apoptosis and autophagy, which are critical in the aging process and the development of age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The abstract references current understanding and hypotheses, citing the role of ROS-induced damage and the involvement of apoptosis and autophagy in aging and age-related diseases such as cancer, Alzheimer's, and Parkinson's disease.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organism level through oxidative damage and cellular death pathways. It addresses aging broadly and links molecular damage to systemic aging processes.

results.title: Evolution of age-specific decline in stress phenotypes is driven by both antagonistic pleiotropy and mutation accumulation

theories.name: Antagonistic Pleiotropy Theory

key_concepts.description: This theory posits that some genes have beneficial effects early in life but detrimental effects later, leading to trade-offs that drive aging as a consequence of selection favoring early-life benefits.

key_concepts.concept: Age-related decline due to genetic trade-offs
key_concepts.description: The decline in stress tolerance and other phenotypes with age is partly caused by genes whose effects shift from positive to negative across the lifespan.

theories.evidence: Novel test calculating additive effects of polymorphisms across ages showing support for AP mechanisms in age-related decline of stress phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: provides a causal explanation for aging via genetic trade-offs, generalizable to organismal aging, and addresses broad aging mechanisms.

theories.name: Mutation Accumulation Theory

key_concepts.description: This theory proposes that mutations with deleterious effects that manifest later in life accumulate in populations because natural selection is weaker at older ages, leading to age-related decline in physiological functions.
The theory predicts that the genetic variants influencing traits will have increasing negative effects as organisms age, contributing to the deterioration of stress response phenotypes.

theories.evidence: Association mapping of polymorphisms affecting stress response phenotypes across ages; observed decline in cold stress survival and starvation resistance consistent with MA predictions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains why aging occurs via accumulation of late-acting deleterious mutations, generalizable to organismal aging, proposes causal mechanisms, and addresses broad aging processes.

results.title: Estrogen-related receptor agonism reverses mitochondrial dysfunction and inflammation in the aging kidney

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction and inflammation as drivers of age-related kidney dysfunction

key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with a decline in mitochondrial function, which impairs cellular energy metabolism and contributes to organ dysfunction, including the kidney.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammation as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Chronic low-grade inflammation increases with age and promotes tissue damage and functional decline, mediated in part by signaling pathways such as cGAS-STING and STAT3.
ERRs are nuclear hormone receptors that regulate mitochondrial biogenesis and function; their decreased expression in aging kidneys contributes to mitochondrial dysfunction and inflammation.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation of aging phenotypes by ERR agonism
key_concepts.description: Pharmacological activation of ERRs reverses mitochondrial dysfunction, inflammation, and kidney damage markers in aged mice, suggesting ERRs as causal modulators of aging processes in the kidney.

theories.evidence: Experimental treatment of aged mice with a pan-ERR agonist reversed age-related albuminuria, podocyte loss, mitochondrial dysfunction, and inflammatory cytokines; STING inhibitor treatment also reversed inflammation and mitochondrial gene expression changes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism linking mitochondrial dysfunction and inflammation mediated by ERRs to systemic aging-related kidney decline; it addresses general aging processes (mitochondrial decline and inflammation) with mechanistic insight and intervention evidence.

results.title: Autophagy-dependent gut-to-yolk biomass conversion generates visceral polymorbidity in agingC. elegans

theories.name: Hyperfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging results from the persistent activity of biological functions that are beneficial during early life or reproduction but become deleterious when they continue unchecked in later life, causing senescent pathologies.
In C. elegans, autophagy converts intestinal biomass into yolk, which leads to visceral pathologies such as intestinal atrophy and yolky lipid accumulation, contributing to aging-related morbidity.
IIS promotes reproduction and activates gut-to-yolk biomass conversion, linking a well-known aging regulatory pathway to hyperfunction-driven senescent pathologies.

theories.evidence: Experimental inhibition of intestinal autophagy or vitellogenesis rescues visceral pathologies and extends lifespan in C. elegans; activation of IIS promotes these pathologies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining aging as a fundamental process driven by hyperfunction of biological programs, with organism-level implications and mechanistic insights.

results.title: Insights into mortality patterns and causes of death through a process point of view model

theories.name: Process Point of View Model of Mortality and Vitality

key_concepts.description: Vitality represents an organism's capacity to survive challenges. Aging and mortality are modeled as the loss of this vitality over time due to both distal (long-term) and proximal (immediate) factors.

Distal factors define the age-related evolution of vitality, shaping how vitality changes over the lifespan, while proximal factors represent the probability distribution of challenges that can cause mortality events.

The immune system is conceptualized as having two vitality streams: one representing immune system development (increasing vitality) and the other representing immunosenescence (vitality dissipation). This duality links immune function directly to mortality patterns.
Mortality is partitioned into juvenile extrinsic mortality, adult extrinsic mortality, and intrinsic adult mortality, each defined by different challenge types and vitality states.

The model explains the 20th-century epidemiological transition primarily as a reduction in extrinsic mortality due to a shift from high magnitude disease challenges to low magnitude stress challenges, alongside a gradual reduction in immunosenescence-related intrinsic mortality.

theories.evidence: Model parameters derived from extensive Swedish mortality data (1751-2010) showing biologically meaningful correlations with economic, health, and cause-of-death patterns; conceptual linkage to hallmarks of aging and immune system dynamics.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the model proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging and mortality at the organism level, linking biological mechanisms (immune system vitality and immunosenescence) to mortality patterns; addresses broad aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Long-lived rodents reveal signatures of positive selection in genes associated with lifespan and eusociality

theories.name: Antagonistic pleiotropy theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Pleiotropic genes with beneficial early-life effects but detrimental late-life effects
key_concepts.description: This theory proposes that certain genes have effects that enhance fitness or survival early in life but cause aging-related decline or damage later in life, leading to senescence as a trade-off.
The theory explains aging as a result of evolutionary pressures favoring traits that improve reproductive success at the cost of longevity, thus aging is an indirect consequence of natural selection.

theories.evidence: Genomic and transcriptomic data from 17 rodent species showing positively selected genes linked to longevity; gene expression patterns during aging in long-lived naked mole-rats and short-lived rats fitting the antagonistic pleiotropy pattern.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains why aging occurs at organismal level via evolutionary mechanism; proposes causal explanation (trade-offs in gene function); addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Ageing mechanisms and associated lipid changes.

theories.name: Programmed Aging Theories (including genetically programmed senescence, telomere shortening, epigenetic alterations)

key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that aging is driven by genetic programs that regulate lifespan and cellular senescence, leading to a programmed decline in tissue function.
Telomeres shorten with each cell division, eventually triggering cellular senescence or apoptosis, contributing to organismal aging.
Changes in epigenetic patterns such as heterochromatin loss and altered DNA methylation affect gene expression and genomic stability, influencing aging processes.

theories.evidence: The abstract references these models as part of the broader discussion of aging mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as these models propose fundamental, organism-level mechanisms explaining aging.

theories.name: DNA Damage and Repair Theory

key_concepts.description: This theory suggests that accumulation of DNA damage and the decline in repair mechanisms lead to cellular dysfunction and aging at the organismal level.

theories.evidence: Mentioned as a key theory alongside others, with reference to DNA damage accompanying somatopause.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental cause of aging through genomic instability.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This theory proposes that aging results from the accumulation of damage caused by free radicals, which are reactive oxygen species that damage DNA, proteins, and lipids over time, leading to cellular dysfunction.

theories.evidence: The abstract mentions the free radical theory as one of several overlapping theories considered in the review, citing its role in macromolecule damage associated with aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging based on damage accumulation applicable at the organism level.

theories.name: Mitochondrial Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: This theory suggests that aging is driven by progressive mitochondrial damage and dysfunction, leading to decreased energy production and increased generation of reactive oxygen species, which further damage cellular components.

theories.evidence: Mentioned as one of the overlapping theories explaining aging mechanisms, linked to somatopause and physiological decline.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it explains a fundamental biological process underlying aging at the organism level.

theories.name: Glycation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This theory posits that aging results from the accumulation of glycated proteins and lipids, which impair cellular function and contribute to tissue stiffness and dysfunction.

theories.evidence: Listed among the several overlapping theories considered in the review.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a biochemical mechanism contributing to systemic aging.

results.title: OPTIMALITY THEORY, GOMPERTZ' LAW, AND THE DISPOSABLE SOMA THEORY OF SENESCENCE.

theories.name: Disposable Soma Theory of Senescence

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that organisms optimally balance resource investment between reproduction and somatic repair. Limited resources mean that increased reproduction diverts resources away from repair, leading to accumulation of damage and senescence.
Senescence evolves as a result of natural selection favoring an optimal strategy that maximizes fitness by balancing reproduction and maintenance costs, rather than perfect somatic maintenance.

The theory predicts specific shapes of mortality curves with age, including an increasing mortality rate due to accumulated damage from reduced repair investment. The model suggests mortality may increase exponentially (Gompertz' Law) or approach linearity at high mortality levels.

theories.evidence: Dynamic programming models constructed and analyzed to explore optimal trade-offs and resulting mortality curves; comparison with empirical mortality patterns such as Gompertz' Law and its exceptions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it is a generalizable evolutionary theory explaining why aging occurs via resource allocation trade-offs, proposes causal mechanisms for senescence, and addresses aging broadly at the organismal level.

results.title: [Chronic inflammation and organismal aging].

theories.name: Chronic inflammation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that persistent, low-level inflammation (inflammaging) contributes causally to the progressive functional decline observed in aging tissues and increased mortality. This inflammation is characterized by elevated inflammatory cytokines and autoantibodies even in healthy aged individuals.

Aged immune systems exhibit altered regulation that leads to chronic inflammation, which in turn promotes aging and age-related diseases. Proper regulation of immune responses may therefore slow organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammation as a common background for age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: Chronic inflammation is proposed as a unifying mechanism underlying many age-associated diseases, linking immune system changes to systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: Correlations between autoantibody presence, inflammatory cytokine levels, and age in healthy individuals; literature citing chronic inflammation as a background for age-related diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (chronic inflammation) underlying organismal aging, applicable broadly beyond specific diseases or organs, and attempts to explain why aging occurs at the organismal level.

results.title: Biological insight, high-throughput datasets and the nature of neuro-degenerative disorders.

theories.name: Idiopathic neuro-degenerative disease hematopoietic stem-cell ageing theory

key_concepts.concept: Hematopoietic stem-cell ageing as a driver of neurodegeneration
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that the aging of hematopoietic stem cells contributes causally to the development of idiopathic neurodegenerative diseases. It suggests a systemic aging mechanism where stem cell dysfunction impacts neurological health.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of biological insight with high-throughput data
key_concepts.description: The theory emphasizes the importance of combining biological understanding with large-scale data analysis to uncover mechanisms underlying neurodegenerative disorders, moving beyond purely data-driven approaches.

theories.evidence: The abstract mentions efforts in developing this theory, implying some experimental or analytical work, but specific data or experiments are not detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (stem cell aging) as a causal mechanism contributing to systemic aging effects (neurodegeneration), thus meeting the criteria of generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope.

results.title: Systemic extracellular acidification is a hallmark of aging

theories.name: Systemic extracellular acidification theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Extracellular acidification as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that a progressive decrease in extracellular pH (acidification) occurs systemically during aging, which correlates with increased mortality and susceptibility to acidotic stress.

Aging leads to downregulation of genes responsible for acid-base regulation and ATP production in excretory organs (e.g., fly excretory tract, mouse kidneys), resulting in insufficient acid elimination and systemic acid-base imbalance.
The acidification process is conserved across species (flies and mice), suggesting a fundamental biological aging mechanism linked to dysregulated systemic acid-base homeostasis.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from fly and mouse models showing age-dependent extracellular acidification, gene expression changes in acid-base regulatory pathways, correlation with mortality rates, and rescue of acidotic stress susceptibility by alkalotic treatment.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining systemic aging processes through acid-base imbalance, supported by cross-species evidence and mechanistic gene expression data.

results.title: [The reversible share of cognitive deficits in older adults].
Effect of aging on glutathione metabolism. Protection by antioxidants.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxygen free radicals as causal agents
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that reactive oxygen species (ROS), or oxygen free radicals, cause cumulative damage to cellular components, leading to the aging process at the organismal level.
Antioxidant mechanisms, such as glutathione metabolism, protect cells from oxidative damage. Changes or declines in these systems with age may contribute to increased oxidative stress and aging.
Administering antioxidants to older organisms may mitigate some aging-related changes by enhancing the capacity to neutralize free radicals, thus potentially slowing aging processes.

theories.evidence: Experiments described in the paper show involvement of glutathione in aging and provide rationale for antioxidant administration to old organisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a general causal mechanism (oxidative damage by free radicals) underlying aging, is generalizable beyond specific organs or diseases, and discusses mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Psychosocial theories of aging: a critical evaluation.

theories.name: Activity theory

key_concepts.description: This theory posits that maintaining activities and social interactions leads to higher life satisfaction and better psychosocial aging outcomes.
It suggests that older adults who continue roles similar to those in earlier life stages experience better adjustment to aging.

theories.evidence: Summary and evaluation of existing research showing lack of clear empirical support.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets psychosocial aging theory criteria as it attempts to explain general psychosocial aging processes, but the paper finds it lacks empirical adequacy and testability.

theories.name: Continuity theory

key_concepts.description: Suggests that older adults strive to maintain internal and external continuity by adapting strategies connected to their past experiences.
Maintaining continuity in activities, relationships, and self-concept promotes better psychosocial adjustment to aging.

theories.evidence: Evaluation of empirical studies showing inconclusive support.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Addresses general psychosocial aging mechanisms but is critiqued for lack of intersubjectivity, testability, and empirical adequacy.

theories.name: Disengagement theory

key_concepts.description: Proposes that aging involves a mutual withdrawal between the aging individual and society, which is considered a natural and acceptable process.
Suggests that reducing social roles and interactions is beneficial for both the individual and society during aging.

theories.evidence: Analysis of relevant research indicating lack of clear empirical support.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Qualifies as a psychosocial aging theory explaining general aging processes, but the paper highlights problems with testability and empirical adequacy.

results.title: The Lag of the Proliferative Aging Clock Underlies the Lifespan-Extending Effect of Calorie Restriction.

theories.name: Proliferative Aging Clock Theory based on Bioenergetics

key_concepts.description: A novel concept proposing that the rate of aging is governed by a bioenergetics-dependent clock linked to the rate of cell division. This clock operates via programmed, proliferative-dependent, and stepwise bioenergetic decline, meaning that aging progresses as cells divide and bioenergetic capacity diminishes.

Calorie restriction (CR) and CR-mimetic factors extend lifespan by slowing the rate of cell division. This slowdown is due to a shortage of 'construction materials' necessary for cell mass doubling during replication, effectively putting a brake on the aging program controlled by the proliferative aging clock.

key_concepts.concept: Aging as a Programmed, Bioenergetics-Dependent Process
key_concepts.description: Aging is viewed as a programmed process regulated by bioenergetic decline linked to cell proliferation. The theory suggests that manipulating bioenergetics and cell division rates can modulate aging and lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Distinction Between Natural Aging and CR Effects
key_concepts.description: The mechanism by which CR extends lifespan is distinct from the mechanism of natural aging. Therefore, CR's life-extending effects do not directly provide a radical remedy for senescence but can still lead to lifespan extension.

To achieve healthy and potentially unlimited life extension, gene expression must be reprogrammed so that bioenergetic levels in cells either remain stable after division (halting aging) or increase (leading to rejuvenation).

theories.evidence: Analysis of empirical scientific data concerning aging and bioenergetics; conceptual development of the proliferative aging clock; references to known effects of calorie restriction and CR-mimetic factors on lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs at the organism level via a bioenergetics-dependent proliferative clock. It addresses aging broadly, not limited to specific organs or diseases, and provides a mechanistic explanation for lifespan extension by CR and related factors.

results.title: The spin-trap N-tert-alpha-phenyl-butylnitrone prolongs the life span of the senescence accelerated mouse.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Free radicals as causal agents of aging
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that reactive oxygen species (free radicals) cause oxidative damage to cellular components, which accumulates over time and leads to aging and age-related degenerative diseases.
The progressive accumulation of oxidative damage to biomolecules such as DNA, proteins, and lipids impairs cellular function and contributes to the aging process.
Spin traps like N-tert-alpha-phenyl-butylnitrone (PBN) can quench reactive free radicals, reducing oxidative damage and thereby potentially extending lifespan.

theories.evidence: Experimental intervention using the spin trap PBN in senescence accelerated mice (SAM-P8) showed a significant extension of mean lifespan compared to controls, supporting the theory.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging applicable at the organism level, explains why aging occurs via oxidative damage from free radicals, and is tested experimentally in a mammalian aging model.

results.title: Oxygen-induced mitochondrial damage and aging.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging Integrated with Mitochondrial Damage and Cell Differentiation

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by damage caused by oxygen-derived free radicals (oxy-radicals) to mitochondrial membranes and mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). This damage accumulates over time, impairing mitochondrial function.

Only irreversibly differentiated cells (e.g., neurons) accumulate aging changes because their mitochondria cannot be rejuvenated through organelle division, unlike cells capable of renewal, explaining differential aging among cell types.
Damage to mtDNA blocks mitochondrial population renewal, causing a decline in cellular energy production, which ultimately leads to cellular senescence and death, contributing to organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Integration with Classic Concepts of Cell Differentiation and Metabolic Rate
key_concepts.description: The theory synthesizes the free radical theory with Minot’s idea that cell differentiation triggers senescence and Pearl’s concept that metabolic rate paces aging, providing a broader framework for understanding aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: The paper references prior views by Harman and Gerschman on free radicals, classic concepts by Minot and Pearl, and provides a mechanistic explanation linking mitochondrial damage to aging; no new experimental data is presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organism level, integrates evolutionary and cellular mechanisms, and addresses differential aging across cell types.

results.title: Increase of oxidation and inflammation in nervous and immune systems with aging and anxiety.

theories.name: Oxidation-Inflammation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: A persistent state characterized by elevated levels of oxidant compounds and reduced antioxidant defenses, leading to cellular and tissue damage that impairs organismal functions.
Sustained inflammatory responses driven by increased inflammatory compounds and decreased anti-inflammatory defenses, contributing to systemic dysfunction and aging.

Oxidation and inflammation are interconnected processes with multiple feedback loops, where oxidants can trigger inflammation, and inflammation can further increase oxidative stress, jointly driving aging.
Age-related oxidative-inflammatory stress disrupts the communication between nervous and immune systems, leading to altered homeostasis, increased morbidity, and mortality.

key_concepts.concept: Anxiety as a chronic oxidative-inflammatory state accelerating aging
key_concepts.description: Anxiety induces oxidative and inflammatory stress particularly in brain and immune cells, promoting immunosenescence and shortening lifespan, thus accelerating aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of prior studies supporting the theory; discussion of a mouse model exhibiting premature aging with anxiety, oxidative stress, immunosenescence, and reduced lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains aging as a fundamental organism-level process via oxidative and inflammatory mechanisms; proposes causal mechanisms; addresses broad aging phenomena including nervous and immune systems; not limited to specific diseases.

results.title: Successful aging: choosing wisdom over despair.

theories.name: Erikson's Developmental Theory of Integrity/Wisdom

key_concepts.description: In late life, individuals strive to achieve a sense of integrity, reflecting a coherent and accepting view of their life and experiences.
Wisdom emerges as a developmental achievement when older adults successfully reconcile life’s challenges and losses, leading to psychological well-being.

theories.evidence: The abstract references Erikson's theory as a theoretical basis but does not present new data or testing.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as a psychosocial aging theory explaining why and how aging occurs at a general organism-level scale through developmental stages and psychological mechanisms.

theories.name: Conscious Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Integration of conditions of old age
key_concepts.description: This concept involves the ability of cognitively intact older adults to consciously integrate the various challenges and changes associated with aging, leading to a more adaptive and positive aging experience.

Older adults face a psychological choice in how they respond to aging, either achieving wisdom through acceptance and integration or falling into despair by resisting or failing to integrate these changes.

theories.evidence: The abstract references theoretical exploration and constructs of personality but does not mention empirical data or experiments.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain psychosocial aging at a general level, proposing mechanisms (choices and integration) that influence aging outcomes broadly in older adults.

results.title: A new interpretative paradigm for Conformational Protein Diseases.

theories.name: Red Queen Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The Red Queen Theory posits that organisms must continuously adapt and evolve not just for reproductive advantage but to maintain their existence against ever-evolving opposing organisms or internal challenges, such as pathogens or molecular dysfunctions. This ongoing evolutionary struggle can drive aging processes as a byproduct of adaptation.

The paper introduces the concepts of mis-exaptation and mis-tinkering to explain how proteins that have physiological roles can become pathogenic through evolutionary repurposing or imperfect evolutionary modifications. These concepts suggest that aging-related diseases may arise from evolutionary compromises or errors in protein function.

key_concepts.concept: Conformational Protein Diseases as aging-related phenomena
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of misfolded proteins with altered conformations that resist degradation and aggregate is framed within the Red Queen Theory to explain why such potentially harmful proteins persist evolutionarily and contribute to aging-related pathologies.

theories.mode: discuss, propose (new interpretative paradigm within the frame of Red Queen Theory)
theories.evidence: The paper references over forty clinically diverse Conformational Protein Diseases and their shared molecular features, evolutionary conservation of proteins from yeast to humans, and introduces new conceptual frameworks (mis-exaptation, mis-tinkering) to interpret these phenomena within the Red Queen Theory context. No direct experimental data is presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain why aging-related protein misfolding diseases occur from an evolutionary and mechanistic perspective, proposing underlying causes and organizing principles applicable broadly to aging and organism-level processes.

results.title: Stability and accuracy of metamemory in adulthood and aging: a longitudinal analysis.
Neuroinflammation and ageing: current theories and an overview of the data.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.description: Aging is accompanied by a persistent, low-level pro-inflammatory state characterized by an up-regulation of inflammatory responses. This chronic inflammation is thought to contribute to many phenotypic characteristics of aging and age-related diseases.
The degree of inflammaging is partially under genetic control, indicating that genetic factors influence the extent and impact of chronic inflammation during aging.
Inflammaging is associated with common age-related diseases such as atherosclerosis, cancer, and Alzheimer’s disease, suggesting that inflammation is a causal driver of systemic aging and pathology.

theories.evidence: Citations of multiple studies showing phenotypic aging characteristics resulting from inflammaging and its association with age-related diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (chronic inflammation) underlying aging at the organism level, connects genetic and environmental factors, and links to systemic aging and diseases.

theories.name: Genetic determination of maximum lifespan potential (MLSP)

key_concepts.description: The maximum lifespan attainable by a species or individual is largely determined by genetic factors, as evidenced by mitochondrial DNA polymorphisms associated with longevity.
While genetics set the potential for lifespan, environmental and lifestyle factors interact with genetic predispositions to influence the aging process.

theories.evidence: References to evidence from multiple species linking mitochondrial DNA polymorphisms to longevity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental, organism-level aging process with a causal genetic basis and considers gene-environment interactions.

theories.name: Free radical theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging results from the accumulation of damage caused by free radicals (reactive oxygen species) generated during normal metabolism, leading to cellular and molecular dysfunction.

theories.evidence: Mentioned as one of the commonly shared theories addressed in the review, with references to studies supporting its role in aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (damage accumulation by free radicals) underlying aging at the organism level.

theories.name: Genetic, cellular, neuroendocrine, and immunological theories of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is influenced by genetic programs or mutations that regulate lifespan and senescence.
Cellular mechanisms such as senescence, apoptosis, and stem cell exhaustion contribute to aging.
Age-related changes in neuroendocrine regulation affect homeostasis and contribute to aging.
Decline in immune function and dysregulation contribute to increased susceptibility to disease and aging.

theories.evidence: The review addresses these theories as part of the current understanding of aging, citing multiple studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as these theories propose general causal mechanisms for aging at organism level, though discussed collectively and not in depth in abstract.

results.title: Expanding the scope of continuity theory. Application to gerontological nursing.

theories.name: Continuity Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that middle-aged and elderly adults adapt to aging-related changes by relying on their accumulated past experiences, decisions, and behaviors, which form the foundation for their current and future responses.

A holistic view of aging that integrates an individual's life history and continuity of self, emphasizing that aging is a process influenced by the continuity of psychological and social patterns over time.
Focuses on how individuals maintain internal and external structures by preserving consistency in their habits, preferences, and relationships as they age.

theories.evidence: The abstract references the application of Continuity Theory in clinical nursing practice to provide individualized care, implying use of existing psychosocial theory rather than new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general psychosocial mechanism explaining how aging individuals adapt over time, addressing aging broadly at the organism-level psychosocial scale with causal explanation of adaptation processes.

results.title: The nature and causes of ageing.

theories.name: Disposable Soma Theory

key_concepts.description: Organisms allocate limited resources between reproduction and maintenance/repair of somatic cells. The theory posits that natural selection favors investing fewer resources in somatic maintenance than would be required for indefinite survival, leading to aging.
Aging is explained as an evolutionary strategy shaped by natural selection, where the decline in maintenance is a consequence of prioritizing reproductive success over longevity.
The theory provides a broad framework to assess the relevance of various model organisms and mechanisms in studying aging, emphasizing the importance of organism-level considerations.

theories.evidence: References to recent evolutionary insights and the use of model organisms and cell systems to study mechanisms of aging within the framework of the disposable soma theory.
