MetR is thought to influence aging by altering methionine metabolism pathways, which affect oxidative stress, methylation reactions, and protein synthesis. These changes may reduce damage accumulation and improve cellular homeostasis, contributing to increased healthspan and lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Challenges and Modifiers of MetR Efficacy
key_concepts.description: The efficacy of MetR is modulated by factors such as gut microbiota activity, compensatory cysteine metabolism, and methionine transfer between cells. These factors can diminish the beneficial effects of MetR, highlighting complexity in its application to humans.

Due to practical challenges in implementing dietary MetR, novel approaches including small molecules, synthetic biotics, and xenotopic tools have been developed to mimic the effects of MetR. These mimetics aim to reproduce the beneficial metabolic effects without strict dietary adherence.

theories.evidence: Citations of lifespan extension and disease attenuation across multiple species; discussion of early-stage clinical trials of MetR mimetics; consideration of metabolic and microbiota factors influencing MetR efficacy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how dietary methionine influences fundamental aging processes across organisms. It addresses underlying metabolic pathways and systemic effects, not limited to a single organ or disease.

results.title: Two Types of Survival Curves of Different Lines of Progeric Mice.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular aging as driver of organismal aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the aging of an organism is fundamentally a consequence of the aging processes occurring within individual cells. This includes the decline in cellular function and viability over time.
Mutations causing progeria may reduce the lifespan of cells, leading to earlier cell death or dysfunction, which cumulatively contributes to organismal aging.
The transition of cells into a senescent state is accelerated by certain mutations, and this accumulation of senescent cells drives systemic aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: Comparative analysis of survival curves from multiple progeric mouse lines showing two distinct patterns; speculation based on observed mutations causing diverse cell malfunctions but converging on reduced cellular lifespan or accelerated senescence; references to previously published works supporting the link between cellular aging and organismal aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organism level, linking cellular senescence to systemic aging; addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases; provides a mechanistic hypothesis rather than mere description.

results.title: Enhancing Late-Life Survival and Mobility via Mitohormesis by Reducing Mitochondrial Calcium Levels.

theories.name: Mitohormesis theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The regulation of calcium ion levels within mitochondria influences cellular aging and fitness. Altering mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake can modulate lifespan and healthspan by affecting mitochondrial function.
A transient increase in ROS acts as a signaling mechanism that activates stress response pathways, promoting antioxidant defenses and mitochondrial maintenance, which contribute to longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Activation of conserved stress response pathways
key_concepts.description: Key transcription factors and kinases such as pmk-1 (p38 MAPK), daf-16 (FOXO), and skn-1 (NRF2) are activated by ROS signaling, leading to enhanced antioxidant defenses and preservation of mitochondrial integrity during aging.

key_concepts.concept: Trade-off between early-life survival and late-life longevity
key_concepts.description: Reducing mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake compromises early-life survival but extends lifespan and preserves mobility in later life, indicating a hormetic effect where mild stress induces beneficial adaptive responses.

theories.evidence: Genetic knockdown of mcu-1 in C. elegans reduces mitochondrial Ca2+ levels, extends lifespan, and preserves motility; pharmacological inhibition with mitoxantrone mimics these effects; live-cell imaging and biochemical assays demonstrate ROS increase and activation of stress pathways; similar effects observed in human fibroblasts.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process via mitochondrial Ca2+ regulation and ROS signaling, proposes causal mechanisms for aging and longevity, addresses organism-level aging, and is supported by experimental evidence in multiple models.

results.title: TOR2 plays the central role in rapamycin-induced lifespan extension in budding yeast.

theories.name: TOR signaling pathway theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: TOR as a central regulator of lifespan
key_concepts.description: The TOR protein, through its complexes TORC1 and TORC2, modulates key signaling pathways that influence cellular growth and metabolism, which in turn affect organismal lifespan. Inhibition of TOR activity, particularly by rapamycin, has been shown to extend lifespan across species.

key_concepts.concept: Differential roles of TOR paralogs in yeast aging
key_concepts.description: In budding yeast, two TOR paralogs exist: TOR1 and TOR2. While TOR1 has been extensively studied, TOR2's role in lifespan regulation is less understood. This theory posits that TOR2 is the primary mediator of rapamycin-induced lifespan extension, analogous to the single TOR gene in mammals.

key_concepts.concept: Rapamycin inhibition of TOR signaling as an anti-aging mechanism
key_concepts.description: Rapamycin binds to the FKBP12-rapamycin-binding domain of TOR proteins to inhibit their activity. This inhibition reduces TOR signaling, which is linked to slowed aging processes and increased lifespan, suggesting a causal mechanism for aging modulation.

theories.evidence: Experimental mutation of the FKBP12-rapamycin-binding domain in TOR2 that blocks rapamycin binding abolished lifespan extension effects of rapamycin, regardless of TOR1 status, indicating TOR2's essential role in mediating rapamycin's anti-aging effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains a fundamental aging process via TOR signaling, proposes a causal mechanism (TOR inhibition leading to lifespan extension), and is generalizable beyond yeast to mammals due to conserved TOR function.

results.title: Effects of Cu-Zn superoxide dismutase overexpression of life span and resistance to oxidative stress in transgenic Drosophila melanogaster.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) as causal agents
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that reactive oxygen species, such as superoxide anion radicals, cause molecular damage that accumulates over time, leading to aging at the organismal level.
Enzymes like copper-zinc superoxide dismutase (Cu-Zn SOD) mitigate oxidative damage by scavenging superoxide radicals, potentially influencing lifespan and resistance to oxidative stress.

theories.evidence: Experimental overexpression of Cu-Zn SOD in transgenic Drosophila melanogaster with measurements of lifespan and resistance to oxidative stress induced by paraquat and hyperoxia.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general, organism-level aging mechanism (oxidative damage), proposes a causal mechanism (ROS-induced molecular damage), and tests the effect of modulating a key enzyme involved in this process on lifespan and stress resistance.

results.title: Patchouli essential oil extends the lifespan and healthspan of Caenorhabditis elegans through JNK-1/DAF-16.

theories.name: JNK-1/DAF-16 signaling pathway as a modulator of aging

key_concepts.description: This pathway involves the c-Jun N-terminal kinase 1 (JNK-1) and the forkhead transcription factor DAF-16, which is a key regulator of longevity and stress resistance in Caenorhabditis elegans. Activation of JNK-1 leads to the nuclear translocation and activation of DAF-16, which then promotes the expression of genes involved in antioxidative defense, stress resistance, and lifespan extension.

The theory posits that modulation of the JNK-1/DAF-16 pathway can causally influence organismal aging by enhancing stress resistance, reducing reactive oxygen species (ROS), and improving physiological markers of aging such as lipid accumulation and reproductive output.

The study suggests that interventions targeting this pathway, such as treatment with patchouli essential oil and its component patchouli alcohol, can delay senescence and extend lifespan by upregulating antioxidative genes and proteins, thereby providing a mechanistic explanation for aging modulation.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from lifespan and healthspan assays in C. elegans, RNA-sequencing showing gene expression changes, stress resistance assays, mutant and transgenic strain analyses, network pharmacology, and molecular docking supporting the involvement of JNK-1/DAF-16 pathway.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (JNK-1/DAF-16 signaling) explaining how aging can be modulated at an organismal level, supported by experimental evidence in a model organism. The pathway is well-known to regulate general aging processes, not limited to a single organ or disease.

results.title: Redox-regulated signalling of adaptations to contractile activity in skeletal muscle: Implications for age-related muscle weakness.

theories.name: Redox Signalling Dysfunction Theory of Age-Related Muscle Weakness

key_concepts.concept: Redox signalling via reactive oxygen species (ROS)
key_concepts.description: ROS such as hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) act as signalling molecules that regulate mitochondrial biogenesis, stress responses, and metabolic regulation in skeletal muscle, rather than merely being harmful byproducts.

key_concepts.concept: Role of peroxiredoxins (Prdxs) in redox signalling
key_concepts.description: Peroxiredoxins, especially Prdx2, mediate redox relays by sensing physiological levels of H2O2 and initiating transcriptional programs that promote muscle adaptation to contractile activity.

With aging, elevated ROS levels coincide with diminished oxidation of Prdx2 during muscle contraction, indicating dysfunctional redox signalling that blunts the adaptive capacity of skeletal muscle, contributing to sarcopenia.
Maintaining a balanced redox state, rather than simply suppressing ROS, is critical for preserving muscle health and function across the lifespan.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from mouse models showing rapid oxidation of Prdx proteins during muscle contraction; transcriptomic analysis of human skeletal muscle myotubes confirming Prdx2's role in mitochondrial gene upregulation; observations of diminished Prdx2 oxidation in aged mouse muscle.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how impaired redox signalling contributes to systemic aging-related muscle weakness; it addresses a fundamental aging process (muscle adaptation decline) with mechanistic insights into redox biology and molecular mediators.

results.title: Whole organism aging: Parabiosis, inflammaging, epigenetics, and peripheral and central aging clocks. The ARS of aging.

theories.name: Systemic coordination theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Loose coordination of aging rates among cells and tissues
key_concepts.description: Although individual organs and cells age at different rates, there is a mechanism that loosely coordinates these rates across the organism to ensure a species-specific lifespan. This coordination is necessary to maintain overall organismal aging within species longevity margins.

key_concepts.concept: Extracellular and systemic factors regulating aging
key_concepts.description: Systemic factors such as damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs), mitochondrial DNA fragments, and vascular proteins circulate through the vascular system and influence aging processes across multiple organs, acting beyond cell-autonomous mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammaging as a systemic aging driver
key_concepts.description: Chronic low-grade inflammation (inflammaging) is proposed as a systemic mechanism that contributes to the coordination and progression of aging at the whole organism level.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic and aging clocks at multiple organizational levels
key_concepts.description: Epigenetic modifications and proposed aging clocks operate not only at the cellular level but also at tissue and brain levels, serving as integrative markers and possibly regulators of systemic aging.
Parabiosis studies, where circulatory systems of young and old animals are joined, provide experimental support for systemic factors influencing aging rates and coordination across the organism.

theories.evidence: Citations and discussion of heterochronic parabiosis experiments, known systemic factors (DAMPs, mitochondrial DNA fragments), inflammaging literature, and epigenetic aging clocks; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining how aging is coordinated at the organism level (generalizability), discusses causal systemic factors and mechanisms (causal explanation), and addresses aging broadly beyond single organs or diseases (scope).

results.title: Sitagliptin Extends Lifespan of Caenorhabditis elegans by Inhibiting Insulin/Insulin-Like Signaling and Activating Dietary Restriction-Like Signaling Pathways.

theories.name: Insulin/Insulin-like Signaling (IIS) Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: IIS pathway as a regulator of lifespan
key_concepts.description: The insulin/insulin-like signaling pathway modulates aging by regulating key transcription factors such as DAF-16/FOXO. Reduced IIS activity leads to increased lifespan and improved stress resistance in model organisms.
DAF-16/FOXO is a critical downstream effector of IIS that promotes expression of genes involved in stress resistance, metabolism, and longevity when IIS is inhibited.

theories.evidence: Lifespan assays in C. elegans treated with sitagliptin showed lifespan extension associated with inhibition of IIS and activation of DAF-16/FOXO, supported by gene expression analysis via GFP fluorescence and qPCR.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining aging at the organism level, involving conserved signaling pathways affecting systemic aging.

theories.name: Dietary Restriction (DR)-Like Signaling Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Dietary restriction, or reduced nutrient intake without malnutrition, activates conserved signaling pathways that enhance stress resistance and longevity across species.

key_concepts.concept: Activation of DR-related pathways by pharmacological agents
key_concepts.description: Certain compounds can mimic dietary restriction effects by activating similar molecular pathways, leading to lifespan extension and improved healthspan.

theories.evidence: Sitagliptin treatment activated dietary restriction-related signaling pathways in C. elegans, contributing to lifespan and healthspan extension, as shown by molecular assays and physiological measurements.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental aging mechanism with causal explanations applicable broadly across organisms.

theories.name: Mitochondrial Function-Related Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial function and signaling pathways regulate cellular energy metabolism and reactive oxygen species production, impacting aging and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation of mitochondrial pathways can extend lifespan
key_concepts.description: Interventions that improve mitochondrial function or activate mitochondrial stress responses can promote longevity and healthspan.

theories.evidence: The study found activation of mitochondrial function-related signaling pathways upon sitagliptin treatment, correlating with lifespan extension in C. elegans.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism influencing systemic aging through mitochondrial regulation.

results.title: Knockdown of neuronal DAF-15/Raptor promotes healthy aging in C. elegans.

theories.name: TORC1 pathway modulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: TORC1 as a regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: The Target of Rapamycin Complex 1 (TORC1) pathway is a conserved nutrient-sensing signaling pathway that influences lifespan across species. Inhibition of TORC1 activity has been shown to extend lifespan, suggesting it plays a causal role in aging regulation.

The theory posits that TORC1 activity in specific tissues, particularly neurons, can modulate systemic aging processes. Neuronal TORC1 inhibition during adulthood promotes longevity and healthspan, indicating spatiotemporal specificity in aging regulation.

Neuronal TORC1 inhibition requires intestinal transcription factors DAF-16/FOXO and PHA-4/FOXA, as well as AMPK (AAK-2), to mediate longevity effects. This suggests a mechanism where neuronal signals influence peripheral tissues to regulate organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental knockdown of neuronal DAF-15/Raptor in C. elegans using auxin-inducible degradation extends lifespan and healthspan; transcriptome profiling shows upregulation of protective genes; genetic dependency on intestinal transcription factors and AMPK demonstrated.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism of aging involving a conserved signaling pathway (TORC1), explains how aging is modulated at organismal level via tissue-specific regulation and cross-tissue signaling, and is not limited to a single disease or organ.

results.title: Apigenin enhancing oxidative resistance and proteostasis to extend lifespan via PTEN-mediated AKT signalling pathway.

theories.name: PTEN-mediated AKT signaling pathway theory of aging

key_concepts.description: PTEN acts as a hub target influencing lifespan by modulating downstream signaling pathways. Its expression level affects aging processes through regulation of AKT phosphorylation and related signaling cascades.

The phosphorylation state of AKT and its downstream effectors such as S6K and Foxo are critical in controlling cellular processes related to aging, including stress resistance and metabolic regulation.
Enhancement of antioxidant defenses, including reduction of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and upregulation of antioxidant enzymes, contributes to lifespan extension by mitigating damage accumulation.
Upregulation of proteostasis-related enzymes and gene expression supports maintenance of protein homeostasis, which is essential for cellular function and longevity.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from yeast and Drosophila models showing lifespan extension, improved oxidative stress resistance, modulation of PTEN expression, AKT phosphorylation, and downstream signaling changes; network analysis supporting PTEN as a hub target.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism involving PTEN and AKT signaling pathways that regulate aging at the organismal level, supported by mechanistic evidence and applicable across species.

results.title: Genetic stability and oxidative stress: common mechanisms in aging and cancer.

theories.name: Genetic instability theory of aging and cancer

key_concepts.concept: Genetic instability as a cause of aging and cancer
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that genetic instability, including both genetic and epigenetic changes, leads to cells losing their proper differentiated state, which contributes to aging and cancer development.

key_concepts.concept: Correlation between cancer rate and aging rate
key_concepts.description: There is a positive correlation observed between the rate of cancer and the rate of aging across different mammalian species, suggesting a shared underlying mechanism.
Oxidative stress is implicated as a factor that increases cancer frequency and is inversely related to lifespan, with longer-lived species exhibiting lower oxidative stress levels.

key_concepts.concept: Differential mechanisms for physiological aging and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: Despite the shared involvement of genetic instability in cancer and some age-related diseases, the paper proposes that physiological aging itself may not be caused by genetic instability, implying distinct mechanisms for aging and disease.

theories.evidence: Correlative data on cancer and aging rates in mammals, observations of cellular differentiation stability in longer-lived species, effects of food restriction on lifespan and cancer onset, and oxidative stress measurements.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain aging and cancer as related processes driven by genetic instability, proposing a causal mechanism with generalizability across species. However, it also distinguishes physiological aging from genetic instability-driven diseases, indicating a nuanced view. The theory addresses fundamental causes and mechanisms, not limited to specific organs or diseases alone.

results.title: Hypoxia-reoxygenation Extends the Lifespan of Caenorhabditis elegans via SKN-1- and DAF-16A-Dependent Stress Hormesis.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress-Induced Hormesis Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Hormesis refers to the biological phenomenon where exposure to a moderate level of stress induces an adaptive beneficial response that enhances the organism's resistance to subsequent, more severe stressors, thereby promoting health and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) as Signaling Molecules
key_concepts.description: Contrary to the traditional view of ROS solely as damaging agents, this concept posits that ROS act as important signaling molecules that trigger protective cellular pathways, leading to improved stress resistance and lifespan extension.

key_concepts.concept: Activation of Stress Response Pathways (SKN-1 and DAF-16)
key_concepts.description: The transcription factors SKN-1 and DAF-16, homologous to mammalian Nrf2 and FOXO3 respectively, mediate oxidative stress responses by upregulating target genes that enhance cellular defense mechanisms, which are crucial for the hormetic lifespan extension observed.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing that hypoxia-reoxygenation (H/R) extends lifespan in C. elegans; mutations in SKN-1 and DAF-16 block this effect; H/R activates these transcription factors and their target genes; antioxidant pre-treatment reduces ROS and abolishes lifespan extension.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how moderate oxidative stress induces adaptive responses that extend lifespan, supported by molecular pathways relevant to organismal aging.

results.title: mTOR as a senescence manipulation target: A forked road.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a tumor suppressor and aging pillar
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is a state of stable cell cycle arrest that acts as a tumor suppressor mechanism but also contributes to aging by accumulating senescent cells that affect tissue function.

The mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) is a central regulator of cell metabolism, proliferation, and survival, influencing cellular senescence through its role in maintaining homeostasis and responding to stress.

key_concepts.concept: Interplay between senescence, autophagy, and mTOR
key_concepts.description: mTOR modulates autophagy, which is involved in cellular quality control, and this interaction affects the development and maintenance of senescent phenotypes relevant to aging and age-associated diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review discussing extensive molecular and cellular mechanisms of mTOR in senescence, citing rapamycin’s lifespan extension effects across species and its pharmacological implications in age-related diseases and cancer.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental aging mechanism (cellular senescence) with causal explanations involving mTOR signaling, applicable broadly to organismal aging and age-associated diseases.

results.title: Lactobacillus brevis MTCC 1750 enhances oxidative stress resistance and lifespan extension with improved physiological and functional capacity in Caenorhabditis elegans via the DAF-16 pathway.

theories.name: Oxidative stress resistance theory of aging mediated by DAF-16 pathway

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) leads to redox imbalance, which contributes to age-related physiological decline and diseases. Resistance to oxidative stress is proposed as a key factor for longevity and healthy aging.

key_concepts.concept: DAF-16 transcription factor as a central regulator
key_concepts.description: DAF-16, a FOXO transcription factor homolog in C. elegans, regulates genes involved in stress resistance and longevity. Activation and nuclear translocation of DAF-16 upregulates antioxidant genes such as sod-3, enhancing oxidative stress resistance and extending lifespan.

The study highlights how dietary components, specifically Lactobacillus brevis MTCC 1750, can modulate signaling pathways that influence aging processes, demonstrating that diet can regulate organismal aging through molecular pathways.

theories.evidence: Experimental data using wild-type, mutant, and transgenic C. elegans strains showing that L. brevis MTCC 1750 reduces ROS accumulation, enhances oxidative stress resistance, prolongs lifespan, and upregulates DAF-16 target gene sod-3. Evidence also shows DAF-16 activation independent of DAF-2 or JNK pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (oxidative stress resistance via DAF-16) explaining how aging occurs and can be modulated at the organismal level. The theory addresses fundamental aging processes, not limited to a specific disease or organ, and provides mechanistic insight.

results.title: Pelota-mediated ribosome-associated quality control counteracts aging and age-associated pathologies across species.

theories.name: Ribosome-associated quality control (RQC) in aging

key_concepts.description: RQC is a biological process that ensures the fidelity of mRNA homeostasis and protein synthesis by rescuing stalled ribosomes and maintaining proteostasis. It acts as a quality control mechanism to prevent accumulation of defective proteins that can cause cellular dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Pelota as a ribosome rescue factor
key_concepts.description: Pelota is a key factor in RQC that promotes longevity and protects against age-related pathologies by facilitating ribosome rescue. It is essential for maintaining cellular function and preventing premature senescence across multiple species.

Pelota maintains proteostasis through autophagy by preventing hyperactivation of the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) signaling pathway, which is known to regulate aging and cellular metabolism. This mechanism helps counteract aging and age-associated diseases.

theories.evidence: Genetic screens in Caenorhabditis elegans demonstrating Pelota's necessity for longevity; experiments showing mitigation of premature senescence in human cells; mouse muscle aging models; cellular and organoid Alzheimer's disease models; mechanistic studies linking Pelota to autophagy and mTOR signaling.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging involving ribosome quality control and proteostasis, supported by cross-species evidence. It addresses aging broadly, linking molecular quality control to organismal aging and age-related pathologies, thus meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Itaconate prolongs the healthy lifespan by activating UPR<sup>mt</sup> in Caenorhabditis elegans.

theories.name: Mitochondrial unfolded protein response (UPRmt) theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that maintaining mitochondrial integrity is crucial for healthy aging. Damage or dysfunction in mitochondria leads to increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) and decreased energy production, contributing to aging.

The mitochondrial unfolded protein response (UPRmt) is a stress response pathway activated upon mitochondrial stress, which helps restore mitochondrial function by signaling to the nucleus to induce protective gene expression.

ATFS-1 is a transcription factor that senses mitochondrial stress and mediates communication between mitochondria and nucleus during UPRmt, coordinating the cellular response to maintain mitochondrial function and promote longevity.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing that itaconate extends lifespan and stress resistance in C. elegans in an ATFS-1-dependent manner; measurements of mitochondrial integrity, ATP content, and ROS levels; activation of UPRmt markers.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (UPRmt activation) explaining how mitochondrial maintenance influences organismal aging, with generalizability beyond a single tissue, and provides mechanistic insight into aging processes.

results.title: Of Mice, Whales, Jellyfish and Men: In Pursuit of Increased Longevity.
Robust assembly of electron transfer chain in the brain of naked mole-rats during aging.

theories.name: Mitochondrial robustness theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The ETC is a critical structural and functional component of mitochondria responsible for oxidative phosphorylation and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production. Robust assembly of ETC complexes and supercomplexes is proposed to maintain mitochondrial efficiency and reduce oxidative damage during aging.

Efficient oxidative phosphorylation supports cellular energy demands and reduces the generation of harmful ROS, which are implicated in aging and age-related pathologies. Preservation of this efficiency is linked to delayed aging phenotypes.

Reduced oxidative stress through maintained ETC integrity limits cellular damage accumulation, which is hypothesized to contribute to longevity and resistance to neurodegeneration and other age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Comparative analysis of ETC assembly in brains of young and old naked mole-rats versus C57BL/6 mice, showing preserved ETC assembly and supercomplex formation in aged naked mole-rats correlating with enhanced mitochondrial function and reduced oxidative stress.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (robust ETC assembly) explaining how aging is delayed systemically via mitochondrial function preservation, applicable broadly to organismal aging and longevity, not limited to a single disease or organ dysfunction.

results.title: Artemisia selengensis Turcz. leaf extract promotes longevity and stress resistance in Caenorhabditis elegans.

theories.name: Insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathway theory of aging

key_concepts.description: This theory posits that the insulin/insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) signaling pathway regulates lifespan and aging processes. Reduced signaling through this pathway activates downstream transcription factors that promote stress resistance and longevity.
DAF-16, a FOXO family transcription factor, is activated when insulin/IGF-1 signaling is reduced, leading to expression of genes involved in stress resistance, metabolism, and longevity.

theories.evidence: The paper reports that Artemisia selengensis leaf extract activates insulin/IGF-1 signaling and DAF-16/FOXO transcription factors in C. elegans, leading to increased lifespan and stress resistance.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process at organism level, proposes causal mechanisms (signaling pathways affecting longevity), and addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases or organs.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.description: This theory suggests that age-related decline in mitochondrial function leads to increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) production and cellular damage, contributing causally to aging.
Excessive ROS generated by dysfunctional mitochondria cause oxidative damage to cellular components, accelerating aging and reducing lifespan.

theories.evidence: The study shows that ASTE reduces intracellular ROS accumulation and modulates mitochondrial dysfunction pathways, correlating with increased lifespan and healthspan in C. elegans.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging involving mitochondrial decline and oxidative stress, applicable at organism level.

theories.name: SIR-2.1 (Sirtuin) signaling theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Sirtuins are NAD+-dependent deacetylases that regulate lifespan by modulating stress resistance, metabolism, and gene expression. Activation of SIR-2.1 in C. elegans is linked to longevity.

theories.evidence: The paper indicates that ASTE activates SIR-2.1 signaling, which contributes to lifespan extension and improved stress resistance in C. elegans.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it explains a general aging regulatory mechanism with causal influence on organismal aging.

results.title: Coniferaldehyde activates autophagy and enhances oxidative stress resistance and lifespan of Caenorhabditis elegans via par-4/aak-2/skn-1 pathway.

theories.name: AMPK-mediated autophagy and oxidative stress resistance theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: AMPK as a central regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) senses cellular energy status and regulates homeostasis, metabolism, stress resistance, cell survival, and autophagy, which are processes implicated in aging.

Activation of autophagy, a cellular degradation and recycling process, helps maintain cellular integrity and function, thereby contributing to increased lifespan and resistance to age-related decline.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress reduction as a mechanism of aging modulation
key_concepts.description: Reducing reactive oxygen species (ROS) and enhancing antioxidant defenses mitigates oxidative damage, which is a key factor in aging and age-related functional deterioration.
This signaling cascade integrates energy sensing and stress response pathways to regulate gene expression (e.g., gst-4) and autophagy-related genes (bec-1, lgg-1), mediating lifespan extension.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing that coniferaldehyde activates autophagy, reduces ROS, enhances antioxidant gene expression, and extends lifespan in C. elegans; genetic mutant analysis demonstrating dependence on AAK-2/AMPK pathway and SKN-1 nuclear localization.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking energy sensing, autophagy, and oxidative stress resistance to organismal aging; addresses fundamental aging processes at the organism level; provides mechanistic explanation rather than mere correlation.

results.title: Exploring age-related iron dysregulation: effects on longevity, body size, and behavior in C. elegans.

theories.name: Iron dysregulation as a causal mechanism of aging

key_concepts.description: Iron accumulates in organisms as they age, which impacts physiological processes broadly. This accumulation is proposed to influence systemic aging by disrupting iron homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Iron regulatory genes influence lifespan and aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Genes regulating iron uptake and homeostasis, such as smf-1, smf-3, and zipt-17, modulate longevity, mobility, body size, and behavior in C. elegans, suggesting iron regulation is a fundamental aging mechanism.

key_concepts.concept: Iron homeostasis affects multiple aging-related traits
key_concepts.description: Altered iron metabolism affects diverse organism-level traits including lifespan, mobility decline, body size changes, and sensory behavior, indicating a systemic role of iron regulation in aging.

theories.evidence: Lifespan assays of iron regulatory gene mutants, mobility and behavioral tests, gene expression analysis over lifespan, and iron accumulation staining (FerroOrange) in C. elegans.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (iron dysregulation) underlying aging at the organism level, supported by mechanistic genetic and phenotypic data, and addresses multiple aging traits beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: Making sense of the costs of adversity throughout the lifespan on aging in humans and other animals.
Is SIRT3 and Mitochondria a Reliable Target for Parkinson's Disease and Aging? A Narrative Review.

theories.name: Sirtuin-mediated regulation of aging and longevity

key_concepts.description: Sirtuins, particularly SIR2 and its homologs like SIRT3, are conserved deacetylase enzymes that regulate lifespan across multiple taxa including yeast, worms, and flies. Overexpression of SIR2 has been shown to extend lifespan, suggesting a fundamental role in aging control.

SIRT3 is a mitochondrial sirtuin that modulates reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels, thereby reducing oxidative stress within mitochondria. This regulation is linked to aging and age-related diseases, positioning SIRT3 as a key factor in mitochondrial maintenance and organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: SIRT3 in neurodegeneration and systemic aging
key_concepts.description: SIRT3 influences neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's by mitigating mitochondrial oxidative damage. Its broader involvement in metabolic and cardiovascular disorders suggests a systemic role in aging and disease pathophysiology.

theories.evidence: Citations of lifespan extension in model organisms via SIR2 overexpression; associations of SIRT3 with ROS regulation, neurodegenerative diseases, and metabolic disorders; narrative synthesis of existing literature.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process through conserved molecular regulators (sirtuins), proposes causal mechanisms (deacetylation affecting ROS and mitochondrial function), and addresses aging broadly across organisms and diseases, thus meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Association of α-Klotho with anti-aging effects of Ganoderma lucidum in animal models.

theories.name: α-Klotho-associated anti-aging mechanism

key_concepts.concept: α-Klotho protein as an anti-aging factor
key_concepts.description: α-Klotho exists in transmembrane and soluble forms and is implicated in regulating aging processes. Increased levels of α-Klotho are associated with improved tissue function and systemic anti-aging effects.

The traditional medicinal fungus Ganoderma lucidum (Gl-SBSP) enhances the expression of both transmembrane and soluble α-Klotho in kidney tissue and elevates soluble α-Klotho in serum and urine, suggesting a mechanism for its anti-aging effects.

Gl-SBSP treatment alleviates structural and functional decline in multiple organs (colon, spleen, kidneys, liver, small intestine) and improves physical performance and lifespan in animal aging models, linking α-Klotho modulation to systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from C. elegans lifespan and healthspan assays, multiple mouse aging models (natural, D-galactose-induced, radiation-induced), biochemical assays (Western blot, ELISA, RT-qPCR), and histopathological analyses demonstrating increased α-Klotho levels and improved aging phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (α-Klotho modulation) underlying systemic aging processes, supported by multi-organ and organism-level evidence, thus generalizable beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: Capsaicinoid-Glucosides of Fresh Hot Pepper Promotes Stress Resistance and Longevity in Caenorhabditis elegans.

theories.name: Stress resistance-mediated lifespan extension via DAF-16/FOXO and SKN-1/Nrf2 pathways

key_concepts.concept: Stress resistance as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that enhancing an organism's resistance to various stressors such as oxidative stress and heat can delay aging and extend lifespan. This is based on the idea that accumulation of damage from stress contributes causally to aging.

key_concepts.concept: DAF-16/FOXO and SKN-1/Nrf2 transcription factors as central regulators
key_concepts.description: These transcription factors regulate the expression of downstream genes involved in stress response and detoxification (e.g., sod-3, hsp-16.2, gst-4, gcs-1). Their activation promotes cellular defense mechanisms that mitigate damage accumulation, thereby slowing aging.

key_concepts.concept: Capsaicinoid-glucosides as modulators of aging pathways
key_concepts.description: Bioactive compounds from hot pepper can induce the activation of stress response pathways mediated by DAF-16 and SKN-1, leading to increased stress resistance and lifespan extension in C. elegans, suggesting a mechanistic link between dietary components and aging regulation.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing that treatment with capsaicinoid-glucosides increased lifespan and stress resistance in C. elegans; gene expression analysis (RT-PCR) demonstrating upregulation of daf-16, skn-1, and downstream target genes; use of different C. elegans strains to confirm dependence on these pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism for aging involving stress resistance pathways that are generalizable to organismal aging, not limited to a single organ or disease. It explains how aging can be modulated by genetic regulators and environmental factors (dietary compounds).

results.title: Model organism life extending therapeutics modulate diverse nodes in the drug-gene-microbe tripartite human longevity interactome.
Therapeutic potential of sirtuin-activating compounds in Alzheimer's disease.

theories.name: Sirtuin-mediated longevity and healthy aging theory

key_concepts.description: Sirtuins are NAD(+)-dependent class III histone deacetylases that regulate cellular functions by deacetylating histone and nonhistone proteins. Activation of sirtuins has been shown to extend lifespan and promote longevity across multiple species, suggesting a conserved role in aging regulation.

key_concepts.concept: Sirtuins as modulators of age-related neurodegeneration
key_concepts.description: Sirtuin activators protect against neurodegenerative processes such as axonal degeneration, poly-glutamine toxicity, and microglia-mediated amyloid beta toxicity, indicating their potential to delay or modify the progression of age-related diseases like Alzheimer's disease.
Sirtuins are evolutionarily conserved from bacteria to humans, implying a fundamental biological role in regulating aging and cellular homeostasis across organisms.

theories.evidence: The abstract references experimental findings in various species showing lifespan extension and neuroprotection by sirtuin activation, as well as protective effects in mammalian models of neurodegeneration. It also cites the evolutionary conservation of sirtuins.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how activation of sirtuins causally influences aging and longevity at an organismal level, proposing a fundamental mechanism conserved across species. It addresses aging broadly, linking molecular mechanisms to systemic aging and age-related disease, thus meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Telomeres and their role in aging and longevity.

theories.name: Telomere attrition theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Telomeres are DNA-protein structures that protect chromosome ends from degradation and maintain genomic integrity, preventing loss of genetic information during cell division.
Telomere length varies widely among individuals, tissues, and species, and generally shortens with chronological age, suggesting a link between telomere dynamics and the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Accelerated telomere shortening and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: Increased telomere loss, potentially driven by oxidative stress and DNA damage, is associated with premature cellular senescence and many chronic diseases of aging, implying a causal role in systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Heritability and sex differences in telomere length
key_concepts.description: Telomere length is highly heritable and tends to be longer in women than men, indicating genetic and possibly hormonal influences on aging mechanisms mediated by telomeres.

theories.evidence: Summary of current research findings linking telomere biology to aging and longevity, including associations with chronic diseases and cellular senescence; mentions scientific disagreements and controversial results.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining aging at the organism level through telomere dynamics; addresses systemic aging rather than a narrow phenomenon; discusses underlying causes and mechanisms.

results.title: Transcription Factor Nrf2 and Mitochondria - Friends or Foes in the Regulation of Aging Rate.

theories.name: Nrf2-mitochondria regulatory loop theory of aging rate

key_concepts.concept: Nrf2 as master regulator of antioxidant systems
key_concepts.description: Nrf2 is a transcription factor that controls cellular antioxidant defenses, influencing redox balance and protecting cells from oxidative damage, which is implicated in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondria as sources and regulators of ROS and metabolism
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) but also regulate cellular metabolism and signaling; their function and quality control impact aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Mutual regulatory loops between Nrf2 and mitochondria
key_concepts.description: Nrf2 activity affects mitochondrial dynamics and quality control, while mitochondrial proteins and mtDNA-encoded peptides influence Nrf2 activity, forming feedback loops that fine-tune cellular redox and metabolic homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of nuclear and mitochondrial signaling in aging regulation
key_concepts.description: Interactions between nuclear genome-encoded mitochondrial proteins, mtDNA-encoded peptides, and Nrf2 link cellular homeostasis maintenance and oxidative stress responses, impacting aging rate and lifespan.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing Nrf2's positive effects on mitochondrial dynamics and quality control; discovery of mtDNA-encoded peptides interacting with nuclear regulatory systems including Nrf2; cited literature on regulatory loops and redox balance.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how cellular redox regulation and mitochondrial function interplay to influence aging rate at the organismal level; it addresses fundamental aging processes beyond narrow phenomena.

results.title: Oxidative Stress & FoxO Transcription Factors in Cardiovascular Aging.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that the accumulation of oxidative damage caused by reactive oxygen species (ROS) leads to functional decline and aging at the organismal level. Oxidative stress damages cellular components such as DNA, proteins, and lipids, contributing to metabolic disorders and inflammation that underlie aging processes.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews 46 peer-reviewed studies, including recent research and reviews, that investigate oxidative stress in cardiovascular aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (oxidative damage) underlying aging, applicable broadly beyond cardiovascular system, and explains why aging occurs.

theories.name: FoxO Transcription Factor Anti-Aging Signaling Theory

key_concepts.concept: FoxO proteins as regulators of anti-aging pathways
key_concepts.description: FoxO transcription factors regulate gene expression programs that promote stress resistance, metabolic homeostasis, and longevity. Their activity modulates cellular responses to oxidative stress and inflammation, thereby influencing aging processes, particularly in the cardiovascular system.

theories.evidence: The paper synthesizes findings from multiple studies highlighting the role of FoxO proteins in cardiovascular aging and anti-aging signaling.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a mechanistic explanation of aging regulation at the organismal level via conserved transcription factors affecting systemic aging processes.

results.title: Role of Mitochondrial DNA in Yeast Replicative Aging.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Mitochondria are among the most vulnerable cellular systems during aging across diverse species, including metazoa and fungi. Their dysfunction is implicated as a key factor in the aging process.
In yeast replicative aging, mitochondria are asymmetrically distributed between mother and daughter cells, leading to accumulation of dysfunctional mitochondria in mother cells as they age.

key_concepts.concept: Decline in mitochondrial function with age
key_concepts.description: Aging yeast mother cells exhibit decreased mitochondrial transmembrane potential and reduced efficiency of mitochondrial protein import, which contributes to mitochondrial dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Loss of mitochondrial DNA and cellular consequences
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction leads to accumulation of mitochondrial protein precursors in the cytoplasm and loss of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which at late stages results in cell death.
Yeast strains lacking mtDNA can have either increased or decreased lifespan depending on their ability to activate compensatory pathways that mitigate mitochondrial dysfunction.

theories.evidence: Review of experimental findings in yeast replicative aging, including observations of mitochondrial potential decline, mtDNA loss, and lifespan changes in strains with or without mtDNA.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organismal level (mitochondrial dysfunction as a fundamental aging driver), discusses underlying mechanisms, and addresses aging broadly beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: Telomerase-Positive Somatic Tissues of Honeybee Queens (Apis mellifera) Display No DNA Replication.

theories.name: Telomerase-related aging theory

key_concepts.description: Telomerase activity maintains telomere length in certain cell types, allowing cells to retain proliferative capacity and tissue regeneration potential, which is linked to aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Telomerase absence and cell cycle arrest
key_concepts.description: The lack of telomerase leads to telomere shortening, causing irreversible cell cycle arrest in most somatic cells, acting as a protective mechanism against cancer but also contributing to aging.

Telomerase may have roles beyond telomere lengthening, as suggested by observations in honeybee queen somatic tissues where telomerase activity is upregulated without corresponding DNA replication, indicating alternative mechanisms influencing aging.

theories.evidence: Observations of upregulated telomerase activity in somatic tissues of honeybee queens without corresponding DNA replication rates; references to previous studies on telomerase functions and aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general biological aging mechanism (telomerase and telomere dynamics) with causal explanations for aging processes and suggests broader organism-level implications via eusocial insect model.

results.title: Iridoid compound 10-O-trans-p-coumaroylcatalpol extends longevity and reduces α synuclein aggregation in Caenorhabditis elegans.

theories.name: DAF-16 mediated longevity pathway

key_concepts.concept: DAF-16 as a longevity-promoting transcription factor
key_concepts.description: DAF-16 is a transcription factor in C. elegans that regulates genes involved in stress resistance, metabolism, and longevity. Activation of DAF-16 leads to increased lifespan and enhanced stress tolerance.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress reduction as a mechanism of aging delay
key_concepts.description: Reduction of reactive oxygen species (ROS) content decreases cellular damage caused by oxidative stress, which is a known contributor to aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Amelioration of protein aggregation in aging
key_concepts.description: Aggregation of proteins such as alpha-synuclein is linked to neurodegenerative diseases and aging. Reducing such aggregation can improve cellular function and organismal healthspan.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from C. elegans lifespan assays, stress resistance tests, ROS measurements, alpha-synuclein aggregation assays, and genetic knockout mutants (daf-16, sir-2.1, mev-1) demonstrating that OCC effects depend on daf-16 activation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (DAF-16 activation) underlying aging and longevity at the organismal level, supported by genetic evidence; addresses general aging processes such as oxidative stress and protein aggregation; and is not limited to a narrow disease or organ.

results.title: Black rice anthocyanin extract enhances the antioxidant capacity in PC12 cells and improves the lifespan by activating IIS pathway in Caenorhabditis elegans.

theories.name: Insulin/IGF-1 Signaling (IIS) Pathway Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathway modulates aging and longevity by regulating downstream transcription factors such as DAF-16/FOXO, which control stress resistance, metabolism, and antioxidant defenses.
Activation of the IIS pathway leads to increased expression of antioxidant enzymes (e.g., SOD-3, CTL-1, GST-4), which reduce reactive oxygen species (ROS) and oxidative damage, thereby slowing aging.
Downregulation of age-1 and daf-2 genes and upregulation of daf-16 are key molecular events in the IIS pathway that influence lifespan extension and stress resistance.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing BRAE treatment increased antioxidant enzyme activities, reduced ROS and malondialdehyde in PC12 cells and C. elegans; lifespan extension and stress resistance in C. elegans; gene expression changes in age-1, daf-2, daf-16; mutational lifespan tests and molecular docking supporting IIS involvement.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The IIS pathway theory is a well-established generalizable biological aging theory explaining causal mechanisms of aging at the organism level, supported by genetic and biochemical evidence. The paper tests and discusses this theory in the context of lifespan extension by BRAE.

results.title: Superoxide signal orchestrates tetrathiomolybdate-induced longevity via ARGK-1 in Caenorhabditis elegans.

theories.name: Superoxide-mediated redox signaling theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Role of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in aging
key_concepts.description: ROS, particularly superoxide (O2•-), act as key redox signaling molecules that influence the aging process. The theory posits that specific oxidants can trigger signaling pathways that modulate healthspan and lifespan, rather than ROS being solely damaging agents.

Longevity can be modulated by controlling superoxide levels in vivo, for example, via inhibition of superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) by tetrathiomolybdate (TM). This precise regulation can promote healthy aging phenotypes such as increased fertility, mobility, stress resistance, and reduced lipofuscin accumulation.

key_concepts.concept: ARGK-1 and insulin/IGF-1 signaling (IIS) axis as downstream effectors
key_concepts.description: Superoxide signaling influences longevity through the ARGK-1 enzyme and downstream insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathways. Disruption of ARGK-1 or daf-16 (a key IIS transcription factor) abolishes the longevity effects, indicating a causal mechanistic pathway linking superoxide signaling to systemic aging regulation.

theories.evidence: Experimental manipulation of superoxide levels in C. elegans using TM and genetic knockdowns (sod-1 RNAi, argk-1 RNAi, daf-16 mutants), lifespan and healthspan assays, transcriptome analysis, and pharmacological interventions (superoxide scavenger Mn(III)TBAP and generator paraquat).
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (redox signaling by superoxide) with a causal mechanism (SOD1 inhibition leading to superoxide-mediated signaling via ARGK-1 and IIS) that affects organismal aging broadly, supported by mechanistic experiments in a model organism.

results.title: The notion of primordial building blocks in construction of genes and transcriptional and processing errors due to random occurrence of oligonucleotide signal sequences.

theories.name: Genetic Programming Theory of Aging with Central Control Hypothesis

key_concepts.description: The lifespan is considered a species-specific genetically programmed trait, implying that aging is controlled by genetic instructions encoded within the organism.

key_concepts.concept: Primordial building blocks and genetic sequence degeneracy
key_concepts.description: Genes are composed of degenerate repeats of short primordial oligonucleotide sequences, leading to frequent random occurrences of transcriptional and processing signal sequences that may cause errors.

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of transcriptional and processing errors with age
key_concepts.description: Random inadvertent transcription of nonsense sequences and missplicing of transcripts increase with age, potentially contributing causally to the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Central control of aging via secreted factors
key_concepts.description: An alternative to cell-autonomous senescence is the hypothesis of central regulation of aging, such as programmed secretion of aging peptide hormones (e.g., by the pituitary), coordinating organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Distinction between somatic cell senescence and organismal aging
key_concepts.description: The theory challenges the equivalence of cessation of cell proliferation with senescence, noting that some differentiated cells (e.g., neurons) are non-proliferative early yet do not necessarily represent aging, suggesting systemic control mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Theoretical reasoning based on gene sequence analysis of beta-2-microglobulin superfamily genes, known biology of cell differentiation and proliferation, and evolutionary considerations of germ line immortality; no direct experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general, organism-level genetic programming mechanism for aging, discusses causal mechanisms (transcriptional errors, central hormonal control), and addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Gut Microbiota and Its Role in Anti-aging Phenomenon: Evidence-Based Review.

theories.name: Gut Microbiota Influence on Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: With increasing age, the richness and diversity of gut microbial species sharply decline, which is linked to unhealthy aging and reduced longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Microbial shift from commensal to pathogenic
key_concepts.description: Aging causes a drift in gut microbiota composition, where beneficial commensal microbes decrease and potentially pathogenic microbes increase, contributing to age-related pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Host-microbiota communication via biomolecules and epigenetics
key_concepts.description: Gut microbiota communicates with the host through biomolecules, epigenetic mechanisms, and signaling pathways, influencing host lifespan and health; disruption in this communication may accelerate aging.

key_concepts.concept: Gut dysbiosis triggering innate immunity and aging-related diseases
key_concepts.description: Age-related gut dysbiosis can activate innate immune responses, leading to chronic inflammation and the development of age-associated pathological syndromes, thereby promoting early aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of various studies showing correlations between gut microbiota changes and aging, including effects on longevity, immunity, and age-related diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking gut microbiota dynamics to systemic aging processes, addressing fundamental aging mechanisms beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Berberine extends healthspan and delays neurodegenerative diseases in Caenorhabditis elegans through ROS-dependent PMK-1/SKN-1 activation.

theories.name: ROS hormesis theory of aging

key_concepts.description: ROS are traditionally viewed as damaging agents contributing to aging and age-related diseases via oxidative stress. However, low levels of ROS can act as signaling molecules that activate protective cellular pathways, leading to beneficial effects on healthspan.

Mild ROS generation triggers activation of stress response pathways such as PMK-1/SKN-1 in C. elegans, which promote cellular defense mechanisms, enhance longevity, and delay neurodegenerative disease progression.

The theory posits that a hormetic effect of ROS—whereby low-level oxidative stress induces adaptive beneficial responses—explains how ROS can both contribute to aging and promote longevity depending on context and dose.

theories.evidence: Experimental data in C. elegans showing that berberine treatment generates ROS, activates PMK-1/SKN-1 signaling, extends healthy lifespan, and delays neurodegenerative disease models dependent on this pathway.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how ROS influence aging at the organismal level via signaling pathways; it addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases; and it provides mechanistic insight rather than mere correlation.

results.title: DAF-16 is involved in colonic metabolites of ferulic acid-promoted longevity and stress resistance of Caenorhabditis elegans.
The effect of nutritional regimes upon collagen concentration and survival of rats.

theories.name: Caloric Restriction Longevity Theory

key_concepts.description: Chronic food restriction at any life stage leads to a distinct increase in lifespan, even if the restriction is only during youth and followed by ad libitum feeding later. This suggests a lasting effect of early nutritional regimes on aging.

key_concepts.concept: Storage of aging modulation in DNA-RNA pathway
key_concepts.description: The delayed effect of food restriction on aging implies that the mechanism is stored biologically, possibly along the DNA-RNA pathway, indicating a molecular or genetic basis for the longevity effect.

key_concepts.concept: Free radicals play a minor role in lifespan extension by undernutrition
key_concepts.description: The effect of food restriction differs from that of free radical blocking agents, suggesting that free radicals contribute only a small proportion to lifespan changes under nutritional regimes.

key_concepts.concept: Collagen accumulation as an aging marker
key_concepts.description: An increase in collagen concentration in organs like kidneys and liver precedes mortality in rats, indicating collagen accumulation may be a marker of involutional aging changes influenced by nutritional status.

theories.evidence: Experimental data on rats showing lifespan extension with food restriction; comparison with effects of free radical blockers; collagen concentration measurements; references to studies in rodents, rotifers, and insects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging modulation via nutritional regimes, discusses underlying molecular pathways, and links physiological markers (collagen) to systemic aging.

results.title: Hickory nut polyphenols enhance oxidative stress resilience and improve the longevity of Caenorhabditis elegans through modulating DAF-16/DAF-2 insulin/IGF-1 signaling.

theories.name: Insulin/IGF-1 Signaling (IIS) Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This pathway is a conserved molecular signaling cascade that regulates longevity and stress resistance in organisms such as Caenorhabditis elegans. DAF-2 is the insulin/IGF-1 receptor homolog, and DAF-16 is a downstream FOXO transcription factor that modulates gene expression related to stress responses and lifespan extension.

The theory posits that modulation of the IIS pathway enhances the organism's ability to resist oxidative damage by upregulating antioxidant enzymes like superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT), and glutathione peroxidase (GPx), thereby reducing reactive oxygen species (ROS) and lipid peroxidation, which are contributors to aging.

Mutations or alterations in genes such as age-1, akt-1/2, daf-2, and daf-16 affect the IIS pathway activity and consequently influence lifespan and aging phenotypes. Activation of DAF-16 leads to expression of protective genes that promote longevity.

theories.evidence: Lifespan analysis, oxidative stress assays, gene knockout and overexpression mutants (age-1, akt-1/2, daf-2, daf-16, SOD-3, GST-4), transcriptomic and qRT-PCR data, GFP reporter strains, and metabolomic profiling of polyphenols.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it explains a fundamental, organism-level aging process via a conserved signaling pathway; proposes causal mechanisms linking IIS modulation to aging; addresses aging broadly beyond a single tissue or disease.

results.title: An underappreciated peculiarity of late-life human mortality kinetics assessed through the lens of a generalization of the Gompertz-Makeham law.

theories.name: Generalized Gompertz-Makeham mortality model with late-life aging rate dynamics

key_concepts.concept: Mortality rate deceleration at late life
key_concepts.description: The observed slowing down of the increase in mortality rates at very old ages (around 90 years in humans), traditionally explained by population heterogeneity where frailer individuals die earlier, leaving more robust individuals.

A newly identified phase starting around age 65 where the life-table aging rate (LAR) accelerates, increasing by about 30% by age 85, which precedes the late-life deceleration phase and cannot be explained by frailty selection alone.

Extension of the classical Gompertz-Makeham mortality model by introducing a time-dependent function f(t) and an additive term C(t), allowing for non-linear dynamics in the logarithm of mortality rate and capturing both acceleration and deceleration phases of aging rate.

key_concepts.concept: Biological aging linked to social factors
key_concepts.description: The acceleration phase coincides with typical retirement age, suggesting a possible link between social/environmental changes and biological aging dynamics.

theories.mode: discuss, propose (generalization of Gompertz-Makeham), analyze empirical mortality data
theories.evidence: Analysis of Human Mortality Database data from France, Sweden, and Japan across multiple time periods and cohorts; LOESS smoothing and derivative analysis of ln mortality rate versus age plots.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging rate dynamics at the organism level, extending a fundamental mortality model and linking biological aging processes to observed demographic patterns.

results.title: Total ginsenosides extend healthspan of aging Drosophila by suppressing imbalances in intestinal stem cells and microbiota.

theories.name: Stem cell and microbiota homeostasis theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The balance of ISC proliferation and function is critical for maintaining gut integrity and function during aging. Disruption leads to hyperproliferation and tissue dysfunction, accelerating aging.
A balanced intestinal microbiota supports healthy gut function and systemic health. Dysbiosis contributes to aging-related decline and disease.

key_concepts.concept: ER stress and IMD signaling pathways
key_concepts.description: Endoplasmic reticulum stress and immune deficiency (IMD) signaling regulate ISC and microbiota homeostasis. Dysregulation of these pathways promotes ISC overproliferation and microbial imbalance during aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from Drosophila showing that total ginsenosides (TG) administration delays gut aging, prevents ISC hyperproliferation by inhibiting ER stress IRE1-mediated JNK signaling, remodels gut microbiota, and inhibits Acetobacter-mediated IMD pathway activation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking stem cell and microbiota homeostasis to systemic aging processes, supported by mechanistic insights and experimental manipulation in a model organism.

results.title: Balanced basal-levels of ROS (redox-biology), and very-low-levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines (cold-inflammaging), as signaling molecules can prevent or slow-down overt-inflammaging, and the aging-associated decline of adaptive-homeostasis.

theories.name: Adaptive Homeostasis Regulation via Balanced ROS and Cold-Inflammaging Signaling

key_concepts.concept: Balanced basal levels of ROS as signaling molecules
key_concepts.description: Reactive oxygen species (ROS), traditionally viewed as harmful oxidative agents, are proposed here to have important physiological roles at balanced basal levels. These ROS act as signaling molecules that help regulate and maintain adaptive homeostasis during aging, particularly in response to mild, non-damaging environmental stimuli.

key_concepts.concept: Very-low-level pro-inflammatory cytokines (cold-inflammaging) as signaling mediators
key_concepts.description: Pro-inflammatory cytokines at very low levels, termed 'cold-inflammaging,' serve as signaling molecules that contribute to adaptive homeostasis. Their presence at these low levels helps to maintain homeostatic stability and prevent overt inflammatory states associated with aging.

key_concepts.concept: Switch from adaptive to maladaptive responses with increased ROS and cytokines
key_concepts.description: If perturbing signals persist, ROS and pro-inflammatory cytokine levels increase beyond basal levels, triggering a shift from adaptive to maladaptive responses. This leads to oxidative stress and overt inflammaging, which are linked to aging-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Sequential incremental potential to slow aging-associated decline
key_concepts.description: The dynamics and time-course of ROS and cytokine signaling at basal levels may sequentially prevent or slow the decline of adaptive homeostasis over the lifespan, thus potentially delaying aging-associated functional decline.

theories.evidence: The abstract references physiological roles demonstrated in Geroscience and describes conceptual scenarios based on known redox biology and immunology; no specific experimental data or citations are detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain HOW aging-associated decline in adaptive homeostasis occurs and how balanced ROS and cytokine signaling regulate this process, thus providing a causal mechanism at the organismal level. It is generalizable beyond specific organs or diseases, addressing fundamental aging processes related to redox and immune signaling dynamics.

results.title: ATFS-1 counteracts mitochondrial DNA damage by promoting repair over transcription.
Unraveling the ROS-Inflammation-Immune Balance: A New Perspective on Aging and Disease.

theories.name: ROS-Inflammation-Immune Balance Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) and Oxidative Stress
key_concepts.description: Aging leads to excessive production of ROS, which damage the antioxidant system and disrupt the redox balance, contributing to cellular and molecular damage.

Organ aging causes chronic low-grade inflammation characterized by an imbalance between proinflammatory and anti-inflammatory factors, which is activated by oxidative stress and contributes to immune system senescence.
The chronic inflammatory state and oxidative stress lead to a decline in immune system function, promoting a disorganized biological state with increased entropy.

key_concepts.concept: Entropy Increase as a Marker of Aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with an increase in entropy, representing a transition from ordered to disordered biological states, which underlies cellular damage and dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Balance Among ROS, Inflammation, and Immune Activity
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that maintaining a balance among ROS production, inflammatory responses, and immune system activity is crucial for preventing or reversing aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review that introduces the ROS-inflammation-immune balance concept for the first time, discusses preclinical evidence for antiaging medications targeting this balance, and cites existing literature on oxidative stress, inflammaging, and immune senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining why and how aging occurs at the organism level through the interplay of ROS, inflammation, and immune system changes; it provides a causal explanation linking oxidative stress and immune dysfunction to aging; and it addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

results.title: Trade-off-invariant rules for evolutionarily stable life histories.
Goal Changes and Healthy Aging.
Developmental epigenetic programming of caste-specific differences in social insects: an impact on longevity.

theories.name: Epigenetic programming of longevity in social insect castes

key_concepts.description: The same genome in social insects can produce distinct castes (queens and workers) with vastly different lifespans due to differential gene expression regulated by epigenetic mechanisms such as DNA methylation.

key_concepts.concept: Nutritional environment as a developmental trigger
key_concepts.description: Larval nutrition determines caste fate by influencing epigenetic marks, leading to caste-specific gene expression patterns that result in phenotypic differences including longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Longevity as a phenotype linked to epigenetic state
key_concepts.description: Queens, which receive different larval diets, develop epigenetic profiles that promote longer lifespan compared to workers, suggesting epigenetic programming as a mechanism underlying lifespan differences.

theories.evidence: Citations and references to studies showing differential DNA methylation patterns linked to larval diet and caste-specific gene expression; comparative lifespan data between queens and workers in multiple social insect species.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (epigenetic regulation) explaining how aging/longevity differences arise at the organismal level in social insects. It addresses fundamental aging processes via developmental programming and epigenetics, not limited to a single organ or disease.

results.title: A study of the molecular mechanism of quercetin and dasatinib combination as senolytic in alleviating age-related and kidney diseases.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the buildup of senescent cells in tissues contributes causally to aging and age-related tissue dysfunction. Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory factors and disrupt normal tissue homeostasis, thereby promoting chronic diseases.
Drugs that selectively eliminate senescent cells (senolytics) can reduce the burden of senescence, thereby alleviating age-related pathologies and extending lifespan, as demonstrated in mouse models.

theories.evidence: The paper references prior research showing that senolytics extend mouse lifespan and reduce senescent cells. It studies the molecular mechanism of quercetin and dasatinib combination as senolytics in alleviating age-related kidney disease, linking senescence reduction to improved outcomes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process (senescent cell accumulation), proposes a causal mechanism (senescent cells drive aging-related dysfunction), and addresses systemic aging beyond a single organ by linking to multiple age-related diseases.

theories.name: α-Klotho Deficiency and Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: α-Klotho protein levels decline with age, and its deficiency accelerates aging phenotypes. Conversely, upregulation of α-klotho extends lifespan and delays onset of multiple age-related diseases.

α-Klotho acts as an endogenous antagonist of Wnt/β-catenin signaling, a pathway implicated in aging and kidney disease. This regulatory role is proposed as a mechanism by which α-klotho exerts protective effects.
There is a negative mechanistic link between α-klotho levels and senescent cell accumulation, suggesting that α-klotho modulates senescence and thereby influences aging.

theories.evidence: The paper cites mouse models lacking α-klotho showing accelerated aging, and studies showing α-klotho upregulation extends lifespan. It investigates how senolytic treatment affects α-klotho/Wnt/β-catenin signaling in kidney disease.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general aging mechanism involving a key protein regulating systemic aging processes and multiple age-related diseases, with causal links to senescence and signaling pathways.

results.title: Specific differences and novel key regulatory genes of sex in influencing exceptional longevity phenotypes.
Non-senescent species are not immortal: Stress and decline in two planaria species.

theories.name: Negligible and Negative Senescence Theory

key_concepts.description: Some species exhibit negligible senescence characterized by constant mortality rates and stable physiological performance with age, contrasting with typical aging species that show decline.
Certain species demonstrate negative senescence where mortality rates decline with age, implying improved survival or performance as they grow older.
Variations in resource availability influence life history traits such as reproduction and maintenance investment, which modulate population viability and aging patterns in non-senescent species.
