theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking gut microbiota-derived metabolites to systemic aging via cellular senescence, addresses fundamental aging processes beyond a single organ or disease, and provides mechanistic insights into how aging occurs.

results.title: Pharmacologic interventions targeting ovarian aging, cancer, and mitochondrial dysfunction: An updated evidence.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction leads to oxidative damage and metabolic disturbances that impair cellular function, particularly in oocytes, contributing to aging phenotypes such as reduced reproductive capacity.
Excessive reactive oxygen species generated by dysfunctional mitochondria cause oxidative damage to DNA, proteins, and lipids, accelerating cellular aging and functional decline.

key_concepts.concept: Role in systemic aging and disease
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial insufficiency is implicated not only in ovarian aging but also in broader age-related diseases including metabolic disorders and cancer, suggesting shared molecular pathways driving organismal aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews mechanisms such as oxidative stress, DNA damage, telomere shortening, and mitochondrial dysfunction, citing recent advances in nutrient supplementation and sirtuin regulation that modulate mitochondrial function.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress) underlying aging at the organismal level, linking reproductive aging to systemic aging and disease.

theories.name: Sirtuin regulation theory in aging

key_concepts.concept: Sirtuins as regulators of redox balance
key_concepts.description: Sirtuins, particularly SIRT1 and SIRT3, regulate cellular redox homeostasis and mitochondrial function, thereby influencing aging processes by protecting cells from oxidative damage.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation of aging via sirtuin activity
key_concepts.description: Enhancing sirtuin activity through pharmacologic or nutrient interventions may preserve mitochondrial function and improve oocyte quality, potentially delaying aging-related decline.

theories.evidence: The review highlights the critical role of sirtuins in oocyte and granulosa cell function and discusses recent advances in targeted nutrient supplementation to enhance sirtuin activity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general mechanism (epigenetic regulation via sirtuins) that causally impacts aging processes, linking molecular regulation to organismal aging.

results.title: Characterizing primary and secondary senescence in vivo.

theories.name: Cellular senescence as a causal driver of systemic aging

key_concepts.description: Cells enter a senescent state due to intrinsic stress or damage, characterized by stable cell cycle arrest and a distinct secretory phenotype. This primary senescence can be induced by various stimuli such as oncogenic signaling (e.g., constitutively active MEK1 or MKK6).

Senescence can propagate non-cell-autonomously through factors secreted by primary senescent cells, notably the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP). This leads to induction of senescence in neighboring cells, amplifying the senescent cell burden in tissues.

Senescent cells exhibit diverse transcriptional profiles depending on the tissue context and the senescence inducer, even within the same cell type. This heterogeneity complicates understanding of senescence roles in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of immune signaling in senescence propagation
key_concepts.description: Interleukin-1β, primarily derived from macrophages, is identified as a key mediator inducing secondary senescence in vivo, highlighting the interplay between immune cells and senescent cells in aging tissues.

theories.evidence: Use of senescence-inducible mouse models expressing constitutively active MEK1 or MKK6 and mCherry to map primary and secondary senescent cells; spatially resolved single-cell RNA expression analyses; identification of IL-1β from macrophages as inducer of secondary senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process (cellular senescence) with causal mechanisms (primary and secondary senescence induction and propagation), generalizable across tissues and organisms, and addresses systemic aging rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: NF-κB activation with aging: characterization and therapeutic inhibition.

theories.name: NF-κB activation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The transcription factor NF-κB shows increased activity in naturally aged organisms and in progeroid models, suggesting it plays a role in the aging process by mediating stress responses.
Aging is driven in part by the accumulation of replicative, oxidative, and genotoxic stress, which may activate NF-κB signaling pathways contributing to tissue homeostasis decline.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic inhibition of NF-κB delays aging
key_concepts.description: Genetic or pharmacologic suppression of NF-κB activity can delay aging pathology and extend healthspan, indicating a causal role of NF-κB activation in aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Observations of NF-κB upregulation in aged and progeroid mice; experimental suppression of NF-κB genetically or pharmacologically leading to delayed aging phenotypes and prolonged healthspan; description of methods to measure NF-κB activation and aging endpoints.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (NF-κB activation) underlying aging across models, addresses systemic aging processes, and includes experimental intervention data supporting causality.

results.title: The dominance of old blood, and age-related increase in protein production and noise.

theories.name: Systemic Proteome Dilution Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The aged systemic environment contains elevated levels of certain proteins that promote progeric (aging-related) phenotypes even in young cells and tissues, indicating that old blood factors can drive aging systemically.

key_concepts.concept: Dilution of age-elevated proteins as rejuvenation
key_concepts.description: Rather than focusing on adding young blood factors, reducing or diluting the concentration of age-elevated proteins in the systemic proteome can recalibrate the proteome to a younger state, potentially reversing tissue aging without requiring donor blood.

Age-related increase in protein synthesis noise (variability in newly synthesized proteins) is a critical mechanism contributing to tissue aging, and modulating this noise is important for understanding and achieving tissue rejuvenation.

theories.evidence: Citations and discussion of heterochronic parabiosis, young plasma injections, neutral blood exchange, therapeutic plasma exchange studies; evidence of increased protein synthesis and proteome noise with age; in vitro and in vivo studies showing aged milieu induces aging phenotypes in young muscle and tissues.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining systemic aging via proteome composition and noise changes; addresses aging broadly at organismal level; provides mechanistic insight into how aged blood factors drive aging phenotypes; connects to general aging processes rather than narrow disease or organ-specific phenomena.

results.title: Strategies to make human skin models based on cellular senescence for ageing research.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the accumulation of senescent cells, which have ceased dividing and secrete pro-inflammatory factors, contributes causally to the aging process at the organismal level by impairing tissue function and promoting age-related pathologies.

Aging is influenced by genetic, physiological, and environmental factors that cumulatively impact cellular and tissue senescence, reflecting a complex interplay of intrinsic and extrinsic mechanisms driving systemic aging.

Developing human skin models that recapitulate cellular senescence and aging processes in vitro allows for mechanistic studies and testing interventions, thereby advancing understanding of aging mechanisms and potential therapies.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing main molecular mechanisms of aging related to cellular senescence and describes procedures to create in vitro aged skin models; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general causal mechanism (cellular senescence) underlying organismal aging, discusses molecular mechanisms, and connects skin aging to systemic aging processes.

results.title: The sirtuin-associated human senescence program converges on the activation of placenta-specific gene PAPPA.

theories.name: Sirtuin deficiency-induced cellular senescence theory

key_concepts.description: Sirtuins (SIRT1-SIRT7) are genes known to promote longevity, primarily through their roles in chromatin modulation and genome organization, which influence cellular aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Chromatin architecture alteration leading to senescence
key_concepts.description: Deficiency in any sirtuin alters 3D genome organization by changing enhancer activity and chromatin contacts, promoting aberrant gene activation that drives cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Activation of placenta-specific gene PAPPA as a pro-senescence effector
key_concepts.description: Sirtuin deficiency causes rewiring of chromatin contacts that aberrantly activate PAPPA, a placenta-specific gene, which mediates pro-senescence effects and may serve as an aging biomarker.

theories.evidence: Experimental evidence from isogeneic human stem cell lines with SIRT1-SIRT7 knockouts showing accelerated cellular senescence; large-scale epigenomic analyses revealing changes in genome organization and enhancer-promoter interactions; identification of PAPPA activation linked to senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how sirtuin deficiency leads to cellular senescence, a fundamental aging process, with genome-wide chromatin changes and gene activation affecting organismal aging; it is not limited to a single organ or disease and addresses a fundamental aging mechanism.

results.title: Protein oxidation and age-dependent alterations in calcium homeostasis.

theories.name: Calcium homeostasis disruption via oxidative post-translational modifications theory

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative modification of calcium regulatory proteins
key_concepts.description: During aging, critical calcium signaling proteins such as calmodulin and plasma membrane Ca-ATPase undergo oxidative post-translational modifications (e.g., methionine oxidation, tyrosine nitration) that impair their function, leading to disrupted calcium homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Loss of calcium homeostasis as a driver of cellular aging
key_concepts.description: The decline in function of calcium regulatory proteins results in elevated intracellular calcium levels, which contribute to reduced cellular function characteristic of aging and predispose organisms to diverse age-related pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Reversibility and regulatory role of oxidative modifications
key_concepts.description: These oxidative modifications may be reversible through intracellular repair enzymes that restore normal redox conditions, suggesting a potential regulatory mechanism that balances cellular survival and energy expenditure under oxidative stress.
A diminished capacity to generate ATP efficiently may underlie the loss of calcium homeostasis and cellular dysfunction during aging, linking metabolic decline to aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Citations of observed oxidation of methionines in calmodulin and nitration of tyrosines in SERCA2a; observed functional declines in calcium regulatory proteins with age; correlation with increased intracellular calcium in senescent cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging at the cellular and organismal level via disruption of calcium homeostasis caused by oxidative damage to key proteins, linking biochemical changes to systemic aging phenotypes.

results.title: The ticking of aging clocks.

theories.name: DNA damage and cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage as fundamental aging driver
key_concepts.description: Persistent DNA damage accumulates over time and acts as a key intrinsic timer or counting mechanism underlying biological aging. This damage triggers cellular responses that contribute to aging at the organismal level.

DNA damage induces cellular senescence, a state of permanent cell cycle arrest, accompanied by the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), which promotes inflammation and tissue dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Feedback loop via immune infiltration and reactive species
key_concepts.description: SASP induces cytotoxic immune cell infiltration, which generates reactive oxygen and nitrogen species (RONS) that cause further DNA damage, creating a self-amplifying cycle that accelerates aging.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic drift linked to DNA damage response
key_concepts.description: Epigenetic changes, potentially driven by DNA damage and its repair processes, contribute to the aging clock by altering gene expression patterns and cellular function over time.

theories.evidence: Citations to molecular mediators such as DNA damage, epigenetic drift, inflammation, and cellular senescence; conceptual integration of known mechanisms; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental, organism-level aging mechanism (DNA damage and senescence), proposes causal mechanisms, and addresses general aging processes beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: EFFECT OF RADIATION ON AGING PROCESSES AND TELOMERE LENGTH.

theories.name: Telomere Shortening Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Telomeres are repetitive nucleotide sequences at the ends of chromosomes that protect chromosome stability and integrity during cell division.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening as a mitotic clock
key_concepts.description: With each cell division, telomeres shorten, eventually triggering cellular senescence or apoptosis, thus acting as a biological clock for cellular aging.

key_concepts.concept: Radiation-induced oxidative stress accelerates telomere shortening
key_concepts.description: Exposure to ionizing and nonionizing radiation increases free radical production, which damages telomeres and accelerates their shortening, thereby promoting cellular aging.

key_concepts.concept: Antioxidant defense mechanisms modulate radiation effects
key_concepts.description: At low radiation doses, antioxidant systems can neutralize free radicals and mitigate telomere damage, but high doses or prolonged exposure overwhelm these defenses, leading to accelerated aging.

theories.evidence: Citations and literature review on radiation effects on telomeres and oxidative stress; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (telomere shortening) underlying biological aging, discusses how radiation-induced oxidative damage accelerates this process, and addresses aging at the cellular and organismal level.

results.title: Propagation of senescent phenotypes by extracellular HMGB1 is dependent on its redox state.

theories.name: Cellular senescence as a systemic aging driver mediated by extracellular redox-sensitive HMGB1

key_concepts.description: HMGB1 exists in multiple redox forms, with the reduced form (ReHMGB1) acting as a potent inducer of cellular senescence, while the oxidized form does not. This redox sensitivity modulates its ability to propagate senescence signals extracellularly.

key_concepts.concept: Paracrine and systemic propagation of senescence
key_concepts.description: ReHMGB1 secreted extracellularly induces senescence-like phenotypes in neighboring cells and multiple tissues, suggesting a mechanism for systemic spread of senescence beyond the initially affected cells.

ReHMGB1 triggers receptor for advanced glycation end products (RAGE)-mediated activation of JAK/STAT and NF-κB pathways, which drive the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) and cell cycle arrest, key features of cellular senescence.

Blocking extracellular HMGB1 reduces systemic senescence markers, inflammation, and improves tissue regeneration, indicating that extracellular HMGB1 is a causal driver of systemic aging phenotypes and a potential therapeutic target.

theories.evidence: In vitro paracrine senescence models, in vivo administration of ReHMGB1 in young mice inducing senescence across tissues, transcriptomic and cytokine profiling showing activation of senescence pathways, and therapeutic blockade of HMGB1 improving muscle regeneration in middle-aged mice.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining how cellular senescence propagates systemically via extracellular HMGB1, providing a causal explanation involving redox-dependent signaling pathways. It addresses aging broadly as a systemic process, not limited to a single tissue or disease.

results.title: Conserved biological processes in partial cellular reprogramming: Relevance to aging and rejuvenation.

theories.name: Partial cellular reprogramming as a rejuvenation mechanism

key_concepts.description: Partial reprogramming induces changes in chromatin structure through histone modifications that regulate gene accessibility. This facilitates activation of pluripotency genes while silencing somatic cell identity, which may reverse some aging-associated epigenetic changes.

Partial reprogramming affects cellular stress responses including inflammation, autophagy, and cellular senescence. These pathways are key regulators of aging and their modulation suggests a mechanism by which reprogramming could influence aging processes.

Reprogramming leads to enhanced mitochondrial activity, which is critical since mitochondrial dysfunction is a hallmark of aging. This improvement may contribute to cellular rejuvenation and systemic aging delay.
Changes in extracellular matrix-related pathways occur during partial reprogramming, potentially affecting tissue structure and function, which are important in organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Comparative analysis of in vitro and in vivo mouse studies and in vitro human studies, supported by data visualizations showing consistent biological process modulation patterns.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism (partial reprogramming) that causally influences fundamental aging processes (epigenetic state, stress responses, mitochondrial function) with broad organismal relevance. It goes beyond narrow phenomena and discusses underlying biological mechanisms.

results.title: Invariances in relations between aging, exposure to external hazards, and mortality reflected in life table aging rate (LAR) patterns examined through the lens of generalized Gompertz-Makeham law.

theories.name: Generalized Gompertz-Makeham Law (gGML) as a natural law linking aging, mortality, and environmental hazards

key_concepts.description: LAR is defined as the age-dependent change in the logarithm of mortality and is equated to the population-averaged biological aging rate (γ) under the Gompertz law. It serves as a measure of aging at the population level.

key_concepts.concept: Influence of External Hazards on Mortality and Aging Rate
key_concepts.description: Population exposure to external hazards affects LAR, causing deviations from the constant aging rate predicted by the Gompertz law. These hazards are categorized as irresistible external hazards and resistible external/internal hazards, each influencing mortality differently.

The gGML extends the canonical Gompertz-Makeham law by allowing its parameters to be population-specific functions of age rather than constants, capturing the dynamic interaction between aging, mortality, and environmental exposures.

Despite the generalization, the modes by which these functions translate into mortality dependence on age remain invariant: linear for exposure to irresistible hazards and exponential for the ability to withstand resistible hazards.

key_concepts.concept: Aging Rate Increment as Cause of LAR Undulations
key_concepts.description: Observed undulations in LAR trajectories, especially transient increases in older ages, are attributed primarily to increments in the biological aging rate γ rather than unrealistically high external hazard exposure.

theories.evidence: Modeling of mortality-vs-age trajectories using mortality data from different countries and historical periods; theoretical analysis of LAR patterns and their relation to hazard exposures and aging rate.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory proposes a generalizable, causal explanation linking biological aging rate and mortality patterns at the population level, incorporating environmental hazard exposures. It addresses aging broadly through a mathematical-natural law framework, meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Hemispheric asymmetry reduction in older adults: the HAROLD model.
Geroscience: A Translational Review.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: With aging, senescent cells accumulate in tissues. These cells are characterized by growth arrest, resistance to apoptosis, and secretion of pro-inflammatory factors, collectively termed the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP). This accumulation is linked to physical impairments and increased mortality.
Senescent cells contribute causally to systemic aging by promoting tissue dysfunction and chronic inflammation, which drive age-related decline in multiple organ systems.

Reducing senescent cell burden using senolytic drugs in animal models extends lifespan and improves physical functions such as grip strength, mobility, and cardiac function, suggesting senescence as a modifiable aging mechanism.

theories.evidence: Citations of animal model experiments showing lifespan extension and functional improvements after senescent cell clearance; human data showing increased senescent cells with age and associations with impairments.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process with causal mechanisms, generalizable across organisms, and connected to systemic aging rather than a single disease.

theories.name: Damage Accumulation and Nutrient Sensing Pathways Theory

key_concepts.description: Caloric restriction extends lifespan and delays age-related diseases by modulating multiple cellular pathways implicated in aging, including nutrient sensing, protein synthesis, autophagy, and inflammation.
Aging is driven by accumulation of molecular damage and dysregulation of nutrient sensing pathways (e.g., mTOR), which can be targeted to slow aging and disease progression.

theories.evidence: Animal studies showing lifespan extension with caloric restriction; human clinical trial data showing reduced mortality and chronic disease incidence with caloric restriction.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes underlying causal mechanisms for aging at organismal level, generalizable beyond specific diseases, and supported by experimental data.

theories.name: Pharmacological Modulation of Aging Pathways Theory

key_concepts.description: Drugs like rapamycin inhibit mTOR signaling, a nutrient sensing pathway, thereby extending lifespan and improving immune function in aged organisms.
Metformin and senolytic drugs target aging biology to slow disease progression and functional decline, representing pharmacological interventions on fundamental aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Animal lifespan extension data with rapamycin; human data showing improved vaccine response with everolimus; clinical trials with caloric restriction and metformin.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Proposes causal mechanisms by targeting fundamental aging pathways; generalizable and connected to systemic aging processes.

results.title: Protein degradation in the aging organism.
The dietary exposome: a brief history of diet, longevity, and age-related health in rodents.

theories.name: Dietary restriction and nutrient modulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Reducing total food intake below ad libitum levels increases lifespan and improves multiple aspects of age-related health in rodents, suggesting a fundamental link between energy intake and aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Protein and amino acid restriction effects
key_concepts.description: Limiting specific dietary components such as total protein, branched chain amino acids, or individual amino acids can mimic the lifespan and healthspan benefits of caloric restriction, indicating nutrient composition plays a causal role in aging modulation.

Intermittent fasting regimens like time-restricted feeding or alternate-day feeding, even without reducing total caloric intake, can significantly influence longevity and late-life health, highlighting the importance of feeding patterns in aging mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Dietary exposome as a modulator of aging
key_concepts.description: The cumulative dietary environment (dietary exposome) shapes aging trajectories and health outcomes, suggesting that diet acts as a systemic modulator of aging processes at the organismal level.

theories.evidence: Citations of numerous rodent studies over more than a century demonstrating lifespan extension and health improvements via various dietary interventions including caloric restriction, protein/amino acid restriction, ketogenic diets, and fasting protocols.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes generalizable, causal mechanisms by which diet influences fundamental aging processes across the organism, supported by broad experimental evidence in rodents; addresses aging broadly rather than specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Free radicals, atherosclerosis, ageing, and related dysmetabolic pathologies: pathological and clinical aspects.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that free radicals, which are reactive oxygen species generated as by-products of normal metabolism and environmental exposures, cause cumulative damage to cellular components such as DNA, proteins, and lipids. This damage, if unrepaired, contributes to cellular aging and dysfunction.

Cells possess enzymatic and structural repair mechanisms as well as natural antioxidants to mitigate oxidative damage. The balance between free radical production and antioxidant defenses influences the rate of aging and onset of degenerative diseases.

External factors like ultraviolet light, cigarette smoke, and pollutants increase free radical burden, accelerating oxidative damage and aging processes. Dietary intake of antioxidants from fruits and vegetables is associated with reduced risk of age-related degenerative diseases.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known biochemical pathways of oxidative damage, epidemiological associations between antioxidant-rich diets and disease risk, and the presence of cellular repair mechanisms. It notes limited data supporting antioxidant supplementation as treatment.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organismal level through damage accumulation by free radicals. It addresses fundamental aging processes rather than narrow disease-specific phenomena.

results.title: Temporal changes in mitochondrial function and reactive oxygen species generation during the development of replicative senescence in human fibroblasts.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction and reactive oxygen species (ROS) theory of cellular senescence

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a driver of cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that age-dependent impairment of mitochondrial energy production leads to cellular senescence, a state of irreversible cell cycle arrest. Dysfunctional mitochondria fail to maintain normal respiratory function, contributing to the aging process at the cellular level.

key_concepts.concept: Excessive mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation
key_concepts.description: Excessive ROS produced by mitochondria is hypothesized to cause oxidative damage that triggers or accelerates cellular senescence. ROS are reactive molecules that can damage DNA, proteins, and lipids, thereby promoting aging-related cellular dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Temporal relationship between mitochondrial dysfunction and replicative senescence
key_concepts.description: The theory addresses whether mitochondrial dysfunction and ROS generation initiate or accelerate replicative senescence, focusing on the timing of mitochondrial changes relative to the onset of senescence.

theories.evidence: Experimental observations in human TIG-1 fibroblasts showed no increase in mitochondrial ROS or decrease in mitochondrial respiratory function during the transition phase of replicative senescence. Additional data included measurements of integrated stress response markers, mitochondrial morphology, mitophagy-related protein levels, and autophagic flux.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process (cellular senescence) with proposed causal mechanisms (mitochondrial dysfunction and ROS). It addresses general aging at the cellular level, not limited to a specific disease or organ, and tests the temporal causality of these mechanisms in replicative senescence, thus meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Role of chemokines in aging and age-related diseases.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Inflammaging refers to the persistent, systemic, low-level inflammation that develops with age and contributes to the functional decline of tissues and organs. This chronic inflammatory state is proposed to be a fundamental mechanism underlying biological aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Role of chemokines in mediating inflammaging
key_concepts.description: Chemokines, through their interaction with G protein-coupled receptors, regulate immune cell trafficking and inflammatory responses. Their dysregulation promotes recruitment of macrophages and other immune cells, sustaining the inflammatory milieu that drives aging processes across multiple organ systems.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of chemokines to modulate aging
key_concepts.description: By using chemokine receptor antagonists and anti-chemokines to suppress pro-inflammatory signaling, it may be possible to reduce inflammaging, thereby delaying aging and mitigating age-related diseases. This approach is under investigation in clinical trials aiming to promote healthy aging and extend lifespan.

theories.evidence: Summary of recent progress in understanding chemokine roles in aging and age-related diseases; references to ongoing clinical trials using chemokine receptor antagonists and anti-chemokines
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism (inflammation mediated by chemokines) underlying aging at the organismal level, discusses evolutionary and physiological relevance, and explores interventions targeting this mechanism.

results.title: Direct and indirect transcriptional targets of DAF-16.

theories.name: Insulin/IGF-1 Signaling (IIS) Pathway Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: DAF-2 gene as insulin/IGF-1 receptor homolog
key_concepts.description: The daf-2 gene encodes a protein homologous to insulin and insulin-like growth factor 1 receptors, which are key regulators of lifespan in C. elegans. Mutations in daf-2 can extend lifespan, implicating this pathway in aging regulation.

key_concepts.concept: DAF-16 as downstream forkhead transcription factor
key_concepts.description: DAF-16 is a forkhead transcription factor acting downstream of DAF-2. It regulates the expression of genes that influence longevity, stress resistance, and metabolism, mediating the effects of insulin/IGF-1 signaling on aging.

key_concepts.concept: Gene expression regulation as mechanism of lifespan determination
key_concepts.description: Changes in gene expression controlled by DAF-16, both direct and indirect targets, are proposed to causally influence lifespan. Identifying these targets helps elucidate how IIS modulates aging at a molecular level.

theories.evidence: Reference to genome-scale gene expression analysis identifying DAF-16 targets in long-lived and short-lived C. elegans mutants; citations of prior genetic mutation studies in daf-2 and daf-16 affecting lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining aging through a conserved signaling pathway affecting organismal lifespan; addresses aging broadly beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: Mitochondria: fundamental characteristics, challenges, and impact on aging.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Mitochondria continuously undergo dynamic processes such as fission, fusion, and biogenesis throughout an organism's lifespan. Due to their intrinsic properties and exposure to external factors, mitochondria are highly vulnerable to accumulating damage over time.

key_concepts.concept: Link between mitochondrial dysfunction and aging
key_concepts.description: The decline in biological function observed during aging is closely associated with mitochondrial dysfunction, suggesting that mitochondrial health is a critical determinant of the aging process at the organismal level.
Mitochondria interact with nuclear DNA, and these interactions may influence aging mechanisms, reflecting complex intracellular communication that impacts cellular and organismal aging.

theories.evidence: The paper provides a comprehensive review of past and present knowledge, citing research progress and therapies targeting mitochondria in various conditions, and discusses mitochondrial characteristics and their impact on aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process by proposing mitochondrial dysfunction as a causal mechanism underlying organismal aging. It is generalizable beyond specific diseases or organs and addresses aging broadly. Therefore, it meets all core criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Genome-wide association and epidemiological evidence linking air pollution to aging mechanisms.

theories.name: Telomere attrition as a causal mechanism of aging accelerated by environmental damage

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length as a biomarker and mechanism of aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres shorten with cell division and stress, leading to cellular senescence and organismal aging. Shorter telomeres are associated with aging phenotypes and age-related diseases.
Exposure to air pollution, specifically PM2.5, causes molecular damage that accelerates telomere attrition, thereby speeding up biological aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Causal link between pollution and aging via telomere dynamics
key_concepts.description: Mendelian randomization and network analyses suggest a causal pathway where air pollution exposure leads to telomere shortening, which in turn contributes to aging and aging-related diseases such as sarcopenia and tumors.

theories.evidence: Global epidemiological studies associating PM2.5 exposure with shorter telomeres and sarcopenia incidence; Mendelian randomization analysis supporting causality; network analysis identifying molecular pathways; phenotypic association studies linking telomere length to tumors.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (telomere shortening) linking environmental damage to systemic aging, supported by causal inference methods and molecular pathway analysis.

results.title: First-generation versus next-generation epigenetic aging clocks: Differences in performance and utility.
Global analysis of aging-related protein structural changes uncovers enzyme-polymerization-based control of longevity.

theories.name: Protein structural alteration theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Protein structural-functional changes drive aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that aging is accompanied by progressive changes in the structure and function of proteins, which underlie cellular phenotypic alterations and contribute to age-related diseases. Structural changes in proteins can disrupt their normal roles, leading to dysfunction at the cellular and organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Enzyme polymerization as a causal mechanism of aging
key_concepts.description: Specifically, the polymerization of the enzyme glutamate synthase (Glt1) into supramolecular assemblies during aging disrupts amino acid homeostasis, which in turn contributes to mitochondrial dysfunction and aging phenotypes. Preventing this polymerization restores cellular homeostasis and extends lifespan, suggesting a causal role.

key_concepts.concept: Proteome-wide mapping to identify aging mechanisms
key_concepts.description: A comprehensive proteome-wide approach using limited proteolysis-mass spectrometry (LiP-MS) can identify proteins undergoing structural changes early in aging, revealing key regulators of translation, protein folding, and metabolism that contribute to aging processes.

theories.evidence: Proteome-wide LiP-MS data identifying age-related protein structural changes; experimental mutation of Glt1 polymerization interface that restored amino acid levels, improved mitochondrial function, and extended lifespan in yeast; creation of an online ProtAge catalog.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: generalizable to organism-level aging mechanisms through fundamental protein structural changes; proposes a causal mechanism (enzyme polymerization disrupting homeostasis); addresses broad aging processes beyond a single disease or organ; provides mechanistic insight into aging.

results.title: ADP-ribosylation, a multifaceted modification: Functions and mechanisms in aging and aging-related diseases.

theories.name: ADP-ribosylation as a molecular mechanism in aging and aging-related diseases

key_concepts.description: ADP-ribosylation is a reversible post-translational modification of proteins and nucleic acids that alters their structure and function, thereby influencing cellular processes relevant to aging.

Enzymes such as ADP-ribosyl transferases, hydrolases, and ADP-ribose binding domains regulate the addition and removal of ADP-ribose groups, modulating biological pathways implicated in organismal aging and cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Connection to aging-related diseases and organismal aging
key_concepts.description: ADP-ribosylation impacts the pathogenesis and progression of multiple aging-related diseases (cardiovascular, neurodegenerative, cancer, metabolic disorders) and is involved in fundamental aging processes and cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Molecular network and mechanisms underlying aging
key_concepts.description: The paper speculates on the underlying molecular mechanisms by which ADP-ribosylation influences aging, suggesting it as a novel regulatory network that may causally contribute to aging and age-related pathologies.

theories.evidence: Summarizes growing experimental evidence and literature on ADP-ribosylation proteins and enzymes, their regulation, and involvement in aging and age-related diseases; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses a molecular mechanism (ADP-ribosylation) that is proposed to causally influence aging broadly at organism and cellular levels, linking it to aging-related diseases and cellular senescence, thus meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: Inter-tissue communication of mitochondrial stress in aging.

theories.name: Mitochondrial unfolded protein response (UPRmt) theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Maintaining protein folding and function within mitochondria is essential for cellular health and normal physiological function.
Cells activate the mitochondrial unfolded protein response (UPRmt) to restore mitochondrial homeostasis and repair mitochondrial function when mitochondrial stress occurs.

Studies in model organisms show that mild mitochondrial damage can extend lifespan by activating UPRmt, suggesting a hormetic effect where controlled mitochondrial stress triggers beneficial adaptive responses.

UPRmt can be induced non-autonomously in tissues not directly experiencing mitochondrial stress through secreted signaling molecules called mitokines, coordinating systemic adaptation to mitochondrial stress.

key_concepts.concept: Systemic regulation of aging by mitochondrial stress signaling
key_concepts.description: The inter-tissue mitochondrial stress communication system regulates organismal adaptation capacity, which is closely linked to aging processes and age-related diseases such as neurodegeneration and cancer.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies in worms, flies, and mice demonstrating mild mitochondrial damage promoting longevity via UPRmt activation; identification of mitokines mediating inter-tissue communication; associations with aging and diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how mitochondrial stress responses and inter-tissue signaling influence systemic aging processes; it addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Hormesis determines lifespan.

theories.name: Hormesis theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Hormesis is characterized by a biphasic dose response where low doses of stressors or agents induce beneficial adaptive responses, enhancing biological functions such as cell proliferation, memory, tissue repair, and longevity, while higher doses are detrimental.

Hormesis defines quantitative limits of biological and phenotypic plasticity for integrative endpoints, indicating that lifespan extension is constrained within a modest range (30-60% increase at maximum), reflecting an organism's capacity to adapt to mild stress.

The hormetic response and associated lifespan extension are consistent across diverse biological models (yeast, nematodes, insects, vertebrates) and various lifespan-extending interventions (dietary supplements, pharmaceuticals, caloric restriction, exercise), suggesting a generalizable mechanism.

theories.evidence: Evaluation of several hundred lifespan-extending agents across multiple species and interventions showing consistent lifespan extension within hormetic quantitative features; references to experimental data from yeast, nematodes, insects, fish, and rodents.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how biological aging can be modulated via hormesis; it addresses aging broadly across species and interventions; it explains underlying principles of lifespan extension rather than describing narrow phenomena.

results.title: Proteasome Activators and Ageing: Restoring Proteostasis Using Small Molecules.

theories.name: Proteostasis Decline Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with a decline in cellular homeostasis and repair pathways, including proteostasis, which is the maintenance of protein folding, function, and degradation. The accumulation of damaged or misfolded proteins due to impaired proteasomal activity contributes to aging-associated cellular dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Proteasome activity as a causal mechanism
key_concepts.description: The proteasome complex is responsible for degrading damaged or unneeded proteins. Declining proteasomal activity with age leads to accumulation of proteotoxic stress, which triggers pathways that drive aging-related changes at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Small molecule proteasome activators as interventions
key_concepts.description: Small molecules that activate the proteasome can restore proteostasis by enhancing protein degradation efficiency, thereby ameliorating stress conditions, protecting neurons, restoring cognitive functions, and extending lifespan. This suggests proteasome activity modulation is a causal lever in aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of multiple genetic studies in model organisms manipulating proteasomal activities showing lifespan extension and improved healthspan; references to studies demonstrating benefits of small molecule proteasome activators on stress resistance, neuronal protection, and cognitive function.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (proteostasis decline via proteasome dysfunction) underlying aging at the organismal level, supported by evolutionary conserved pathways and intervention studies; not limited to specific organs or diseases but addresses systemic aging processes.

results.title: Biomedical challenges of human senescence: a review.

theories.name: General theories of human senescence

key_concepts.concept: Genetic and environmental factors in aging
key_concepts.description: The theory considers the interplay between genetic predispositions and environmental influences as key determinants of the aging process, suggesting that both intrinsic and extrinsic factors contribute to senescence.

This concept addresses how the immune system changes with age, particularly its declining ability to respond to infectious agents, which is proposed as a significant mechanism influencing overall aging and vulnerability.
Aging is viewed as a complex process influenced by multiple biological and clinical factors, including but not limited to genetics, environment, immune function, and public health improvements.

theories.evidence: Summary and discussion of published original research and reviews over the past one hundred years, addressing various hypotheses and mechanisms involved in aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper addresses aging broadly at the organism level, discusses causal mechanisms including genetic and environmental factors and immune system behavior, and synthesizes multiple hypotheses, thus meeting the criteria for an aging theory-related paper.

results.title: Xenotopic synthetic biology: Prospective tools for delaying aging and age-related diseases.

theories.name: Metabolic dysregulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic dysregulation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that disruptions in metabolic processes are a fundamental cause of aging and age-related deterioration. It suggests that age-associated changes in metabolism contribute causally to the aging phenotype.

key_concepts.concept: Use of non-mammalian enzymes to reverse metabolic aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that enzymes derived from lower organisms can modulate key metabolic parameters linked to aging, such as amino acid levels, redox potentials, mitochondrial function, and reactive oxygen species, thereby potentially delaying aging.

key_concepts.concept: Targeting metabolic pathways beyond genetic manipulation
key_concepts.description: Since aging is complex and genetic interventions alone may be insufficient, this approach advocates for synthetic biology tools that introduce xenotopic enzymes to restore youthful metabolic states.

theories.evidence: Citations of various enzymes from lower organisms (e.g., METase, ASNase, NDI1, AOX) shown to affect metabolic parameters linked to aging; discussion of their biochemical roles and potential applications.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (metabolic dysregulation) underlying aging at the organismal level and suggests an intervention strategy targeting fundamental aging processes rather than specific diseases or organs.

results.title: [Key Molecular Mechanisms of Aging, Biomarkers, and Potential Interventions].

theories.name: Molecular Damage Accumulation and Homeostatic Decline Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is initiated by molecular damage that accumulates over time, causing defects at the cellular level. These lesions trigger cellular stress responses aimed at compensating for damage.
The cellular and systemic mechanisms responsible for maintaining homeostasis and repairing damage gradually lose efficiency with age, leading to an inability to fully recover from molecular errors.

key_concepts.concept: Phase transition from health to disease
key_concepts.description: When accumulated errors in regulatory networks surpass a critical threshold, the organism undergoes a systemic shift from a healthy state to disease, marking a fundamental aging-related decline.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews molecular, cellular, tissue, and systemic level mechanisms, discusses biomarkers of aging, and considers interventions; evidence is drawn from existing literature as it is a review.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging as a systemic process driven by molecular damage accumulation and homeostatic failure, applicable at organismal level.

results.title: Maximising the yeast chronological lifespan.
The two faces of oxygen.

theories.name: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) Damage Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Reactive oxygen species are byproducts of metabolism that cause damage to a wide variety of cellular molecules, contributing to aging by accumulating molecular damage over time.
An organism's ability to repair ROS-induced damage diminishes with age, leading to increased molecular and cellular dysfunction.
Enhancing protective enzymes that counteract ROS damage has been shown to extend lifespan in some invertebrate models, supporting a causal role of ROS in aging.
Recent findings suggest ROS also have important roles in normal cell signaling, indicating a more complex relationship with aging than solely causing damage.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies extending invertebrate lifespan by enhancing protective enzymes; recent studies revealing ROS roles in cell signaling.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (ROS-induced damage accumulation) explaining why aging occurs, with evolutionary and biochemical rationale; addresses organism-level aging; discusses both damage and signaling roles.

results.title: Role of fruits in aging and age-related disorders.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that aging results from the accumulation of damage caused by reactive oxygen species (ROS) and free radicals, which impair cellular components and functions over time.

theories.evidence: The abstract references oxidative stress as one of the mechanisms controlling and initiating aging, citing it among other factors.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain a fundamental biological process underlying aging, proposes a causal mechanism, and is broadly applicable beyond specific organs or diseases.

theories.name: Telomere Shortening Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This theory suggests that progressive shortening of telomeres during cell division leads to cellular senescence and contributes to organismal aging by limiting regenerative capacity.

theories.evidence: Telomere shortening is mentioned as one of the mechanisms initiating aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a causal explanation for aging at the cellular level with implications for organismal aging, and is a broadly recognized aging theory.

theories.name: AMP-Activated Protein Kinase (AMPK) and Sirtuin-1 (SIRT1) Pathway Theory

key_concepts.description: This concept involves energy-sensing pathways that regulate metabolism, stress resistance, and longevity. Activation of AMPK and SIRT1 is proposed to promote healthy aging by enhancing cellular maintenance and repair mechanisms.

theories.evidence: The abstract lists AMPK and SIRT1 as mechanisms controlling and initiating aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes mechanistic pathways influencing aging processes at the organismal level, linking metabolism and longevity.

results.title: Carrying Excess Baggage Can Slowdown Life: Protein Clearance Machineries That Go Awry During Aging and the Relevance of Maintaining Them.

theories.name: Proteostasis Decline Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The proteostasis network comprises proteolytic machineries, chaperones, and their regulators that coordinate protein synthesis, folding, transport, and degradation to maintain cellular protein homeostasis.

During aging, endogenous and external stresses reduce the capacity of the proteostasis network, leading to impaired clearance of aberrant and aggregated proteins, which compromises proteome integrity and fundamental physiological processes.

The decline in proteostasis affects organismal functions including reproductive fitness and contributes to age-associated pathological consequences, such as neurodegenerative diseases characterized by protein aggregation.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews known associations between impaired protein clearance and neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, discusses proteome-wide changes during aging, and considers genetic and pharmacological interventions to augment proteostasis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs via decline in protein quality control systems affecting the whole organism; it addresses fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases and discusses underlying causes.

results.title: Recent Advances in Anti-Aging Therapeutic Strategies Targeting DNA Damage Response and Senescence-Associated Secretory Phenotype-Linked Signaling Cascade.

theories.name: DNA Damage Response (DDR) and Senescence-Associated Secretory Phenotype (SASP) Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: DDR is a cellular signaling cascade activated by DNA damage such as telomere shortening, tumor formation, and mitochondrial dysfunction. Persistent DDR signaling involves proteins like MDC1, 53BP1, H2AX, ATM, ARF, P53, PI3K-Akt, BRAF, Sirtuins, and NAD+, which collectively contribute to cellular aging by promoting cell cycle arrest.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular Senescence and Cell Cycle Arrest
key_concepts.description: Cells undergoing persistent DDR enter a permanent state of cell cycle arrest known as senescence. This arrest prevents proliferation but leads to functional decline and contributes to organismal aging.

Senescent cells secrete a variety of pro-inflammatory and tissue remodeling factors collectively termed SASP. SASP factors promote age-related tissue dysfunction and contribute to the development of age-associated diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Faulty DNA Repair and Accelerated Aging
key_concepts.description: Impairments in DNA repair mechanisms exacerbate the accumulation of senescent cells and SASP, accelerating aging and increasing susceptibility to age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews known molecular players in DDR and SASP signaling pathways and their roles in aging. It cites signaling molecules and pathways involved in DDR and senescence, and discusses their contribution to aging and age-related diseases. It also explores therapeutic strategies targeting these pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs at the organismal level through DNA damage accumulation, persistent DDR signaling, and senescence. It addresses fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases or organs and discusses underlying molecular mechanisms.

results.title: Aging reshapes the adaptive immune system from healer to saboteur.

theories.name: Adaptive immunity deterioration theory of aging

key_concepts.description: With aging, adaptive immune function declines, reducing the ability to detect and clear damaged or senescent cells. This impairment indirectly disrupts tissue homeostasis and regenerative capacity, contributing to systemic aging.
Aged adaptive immune cells often acquire harmful phenotypes that promote chronic inflammation (inflammaging), tissue damage, and cellular senescence, directly exacerbating age-associated pathologies.
Maintenance of tissue and microbiota homeostasis in the gut by adaptive immunity is crucial for healthy aging, and its disruption with age has systemic consequences.

theories.evidence: The paper is a Perspective discussing mechanisms and citing existing literature linking adaptive immunity decline to inflammaging, senescence, and age-related diseases; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how aging of the adaptive immune system drives systemic aging processes, with broad organism-level implications beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: The interplay between tauopathy and aging through interruption of UPR/Nrf2/autophagy crosstalk in the Alzheimer's disease transgenic experimental models.

theories.name: Tauopathy-accelerated brain aging via disruption of UPR/Nrf2/autophagy crosstalk

key_concepts.concept: Tauopathy as a driver of accelerated aging
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of pathological tau protein aggregates (tauopathy) is proposed to accelerate brain aging processes, leading to earlier onset of aging-related cellular dysfunction.
UPR, a cellular stress response related to endoplasmic reticulum stress, is upregulated in tauopathy, indicating that protein misfolding stress contributes to aging-related neurotoxicity.

Alterations in redox signaling pathways, including activation of Nrf2 and changes in antioxidant levels, are implicated in the interaction between tauopathy and aging, suggesting oxidative stress as a mechanistic link.
Autophagy, a key cellular degradation and recycling process, is disrupted in tauopathy models, which may reduce cellular clearance capacity and contribute to accelerated aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from transgenic Drosophila expressing human tauR406W showing earlier onset of aging markers (UPR, redox signaling, autophagy changes) compared to controls; bioinformatic analysis of tauPS19 transgenic mice microarray data supporting increased expression of aging-related stress response genes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking tauopathy-induced cellular stress responses (UPR, oxidative stress, autophagy) to accelerated brain aging, addressing organism-level aging processes beyond a single disease phenotype.

results.title: What matters in aging is signaling for responsiveness.

theories.name: Signaling for Responsiveness Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by a decline in the organism's capacity to adapt to internal and external environmental changes through physiological and behavioral mechanisms, leading to deterioration in maintenance, survival, and growth processes.

Signaling systems are the vital link that governs physiological responsiveness, mediating the organism's ability to respond to environmental and internal stimuli, and their impairment is a key driver of aging-related decline.
Intervening in aging by restoring compromised signaling and responsiveness mechanisms offers a novel mechanistic approach to control aging and treat age-related disorders.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review that discusses existing knowledge about signaling systems and responsiveness decline with aging; it proposes a new perspective on targeting these systems for intervention but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (decline in signaling-mediated responsiveness) underlying aging at the organism level, linking physiological decline to aging processes broadly, and suggests intervention strategies targeting this mechanism.

results.title: Telomere Dynamics in Zebrafish Aging and Disease.

theories.name: Telomere Shortening Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere attrition as a systemic aging driver
key_concepts.description: Telomere shortening in specific tissues not only triggers cellular senescence locally but also causes widespread organ dysfunction through interorgan communication, thereby influencing the aging process at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Interorgan communication mediated by telomere dynamics
key_concepts.description: Shortening of telomeres in one organ can propagate signals through biological networks affecting other tissues, suggesting a systemic mechanism by which aging progresses beyond isolated cellular events.

key_concepts.concept: Zebrafish as a model for studying telomere-related aging
key_concepts.description: Zebrafish telomere biology closely resembles that of humans, making them a valuable model to investigate how telomere dynamics impact systemic aging and disease, providing insights relevant to human health and longevity.

theories.evidence: Comparative telomere length data across fish species; emerging zebrafish model studies showing systemic effects of telomere shortening; literature citations on telomere biology and aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how telomere shortening drives systemic aging through interorgan communication, addressing organism-level aging beyond cellular senescence, thus meeting all core criteria.

results.title: In vivo cyclic induction of the FOXM1 transcription factor delays natural and progeroid aging phenotypes and extends healthspan.

theories.name: FOXM1 repression and senescence-associated aging theory

key_concepts.concept: FOXM1 transcription factor role in aging
key_concepts.description: FOXM1 is a transcription factor with both transcriptional and non-transcriptional functions essential for cellular homeostasis. Its repression during cellular aging contributes to the development of senescence phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: FOXM1 repression as a causal driver of cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: The downregulation of FOXM1 during aging leads to cellular senescence, which is a hallmark of aging. Restoring FOXM1 expression can reverse senescence phenotypes at the cellular level.

key_concepts.concept: FOXM1 genetic rewiring delays organismal aging
key_concepts.description: Cyclic induction of FOXM1 in vivo in both progeroid and naturally aged mice reinstates FOXM1 functions, mitigates cellular aging hallmarks, delays aging phenotypes, and extends lifespan, suggesting FOXM1 repression is causally linked to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from in vivo cyclic induction of an N-terminal truncated FOXM1 transgene in progeroid and naturally aged mice showing mitigation of aging hallmarks, improved molecular and histopathological features, and lifespan extension.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (FOXM1 repression) underlying aging at the organismal level, supported by experimental intervention in mice models, and addresses both natural and progeroid aging broadly rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Longevity Pathways (mTOR, SIRT, Insulin/IGF-1) as Key Modulatory Targets on Aging and Neurodegeneration.

theories.name: Longevity signaling pathways theory (mTOR, SIRT, IIS)

key_concepts.description: The mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway regulates cell growth, metabolism, and protein synthesis. It is implicated in aging and neurodegeneration by modulating processes such as stress response and brain plasticity.
Sirtuins are NAD+-dependent deacetylases involved in cellular stress resistance, metabolism, and longevity. They influence aging by regulating gene expression and promoting cellular homeostasis.

The IIS pathway controls metabolism, growth, and lifespan. Alterations in IIS signaling are linked to aging and age-related diseases, including neurodegeneration, by affecting cellular maintenance and stress responses.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews epidemiologic studies and current advances in understanding these pathways, citing their roles in metabolism, cognition, stress response, brain plasticity, and differences between normal aging and neurodegeneration.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses fundamental, organism-level aging mechanisms through well-established signaling pathways that modulate aging and neurodegeneration. It proposes causal mechanisms underlying aging processes and discusses their generalizability beyond specific diseases.

results.title: The intricate link between circadian rhythms and aging: can resetting our circadian clock hold the key to longevity?

theories.name: Circadian Clock Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: The circadian clock controls daily physiological processes that influence aging. Disruptions in circadian rhythms can lead to metabolic dysfunction, impaired immune responses, increased DNA damage, and higher susceptibility to age-related diseases, suggesting a causal role in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Circadian clock influences key aging molecular pathways
key_concepts.description: The circadian clock modulates molecular pathways implicated in aging, including insulin/IGF signaling, mTOR, and sirtuin pathways. These pathways are known regulators of lifespan and healthspan, linking circadian regulation to fundamental aging mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Interventions targeting circadian rhythms can promote healthy aging
key_concepts.description: Maintaining robust circadian rhythms through lifestyle interventions such as regular sleep-wake cycles, time-restricted feeding, and physical activity may extend healthspan and longevity. This suggests that circadian rhythm maintenance is a potential strategy to mitigate aging-related decline.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known associations between circadian disruption and aging phenotypes, and mentions molecular pathways linked to aging regulated by the circadian clock. It also cites interventions that maintain circadian rhythms and their potential benefits, likely based on existing literature.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how aging occurs at an organismal level via circadian regulation, proposes causal mechanisms linking circadian disruption to aging processes, and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a single organ or disease. Thus, it meets the core requirements for an aging theory.

results.title: Mitochondrial DNA Mutations and Ageing.

theories.name: Mitochondrial DNA Mutation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria are essential organelles involved in energy production and other cellular processes. Dysfunction in mitochondria, particularly due to mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), is proposed to impair oxidative phosphorylation capacity, which may contribute to the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Causal role of mtDNA mutations in aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that accumulation of mutations in mitochondrial DNA leads to progressive decline in mitochondrial function, which in turn causes cellular and tissue aging. However, there is debate whether these mutations are a cause or consequence of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction in stem cell aging and inflammation
key_concepts.description: Recent findings suggest that mitochondrial dysfunction due to mtDNA mutations may affect stem cell function and contribute to age-related inflammation, linking mitochondrial genetics to systemic aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews current evidence on mitochondrial DNA mutations affecting oxidative phosphorylation and mitochondrial function, and discusses recent discoveries related to stem cell aging and inflammation. It cites prior studies linking mtDNA mutations to aging phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process at the organismal level by proposing mitochondrial DNA mutations as a causal mechanism. It addresses general aging rather than a specific disease or organ, and discusses underlying mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Explaining tip-of-the-tongue experiences in older adults: The role of brain-based and cardiorespiratory fitness factors.
Peripheral Immunosenescence and Central Neuroinflammation: A Dangerous Liaison - A Dietary Approach.

theories.name: Inflamm-aging and Neuroinflammation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging leads to impaired innate and adaptive immune responses, resulting in a systemic proinflammatory state known as inflamm-aging. This immune dysfunction is a fundamental driver of aging-related systemic changes.

key_concepts.concept: Neuroinflammation as a consequence of peripheral immune changes
key_concepts.description: Peripheral immune dysregulation causes inflammatory mediators to cross the blood-brain barrier, activating microglia and infiltrating T cells in the CNS. This triggers a cascade of free radical production and proinflammatory cytokines, leading to neuronal damage and neurodegeneration.

An age-related shift towards proinflammatory Th17 cells over anti-inflammatory T regulatory cells in the brain contributes to a chronic proinflammatory environment, exacerbating neuroinflammation and neuronal injury.

Dietary components such as polyunsaturated fatty acids, polyphenols, micronutrients, and pre/probiotics can modulate immune responses by reducing oxidative stress and inflammation, potentially mitigating age-related immune dysfunction and neurodegeneration.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known mechanisms of immune aging and neuroinflammation, involvement of microglia and T cells, and the impact of dietary compounds, citing typical neurodegenerative diseases as examples. No new experimental data are presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains a fundamental aging process (immune system dysregulation leading to systemic and CNS aging), proposes causal mechanisms (immune impairment causing inflamm-aging and neuroinflammation), and addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow disease or organ. The dietary modulation aspect links to intervention but within the theoretical framework.

results.title: [NAD<sup>+</sup> metabolism as a target for anti-aging].

theories.name: NAD+ Metabolism and Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by disruptions in pathways that sense and respond to nutritional and metabolic states, with NAD+ playing a central regulatory role.

key_concepts.concept: NAD+ as a regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: NAD+ functions as a co-factor in energy metabolism and as a substrate for enzymes like sirtuins, PARP, and CD38, which are involved in transcription, DNA repair, stress responses, inflammation, and post-transcriptional modifications.

key_concepts.concept: Age-related NAD+ decline and its consequences
key_concepts.description: With aging, increased DNA damage and chronic inflammation lead to overconsumption of NAD+ by PARP and CD38, reducing NAD+ levels, which in turn decreases sirtuin and PARP activity, impairing energy metabolism and promoting aging and related diseases.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent proposals and biological roles of NAD+, description of molecular pathways involving NAD+, and discussion of age-related changes in NAD+ metabolism; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs at the organism level through NAD+ metabolism disruption, linking molecular pathways to systemic aging processes.

results.title: Germ cells and the aging niche: a systems approach to reproductive longevity.

theories.name: Niche-Germ Cell Interaction Theory of Reproductive Aging

key_concepts.description: The microenvironment or niche surrounding germ cells changes dynamically with age, influencing the function and longevity of germ cells. This niche is not static but undergoes age-related signaling alterations that impact reproductive capacity.

A comprehensive approach integrating genetics, epigenetics, and cellular behavior data (multi-omics) is necessary to understand the complex interactions between germ cells and their niche, highlighting the systemic nature of reproductive aging.

Epigenetic modifications such as DNA methylation and histone acetylation play a critical role in regulating communication between germ cells and their niche, affecting reproductive aging and potentially modulating reproductive lifespan.

theories.evidence: Citations and evidence from model organisms like Drosophila and C. elegans demonstrating age-related changes in niche signaling affecting germ cell function; integration of multi-omics data and epigenetic studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for reproductive aging at the organismal level, focusing on the interaction between germ cells and their niche as a fundamental aging process rather than a narrow phenomenon. It addresses causal explanations (niche signaling changes and epigenetic modulation) and is broadly applicable to reproductive aging.

results.title: The immunosenescence clock: A new method for evaluating biological age and predicting mortality risk.

theories.name: Immunosenescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Immune system aging as a driver of biological aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that changes in the immune system, including alterations in immune cell abundance and function, contribute fundamentally to the aging process at the organismal level. Immunosenescence reflects a decline or dysregulation of immune function that impacts overall physiological aging.

key_concepts.concept: Use of omics data to capture immune aging
key_concepts.description: The approach integrates transcriptomic and proteomic data from peripheral blood mononuclear cells to quantify immune system changes, aiming to provide a comprehensive measure of immune age that correlates with biological age and mortality risk.

Factors that accelerate or delay immunosenescence are summarized, implying that immune aging is not fixed but can be influenced, which supports the concept that targeting immunosenescence could modulate overall aging and longevity.

theories.evidence: Presentation of existing immunosenescence clocks developed to date, their functional differences, and discussion of factors influencing immunosenescence; use of omics data from PBMCs; references to biological age and mortality prediction.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (immune system aging) underlying organism-level aging, provides causal explanation (immune system changes driving aging), and addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow disease or organ. The immunosenescence clock is framed as a tool to understand and predict biological aging and mortality risk, linking immune aging to systemic aging.

results.title: Tissue mosaicism following stem cell aging: blood as an exemplar.

theories.name: Stem Cell Aging and Somatic Mosaicism Theory

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by the loss of regenerative capacity in stem cells, which underlies the aging process across all tissues by reducing their ability to maintain tissue homeostasis and repair.

key_concepts.concept: Somatic mosaicism as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: With age, tissues develop cellular patchworks (somatic mosaicism) due to clonal expansions and genetic/nongenetic changes in stem cells, reflecting the accumulation of cellular heterogeneity and mutations that contribute to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Intrinsic and extrinsic factors in stem cell aging
key_concepts.description: Both cell-intrinsic changes in aged stem cells and alterations in their microenvironment (milieu) create conditions that promote somatic mosaicism and influence tissue aging.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic and nongenetic mechanisms driving mosaicism
key_concepts.description: Multiple mechanisms, including genetic mutations and epigenetic or environmental factors, contribute to the emergence of somatic mosaicism during aging.

theories.evidence: Draws on insights from hematopoietic aging literature and observations of somatic mosaicism in multiple tissues; discusses existing methodologies for detecting clonal expansions; proposes avenues for modifying mosaicism.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging at the organismal level via stem cell aging and somatic mosaicism; addresses fundamental mechanisms underlying aging broadly; not limited to a single disease or organ without connection to systemic aging.

results.title: DNA damage and its links to neuronal aging and degeneration.

theories.name: DNA damage accumulation theory of neuronal aging

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage as a driver of neuronal aging
key_concepts.description: DNA damage accumulates in neurons over time, leading to functional decline and contributing to neurodegeneration. This damage is a fundamental cause of aging-related neuronal dysfunction rather than a mere correlation.

key_concepts.concept: Chromatin organization influences DNA repair outcomes
key_concepts.description: The spatial organization of chromatin at DNA damage sites affects how effectively neurons can repair DNA lesions, linking genome architecture to aging processes in neurons.

key_concepts.concept: Programmed DNA breaks from neuronal activity
key_concepts.description: Neuronal activity induces programmed DNA breaks, which may overwhelm DNA repair mechanisms, thereby promoting neuronal dysfunction and aging.
DNA damage triggers inflammatory responses that contribute to the age-related decline in neuronal functions, linking genome instability to systemic aging effects.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent advances including next-generation sequencing revealing DNA damage hotspots, chromosome conformation capture studies on chromatin topology, and emerging evidence on DNA damage-induced inflammation.
