theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how DNA damage accumulation and repair inefficiency drive neuronal aging, with implications for organism-level aging and neurodegeneration.

results.title: Bidirectional causal associations between aging and major mental disorders: A population-based study using the two-sample mendelian randomization method from the UK biobank (AM-SRNMA 002).
Using yeast to discover the fountain of youth.

theories.name: Replicative and Chronological Aging Models in Yeast

key_concepts.description: This concept measures aging by the number of daughter cells a mother yeast cell can produce before senescence. It reflects cellular aging related to division capacity and is used as a model for mitotic cell aging.
This concept measures aging by the survival time of non-dividing yeast cells in stationary phase. It models post-mitotic aging and longevity under nutrient-deprived conditions.
Identification of individual genes in yeast that influence aging processes suggests genetic and molecular pathways can causally affect lifespan, providing mechanistic insights into aging.

theories.evidence: The paper references genetic studies in yeast identifying genes affecting aging, and presents models explaining replicative and chronological aging phenomena, supported by prior research in yeast and applicability to higher eukaryotes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain fundamental aging processes at the organismal level using yeast as a model, proposes causal genetic mechanisms, and addresses general aging phenomena (replicative and chronological aging) rather than narrow disease or organ-specific issues.

results.title: [Aging, oxygen and the gene].

theories.name: Oxygen stress (oxidative damage) theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxygen-induced damage as a cause of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that exposure to oxygen and the resulting oxidative stress cause molecular and cellular damage that accumulates over time, leading to aging and natural death. This damage is linked to the fundamental process of life itself, as oxygen metabolism is essential but also inherently damaging.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic basis of aging linked to mitochondrial function
key_concepts.description: The mev-1 mutant of C. elegans, which has a mutation in succinate-reductase cytochrome b (a mitochondrial enzyme), shows a shorter lifespan and hypersensitivity to oxygen. This suggests that mitochondrial dysfunction and the resulting oxidative stress are causally involved in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Aging as an inevitable consequence of life processes
key_concepts.description: The theory frames aging and natural death as unavoidable outcomes of the biological processes that sustain life, implying that life itself carries intrinsic limitations that prevent eternal survival.

theories.evidence: Isolation and characterization of the mev-1 mutant in C. elegans with shorter lifespan and oxygen hypersensitivity; identification of mutation in mitochondrial succinate-reductase cytochrome b; references to widely accepted evidence linking oxygen stress and possibly apoptosis to aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (oxidative damage) underlying aging applicable at the organism level; links genetic and biochemical mechanisms to aging; addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow phenomenon; provides causal explanation rather than mere correlation.

results.title: From White to Brown - Adipose Tissue Is Critical to the Extended Lifespan and Healthspan of Growth Hormone Mutant Mice.

theories.name: Growth Hormone Signaling and Adipose Tissue Function in Aging

key_concepts.description: Decreased GH action is linked to extended longevity, suggesting that GH signaling pathways influence lifespan. GH affects multiple tissues including liver, muscle, and adipose tissue, and alterations in GH signaling can modulate aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Adipose Tissue (AT) as a Mediator of Aging
key_concepts.description: Adipose tissue biology and function are critical in the regulation of lifespan and healthspan, particularly in GH-mutant animals. Changes in AT, including shifts from white to brown adipose tissue, may underlie mechanisms that extend longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Intersection of GH and AT in Aging
key_concepts.description: The interaction between GH signaling and adipose tissue function is proposed as a key determinant of aging outcomes. This intersection may explain how metabolic and endocrine changes influence systemic aging and healthspan.

theories.evidence: Citations and synthesis of numerous studies over the past 20 years demonstrating links between GH action, adipose tissue alterations, and longevity in mice and humans.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking GH signaling and adipose tissue function to systemic aging and lifespan regulation. It addresses aging broadly, not limited to a single organ or disease, and discusses underlying biological mechanisms.

results.title: Dysfunctional mitochondria in age-related neurodegeneration: Utility of melatonin as an antioxidant treatment.

theories.name: Mitochondrial oxidative damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: As neurons age, mitochondrial function degrades, leading to inefficient oxidative phosphorylation and increased electron leakage from the electron transport chain. This causes elevated production of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species within mitochondria.

The increased reactive oxygen and nitrogen species cause progressive molecular damage inside mitochondria, which accelerates the decline in mitochondrial physiology and contributes to the aging process at the cellular and organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Role of melatonin as an antioxidant
key_concepts.description: Melatonin, synthesized in neuronal mitochondria, acts as a free radical scavenger and indirect antioxidant. It reduces electron leakage, detoxifies reactive species, and upregulates antioxidant enzymes via the SIRT3/FOXO pathway, thereby protecting mitochondrial function and slowing aging-related damage.

In neurodegenerative diseases, neurons often shift to Warburg-type metabolism, reducing mitochondrial acetyl coenzyme A and thus melatonin synthesis. This metabolic change increases mitochondrial susceptibility to oxidative stress and damage, linking metabolic dysfunction to aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known biochemical pathways (electron transport chain, ROS/RNS generation), melatonin synthesis and antioxidant roles, and metabolic changes in neurodegeneration; it also cites molecular pathways like SIRT3/FOXO and enzyme activities, but no new experimental data is presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (mitochondrial decline and oxidative damage accumulation) with causal mechanisms (ROS/RNS damage, metabolic shifts, antioxidant defense). It addresses aging broadly at the cellular and organismal level, not limited to a single disease, and proposes underlying causes of aging.

results.title: From aldehyde metabolism to delay aging: targeting ALDH2 as a novel strategy.

theories.name: Aldehyde-induced damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aldehydes accumulate in cells from both endogenous metabolism and environmental sources, leading to cross-linking of DNA and proteins. This molecular damage disrupts cellular functions and contributes to premature aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Role of ALDH2 in aldehyde detoxification
key_concepts.description: ALDH2 is a mitochondrial enzyme that catalyzes the oxidation of reactive aldehydes into less harmful acid metabolites, thereby reducing aldehyde-induced cellular damage. Efficient aldehyde metabolism by ALDH2 is proposed to protect cells and delay aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of ALDH2 to delay aging
key_concepts.description: Enhancing ALDH2 activity or using aldehyde scavengers could improve clearance of reactive aldehydes, safeguard cellular functions, and mitigate molecular damage. This intervention strategy is proposed as a novel approach to delay aging and treat age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Overview of aldehyde sources and metabolism, structural and functional characterization of ALDH2, and discussion of potential therapeutic strategies; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (aldehyde-induced molecular damage) underlying aging, discusses an enzymatic pathway (ALDH2) that modulates this damage, and suggests a therapeutic intervention targeting a fundamental aging process. The theory is generalizable beyond specific diseases and organs.

results.title: Cellular senescence and tumor promotion: Role of the Unfolded Protein Response.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a stress response
key_concepts.description: Senescence is described as a cellular state triggered by stress, leading to a stable cell cycle arrest and altered cellular functions. It is implicated in both physiological and pathological processes, including aging and cancer.

The ER is a key organelle involved in sensing cellular stress and maintaining proteostasis. Disruption of ER homeostasis is linked to the onset and maintenance of senescence, suggesting a mechanistic connection between proteostasis failure and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Unfolded Protein Response (UPR) activation during senescence
key_concepts.description: The UPR is a signaling pathway activated in response to accumulation of misfolded proteins in the ER. Its activation during senescence may contribute to the establishment and persistence of the senescent phenotype, potentially influencing aging and tumorigenesis.
Modulating UPR pathways could allow elimination of senescent cells or alteration of their secretory phenotype, which may prevent neoplastic transformation and impact aging-related pathologies.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing evidence linking UPR activation and ER proteostasis perturbation to senescence, citing direct evidence of ER homeostasis disruption during senescence and discussing potential therapeutic implications.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory explains a fundamental cellular mechanism (senescence) that contributes to organismal aging, proposes causal mechanisms (ER stress and UPR activation), and connects cellular processes to systemic aging and disease. Thus, it meets the criteria of generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope.

results.title: Targeting organ-specific mitochondrial dysfunction to improve biological aging.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria, as primary ATP producers and regulators of programmed cell death, are central to maintaining tissue function. Their dysfunction leads to progressive age-related decline in cellular homeostasis and organ function, contributing broadly to biological aging.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial DNA damage and reactive oxygen species (ROS) homeostasis
key_concepts.description: Damage to mitochondrial DNA and imbalance in ROS production and clearance disrupt mitochondrial function, promoting cellular and tissue aging. ROS act both as damaging agents and signaling molecules influencing aging processes.

The processes of mitochondrial biogenesis, mitophagy (turnover), and dynamic changes (fusion/fission) regulate mitochondrial quality and quantity. Dysregulation of these processes contributes to organ-specific aging phenotypes.
Different tissues have unique mitochondrial features and vulnerabilities, necessitating organ-specific approaches to understand and target mitochondrial dysfunction in aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews recent advances and preclinical/clinical studies on mitochondrial dysfunction mechanisms and therapeutic interventions targeting mitochondria across multiple organs.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (mitochondrial dysfunction) underlying aging at the organism level, discusses molecular mechanisms, and addresses multiple organ systems, thus explaining how biological aging occurs.

results.title: Inherited enhancement of hydroxyl radical generation and lipid peroxidation in the S strain rats results in DNA rearrangements, degenerative diseases, and premature aging.

theories.name: Oxidative Damage Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that increased generation of hydroxyl radicals (OH-radicals), highly reactive oxygen species, causes oxidative damage to cellular components, contributing to aging. In this paper, the S strain rats exhibit enhanced OH-radical production due to oxidation and autooxidation of accumulated monosaccharides.

Lipid peroxidation refers to the oxidative degradation of lipids in cell membranes, leading to membrane fragility and dysfunction. The paper reports enhanced lipid peroxidation in liver and myocardium tissues of S rats, linking it to cellular damage and aging phenotypes.
The accumulation of oxidative damage leads to DNA rearrangements and genomic instability, which are proposed as causal factors in degenerative diseases and premature aging observed in the S rats.

The theory connects oxidative damage to systemic aging manifestations such as cataracts, emphysema, tumors, cardiomyopathy-like changes, scoliosis, brain dysfunctions, low fertility, and shortened lifespan, indicating that oxidative stress drives organism-level aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data comparing S and R rat strains showing higher hydroxyl radical generation, lipid peroxidation, DNA rearrangements, and aging-related phenotypes in S rats; long-term inbreeding with observed genomic instability; phenotypic characterization including cataracts, tumors, and reduced lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains a fundamental biological aging process (oxidative damage) with causal mechanisms (radical generation causing molecular damage), applies broadly to organismal aging (multiple tissues and systemic phenotypes), and is supported by experimental evidence in a model organism.

results.title: Evaluation of role of oxidative stress on aging in Caenorhabditis elegans: a brief review.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that the accumulation of oxidative damage caused by reactive oxygen species (ROS) and other pro-oxidant events contributes causally to the aging process by impairing cellular components and functions over time.

key_concepts.concept: Contribution to normal aging versus disease
key_concepts.description: The theory distinguishes between oxidative stress as a driver of normal, organismal aging and its role in age-related pathologies, suggesting that oxidative stress is relevant to general aging beyond specific diseases.

Studies in Caenorhabditis elegans are used to investigate the causal role of oxidative stress in aging, with the majority of evidence supporting oxidative stress as a significant contributor to normal aging in this species.

theories.evidence: The paper evaluates and synthesizes data from C. elegans studies, including conflicting findings, to assess the role of oxidative stress in aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (oxidative damage) underlying aging at the organismal level, supported by evolutionary and experimental data in a model organism, and addresses aging broadly rather than a specific disease.

results.title: Alterations of receptors and insulin-like growth factor binding proteins in senescent cells.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: SASP is a functional trait of senescent cells involving the secretion of various factors that influence the tissue environment. It mediates autocrine and paracrine signaling that affects cellular behavior and contributes to aging-related tissue dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Alterations in receptors and insulin-like growth factor binding proteins
key_concepts.description: Changes in the production of receptors and binding proteins in senescent cells modulate the reception and transmission of SASP signals. These alterations are implicated in the induction and maintenance of senescence, as well as in aging-related structural and functional decline.
Senescent cells, through their altered signaling and secretory profiles, can promote cancer development, linking cellular senescence to age-related disease processes.

theories.evidence: Literature review summarizing current knowledge on senescence-associated changes in receptors and binding proteins, and their roles in senescence and aging-related dysfunction.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general biological aging mechanism (cellular senescence) with causal explanations involving SASP and receptor alterations, applicable broadly to organismal aging and aging-related diseases.

results.title: Delta Opioid Peptide [d-Ala2, d-Leu5]-Enkephalin Improves Physical and Cognitive Function and Increases Lifespan in Aged Female Mice.

Circadian organization of clock factors, antioxidant defenses, and cognitive genes expression, is lost in the cerebellum of aged rats. Possible targets of therapeutic strategies for the treatment of age-related cerebellar disorders.
Subfield history: Caenorhabditis elegans as a system for analysis of the genetics of aging.
Translational regulation in stress biology.

theories.name: Proteostasis loss and translational dysregulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The decline in the cellular capacity to maintain protein homeostasis, leading to accumulation of damaged or misfolded proteins, which contributes to cellular dysfunction and aging.
The accumulation of oxidative modifications to cellular components, including proteins, which impairs their function and promotes aging-related cellular decline.
Alterations in nutrient sensing pathways that affect cellular metabolism and protein synthesis, influencing aging and lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Translational regulation as sensor and effector
key_concepts.description: Changes in protein synthesis machinery act both as sensors of cellular stress and as effectors that modulate the cellular response, impacting longevity.
The theory considers whether age-associated changes in translation are beneficial adaptations to stress or harmful processes that accelerate aging.

theories.evidence: Review of literature linking age-associated stressors (proteostasis loss, oxidative damage, nutrient sensing) to changes in translation and lifespan regulation; comparison of stress-induced translational programs with aging-related protein synthesis alterations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses general mechanisms underlying aging at the organismal level by linking fundamental stressors to translational regulation, proposes causal mechanisms for aging, and discusses their impact on longevity broadly rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

results.title: Cellular aging and transformation suppression: a role for retinoic acid receptor beta 2.

theories.name: Cellular senescence as a tumor suppression mechanism mediated by retinoic acid receptor beta 2

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a programmed negative growth regulation
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is characterized by a finite proliferative capacity and acts as a program that limits cell proliferation, which is proposed to be a fundamental cellular aging process linked to organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Retinoic acid receptor beta 2 (RAR beta 2) upregulation in senescent cells
key_concepts.description: RAR beta 2 isoform transcription is selectively increased in fibroblasts with decreased proliferative capacity, independent of donor age, suggesting a role for RA signaling in regulating cellular aging and growth arrest.

key_concepts.concept: Link between senescence and tumor suppression
key_concepts.description: Genetic mechanisms controlling senescence, including RAR beta 2 expression, may also suppress neoplastic transformation, as RAR beta 2 inhibits oncogene-induced focus formation similarly to tumor suppressor p53.

theories.evidence: Expression studies of RAR isoforms in human fibroblasts from donors of various ages, nuclear run-on assays showing transcriptional upregulation of RAR beta 2, repression of protooncogene c-fos in senescent cells, and functional assays demonstrating RAR beta 2 inhibition of oncogene-induced transformation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism linking cellular senescence (a fundamental aging process) to aging and tumor suppression via RA signaling; it addresses organism-level aging processes through cellular mechanisms and proposes causal pathways.

results.title: mTORC2: A neglected player in aging regulation.

theories.name: mTOR signaling pathway as a regulator of aging

key_concepts.description: mTOR functions within two distinct complexes, mTORC1 and mTORC2, each regulating different downstream signaling pathways that impact cellular processes relevant to aging.
Aberrant activation of mTORC1 promotes pro-proliferative effects and has been extensively studied as a driver of aging progression.

Although less studied, mTORC2 is implicated in aging regulation, with genetic elimination of its unique subunits (e.g., RICTOR) shown to alleviate aging progression, suggesting a distinct and multifaceted regulatory role in cellular senescence and organismal aging.
Pharmacological inhibition of mTOR complexes, including mTORC2, is being explored for anti-aging effects, highlighting the therapeutic potential of targeting mTOR signaling pathways.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent studies showing genetic elimination of mTORC2 subunits alleviating aging progression; summary of molecular signaling regulation of mTORC2 in cellular senescence and organismal aging; overview of mTOR inhibitors research in anti-aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses mTOR signaling as a fundamental biological mechanism regulating aging at the organismal level, proposing causal roles for mTORC1 and mTORC2 complexes in aging processes. It addresses general aging mechanisms beyond specific diseases or organs and synthesizes evidence linking mTORC2 to aging regulation, thus meeting all core criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Autophagy, aging, and age-related neurodegeneration.

theories.name: Autophagy impairment theory of aging and neurodegeneration

key_concepts.concept: Autophagy as a cellular clearance mechanism
key_concepts.description: Autophagy is a conserved biological process that degrades damaged or unnecessary cellular components and recycles nutrients, playing a critical role in maintaining cellular homeostasis.

Many proteins associated with neurodegenerative diseases are substrates for autophagy, and upregulation of autophagy can reduce disease pathology by clearing toxic proteins, proinflammatory molecules, and dysfunctional organelles.

key_concepts.concept: Feedback loop between aging, autophagy impairment, and protein aggregation
key_concepts.description: Aging and mutations linked to neurodegeneration impair autophagy, which in turn reduces clearance of disease-associated proteins, leading to their accumulation and aggregation, thereby exacerbating cellular dysfunction and aging-related decline.

key_concepts.concept: Connection between autophagy inhibition and cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: Inhibition of autophagy induces neuronal and glial senescence, a state that increases with age and contributes to neurodegenerative pathology, linking autophagy dysfunction to systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: Citations of animal model studies showing autophagy upregulation ameliorates neurodegeneration; observations of autophagy impairment in aging and disease contexts; evidence linking autophagy inhibition to cellular senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process by proposing autophagy impairment as a causal mechanism driving aging and neurodegeneration at the organismal level. It addresses general aging mechanisms (cellular clearance, senescence) rather than narrow disease-specific phenomena, meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Exercise and exerkines: Mechanisms and roles in anti-aging and disease prevention.

theories.name: Exercise-induced exerkine regulation theory of aging attenuation

key_concepts.description: Exerkines are bioactive molecules secreted by various tissues (hepatokines, myokines, adipokines, osteokines, neurokines) in response to exercise. They act locally and systemically to modulate biological pathways that counteract aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Exercise modulation of mitochondrial function and inflammation
key_concepts.description: Exercise influences mitochondrial function and immune/inflammatory responses, which are key drivers of aging. By regulating these pathways through exerkines, exercise attenuates age-related functional decline and disease susceptibility.

key_concepts.concept: Promotion of tissue homeostasis and metabolic balance
key_concepts.description: Exerkines help maintain tissue homeostasis and metabolic balance, which supports healthy longevity and reduces the risk of age-related diseases such as type 2 diabetes and osteoporosis.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing existing studies on exercise, exerkines, and their roles in anti-aging and disease prevention. It cites evidence linking exercise-induced exerkines to improved mitochondrial function, immune modulation, and protection against age-related diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism by which exercise-induced exerkines modulate fundamental aging processes (inflammation, mitochondrial dysfunction) at the organismal level. It addresses aging broadly and links molecular mechanisms to systemic aging and disease prevention.

results.title: The Impact of Early Life Adversity on Peripubertal Accelerated Epigenetic Aging and Psychopathology.
Metabolic dysregulation of trained immunity in immune aging and the impact of dietary patterns.

theories.name: Trained Immunity as a Mechanism Linking Immune Aging and Age-Associated Pathologies

key_concepts.description: Trained immunity refers to the process by which the innate immune system undergoes memory-like epigenetic and metabolic reprogramming after an initial infectious challenge, leading to altered immune responses upon subsequent exposures.

Endogenous compounds such as oxidized LDL, lipoprotein(a), glucose, uric acid, and monosodium urate can induce trained immunity similarly to microbial structures, causing metabolic dysfunctions in lipids, glucose, and proteins that perpetuate a proinflammatory feedback loop.

With advanced age, homeostatic disruptions make molecular mechanisms of trained immunity susceptible to maladaptive activation, which may link immune aging to systemic age-associated diseases like cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and hyperuricemia.
Dietary patterns influence immunometabolism and can modulate trained immunity during aging, potentially impacting the balance between adaptive and maladaptive immune responses.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review discussing current knowledge and citing examples of metabolic pathways involved in trained immunity and their consequences in aging and age-related diseases; it references known endogenous inducers and metabolic dysfunctions linked to maladaptive trained immunity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it proposes a general mechanism (trained immunity metabolic reprogramming) that causally links immune system changes to systemic aging and age-associated pathologies, with generalizability beyond specific diseases and organs. It explains how metabolic and epigenetic changes in innate immunity contribute to aging processes.

results.title: A review on polyamines as promising next-generation neuroprotective and anti-aging therapy.

theories.name: Polyamine-mediated neuroprotection and anti-aging mechanism

key_concepts.concept: Polyamines as regulators of cellular functions
key_concepts.description: Polyamines such as putrescine, spermidine, and spermine are ubiquitous polycations with high brain concentrations. They regulate gene expression, ion channels, mitochondrial calcium transport, autophagy induction, and programmed cell death, which are processes relevant to aging and neurodegeneration.

key_concepts.concept: Altered polyamine metabolism linked to aging and neurodegeneration
key_concepts.description: Changes in polyamine levels and metabolism are strongly implicated in aging, stress responses, cognitive dysfunction, and neurodegenerative disorders, suggesting a causal role in these processes.

key_concepts.concept: Dietary polyamine supplementation as an anti-aging intervention
key_concepts.description: Supplementation of polyamines in the diet has been reported to induce anti-aging and antioxidant effects, improve locomotor and cognitive functions, indicating a potential therapeutic strategy to counteract neurodegeneration and aging-related decline.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies reporting polyamine roles in gene regulation, mitochondrial function, autophagy, and neuroprotection; reports on dietary supplementation effects on aging and cognitive function.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging-related process (neurodegeneration and cognitive decline) via polyamine regulation, proposing mechanisms (gene expression, autophagy, mitochondrial function) that causally link polyamines to aging. Although focused on neuroprotection, it connects to general aging mechanisms and systemic aging processes, meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: Towards a life prolonging pill? Small molecules with anti-ageing properties.
Molecular imaging for senescent cells-targeted therapeutics in aging and age-related diseases.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells as causal drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate with age and contribute to aging and age-related diseases by adopting a permanent cell cycle arrest and altering tissue function.
Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory cytokines, proteases, and other factors that disrupt tissue microenvironments and promote systemic aging phenotypes.
Removing senescent cells using senolytics or modulating their phenotype with senomorphics can delay aging processes and ameliorate age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies showing that clearance of senescent cells delays aging and treats age-related diseases; description of senescent cell phenotypes; discussion of senolytics and senomorphics research.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it explains a general causal mechanism of aging applicable organism-wide, proposes why senescent cells drive aging, and discusses therapeutic interventions targeting this mechanism.

results.title: Mitochondrial genetics of aging: intergenomic conflict resolution.

theories.name: Mitochondrial Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS)
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria produce the majority of reactive oxygen species as byproducts of aerobic respiration. These ROS are highly reactive and can damage cellular components, contributing to the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Intergenomic conflict between mitochondrial and nuclear genomes
key_concepts.description: The evolutionary fusion of mitochondrial and nuclear genomes has led to complex biochemical and genetic interactions. Conflicts between these genomes influence mitochondrial function and may impact aging mechanisms.

Communication between mitochondrial and nuclear genomes regulates cellular energy and stress responses. This cross-talk is implicated in aging and may reveal new pathways for understanding and potentially modulating aging.

theories.mode: discuss, review, propose new paths for investigation
theories.evidence: Discussion of evolutionary history of mitochondria, biochemical and genetic conflicts, and their role in generating ROS implicated in aging; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (mitochondrial ROS and intergenomic conflict) underlying aging at the organism level, discusses evolutionary and biochemical bases, and addresses systemic aging processes.

results.title: Carcinogenesis, genetic instability and genomic entropy: insight derived from malignant brain tumor age specific mortality rate dynamics.

theories.name: Genomic Entropy Theory of Aging-Related Carcinogenesis

key_concepts.description: Aging-related carcinogenesis is attributed to inherent genetic instability that accumulates over time, leading to activation of oncogenes and inactivation of tumor suppressor genes. This instability is viewed as a fundamental aging process influencing cancer development.

The theory proposes that the genome undergoes an increase in informational entropy with age, reflecting a loss of genetic information integrity. This entropy increase is linked to the multistep genetic abnormalities observed in malignant brain tumors and is considered a thermodynamic measure of aging at the genomic level.

Using the Strehler-Mildvan modification of the Gompertz mortality model, the paper interprets age-specific mortality rates of malignant brain tumors as reflecting the rate of increase in genomic entropy. This approach connects mortality dynamics with fundamental aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Analysis of age-specific malignant brain tumor mortality rates in the US (1962-1988) using Gompertzian models and thermodynamic interpretation of genomic entropy; references to genetic abnormalities in oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (genomic entropy increase) explaining aging-related carcinogenesis, linking genetic instability to systemic aging processes and mortality dynamics. It addresses aging broadly through genome-level changes and mortality patterns rather than focusing narrowly on cancer alone.

results.title: Mapping the immune-genetic architecture of aging: A single-cell causal framework for biomarker discovery and therapeutic targeting.
NIPSNAP1 and NIPSNAP2 facilitate healthy aging independent of mitophagy.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a causal driver of aging

key_concepts.description: The maintenance of mitochondrial function and integrity is crucial for cellular health. NIPSNAP1 and NIPSNAP2 proteins are involved in mitochondrial quality control mechanisms that help preserve mitochondrial physiology.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction leads to systemic aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Loss of NIPSNAP1/2 impairs mitochondrial function, which results in metabolic shifts (enhanced glycolysis), muscle weakness, frailty, and increased fibrosis and inflammation in multiple organs, linking mitochondrial health directly to organismal aging.

Despite accumulation of Parkin, a key mitophagy regulator, mitophagy was not affected by NIPSNAP1/2 loss, suggesting that these proteins facilitate healthy aging through mitochondrial quality control pathways distinct from mitophagy.

theories.evidence: Generation of Nipsnap1/2 double knockout mice, physiological assessments showing impaired mitochondrial function, metabolic changes, muscle strength decline, organ fibrosis and inflammation, and RNA-seq data revealing pro-aging transcriptome reprogramming.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking mitochondrial quality control to systemic aging, supported by mechanistic and organism-level evidence, addressing aging broadly rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific phenomenon.

results.title: [Relationship between atherosclerosis and the aging process].

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Free radicals, such as reactive oxygen species, cause cellular injury by damaging vascular endothelial cells, which is implicated in aging and related pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress linking aging and atherogenesis
key_concepts.description: Increased serum lipid peroxides and active oxygen species produced by macrophages contribute to the initiation and progression of atherosclerosis, suggesting oxidative damage as a causal mechanism connecting aging and vascular disease.

key_concepts.concept: Role of oxidized LDL and inflammatory cells
key_concepts.description: Oxidized low density lipoprotein (LDL) is incorporated by macrophages, promoting atheroma formation, indicating that oxidative modification of lipids and immune cell activation are key processes in aging-related vascular pathology.

theories.evidence: Review of studies showing increased serum lipid peroxide levels, macrophage activity producing active oxygen, platelet aggregation induced by H2O2, and chemotactic effects of thrombin and oxidized LDL on smooth muscle cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (oxidative damage by free radicals) explaining aging at the organism level, linking vascular aging and systemic aging processes.

results.title: Roles of chromatin and genome instability in cellular senescence and their relevance to ageing and related diseases.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is described as a state of irreversible cell-growth arrest accompanied by functional deterioration, which acts as a pivotal driver of organismal aging by impairing tissue function and promoting age-related pathologies.
Mechanisms such as heterochromatin loss, telomere attrition, and DNA damage contribute to genome instability, which triggers cellular senescence and thereby promotes aging and related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammation and innate immunity in aging
key_concepts.description: Genome instability and cellular senescence activate innate immune responses and inflammation, which further exacerbate tissue dysfunction and aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of chromatin and genome stability
key_concepts.description: Emerging strategies aim to restore heterochromatin stability, maintain telomere integrity, and enhance DNA repair capacity to counteract cellular senescence and delay aging-associated diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing literature on heterochromatin loss, telomere attrition, DNA damage, and their roles in cellular senescence and aging; discusses therapeutic approaches; outlines research challenges and future directions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it addresses aging as a fundamental biological process, proposes cellular senescence driven by genome instability as a causal mechanism, and discusses organism-level aging and related diseases.

results.title: Sirtuins: common targets in aging and in neurodegeneration.

theories.name: Sirtuin-mediated regulation of aging and neurodegeneration

key_concepts.concept: Sirtuins as genetic regulators of lifespan
key_concepts.description: Sirtuins, members of the Sir2 family of NAD(+)-dependent deacetylases, have been shown to regulate longevity in model organisms such as yeast, worms, and flies. This suggests a conserved role for sirtuins in modulating aging processes at a genetic and molecular level.

key_concepts.concept: Cross talk between sirtuins and age-related neurodegenerative disorders
key_concepts.description: In mammals, seven sirtuin homologs (Sirt1-7) potentially coordinate to influence both aging and the onset or progression of neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and Huntington's diseases. This implies that sirtuins may link fundamental aging mechanisms with disease pathogenesis.

Because of their regulatory role in aging and neurodegeneration, sirtuins are considered promising targets for therapeutic interventions aimed at modulating aging processes and treating age-related neurodegenerative disorders.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known lifespan regulation by sirtuins in model organisms and their homologs in mammals, as well as their involvement in neurodegenerative diseases, citing prior research without presenting new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how sirtuins regulate aging as a fundamental process and their mechanistic role in linking aging with neurodegeneration, thus meeting the criteria of generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope.

results.title: The interplay between circadian rhythms and aging: molecular mechanisms and therapeutic strategies.

theories.name: Circadian Rhythm Disruption Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Circadian rhythms as regulators of physiological functions
key_concepts.description: Circadian rhythms operate on a roughly 24-hour cycle and regulate key biological processes such as sleep, cognitive function, immune responses, and hormone secretion. These rhythms are controlled by core clock genes including BMAL1 and Per2.

key_concepts.concept: Age-related circadian disruption contributes to systemic aging
key_concepts.description: With aging, circadian rhythms become disrupted, leading to altered sleep patterns and impaired regulation of physiological systems. This disruption is implicated in the progression of neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, as well as metabolic disorders such as obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease.

key_concepts.concept: Molecular mechanisms linking circadian genes to aging
key_concepts.description: Core clock genes (e.g., BMAL1, Per2) play regulatory roles in maintaining circadian homeostasis. Changes in their expression or function with age may drive molecular pathways that contribute to aging phenotypes and disease progression.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of circadian pathways to promote healthy aging
key_concepts.description: Interventions including pharmacological agents and lifestyle modifications aimed at restoring or optimizing circadian rhythms are proposed as promising strategies to extend lifespan and improve quality of life during aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies linking circadian disruption to neurodegenerative and metabolic diseases; discussion of molecular roles of CLOCK genes; presentation of emerging therapeutic approaches targeting circadian pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging through circadian rhythm disruption affecting systemic physiological regulation. It addresses broad aging processes and suggests underlying molecular mechanisms and intervention strategies.

results.title: Psychological and metabolic stress: a recipe for accelerated cellular aging?

theories.name: Stress-induced cellular senescence theory

key_concepts.description: Chronic stress, including psychological stress and metabolic stress from overeating, leads to hormonal imbalances such as elevated cortisol and insulin and suppression of anabolic hormones, creating a biochemical environment that promotes aging.
The combined effects of stress and visceral fat accumulation promote systemic inflammation and oxidative stress, which are key drivers of cellular aging mechanisms.

Stress-induced biochemical changes dampen telomerase activity, leading to telomere length shortening and increased cellular senescence, particularly in immune cells, linking stress to accelerated biological aging and chronic disease.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews hormonal and metabolic pathways, links chronic stress to telomere shortening and immune cell senescence, and discusses associations with chronic diseases and mortality; it also considers gene-environment interactions and potential interventions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how chronic stress accelerates biological aging at the organism level through cellular senescence and telomere dynamics, with broad implications beyond specific diseases.

results.title: Discovering geroprotectors through the explainable artificial intelligence-based platform AgeXtend.
IL-1 signaling in aging and cancer: An inflammaging feedback loop unveiled.
Mitochondrial dysfunction in mammalian ageing.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.description: With increasing age, mammals accumulate mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which correlates with deteriorating mitochondrial respiratory chain function. This accumulation is proposed to contribute causally to aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Respiratory chain deficiency and cell loss
key_concepts.description: A subset of cells in various tissues exhibit mosaic respiratory chain deficiency, leading to increased apoptosis and cell loss, which is implicated as a mechanism underlying age-associated mitochondrial dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) and mitochondrial dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Although mitochondrial dysfunction has often been linked to increased ROS production as a cause of aging, experimental evidence, especially from mouse models with mtDNA mutations, shows minimal or no increase in oxidative stress, challenging the ROS-centric view.

theories.evidence: Correlative data showing increased mtDNA mutations and respiratory chain deficiency in aged human tissues; mouse experimental models linking somatic mtDNA mutations to aging phenotypes; mouse models showing little oxidative stress despite respiratory chain deficiency.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory attempts to explain aging as a fundamental process via mitochondrial dysfunction; proposes causal mechanisms involving mtDNA mutations and respiratory chain deficiency; addresses aging broadly across multiple tissues and phenotypes.

results.title: C. elegans gives the dirt on aging.

theories.name: Insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathway theory of aging

key_concepts.description: This pathway regulates metabolism and development and has been shown to influence lifespan in C. elegans. Reduced signaling through this pathway is associated with increased longevity, suggesting it plays a causal role in aging.

A network of genes controls aging processes, with the insulin/IGF-1 pathway being a central component. These genetic networks integrate environmental and internal signals to modulate aging at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic and developmental control of aging
key_concepts.description: Metabolic activity and developmental timing are linked to aging, with pathways that regulate these processes influencing lifespan and aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: Molecular characterization of pathways in C. elegans, presentations at a recent conference expanding knowledge of genetic networks controlling aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining aging at the organism level, supported by genetic and molecular data in a model organism with implications for broader biology.

theories.name: Mitochondrial activity theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial activity influences aging by affecting cellular energy metabolism and the generation of reactive oxygen species, which can cause damage contributing to aging.

theories.evidence: Mentioned as one of the pathways controlling lifespan in C. elegans, with molecular studies characterizing its role.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental biological mechanism with causal implications for aging at the organismal level.

theories.name: Reproduction-related aging theory

key_concepts.description: Reproductive processes and signals influence lifespan, potentially through resource allocation trade-offs or hormonal regulation affecting aging.

theories.evidence: Identified as one of the pathways controlling lifespan in C. elegans, with molecular characterization.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Potentially meets criteria as it links reproduction to systemic aging mechanisms, but details are limited in the abstract.

results.title: Targeted partial reprogramming of age-associated cell states improves markers of health in mouse models of aging.

theories.name: Cellular senescence and epigenetic dysregulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Aging involves increased cellular senescence, where aged or stressed cells enter a state of permanent growth arrest and secrete proinflammatory factors that contribute to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging.
Aging is associated with dysregulation of the epigenome, leading to altered gene expression patterns that reduce cellular rejuvenation capacity and promote age-related phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Partial cellular reprogramming to reverse aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Targeted expression of reprogramming factors (OSK) in aged or stressed cells can partially reset epigenetic marks and reduce senescence-associated inflammation, improving health markers and extending lifespan.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from mouse models of Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome and naturally aged wild-type mice showing reduced proinflammatory cytokines, improved hematopoietic stem cell composition, delayed aging phenotypes, extended lifespan, and improved wound healing after targeted partial reprogramming; also human fibroblast data showing reduced inflammation gene expression.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism for aging involving cellular senescence and epigenetic dysregulation at the organismal level, supported by intervention experiments that test and manipulate these mechanisms to affect aging outcomes.

results.title: [Aging and hemispheric cerebral lateralization].

theories.name: Age-Related Asymmetry Reduction Model (HAROLD Model)

key_concepts.concept: Reduction of hemispheric asymmetry with age
key_concepts.description: This model suggests that older adults show less lateralized brain activity, with increased bilateral activation during cognitive tasks. This reduction in asymmetry may reflect compensatory mechanisms or dedifferentiation (loss of neural specialization) in the aging brain.

Dedifferentiation posits that bilateral activation reflects a decline in the ability to recruit specialized neural circuits, while compensation suggests that bilateral activation is an adaptive response to maintain cognitive function despite aging-related decline.

theories.evidence: Brain imaging studies documenting reduced asymmetry and bilateral activation patterns in older adults
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria: addresses a general brain aging phenomenon and proposes mechanistic interpretations (dedifferentiation, compensation). However, it focuses on neural activity patterns rather than fundamental causes of aging at the organism level, limiting its generalizability as a broad aging theory.

theories.name: Right Hemi-Aging Model

key_concepts.description: This model proposes that the right cerebral hemisphere ages faster or deteriorates earlier than the left hemisphere, leading to changes in hemispheric asymmetry observed in elderly individuals. It is supported primarily by behavioral studies indicating differential decline.

theories.evidence: Behavioral studies supporting differential aging of the right hemisphere
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria partially: attempts to explain a general aging-related change in brain lateralization, proposes a causal mechanism (right hemisphere ages faster), and addresses aging broadly in the brain. However, it is focused on cerebral lateralization and cognitive aging rather than systemic organismal aging, so its generalizability to overall biological aging is limited.

results.title: Inflammaging is driven by upregulation of innate immune receptors and systemic interferon signaling and is ameliorated by dietary restriction.

theories.name: Inflammaging as a driver of systemic aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by persistent, low-level inflammation across multiple tissues, termed inflammaging, which contributes to increased risk of age-related diseases.
During aging, there is an upregulation of innate immune system receptors, which leads to enhanced immune activation and inflammatory signaling.
Interferon regulatory factors and Stat1-mediated transcription activate interferon signaling pathways, promoting the inflammatory state associated with aging.
Aging induces chromatin opening that facilitates transcriptional upregulation of the inflammaging gene network, linking epigenetic changes to inflammatory gene expression.
Dietary restriction ameliorates inflammaging by reversing chromatin accessibility and transcriptional changes in the inflammaging network, highlighting a potential intervention mechanism.

theories.evidence: Multi-tissue gene network analysis showing chromatin and transcriptional changes; demonstration that dietary restriction reverses these inflammaging-associated alterations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (inflammaging driven by innate immune receptor upregulation and interferon signaling) explaining systemic aging processes and how dietary restriction modulates these mechanisms.

results.title: The Changes of Mitochondria during Aging and Regeneration.

theories.name: Mitochondrial Homeostasis Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that progressive dysfunction of mitochondria in cells leads to decreased cellular energy production, which contributes to the decline in cellular and tissue function observed during aging.

key_concepts.concept: Link between mitochondrial changes and regenerative capacity
key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with diminished regenerative ability, potentially due to impaired mitochondrial function affecting stem cells and tissue repair mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial homeostasis as a causal mechanism
key_concepts.description: Maintaining mitochondrial homeostasis is proposed as a key factor influencing longevity and healthspan, suggesting that disruptions in mitochondrial dynamics, biogenesis, or quality control may causally contribute to aging.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing various studies that show correlations between aging, regeneration, and mitochondrial function; it discusses mitochondrial changes during aging and regeneration but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process (mitochondrial dysfunction) as a causal mechanism affecting organismal aging and regenerative capacity, with generalizable implications beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Ageing-related decline of translation as a consequence of transcription dysregulation.

theories.name: Transcription Dysregulation-Induced Decline of Translational Fidelity Theory

key_concepts.description: During ageing, large-scale changes occur in transcription that alter the codon usage profile of the transcriptome, affecting the overall mRNA pool available for translation.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on translation kinetics and fidelity
key_concepts.description: The shift in translation speed and accuracy with age is not due to changes in codon identity, tRNA abundance, or ribosome anticodon-codon specificity, but rather a systemic consequence of altered transcriptome composition.

Changes in transcript codon usage induce increased ribosome collisions and stalling during translation elongation, which disrupts the control over translation rates and leads to assimilation of codon translation speeds.

key_concepts.concept: Consequences for protein homeostasis and disease
key_concepts.description: The decline in translational fidelity contributes to protein homeostasis failure, which is implicated in ageing-related diseases such as cancer and neurodegeneration, especially in the brain.

theories.evidence: Computational modelling of ageing yeast and worm Riboseq data demonstrating systematic changes in translation kinetics linked to transcriptional changes; analysis showing independence from codon identity and tRNA abundance.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining why translational fidelity declines with age, linking transcriptional dysregulation to systemic ageing processes affecting protein homeostasis and disease; it addresses a fundamental ageing process at the organismal level through molecular mechanisms.

results.title: Cooperation between inhibitory immune checkpoints of senescent cells with immunosuppressive network to promote immunosenescence and the aging process.

theories.name: Cellular senescence and immune checkpoint cooperation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells promote aging via immune system remodeling
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate in tissues and secrete pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines (SASP), which remodel immune functions and contribute to the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells express inhibitory immune checkpoint ligands
key_concepts.description: Beyond secretion, senescent cells express increased levels of ligands for inhibitory immune checkpoint receptors (e.g., PD-L1), acting as 'don't eat me' signals that induce immune cell exhaustion.

key_concepts.concept: Immune cell exhaustion and immunosuppressive phenotype induction
key_concepts.description: Activation of inhibitory checkpoint receptors on immune cells leads to their exhaustion and differentiation into immunosuppressive phenotypes such as MDSCs, Tregs, and M2 macrophages.

key_concepts.concept: Reciprocal cooperation between senescent and immunosuppressive cells
key_concepts.description: Immunosuppressive cells stimulate senescent cells to express more inhibitory ligands, creating a feedback loop that maintains low-grade inflammation and promotes both cellular and immune senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Immune senescence as a driver of systemic aging
key_concepts.description: The cooperation between senescent cells and immunosuppressive networks enhances immune senescence/exhaustion, which in turn promotes cellular senescence in tissues via bystander effects, linking immune dysfunction to organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent studies demonstrating ligand expression on senescent cells, immune exhaustion, and immunosuppressive cell differentiation; conceptual integration of these findings into a cooperative model.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process (immune and cellular senescence cooperation), proposes causal mechanisms (immune checkpoint ligand expression and immune exhaustion), and addresses systemic aging beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Interoception and aging.

theories.name: Interoception-aging interaction theory

key_concepts.concept: Interoception as body internal state perception and regulation
key_concepts.description: Interoception involves the body's perception and regulation of internal physiological states through complex neural and sensory mechanisms, playing a key role in maintaining homeostasis.
Homeostasis is the dynamic process by which organisms maintain optimal internal balance via neural, endocrine, and behavioral functions, integrating multiple physiological systems.

key_concepts.concept: Bidirectional relationship between interoception and aging
key_concepts.description: Aging influences interoceptive processes, and conversely, interoception may affect the aging process, suggesting a regulatory feedback mechanism that impacts systemic aging.
Metabolites of arachidonic acid are proposed as promising biomarkers linking interoceptive function and aging, potentially reflecting underlying physiological changes during aging.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review proposing an updated definition of interoception, discussing homeostasis, and synthesizing existing knowledge to frame interoception-aging interactions; it also highlights arachidonic acid metabolites as biomarkers based on literature.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism linking interoception to systemic aging processes, offers causal explanations on how aging and interoception interact, and addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: An engineer's approach to the development of real anti-aging medicine.
The effect of low oxygen tension on the in vitro-replicative life span of human diploid fibroblast cells and their transformed derivatives.

theories.name: Oxygen-induced cellular senescence theory

key_concepts.concept: Oxygen tension as a modulator of cellular aging
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that higher oxygen levels (20% atmospheric oxygen) accelerate cellular senescence in human diploid fibroblasts, while lower oxygen tensions (1%, 6%, 12%) extend the replicative lifespan of these cells. Oxygen acts as an environmental stressor influencing the rate of cellular aging.

Younger cells exhibit greater resistance to the detrimental effects of higher oxygen tension compared to older cells, suggesting that cellular age modulates susceptibility to oxidative stress and senescence.

Cells transformed by SV40 large T antigen lose the oxygen-dependent modulation of replicative lifespan, indicating that certain oncogenic transformations can override oxygen-induced senescence mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from serial culture of human diploid fibroblasts under varying oxygen tensions showing lifespan extension at low oxygen; experiments with Werner syndrome fibroblasts showing similar effects; SV40 large T-transformed cells showing no oxygen effect.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (oxygen tension) influencing cellular senescence, which is a fundamental aging process; it addresses aging broadly at the cellular level with implications for organismal aging; it provides mechanistic insight into how environmental oxygen modulates aging.

results.title: CaMK modulates sensory neural activity to control longevity and proteostasis.

theories.name: Sensory Neural Activity Modulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that specific patterns of neural activity, particularly in sensory neurons, causally influence organismal aging and longevity. Alterations in neural excitation levels can modulate lifespan by affecting downstream molecular pathways.

CaMK4 (in humans) and its homolog CMK-1 (in C. elegans) regulate sensory neuron activity. Reduced expression or loss of function leads to decreased excitation in thermosensory neurons, which correlates with increased longevity and improved proteostasis.

Suppression of thermosensory AFD neuron activity promotes release of INS-1/insulin from AIZ neurons, which activates the DAF-16/FOXO transcription factor in the intestine, linking neural activity to systemic aging regulation via endocrine signaling.

theories.evidence: Correlation between human longevity and reduced CaMK4 expression; genetic loss-of-function experiments in C. elegans showing increased lifespan and proteostasis; neural circuit analysis demonstrating causal links between neuron activity, insulin signaling, and DAF-16 activation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory proposes a generalizable causal mechanism by which neural activity modulates systemic aging and longevity, supported by molecular and organismal data, and connects neural regulation to known aging pathways (DAF-16/FOXO). It addresses aging broadly at the organism level.

results.title: The potential use of nanozyme in aging and age-related diseases.

theories.name: Oxidative Damage Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that reactive oxygen species (ROS) cause cumulative damage to proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids, which contributes to the biological aging process. The damage impairs cellular function and promotes age-related decline.

key_concepts.concept: Role of ROS in aging and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: ROS are chemically reactive molecules containing oxygen that can induce oxidative stress, leading to cellular and tissue damage. This oxidative stress is linked to the development of multiple age-associated diseases such as cardiovascular and neurological disorders.

theories.evidence: The abstract references widely accepted ideas and existing literature that oxidative damage contributes to aging and age-related diseases, but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organism level, addressing fundamental biological processes and linking oxidative damage to systemic aging and disease.

results.title: Consecutive skeletal muscle PGC-1α overexpression: A double-edged sword for mitochondrial health in the aging brain.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging leads to reduced mitochondrial biogenesis, characterized by decreased expression of key regulators such as PGC-1α, FNDC5, and mtDNA content, which impairs cellular energy production and function.
Age-related mitochondrial dysfunction contributes to increased oxidative stress and inflammatory responses, which further damage cellular components and exacerbate aging phenotypes.
Aging disrupts the balance of mitochondrial fusion and fission processes, leading to impaired mitochondrial quality control and function.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from aged mice with skeletal muscle-specific PGC-1α overexpression showing changes in mitochondrial biogenesis markers, oxidative stress indicators, inflammatory markers, and mitochondrial dynamics proteins in both skeletal muscle and hippocampus.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining aging at the organism level through mitochondrial dysfunction and its systemic effects; it addresses fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Regenerative characteristics of the immortal jellyfish, Turritopsis dohrnii, and their potential implications for human aging.

theories.name: Regeneration and transdifferentiation as mechanisms for biological rejuvenation

key_concepts.description: A process by which differentiated cells transform into another cell type without reverting to a pluripotent state. In Turritopsis dohrnii, this allows the jellyfish to revert from a mature medusa stage back to a juvenile polyp stage, effectively resetting its life cycle and avoiding death.

The jellyfish's ability to rejuvenate via cellular transdifferentiation leads to a form of biological immortality, as it can theoretically repeat its life cycle indefinitely, escaping senescence and death that typically characterize aging organisms.

Understanding the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying the jellyfish's regenerative capacity may provide insights into human aging and potential therapeutic avenues to enhance tissue regeneration and counteract age-related degeneration.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews known regenerative characteristics of Turritopsis dohrnii, discusses transdifferentiation mechanisms, and explores their potential relevance to human aging and disease, citing recent studies on regeneration and aging-related disorders.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological process (aging and rejuvenation) at the organismal level by proposing a causal mechanism (transdifferentiation-driven regeneration) that counters aging. It is generalizable beyond the jellyfish by exploring implications for human aging, thus meeting the core criteria of an aging theory.

results.title: Epigenetic clocks, aging, and cancer.
Synthesis, modification and turnover of proteins during aging.

theories.name: Protein damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging involves a reduction in the cellular capacity to recognize and degrade damaged proteins via proteasomal and lysosomal pathways, leading to accumulation of abnormal proteins.
The buildup of damaged and misfolded proteins increases molecular heterogeneity and impairs protein function, which contributes to aging phenotypes and age-related diseases.
Alterations in protein synthesis rates, accuracy, post-translational modifications, and turnover disrupt proteostasis, which is a fundamental molecular characteristic of aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of age-related pathologies linked to protein damage such as cataracts, sarcopenia, and neurodegenerative diseases; general molecular observations about protein synthesis and degradation changes during aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the molecular level through protein damage accumulation and impaired proteostasis, applicable broadly to organismal aging and linked to systemic aging phenotypes.

results.title: Deciphering the Biological Aging Impact on Alveolar Bone Loss: Insights From α-Klotho and Renal Function Dynamics.

theories.name: α-Klotho mediated biological aging theory

key_concepts.concept: α-Klotho as a biological aging marker
key_concepts.description: α-Klotho protein levels decrease with biological aging and are negatively correlated with impaired renal function and alveolar bone loss, suggesting it serves as an indicator of systemic biological aging rather than chronological age.

key_concepts.concept: Renal function decline drives systemic aging effects
key_concepts.description: Decreased renal function leads to downregulation of α-Klotho expression in the renal cortex, which is associated with aggravated alveolar bone loss, indicating a renal-alveolar bone axis linking kidney aging to systemic tissue degeneration.

key_concepts.concept: Distinction between chronological age and biological aging
key_concepts.description: Chronological age shows an inversely U-shaped association with alveolar bone loss, with age above 62 years becoming protective in men, highlighting that biological aging processes (reflected by α-Klotho and renal function) rather than chronological age per se drive alveolar bone loss.

theories.evidence: Multivariate regression, smooth curve fittings, generalized additive models on large human cohorts; gene expression data from kidney transplant recipients; 2-sample Mendelian randomization showing causal negative association between genetically predicted α-Klotho levels and alveolar bone loss susceptibility.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking systemic biological aging (via α-Klotho and renal function) to tissue degeneration (alveolar bone loss), addressing aging beyond chronological age and specific disease, with mechanistic and causal evidence.

results.title: Rationally reprogramming single-cell aging trajectories and lifespan through dynamic modulation of environmental inputs.

theories.name: Nutrient-modulated cellular aging theory

key_concepts.concept: Environmental nutrient levels influence cellular lifespan
key_concepts.description: Variations in nutrient availability, specifically glucose levels, can modulate the aging process at the cellular level, affecting lifespan outcomes.

key_concepts.concept: Dynamical systems model of aging circuits
key_concepts.description: A core regulatory circuit in yeast aging can be modeled dynamically to understand how changes in nutrient inputs alter aging trajectories and lifespan.
Alternating nutrient conditions, similar to intermittent fasting regimens, can extend lifespan by modulating the aging process through environmental inputs.

theories.evidence: Use of a dynamical systems model applied to yeast aging circuits; comparison of lifespan extension under static and alternating glucose levels resembling intermittent fasting.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how environmental nutrient modulation affects cellular aging trajectories and lifespan, with implications beyond a single narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Cardiovascular Aging and Exercise: Implications for Heart Failure Prevention and Management.

theories.name: Accelerated Aging Phenotype Theory in Cardiovascular Disease

key_concepts.concept: Accelerated aging as a driver of cardiovascular disease
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that certain cardiovascular conditions, such as heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, can be understood as manifestations of an accelerated aging process. The accelerated aging phenotype is associated with increased morbidity and mortality and reflects systemic biological aging beyond chronological age.

key_concepts.concept: Modifiability of biological aging by lifestyle factors
key_concepts.description: Biological aging is not fixed but highly heterogeneous and influenced by health behaviors, genetics, and environment. Physical activity and exercise training can significantly modify the biological effects of accelerated aging, suggesting that aging processes are amenable to intervention.

key_concepts.concept: Exercise as a therapeutic intervention targeting aging mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Exercise is presented as a potent therapeutic strategy that can mitigate the deleterious effects of accelerated aging on cardiovascular and peripheral tissues, improving clinical outcomes in age-related cardiovascular disease.

theories.evidence: The paper is a state-of-the-art review citing age-related changes in cardiovascular and peripheral tissues, epidemiological associations between aging and cardiovascular disease, and evidence supporting exercise benefits in modifying aging phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain why cardiovascular aging occurs as a systemic accelerated aging process, proposes causal mechanisms linking aging to disease, and discusses modifiable factors influencing aging broadly at the organism level. Thus, it meets all core criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: The role of the LINC complex in ageing and microgravity.

theories.name: LINC Complex Dysregulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: LINC Complex Structural and Signaling Role
key_concepts.description: The LINC complex connects the nuclear envelope to the cytoskeleton, providing structural support to the nucleus and facilitating mechanical signaling between the extracellular environment and the nucleus. This mechanical linkage is crucial for maintaining nuclear integrity and proper gene expression.

Functional mechanotransduction depends on gravitational loading. Altered gravity conditions, such as microgravity or simulated microgravity, disrupt normal mechanotransduction pathways, leading to changes in nuclear mechanics and gene expression that are dependent on the LINC complex.

key_concepts.concept: LINC Complex Dysregulation as a Driver of Aging Phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Dysregulation of the LINC complex leads to nuclear shape abnormalities and loss of nuclear integrity, phenomena observed in both Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome (HGPS) and aged cells. This suggests that LINC complex dysfunction contributes causally to cellular and organismal aging.

Exposure to microgravity environments, such as during spaceflight, induces cellular and physiological changes resembling accelerated aging. This supports the idea that loss of gravitational loading affects aging processes via mechanisms involving the LINC complex.

theories.evidence: Citations of research from mechanobiology studies onboard the ISS and simulated microgravity experiments; observations of nuclear abnormalities in HGPS and aged cells linked to LINC complex dysfunction; parallels drawn between microgravity effects and aging phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging mechanism at the organismal level by linking mechanical signaling and nuclear integrity to aging processes. It proposes a causal mechanism (LINC complex dysregulation) that affects systemic aging phenotypes, supported by evidence from disease models and altered gravity studies. Thus, it meets the criteria of generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope.

results.title: Harnessing the FOXO-SIRT1 axis: insights into cellular stress, metabolism, and aging.

theories.name: FOXO-SIRT1 axis theory of aging

key_concepts.description: This concept describes the interaction between FOXO transcription factors and the deacetylase SIRT1, which together regulate cellular stress responses, metabolic homeostasis, and longevity. SIRT1 deacetylates FOXO proteins, modulating their activity to enhance antioxidant defenses and metabolic adaptation.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress defense and redox signaling
key_concepts.description: FOXO factors activate genes encoding antioxidant enzymes like superoxide dismutase and catalase, counteracting oxidative damage. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) act as secondary messengers influencing FOXO-SIRT1 activity, integrating redox signaling with metabolic regulation.

The FOXO-SIRT1 axis modulates glucose and lipid metabolism, mitochondrial biogenesis, and autophagy, maintaining cellular stability and energy balance. Interaction with redox-sensitive regulators such as Nrf2 and PGC-1α further orchestrates adaptive stress responses and mitochondrial health.

Pharmacological agents like resveratrol, alpha-lipoic acid, curcumin, and NAD+ precursors can enhance FOXO-SIRT1 activity, improving insulin sensitivity, reducing oxidative stress, and restoring metabolic balance, thereby potentially mitigating aging-related metabolic dysfunction.

theories.evidence: The paper synthesizes current advancements and recent evidence from molecular studies highlighting FOXO-SIRT1 regulation, redox signaling roles, and pharmacological interventions; specific experimental data are not detailed in the abstract but references to recent findings are implied.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how cellular stress responses and metabolic regulation via the FOXO-SIRT1 axis contribute to aging at the organismal level.
