key_concepts.description: The lowered NF-kappa B induction is attributed to impaired degradation of its inhibitor I kappa B-alpha due to decreased proteasomal activity, which may underlie multiple aspects of immune senescence including impaired T cell activation and accumulation of aberrant proteins.

theories.evidence: Studies in humans and mice showing lowered NF-kappa B induction in T cells from elderly subjects linked to impaired proteasomal degradation of I kappa B-alpha; observed immune functional declines such as reduced cytokine expression and T cell activity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (proteasomal impairment leading to NF-kappa B dysregulation) explaining why immune aging occurs, with implications for systemic immune senescence; it is not limited to a narrow phenomenon but addresses a fundamental aging-related decline in immune function.

results.title: Stimulation, regulation, and inflammaging interventions of natural compounds on nuclear factor kappa B (NF-kB) pathway: a comprehensive review.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory mediated by NF-kB pathway

key_concepts.concept: NF-kB as a central regulator of inflammation and aging
key_concepts.description: NF-kB is a transcription factor activated by various stimuli that controls expression of genes involved in inflammation, immune responses, and cell cycle regulation. Chronic activation of NF-kB leads to persistent low-grade inflammation, termed inflammaging, which contributes to aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation (inflammaging) as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Inflammaging refers to the chronic, systemic, low-grade inflammation that develops with age and underlies many age-related pathologies. NF-kB activation is a key molecular mechanism driving this inflammaging process.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation of NF-kB pathway by natural phytochemicals
key_concepts.description: Certain natural compounds can inhibit NF-kB activation, thereby reducing pro-inflammatory signaling and cellular stress associated with aging. This modulation may enhance cellular resilience and healthspan by attenuating inflammaging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing literature on NF-kB signaling, its role in inflammaging, and the effects of phytochemicals on this pathway; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (NF-kB-driven inflammaging) underlying biological aging and age-related diseases, with broad organism-level implications and mechanistic explanation.

results.title: Longevity pathways: HSF1 and FoxO pathways, a new therapeutic target to prevent age-related diseases.

theories.name: HSF1 and FoxO Longevity Pathways Theory

key_concepts.description: Aging leads to the attenuation of the Heat Shock Factor 1 (HSF1) pathway, which normally helps prevent the accumulation of toxic beta-amyloid fibrils. The failure of this pathway contributes to increased proteotoxic stress and protein deposition associated with aging and neurodegenerative diseases.

key_concepts.concept: FoxO pathway activation as a compensatory defense
key_concepts.description: In response to HSF1 pathway decline, the FoxO pathway is activated, promoting the formation of less toxic high molecular weight protein aggregates. This acts as a defense mechanism to mitigate proteotoxicity and cellular damage during aging.

Simultaneous upregulation of both HSF1 and FoxO pathways is proposed to reduce protein deposition and proteotoxicity more effectively than targeting either pathway alone. This combined intervention could delay or prevent the onset of multiple age-related diseases by affecting multiple genes and systems.

Modulating these pathways may have broad effects beyond neurodegeneration, potentially delaying cognitive decline, cancer, diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases due to their roles in multisystem regulation and gene activation.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known associations between pathway failures and age-related diseases, and cites interventions that activate multiple genes to ameliorate aging phenotypes. It also discusses mechanistic roles of HSF1 and FoxO pathways in protein aggregation and toxicity, though no specific experimental data is detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging involving fundamental longevity pathways affecting multiple systems and diseases. It addresses aging broadly, not limited to a single organ or disease, and suggests mechanisms underlying aging-related proteotoxicity and multisystem dysregulation.

results.title: Mitochondrial ROS production, oxidative stress and aging within and between species: Evidences and recent advances on this aging effector.

theories.name: Mitochondrial Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial ROS production as a regulated mechanism
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria are the main cellular source of reactive oxygen species (ROS), and their production of free radicals is not merely a byproduct but a highly regulated process that influences biological aging and longevity in a species-specific manner.

key_concepts.concept: Molecular damage induced by mitochondrial free radicals
key_concepts.description: The free radicals generated by mitochondria cause molecular damage, particularly to mitochondrial DNA, which has biological consequences that affect the rate of aging across different animal species.

Mitochondria play a fundamental role in determining animal longevity by mediating cellular decline through oxidative stress and free radical production, linking mitochondrial function directly to the aging process.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews recent evidence showing species-specific regulation of mitochondrial free radical production and its impact on longevity, citing molecular damage and adaptive responses related to mitochondrial DNA.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging at the organism level, addressing fundamental mechanisms (mitochondrial ROS and damage) that influence systemic aging and longevity.

results.title: DNA methylation and histone variants in aging and cancer.

theories.name: Epigenetic drift and DNA methylation aging theory

key_concepts.description: With aging, errors accumulate in the maintenance of DNA methylation patterns, leading to global hypomethylation and focal hypermethylation. This disrupts gene regulation, including the repression of repeated DNA sequences and silencing of tumor suppressor genes.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic clocks as biological age metrics
key_concepts.description: Epigenetic clocks quantify DNA methylation levels at specific genomic sites to estimate biological age, reflecting underlying molecular aging processes rather than just chronological time.

key_concepts.concept: Histone variant alterations in aging chromatin
key_concepts.description: Histone variants, which have specialized roles in transcription and genome stability, tend to accumulate in aged post-mitotic cells, potentially affecting chromatin structure and function during aging.

theories.evidence: Comprehensive review of recent results in mice and humans on DNA methylation and histone variant modifications during aging and cancer; references to epigenetic clocks and their use as biomarkers; discussion of molecular changes linked to aging and cancer.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining aging at the molecular level (epigenetic changes) that affect the organism broadly; discusses underlying causes of aging-related molecular disorder; connects epigenetic changes to systemic aging and cancer.

results.title: Rubidium Chloride Increases Life Span Through an AMPK/FOXO-Dependent Pathway in Caenorhabditis elegans.

theories.name: AMPK/FOXO pathway theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) as a regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: AMPK is a cellular energy sensor that maintains life span and stress responses. It modulates metabolic and stress resistance pathways, influencing organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: FOXO transcription factors as downstream effectors
key_concepts.description: FOXO proteins, such as DAF-16 in C. elegans, regulate gene expression related to longevity and stress resistance. Their nuclear translocation is critical for activating protective genes.

key_concepts.concept: Rubidium chloride (RbCl) modulates AMPK/FOXO to delay aging
key_concepts.description: RbCl treatment increases life span and stress resistance by inducing superoxide dismutase expression and promoting DAF-16 nuclear localization, implicating the AMPK/FOXO pathway in aging regulation.

theories.evidence: Experimental data in Caenorhabditis elegans showing increased life span and stress resistance upon RbCl treatment; requirement of AAK-2 (AMPK homolog) and DAF-16 (FOXO homolog) for antiaging effects; induction of superoxide dismutase expression.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging can be modulated via a conserved signaling pathway (AMPK/FOXO) affecting organismal aging; it is not limited to a single organ or disease and addresses fundamental aging processes.

results.title: Autophagy in aging-related diseases and cancer: Principles, regulatory mechanisms and therapeutic potential.

theories.name: Autophagy decline theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Autophagy is a natural biological process responsible for degrading damaged organelles and toxic macromolecules, thereby preserving cellular homeostasis. Its proper function is essential to prevent accumulation of cellular damage.

With aging, there is a decline in autophagy flux, leading to accumulation of cellular damage, which contributes to the development of various aging-associated diseases such as neurological disorders, cardiovascular diseases, and cancer.

key_concepts.concept: Molecular regulators of autophagy and aging
key_concepts.description: Key molecular pathways and proteins including MTOR, AMPK, ATG proteins, insulin/IGF1, TOR, PKA, AKT/PKB, caloric restriction, and mitochondrial respiration regulate autophagy and lifespan, linking autophagy modulation to aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Specific autophagy types in aging regulation
key_concepts.description: Selective autophagy types such as mitophagy target mitochondria for degradation, removing mitochondria with genomic mutations, thereby influencing aging by maintaining mitochondrial quality and function.

theories.evidence: The paper evaluates molecular mechanisms and pathways (MTOR, AMPK, ATG proteins, insulin/IGF1, etc.) linked to autophagy and aging, citing their changes during aging and roles in disease pathogenesis; references to aging-associated diseases and lifespan regulation are discussed.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs via decline in autophagy, affecting organismal aging and disease; addresses fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases; discusses underlying molecular pathways and lifespan regulation.

theories.name: Autophagy in cancer progression and aging-related diseases

key_concepts.concept: Dual role of autophagy in cancer
key_concepts.description: Autophagy can both enhance and decrease cancer progression by regulating hallmarks such as proliferation, metastasis, therapy resistance, and immune reactions.
Given its regulatory role in carcinogenesis and aging-related pathologies, autophagy and its molecular regulators (MTOR, AMPK, ATG proteins) are promising targets for therapeutic intervention.

theories.evidence: Discussion of autophagy’s influence on cancer hallmarks and aging-related diseases, highlighting molecular pathways and therapeutic potential.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it links autophagy mechanisms to systemic aging and disease progression, but focus is more on disease modulation than explaining fundamental aging mechanisms; still connected to general aging processes.

results.title: Biological resilience and aging: Activation of stress response pathways contributes to lifespan extension.

theories.name: Stress Response Activation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is not purely stochastic damage accumulation but is strongly influenced by genetic factors that regulate lifespan.
Long-lived genetic mutants activate multiple stress response pathways, which enhance resistance to various exogenous stressors, contributing to lifespan extension.
There is a significant positive correlation between an organism’s resistance to stress and its lifespan, suggesting stress response pathways play a causal role in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Requirement of stress pathways for normal lifespan
key_concepts.description: Disruption of stress response pathways reduces lifespan in both long-lived mutants and wild-type organisms, indicating these pathways are essential for normal aging processes.

theories.evidence: Data from genetic mutants in model organisms showing lifespan extension linked to activation of stress response pathways; disruption experiments reducing lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a general causal mechanism of aging applicable organism-wide, proposes activation of stress response pathways as a fundamental aging mechanism, and links genetic regulation to lifespan.

results.title: Connecting the emotional-cognitive puzzle: The role of tyrosine kinase B (TrkB) receptor isoform imbalance in age-related emotional and cognitive impairments.
Genes, culture, and aging flies--what the lab can and cannot tell us about natural genetic variation for senescence.
The immunometabolic roots of aging.

theories.name: Immunometabolic theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic alterations as drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: Metabolic changes at cellular and systemic levels are proposed as main drivers of organismal dysfunction during aging, impacting overall cellular and organ function.
A dysfunctional immune system, influenced by metabolic perturbations, has pleiotropic effects that accelerate the overall aging process in the organism.
The theory emphasizes the interaction between metabolic changes and the decline in immune cell function (immunosenescence) as a key mechanism underlying aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references recent studies highlighting metabolic changes and immune dysfunction in aging, but does not specify new experimental data within the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking metabolism and immune system decline to systemic aging, addressing organism-level aging processes.

results.title: Brain health promotion: Tactics within a strategic approach based upon valid, yet evolving scientific evidence.

theories.name: Hormesis and Preconditioning Theory of Aging Resilience

key_concepts.description: Hormesis refers to the biological phenomenon where exposure to low doses of a stressor or toxin induces adaptive beneficial effects on the organism, enhancing its resilience to subsequent stress and damage. This process is proposed to sustain structural and functional integrity during aging by activating protective cellular pathways.

Preconditioning involves exposing biological systems to mild stress or sub-lethal insults that trigger endogenous protective mechanisms, thereby increasing resistance to future, more severe stressors. This mechanism is suggested to protect neurological function and other biological systems from age-related decline.

key_concepts.concept: Biological Resilience as a Mechanism to Counteract Aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that enhancing biological resilience through hormetic and preconditioning processes can mitigate the effects of aging by maintaining system integrity and reducing vulnerability to age-associated diseases. This resilience is viewed as a fundamental process influencing organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Summarizes a vast scientific literature over two decades indicating hormesis and preconditioning protect biological systems from aging effects and certain diseases; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how aging effects can be mitigated via biological resilience processes applicable at organism level, focusing on fundamental aging processes rather than narrow disease or organ-specific phenomena.

results.title: Roles of Brd4 in Vascular Smooth Muscle Cells: Implications for Aging and Vascular Dysfunction.

theories.name: Epigenetic regulation of vascular aging via Brd4-mediated control of smooth muscle cell senescence

key_concepts.concept: Brd4 as an epigenetic reader influencing vascular aging
key_concepts.description: Brd4 is a bromodomain-containing protein that reads epigenetic marks and regulates gene expression. Its expression declines in aged vascular tissues and senescent vascular smooth muscle cells, suggesting a role in the aging process of the vasculature.

key_concepts.concept: Brd4 depletion induces cellular senescence in vascular smooth muscle cells
key_concepts.description: Inhibition or knockout of Brd4 in vascular smooth muscle cells leads to increased cellular senescence, as evidenced by senescence-associated β-galactosidase staining, indicating that Brd4 normally acts to suppress senescence in these cells.

key_concepts.concept: Brd4 influences vascular function and aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Loss of Brd4 in smooth muscle cells results in increased arterial stiffness, elevated blood pressure, and enhanced contractile responses, which are hallmarks of vascular aging and dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Brd4 regulates autophagy and cytoskeletal gene expression
key_concepts.description: Transcriptomic analysis reveals that Brd4 knockout leads to dampened autophagy and downregulation of microtubule-related genes such as α-tubulin (Tuba4a), linking epigenetic regulation by Brd4 to cellular maintenance pathways that influence senescence.

theories.evidence: Experimental evidence includes pharmacological inhibition and genetic knockout of Brd4 in mouse aortic smooth muscle cells and mice, assessment of senescence markers, vascular function tests (arterial stiffness, blood pressure, contractility), RNA-sequencing transcriptome profiling, and in vitro mechanistic studies linking autophagy and cytoskeletal changes to senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper proposes a mechanistic role of Brd4 in regulating vascular smooth muscle cell senescence and vascular aging, addressing a general aging process at the organismal level (vascular aging as a systemic aging component). It provides causal explanations linking epigenetic regulation to cellular senescence and vascular dysfunction, thus meeting the criteria for an aging theory related to epigenetic regulation and cellular senescence as drivers of systemic aging.

results.title: Cellular senescence and PAPP-A.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cells enter a state of permanent growth arrest known as senescence, which accumulates with age and contributes to organismal aging by altering tissue function and promoting inflammation through the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP).

Senescent cells secrete a complex mixture of pro-inflammatory cytokines, growth factors, and proteases that impact the tissue microenvironment, influencing aging processes and age-related pathologies.

theories.evidence: The abstract references the major impact of cellular senescence and its secretome on growth and aging, implying citation of existing studies and knowledge in the field.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how cellular senescence contributes to systemic aging beyond specific organs or diseases.

theories.name: PAPP-A Regulation of IGF-I and Aging

key_concepts.concept: PAPP-A as a regulator of IGF-I bioavailability
key_concepts.description: Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) is a protease that modulates the availability of insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I), a key growth factor involved in development and aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Impact of PAPP-A on growth and aging
key_concepts.description: By regulating IGF-I, PAPP-A influences organismal growth and aging, suggesting a mechanistic link between protease activity, growth factor signaling, and aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: The abstract mentions exploring a new perspective on the role of PAPP-A in aging, likely based on recent findings or synthesis of existing data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general mechanism influencing aging at the organismal level through modulation of a fundamental growth factor pathway.

results.title: Epigenetic regulation of aging in honeybee workers.

theories.name: Epigenetic regulation of aging via vitellogenin in honeybee workers

key_concepts.description: Aging rates and longevity can vary significantly within a species depending on environmental and social factors, as exemplified by different honeybee castes exhibiting distinct lifespans despite genetic similarity.

key_concepts.concept: Role of vitellogenin in somatic maintenance
key_concepts.description: Vitellogenin, a yolk protein, is implicated as a key regulatory molecule influencing the aging process and somatic maintenance in honeybee workers, linking reproductive physiology to longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Life history context of aging regulation
key_concepts.description: The variation in aging patterns among honeybee worker castes is framed within life history theory, suggesting that environmental and physiological factors modulate aging as an adaptive trait.

theories.evidence: Summary of current understanding and literature on vitellogenin's role and caste-dependent aging patterns in honeybee workers; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (epigenetic regulation via vitellogenin) explaining how aging is modulated at the organismal level in honeybee workers, linking environmental cues to aging processes; provides causal explanation through regulatory circuitry affecting somatic maintenance; addresses aging broadly in the context of life history and phenotypic plasticity rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific focus.

results.title: Distinct profiles of cellular senescence-associated gene expression in the aged, diseased or injured central nervous system.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence refers to a state of stable cell cycle arrest accompanied by changes in gene expression, secretory profiles, and function. It is proposed as a causal mechanism contributing to organismal aging by promoting tissue dysfunction and chronic inflammation.

key_concepts.concept: Distinct senescence gene expression profiles in aging and CNS diseases
key_concepts.description: Different patterns of cellular senescence-associated gene expression are observed in aged brains versus brains affected by CNS diseases such as Alzheimer's disease and demyelination. This suggests that senescence manifests differently depending on the context but converges on a common aging-related pathway.

key_concepts.concept: Common activation of cellular senescence across diverse CNS pathologies
key_concepts.description: Despite unique gene expression profiles in different disease models, cellular senescence is a shared endpoint, indicating it may be a unifying mechanism linking aging, injury, and disease in the central nervous system.

theories.evidence: Comparative gene expression analysis of 88 curated cellular senescence genes in aged mouse brains, Alzheimer's disease mouse model (5xFAD), and cuprizone-induced demyelination model; corroboration with human aging and AD gene expression datasets.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (cellular senescence) explaining aging at the organismal level, supported by gene expression data across aging and disease states, addressing aging broadly beyond single diseases.

results.title: Enhancing immunity during ageing by targeting interactions within the tissue environment.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence as a Driver of Immune Aging

key_concepts.description: Senescence is a state of stable cell cycle arrest that occurs in various cell types, including lymphoid and non-lymphoid tissues, contributing to immune dysfunction during aging.
Senescent cells promote chronic, low-grade inflammation ('inflammageing'), which in turn exacerbates senescence, creating a self-reinforcing cycle that impairs immune function.

key_concepts.concept: Targeting senescent cells to restore immunity
key_concepts.description: Therapies such as senolytics aim to eliminate senescent cells to break the cycle of inflammation and senescence, thereby improving immune responses in aged tissues.

theories.evidence: Citations and synthesis of existing literature on senescence and inflammageing; discussion of therapeutic approaches including senolytics and senomorphics.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (cellular senescence) driving systemic immune aging, discusses underlying processes and therapeutic implications, and addresses aging at the organismal immune system level.

theories.name: Inflammageing as a Mechanism of Immune Decline

key_concepts.description: Inflammageing refers to the persistent, systemic, low-level inflammation observed during aging that contributes to immune dysfunction and increased disease susceptibility.
Inflammation and senescence mutually reinforce each other, leading to progressive deterioration of immune tissue environments.
Senomorphic therapies aim to inhibit inflammatory pathways to reduce inflammageing and improve immune function without necessarily eliminating senescent cells.

theories.evidence: Review of literature on inflammageing and its role in immune aging; evaluation of anti-inflammatory therapeutic strategies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it explains a fundamental aging process (inflammageing) with causal mechanisms affecting systemic immune aging and discusses interventions targeting this mechanism.

results.title: Characterisation of mitochondrial DNA deletions by long-PCR in central nervous system regions of young, middle- and old-aged rats.

theories.name: Mitochondrial DNA damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that mutations and deletions in mitochondrial DNA accumulate over time, impairing mitochondrial function. This damage affects the electron transport chain complexes, reducing ATP production and contributing to cellular and organismal aging.

Post-mitotic cells, such as neurons in the central nervous system, are particularly susceptible to mitochondrial DNA damage because they do not divide and dilute damaged mitochondria, leading to progressive dysfunction with age.

key_concepts.concept: Regional variation in mitochondrial DNA damage
key_concepts.description: Different regions of the central nervous system show varying levels of mitochondrial DNA deletions, suggesting that some areas are more prone to mitochondrial dysfunction and thus may contribute differentially to aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: The study presents experimental data detecting mitochondrial DNA deletions in multiple CNS regions of young, middle-aged, and old rats using long-PCR. The findings show increased deletions with age, especially in the major arc of mtDNA, consistent with previous human brain data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process (mitochondrial genome damage accumulation) with causal mechanisms (mtDNA deletions impairing mitochondrial function). It is generalizable to organismal aging, particularly in post-mitotic tissues, and not limited to a specific disease or narrow phenomenon.

results.title: [Reserva cognitiva y demencias: Limitaciones del efecto protector en el envejecimiento y el deterioro cognitivoLimited protective effects of cognitive reserve on the progression of cognitive impairment].

theories.name: Cognitive Reserve Theory

key_concepts.description: Cognitive reserve refers to the brain's ability to cope with neuropathological damage and maintain cognitive function despite the presence of brain injury or neurodegeneration. It is proposed as a protective factor that can delay or attenuate cognitive impairment.

Although cognitive reserve can protect against cognitive decline in early or minimal stages of impairment, its protective effect diminishes or fails in advanced stages of neurodegenerative diseases, allowing progression of cognitive damage.

theories.evidence: Systematic review of studies showing that high cognitive reserve protects only in minimal cognitive impairment but not in later stages.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism explaining how cognitive aging and impairment occur and progress at the organism level, addressing why some individuals maintain function despite brain pathology. It provides a causal explanation of resilience and limits of protection in aging cognition.

results.title: Immunosenescence and inflammaging: Mechanisms and role in diseases.

theories.name: Immunosenescence and Inflammaging Theory

key_concepts.description: Immunosenescence refers to the progressive decline in immune system function associated with aging. This decline involves cellular and molecular alterations that impair immune responses, leading to increased susceptibility to infections, cancer, and other age-related diseases.

Inflammaging is characterized by chronic, low-grade, systemic inflammation that occurs with aging in the absence of overt pathogenic stimuli. It is proposed as a pathological state contributing to aging and age-related diseases, driven by mechanisms distinct from classical inflammatory responses.

The theory posits that immunosenescence and inflammaging are interconnected processes that together contribute to the pathogenesis of multiple aging-related diseases, including cancer, infections, dementia, and neurodegenerative disorders.

theories.evidence: The paper is a comprehensive review summarizing recent molecular characterizations and disease relevance studies linking immunosenescence and inflammaging to aging-related diseases. It cites mounting evidence from the literature but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging-related immune dysfunction and systemic inflammation as fundamental aging processes. It addresses organism-level aging mechanisms and their role in multiple diseases, not limited to a single organ or condition.

results.title: The Nuclear Envelope in Ageing and Progeria.

theories.name: Nuclear Envelope Dysfunction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Nuclear envelope as a regulator of genome stability and gene expression
key_concepts.description: The nuclear envelope compartmentalizes eukaryotic cells, providing physical stability to the nucleus and regulating gene expression by controlling nuclear import of transcription factors and organizing chromatin into open and closed compartments. This regulation is crucial for DNA replication and repair, thereby maintaining genome stability, which is fundamental to organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Mutations in nuclear lamina components cause progeroid syndromes
key_concepts.description: Mutations in LMNA and BANF1 genes, encoding nuclear lamina proteins, cause Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome (HGPS) and Nestor-Guillermo Progeria Syndrome (NGPS), respectively. These syndromes manifest accelerated aging phenotypes, linking nuclear envelope defects directly to systemic aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Shared cellular defects between progeroid syndromes and normal aging
key_concepts.description: Cells from progeria patients and healthy aged individuals show similar defects, including increased DNA damage and epigenetic alterations, suggesting that nuclear envelope dysfunction contributes causally to general aging mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Nucleocytoplasmic transport defects in neurodegenerative diseases as aging-related mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Age-related neurodegenerative diseases like ALS and Huntington's disease involve defects in nucleocytoplasmic transport, characterized by accumulation of nuclear pore proteins and transport factors in inclusions. Genetic manipulation of this transport machinery can alleviate disease phenotypes, indicating a mechanistic link to aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of progeria syndromes caused by LMNA and BANF1 mutations; observations of cellular defects in patient and aged donor cells; descriptions of nucleocytoplasmic transport defects in neurodegenerative disease models and genetic intervention studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism (nuclear envelope dysfunction) underlying aging and age-related diseases, with causal explanations linking nuclear structure and transport to genome stability and cellular aging processes. It addresses organism-level aging beyond specific diseases by connecting progeroid syndromes and normal aging.

results.title: [Research advances in immunosenescence and inflammation in lung diseases].

theories.name: Immunosenescence and Inflamm-aging Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Immunosenescence refers to the age-related decline in both innate and adaptive immune system functions. This decline leads to dysregulation and reduced immune responsiveness, contributing to increased vulnerability to infections and diseases in the elderly.

Inflamm-aging is a chronic, low-level inflammatory state driven by immunosenescence. This persistent inflammation is implicated as a contributing factor to the progression of age-related diseases and general systemic aging.

The theory connects immunosenescence and inflamm-aging to the pathophysiology of various pulmonary diseases in the elderly, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, asthma, and lung infections, suggesting these immune changes drive systemic aging effects manifesting in lung pathology.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review discussing existing knowledge and literature on immunosenescence and inflamm-aging in relation to lung diseases in elderly populations; no new experimental data is presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (immune system decline and chronic inflammation) that affects organism-level aging and disease susceptibility. It proposes causal mechanisms (immune decline causing inflamm-aging) that contribute broadly to aging, not limited to a single organ or disease, thus meeting the core criteria.

results.title: Immunoinformatic-based drug design utilizing hesperetin to target CISD2 activation for liver aging in humans.

theories.name: CISD2-mediated cellular maintenance theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: CISD2 as a regulator of cellular homeostasis
key_concepts.description: CISD2 protein regulates intracellular calcium levels and maintains the integrity and function of the endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria, which are critical for cellular health and longevity.

CISD2 expression decreases with age, leading to impaired cellular functions such as disrupted calcium homeostasis, increased oxidative stress, and metabolic dysregulation, which contribute to aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: CISD2’s protective role against age-related cellular stress
key_concepts.description: By maintaining organelle integrity and regulating translation factors like Nrf2 and IL-6, CISD2 protects cells from oxidative and metabolic stress, thereby promoting cellular longevity and healthy liver aging.

key_concepts.concept: Pharmacological activation of CISD2 by hesperetin
key_concepts.description: Hesperetin (HST) is proposed as a CISD2 activator that can modulate metabolic pathways to counteract metabolic dysfunction and age-related illnesses, highlighting a potential therapeutic intervention targeting CISD2 to promote healthy aging.

theories.evidence: In silico docking studies showing HST as a CISD2 activator; literature linking CISD2 to longevity, cellular homeostasis, and age-related metabolic dysfunction; associations with oxidative stress and metabolic disorders.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging at the cellular and organismal level via CISD2’s role in maintaining cellular homeostasis and mitigating age-related decline; it connects molecular mechanisms to systemic aging and longevity.

results.title: FoxO3 Regulates the Progress and Development of Aging and Aging-Related Diseases.

theories.name: FoxO3 signaling theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: FoxO3 as a key transcription factor
key_concepts.description: FoxO3 encodes a transcription factor that integrates various intrinsic and extrinsic stimuli to regulate cellular processes relevant to aging, such as cell differentiation, protein homeostasis, stress resistance, and stem cell maintenance.

key_concepts.concept: Regulation of longevity and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: FoxO3 signaling pathways modulate aging and promote longevity by influencing molecular pathways that affect the progression of aging and the development of age-related diseases including cardiovascular diseases, neurodegenerative diseases, cancer, and diabetes.
Upstream and downstream molecules in the FoxO3 signaling pathways are proposed as potential therapeutic targets for interventions aimed at aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Current evidence from molecular studies indicating FoxO3’s role in longevity and age-related diseases; overview of signaling pathways and clinical prospects mentioned, but no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how FoxO3 regulates aging processes and age-related diseases at an organismal level; it addresses fundamental aging mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Daytime-Restricted Feeding Alleviates D-Galactose-Induced Aging in Mice and Regulates the AMPK and mTORC1 Activities.

theories.name: Time-Restricted Feeding (TRF) as a Modulator of Aging via Metabolic Pathways

key_concepts.description: The timing of food intake influences circadian rhythm-related gene expression, which in turn affects metabolic homeostasis and health outcomes. Disruptions or shifts in feeding time can impact aging processes through these circadian mechanisms.

AMPK activation promotes cellular energy homeostasis and longevity, while mTORC1 signaling is associated with growth and aging. Modulation of these pathways by TRF (especially daytime-restricted feeding) can retard aging by enhancing AMPK activity and suppressing mTORC1 activity.

TRF reduces oxidative damage and inflammatory responses, which are key drivers of aging. This reduction is linked to improved physical and cognitive functions and decreased expression of aging markers such as SA-β-gal and p16 in peripheral tissues.
The beneficial effects of TRF on aging share mechanistic similarities with metformin, a known pharmacological agent that modulates AMPK and mTOR pathways to extend healthspan and delay aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from mice under progeric aging conditions showing improved physical and memory capacities, enhanced organ functions, reduced oxidative damage and inflammation, decreased aging markers, and altered AMPK/mTORC1 signaling under DRF regimens.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory attempts to explain how aging can be modulated at the organismal level through metabolic and circadian mechanisms (generalizability), proposes causal pathways involving AMPK and mTORC1 signaling (causal explanation), and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a single organ or disease (scope).

results.title: Aging and Inflammation.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with persistent activation of the immune system, characterized by elevated circulating inflammatory markers and activated immune cells in tissues, leading to a chronic inflammatory state termed 'inflammaging'. This chronic inflammation contributes to increased risk of age-related diseases, frailty, and mortality.

key_concepts.concept: Imbalance between damage accumulation and resilience mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Aging results from a progressive disequilibrium between stochastic damage accumulation and the body's resilience mechanisms that repair damage. When repair mechanisms fail or become dysregulated, chronic inflammation arises, exacerbating aging phenotypes.
Age-related intrinsic dysregulation of immune function, including immunosenescence, impairs the immune response to acute stressors and contributes to chronic inflammation and systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of NF-κB and proinflammatory mediators
key_concepts.description: The transcription factor NF-κB plays a central role in regulating chronic inflammation during aging by controlling proinflammatory gene expression, making it a key mechanistic target in inflammaging.

key_concepts.concept: Influence of microbiome and integrated stress response
key_concepts.description: Age-related changes in the gastrointestinal microbiome (dysbiosis) and the integrated stress response modulate the inflammatory response to damage and stress, linking systemic aging to microbial and cellular stress pathways.

theories.evidence: The abstract references recent advances in understanding mechanisms leading to inflammaging, studies on NF-κB and proinflammatory mediators, and clinical trials targeting inflammation, as well as nonpharmacological interventions like diet and exercise.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs systemically via chronic inflammation driven by immune dysregulation and damage accumulation; it addresses aging broadly and links inflammation causally to aging phenotypes and diseases.

results.title: Structure-(Dys)function relationships in mitochondrial electron transport chain complex II?

theories.name: Mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (ROS) theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial ROS as causal agents of aging
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that reactive oxygen species generated by mitochondria cause oxidative damage that accumulates over time, leading to aging at the organismal level. The theory suggests that electron transport chain complexes, primarily I and III, are major sources of these ROS.

key_concepts.concept: Role of complex II (succinate dehydrogenase) in ROS production
key_concepts.description: Although traditionally considered a minor source of ROS, mutations in complex II proteins (e.g., mev-1 in C. elegans) increase oxidative stress and reduce lifespan, implicating complex II in aging-related ROS generation.

key_concepts.concept: Electron leakage mechanisms in aging mitochondria
key_concepts.description: Structural insights into complex II suggest possible mechanisms for electron leakage that could increase ROS production in aged organisms, providing a mechanistic explanation for how mitochondrial dysfunction contributes to aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of prior studies including mev-1 mutant lifespan data in C. elegans and recent structural determination of E. coli succinate dehydrogenase by Yankovskaya et al.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (mitochondrial ROS) underlying aging applicable at the organism level, discusses evolutionary and biochemical bases, and connects molecular dysfunction to systemic aging.

results.title: NAD+ and NADH in brain functions, brain diseases and brain aging.

theories.name: NAD+/NADH Central Regulatory Network Theory of Brain Aging

key_concepts.concept: NAD+ and NADH as fundamental regulators
key_concepts.description: NAD+ and NADH mediate multiple major biological processes including calcium homeostasis, energy metabolism, mitochondrial functions, and cell death, which are all critical to cellular and organismal aging.

NAD+ and NADH, together with ATP and Ca2+, form a central regulatory network that maintains the intrinsic harmony of life processes, suggesting a fundamental role in regulating aging and brain function.

key_concepts.concept: Role in brain aging and diseases
key_concepts.description: NAD+ and NADH influence brain-specific processes such as neurotransmission, learning and memory, and may mediate brain senescence and tissue damage in brain illnesses, linking their metabolism to systemic aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Citations of numerous studies linking NAD+/NADH to biological processes and brain functions; latest studies showing NADH transport across astrocyte membranes and NAD+ administration reducing ischemic brain injury.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism underlying aging at the organismal level via NAD+/NADH metabolism; connects metabolic regulation to brain aging and systemic aging processes; not limited to a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Cellular ageing and the actin cytoskeleton.

theories.name: Actin Cytoskeleton-Linked Cellular Aging Theory

key_concepts.concept: Dynamic role of actin cytoskeleton in signaling
key_concepts.description: The actin cytoskeleton is not merely a structural scaffold but actively participates in downstream signaling pathways that influence cellular activities and fate decisions, including aging.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress-induced damage to actin cytoskeleton
key_concepts.description: Damage sustained by the actin cytoskeleton under oxidative stress conditions is directly linked to apoptosis, suggesting a mechanistic connection between cytoskeletal integrity and cell death pathways relevant to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Actin-mediated inheritance of mitochondria and anti-aging factors
key_concepts.description: Actin-based propulsion mechanisms are essential for the proper inheritance of mitochondria and anti-aging factors during cell division, implicating cytoskeletal dynamics in the maintenance of cellular homeostasis and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Influence of actin on protein aggregation
key_concepts.description: Actin directly affects the formation of protein aggregates, which are known to be involved in aging processes, linking cytoskeletal dynamics to proteostasis and cellular aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of yeast studies showing actin interaction with aging and cell death pathways, observations of oxidative stress effects on actin linked to apoptosis, and roles of actin in mitochondrial inheritance and protein aggregation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental cellular mechanism (actin cytoskeleton dynamics) that influences aging processes broadly through signaling, damage response, and organelle inheritance, thus meeting generalizability and causal explanation criteria. It addresses aging at the cellular level with implications for organismal aging via homeostasis maintenance.

results.title: Immunosenescence in autoimmune diseases.

theories.name: Immunosenescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The immune system undergoes age-related changes including alterations in lymphocyte quantity, phenotype, and function, as well as a narrowing of the B and T cell receptor repertoire, which collectively contribute to a decline in immune competence.

Senescent immune cells develop a senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) that exacerbates chronic inflammation and tissue damage, thereby linking cellular senescence to systemic immune aging and autoimmune disease progression.

Mitochondrial dysfunction and metabolic disturbances promote the accumulation of senescent cells, which act as upstream drivers of immunosenescence, suggesting a mechanistic link between cellular metabolism, senescence, and immune aging.

key_concepts.concept: Bidirectional relationship between autoimmune diseases and immunosenescence
key_concepts.description: Autoimmune diseases and immunosenescence influence each other, where aging-related immune changes increase susceptibility to autoimmune diseases, and autoimmune pathology further accelerates immune aging.

theories.evidence: Summary of existing literature on immune cell changes, SASP, mitochondrial dysfunction, and their roles in autoimmune diseases and aging; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging at the organismal level through immune system aging mechanisms; connects cellular senescence and metabolic dysfunction to systemic aging and disease susceptibility.

results.title: The implication of telomerase activity and telomere stability for replicative aging and cellular immortality (Review).

theories.name: Telomere Shortening and Telomerase Activity Theory of Replicative Aging

key_concepts.description: Telomeres are specialized chromosomal end structures composed of TTAGGG repeats that protect chromosomes from degradation, fusion, and recombination, thereby maintaining genomic stability.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere Shortening as a Cause of Cellular Senescence
key_concepts.description: Due to the end-replication problem, telomeres shorten with each cell division in most somatic cells, eventually reaching a critical length that triggers cellular senescence, limiting proliferative capacity.

key_concepts.concept: Role of Telomerase in Telomere Maintenance and Cellular Immortality
key_concepts.description: Telomerase is a ribonucleoprotein enzyme that can elongate telomeres by adding TTAGGG repeats, thereby counteracting telomere shortening. Its activity is low or absent in most normal somatic cells but high in malignant tumor cells, enabling unlimited proliferation.

key_concepts.concept: Regulation of Telomerase and Telomere Length
key_concepts.description: Telomerase activity and telomere length are regulated by multiple mechanisms, including telomerase RNA component, associated proteins, and telomere-binding proteins that may provide negative feedback to control telomerase function.

theories.evidence: Summary of experimental findings including cloning of telomerase RNA component, antisense experiments showing telomere shortening without telomerase, detection of telomerase activity in various cell types, and identification of telomere-binding proteins.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining replicative aging at the cellular level with implications for organismal aging, discusses underlying molecular mechanisms, and links cellular senescence to telomere dynamics.

results.title: Promises and challenges of senolytics in skin regeneration, pathology and ageing.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a causal driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate with age and contribute to tissue dysfunction and aging phenotypes. The chronic presence of senescent cells is detrimental, promoting aging and age-related diseases.
Senescent cells have a paradoxical role: transient senescence is beneficial during development and wound healing, while persistent senescence leads to aging and pathology.

Senolytic drugs selectively eliminate senescent cells, aiming to reduce senescent cell burden and ameliorate aging-related tissue dysfunction, representing a therapeutic strategy to target aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Summary of recent research on skin senescence, detection methods, and senolytic drug studies; citations implied though not detailed in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging (accumulation of senescent cells), is broadly applicable beyond skin, and discusses intervention targeting this mechanism.

results.title: Ceramide, stress, and a "LAG" in aging.

theories.name: Ceramide-mediated aging theory

key_concepts.concept: Role of LAG1 gene in ceramide synthesis
key_concepts.description: The LAG1 gene, known as a longevity assurance gene, is implicated in the synthesis of ceramide, a lipid molecule. This connection suggests that genetic regulation of ceramide production may influence aging processes.
Ceramide plays a role in cellular stress responses in yeast and mammals, indicating that it may mediate how organisms respond to environmental and physiological stressors that contribute to aging.
In mammals, ceramide is linked to cellular senescence, a state of irreversible cell cycle arrest that contributes to organismal aging, suggesting ceramide as a causal factor in aging mechanisms.
Evidence from yeast, Drosophila, and mammals points to conserved roles of ceramide in aging, supporting the generalizability of this mechanism across different organisms.

theories.evidence: The paper examines existing studies implicating LAG1 in ceramide synthesis and the role of ceramide in stress responses and senescence across multiple species (yeast, Drosophila, mammals).
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism linking ceramide metabolism to organismal aging, supported by cross-species evidence and connecting cellular senescence and stress responses to systemic aging.

results.title: Role of stem cells in ageing and age-related diseases.

theories.name: Stem Cell Functional Decline Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by a gradual reduction in stem cells' abilities, including self-renewal, differentiation, and growth factor secretion, which leads to diminished organ maintenance, regeneration, and homeostasis.

The decline in stem cell function is attributed to both damaging extrinsic environmental factors and progressively worsening intrinsic genetic and biochemical processes, which together impair stem cell performance over time.

Aging adversely affects the stem cell microenvironment or niche, disrupting molecular pathways critical for stem cell homing, self-renewal, differentiation, and secretion, thereby further compromising tissue repair and regeneration.

key_concepts.concept: Stem cell numerical and heterogeneity decline
key_concepts.description: Age-dependent changes include a reduction in stem cell numbers and loss of heterogeneity, which contribute to a drastic reduction in regenerative potential and drive systemic aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references extensive documentation of aging-associated changes in stem cells, including empirical research and clinical trials, though no specific experiments or data are detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs at the organism level through stem cell decline and niche disruption, addressing fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Ras: the other pro-aging pathway.

theories.name: Ras signaling pathway as a pro-aging mechanism

key_concepts.description: The Ras signaling pathway, involving Ras proteins, adenylate cyclase, protein kinase A, and transcription factors Msn2 and Msn4, regulates chronological aging in yeast. This pathway influences stress resistance and life span, suggesting a conserved role in aging processes.

The Ras pathway is related to the insulin/IGF-1/PI3K/Akt pathway, a well-established longevity regulator in worms, flies, and mice. Ras proteins play a major role in mammalian IGF-1 signaling, implying that Ras homologs might accelerate aging in mammals.

While Ras has not been directly implicated in longevity regulation in worms or flies, its conserved role in yeast and mammals suggests a broader, organism-level mechanism influencing aging, potentially linking cellular stress resistance pathways to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Data from experiments in yeast, worms, flies, and mice; organismal and cellular level studies; references to known pathways such as insulin/IGF-1 signaling and yeast Ras2 pathway.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging involving a conserved signaling pathway; connects molecular signaling to organismal aging; discusses underlying causes and evolutionary conservation.

results.title: Crosstalk between protein misfolding and endoplasmic reticulum stress during ageing and their role in age-related disorders.

theories.name: Proteostasis collapse theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging involves deterioration of cellular systems responsible for maintaining protein folding and quality control, leading to accumulation of misfolded and aggregated proteins that impair cell function.

key_concepts.concept: Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress and unfolded protein response (UPR)
key_concepts.description: Increased protein misfolding induces ER stress, which activates the UPR as an adaptive mechanism to restore homeostasis; failure or prolonged ER stress triggers apoptosis, contributing to aging-related cellular decline.

key_concepts.concept: Protein misfolding diseases as manifestations of aging
key_concepts.description: Age-related accumulation of insoluble protein aggregates (fibrils, plaques) in organs underlies common late-life diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, type II diabetes, and cancer, linking proteostasis failure to systemic aging pathology.

theories.evidence: Citations and molecular perspectives on proteostasis machinery, ER stress, UPR activation, and their roles in age-related diseases; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs at the organismal level through proteostasis collapse and ER stress pathways, linking molecular dysfunction to systemic aging and disease.

results.title: Mouse and human cells versus oxygen.

theories.name: DNA damage and replicative senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage as a driver of cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that accumulation of DNA damage, particularly oxidative damage, leads to cellular senescence, a permanent growth arrest state that contributes to organismal aging. Mouse cells accumulate more DNA damage under oxidative stress and enter senescence rapidly.

key_concepts.concept: Species differences in DNA damage response and senescence
key_concepts.description: Human cells are more resistant to oxidative DNA damage and enter replicative senescence primarily due to telomere shortening rather than DNA damage, unlike mouse cells. This suggests different mechanisms of cellular aging between species.

key_concepts.concept: Checkpoint efficiency in response to DNA/chromosomal damage
key_concepts.description: Human cells have more efficient cell cycle checkpoints that prevent division when chromosomal abnormalities or telomere shortening occur, whereas mouse cells can continue dividing despite DNA damage, leading to immortalization in culture.

theories.evidence: Citations of experimental data from Judith Campisi's lab showing differential responses of mouse and human cells to oxygen-induced DNA damage and senescence in culture; comparative analysis of cellular behavior.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (DNA damage and telomere shortening) explaining cellular senescence as a fundamental aging process, with implications for organismal aging; addresses general aging mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Pharmaceutical and nutraceutical activation of FOXO3 for healthy longevity.

theories.name: FOXO3-mediated geroprotection theory

key_concepts.description: FOXO3 is identified as a gene intricately involved in aging and healthspan, with genetic variants linked to human longevity, reduced disease risks, and better self-reported health.
Compounds that activate FOXO3 or influence lifespan and healthspan in a FOXO3-dependent manner are proposed as direct approaches to promote healthy longevity by targeting aging pathways.

Various pharmaceuticals (e.g., PI3K/AKT inhibitors, AMPK activators, HDAC inhibitors) and nutraceuticals (e.g., polyphenols, terpenoids) can activate FOXO3, suggesting a mechanistic basis for interventions that modulate aging processes.

theories.evidence: Review of compounds known to activate FOXO3 or affect healthspan/lifespan in a FOXO3-dependent manner, including genetic association studies linking FOXO3 variants to longevity and disease risk.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism (FOXO3 activity) influencing aging and healthspan at the organismal level, supported by genetic and pharmacological evidence; addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow disease or organ.

results.title: Sumoylation in Cellular Senescence and Aging.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence refers to the irreversible growth arrest of cells in response to various stressors. Senescent cells accumulate with age and contribute to tissue dysfunction and organismal aging through secretion of pro-inflammatory factors and altering tissue microenvironments.

Sumoylation is a reversible post-translational modification that attaches SUMO peptides to target proteins, modulating their function. Key proteins that regulate cellular senescence are modified by sumoylation, influencing the senescence process and potentially impacting aging.

Global protein sumoylation levels and expression of sumoylation pathway components change during organismal aging, suggesting sumoylation dynamics may be involved in the aging process at the organism level.

theories.evidence: Summary of recent findings showing altered sumoylation in aging and sumoylation of senescence regulators; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory addresses a fundamental aging mechanism (cellular senescence) with sumoylation as a regulatory process, linking molecular modification to organismal aging. It proposes causal mechanisms (sumoylation modulating senescence factors) and is generalizable beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Age-associated alterations in immune function and inflammation.

theories.name: Immunosenescence theory

key_concepts.description: Immunosenescence describes the progressive deterioration of the immune system with age, characterized by reduced proliferation and function of immune cells, especially T cells, leading to impaired immune responses.

key_concepts.concept: Alterations in innate and adaptive immunity
key_concepts.description: Age causes changes in innate immune functions such as chemotaxis, phagocytosis, natural killer activity, and antigen presentation, as well as adaptive immunity changes including decreased naive T cells and altered B cell function.

key_concepts.concept: Increased susceptibility to infections and cancer
key_concepts.description: The decline in immune competence due to immunosenescence results in higher vulnerability of older adults to infections, reduced vaccine efficacy, and increased cancer risk.

theories.evidence: Summary of multiple studies describing cellular and functional immune changes with age across species; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging-related immune decline affecting organismal aging; addresses broad immune system changes linked to aging.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.description: Inflammaging refers to the persistent, systemic, low-level inflammatory state observed in older individuals, characterized by elevated circulating inflammatory mediators.
This chronic inflammation is proposed to contribute causally to various age-associated diseases and functional impairments, linking immune dysregulation to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies measuring increased inflammatory markers in older adults; conceptual linkage to aging consequences.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a general mechanism explaining how systemic inflammation drives aging processes broadly, beyond specific diseases.

results.title: Mechanisms underlying the interplay between autophagy and the inflammasome in age-related diseases: Implications for exercise immunology.

theories.name: Autophagy-Inflammasome Dysregulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Autophagy is a cellular process responsible for degrading damaged organelles and misfolded proteins. With aging, autophagic activity decreases, leading to accumulation of dysfunctional cellular components that contribute to cellular dysfunction.

The inflammasome is a key mediator of inflammatory responses. In aging tissues, inflammasome activation becomes excessive, driving chronic low-grade inflammation known as inflammaging, which contributes to systemic aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Interplay between autophagy decline and inflammasome activation
key_concepts.description: The dysregulated interaction between reduced autophagy and increased inflammasome activation exacerbates cellular dysfunction and inflammation, promoting the development and progression of multiple age-related diseases such as cancer, arthritis, neurodegeneration, and cardiovascular diseases.

Moderate exercise enhances autophagic flux and mitochondrial quality control, reducing reactive oxygen species and suppressing inflammasome activation. This leads to decreased pro-inflammatory cytokines and restoration of cellular homeostasis, mitigating aging effects and disease progression.

theories.evidence: The paper cites findings from animal and human studies showing exercise-induced upregulation of autophagy proteins (BECLIN1, LC3, ATG12), reduction of inflammasome activation (NLRP3), decreased inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-18), and improvements in cognitive function, joint health, and cardiovascular risk.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining aging as a systemic process involving autophagy decline and inflammasome-driven inflammation; it addresses multiple organ systems and age-related diseases; it provides mechanistic explanations rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Heterogeneous aging across multiple organ systems and prediction of chronic disease and mortality.
Is aging a "Retro"spective event?

theories.name: Endogenous Retrovirus Reactivation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Endogenous retroviruses, remnants of ancient viral infections embedded in the genome, become reactivated during old age. This reactivation is linked to epigenetic derepression, meaning that the usual silencing mechanisms controlling ERVs weaken with age.
The reactivated ERVs contribute causally to the induction of cellular senescence, a state of permanent cell cycle arrest that is a known driver of aging phenotypes and tissue dysfunction.
ERV reactivation leads to age-associated chronic inflammation, a hallmark of aging, by triggering immune responses that sustain inflammatory signaling in aged tissues.

theories.evidence: The abstract references findings by Liu et al. showing ERV reactivation in old age induces senescence and is associated with epigenetic derepression and chronic inflammation, indicating experimental data supporting these mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (cellular senescence and chronic inflammation) at the organismal level via ERV reactivation, proposes a causal mechanism (epigenetic derepression leading to ERV activation causing senescence), and addresses broad aging phenomena rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific effect.

results.title: Gcn5- and Bre1-mediated Set2 degradation promotes chronological aging of Saccharomyces cerevisiae.
Murine models of life span extension.

theories.name: Growth Hormone/Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (GH/IGF-1) Signaling Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This pathway involves growth hormone and insulin-like growth factor 1 signaling that regulates growth and metabolism. Mutations or defects in this pathway can lead to dwarfism and are associated with extended lifespan in mice, suggesting a causal role in aging regulation.

Targeted mutations in components of the GH/IGF-1 pathway, such as the GH receptor, p66Shc, and IGF-1 receptor, can extend lifespan. Some mutations decouple longevity effects from dwarfism, indicating that lifespan extension is not solely due to reduced body size but involves specific genetic mechanisms.
The lifespan extension observed in mutant mice may result from an increased capacity to resist oxidative damage, linking the GH/IGF-1 pathway to damage accumulation theories of aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of mutant mice models with defects in GH/IGF-1 pathway showing extended lifespan and phenotypic resemblance to caloric restriction; targeted mutations affecting pathway components and their effects on lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging involving a fundamental neurohormonal pathway affecting organismal lifespan, supported by genetic evidence in model organisms.

results.title: The constantly changing face of chromatin.

theories.name: Chromatin structure and aging theory

key_concepts.description: Chromatin is not static but highly dynamic, with various proteins altering its structure, which in turn regulates cellular functions. This dynamic nature is crucial for understanding how chromatin influences cell behavior over time.

Changes in chromatin structure and function are proposed to be linked to the aging process at the cellular level. The theory suggests that alterations in chromatin may contribute causally to aging mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Mechanistic link between chromatin and aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that elucidating the mechanisms by which chromatin alterations affect aging will provide fundamental insights into why and how biological aging occurs, potentially revealing chromatin as a driver or regulator of aging.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing recent findings on chromatin dynamics and its regulatory roles, discussing possible links to aging without presenting new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain aging as a fundamental process via chromatin dynamics, proposes mechanisms linking chromatin changes to aging, and addresses aging broadly at the cellular level, thus meeting the core criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Autophagy and metabolic aging: Current understanding and future applications.

theories.name: Autophagy-mediated metabolic aging theory

key_concepts.description: Metabolic aging is characterized by a gradual decline in cellular metabolic function across various tissues, driven by factors such as defective hormonal signaling, impaired nutrient sensing, mitochondrial dysfunction, replicative stress, and cellular senescence. This decline contributes to systemic aging and age-related diseases.

Autophagy is a cellular housekeeping process that maintains tissue rejuvenation and health by degrading and recycling damaged cellular components. Proper autophagy function is essential to prevent the accumulation of cellular damage that underlies metabolic aging.

Environmental toxins, hormonal imbalances, lifestyle changes, and nutrient imbalances can disrupt autophagy, leading to premature cellular fatigue and early onset of metabolic aging, which may manifest as metabolic diseases and cancers at younger ages.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review that synthesizes current understanding and literature on autophagy’s role in metabolic aging, discussing regulatory mechanisms and extrinsic factors affecting autophagy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (metabolic aging) at the organismal level, proposes autophagy dysfunction as a causal mechanism, and addresses broad aging phenomena rather than narrow disease-specific issues.

results.title: Gene regulatory networks in disease and ageing.
The potential roles of excitatory-inhibitory imbalances and the repressor element-1 silencing transcription factor in aging and aging-associated diseases.

theories.name: Excitatory-Inhibitory (E/I) Imbalance Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging induces an increase in excitatory neural signaling relative to inhibitory signaling, causing an imbalance in the excitatory-inhibitory (E/I) ratio in the central nervous system. This imbalance is linked to neural pathologies and shorter lifespans across multiple species.
The E/I imbalance is associated with aging-related neural dysfunction and diseases such as Alzheimer's, suggesting that maintaining E/I homeostasis is critical for healthy aging and longevity.

theories.evidence: Correlations between increased excitatory signaling and shorter lifespan in mice, flies, and worms; human longevity correlates with repression of excitatory neurotransmission genes; literature on neural pathologies linked to E/I imbalance.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging-related changes in neural signaling contribute to organism-level aging and neurodegeneration.

theories.name: REST (Repressor Element-1 Silencing Transcription Factor) Protective Role Theory

key_concepts.description: REST is upregulated in response to senescent stimuli and acts to repress genes involved in excitatory neurotransmission, thereby countering hyperexcitability and maintaining neuronal homeostasis.
REST activity reduces insulin/insulin-like signaling pathway activity, oxidative stress, and neurodegeneration, suggesting it plays a protective role against aging-associated neural decline.

theories.evidence: Literature evidence on REST upregulation with senescence, its regulatory effects on excitatory signaling and stress pathways, and correlations with neuroprotection.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a mechanistic explanation for how a transcription factor modulates aging-related neural changes and contributes to systemic aging processes.

results.title: Dietary advanced glycation end products (AGEs): A modifiable risk factor in the prevention of chronic diseases associated with aging?

theories.name: Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: AGEs are heterogeneous compounds formed via non-enzymatic reactions between reducing sugars or their oxidation metabolites and amino groups in proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids. They accumulate endogenously, especially under hyperglycemic conditions, and exogenously through dietary intake, particularly from thermally processed foods.

key_concepts.concept: AGEs as causal contributors to aging and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of AGEs in tissues is associated with biological aging and the pathogenesis of multiple chronic diseases common in aging, such as diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, musculoskeletal disorders, and neurodegeneration. AGEs contribute to cellular senescence and tissue dysfunction, suggesting a mechanistic role in systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Dietary modulation of systemic AGE burden
key_concepts.description: Dietary intake of AGEs significantly contributes to the total systemic load of these compounds. Therefore, reducing dietary AGEs is proposed as a modifiable risk factor to prevent or delay chronic diseases associated with aging, implying a potential intervention point in the aging process.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews current evidence on molecular mechanisms linking dietary and endogenous AGEs to cellular senescence and age-associated pathologies, citing studies on AGE formation, accumulation, and disease associations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (AGE accumulation) with causal mechanisms (non-enzymatic glycation leading to cellular senescence and disease), has generalizability across multiple tissues and diseases, and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

results.title: Aging at the interface of stem cell renewal, apoptosis, senescence, and cancer.
Meeting report--National Institute on Aging Workshop on the Comparative Biology of Aging.
Environmental Training and Synaptic Functions in Young and Old Brain: A Presynaptic Perspective.
Lamin A involvement in ageing processes.

theories.name: Lamin A sensor theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Lamin A as a stress sensor
key_concepts.description: Lamin A acts as a sensor of intrinsic cellular and environmental stress by transient accumulation of prelamin A, which triggers cellular stress response mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Prelamin A accumulation and stress response
key_concepts.description: Stable elevation of prelamin A levels exacerbates the sensor activity of lamin A, leading to a permanent stress response state that contributes to accelerated aging.

Accumulated prelamin A affects multiple aging-related pathways including mTOR signaling, epigenetic modifications, inflammation, microRNA activation, and mechanosignaling, linking lamin A defects to systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: Citations of progeroid laminopathies caused by LMNA mutations, description of molecular pathways affected by prelamin A accumulation, and mechanistic links to accelerated aging phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how lamin A dysfunction drives systemic aging processes through stress sensing and response pathways, supported by disease models and molecular data.

results.title: Functional connectivity-based compensation in the brains of non-demented older adults and the influence of lifestyle: A longitudinal 7-year study.
Insights into targeting cellular senescence with senolytic therapy: The journey from preclinical trials to clinical practice.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cell cycle arrest in response to damage
