key_concepts.description: Cells enter a state of permanent cell cycle arrest when exposed to harmful stimuli, preventing proliferation but remaining metabolically active.

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cell accumulation and tissue dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Persistent senescent cells accumulate with age and secrete a variety of proteins (senescence-associated secretory phenotype, SASP) that can disrupt tissue structure and function, contributing to organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Senolytic intervention to remove senescent cells
key_concepts.description: Targeted elimination of senescent cells using small-molecule senolytic drugs can delay, halt, or reverse age-related diseases and dysfunction, suggesting a causal role of senescence in aging.

theories.evidence: Summary of preclinical models demonstrating that senolytic interventions delay or reverse diseases; discussion of translation to clinical practice.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging mechanism (cellular senescence) with causal implications for systemic aging; proposes underlying mechanisms; discusses interventions targeting senescence as a general aging process.

results.title: Autophagy and senescence, converging roles in pathophysiology as seen through mouse models.

theories.name: Cellular senescence and autophagy interplay theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate in the body with advancing age, contributing to aging-related pathologies. These cells undergo permanent cell cycle arrest and secrete pro-inflammatory factors that affect tissue function.
Autophagy, a cellular degradation and recycling process, decreases in activity as organisms age, impairing cellular homeostasis and contributing to aging and disease.
Senescence and autophagy pathways converge in their effects on aging and cancer development, as evidenced by genetic mouse models showing overlapping pathological outcomes.

theories.evidence: Review of evidence from genetic mouse models linking senescence and autophagy to aging and cancer; references to molecular, cellular, and physiological changes correlated with age.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses general aging mechanisms (senescence and autophagy) with causal explanations for aging processes, supported by organism-level models; it is not limited to a narrow phenomenon or specific disease alone.

results.title: Adipose-derived stem cells regulate metabolic homeostasis and delay aging by promoting mitophagy.

theories.name: Mitophagy-mediated metabolic homeostasis theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitophagy as a driver of aging delay
key_concepts.description: Mitophagy, the selective degradation of damaged mitochondria, is proposed as a key mechanism that eliminates intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) and improves mitochondrial quality, thereby delaying cellular and organismal aging.

The theory posits that aging involves a shift in cellular metabolism from anabolism to catabolism, and that promoting mitophagy can restore metabolic balance towards anabolism, which supports tissue and organismal health.

key_concepts.concept: Stem cell intervention to modulate aging
key_concepts.description: Adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells (ADSCs) are proposed to exert anti-aging effects by promoting mitophagy and metabolic homeostasis, thereby delaying replicative senescence and improving aging phenotypes in progeroid models.

theories.evidence: Experimental intervention with ADSCs on senescent cells and POLG knockin progeroid animal models showed delayed replicative senescence, improved metabolic profiles via metabolomics, enhanced mitophagy, reduced ROS, and amelioration of aging phenotypes such as alopecia and kyphosis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (mitophagy-mediated mitochondrial quality control) underlying aging, supported by experimental data in cells and animal models, addressing systemic aging processes rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: The cGAS-STING pathway in aging and neurological diseases: From mechanisms to treatment.

theories.name: cGAS-STING pathway as a driver of aging-related inflammation and cellular dysfunction

key_concepts.description: The cGAS-STING pathway detects cytosolic DNA, triggering immune signaling cascades that lead to the production of interferons and inflammatory cytokines. This immune activation is implicated in aging-related chronic inflammation.

key_concepts.concept: Link to cellular dysfunction in aging
key_concepts.description: Dysfunctions such as autophagy impairment, mitochondrial dysfunction, chromosome instability, and micronucleus DNA formation are connected to aberrant activation of the cGAS-STING pathway, contributing to cellular and tissue aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role in neurodegenerative and neuroimmune diseases
key_concepts.description: The pathway is involved in the pathogenesis of aging-related neurological disorders by mediating neuroinflammation and immune responses, suggesting a mechanistic link between innate immunity and neurodegeneration.

theories.evidence: Summary of relationships between aging phenomena and cGAS-STING pathway; references to neurodegenerative diseases and immune dysfunction; discussion of therapeutic inhibitors targeting the pathway.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a mechanistic explanation of aging-related chronic inflammation and cellular dysfunction at an organismal level, linking immune signaling to general aging processes and neurological disease; it addresses causal mechanisms rather than mere correlation.

results.title: Altered microRNA expression links IL6 and TNF-induced inflammaging with myeloid malignancy in humans and mice.

theories.name: Inflammaging-driven hematopoietic stem cell aging and myeloid malignancy theory

key_concepts.concept: Inflammaging as a driver of HSC dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Chronic low-grade inflammation associated with aging ('inflammaging') contributes causally to impaired hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) function and increased risk of myeloid malignancy. This inflammation involves pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL6 and TNF.

Decline or loss of microRNA miR-146a with age leads to increased inflammation by dysregulating inflammatory signaling pathways, particularly involving NF-κB, IL6, and TNF, which promotes HSC dysfunction and malignant transformation.

key_concepts.concept: Cell-extrinsic and cell-intrinsic mechanisms linking inflammation to HSC aging
key_concepts.description: Loss of miR-146a increases both the inflammatory milieu (cell-extrinsic) and the sensitivity of HSCs to inflammatory cytokines (cell-intrinsic), together driving premature HSC aging and myeloid malignancy.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammation reduction as a therapeutic intervention
key_concepts.description: Targeting IL6 or TNF to reduce inflammation can restore HSC function and reduce malignancy incidence, supporting a causal role of inflammaging in systemic aging of the hematopoietic system.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from miR-146a-null mice showing premature HSC aging, inflammation, and myeloid malignancy; single-cell assays of HSC function; DNA methylation and transcriptome profiling implicating inflammatory pathways; intervention studies targeting IL6 and TNF that restore HSC function and reduce malignancy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (inflammaging via miR-146a loss) underlying systemic aging of the hematopoietic system and increased malignancy risk; it explains why and how aging occurs at the organism level via inflammatory signaling; it is not limited to a narrow phenomenon but addresses fundamental aging processes in HSCs and systemic inflammation.

results.title: The mitochondrial production of reactive oxygen species in relation to aging and pathology.

theories.name: Mitochondrial free radical theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Mitochondria produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) as byproducts of aerobic respiration, particularly at complex I of the electron transport chain.
ROS cause oxidative damage to mitochondrial lipids, proteins, and mtDNA, impairing mitochondrial function.

key_concepts.concept: Vicious cycle of ROS and mitochondrial dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Damage to mtDNA leads to defective respiratory complex subunits, reducing electron transfer efficiency and increasing ROS production, creating a self-amplifying cycle of oxidative stress and energetic decline.

key_concepts.concept: Energetic decline as a cause of aging
key_concepts.description: The resulting mitochondrial energetic deficiency is proposed as a fundamental cause of aging and age-related degenerative diseases.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing age-related decline in complex I activity in rat brain and liver mitochondria and human platelets; biochemical studies identifying Fe-S cluster N2 as the electron donor to oxygen; effects of CoQ analogues on ROS production; evidence for antioxidant role of reduced CoQ(10) and involvement of cellular reductases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging at the organismal level based on mitochondrial ROS and damage accumulation, explaining why aging occurs through energetic decline; it is not limited to a specific organ or disease but addresses systemic aging.

results.title: Attenuated heat shock transcriptional response in aging: molecular mechanism and implication in the biology of aging.

theories.name: Heat Shock Response Attenuation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by a progressive decline in the ability of cells and organisms to mount an effective heat shock transcriptional response to environmental and physiological stresses, leading to reduced production of heat shock proteins (HSPs).

HSF1 is a key transcription factor regulating the heat shock response. Age-dependent changes in cellular redox status, including increased reactive oxygen species and accumulation of oxidatively-modified proteins, impair HSF1 regulation and function, contributing to the diminished heat shock response in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on protein homeostasis and organismal health
key_concepts.description: Since HSPs are crucial for protein homeostasis and signal transduction, the compromised ability to produce HSPs in response to stress during aging likely contributes to increased morbidity and mortality observed in aged organisms.

theories.evidence: Experimental evidence from multiple mammalian aging model systems including human diploid fibroblasts, whole animals, animal-derived cells and cultures, and peripheral blood mononuclear cells from human donors.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (attenuated heat shock response via HSF1 dysfunction) explaining why aging occurs at the organismal level by linking impaired stress response and protein homeostasis to aging phenotypes.

results.title: Developing a research agenda in biogerontology: basic mechanisms.
Role of circadian CLOCK signaling in cellular senescence.

theories.name: Circadian CLOCK signaling as a regulator of cellular senescence and aging

key_concepts.description: The circadian rhythm aligns physiological processes with the 24-hour light-dark cycle, maintaining cellular and tissue homeostasis essential for organismal health.

key_concepts.concept: CLOCK protein's dual role in aging and cancer
key_concepts.description: CLOCK protein regulates gene transcription related to tissue homeostasis, cellular senescence, and DNA repair. In normal cells, it promotes rejuvenation by activating DNA repair factors and modulating metabolism, whereas in tumor cells, oncogenic factors hijack CLOCK signaling to inhibit senescence and promote proliferation.
CLOCK interacts with pathways such as mTOR and NF-κB to regulate autophagy and control harmful secretions that affect tissue function, linking circadian regulation to aging mechanisms.
Gut microbiota-derived signals via the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR) can disrupt the CLOCK-BMAL1 complex, thereby affecting circadian rhythms and potentially accelerating aging processes.

theories.evidence: Draws from animal and human studies, molecular research on CLOCK interactions with DNA repair factors (e.g., XPA), oncogenic drivers (c-MYC, Pdia3), and signaling pathways (mTOR, NF-κB), as well as microbiota-related influences.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining how circadian CLOCK signaling influences cellular senescence and systemic aging processes, providing causal explanations and linking molecular pathways to organism-level aging.

results.title: The regulation of stem cell aging by Wnt signaling.

theories.name: Wnt signaling regulation of stem cell aging

key_concepts.concept: Wnt signaling as a regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: Wnt signaling is a highly conserved secreted molecule essential for development and tissue function. It regulates aging processes by influencing stem cell behavior and tissue regeneration.

key_concepts.concept: Downregulation of Wnt signaling impairs neurogenesis
key_concepts.description: With aging, Wnt signaling decreases in neuronal tissue, leading to reduced neurogenesis and contributing to age-related neuronal dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Excessive Wnt signaling causes sarcopenia via satellite cell trans-differentiation
key_concepts.description: In skeletal muscle, excessive upregulation of Wnt signaling with aging induces myogenic-to-fibrogenic trans-differentiation of satellite cells, impairing muscle regeneration and causing sarcopenia.

key_concepts.concept: Exercise modulates Wnt signaling to counteract aging effects
key_concepts.description: Exercise upregulates Wnt signaling, promoting neurogenesis and myogenesis, thereby preventing or mitigating age-related tissue decline.

theories.mode: review, discuss, propose exercise as therapy
theories.evidence: Summary of recent research findings and literature on Wnt signaling pathways in aging neuronal and muscle tissues; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological mechanism (Wnt signaling) that regulates aging processes across multiple tissues, proposes causal mechanisms (signaling changes causing stem cell dysfunction and tissue aging), and links to systemic aging phenomena such as sarcopenia and neurogenesis decline. Thus, it meets the criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: The hormetic and hermetic role of IL-6.

theories.name: Hormesis theory of aging mediated by IL-6

key_concepts.description: Hormesis is a biological phenomenon where a molecule or stimulus can have beneficial effects at low doses but harmful effects at high doses. In the context of IL-6, low or controlled release promotes anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and pro-myogenic effects, whereas high systemic levels induce pro-inflammatory, pro-oxidant, and pro-fibrotic responses.

IL-6 is proposed as a 'Gerokine,' a cytokine that acts as a determinant in the transition from normal physiological aging to age-related pathological conditions. Its deregulation is implicated in chronic inflammation and oxidative stress, key drivers of aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Dual and hermetic nature of IL-6 signaling
key_concepts.description: IL-6 has pleiotropic and sometimes contradictory effects on different tissues, depending on the intensity, persistence, and context of signaling. This complexity underlies its role in both maintaining tissue homeostasis and contributing to aging-related dysfunction.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews mechanistic insights and molecular networks involving IL-6 in aging and chronic diseases, with a focus on skeletal muscle. It discusses existing literature on IL-6's dual roles and its involvement in inflammation and oxidative stress related to aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how IL-6 signaling contributes causally to aging processes via hormesis and inflammatory regulation, addressing systemic aging mechanisms rather than a narrow phenomenon. It proposes underlying principles (hormesis, Gerokine concept) that relate to organism-level aging and age-related diseases.

results.title: Senescence-associated alterations in the extracellular matrix: deciphering their role in the regulation of cellular function.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Senescent cells develop a distinct secretory profile known as the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), which alters the composition and organization of the extracellular matrix (ECM) and influences the tissue microenvironment.

key_concepts.concept: ECM alterations as mediators of aging
key_concepts.description: Changes in the ECM driven by senescent cells disrupt normal tissue homeostasis and contribute to age-related tissue dysfunction and pathologies, suggesting that ECM remodeling is a key mechanism linking cellular senescence to organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Targeting senescence-associated ECM changes for anti-aging
key_concepts.description: Because senescence-associated ECM alterations may drive age-related conditions, they represent potential targets for novel anti-aging therapeutic interventions aimed at restoring tissue function and delaying aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews characteristic ECM changes elicited by cellular senescence and discusses their interplay with senescent cells in normal aging and age-associated diseases, citing existing literature.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (senescent cells altering ECM) that contributes to systemic aging processes, is generalizable beyond specific organs or diseases, and addresses fundamental aging biology.

results.title: NAD<sup>+</sup> glycohydrolases-CD38 as a therapeutic target in aging: physiological roles, molecular mechanisms, and future opportunities in anti-aging research.

theories.name: CD38-mediated NAD+ depletion theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: NAD+ decline as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) is essential for cellular metabolism and energy production. Its levels decline with age, contributing to tissue dysfunction and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: CD38 as a major NAD+ consumer
key_concepts.description: CD38 is a multifunctional enzyme that degrades NAD+, and its expression increases with age, leading to accelerated NAD+ depletion.
The age-associated increase in CD38 expression reduces NAD+ availability, which impairs cellular homeostasis and accelerates aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of CD38 to slow aging
key_concepts.description: Inhibiting CD38 activity can restore NAD+ levels, ameliorate age-related tissue degeneration, and potentially slow down the aging process.

theories.evidence: Correlative studies showing increased CD38 expression with age, experimental data indicating CD38 deficiency slows aging, and research on small-molecule CD38 inhibitors as therapeutic agents.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory proposes a general causal mechanism for aging based on NAD+ metabolism regulated by CD38, applicable broadly to organismal aging and age-related diseases. It explains how a molecular mechanism (CD38-mediated NAD+ depletion) drives systemic aging, meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Age and gender intersectionality among African Americans: Salivary uric acid is associated with shorter telomere length in younger adults and men.
Boosting neuronal activity-driven mitochondrial DNA transcription improves cognition in aged mice.

theories.name: Neuronal activity-driven mitochondrial DNA transcription coupling (E-TC_mito) theory of brain aging

key_concepts.concept: Age-dependent coupling between neuronal excitation and mitochondrial DNA transcription
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that neuronal and synaptic excitation regulate mitochondrial DNA transcription through a specific coupling mechanism (E-TC_mito) that differs from classical nuclear excitation-transcription coupling (E-TC_nuc). This coupling is critical for maintaining mitochondrial function in neurons.

key_concepts.concept: Repurposing of nuclear excitation-transcription molecules for mitochondrial regulation
key_concepts.description: Molecules traditionally involved in nuclear excitation-transcription coupling are repurposed in neurons to regulate mitochondrial DNA expression in synaptically active areas, linking neuronal activity directly to mitochondrial gene expression.

key_concepts.concept: Age-related decline in E-TC_mito effectiveness contributes to neurological deficits
key_concepts.description: The weakening of this mitochondrial transcription coupling with age leads to impaired mitochondrial function and synaptic deficits, which underlie cognitive decline observed in aging brains.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic potential of boosting E-TC_mito to ameliorate cognitive decline
key_concepts.description: Enhancing the E-TC_mito mechanism in aged animals improves mitochondrial function and cognitive performance, suggesting a causal role of this pathway in brain aging and a potential intervention target.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from aged mice demonstrating age-dependent decline in E-TC_mito, molecular characterization of the coupling mechanism, and intervention studies showing cognitive improvement upon boosting E-TC_mito.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how neuronal activity influences mitochondrial function contributing to brain aging, with implications for systemic cognitive decline. It addresses aging broadly at the organismal level (brain function), proposes causal mechanisms, and is not limited to a narrow phenomenon or disease.

results.title: Pin1: a new genetic link between Alzheimer's disease, cancer and aging.

theories.name: Pin1-mediated regulation theory of aging and age-related diseases

key_concepts.description: Pin1 is a unique enzyme that catalyzes conformational changes in phosphorylated proteins, switching them between distinct functional states. This post-phosphorylation regulation is critical for cellular signaling and protein activity.

In neurons, Pin1 maintains cellular health by restoring phosphorylated tau and amyloid precursor protein to functional states. Loss of Pin1 activity leads to accumulation of abnormal tau and β-amyloid, key pathological features of Alzheimer's disease.

key_concepts.concept: Pin1 role in cancer and cell cycle regulation
key_concepts.description: Pin1 regulates the cell cycle and is essential for cell division. Overexpression of Pin1 can promote oncogenesis through multiple signaling pathways, linking it to cancer development.

key_concepts.concept: Inverse relationship between Alzheimer's disease and cancer mediated by Pin1
key_concepts.description: Epidemiological data suggest an inverse risk relationship between neurodegenerative diseases and cancer, potentially explained by Pin1 activity levels influencing both processes.
Pin1 deficiency in mice causes an early-aging phenotype, indicating that Pin1 activity is necessary for healthy aging and prevention of age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Epidemiologic data on inverse disease risk, mouse model data showing early-aging phenotype with Pin1 deficiency, biochemical studies on Pin1 function in tau and amyloid regulation, and cancer signaling pathways involving Pin1.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (Pin1 enzyme activity) linking molecular regulation to systemic aging and age-related diseases, addressing aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases, and offering mechanistic insight into why aging and related pathologies occur.

results.title: The Role of Innate Immunity in Healthy Aging Through Antimicrobial Peptides.

theories.name: Innate Immunity and Antimicrobial Peptides (AMPs) as Modulators of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Innate immune system as a first line of defense
key_concepts.description: The innate immune response provides a rapid, nonspecific defense against pathogens and abnormal cells, which is crucial for maintaining health especially in aging organisms where immune function declines.

key_concepts.concept: Role of antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) in aging
key_concepts.description: AMPs are immune effectors produced by innate immunity that have conserved regulatory mechanisms across species and may modulate aging processes and age-related diseases by maintaining immune homeostasis and preventing infections.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary conservation of innate immunity mechanisms
key_concepts.description: The regulatory pathways controlling AMP production are conserved from invertebrates to mammals, suggesting an evolutionary adaptation of innate immunity that impacts healthspan and longevity.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing studies on innate immunity and AMPs across species, summarizing evolutionary principles and regulatory mechanisms; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism (innate immunity via AMPs) influencing aging broadly, discusses conserved causal pathways, and connects immune aging to systemic aging processes.

results.title: Host and microbiota metabolic signals in aging and longevity.

theories.name: Metabolite signaling theory of aging and longevity

key_concepts.description: Specific metabolites produced by the host organism and its microbiota act as signaling molecules that actively regulate the aging process and longevity. These metabolites influence molecular pathways that modulate lifespan and healthspan.

The symbiotic relationship between the host and its microbiota generates a diverse array of metabolites that collectively impact aging. The metabolic crosstalk between host and microbiota is a fundamental mechanism influencing systemic aging.

State-of-the-art technologies for metabolite discovery, profiling, and imaging are crucial for identifying aging- and longevity-regulating metabolites and understanding their molecular mechanisms. These tools facilitate systematic exploration of metabolic signals in aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of emerging studies uncovering specific metabolites that regulate longevity; discussion of recent technological advances enabling these discoveries.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (metabolite signaling) underlying aging and longevity at the organismal level, integrating host and microbiota contributions. It addresses fundamental biochemical processes influencing systemic aging rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Cellular senescence in ageing, age-related disease and longevity.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is defined as a state where cells permanently stop dividing, which prevents proliferation. This arrest can be triggered by telomere shortening (replicative senescence) or by stress factors (stress-induced premature senescence).

Senescent cells secrete proinflammatory cytokines and other factors that create a low-grade chronic inflammatory environment. This SASP contributes to tissue dysfunction and promotes age-related pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Dual role in cancer and aging
key_concepts.description: While cellular senescence acts as a tumor suppressive mechanism by halting proliferation of damaged cells, the SASP paradoxically can promote cancer development through inflammation and tissue remodeling.
Senescent cells accumulate in various tissues with age and contribute to diseases such as atherosclerosis and insulin resistance by affecting vascular cells and adipocytes, respectively.

Modulating cellular senescence through elimination of senescent cells, epigenetic reprogramming, or altering SASP is proposed as a pro-longevity strategy, with some pharmacological interventions showing promise.

theories.evidence: Detection of senescent cells in multiple species and tissues using markers; evidence linking senescent cells and SASP to inflammation and age-related diseases; references to pharmacological interventions targeting senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental biological aging process at organism level; proposes causal mechanisms (cell cycle arrest, SASP-driven inflammation); addresses aging broadly including systemic effects and age-related diseases; not limited to single organ or disease.

results.title: Exploring the fuzzy border between senolytics and senomorphics with chemoinformatics and systems pharmacology.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Senescent cells progressively accumulate in tissues during aging, contributing to age-related functional decline and disease.
Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory molecules collectively termed SASP, which promote chronic inflammation and tissue dysfunction, driving aging and degenerative diseases.

Pharmacological approaches such as senolytics (which selectively eliminate senescent cells) and senomorphics (which modulate SASP) aim to mitigate the detrimental effects of senescent cells on organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Comparative chemoinformatic and systems pharmacology analysis of 84 senolytics and 79 senomorphics, including physicochemical, structural, pharmacological properties and transcriptome perturbation data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a general causal mechanism of aging (cellular senescence and SASP), proposes pharmacological interventions targeting fundamental aging processes, and addresses organism-level aging consequences.

results.title: Metabolic regulation of immunological aging.

theories.name: Immunometabolic theory of aging

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that changes in cellular and organismal metabolism after reproductive age influence the function and aging of the immune system, linking metabolic alterations to immunological decline.

key_concepts.concept: Chronic inflammation from innate immune cells
key_concepts.description: Unresolved chronic inflammation driven by innate immune cells contributes to organismal functional decline and limits healthspan and lifespan, acting as a mechanistic driver of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Thymic involution and T cell repertoire restriction
key_concepts.description: Age-related thymic involution leads to loss of naive T cells and a restricted T cell receptor diversity, impairing adaptive immunity and contributing to immunosenescence and systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of immune and metabolic systems in aging
key_concepts.description: The immune and metabolic systems are interconnected and modifiable; their dysregulation underlies increased disease susceptibility and functional decline with age, suggesting a unifying mechanism for aging.
Genetic, pharmacological, and dietary interventions that modulate immunometabolic pathways may extend lifespan and healthspan by mitigating immunological aging.

theories.mode: review, synthesize, highlight potential unifying mechanisms
theories.evidence: Overview and synthesis of hallmarks of immunological aging, discussion of genetic, pharmacological, and dietary interventions; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging involving immune and metabolic system interactions, addressing organism-level aging mechanisms and potential interventions.

results.title: Cellular parabioisis as a senotherapeutic approach.

theories.name: Cellular parabiosis theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Cells communicate through direct and indirect signaling mechanisms, which regulate individual and collective cellular behaviors. This communication is fundamental to maintaining tissue health and delaying age-related dysfunction.
Aging is associated with increased heterogeneity among cells, including senescent and stem cells, which contributes to functional decline and the development of age-related diseases.

Heterochronic parabiosis and stem cell transplantation studies show that exposure to a youthful systemic environment can restore balanced signaling, reduce cell heterogeneity, and rejuvenate aged cells, reversing age-related regenerative decline.

Cellular parabiosis-like approaches, including stem cell transplantation, hold promise as senotherapeutic strategies to combat aging and its associated pathologies by restoring tissue function and regenerative capacity.

theories.evidence: Citations of heterochronic parabiosis and stem cell transplantation studies, reports on autologous and allogeneic stem cell transplants, and references to ongoing clinical trials.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining how aging occurs through altered cellular communication and heterogeneity, offers a causal explanation linking cell signaling and heterogeneity to aging, and addresses aging broadly at the organismal level through systemic and cellular interactions.

results.title: The Essential Mechanisms of Aging: What Have We Learnt in Ten Years?

theories.name: Entropy-Linked Molecular Dysfunction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Molecular dysfunction due to failure of maintenance systems
key_concepts.description: Aging results from the progressive failure of cellular and molecular maintenance mechanisms, leading to accumulation of dysfunctional molecules and systems.

key_concepts.concept: Entropy increase as a fundamental driver of biological aging
key_concepts.description: Biological aging is linked to an increase in entropy at the molecular level, which differs fundamentally from entropy-related damage in inorganic materials.

key_concepts.concept: Lipofuscin accumulation as an indicator of irreversible molecular damage
key_concepts.description: Lipofuscin formation represents an important biochemical hallmark of aging, reflecting irreparable accumulative changes that increase biological entropy.

key_concepts.concept: Role of biochemical functional groups ('life codes') beyond genomics and proteomics
key_concepts.description: Functional groups of biomolecules, such as carbonyl groups, are proposed as critical 'missing codes' in understanding aging mechanisms, extending beyond traditional genetic and protein-centric views.

theories.evidence: Discussion of biochemical processes like carbonylation, oxidation, glycation, lipofuscin formation; historical interpretation of aging mechanisms; conceptual linkage of entropy and aging; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging at the molecular and biochemical level, addressing fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: The Proteasome and Ageing.

theories.name: Proteasome dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Proteasome function in protein quality control
key_concepts.description: The proteasome is a multi-subunit proteolytic complex responsible for degrading normal and damaged proteins, maintaining cellular homeostasis by removing abnormal or misfolded proteins that could otherwise accumulate and cause cellular damage.

With aging, the proteasome's capacity to degrade damaged proteins diminishes, as evidenced by decreased catalytic activity and altered expression of proteasome subunits in various tissues such as muscle, skin, and brain.

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of damaged proteins and feedback inhibition
key_concepts.description: The age-related buildup of damaged or misfolded proteins further impairs proteasome activity, creating a vicious cycle that exacerbates protein aggregation and cellular dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Link between proteasome dysfunction and longevity
key_concepts.description: Studies suggest that proteasome activity is connected to organismal lifespan, implying that maintaining proteasome function may influence aging and age-related pathologies, including neurodegenerative diseases characterized by protein aggregates.

theories.evidence: Evidence is drawn from multiple studies on cultured cells, model organisms, and humans showing decreased proteasome activity with age, altered proteasome subunit expression, and associations with longevity and neurodegenerative disease pathology.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs via proteasome dysfunction leading to accumulation of damaged proteins; it addresses aging broadly across tissues and organisms; and it provides mechanistic insight rather than mere correlation.

results.title: [Long-Term Effects of Epigenome Memory on Physiological Function in Aging].

theories.name: Epigenomic Memory Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The epigenome acts beyond gene regulation by capturing and storing information about environmental exposures and cellular stress, such as lifestyle factors, obesity, and DNA damage. This stored information can persist long-term, influencing cellular identity and function.
Epigenomic memory can imprint lasting changes that alter cellular and organ function, thereby contributing to the biological aging process and the development of age-related diseases.
Stress-induced DNA damage in early life can establish epigenomic memory that accelerates aging, suggesting a causal mechanism linking environmental insults to systemic aging.

Therapeutic strategies aimed at resetting or reprogramming epigenomic information hold promise for reversing aging phenotypes and treating age-related diseases, indicating a potential intervention point within this theory.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent studies showing early-life stress-induced DNA damage effects and emerging therapeutic approaches targeting epigenomic resetting; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs via epigenomic memory affecting cellular and organismal function. It addresses aging broadly and discusses underlying mechanisms rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Acetylome regulation by sirtuins in the brain: from normal physiology to aging and pathology.

theories.name: Sirtuin-mediated regulation of aging via acetylome dynamics

key_concepts.description: Lysine acetylation is a widespread post-translational modification affecting about one tenth of the proteome, influencing protein function and cellular processes. The acetylome represents the full set of acetylated proteins, whose dynamic regulation is critical for physiological and pathological states.

Sirtuins are a family of enzymes that remove acetyl groups from lysine residues on proteins using NAD+ as a cofactor. They regulate diverse cellular processes including transcription, DNA repair, energy metabolism, mitochondrial biogenesis, apoptosis, autophagy, and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of sirtuins in brain physiology and aging
key_concepts.description: In the brain, sirtuins modulate both histone and non-histone protein acetylation, impacting circadian rhythms, neurogenesis, synaptic function, cognition, serotonin synthesis, myelination, and neuropathology. Their regulation of acetylome dynamics is proposed to influence molecular mechanisms underlying brain aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews recent advances from functional genomics and proteomics studies identifying acetylome components and sirtuin functions, citing their involvement in multiple cellular and brain-specific processes relevant to aging and pathology.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how sirtuin-regulated acetylome dynamics causally influence aging processes at a systemic level, particularly in the brain, linking molecular mechanisms to organismal aging. It proposes a generalizable mechanism (protein acetylation regulation) affecting aging, not limited to a single organ or disease, and discusses causal pathways rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Why females live longer than males: control of longevity by sex hormones.

theories.name: Estrogen-mediated oxidative damage reduction theory of sex differences in longevity

key_concepts.description: Estrogens bind to estrogen receptors and increase the expression of genes associated with longevity, including those encoding antioxidant enzymes such as superoxide dismutase and glutathione peroxidase.

key_concepts.concept: Reduction of mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (ROS)
key_concepts.description: Due to estrogen action, mitochondria in females produce fewer reactive oxygen species compared to males, which may reduce oxidative damage and contribute to longer lifespan.
Sex hormones, particularly estrogens, are proposed as causal factors influencing aging rates and longevity differences between sexes by modulating oxidative stress and gene expression.

theories.evidence: Citations of gene expression changes linked to estrogen receptor binding, observations of lower mitochondrial ROS production in females, and epidemiological data on female longevity advantage.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological difference in aging rates between sexes by proposing a causal mechanism involving sex hormones and oxidative damage, thus meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: Reactive oxygen species and aging: evolving questions.

theories.name: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) Damage Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Reactive oxygen species are proposed to contribute to aging by causing cumulative damage to cellular components such as DNA, proteins, and lipids, thereby impairing cellular function over time.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic and pathway involvement in ROS homeostasis
key_concepts.description: Specific genes and molecular pathways that regulate ROS levels and oxidative stress responses have been linked to lifespan and aging processes, particularly in model organisms like Caenorhabditis elegans and Drosophila.
The theory explores whether the role of ROS in aging observed in lower organisms extends to higher organisms, questioning the universality and extent of ROS involvement in aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies linking ROS homeostasis genes and pathways to aging in lower organisms; discussion of emerging questions about ROS roles in higher organisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process (oxidative damage accumulation) with proposed causal mechanisms (ROS-mediated damage), and discusses generalizability across species.

results.title: Inflamm-ageing: How cytokines and nutrition shape the trajectory of ageing.

theories.name: Inflamm-ageing theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Inflamm-ageing refers to the age-related increase in pro-inflammatory molecules such as cytokines and chemokines, leading to a persistent, low-grade inflammatory state that mechanistically contributes to the aging process and age-related health decline.

key_concepts.concept: Balance between pro- and anti-inflammatory cytokines determines aging trajectory
key_concepts.description: The relative levels of pro-inflammatory versus anti-inflammatory cytokines influence whether an individual experiences healthy or unhealthy aging, suggesting inflammation regulation is a key mechanism shaping aging outcomes.

key_concepts.concept: Interaction between nutrition, inflammation, and aging
key_concepts.description: Malnutrition and nutritional imbalances in elderly individuals affect the balance of inflammatory mediators, linking nutritional status to inflamm-ageing and downstream consequences such as sarcopenia and frailty, thereby influencing the overall aging trajectory.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews current evidence including observed increased pro-inflammatory cytokines in aged populations, associations between malnutrition and altered cytokine levels, and links between inflammation, sarcopenia, and frailty.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how systemic inflammation drives biological aging at the organism level, supported by mechanistic links and evolutionary rationale.

results.title: Changes in brain proteasome dynamics associated with aging.

theories.name: Proteasome decline theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Proteasomes, which are essential for protein degradation and cellular homeostasis in neurons and glial cells, show decreased function with aging. This decline affects nervous system processes critical for brain health and may contribute to age-related cognitive decline.

The decline in proteasome function with age is linked to a decrease in the formation of proteasomes, including both 20S and 26S complexes. This reduction is associated with changes in proteasome subunit levels and accumulation of UMP1, a protein required for proteasome assembly.
With aging, there is an increase in the PA28-20S-PA700 complex, which is involved in immunity, suggesting a shift in proteasome complex composition that may influence brain aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from mouse brains at different ages showing decreased peptidase activity, increased ubiquitinated proteins, slight decrease in proteasome subunits, and accumulation of UMP1 protein.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (decline in proteasome formation and function) underlying aging at the organismal level (brain aging and cognitive decline), with generalizable implications for nervous system aging and possibly systemic aging.

results.title: Cardioprotective response and senescence in aged sEH null female mice exposed to LPS.

theories.name: Cellular senescence as a causal driver of systemic aging

key_concepts.description: Cells enter a state of permanent growth arrest in response to stress or damage, contributing to age-related tissue dysfunction and chronic inflammation. Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory factors that can disrupt tissue homeostasis and promote aging phenotypes.

Markers such as Il-6, Mcp1, Il-1β, Nlrp3, p21, p16, SA-β-gal, and Gdf15 indicate the presence of senescent cells and inflammatory processes that increase with age, linking cellular senescence to systemic aging and organ dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation of senescence by soluble epoxide hydrolase (sEH)
key_concepts.description: sEH metabolizes epoxy fatty acids into less bioactive diols, influencing inflammatory and senescence pathways. Genetic deletion or pharmacological inhibition of sEH attenuates senescence markers and inflammation, suggesting sEH as a modulator of aging processes in the heart.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from aged female mice with genetic deletion or pharmacological inhibition of sEH showed reduced cardiac dysfunction after LPS exposure, accompanied by decreased expression of inflammatory and senescence markers. Bulk RNA-sequencing and confirmatory analyses support these findings.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (cellular senescence and inflammation) underlying systemic aging processes in the heart, with generalizability beyond a single disease or organ by linking sEH activity to aging modulation.

results.title: Caloric intake and aging: mechanisms in rodents and a study in nonhuman primates.

theories.name: Caloric Restriction (CR) Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Reducing caloric intake without malnutrition has been shown to increase maximum lifespan in rodents and is hypothesized to have similar effects in primates. This suggests a fundamental biological mechanism linking energy intake to aging processes.

CR may retard aging by lowering oxidative stress, particularly in post-mitotic tissues, through decreased mitochondrial production of free radicals. This reduction in oxidative damage is proposed as a causal mechanism slowing biological aging.

CR induces systemic physiological changes such as decreased blood glucose and insulin levels, improved insulin sensitivity, and lowered body temperature, which are thought to contribute to its anti-aging effects.
Studies in rhesus monkeys suggest that CR effects observed in rodents may be applicable to primates, supporting the generalizability of CR as a fundamental aging mechanism across species.

theories.evidence: Rodent lifespan extension studies, physiological data from rhesus monkey CR trials, ongoing longitudinal data collection on oxidative stress and longevity in primates.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging (energy intake affecting oxidative stress and systemic physiology), addresses aging broadly across species, and is not limited to a specific organ or disease.

results.title: Telomeres and human aging: facts and fibs.

theories.name: Telomere attrition theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length and attrition rate as aging biomarkers
key_concepts.description: Telomeres shorten with cell division and age, and their length and rate of shortening may reflect biological aging processes beyond chronological age.

key_concepts.concept: Link between telomere dynamics and age-related disorders
key_concepts.description: Shorter telomeres in white blood cells are associated with increased risk of age-related diseases, possibly mediated by oxidative stress and inflammation.
Telomere length varies widely among individuals, is highly heritable, and differs by sex, with women generally having longer telomeres.
It remains unresolved whether telomere dynamics are a causal driver of aging or merely a proxy reflecting other fundamental aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Citations of accumulating data on white blood cell telomere length variability, heritability, sex differences, associations with age-related diseases, oxidative stress, inflammation, and mortality risk.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process (telomere shortening) with proposed causal links to aging and morbidity at the organism level, discusses mechanisms (oxidative stress, inflammation), and addresses general aging rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: The expression of proliferation-dependent antigens during the lifespan of normal and progeroid human fibroblasts in culture.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging at the cellular level is characterized by a decreasing fraction of cells capable of proliferation, leading to a limited lifespan of cell cultures. This decline in proliferative cells is a hallmark of cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Accelerated cellular aging in progeroid syndromes
key_concepts.description: In diseases like Werner's Syndrome, which exhibit premature aging symptoms, fibroblasts show a significantly accelerated loss of proliferative capacity compared to normal cells, suggesting that cellular senescence mechanisms contribute causally to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Indirect immunofluorescence assays measuring proliferation-dependent antigens in normal and Werner's Syndrome fibroblasts; comparison of rates of decline in proliferative cell fractions during cellular aging in culture.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (cellular senescence) explaining why aging occurs at the cellular and organismal level, generalizable beyond a single tissue, and supported by comparative data from normal and progeroid cells.

results.title: Does anti-aging equal anti-microbial?

theories.name: Insulin/IGF-1 Signaling Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: A major conserved signaling pathway that regulates aging rate and lifespan across species. Alterations in this pathway influence longevity by modulating stress resistance and metabolic processes.

key_concepts.concept: Link between longevity and innate immunity
key_concepts.description: Genetically determined longevity is associated with enhanced innate immune responses, leading to increased resistance to bacterial infections and stress, suggesting a mechanistic connection between aging and immune function.

key_concepts.concept: Common mechanism underlying aging and disease susceptibility
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that the insulin/IGF-1 pathway not only regulates aging but also affects susceptibility to a broad range of diseases by modulating immune defense, implying a shared causal mechanism for aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies in Caenorhabditis elegans showing that reduced insulin/IGF-1 signaling leads to increased lifespan and enhanced resistance to bacterial infection.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the organismal level, linking a conserved signaling pathway to systemic aging and disease risk.

results.title: Comprehensive human proteome profiles across a 50-year lifespan reveal aging trajectories and signatures.

theories.name: Proteostasis Decline Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by a decline in the maintenance of protein homeostasis, leading to the accumulation of misfolded or aggregated proteins such as amyloids, which impair cellular and tissue function.
During aging, the correlation between mRNA levels and protein abundance weakens, indicating dysregulation in protein synthesis, folding, and degradation processes that contribute to aging phenotypes.
Specific proteins, termed senoproteins (e.g., GAS6), accumulate or change in aging tissues and plasma, potentially acting as causal drivers of vascular and systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: Comprehensive proteomic and histological analysis of 516 samples from 13 human tissues across five decades; identification of amyloid accumulation; development of tissue-specific proteomic age clocks; temporal aging trajectories; plasma proteomic signatures; identification of candidate senoproteins.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism (proteostasis decline and senoproteins) underlying systemic aging, supported by multi-tissue data and temporal dynamics; connects molecular changes to organism-level aging trajectories.

results.title: Senotherapeutic approach to age-related endocrine diseases.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cells enter a state of irreversible cell-cycle arrest as organisms age, leading to the accumulation of senescent cells in tissues, including endocrine glands.
Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory and pro-fibrotic factors that contribute to tissue dysfunction and exacerbate endocrine dysregulation, driving age-related endocrine diseases.

The accumulation of senescent cells and their secretions disrupt hormone metabolism (melatonin, cortisol, insulin, growth, thyroid hormones) and circadian rhythms, linking cellular senescence to systemic aging effects.

theories.evidence: Citations and discussion of senescent cell accumulation in endocrine glands, SASP effects on metabolic syndrome, sarcopenia, osteoporosis, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hormonal dysregulation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (cellular senescence and SASP) explaining systemic aging processes and age-related endocrine diseases, addressing fundamental aging biology beyond specific diseases.

results.title: Aging-related research in the "-omics" age.
Ribosomal DNA and the nucleolus at the heart of aging.

theories.name: rDNA/Nucleolar Instability Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The nucleolus is not only responsible for ribosome biosynthesis but also acts as a dynamic nuclear compartment that senses, signals, and responds to intrinsic and environmental cellular insults, making it central to cellular homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: rDNA instability driving cellular senescence and organismal aging
key_concepts.description: Instability in ribosomal DNA and nucleolar architecture is linked causally to cellular senescence and aging across species from yeast to mammals, suggesting that maintaining rDNA integrity is critical for longevity.

The functionality of the nucleolus and the structural organization of rDNA influence processes of meiotic and transgenerational rejuvenation, indicating a mechanistic basis for how aging-related damage might be reset across generations.

theories.evidence: Emerging findings from multiple species including yeast and mammals are cited to support links between rDNA/nucleolar instability and aging; evidence includes cellular senescence markers and observations of nucleolar dynamics.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how rDNA/nucleolar instability drives aging at the organismal level, supported by evolutionary conservation; it addresses fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Along the Trajectory to Understanding Cellular Aging: More Lessons from Yeast.

theories.name: Cellular aging trajectories theory

key_concepts.description: Aging at the cellular level does not follow a single uniform pathway but progresses through multiple distinct trajectories, each characterized by unique temporal and functional dependencies among cellular subprocesses.
Cellular aging involves a stepwise decline in the ability to maintain physiological balance, with each stage representing a further loss of homeostasis that cumulatively leads to functional decline.

Studies in Saccharomyces cerevisiae have enabled detailed observation of replicative lifespan and aging trajectories, providing a framework to understand cellular aging mechanisms that may be conserved in metazoa.

theories.evidence: Citations and recent technical advances in observing replicative lifespan in yeast; comparative insights drawn to metazoan cellular aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging at the cellular level with broad implications for organismal aging; it addresses fundamental mechanisms of aging progression rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Towards prevention of aneuploidy-associated cellular senescence and aging: more questions than answers?

theories.name: Aneuploidy-induced cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Aneuploidy as a driver of cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: Aneuploidy, the presence of an abnormal number of chromosomes, accompanies the entry into cellular senescence and can itself induce senescence in cells. This suggests a causal role of chromosomal imbalance in triggering the senescence program.

key_concepts.concept: Link between aneuploidy, senescence, and aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that aneuploidy contributes to organismal aging by promoting cellular senescence, which in turn drives aging phenotypes. The convergence of aneuploidy and senescence leads to chronic inflammation, a major factor in unhealthy aging.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammation via SASP and cGAS-STING pathway
key_concepts.description: Aneuploidy can induce the Senescence Associated Secretory Phenotype (SASP), either directly or through micronuclei formation that causes DNA leakage into the cytoplasm, activating the cGAS-STING innate immune pathway. This inflammatory response is implicated as a mechanism linking aneuploidy and aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews in vitro evidence showing aneuploidy accompanies and induces senescence, discusses emerging in vivo data linking aneuploidy to senescence and aging, and cites mechanistic pathways such as SASP and cGAS-STING activation. It also highlights nutritional intervention studies aimed at preventing aneuploidy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism linking chromosomal abnormalities to cellular senescence and systemic aging, addresses organism-level aging processes, and discusses underlying mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Pathogens accelerate features of human aging: A review of molecular mechanisms.

theories.name: Pathogen-Accelerated Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Many pathogens, including viruses, bacteria, fungi, and parasites, persist long-term in host tissues and nerves, expressing proteins and metabolites that interfere with host cellular functions such as immune signaling, mitochondrial activity, gene expression, and epigenetic regulation.

Pathogens can manipulate host longevity-regulating pathways by distorting signaling mechanisms such as mTOR and AMPK, which are critical for immunometabolic regulation and cellular homeostasis, thereby accelerating aging features.

Pathogen activity contributes to the development of age-related diseases, exemplified by Alzheimer's disease where amyloid-β plaques may form as an antimicrobial response to infection, linking infection to pathological aging processes.

Interventions like low-dose rapamycin, metformin, glutathione, and NAD+ may partly exert their beneficial effects by controlling persistent infections, suggesting that targeting pathogens is integral to modulating aging and healthspan.

theories.evidence: Review of molecular mechanisms from literature including pathogen-host interactions, signaling pathway dysregulation, and links to age-related diseases; discussion of emerging diagnostic tools and therapeutic interventions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how persistent infections accelerate systemic aging processes by interfering with fundamental cellular and molecular pathways; addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases; provides mechanistic insight rather than mere correlation.

results.title: Immune surveillance of senescence: potential application to age-related diseases.

theories.name: Cellular senescence immune surveillance theory

key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate with age in tissues, contributing to chronic microinflammation and age-related pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Immune system clearance of senescent cells
key_concepts.description: The innate and adaptive immune systems, including macrophages, NK cells, and T cells, normally identify and eliminate senescent cells to maintain tissue homeostasis.
Senescent cells can evade immune clearance by expressing immune checkpoint proteins and non-classical MHC variants, similar to mechanisms used by cancer cells.
When immune surveillance is compromised, senescent cells accumulate, accelerating the aging process and promoting age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic potential of immune checkpoint blockade
key_concepts.description: Blocking immune checkpoints may restore immune surveillance of senescent cells, potentially ameliorating age-related tissue dysfunction and diseases.

theories.evidence: Citations of multiple lines of evidence linking senescent cell accumulation to inflammation and aging; analogy to cancer immune evasion; suggestion of immune checkpoint blockade as a therapeutic strategy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how impaired immune clearance of senescent cells drives systemic aging and age-related diseases. It addresses a fundamental aging process (senescence accumulation) with mechanistic insight (immune surveillance and escape).

results.title: Macroautophagy in quiescent and senescent cells: a pathway to longevity?

theories.name: Macroautophagy in cellular quiescence and senescence as a longevity mechanism

key_concepts.description: Cellular quiescence is a reversible exit from the cell cycle that is important for maintaining many cell types, including adult stem cells, which are critical for organismal health. Aging and cellular dysfunction impair the survival and reactivation of these quiescent cells over time, linking quiescence to aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Role of macroautophagy and lysosomal function
key_concepts.description: Macroautophagy and lysosomal function are essential for maintaining the function and viability of quiescent cells throughout life. These processes help clear damaged cellular components and maintain cellular homeostasis, which may influence organismal aging and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Dual role of macroautophagy in senescence
key_concepts.description: Macroautophagy can have both pro-senescence and anti-senescence effects depending on the cellular context. This dual role suggests a complex regulatory function of autophagy in aging and cellular senescence.
Stimulating macroautophagy and lysosomal function may promote quiescent cell function and tissue regeneration, representing a possible intervention strategy to delay aging or improve longevity.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing studies and findings on autophagic processes and lysosomal function in quiescent and senescent cells, highlighting both pro- and anti-senescence roles of macroautophagy. It discusses unanswered questions and potential interventions but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper addresses a general biological aging mechanism (macroautophagy) that impacts cellular quiescence and senescence, which are fundamental to organismal aging. It discusses causal mechanisms (autophagy's role in maintaining cell function and influencing senescence) and considers interventions, thus meeting the criteria for an aging theory-related paper.

results.title: From biology of ageing to geroscience: where will knowledge take us?
Lifetime chronic stress exposures, stress hormones, and biological aging: Results from the Midlife in the United States (MIDUS) study.

theories.name: Stress hormone-mediated acceleration of biological aging

key_concepts.concept: Chronic psychosocial stress as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Chronic exposure to psychosocial stress, especially during childhood, is proposed to accelerate biological aging processes, increasing risk for age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Stress hormones impacting cellular aging mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Stress hormones such as norepinephrine, epinephrine, and cortisol influence biological aging by promoting DNA damage response activation, cellular senescence, and the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), which are key hallmarks of aging.
Stress hormones mediate the relationship between early life stress exposures and later biological aging markers, suggesting a mechanistic pathway linking psychosocial stress to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Cross-sectional human data from 531 adults measuring chronic stress exposures, urinary stress hormone levels, and RNA sequencing-based aging biomarkers (DDR, p16INK4a, SASP). Statistical mediation analyses support stress hormones as mediators between childhood stress and aging markers.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking chronic psychosocial stress and stress hormones to fundamental biological aging processes at the organism level. It addresses systemic aging mechanisms (DNA damage, senescence) rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Mitochondrial-to-nuclear communication in aging: an epigenetic perspective.

theories.name: Mitochondrial-to-nuclear communication as an epigenetic regulator of aging

key_concepts.description: Mitochondria act as signaling organelles that communicate their functional state to the nucleus, triggering transcriptional programs that adapt cellular homeostasis and stress responses essential for organismal health and aging.
Altered levels of mitochondrial metabolites or stress signals influence epigenetic changes in the nucleus, which in turn regulate gene expression patterns that affect aging processes.
Certain mitochondrial metabolites serve as signals that promote longevity by modulating epigenetic states and maintaining cellular homeostasis during aging.

theories.evidence: Summarizes recent studies on mechanisms of mito-nuclear communication and epigenetic regulation in aging; references emerging research findings (no specific experiments detailed in abstract).
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how mitochondrial signaling affects aging at the organismal level via epigenetic regulation; addresses fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Aging promotes metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease by inducing ferroptotic stress.

theories.name: Ferroptosis as a conserved mechanism of aging-related tissue degeneration

key_concepts.description: Ferroptosis, a regulated form of cell death characterized by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, is proposed as a key mechanism driving tissue degeneration associated with aging. The study identifies genes controlling ferroptosis as part of an aging hepatocyte gene signature enriched in aged and diseased tissues.

The aging hepatocyte gene signature, including ferroptosis-related genes, is enriched not only in aged livers but also in failing human hearts, diseased kidneys, and pancreatic islets from diabetic individuals, suggesting ferroptosis is a conserved degenerative mechanism across multiple organs during aging.

key_concepts.concept: Causal role in metabolic dysfunction-associated liver disease
key_concepts.description: Aged mice exhibit increased hepatocyte ferroptosis and liver degeneration under metabolic stress-inducing diets compared to young mice. Pharmacological inhibition of ferroptosis reverses aging-exacerbated liver damage and shifts the liver transcriptome toward a younger state, supporting a causal role for ferroptosis in aging-related liver pathology.

theories.evidence: Transcriptomic analyses of hepatocytes from young and aged mice, cross-species transcriptomic deconvolution in human and mouse diseased tissues, functional studies in mice demonstrating increased ferroptosis and liver degeneration with age, and ferroptosis inhibition experiments reversing damage.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism (ferroptosis) underlying aging-related tissue degeneration across multiple organs, supported by mechanistic and functional evidence, thus explaining how aging promotes organ dysfunction.

results.title: Chronobiology of the neuroimmunoendocrine system and aging.

theories.name: Circadian neuroimmunoendocrine aging theory

key_concepts.description: Aging leads to a decline in the function and regulation of homeostatic systems including the nervous, endocrine, and immune systems, which are interconnected and maintain physiological balance.

key_concepts.concept: Circadian system disruption as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The circadian system, which regulates daily physiological rhythms, becomes dysregulated with age, contributing to impaired function of the neuroimmunoendocrine system and overall health decline.
Immune system parameters, especially lymphocyte function, show age-related changes that vary with circadian timing, indicating that immune aging is modulated by circadian rhythms.

key_concepts.concept: Role of immunomodulatory hormones and proinflammatory cytokines
key_concepts.description: Hormones like melatonin regulate biological rhythms and influence aging processes, while proinflammatory cytokines mediate neuroimmune interactions that become disturbed with aging.

key_concepts.concept: Seasonal and daily variation in immune aging
key_concepts.description: Immune function impairment in older adults is more pronounced at certain times of day (early afternoon) and seasons (winter), suggesting that temporal biological rhythms modulate aging effects.

theories.evidence: Citations and references to observed circadian patterns in neuroimmunoendocrine variables, age-related immune function changes, hormonal regulation (melatonin), and proinflammatory cytokine involvement; observational data on immune function variation by time of day and season in mature adults.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism linking circadian regulation and neuroimmunoendocrine system impairment to aging; provides causal explanations involving hormonal and cytokine regulation; addresses aging broadly at organismal level rather than narrow disease or organ-specific focus.

results.title: Potential Regulators of the Senescence-Associated Secretory Phenotype During Senescence and Aging.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence and Senescence-Associated Secretory Phenotype (SASP) Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Senescent cells enter a state of permanent cell cycle arrest and secrete a complex mixture of factors collectively called the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), which includes cytokines, chemokines, proteases, growth factors, and enzymes involved in extracellular matrix remodeling.

SASP has beneficial roles such as reinforcing senescence arrest, recruiting immune cells for clearance of damaged or potentially tumorigenic cells, limiting or inducing fibrosis, and promoting wound healing and tissue regeneration. Conversely, chronic SASP activity contributes to aging by mediating inflammation, tissue destruction, and promoting tumor growth and survival.

SASP production is regulated at multiple biological levels including chromatin remodeling, transcriptional control, mRNA translation, intracellular trafficking, and secretion, indicating complex control mechanisms that influence aging and senescence processes.

theories.evidence: Summary of identified SASP modulators and signaling pathways from existing literature; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general, organism-level aging mechanism (cellular senescence and its secretory phenotype) explaining how aging occurs via chronic inflammation and tissue dysfunction; proposes causal mechanisms and regulatory pathways; not limited to a single organ or disease.

results.title: Polyploidisation pleiotropically buffers ageing in hepatocytes.

theories.name: Polyploidisation buffering theory of aging in hepatocytes

key_concepts.concept: Polyploidisation as a genetic buffering mechanism
key_concepts.description: Polyploidy in hepatocytes leads to fundamentally different cell states that buffer against transcriptional dysregulation and age-related decline. This buffering occurs through pleiotropic effects, allowing cells to maintain robust gene regulatory networks despite aging.

key_concepts.concept: Non-random allelic segregation restoring wild-type genome
key_concepts.description: During aging, tetraploid hepatocytes undergo selection favoring wild-type alleles, which restores non-deleterious genetic perturbations. This suggests a mechanism where polyploidy enables genomic stability and functional preservation in aging cells.

key_concepts.concept: Polyploid cells better adapted to overcome genomic perturbations
key_concepts.description: Tetraploid hepatocytes exhibit more robust transcriptional networks and are better equipped to handle genetic perturbations, which may suppress aging-related phenotypes such as steatosis.

theories.evidence: Single-nucleus RNA sequencing of hepatocytes with different ploidy levels from young and old mice; comparison with haploinsufficient strains for liver-specific regulators (HNF4A, CEBPA, CTCF); histological evaluation of liver tissue; genomic allele composition analysis by BaseScope.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how polyploidy modulates aging at the cellular and tissue level, with implications for systemic aging processes. It addresses aging broadly by linking genetic and transcriptional buffering to age-related functional decline, not limited to a single disease or narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Pathological aging is alleviated by neutralization of the autophagy-repressive tissue hormone DBI/ACBP.

theories.name: DBI/ACBP-mediated autophagy repression theory of pathological aging

key_concepts.concept: DBI/ACBP as an autophagy-inhibitory tissue hormone
key_concepts.description: DBI/ACBP is a hormone produced by multiple cell types that inhibits macroautophagy/autophagy, a cellular recycling process important for maintaining cellular homeostasis and health.
Plasma levels of DBI/ACBP increase with chronological age and further rise in disease states, correlating with clinical markers of poor health and comorbidity, suggesting a systemic role in aging.

key_concepts.concept: DBI/ACBP as a driver of pathological aging via autophagy repression and senescence promotion
key_concepts.description: Elevated DBI/ACBP contributes causally to aging-related pathologies by repressing autophagy and promoting cellular senescence in multiple organs, thereby driving systemic aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic neutralization of DBI/ACBP ameliorates aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Neutralizing DBI/ACBP with monoclonal antibodies in various mouse models of aging and organ-specific damage reduces senescence markers, restores metabolic and protective gene expression, and improves multiple aging-related functional impairments.

theories.evidence: Correlative human data showing increased DBI/ACBP with age and disease; multiple mouse model experiments demonstrating that anti-DBI/ACBP therapy improves aging phenotypes, reduces senescence markers, and restores gene expression profiles.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory proposes a general causal mechanism for aging (autophagy repression by DBI/ACBP), supported by evidence across multiple organs and systemic aging models, explaining why aging occurs and how it can be modulated.

results.title: Yeast aging and apoptosis.

theories.name: Apoptosis as a pro-survival and anti-aging program

key_concepts.concept: Apoptosis as a balance between cell death and organismal survival
key_concepts.description: Although apoptosis leads to the death of individual cells, it serves a crucial role in maintaining the health and survival of multicellular organisms by removing damaged or dysfunctional cells, thereby contributing to healthy development and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Conservation of apoptotic machinery in yeast
key_concepts.description: Yeast possess a functional and evolutionarily conserved apoptotic system, allowing the study of apoptosis in a simpler genetic model. This conservation suggests fundamental roles of apoptosis beyond multicellularity.

key_concepts.concept: Interconnection between aging and apoptosis in yeast
