key_concepts.description: Yeast aging, both replicative and chronological, is closely linked to apoptosis, although the causal direction remains unclear. This relationship provides a model to explore whether apoptosis drives aging or is a consequence of aging processes.

theories.evidence: Experimental results from yeast genetic models demonstrating conserved apoptotic pathways and their relationship to replicative and chronological aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it proposes a general mechanism (apoptosis) that may causally influence aging at the organismal level, supported by conserved pathways and experimental data in a model organism. It addresses aging broadly through fundamental cellular processes rather than narrow disease or organ-specific phenomena.

results.title: Thymic microenvironment's impact on immunosenescence.

theories.name: Thymic microenvironment degeneration theory of immunosenescence

key_concepts.concept: Thymic involution as a driver of immunosenescence
key_concepts.description: Age-related thymic involution involves the loss of thymic epithelial network and T cell development capacity, replaced by adipose tissue, leading to decreased naïve T cell output and increased memory T cells, contributing to systemic immunosenescence.

key_concepts.concept: Degenerative changes in the thymic microenvironment as primary cause
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the primary cause of thymic dysfunction with age is degenerative changes in the thymic microenvironment rather than intrinsic defects in progenitor cells, impairing thymopoiesis and T cell development.

key_concepts.concept: Reversibility of thymic involution by restoring microenvironment
key_concepts.description: Experimental transplantation of fetal thymus tissue into aged mice restores thymic output, T cell production, cytokine expression, and normal thymic T cell development, suggesting that microenvironmental rejuvenation can reverse immunosenescence.

theories.evidence: Experimental transplantation of fetal thymus tissue into aged mice, flow cytometry analysis of T cell populations, PCR quantification of T cell receptor excision circles, gene expression analysis of cytokines and progenitor cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining why systemic immunosenescence occurs with age via thymic microenvironment degeneration; it addresses a fundamental aging process (immune aging) at the organism level and tests mechanisms causally linked to aging.

results.title: Kaempferol, a widely ingested dietary flavonoid and supplement, enhances biological performance via hormesis, especially for ageing-related processes.

theories.name: Hormesis theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Hormesis refers to a biphasic dose response where low doses of a stressor or compound induce beneficial adaptive responses that enhance biological performance, while higher doses may be harmful. This concept explains how mild stress can activate cellular defense mechanisms that improve resilience and function, potentially slowing aging processes.

Certain flavonoids, including kaempferol, quercetin, and fisetin, exhibit senolytic properties, meaning they selectively induce death of senescent cells. Removing senescent cells is proposed to alleviate age-related tissue dysfunction and systemic aging, supporting a causal role of cellular senescence in aging.

Kaempferol has been studied at molecular, cellular, and whole-animal levels, showing broad biological effects including chemoprevention and enhancement of age-related endpoints across multiple organ systems. This suggests hormesis and senolytic mechanisms may operate systemically, influencing organismal aging.

theories.evidence: The paper integrates experimental data from clinical trials, cellular and animal studies demonstrating hormetic dose responses and senolytic effects of kaempferol and related flavonoids.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The hormesis theory as discussed attempts to explain how mild stressors like kaempferol induce adaptive responses that improve biological performance and impact aging broadly. The senolytic activity connects to a causal mechanism of aging via removal of senescent cells. The scope is organism-level and mechanistic, meeting all core criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Impact of smoking and alcohol consumption on telomere length: A univariable and multivariable Mendelian randomization study.

theories.name: Telomere attrition as a causal mechanism of biological aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length as a biomarker of biological aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres are protective DNA-protein structures at chromosome ends that shorten with each cell division, and their length is associated with cellular senescence and organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Lifestyle factors causally influencing telomere shortening
key_concepts.description: Modifiable behaviors such as smoking and alcohol consumption contribute causally to accelerated telomere shortening, thereby potentially accelerating biological aging and increasing risk for age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence driven by telomere shortening
key_concepts.description: Shortened telomeres trigger cellular senescence, a state of irreversible growth arrest that contributes to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Mendelian randomization analyses using large-scale genetic data sets demonstrated significant causal associations between genetic predisposition to smoking and alcohol consumption and shorter telomere length, with multiple sensitivity analyses confirming robustness and absence of pleiotropy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (telomere shortening) underlying biological aging at the organism level, supported by genetic causal inference methods, and links modifiable lifestyle factors to fundamental aging processes.

results.title: Evidence of Embodiment-based changes in older Adult Language.
[Molecular bases of cellular senescence: Hayflick phenomenon 50 years later].

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Limited proliferative capacity of somatic cells
key_concepts.description: Normal human somatic cells can only divide a finite number of times before entering a state of senescence, which halts further proliferation.

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage as a trigger for senescence
key_concepts.description: Senescence is induced by extensive and irreparable DNA damage, which can occur in telomeric and non-telomeric regions of the genome.
The main cause of DNA damage leading to senescence is oxidative stress, which increases due to deteriorated mitochondrial function with age.

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of senescent cells drives aging and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate in tissues during aging and causatively contribute to the development of various pathologies in elderly individuals, including cancer.

theories.evidence: The paper summarizes current knowledge 50 years after Hayflick's discovery, citing the role of oxidative stress, DNA damage, cell cycle effectors, and markers of senescence, as well as links to age-related diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general, organism-level causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs (accumulation of senescent cells driven by DNA damage and oxidative stress), with broad applicability beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: YTHDF1 differentiates the contributing roles of mTORC1 in aging.

theories.name: mTORC1 regulation in aging via YTHDF1-mediated lysosomal signaling

key_concepts.concept: mTORC1 as a central aging regulator
key_concepts.description: mTOR complex 1 (mTORC1) functions as a key metabolic sensor that integrates environmental and cellular signals to regulate aging processes. Its activity influences protein and cholesterol synthesis pathways that impact organismal aging.

YTHDF1, an m6A RNA-binding protein, is anchored on the lysosome surface by LAMP2, where it recruits TSC2 to inhibit mTORC1 activity. This represents a novel regulatory mechanism linking RNA-binding proteins to mTORC1 signaling and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Differential contributions of mTORC1 downstream pathways
key_concepts.description: Loss of YTHDF1 activates the mTORC1-SREBP2 axis, promoting cholesterol biosynthesis but does not affect m6A-reader-regulated protein translation. This suggests distinct mTORC1-mediated pathways differentially influence aging.

Rapamycin treatment, which inhibits mTORC1, restores healthspan in mice, contrasting with the lifespan shortening caused by YTHDF1 depletion. This supports the causal role of mTORC1 regulation in aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from murine models showing accelerated aging upon YTHDF1 loss, molecular interaction studies demonstrating YTHDF1-TSC2-mTORC1 regulation, and rapamycin intervention restoring healthspan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains a fundamental aging mechanism via mTORC1 regulation at the organism level, proposes causal molecular pathways, and addresses broad aging processes beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Impact of Aging and Cellular Senescence in the Pathophysiology of Preeclampsia.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a causal driver
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is the process by which cells irreversibly stop dividing in response to physiological and maladaptive stimuli. This state contributes to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging by promoting inflammation and impairing regenerative capacity.

key_concepts.concept: Link between senescence and disease pathogenesis
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate with age and are implicated in the pathophysiology of age-related diseases, including cardiovascular and kidney diseases. In the context of preeclampsia, senescence may mechanistically contribute to disease onset and progression.

key_concepts.concept: Senescence as a mechanistic bridge to future disease risk
key_concepts.description: The presence of senescent cells in preeclampsia may explain the increased risk of subsequent chronic diseases, suggesting that senescence is not only a marker but a causal factor linking pregnancy complications to long-term health outcomes.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses existing evidence linking cellular senescence mechanisms to preeclampsia development and future disease risk, likely citing experimental and clinical studies (though details are limited to abstract).
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains a fundamental biological aging process (cellular senescence) with causal mechanisms, has generalizability beyond a single disease, and connects cellular-level processes to organism-level aging and disease risk.

results.title: The deficit in low molecular weight thiols as a target for antiageing therapy.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) and Oxidative Damage
key_concepts.description: ROS such as superoxide radicals are continuously generated in cells and tissues. Excessive ROS production or insufficient antioxidant defenses lead to oxidative stress, causing damage to biomolecules and contributing to aging.

Endogenous antioxidants like glutathione and dietary antioxidants (vitamins A, C, E) scavenge ROS to prevent tissue damage. A decline in antioxidant levels with age impairs this protective mechanism, exacerbating oxidative damage.

Beyond damage, oxidative stress dysregulates redox-sensitive signaling pathways, which may contribute to aging-related degenerative processes, indicating a mechanistic link between redox balance and aging.

Deficits in low molecular weight thiols, particularly glutathione and its precursor cysteine, are implicated in aging. Supplementation with cysteine shows beneficial effects on aging parameters such as skeletal muscle function, suggesting intervention potential.

theories.evidence: Citations of genetic studies in model organisms (mice, Drosophila, C. elegans) linking oxidative stress to aging; observations of decreased antioxidant levels with age; reports of cysteine supplementation improving muscle function in aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory attempts to explain aging as a fundamental process via oxidative damage and redox signaling dysregulation (generalizable), proposes causal mechanisms (ROS and antioxidant imbalance), and addresses aging broadly rather than a single organ or disease.

results.title: Aging, senescence and mitochondria: the PGC-1/ERR axis.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging via the PGC-1/ERR axis

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a central regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging results from the progressive accumulation of cellular and tissue damage, with deregulated mitochondrial function playing a pivotal role in driving this degenerative process. Mitochondrial decline leads to impaired energy metabolism and contributes to organ dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Role of the PGC-1/ERR axis in mitochondrial regulation
key_concepts.description: The PGC-1 family of transcriptional coactivators and the estrogen-related receptor (ERR) nuclear receptors act as master regulators of mitochondrial biogenesis and function. Alterations in this axis are implicated in age-associated mitochondrial deregulation and tissue dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Pharmacological targeting of the PGC-1/ERR axis
key_concepts.description: Modulating the PGC-1/ERR axis offers potential therapeutic avenues to alleviate or delay the onset of aging and its adverse effects by restoring mitochondrial function.

theories.evidence: Summary of key discoveries from multiple studies over the last decade implicating the PGC-1/ERR axis in mitochondrial deregulation during aging; pharmacological implications are highlighted but no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (mitochondrial dysfunction regulated by PGC-1/ERR) underlying organism-level aging processes, discusses mechanisms rather than mere correlations, and addresses aging broadly rather than a specific disease or organ alone.

results.title: Endothelial Cell Senescence Effect on the Blood-Brain Barrier in Stroke and Cognitive Impairment.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: With advancing age and exposure to cellular stressors such as hypertension and diabetes, endothelial cells accumulate senescent characteristics. These senescent cells exhibit altered functions that contribute to aging-related vascular dysfunction.

Senescent endothelial cells in the blood-brain barrier show altered tight junction proteins, increased permeability, and disrupted extracellular matrix, leading to a compromised barrier that affects brain homeostasis and contributes to stroke and cognitive impairment.

key_concepts.concept: Contribution to Vascular and Cognitive Decline
key_concepts.description: Senescent endothelial cells impair angiogenesis and vascular remodeling, promote microvascular dysfunction, and disrupt cerebral perfusion and autoregulation, thereby increasing risks of hemorrhagic transformation in stroke and vascular cognitive impairment.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing existing evidence on senescent endothelial cells’ altered properties, their impact on blood-brain barrier integrity, and their role in stroke and cognitive impairment. It also references ongoing clinical trials testing senolytics targeting senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a general causal mechanism (cellular senescence) explaining aging-related vascular and cognitive decline at the organism level, discusses underlying causes and mechanisms, and connects cellular senescence to systemic aging effects.

results.title: The protein paradox, carnivore diet & hypertrophy versus longevity. Short term nutrition and hypertrophy versus longevity.
Crosstalk between the DNA damage response and cellular senescence drives aging and age-related diseases.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as irreversible cell-cycle arrest
key_concepts.description: Cells enter a state where they permanently stop dividing in response to stressors, remaining metabolically active but unable to proliferate, which accumulates with age.
Over time, DNA damage builds up and activates the DNA damage response pathway, which induces cellular senescence, linking molecular damage to cellular aging.

key_concepts.concept: Senescence drives inflammation and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory factors that contribute to chronic inflammation, promoting the development of multiple age-related pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: DNA repair defects and senescence cause premature aging
key_concepts.description: Mutations or deficiencies in DNA repair genes or senescence pathways lead to accelerated aging phenotypes, supporting a causal role in organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of DNA damage and senescence extends longevity
key_concepts.description: Interventions that reduce DNA damage or clear senescent cells can rescue aging phenotypes and provide neuroprotection, indicating mechanistic causality.

theories.evidence: Citations of accumulating evidence linking DNA damage to senescence, references to premature aging diseases caused by DNA repair defects, and therapeutic studies showing rescued longevity and neuroprotection.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process at organism level, proposes causal mechanisms (DNA damage inducing senescence), addresses broad aging and age-related diseases, and discusses evolutionary and mechanistic logic.

results.title: A common signature of cellular senescence; does it exist?

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is characterized by an irreversible arrest of the cell cycle, typically in G0, G1, or G2 phases, preventing further cell division. This arrest is a fundamental feature that distinguishes senescent cells from proliferating cells.

Senescent cells secrete a variety of pro-inflammatory cytokines, growth factors, and proteases collectively known as SASP, which contribute to aging and aging-related diseases by affecting tissue microenvironments and systemic inflammation.

DNA damage, alterations in nuclear architecture, and chromatin remodeling are key signaling events that induce and maintain the senescent state, leading to changes in gene expression and SASP production.

key_concepts.concept: Gero Stage (GS) and permanent proliferation arrest
key_concepts.description: Beyond temporary cell cycle arrest, cells may exit the cycle into a state termed GS, ensuring irreversible cessation of proliferation. This may involve processes like polyploidization or depolyploidization, consolidating the senescent phenotype.

theories.evidence: The abstract references accumulated knowledge about senescent cells in various cell types, their secretory phenotype, DNA damage signaling, and cell cycle dynamics. It synthesizes these findings to propose a common signature of cellular senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory explains a fundamental biological aging process at the organismal level by proposing mechanisms (cell cycle arrest, SASP, DNA damage) that causally contribute to aging and age-related diseases. It is generalizable across cell types and links cellular changes to systemic aging effects.

results.title: Selective manipulation of aging: a novel strategy for the treatment of neurodegenerative disorders.

theories.name: Insulin/Insulin-like Growth Factor Signalling (IIS) Aging Regulatory Pathway Theory

key_concepts.concept: IIS pathway as a regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: The insulin/insulin-like growth factor signalling pathway is a conserved biological pathway that regulates lifespan and aging processes across species. Reduced activity of this pathway has been shown to extend lifespan and improve stress resistance in model organisms.

key_concepts.concept: Link between IIS and toxic protein aggregation
key_concepts.description: Reduced IIS activity protects against toxic protein aggregation, which is a hallmark of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's, Huntington's, and Parkinson's diseases. This suggests that IIS modulates mechanisms that influence proteostasis and cellular health during aging.

Pharmacological or genetic reduction of IIS activity in mammalian models partially protects against neurodegenerative disease phenotypes, including premature death and behavioral impairments, indicating that targeting IIS could be a strategy to slow aging and delay onset of age-related neurodegenerative disorders.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies in worms and flies showing protection from toxic protein aggregation by reducing IIS; mammalian studies demonstrating partial protection in Alzheimer's-model mice upon IIS reduction.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging (IIS pathway activity modulates aging and proteostasis), addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases, and provides mechanistic explanations linking aging to neurodegeneration.

results.title: Simultaneous overexpression of copper- and zinc-containing superoxide dismutase and catalase retards age-related oxidative damage and increases metabolic potential in Drosophila melanogaster.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by the progressive accumulation of molecular damage caused by reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as superoxide and hydrogen peroxide, leading to cellular and tissue dysfunction.
Enzymes like copper- and zinc-containing superoxide dismutase (Cu,Zn-SOD) and catalase mitigate oxidative damage by detoxifying ROS, thereby slowing the aging process.
Higher metabolic potential, reflected by increased oxygen consumption and mitochondrial function, is associated with delayed aging and extended lifespan, possibly due to reduced oxidative damage.

theories.evidence: Experimental overexpression of Cu,Zn-SOD and catalase in Drosophila melanogaster reduced age-related oxidative DNA damage (8-hydroxydeoxyguanosine), slowed decline in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase activity, decreased mitochondrial H2O2 generation, and increased metabolic potential and lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a general causal mechanism for aging (oxidative damage accumulation), is broadly applicable beyond a single organ or disease, and provides mechanistic explanation for aging at the organismal level.

results.title: Impact of ageing and disuse on neuromuscular junction and mitochondrial function and morphology: Current evidence and controversies.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that progressive deterioration of mitochondrial function contributes causally to aging processes, particularly through impaired energy production and increased cellular damage, which affect multiple tissues including skeletal muscle and motor neurons.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial defects leading to neuromuscular junction (NMJ) instability
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction in motor axon terminals and muscle fibers is proposed to cause instability and deterioration of the NMJ, which in turn contributes to loss of motor units and muscle atrophy observed in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Bidirectional relationship between mitochondrial dysfunction and NMJ deterioration
key_concepts.description: Two perspectives are discussed: one where mitochondrial dysfunction in skeletal muscle triggers NMJ instability, and another where mitochondrial defects in motor neuron terminals primarily cause NMJ deterioration, highlighting a complex interplay influencing neuromuscular aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews current evidence from human and animal studies showing mitochondrial defects in motor neurons and muscle fibers linked to NMJ instability and motor unit loss; it discusses studies supporting both perspectives on the causal role of mitochondrial dysfunction in NMJ deterioration.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process (neuromuscular aging) via mitochondrial dysfunction, proposes causal mechanisms, and addresses systemic aging effects beyond a single organ. Thus, it meets all core criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Heat shock proteins function as signaling molecules to mediate neuron-glia communication in C. elegans during aging.

theories.name: Neuron-glia communication-mediated modulation of brain aging

key_concepts.description: Neurons transmit proteins, specifically heat shock proteins, to glial cells through extracellular vesicles, representing a novel mode of intercellular communication beyond classical ligand-receptor interactions.
The neuronal heat shock proteins activate the unfolded protein response pathway in glia, specifically the IRE1-XBP1 signaling axis, which modulates glial function and gene expression.

Activation of the IRE1-XBP1 pathway leads to changes in the transcription of chondroitin synthases, enzymes involved in extracellular matrix remodeling, which contributes to protecting neurons embedded in glia from aging-related functional decline.

key_concepts.concept: Differential aging rates of sensory neurons governed by neuron-glia cross-talk
key_concepts.description: Different sensory neurons in C. elegans age at different rates, and this heterogeneity is regulated by the communication between neurons and glia, suggesting a systemic mechanism influencing neuronal aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from C. elegans showing protein transfer via extracellular vesicles, activation of glial signaling pathways, transcriptional changes in chondroitin synthases, and functional protection against aging-related decline.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper proposes a mechanism explaining how neuron-glia communication influences aging at the nervous system level, addressing a fundamental aging process with causal pathways (protein transfer and signaling activation). It is generalizable to organismal brain aging rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific phenomenon. Thus, it meets the criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Poly(ADP-Ribose) Polymerases in Aging - Friend or Foe?

theories.name: PARP-mediated aging theory

key_concepts.description: Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerases (PARPs), especially PARP-1, PARP-2, and PARP-3, are activated by DNA damage and facilitate DNA repair, which is essential for maintaining genomic integrity and is considered a prerequisite for successful aging.

While PARP activation supports DNA repair, it simultaneously limits metabolic fitness, increasing susceptibility to metabolic diseases, suggesting a trade-off between genome maintenance and metabolic health during aging.

key_concepts.concept: PARP involvement in multiple aging pathways
key_concepts.description: PARPs mediate several other aging-related pathways including proteostasis, nutrient sensing, stem cell proliferation, and cellular communication, indicating a broad role in regulating aging processes beyond DNA repair.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing current knowledge on PARPs in aging, citing various studies linking PARP activity to DNA repair, metabolic fitness, and other aging-related pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain aging as a fundamental process through PARP-mediated mechanisms affecting genome integrity and metabolic regulation, addressing multiple aging pathways, thus meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: Nuns and monkeys: investigating the behavior of our oldest old.
Cancer and aging: yin, yang, and p53.

theories.name: p53-mediated aging theory

key_concepts.concept: Role of p53 in tumor suppression and aging
key_concepts.description: p53 is a tumor suppressor protein that regulates cell cycle and apoptosis. Hyperactivation of p53 can lead to enhanced tumor suppression but may also induce premature aging phenotypes, suggesting a trade-off between cancer prevention and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Premature aging induced by hyperactive p53 allele
key_concepts.description: A hyperactive allele of p53 in mice causes some premature aging phenotypes, indicating that p53 activity influences aging processes beyond cancer control.

key_concepts.concept: Mechanistic link between cancer suppression and aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that mechanisms evolved to suppress cancer, such as p53 activation, may causally contribute to aging by promoting cellular senescence or apoptosis, thus reducing tissue regenerative capacity.

theories.evidence: Discussion based on a recent Nature paper showing hyperactive p53 allele causing premature aging in mice, along with previous findings on aging mechanisms related to p53.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (p53 activity) explaining how aging occurs at an organismal level, linking cancer suppression and aging as fundamental biological processes.

results.title: [Senescence of the pulmonary endothelial cells: VEGF, a new target in pulmonary pathologies and aging].

theories.name: VEGF signaling deficiency theory of endothelial cell senescence and vascular aging

key_concepts.description: A reduction in vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) signaling in endothelial cells is proposed as a key mechanism driving cellular senescence. This deficiency is linked to an increase in a soluble receptor form (sVEGFR1) that sequesters VEGF, preventing it from activating its functional receptor VEGFR2.

key_concepts.concept: Endothelial cell senescence as a driver of vascular aging
key_concepts.description: Without adequate VEGF survival signals, endothelial cells undergo senescence, which contributes to the depletion of microvessels and thus vascular aging at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Connection to pulmonary aging and pathologies
key_concepts.description: The theory extends to explain how VEGF signaling deficiency and resultant endothelial senescence contribute to lung aging and pulmonary diseases such as pulmonary hypertension and emphysema, linking vascular aging to systemic organismal aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references a proposed mechanism involving VEGF signaling and sVEGFR1 levels affecting endothelial cell senescence, with implications for pulmonary pathologies; however, specific experimental data or citations are not detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how vascular aging occurs via endothelial cell senescence driven by VEGF signaling deficiency, linking cellular mechanisms to organismal aging and disease.

results.title: Foreseeable pharmaceutical repair of age-related extracellular damage.

theories.name: Damage Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Metabolic processes inherently produce molecular and cellular alterations that accumulate over time. These alterations are initially harmless but can become pathogenic when they reach a critical abundance.
Aging is conceptualized as a two-step process: first, metabolism causes accumulating damage; second, once damage surpasses a threshold, it leads to tissue and organismal pathology.

Damage is categorized into intracellular and extracellular types. Intracellular damage is complex and requires advanced genetic and cellular therapies, while extracellular damage is more accessible to pharmaceutical repair.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic repair to maintain sub-pathogenic damage levels
key_concepts.description: Periodic repair of accumulated damage, especially extracellular damage, can prevent age-related pathology by keeping damage below pathogenic levels, offering a promising intervention strategy.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews major types of extracellular damage and promising pharmaceutical repair avenues; it discusses the conceptual framework of damage accumulation as a cause of aging but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging as damage accumulation caused by metabolism, applicable at the organism level; it addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Effect of Caloric Restriction on Aging: Fixing the Problems of Nutrient Sensing in Postmitotic Cells?

theories.name: Metabolic Dysfunction and Nutrient Sensing Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic disorders as drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that metabolic dysfunctions, particularly insulin resistance, contribute causally to the development of age-related diseases and normal aging processes. Disruption in glucose metabolism leads to systemic pathologies such as obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases, which are linked to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of postmitotic cells in aging
key_concepts.description: Highly differentiated, long-lived postmitotic cells (e.g., neurons, cardiomyocytes, skeletal muscle cells) have lifespans comparable to the organism and require proper metabolic homeostasis and nutrient sensing to maintain function. Dysfunction in these cells due to impaired nutrient sensing accelerates aging.

Nutrient sensors such as AMPK regulate cellular energy metabolism and cytoplasmic clean-up systems. Age-related impairment of these sensors leads to metabolic dysregulation in postmitotic cells, contributing to organismal aging.

Caloric restriction helps prevent metabolic disorders by improving nutrient sensing and metabolic homeostasis, thereby potentially slowing aging and extending lifespan, as demonstrated in laboratory animals.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing literature on metabolic disorders, insulin resistance, and caloric restriction effects on lifespan in laboratory animals; discusses evidence of insulin resistance in various postmitotic cells; and cites the role of nutrient sensors like AMPK.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (metabolic dysfunction and nutrient sensing impairment) underlying aging at the organism level, discusses evolutionary and physiological logic, and connects cellular dysfunction to systemic aging.

results.title: Spt4 promotes cellular senescence by activating non-coding RNA transcription in ribosomal RNA gene clusters.

theories.name: rDNA instability-driven cellular senescence theory

key_concepts.concept: rDNA instability as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The ribosomal RNA gene cluster is a highly unstable genomic region whose stability influences replicative lifespan, particularly in budding yeast. Instability in this region contributes to cellular aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Non-coding RNA transcription at rDNA E-pro promoter
key_concepts.description: Transcription of non-coding RNAs from the E-pro promoter within the rDNA cluster promotes instability, which in turn accelerates cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Role of Spt4 in promoting aging
key_concepts.description: Spt4, a transcription elongation factor, increases with age and facilitates non-coding RNA transcription at the E-pro locus, thereby promoting rDNA instability and restricting lifespan in a SIR2-dependent manner.
The lifespan extension observed upon Spt4 deletion requires SIR2, indicating that Spt4 acts through pathways involving this longevity-associated gene.

theories.evidence: Genetic experiments in budding yeast showing that deletion of Spt4 increases rDNA stability, reduces non-coding RNA transcription, and extends replicative lifespan; dependency on SIR2; observation that Spt4 levels increase with age.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how genomic instability at rDNA driven by non-coding RNA transcription promotes cellular senescence, which is a fundamental aging process at the organismal cell level. The mechanism is not limited to a single disease or organ and involves causal explanation rather than mere correlation.

results.title: Microglial STING is a central safeguard against neurological decline with age.

theories.name: STING-mediated neuroprotection theory in aging CNS

key_concepts.description: The STING (stimulator of interferon genes) pathway in microglia acts as a protective mechanism that preserves central nervous system function during physiological aging by preventing blood-brain barrier breakdown and neurological decline.

STING deficiency leads to increased neuronal DNA damage, altered proinflammatory and type I interferon responses, and enhanced cellular senescence signatures, which collectively contribute to CNS aging and neurodegeneration.
Loss of STING causes changes in microglial phenotypes and transcriptomes, indicating that STING signaling modulates microglial function and inflammatory status during aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from physiologically aged mice showing that STING deficiency exacerbates neurological decline, BBB breakdown, microhemorrhages, neuromotor deficits, and molecular signatures of DNA damage and inflammation; rescue experiments demonstrating microglial-STING expression protects against age-associated CNS changes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging-related CNS decline occurs via STING pathway dysfunction, linking molecular, cellular, and organismal aging processes; it addresses aging broadly at the organismal CNS level rather than a narrow disease context.

results.title: Current senolytics: Mode of action, efficacy and limitations, and their future.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: A cellular state characterized by near-permanent cell cycle arrest and a distinct secretory phenotype. Senescent cells accumulate progressively with age and contribute to aging-related functional decline.

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cell accumulation as causal driver
key_concepts.description: The buildup of senescent cells in tissues disrupts normal biological functions at cellular and higher organizational levels, provoking deleterious effects that contribute to organismal aging.

Pharmacological agents that selectively eliminate senescent cells in vivo, which can ameliorate diseases and dysfunctions associated with elevated senescent cell burden, thus testing the causal role of senescence in aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies showing senescent cell accumulation with aging, beneficial effects of senolytics in disease models, classification of senolytic agents and their mechanisms of action.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a general causal mechanism of aging (senescent cell accumulation), proposes underlying biological processes, and discusses interventions that test the theory's predictions.

results.title: Lipofuscin and aging: a matter of toxic waste.

theories.name: Lipofuscin accumulation and cellular aging theory

key_concepts.description: Lipofuscin is a membrane-bound cellular waste product that cannot be degraded or ejected from cells, accumulating especially in postmitotic cells such as neurons. It is considered an 'aging pigment' and a biomarker of cellular and organismal aging.
The major source of lipofuscin is incomplete lysosomal degradation of damaged mitochondria, leading to its accumulation within cells over time.

Lipofuscin accumulation impairs cellular systems including the ubiquitin/proteasome pathway, causing lysosomal and proteasomal inhibition. This creates a damaging feedback loop termed a 'garbage catastrophe' that exacerbates cellular dysfunction and contributes to aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references accumulating evidence and prevailing thought about lipofuscin’s origin and effects, including its regional brain distribution and impact on proteasomal pathways, but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: This theory attempts to explain a fundamental cellular mechanism contributing to aging at the organismal level by proposing a causal feedback loop involving waste accumulation and impaired degradation systems. It is generalizable beyond a single organ, proposes causal mechanisms, and addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow disease or tissue.

results.title: Caloric restriction: conservation of cellular replicative capacity in vitro accompanies life-span extension in mice.

theories.name: Caloric Restriction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Reducing caloric intake to about 60% of ad libitum feeding significantly extends both mean and maximum lifespan in mice by 30-40%, suggesting a fundamental influence of nutrient intake on aging.

Caloric restriction delays or decreases the age-related loss of proliferative potential in multiple cell types across various tissues, indicating that CR conserves the ability of cells to replicate, which is linked to slowed aging.

The delay in loss of proliferative potential due to CR varies by tissue type and strain, with some tissues showing prolonged maintenance of replicative capacity, highlighting complexity in how CR influences systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data comparing proliferative potential of cells from multiple tissues and strains of mice under caloric restriction versus ad libitum feeding, showing delayed loss of replicative capacity and extended lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (caloric intake modulates aging by preserving cellular replicative potential), addresses aging broadly across tissues and strains, and provides mechanistic insight into how aging is slowed.

results.title: Immunopharmacology of senescence: targeting the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP)-a mechanism-based review.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cells permanently stop dividing in response to stress, which serves as a protective mechanism against cancer and aids tissue repair.
Senescent cells secrete inflammatory factors that can cause chronic inflammation, disrupt immune function, and contribute to systemic aging and age-related diseases when these cells persist.

key_concepts.concept: Immune system interaction with senescent cells
key_concepts.description: The immune system's ability to clear or fail to clear senescent cells influences whether these cells cause harm or remain beneficial, highlighting the immune system's role in modulating aging processes.

theories.evidence: Summary of latest research findings on immune engagement with senescent cells, pharmacological targeting of SASP, and therapies aimed at removing or modulating senescent cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental, organism-level aging mechanism (cellular senescence and SASP), proposes causal mechanisms (inflammatory secretions causing aging phenotypes), and addresses systemic aging rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Translational potential of GADD45α: biomarker and therapeutic target in age-associated neurodegeneration and longevity.

theories.name: GADD45α-mediated genome maintenance and epigenetic regulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: GADD45α coordinates DNA repair pathways such as nucleotide and base excision repair to preserve genomic integrity, which declines with age and contributes to aging and age-related diseases.
GADD45α enforces G2/M cell cycle checkpoints to prevent the propagation of damaged DNA, thereby reducing the accumulation of mutations that drive aging.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial quality control and oxidative stress defense
key_concepts.description: GADD45α promotes mitochondrial resilience under oxidative stress, helping maintain cellular homeostasis and reducing damage accumulation associated with aging.
GADD45α modulates epigenetic mechanisms, mitigating age-associated DNA methylation drift and sustaining chromatin plasticity, which are key factors in cellular aging.
GADD45α exhibits neuroprotective actions in models of Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases, linking its function to systemic aging and longevity.

theories.evidence: Multi-omics analyses, in vivo rodent studies, Drosophila lifespan assays, and literature synthesis on GADD45α functions in DNA repair, epigenetics, mitochondrial function, and neurodegeneration.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining aging processes at the organismal level through genome maintenance, epigenetic regulation, and cellular homeostasis; integrates multiple aging hallmarks; and connects molecular functions to systemic aging and longevity.

results.title: Immune gene regulation is associated with age and environmental adversity in a nonhuman primate.
Nuclear hormone receptors, metabolism, and aging: what goes around comes around. Transcription factors link lipid metabolism and aging-related processes.

theories.name: Nuclear Hormone Receptors (NHRs) as Integrators of Metabolism and Aging

key_concepts.description: Nuclear hormone receptors are transcription factors that regulate lipid metabolism and other metabolic pathways. They coordinate essential metabolic processes that are fundamental to organismal function and energy homeostasis.

NHRs influence aging by modulating processes such as maturation, fecundity, and circadian rhythms, which are tightly linked to the aging process. This suggests that NHRs may serve as molecular links connecting metabolism and systemic aging.

NHRs also regulate periodic processes like circadian rhythms, which have been recently implicated in aging. This highlights a broader role for NHRs in coordinating time-dependent biological functions that impact aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews mounting evidence from previous studies linking NHR-regulated processes to aging, including metabolism, maturation, fecundity, and circadian rhythm control. Specific experimental data are not detailed in the abstract but are implied to be cited in the full review.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain aging as a fundamental process by proposing that NHRs coordinate multiple essential biological processes that influence aging at the organismal level. It provides a causal framework linking metabolism and aging through transcriptional regulation, thus meeting the criteria of generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope.

results.title: Mitophagy in relation to chronic inflammation/ROS in aging.

theories.name: Mitophagy-related mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: During aging, mitochondria accumulate damage from various assaults, leading to impaired function. This dysfunction contributes to systemic aging and age-related diseases by promoting cellular stress.

key_concepts.concept: Mitophagy as a quality control mechanism
key_concepts.description: Mitophagy is a selective autophagy process that removes damaged or dysfunctional mitochondria to maintain cellular homeostasis. Efficient mitophagy prevents accumulation of defective mitochondria that would otherwise exacerbate aging.

key_concepts.concept: Link between mitochondrial dysfunction, inflammation, and oxidative stress
key_concepts.description: Accumulation of defective mitochondria triggers inflammatory responses and oxidative stress, which accelerate aging processes. Mitophagy modulates this relationship by controlling mitochondrial quality.

theories.mode: review, discuss, propose future research directions
theories.evidence: Citations and synthesis of existing research highlighting mitophagy's role in aging and age-related diseases; no new experimental data presented in abstract
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (mitochondrial dysfunction and mitophagy) underlying aging at the organismal level, linking cellular quality control to systemic aging processes.

results.title: The role of cellular senescence in tissue repair and regeneration.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Senescent cells progressively accumulate in tissues as organisms age, leading to a decline in tissue function and contributing to age-related diseases.

While senescent cells contribute negatively to aging by impairing tissue function, they also play beneficial roles during embryogenesis and tissue repair by acting as morphogenetic forces that promote development and regeneration.

The presence and activity of senescent cells influence the regenerative capacity of tissues, which varies across species and declines with age, linking senescence to the organism's overall aging process.

theories.evidence: Citations and comparative analyses of organismal models ranging from fish and amphibians with high regenerative capacity to mammals with limited regeneration; references to recent studies showing positive roles of senescence in development and repair.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (cellular senescence) explaining why aging occurs at the organismal level, discusses underlying causes and evolutionary aspects, and connects cellular senescence to systemic aging and regeneration.

results.title: Chronological versus immunological aging: Immune rejuvenation to arrest cognitive decline.

theories.name: Immunological aging as a driver of brain aging

key_concepts.concept: Immune system's role in brain maintenance
key_concepts.description: The immune system significantly supports higher brain functions and is pivotal for lifelong brain maintenance, suggesting that brain health is closely linked to immune system status.

key_concepts.concept: Impact of immune aging on brain aging
key_concepts.description: Aging of the immune system negatively affects brain function, implying that immunosenescence contributes causally to cognitive decline and brain aging.
Rejuvenating the immune system could revitalize brain function and potentially arrest cognitive decline, proposing immune system-targeted interventions as a strategy against brain aging.

theories.evidence: The article is a perspective piece discussing emerging understanding and proposing conceptual links; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking immune system aging to brain aging, addressing systemic aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Reproductive aging and telomeres: Are women and men equally affected?

theories.name: Reproductive aging as a driver of organismal aging

key_concepts.concept: Reproductive organ aging initiates systemic aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging of reproductive organs, marked by decreased sexual hormone levels, acts as a starting point for organismal decay and infertility. These hormones have protective effects on multiple organs, so their decline triggers broader aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Sexual hormone decline as a causal mechanism
key_concepts.description: Sexual hormones produced by reproductive organs protect health by acting on various body systems. Their reduction with reproductive aging leads to systemic physiological deterioration, linking reproductive aging causally to overall aging.

key_concepts.concept: Sex differences in reproductive aging pace and impact
key_concepts.description: The theory acknowledges that reproductive aging occurs differently in women and men, with women showing more overt signs and men experiencing subtler but still consequential declines, affecting fertility and systemic aging differently by sex.

The theory emphasizes the importance of identifying molecular mechanisms driving reproductive aging, which may reveal targets to halt or reverse aging processes, thus connecting molecular biology to organism-level aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract indicates a review of current knowledge and molecular pathways involved in reproductive aging, but does not specify new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (organismal aging) starting from reproductive aging, proposes causal mechanisms (hormonal decline), and addresses general aging beyond a single organ by linking reproductive aging to systemic effects.

results.title: Physiological complexity, aging, and the path to frailty.

theories.name: Loss of Physiological Complexity Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Healthy physiological function depends on complex interactions among multiple control systems operating over various time scales, producing outputs with fractal-like variability. This complexity allows organisms to adapt rapidly to internal and external stresses.

key_concepts.concept: Loss of Complexity with Aging and Disease
key_concepts.description: Aging and disease are associated with a reduction in the complexity of physiological dynamics, which impairs the organism's ability to respond adaptively to perturbations.
The diminished physiological complexity contributes to the development of frailty, a syndrome characterized by decreased resilience and increased vulnerability to stressors.

theories.evidence: The abstract references the quantification of physiological variability using fractal analysis and correlates loss of complexity with aging, disease, and frailty, implying citation of empirical studies though no specific experiments are detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging at the organism level, linking systemic physiological dynamics to aging and frailty, rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

results.title: Nucleotide excision repair deficiencies and the somatotropic axis in aging.

theories.name: Genome instability theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The accumulation of DNA damage and mutations over time leads to a decline in genomic integrity, which contributes causally to the aging process and shortens lifespan.

Failures in DNA repair mechanisms, such as nucleotide excision repair, accelerate aging and promote age-related pathologies including cancer, indicating a mechanistic link between DNA repair capacity and organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Progeroid syndromes as models of accelerated aging
key_concepts.description: Genetic disorders characterized by defects in nucleotide excision repair pathways cause premature aging phenotypes, supporting the causal role of DNA damage accumulation in systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of progeroid syndromes and mouse models with nucleotide excision repair defects that exhibit rapid aging and premature death; references to increasing body of evidence linking genome instability to aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (genome instability) underlying aging at the organismal level, supported by genetic models and disease phenotypes, thus explaining why aging occurs.

results.title: Role of low-dose radiation in senescence and aging: A beneficial perspective.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is the permanent arrest of the cell cycle triggered by various stressors such as DNA damage, oxidative stress, and oncogene activation. The accumulation of senescent cells contributes causally to age-related tissue dysfunction, organ disorders, and chronic diseases.
Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory cytokines and other factors (SASP) that affect the tissue microenvironment, promoting chronic inflammation and further aging-related damage.

key_concepts.concept: Removal or inhibition of senescent cells to delay aging
key_concepts.description: Interventions that inhibit cellular senescence or promote the clearance of senescent cells can potentially prevent or delay aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews experimental evidence from various aging models and diseases (cardiovascular, neurological, arthritis, osteoporosis, pulmonary diseases) showing the role of senescent cells in aging and how low-dose radiation (LDR) may modulate these effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it addresses a general causal mechanism of aging at the organismal level (accumulation of senescent cells), proposes causal explanations (cell cycle arrest, SASP), and discusses broad aging-related outcomes beyond specific diseases.

theories.name: Hormesis Theory of Aging via Low-Dose Radiation

key_concepts.concept: Low-dose radiation (LDR) induces beneficial biological effects
key_concepts.description: Unlike high-dose radiation, LDR can stimulate protective responses such as enhanced DNA repair, antioxidative effects, and immune modulation, which may promote longevity and delay aging.

key_concepts.concept: LDR modulates aging by preventing cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: LDR may inhibit the onset of cellular senescence or promote the removal of senescent cells, thereby mitigating age-related tissue dysfunction and chronic diseases.

key_concepts.concept: LDR as a potential anti-aging intervention
key_concepts.description: Experimental data suggest LDR can improve growth, development, and delay progression of age-related diseases, indicating a hormetic effect that could be harnessed to influence aging processes.

theories.evidence: The paper cites experimental studies showing LDR effects on immune response, hematopoiesis, antioxidative capacity, DNA damage repair, and disease models relevant to aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism explaining how a low-level stressor (LDR) can causally modulate aging processes systemically, not limited to one organ or disease.

results.title: Healthy Diets and Lifestyles in the World: Mediterranean and Blue Zone People Live Longer. Special Focus on Gut Microbiota and Some Food Components.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging is driven by a persistent, low-level inflammatory state termed 'inflammaging,' which contributes to the decline in physiological function and the development of age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Role of NF-kB pathway in inflammaging
key_concepts.description: Activation of the NF-kB signaling pathway leads to increased production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, which exacerbate inflammaging and promote aging-related tissue damage.
Induction of regulatory T cells and production of anti-inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-10 can counteract inflammaging, thereby potentially slowing aging processes and promoting longevity.

theories.evidence: Citations of dietary components (fibers, polyphenols, beta-glucans, unsaturated fatty acids) that inhibit NF-kB and promote anti-inflammatory cytokines; association of Mediterranean and Blue Zone diets with reduced inflammaging and increased longevity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (inflammation) underlying aging at the organism level, supported by molecular pathways and linked to lifestyle factors influencing systemic aging.

results.title: We Are What We Eat: Ubiquitin-Proteasome System (UPS) Modulation Through Dietary Products.

theories.name: Ubiquitin-Proteasome System (UPS) Modulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging involves a decline in the efficiency of cellular defense mechanisms, including the proteostasis network responsible for maintaining protein homeostasis through proper folding, trafficking, and degradation.

With aging, there is an accumulation of oxidized and misfolded proteins due to increased oxidative stress and reduced proteolytic capacity, contributing to cellular dysfunction and age-related diseases.
The ubiquitin-proteasome system is the primary cellular mechanism for targeted protein degradation, playing a crucial role in removing damaged proteins and maintaining proteostasis.
Natural dietary compounds can activate or enhance UPS function, potentially improving proteostasis, delaying aging processes, and reducing the onset or progression of age-related disorders.

theories.evidence: Summary of natural compounds and extracts from edible products shown to have antiaging and anti-aggregation properties linked to UPS modulation; references to research identifying UPS activators.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (UPS decline and modulation) explaining aging at the organism level through proteostasis failure and oxidative damage accumulation; links dietary modulation as an intervention affecting this fundamental aging process.

results.title: Defining and characterizing neuronal senescence, 'neurescence', as G<sub>X</sub> arrested cells.

theories.name: Neuronal senescence ('neurescence') as G_X arrested cells

key_concepts.description: The theory extends the concept of cellular senescence, traditionally observed in mitotic cells, to postmitotic neurons, proposing that neurons can enter a senescent-like state despite their quiescent nature.

A novel cell state termed G_X is introduced to describe neuronal cell cycle arrest that occurs after passing through the G_0 quiescent phase, distinguishing it from classical G_0 quiescence and replicative senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Neurescence as a protective yet senescence-prone state
key_concepts.description: Exit from G_0 quiescence may protect neurons from apoptosis but predispose them to enter the neurescent state, characterized by stable cell cycle arrest and resistance to apoptosis, analogous to senescence in dividing cells.

theories.evidence: Summary of recent in vivo studies and human tissue data indicating senescence markers in neurons; conceptual framework distinguishing G_X from G_0 and classical senescence; criteria proposed for identifying neurescent cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining how postmitotic neurons undergo a senescence-like state, offering a causal explanation for neuronal aging at the cellular level with implications for organismal aging.

results.title: Does the liver facilitate aging-related cognitive impairment: Conversation between liver and brain during exercise?
Dissecting metabolic regulation of behaviors and physiology during aging in Drosophila.

theories.name: Metabolic regulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic imbalance as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that disruptions in conserved metabolic pathways, including one-carbon metabolism and mitochondrial function, contribute causally to physiological and behavioral decline during aging. Metabolic imbalance affects systemic homeostasis and aging phenotypes.

Metabolic genes influence aging phenotypes both within specific tissues (cell-autonomous) and through inter-tissue communication (non-cell-autonomous), such as neuro-muscle signaling, impacting systemic aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: AMPK signaling as a central regulator
key_concepts.description: AMPKα kinase activity modulates age- and tissue-specific behavioral and metabolic functions, linking neuronal energy sensing, motor function, and lipid homeostasis, thus playing a key mechanistic role in aging regulation.

theories.evidence: Genetic manipulations (knockdown and overexpression) of metabolic and mitochondrial genes in Drosophila models; behavioral assays (sleep-circadian rhythms, locomotion); lipid droplet analysis; tissue-specific driver usage to dissect cell-autonomous vs. non-cell-autonomous roles.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes causal mechanisms (metabolic and mitochondrial gene functions, AMPK signaling) underlying systemic aging processes, with generalizable principles beyond specific organs or diseases. The study addresses fundamental metabolic regulation of aging phenotypes at organismal level.

results.title: Social environment as a modulator of immunosenescence.

theories.name: Social environment modulation of immunosenescence theory

key_concepts.concept: Immunosenescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Immunosenescence refers to the aging-related rearrangement and decline in immune system function, leading to increased susceptibility to infections, autoimmune diseases, and cancer, thereby contributing to systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Social environment as a modulator of immunosenescence
key_concepts.description: The social context, including negative environments like loneliness or social isolation and positive environments with social support, profoundly influences immune function and the rate of immunosenescence, thus modulating overall aging.

Interactions between the nervous, immune, and endocrine systems mediate how stress and social environments impact immune aging, with mechanisms involving stress responses, hormesis, and resilience influencing immunosenescence dynamics.

key_concepts.concept: Molecular mechanisms linking social environment and immunosenescence
key_concepts.description: Potential molecular pathways are proposed to underlie how positive and negative social environments affect immune aging, although these mechanisms are suggested rather than fully elucidated.

theories.evidence: Citations of growing evidence associating social isolation with immune impairments and decreased lifespan, and positive social environments with improved immunity and increased lifespan; discussion of neuroimmunoendocrine communication and stress-related mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging via modulation of immunosenescence by social environment, addressing systemic aging processes beyond a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Ca<sup>2+</sup>/calmodulin signaling in organismal aging and cellular senescence: Impact on human diseases.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence refers to the permanent cell cycle arrest that cells undergo in response to various stressors. Senescent cells accumulate with age and contribute to tissue dysfunction and organismal aging by secreting pro-inflammatory factors and altering tissue microenvironments.

key_concepts.concept: Role of Ca2+/calmodulin signaling in senescence
key_concepts.description: Ca2+ ions and their sensor protein calmodulin regulate numerous cellular signaling pathways. Dysregulation of Ca2+/CaM signaling affects cellular processes linked to aging and senescence, including protein inactivation by oxidative/nitrosative stress, which may contribute to aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Connection between cellular senescence and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: Senescence mechanisms influenced by Ca2+/CaM signaling are implicated in the pathogenesis of multiple age-associated diseases such as heart and neuronal diseases, cancer, and metabolic disorders, suggesting a systemic impact of senescence on organismal aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews literature on Ca2+/CaM involvement in cellular aging and senescence, highlighting molecular aging processes in heart, neuronal diseases, cancer, and metabolic diseases, and discusses oxidative/nitrosative inactivation of proteins in aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory addresses a general causal mechanism (cellular senescence) contributing to organismal aging, discusses underlying molecular pathways (Ca2+/CaM signaling), and connects cellular processes to systemic aging and age-related diseases, thus meeting all core criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Potential implications of natural compounds on aging and metabolic regulation.

theories.name: Metabolic regulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Loss of metabolic homeostasis as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by a progressive decline in the body's ability to maintain stable metabolic processes, which contributes fundamentally to the aging phenotype.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation of metabolic pathways to delay aging
key_concepts.description: Targeting key metabolic pathways involved in carbohydrate, protein, lipid, and NAD+ metabolism can influence the aging process and promote healthy aging.

key_concepts.concept: Natural compounds as modulators of metabolism and aging
key_concepts.description: Certain natural compounds such as phenolic compounds, terpenoids, alkaloids, and nucleotide compounds can regulate metabolic pathways and exhibit anti-aging effects by restoring or optimizing metabolic homeostasis.

theories.evidence: Summary of recent findings from multiple studies on metabolic pathways and natural compounds with anti-aging effects; discussion of metabolomics as a tool to identify targets and mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging centered on metabolic dysregulation, discusses underlying mechanisms at organismal level, and synthesizes evidence on natural compounds modulating these mechanisms.

results.title: Deciphering clock genes as emerging targets against aging.

theories.name: Clock Genes and Circadian Rhythm Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Clock genes are genetic components that control the circadian rhythms, which are the roughly 24-hour cycles in physiological processes. These rhythms influence various biological functions and their disruption is linked to aging.
Disruptions in circadian rhythms, common in older individuals, are proposed to accelerate the aging process and contribute to the development of aging-related degenerative diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Clock Genes Influence Aging-Related Degenerative Diseases
key_concepts.description: The theory connects clock gene function and polymorphisms to the pathogenesis of diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and osteoarthritis, suggesting a mechanistic link between circadian regulation and systemic aging.

theories.evidence: The paper systematically summarizes existing literature on clock genes, their polymorphisms, and their roles in aging and degenerative diseases; it is a review article without new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (circadian rhythm regulation by clock genes) influencing systemic aging and age-related diseases, addressing aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Deciphering the anti-senescent effects of Clioquinol: Lifespan prolongation, metabolic homeostasis, and phenotypic rehabilitation in Drosophila melanogaster.

theories.name: Multi-pathway signaling modulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Signaling pathway regulation as a mechanism of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging and anti-aging effects can be mediated by modulation of multiple conserved signaling pathways that regulate cellular stress responses, metabolism, inflammation, and growth. Key pathways include HIF-1, Notch, P53, JAK-STAT, FOXO, IL-17, TNF, PI3K-Akt, and mTOR, whose differential activation or inhibition influences organismal aging and lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of metabolic homeostasis and stress resistance
key_concepts.description: Aging is influenced by the organism’s ability to maintain metabolic balance and resist stress. Enhancing glycolipid metabolism and stress resistance through pathway modulation can delay aging phenotypes and extend lifespan.

Modulating these pathways affects multiple aging-related phenotypes such as intestinal inflammation, obesity, digestive decline, and neurodegeneration, suggesting a systemic, organism-level mechanism rather than isolated tissue effects.

theories.evidence: Experimental lifespan extension and phenotypic improvements in Drosophila under normal and high-fat diets, Alzheimer's model flies; gene-deficient lifespan experiments; transcriptomic analyses showing differential expression in multiple aging-related signaling pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging involving conserved signaling pathways affecting systemic aging processes; supported by mechanistic gene expression data and functional lifespan assays; not limited to single organ or disease but addresses broad aging phenomena.

results.title: Morphological, physiological and biochemical alterations in livers of rodents induced by protease inhibitors: a comparison with old livers.

theories.name: Protease inhibitor model of aging

key_concepts.concept: Protease inhibition leading to lipofuscin accumulation
key_concepts.description: The model proposes that inhibition of thiol proteases by compounds such as leupeptin and E-64C causes accumulation of lipofuscin-like pigments in cells, which is a hallmark of aging. This accumulation is suggested to mimic or induce cellular aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Lipofuscin as a marker and mediator of cellular aging
key_concepts.description: Lipofuscin, a fluorescent pigment accumulating in aged cells, is considered both a marker and a potential contributor to cellular aging. The model links protease inhibition to increased lipofuscin formation, suggesting a mechanistic pathway for aging.

Originally proposed based on brain tissue studies, this model is tested here in liver tissues of rodents, showing similar lipofuscin accumulation and functional decline, indicating the model's applicability beyond a single organ and species.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing dose-dependent induction of lipofuscin-like pigments in young rat and mouse livers after administration of protease inhibitors leupeptin and E-64C; observed decline in hepatobiliary transport functions similar to aging; comparison with old rat livers' pigment fluorescence and dolichol concentration.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (protease inhibition causing lipofuscin accumulation) explaining a fundamental aging process at the cellular and tissue level, with evidence across organs and species, and links to functional decline resembling aging.

results.title: Aging by the clock and yet without a program.

theories.name: Damage Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Stochastic accumulation of molecular errors and damage
key_concepts.description: Aging results from the random buildup of molecular damage over time, including DNA damage and other cellular errors, rather than from a programmed sequence of events.
The accumulation of damage is driven by the body's declining ability to maintain and repair molecular and cellular components, leading to increased entropy and functional decline.
The progressive accumulation of damage contributes to a rise in systemic disorder (entropy), which underlies the aging process at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Role of DNA repair capacity in longevity
key_concepts.description: Comparative studies across species suggest that enhanced DNA repair mechanisms are associated with exceptional longevity, supporting the importance of damage repair in aging.

theories.evidence: Cross-species comparisons indicating DNA repair capacity correlates with longevity; references to aging clocks and natural selection theory arguments.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains aging as a fundamental process via damage accumulation; proposes causal mechanisms; addresses organism-wide aging rather than narrow phenomena.

theories.name: Programmed Aging Theory (Critiqued)

key_concepts.description: The idea that aging is driven by an intrinsic genetic or epigenetic program that actively causes aging processes in a regulated manner.

key_concepts.concept: Aging clocks as evidence for programming
key_concepts.description: Recent development of precise aging clocks has been used to argue for the existence of a biological aging program.
The weakening of natural selection after reproduction onset suggests that aging may not require a programmed mechanism but can result from accumulated damage.

theories.evidence: Discussion of aging clocks and evolutionary theory regarding natural selection; no new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: While it discusses a general aging theory, the paper critiques rather than supports it; still meets criteria as it addresses a general causal explanation of aging.

results.title: Suppression of autophagy induces senescence in the heart.

theories.name: Autophagy suppression-induced cellular senescence theory

key_concepts.concept: Autophagy as a cellular quality control mechanism
key_concepts.description: Generalized autophagy degrades cytosolic materials non-selectively, maintaining cellular homeostasis and quality control. Its decline with aging leads to accumulation of damaged cellular components, contributing to aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Suppression of autophagy directly induces cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: Reduction or loss of autophagy function in cardiomyocytes causes accumulation of senescent cells characterized by DNA damage and SASP, which promotes aging and dysfunction in the heart.

key_concepts.concept: Senescence as a causal driver of organ-level aging and dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Senescent cardiomyocytes negatively affect myocardial function through paracrine mechanisms, linking cellular senescence induced by autophagy suppression to systemic cardiac aging and dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of senescent cells mitigates aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Use of senolytic agents like ABT-263 reduces senescent cell burden and improves cardiac function, supporting the causal role of senescence induced by autophagy suppression in aging-related cardiac decline.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from cardiac-specific Atg7 knockout mice showing accumulation of senescent cardiomyocytes and cardiac dysfunction; in vitro cultured cardiomyocytes with Atg7 downregulation; use of senolytic ABT-263 improving cardiac function; observations in doxorubicin-treated hearts with autophagy suppression and senescence induction.
