theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process (cellular senescence induced by autophagy decline) with causal mechanisms linking autophagy suppression to senescence and organ dysfunction; generalizable beyond specific disease; supported by mechanistic experiments.

results.title: Uncovering the multivariate genetic architecture of frailty with genomic structural equation modeling.
Mechanisms of aging-related secretory phenotype regulation in osteoporosis: Network regulation, trade-offs and homeostasis.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cells enter a permanent state of growth arrest where they lose the ability to proliferate, triggered by various intracellular and extracellular stressors.

Senescent cells secrete a complex mixture of bioactive molecules including cytokines, chemokines, growth factors, and proteases that affect neighboring cells and tissue microenvironment through autocrine and paracrine signaling.

key_concepts.concept: Contribution to systemic aging and tissue dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Accumulation of senescent cells and their SASP factors disrupt tissue homeostasis, promote chronic inflammation, and impair function of tissue-specific cells, thereby accelerating organismal aging and age-related diseases such as osteoporosis.

theories.evidence: Citations of emerging evidence linking senescent cell accumulation and SASP production to osteoporosis and skeletal aging; description of hallmark features of senescent cells and their secretory profile.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how cellular senescence drives systemic aging through SASP-mediated disruption of tissue homeostasis; theory is generalizable beyond osteoporosis to organismal aging; provides causal explanation rather than mere correlation; focuses on a fundamental aging process.

results.title: Aging-Associated Mitochondrial Decline Accelerates Skin Aging and Obesity.

theories.name: Mitochondrial Decline Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial number and function decline with age
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that a reduction in the number and/or activity of mitochondria in cells is a primary driver of aging phenotypes. In this paper, epidermal cells show age-related decreases in mitochondrial number, suggesting mitochondrial decline is a fundamental aging mechanism.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction leads to impaired tissue homeostasis
key_concepts.description: Declining mitochondrial function disrupts cellular metabolism and homeostasis, contributing to aging-related impairments such as delayed hair regrowth and impaired wound healing in skin.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial decline in epidermal cells contributes to systemic aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: The study links mitochondrial dysfunction in skin epidermal cells to broader systemic effects, including obesity, through impaired fatty acid metabolism, indicating a causal role of mitochondrial decline in organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from mice lacking TFAM in epidermal cells showing phenotypes resembling aged skin and systemic obesity; observations of mitochondrial number decline in aged epidermal cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (mitochondrial decline) underlying aging at the organism level, supported by mechanistic evidence and systemic effects beyond a single tissue.

results.title: DNA Damage and the Aging Epigenome.

theories.name: DNA damage-driven aging theory with epigenetic alterations

key_concepts.concept: DNA damage as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that accumulation of DNA damage over time leads to cellular malfunction and contributes causally to organismal aging. DNA lesions impair critical processes such as transcription and replication, which in turn cause somatic mutations and functional decline.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic alterations induced by persistent DNA damage
key_concepts.description: Beyond direct genetic damage, DNA lesions trigger widespread changes in the epigenome that disrupt cell homeostasis. These epigenetic changes accumulate with age and contribute to the aging phenotype and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Link between genome instability and systemic aging
key_concepts.description: The theory integrates genome instability and epigenetic dysregulation as interconnected mechanisms underlying aging, supported by evidence from progeroid syndromes and DNA repair-deficient animal models.

theories.evidence: Citations of progeroid patient data and animal models with DNA repair defects; recent studies showing epigenetic changes following DNA damage; conceptual integration of genome instability and epigenetic alterations in aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains aging as a fundamental process via DNA damage and epigenetic mechanisms; proposes causal mechanisms linking DNA lesions to aging phenotypes; addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Changes in DNA double-strand break repair during aging correlate with an increase in genomic mutations.

theories.name: DNA damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) as critical damage
key_concepts.description: DSBs are among the most harmful types of DNA damage, threatening genomic integrity and cellular function. Accumulation of unrepaired or misrepaired DSBs contributes to aging by increasing genomic mutations.

key_concepts.concept: Shift in DNA repair pathway usage with age
key_concepts.description: During replicative aging, cells shift from high-fidelity homologous recombination (HR) repair to more error-prone non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ) and alternative mutagenic repair pathways, leading to increased genomic instability.

key_concepts.concept: Decline in repair factor recruitment and function
key_concepts.description: Aging cells show decreased recruitment of key repair proteins (e.g., Dna2-Sgs1, Exo1 for HR; Ku70 for NHEJ) to DSB sites, impairing repair efficiency and fidelity, which promotes mutation accumulation.

key_concepts.concept: Genomic mutations as a consequence of altered repair
key_concepts.description: Advanced replicative age correlates with increased repair products containing deletions and microhomologies, indicative of mutagenic repair events that contribute to genomic instability and aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from S. cerevisiae replicative aging model showing changes in repair protein association, repair pathway usage, and mutation patterns at DSB sites.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging based on DNA damage accumulation and repair pathway shifts, applicable broadly to organismal aging beyond a single disease or organ.

results.title: [The correlations between aging of the human body, oxidative stress and reduced efficiency of repair systems].

theories.name: Oxidative Stress and Damage Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative damage by reactive oxygen species (ROS)
key_concepts.description: Reactive oxygen species cause damage to cellular macromolecules such as proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids. This oxidative damage is proposed as a fundamental mechanism driving the aging process and the development of age-related diseases.
Oxidative stress leads to DNA damage, including mutations that can promote tumor development. This damage accumulation is a key causal factor in aging and age-associated pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Decline in repair system efficiency with age
key_concepts.description: Repair mechanisms, including homologous recombination for DNA repair and simpler repair systems for proteins and lipids, become less efficient with aging. This decline results in increased cellular damage and contributes to aging phenotypes and diseases.

theories.evidence: Summary of current knowledge and citations regarding oxidative damage, repair mechanisms, and their decline with age; references to diseases linked to oxidative damage such as cancer, neurodegeneration, and atherosclerosis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (oxidative damage and repair decline) explaining why aging occurs at the organismal level, linking molecular damage accumulation to systemic aging and disease.

results.title: Individual DNA Methylation Profile is Correlated with Age and can be Targeted to Modulate Healthy Aging and Longevity.

theories.name: Epigenetic Aging Theory (DNA Methylation-based Aging Theory)

key_concepts.concept: DNA Methylation as an Epigenetic Modification
key_concepts.description: DNA methylation is a key epigenetic modification that changes with age. These modifications occur at specific sites and genome-wide, influencing gene expression and cellular function, thereby contributing to the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Methylation Patterns Correlate with Chronological and Biological Aging
key_concepts.description: Patterns of DNA methylation are associated not only with chronological age but also with biological aging or the quality of aging, reflecting individual differences in aging rate and health status.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial DNA Methylation and Nuclear Genome Interaction
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial DNA undergoes methylation modifications and can modulate global DNA methylation levels of the nuclear genome, suggesting a cross-talk mechanism that influences aging and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Methylome Remodeling as a Biomarker and Target for Intervention
key_concepts.description: Age-related remodeling of the methylome reflects aging and decline, making DNA methylation profiles excellent biomarkers of aging and frailty. Understanding these mechanisms opens opportunities for targeted treatments to modulate aging rate and promote longevity.

theories.evidence: Literature data analysis on DNA methylation variations during lifetime, associations with aging and longevity, and recent findings on mitochondrial DNA methylation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism (epigenetic changes via DNA methylation) underlying biological aging at the organism level, discusses mechanisms and evolutionary/environmental influences, and links to systemic aging and longevity.

results.title: Immunosenescence and Ageing: An Entangled Web of Senescence and Declining Immunity.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cells enter a durable cell-cycle arrest state known as senescence, which is a hallmark of aging. Senescent cells accumulate with age and contribute to functional decline.
Senescent cells secrete SASP molecules that recruit immune cells to clear these cells, linking senescence to immune system function and systemic aging.
Senescence is essential for physiological functions but becomes chronic due to immune system decline, leading to pathological aging.

theories.evidence: References to animal studies demonstrating systemic aging driven by senescence and immune deficiencies; discussion of senolytic and senomorphic drug interventions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging at the organism level, linking cellular senescence and immune system decline to systemic aging.

theories.name: Immunosenescence as a Driver of Systemic Aging

key_concepts.description: The aging of immune cells leads to immune deficiencies that impair clearance of senescent cells, contributing to chronic senescence and systemic aging.
Restoring thymic function can reverse immunosenescence and systemic aging, suggesting immune system aging is a key causal factor.
Targeting immunosenescence through thymic regeneration or senolytic drugs may alleviate aging-related decline, highlighting immune aging as a therapeutic target.

theories.evidence: Citations of animal studies showing systemic aging driven by immunosenescence; references to thymic regeneration studies and senolytic drug research.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how immune system aging drives organism-level aging.

results.title: Smoke's Enduring Legacy: Bridging Early-Life Smoking Exposures and Later-Life Epigenetic Age Acceleration.
Breathe it in - Spotlight on senescence and regeneration in the lung.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is described as a highly coordinated and programmed state that cells enter, which is not merely a random damage accumulation but a regulated process with functional roles.

key_concepts.concept: Dual role in tissue physiology and pathology
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells have a transient beneficial role in limiting tissue damage and promoting regeneration after acute stress, but their persistent accumulation drives age-related decline in organ function.
The accumulation of senescent cells in the lung exemplifies how cellular senescence contributes causally to age-related organ dysfunction, linking cellular mechanisms to organism-level aging.

theories.evidence: Recent advances in tools to track and isolate senescent cells in vivo are cited, along with observations of their transient versus persistent presence affecting lung function and pathology.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process at organism level, proposes a causal mechanism (senescent cell accumulation), and addresses broad aging-related decline beyond a single disease.

results.title: Inside insulin signaling, communication is key to long life.

theories.name: Insulin/IGF signaling theory of aging

key_concepts.description: A conserved hormonal signaling pathway involving insulin and insulin-like growth factors that regulates metabolism, growth, and longevity across species. Modulation of this pathway influences aging rates and lifespan.

Inhibition of insulin/IGF signaling in specific tissues (e.g., adipose tissue) can have systemic effects on organismal aging by communicating signals to other tissues, thereby coordinating longevity and stress resistance at the organismal level.

Changes in insulin/IGF signaling in one tissue affect other peripheral tissues through signaling mechanisms that do not require direct cell contact, highlighting the importance of intercellular communication in aging regulation.

theories.evidence: Cited recent Nature paper by Tatar et al. demonstrating that adipose-specific inhibition of insulin/IGF signaling in Drosophila delays aging, increases oxidative stress resistance, and modulates lipid metabolism; also references similar findings in C. elegans.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental and general aging mechanism (insulin/IGF signaling) with causal explanations (signaling pathway modulation affects aging), applicable organism-wide via inter-tissue communication, and supported by experimental data.

results.title: The transcription factor STAT3 and aging: an intermediate medium.

theories.name: STAT3 signaling as a regulator of aging

key_concepts.concept: STAT3 as a core regulatory factor
key_concepts.description: STAT3 is described as a central transcription factor involved in regulating multiple processes relevant to aging, including metabolism, development, cellular senescence, and apoptosis.
During aging, changes in growth factors and cytokines activate STAT3 to varying degrees, which in turn modulates inflammatory pathways that contribute to chronic inflammation, a hallmark of aging.

key_concepts.concept: STAT3 influence on mitochondrial function, autophagy, and cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: STAT3 regulates mitochondrial function and autophagy processes, both critical for cellular homeostasis, and influences cellular senescence, thereby impacting the aging process at the cellular and organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of STAT3 to delay aging and treat aging-related diseases
key_concepts.description: The review emphasizes that drugs targeting STAT3 signaling pathways hold promise for treating senescence-related diseases and potentially delaying aging, suggesting a causal role of STAT3 in aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing existing literature on STAT3's role in aging-related processes such as mitochondrial function, inflammation, autophagy, and cellular senescence, and discusses drug development targeting STAT3.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how STAT3 signaling causally regulates fundamental aging processes at the organismal level through mechanisms like inflammation and cellular senescence, thus meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: Exploring cellular senescence in the musculoskeletal system: Any insights for biomarkers discovery?

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: With advancing age and pathological conditions, senescent cells accumulate in tissues such as muscle and bone. These cells cease to divide and resist apoptosis, leading to their persistence in the tissue microenvironment.
Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory factors that induce local inflammation, promote senescence in neighboring cells, and impair tissue homeostasis and repair mechanisms.
The buildup of senescent cells in musculoskeletal tissues negatively affects muscle regeneration and bone turnover, contributing to functional decline, frailty, and disorders like osteoporosis.

key_concepts.concept: Role of oxidative stress and DNA damage
key_concepts.description: Age-related accumulation of oxidative stress and DNA damage in niche cells triggers the onset of cellular senescence, which is exacerbated by weakened immune clearance mechanisms.

theories.evidence: The abstract references correlations between senescent cell accumulation and impaired muscle regeneration and bone turnover, as well as the role of oxidative stress and DNA damage. It also discusses the secretory profile of senescent cells and its effects on tissue inflammation and homeostasis, citing current knowledge without presenting new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory meets all criteria: it provides a generalizable causal explanation for aging at the organism level via cellular senescence mechanisms, addresses broad aging processes in musculoskeletal tissues linked to systemic aging, and proposes underlying mechanisms involving senescent cell accumulation and SASP.

results.title: Pilot study on CpG methylation of the NRF2 promoter across different ages and sexes in healthy and lung cancer prediagnostic individuals.

theories.name: Redox clock theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: NRF2 promoter CpG methylation as an epigenetic marker
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that age-related changes in the methylation status of the NRF2 gene promoter reflect alterations in oxidative stress regulation, which is a fundamental aging process. Increased methylation correlates with reduced NRF2 expression, impacting cellular redox homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress regulation as a driver of biological aging
key_concepts.description: NRF2 is a master regulator of antioxidant responses; its epigenetic repression with age suggests a mechanistic link between declining oxidative stress defenses and systemic aging. This supports oxidative stress accumulation as a causal mechanism in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic clock based on redox regulation
key_concepts.description: The 'redox clock' is a novel epigenetic aging biomarker derived from NRF2 promoter methylation patterns, proposed to model biological aging and accelerated aging more sensitively than established epigenetic clocks. It reflects mechanistic aging processes rather than just chronological age.

theories.evidence: Methylation-sensitive enzyme assays and Illumina MethylationEPIC microarray data from two independent healthy cohorts; correlation of specific CpG methylation sites with age; differential methylation and gene expression patterns by sex and age; application of the redox clock to discriminate prediagnostic lung cancer cases from controls, outperforming established epigenetic clocks.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism linking epigenetic regulation of oxidative stress pathways to systemic biological aging; it addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases, and provides mechanistic insight rather than mere correlation or prediction.

results.title: The emotion paradox in the aging body and brain.

theories.name: Autonomic Compensation Model

key_concepts.description: With aging, parasympathetic activity decreases and sympathetic (noradrenergic) activity increases, leading to low heart rate variability and high noradrenaline levels in older adults.

key_concepts.concept: Noradrenergic hyperactivity as a response to aging pathology
key_concepts.description: Failing organs, early Alzheimer's pathology, and other age-related diseases trigger increased noradrenergic activity, representing a chronic sympathetic hyperactivity state.

key_concepts.concept: Compensatory regulatory activity in the pregenual prefrontal cortex
key_concepts.description: The older brain attempts to compensate for noradrenergic hyperactivity by increasing autonomic regulatory efforts in the pregenual PFC, which biases emotional processing toward stimuli that promote parasympathetic activity and emotional well-being.

key_concepts.concept: Limitations of compensation due to nerve conduction decline
key_concepts.description: Age-related declines in nerve conduction reduce the pregenual PFC's ability to fully suppress hyperactive noradrenergic activity and to increase peripheral heart rate variability.

key_concepts.concept: Paradoxical improvement in emotional well-being despite physiological decline
key_concepts.description: The compensatory autonomic regulation in the brain leads to enhanced emotional well-being in older adults, despite physiological markers (low HRV, high noradrenaline) that in younger adults correlate with stress and unhappiness.

theories.evidence: The abstract presents a conceptual model based on known physiological changes with aging (parasympathetic decline, sympathetic increase), neuroanatomical focus on pregenual PFC, and observed paradoxical emotional outcomes; no direct experimental data described in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how aging-related autonomic changes lead to altered emotional experience at the organism level, linking physiological aging processes to systemic emotional aging.

results.title: The activity of early-life gene regulatory elements is hijacked in aging through pervasive AP-1-linked chromatin opening.

theories.name: AP-1-linked chromatin opening as a driver of organismal maturation and aging

key_concepts.description: Certain candidate cis-regulatory elements lose accessibility progressively during organismal maturation and aging, particularly those enriched for cell-type identity transcription factor binding sites (TFBSs). This loss is linked to changes in gene expression related to development and metabolism.

There is a shift in transcription factor binding from cell identity TFBS-rich cCREs to cCREs enriched with activator protein 1 (AP-1) TFBSs. This redistribution, combined with mild downregulation of cell identity transcription factors, drives chromatin remodeling and transcriptome reprogramming.

key_concepts.concept: AP-1-driven chromatin opening hijacked in aging
key_concepts.description: The mechanism that drives organismal maturation via AP-1-linked chromatin opening is co-opted or hijacked during aging, resulting in ongoing chromatin opening that disrupts cell identity regulatory elements and alters cell function.

theories.evidence: Profiling of age-related chromatin and transcriptional changes across 22 murine cell types, analysis alongside mouse and human maturation datasets, experimental manipulation elevating AP-1 or depleting repressive H3K27me3 to trigger chromatin remodeling.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs at the chromatin and transcriptional regulation level, linking developmental processes to aging. It addresses organism-level aging processes through epigenetic and transcriptional regulation, meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: Key miRNAs in Modulating Aging and Longevity: A Focus on Signaling Pathways and Cellular Targets.

theories.name: miRNA-mediated regulation of aging via conserved signaling pathways

key_concepts.description: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are short non-coding RNAs that regulate gene expression post-transcriptionally by binding to target mRNAs. Their differential expression during aging suggests they play a role in modulating cellular and organismal aging processes.

miRNAs influence longevity and aging by modulating well-known aging-related signaling pathways such as the insulin/insulin-like growth factor signaling (IIS) pathway, which is conserved across species and implicated in lifespan regulation.

key_concepts.concept: miRNAs modulating cellular senescence and tissue aging
key_concepts.description: Certain miRNAs contribute to the regulation of cellular senescence, a key driver of systemic aging, and affect age-related changes in various tissues including heart, skin, bone, brain, and muscle, linking molecular regulation to organismal aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews data from invertebrate model organisms showing miRNAs modulate lifespan via IIS pathway, and mammalian studies measuring tissue-specific miRNA expression changes with age; also discusses miRNAs roles in cellular senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general mechanism (miRNA regulation) underlying aging across organisms, proposes causal roles via conserved pathways and cellular senescence, and links molecular regulation to systemic aging processes.

results.title: S913 phosphorylation of Ulk1 protects the heart from aging through inhibition of cardiac senescence.

theories.name: Cellular senescence as a causal driver of systemic aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that senescence of cardiomyocytes, characterized by markers such as P16, P21, IL6, γH2AX, and P53, contributes causally to the development of cardiac dysfunction, fibrosis, and hypertrophy, thereby accelerating cardiac aging.

key_concepts.concept: GSK-3β-Ulk1-autophagy pathway regulates senescence and aging
key_concepts.description: Phosphorylation of Ulk1 at Ser913 by GSK-3β is proposed to stimulate autophagy, which protects the heart from aging. Disruption of this phosphorylation leads to increased cardiomyocyte senescence and premature cardiac aging, suggesting autophagy as a protective mechanism against aging.

Pharmacological removal of senescent cells using ABT-263 attenuates cardiac dysfunction, hypertrophy, and fibrosis, supporting the causal role of senescent cells in driving cardiac aging and validating senescence as a therapeutic target.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from systemic and cardiac-specific Ulk1S913A knock-in mice showing accelerated cardiac aging phenotypes and increased senescence markers; RNA-seq data revealing gene expression changes related to senescence and metabolism; in vitro overexpression studies inducing senescence; senolytic treatment reversing aging phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory addresses a general aging mechanism (cellular senescence) with causal explanation (senescence driving cardiac aging), supported by mechanistic insights (GSK-3β-Ulk1-autophagy pathway), and is generalizable to organismal aging beyond just cardiac tissue due to the systemic role of senescence.

results.title: Rethinking rare disease: longevity-enhancing drug targets through X-linked aneuploidy.
Complex Interplay Between Estrogen and Aging via Lipid Metabolism and Inflammation Forms the Novel Treatment Strategies for Atherosclerosis.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells as drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate with age and contribute to tissue dysfunction by secreting pro-inflammatory factors known as the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), which promotes chronic inflammation and age-related pathologies.

SASP comprises a variety of cytokines, chemokines, and proteases secreted by senescent cells that alter the tissue microenvironment, exacerbate inflammation, and impair normal cellular functions, thereby accelerating aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Targeting senescent cells as an intervention
key_concepts.description: Elimination of senescent cells or inhibition of SASP is proposed as a therapeutic strategy to mitigate aging-related vascular dysfunction and diseases such as atherosclerosis.

theories.evidence: Citations of emerging evidence linking vascular senescence pathways to estrogen and aging interactions; proposal of senolytic interventions and SASP inhibition as therapeutic approaches.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (cellular senescence) underlying aging processes, links it to systemic aging (vascular aging and atherosclerosis), and discusses interventions targeting this mechanism.

theories.name: Hormonal modulation of aging via estrogen pathways

key_concepts.concept: Estrogen's role in modulating vascular aging
key_concepts.description: Estrogen influences lipid metabolism, inflammatory responses, and vascular function, thereby modulating aging-related changes in the cardiovascular system.

key_concepts.concept: Bidirectional interplay between estrogen deficiency and aging
key_concepts.description: Aging exacerbates endothelial dysfunction caused by estrogen deficiency, creating a feedback loop that accelerates vascular aging and atherosclerosis progression.

Effective estrogen replacement therapies must consider timing relative to menopausal transition, receptor subtype specificity, and aging-related changes in the vascular microenvironment to optimize benefits and minimize risks.

theories.mode: review, synthesize, propose refined therapeutic strategies
theories.evidence: Review of literature on estrogen effects on vascular senescence and aging; proposal of tissue-selective estrogen analogs and timing considerations for therapy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general mechanism (hormonal regulation) influencing systemic aging processes, proposes causal pathways, and integrates evolutionary and physiological aspects.

results.title: Is taurine an aging biomarker?
Autophagy in aging and in neurodegenerative disorders.

theories.name: Autophagy decline theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Autophagy is a cellular process responsible for bulk degradation and recycling of long-lived proteins, damaged organelles, and macromolecular aggregates, maintaining cellular homeostasis by removing worn-out components.

key_concepts.concept: Decline of autophagic activity with age
key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by diminished autophagic activity, leading to accumulation of nonfunctional cellular components due to oxidative damage and reduced turnover, which contributes to cellular aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of lysosomes and mitochondria in aging
key_concepts.description: Lysosomes are critical organelles in aging because they fuse with autophagosomes to degrade cellular debris; inefficient removal of defective mitochondria by lysosomes exacerbates aging progression.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies in yeast and mammalian systems elucidating molecular mechanisms of autophagy; observed correlations between reduced autophagy and aging phenotypes; references to pathological conditions linked to autophagy dysfunction.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs at the cellular and organismal level through decline in autophagy, addressing fundamental aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Drugging non-coding RNAs-A new light of hope in senescence-related cancer therapy.

theories.name: Senescence-Associated Secretory Phenotype (SASP) theory of aging-related cancer progression

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging and cancer
key_concepts.description: Senescence is described as a natural aging process that induces cancer in neighboring cells through the production of Senescence-Associated Secretory Phenotypes (SASPs). These secreted factors from senescent cells contribute to the aging microenvironment and promote tumorigenesis.

key_concepts.concept: Role of non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) in regulating senescence
key_concepts.description: Non-coding RNAs are emerging as important regulators of cellular senescence and aging processes. They influence various cellular pathways involved in senescence and may modulate SASP production, thereby affecting cancer progression.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of ncRNAs to control senescence and cancer
key_concepts.description: Targeting ncRNAs with small molecules or in combination therapies is proposed as a novel approach to control senescence and inhibit the accumulation of senescent cells, aiming to prevent or treat aging-related cancer development.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing existing studies on ncRNAs roles in senescence and cancer, emphasizing recent research and therapeutic strategies; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses cellular senescence as a fundamental aging process with causal mechanisms (SASP), discusses ncRNAs as regulators influencing aging and cancer broadly, and proposes therapeutic interventions targeting these mechanisms. It links senescence to organism-level aging and cancer progression, not limited to a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Beyond the 900-day rule: Reclaiming healthspan as geroscience's primary goal.

theories.name: Intrinsic versus Manifest Aging Dual-Track Framework

key_concepts.description: Aging processes studied under idealized, controlled conditions such as genetically uniform, sterile environments, focusing on lifespan extension as a primary endpoint.

Aging as it occurs in real-world, metabolically and immunologically stressful environments characterized by chronic inflammation, metabolic drift, frailty, cognitive decline, and immune erosion, often preceding death.

The idea that improvements in healthspan (functional health and quality of life) can occur independently of significant lifespan extension, as exemplified by interventions like CaAKG that reduce frailty without large lifespan gains.

A proposed approach combining rigorous lifespan testing in idealized models with phenotype-driven studies in real-world aging models to better capture the complexity and translational relevance of aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of interventions such as GlyNAC, NLRP3 inhibition, and CaAKG showing functional benefits in real-world aging models; discussion of the '900-day rule' and its limitations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable framework explaining how aging should be studied and conceptualized at an organismal level, addressing causal mechanisms indirectly by emphasizing environmental and physiological contexts influencing aging trajectories and healthspan.

results.title: More than a sum of our cells.
Apheresis for senescence: Targeting the senescence-associated secretory phenotype to delay aging and age-related diseases.

theories.name: Cellular senescence and senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cells enter a state of permanent growth arrest called senescence, which accumulates with age and contributes causally to organismal aging by impairing tissue function.

Senescent cells secrete a complex mixture of pro-inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, proteases, and growth factors collectively termed SASP, which promote chronic inflammation (inflammaging) and disrupt tissue homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: SASP-driven chronic inflammation and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: SASP factors induce systemic inflammation that contributes to the pathogenesis of multiple age-related diseases including cardiovascular disease, neurodegeneration, and cancer.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of SASP to delay aging
key_concepts.description: Interventions such as senolytics, SASP inhibitors, and novel approaches like therapeutic plasma exchange (TPE) and selective apheresis aim to reduce SASP burden, systemic inflammation, and restore a youthful systemic environment to improve healthspan.

theories.evidence: Citations of prior studies on senescence, SASP, inflammaging, and anti-aging interventions including senolytics and plasma exchange; mechanistic rationale for TPE and selective apheresis as emerging therapies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process (cellular senescence and SASP) with causal mechanisms (SASP-induced inflammation), generalizable to organismal aging and multiple age-related diseases, and discusses therapeutic interventions targeting this mechanism.

results.title: From telomeres and senescence to integrated longevity medicine: redefining the path to extended healthspan.

theories.name: Cellular senescence and telomere attrition theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence refers to the irreversible growth arrest of cells in response to damage or stress, contributing to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging. It is considered a core hallmark of biological aging that limits healthspan.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere attrition as a causal mechanism
key_concepts.description: Telomeres, protective DNA-protein complexes at chromosome ends, shorten with each cell division, eventually triggering senescence or apoptosis. Telomere shortening is proposed as a fundamental aging mechanism influenced by oxidative stress and metabolic factors.

Contrary to being inevitable, telomere shortening can be modulated by lifestyle, oxidative stress levels, and metabolic regulation, suggesting aging is a modifiable process rather than strictly programmed.

key_concepts.concept: Systemic inflammation as an aging hallmark
key_concepts.description: Chronic, low-grade systemic inflammation (inflammaging) is linked to cellular senescence and telomere attrition, contributing to the decline in physiological function with age.

theories.evidence: Citations of emerging evidence on telomere dynamics influenced by oxidative stress and metabolism; references to biomarker tracking and metabolic interventions in clinical contexts.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging mechanisms at the organismal level, integrating cellular senescence and telomere biology as fundamental aging drivers.

theories.name: Integrated longevity medicine framework

key_concepts.description: Utilizing telomere-based biomarkers and metabolic interventions to tailor strategies aimed at delaying aging and extending healthspan on an individual basis.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of geroscience into clinical practice
key_concepts.description: Combining biomarker tracking, metabolic therapies, and preventive interventions to redefine aging as a modifiable process, enabling proactive healthspan extension.

theories.evidence: Discussion of clinical translation challenges and emerging biomarker-guided interventions; conceptual framework rather than direct experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: While more applied and translational, this framework is grounded in general aging mechanisms and proposes a systemic approach to modulate aging, thus meeting criteria as a theory-related intervention framework.

results.title: The Roles of Mitochondrial Dysfunction and Reactive Oxygen Species in Aging and Senescence.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) as causal agents
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that reactive oxygen species and free radicals are toxic molecules that cause direct biological damage to cellular components, leading to oxidative stress and contributing to the aging process.

Oxidative damage accumulates in key molecular targets such as mitochondrial DNA and proteins like aconitase, impairing mitochondrial function and morphology, which in turn drives tissue aging and functional decline.

Cells possess enzymatic and non-enzymatic compounds to neutralize ROS toxicity, and processes like autophagy and mitophagy help clear oxidized, non-functional proteins, mitigating damage accumulation.

theories.evidence: Citations and discussion of oxidative damage in mitochondria, mitochondrial DNA mutations, protein dysfunction, and the role of antioxidant systems and autophagy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging based on damage accumulation by ROS, applicable broadly at the organism level, and explains why aging occurs via oxidative stress.

theories.name: Telomere-Driven Replicative Senescence Theory

key_concepts.description: Telomeres shorten with cell division, and this shortening acts as a significant trigger for replicative senescence, limiting cellular proliferative capacity.
Oxidative stress increases the rate of telomere shortening, thereby accelerating the onset of replicative senescence, while antioxidants can slow this process.
Replicative senescence driven by telomere shortening is framed primarily as a cellular stress response modulated by oxidative damage.

theories.evidence: References to the relationship between oxidative stress and telomere dynamics, and their impact on cellular senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it explains a general mechanism of aging at the cellular level with implications for organismal aging, proposing causal links between oxidative stress, telomere attrition, and senescence.

results.title: Understanding Longevity: SIN-3 and DAF-16 Revealed as Independent Players in Lifespan Regulation.

theories.name: SIN-3 and DAF-16 Functional Interaction Theory of Lifespan Regulation

key_concepts.concept: SIN-3 as a regulatory protein in aging
key_concepts.description: SIN-3 is a unique transcriptional regulator that influences aging without directly binding DNA. It functions through multiple protein interactions, suggesting a role in modulating gene expression relevant to aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: DAF-16/FOXO as a key factor in stress response and longevity
key_concepts.description: DAF-16 is a well-known transcription factor involved in stress response and lifespan regulation, acting downstream of insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathways to promote longevity and healthy aging.

key_concepts.concept: Functional interaction without direct physical interaction
key_concepts.description: Although SIN-3 and DAF-16 do not physically interact at the protein level, genetic and transcriptomic data indicate they functionally cooperate, with SIN-3 potentially dominating or modulating DAF-16 activity to regulate stress responses and lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Concerted gene regulation as a mechanism for lifespan control
key_concepts.description: The interplay between SIN-3 and DAF-16 involves coordinated regulation of gene expression that impacts vital biological processes and stress responses, thereby influencing healthy aging and longevity.

theories.evidence: Phenotypic profiling of mutants, protein interaction assays showing lack of direct interaction, genomics and transcriptomics data indicating concerted gene regulation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain mechanisms of lifespan regulation at the organismal level by proposing how two regulatory proteins functionally interact to influence aging processes. It addresses causal mechanisms (gene regulation and stress response pathways) relevant to general aging, not limited to a single organ or disease. Thus, it meets the core requirements of an aging theory.

results.title: The dichotomic role of cytokines in aging.

theories.name: Inflammaging cytokine dichotomy theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic inflammation as a dual-role factor in aging
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that cytokines elevated during chronic inflammation in aging (inflammaging) have both beneficial and detrimental effects on longevity and aging processes.

Certain cytokines such as IL-1β, type I interferons, IL-6, and TNF can positively regulate macroautophagy, mitochondrial function, anti-tumor immune responses, and skeletal muscle biogenesis, potentially contributing to increased longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Detrimental effects of the same cytokines
key_concepts.description: These cytokines can also induce sarcopenia, tissue damage, and promote tumorigenesis, highlighting an antagonistic and harmful role in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of anti-inflammatory and other cytokines in aging
key_concepts.description: Cytokines like IL-10 have anti-inflammatory roles, while others such as IL-11 promote senescence, and IL-4 and IL-15 promote longevity, indicating a complex regulatory network influencing aging.

key_concepts.concept: Downstream cytokine-mediated signaling as aging regulators
key_concepts.description: Specific signaling pathways downstream of cytokines are discussed as regulators of aging, suggesting mechanistic links between cytokine activity and aging processes.

theories.evidence: Discussion based on known cytokines and their roles in inflammaging, referencing their effects on autophagy, mitochondrial function, immune responses, muscle biogenesis, senescence, and tumorigenesis; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging via cytokine-mediated inflammaging mechanisms affecting systemic aging processes; addresses both beneficial and detrimental roles, thus providing an organizing principle for aging regulation.

results.title: The ageing epigenome and its rejuvenation.

theories.name: Epigenetic theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic alterations as drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with changes in epigenetic mechanisms such as DNA methylation, histone modifications, chromatin remodeling, and non-coding RNA regulation. These epigenetic changes alter gene expression patterns, leading to functional decline of tissues and organs.

Manipulating epigenetic mechanisms through interventions like partial reprogramming, metabolic manipulation, or senescent cell ablation can rejuvenate the epigenome, potentially delaying aging and extending healthspan and lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic interventions as a strategy for healthspan extension
key_concepts.description: Targeting epigenetic regulators is central to the effectiveness of various rejuvenating interventions, suggesting that epigenetic modifications are causal contributors to aging rather than mere correlates.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing knowledge and interventions including metabolic manipulation, partial reprogramming, heterochronic parabiosis, pharmaceutical administration, and senescent cell ablation, citing their effects on epigenetic mechanisms and aging outcomes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria because it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging at the organism level via epigenetic changes, discusses mechanisms underlying aging, and connects these to broad aging processes and interventions.

results.title: Mitoresilience: Hormesis, Psycho-physical Resilience, Mitochondria and Heart Rate Variability as Relevant Interplaying Elements in Longevity Medicine.

theories.name: Mitohormesis and Mitoresilience Theory

key_concepts.description: Hormesis refers to a biphasic dose-response to mild stressors such as fasting, polyphenol intake, exercise, and mental engagement, which activate adaptive cellular metabolic pathways that promote resilience and longevity.

Mitochondria are considered core players in aging processes and primary targets of hormetic interventions, where mild stress induces beneficial mitochondrial adaptations that improve cellular function and delay senescence.

The interaction between psychological and physical stress and mitochondrial function influences health and disease balance, suggesting a mind-mitochondria axis that impacts cellular senescence and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Autonomic nervous system and heart rate variability (HRV) as resilience markers
key_concepts.description: HRV is used as a quantifiable measure of individual psychophysical resilience, reflecting autonomic nervous system status and serving as a biomarker to monitor interventions targeting hormetic pathways.

theories.evidence: Citations of research showing hormesis effects on sirtuin activation, mTOR and IGF-1 downregulation, Nrf2 upregulation, autophagy, and the role of mitochondria; references to psychobiological studies linking mind and mitochondrial function; HRV as a validated method to quantify resilience.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how biological aging occurs through mitochondrial-centered hormetic and psychobiological resilience mechanisms, proposing causal pathways and generalizable principles applicable to organismal aging. It integrates biochemical, cellular, and systemic levels, meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Circadian clock and its effect on aging and lifespan.

theories.name: Circadian Clock Dysfunction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Circadian clocks generate daily transcriptional rhythms that schedule key cellular activities to maintain homeostasis and resilience, coordinating central and peripheral clocks through oscillations of transcriptional activators and translational repressors.
With aging, the functional synchrony of the circadian system deteriorates, which exacerbates age-related disorders and negatively impacts organismal aging and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Circadian disruption accelerates aging and reduces lifespan
key_concepts.description: Disruption of circadian rhythms, whether due to aging or environmental factors such as modern lifestyle (e.g., shift work, electronic device use), adversely affects aging processes and longevity, as shown in animal models.

key_concepts.concept: Interventions targeting circadian rhythms can promote healthy aging
key_concepts.description: Non-pharmacological interventions like dietary restriction and physical exercise can regulate circadian rhythms, attenuate aging effects, and extend lifespan, suggesting that resetting circadian clocks may improve cellular homeodynamics and physiology.

theories.evidence: Citations of accumulating evidence from animal models showing aging-related circadian dysfunction and its impact on longevity; discussion of recent findings on dietary and exercise interventions affecting circadian rhythms and aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how aging occurs through disruption of a fundamental biological timing system (circadian clock) that regulates organism-wide homeostasis, proposes causal mechanisms linking circadian dysfunction to aging and longevity, and discusses interventions that modulate this system to affect aging outcomes. Thus, it meets the criteria of generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope.

results.title: Roles of Apoptosis and Cellular Senescence in Cancer and Aging.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a tumor-suppressor mechanism
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is a cellular response to stress-induced damage that prevents the proliferation of damaged cells, thereby suppressing tumor formation during early and reproductive stages of life.

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of senescent cells promotes aging
key_concepts.description: With aging, senescent cells accumulate in tissues, which contributes to tissue dysfunction and the aging phenotype, indicating a trade-off between cancer prevention and aging.

Apoptosis and cellular senescence are two essential cellular responses to damage, and their deregulation affects cancer and aging differently; understanding this balance is key to therapeutic strategies.

theories.evidence: Overview of literature on apoptosis and senescence roles in cancer and aging; references to recent discoveries about anticancer agents inducing senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining aging at the organismal level through accumulation of senescent cells, connects to cancer biology, and discusses underlying mechanisms.

results.title: Dynamics of redox signaling in aging via autophagy, inflammation, and senescence.

theories.name: Redox signaling theory of aging involving autophagy, inflammation, and senescence

key_concepts.concept: Redox signaling and reactive oxygen species (ROS)
key_concepts.description: ROS are chemically reactive molecules derived from oxygen that act as signaling molecules in cells. The theory posits that dynamic redox signaling, through controlled ROS levels, regulates key aging-related processes such as autophagy, inflammation, and cellular senescence.

Autophagy is a cellular degradation and recycling process that maintains cellular homeostasis. The theory suggests that redox signaling modulates autophagy, which in turn influences aging by removing damaged cellular components and maintaining cell function.

Inflammation is a hallmark of aging, often driven by oxidative stress. The theory highlights multiple ROS-generating pathways (NOX, TNF-α, IL-1β, xanthine oxidase, COX, myeloperoxidase) that contribute to chronic inflammation, linking redox signaling to age-related inflammatory processes.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence and senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP)
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate with age and secrete pro-inflammatory factors (SASP). The theory connects ROS production to the induction and maintenance of senescence, implicating redox signaling as a causal driver of systemic aging and age-related disorders.

key_concepts.concept: Crosstalk among autophagy, inflammation, and senescence
key_concepts.description: The theory emphasizes the interplay between these three processes mediated by balanced ROS levels, suggesting that their dynamic interactions determine aging progression and the development of age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews known ROS sources and pathways, discusses their roles in autophagy, inflammation, and senescence, and cites various molecular pathways (NOX, TNF-α, IL-1β, etc.). It also references oxidative damage as an aging marker and links to age-related disorders, though no new experimental data are presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging via redox signaling mechanisms affecting fundamental aging processes (autophagy, inflammation, senescence) at the organismal level. It integrates multiple pathways and mechanisms rather than focusing narrowly on one organ or disease.

results.title: Epigenetic reprogramming as a key to reverse ageing and increase longevity.

theories.name: Epigenetic Reprogramming Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic modifications as drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is closely associated with changes in epigenetic marks such as DNA methylation and histone modifications, which lead to cellular decline and increased susceptibility to age-related diseases.

Using transcription factors to partially reprogram cells can reset the epigenetic aging clock, reversing cellular aging without erasing cellular identity, thereby potentially reversing aging at the cellular level.
Small molecules, including DNA methyltransferase inhibitors and histone deacetylase inhibitors, can modulate epigenetic states to promote rejuvenation and counteract aging-related epigenetic changes.
Epigenetic clocks provide accurate measures of biological age and are used to assess aging and evaluate the effectiveness of reprogramming and rejuvenation interventions.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing current literature on epigenetic changes during aging, reprogramming strategies using transcription factors, chemical interventions, and epigenetic clocks; it cites recent advances and emerging biotech applications.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (epigenetic changes) underlying aging and interventions that can reverse aging processes at the cellular and organismal level; addresses fundamental aging mechanisms beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Common factors among three types of cells aged in mice.
Effects of Dietary Restriction on PGC-1α Regulation in the Development of Age-associated Diseases.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress theory of aging

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that the decline in mitochondrial function with age leads to reduced energy production and increased cellular damage, contributing to the aging process and age-related diseases.

The accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated by mitochondria causes oxidative damage to cellular components, which is proposed to drive aging and the development of degenerative diseases.

theories.evidence: Literature review citing studies linking mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress to aging and age-associated diseases; evidence from lifespan extension in organisms with dietary restriction and PGC-1α upregulation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism underlying aging applicable across organisms, explaining why aging occurs via mitochondrial decline and oxidative damage.

theories.name: Dietary restriction-mediated regulation of PGC-1α as a modulator of aging

key_concepts.description: Reducing nutrient intake without malnutrition triggers molecular pathways that promote longevity and delay age-related diseases, potentially by improving mitochondrial health.

PGC-1α is a transcriptional coactivator that promotes mitochondrial biogenesis and function; its expression is inducible by dietary restriction and is implicated in maintaining mitochondrial integrity during aging.

theories.evidence: Review of studies showing dietary restriction increases PGC-1α expression in tissues, correlating with lifespan extension and reduced incidence of non-communicable diseases in various organisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a mechanistic link between a general intervention (dietary restriction) and aging via regulation of mitochondrial function, applicable broadly across organisms.

results.title: [Cognitive reserve and neural networks in normal aging and Alzheimer's disease].
Aging and Proteins: What Does Proteostasis Have to Do with Age?

theories.name: Proteostasis Loss Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Proteostasis refers to the maintenance of cellular protein homeostasis through regulation of protein synthesis, folding, and degradation. The loss or dysfunction of proteostasis is proposed as a fundamental mechanism contributing to aging by impairing cellular function.
Improved proteostasis mechanisms have been observed in long-lived animals, suggesting that enhanced control of protein homeostasis can promote lifespan extension and healthy aging.
Components of the proteostasis network may serve as biomarkers of healthy aging, reflecting the biological age and functional state of the organism beyond chronological age.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing literature linking proteostasis dysfunction to aging and age-related diseases such as Alzheimer's, and cites reports on long-lived animals with improved proteostasis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (loss of proteostasis) with causal mechanisms (protein synthesis, folding, degradation dysfunction) that impact organismal aging broadly. It is not limited to a single disease or organ and proposes underlying biological mechanisms, meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Context-dependent roles of cellular senescence in normal, aged, and disease states.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is characterized by a permanent cessation of cell division, which occurs in response to various stressors such as tissue damage and contributes to aging and age-related diseases.

Senescent cells secrete a complex mixture of factors (SASP) that influence tissue regeneration and function, with effects that can be beneficial or detrimental depending on context such as tissue type, injury duration, and organismal age.

The impact of senescent cells varies with the tissue environment and age; transient senescence may aid tissue repair, whereas persistent senescence is linked to chronic degenerative diseases but may also support tissue function in the elderly.

theories.evidence: Summary of recent data and literature on senescent cell roles in tissue regeneration, aging, and disease; discussion of senolytic therapies and cellular reprogramming as potential interventions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental biological aging process at the organism level, proposes mechanisms (cell cycle arrest and SASP) causally linked to aging, and addresses broad aging phenomena including tissue regeneration and age-related diseases.

results.title: Stress responses during ageing: molecular pathways regulating protein homeostasis.

theories.name: Proteostatic Stress Response Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This concept involves the maintenance and restoration of the proper balance and function of proteins within cells and organisms. Proteostasis is crucial for cellular health, and its decline is linked to aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Heat Stress and Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress Responses
key_concepts.description: These are cellular stress response pathways that detect and mitigate damage caused by misfolded or aggregated proteins. Their regulation influences longevity by preserving protein quality and cellular function during aging.

key_concepts.concept: Cross Talk Between Stress Response Mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Different proteostatic stress responses interact systemically to coordinate organismal aging processes, suggesting an integrated network that impacts overall physiological aging.

theories.evidence: The paper surveys recent studies across diverse organisms highlighting the role of proteostatic stress response pathways in aging, referencing well-studied pathways like insulin/IGF-1 and dietary restriction, and emphasizing molecular pathways mediating stress responses.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging via proteostasis mechanisms affecting organismal aging broadly, not limited to specific diseases or organs.

theories.name: Insulin/Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IIS) Signaling Pathway in Aging

key_concepts.concept: IIS Pathway as a Regulator of Longevity
key_concepts.description: The insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathway is a conserved molecular pathway that influences aging by regulating growth, metabolism, and stress resistance, thereby affecting lifespan across species.

theories.evidence: Referenced as one of the most broadly and well-studied pathways influencing aging, with extensive prior research cited.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as a well-established biological aging theory explaining causal mechanisms of aging at the organismal level.

theories.name: Dietary Restriction Pathway in Aging

key_concepts.concept: Dietary Restriction as a Longevity Modulator
key_concepts.description: Dietary restriction without malnutrition extends lifespan and delays aging by modulating metabolic and stress response pathways, thereby influencing systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: Mentioned as a well-studied pathway influencing aging, supported by diverse organism studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as a generalizable and causal aging theory with broad organismal relevance.

results.title: Endogenous retroviruses in development and health.
Tissue-origin transcriptomic interactions as indicators of inflammatory aging and aging gene discovery.
A Transition From Interindividual Uniformity to Diversity in Appearance and Transcriptional Features at Midlife in Caenorhabditis elegans.
The biological roots of the sex-frailty paradox.

theories.name: Inflamm-aging theory

key_concepts.description: Inflamm-aging refers to the persistent, low-level inflammatory state that develops with age and contributes to the pathophysiology of multiple age-related diseases and conditions.

The rate and features of inflamm-aging differ between women and men, potentially explaining sex-specific aging trajectories and disease risks, such as the higher lifetime risk of Alzheimer's disease in women.

key_concepts.concept: Continuum between aging and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: A shared set of biological mechanisms underlies both aging and age-related diseases, progressing at different rates in men and women, leading to distinct aging phenotypes and the sex-frailty paradox.

theories.evidence: Citations to epidemiological observations of sex differences in longevity, frailty, and Alzheimer's disease risk; conceptual integration of inflamm-aging with sex differences in aging trajectories.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism (chronic inflammation) explaining differential aging processes at the organism level, with evolutionary and biological implications for sex differences in aging.

results.title: Combined Effects of Methoprene and Metformin on Reproduction, Longevity, and Stress Resistance in Anastrepha ludens (Diptera: Tephritidae): Implications for the Sterile Insect Technique.
Recombination Rate Variation in Social Insects: An Adaptive Perspective.
Mitophagy: A promising therapeutic target for neuroprotection during ageing and age-related diseases.

theories.name: Mitophagy theory of aging and neurodegeneration

key_concepts.concept: Mitophagy as a cellular quality control mechanism
key_concepts.description: Mitophagy is an evolutionarily conserved process that selectively removes damaged mitochondria, maintaining mitochondrial health and metabolic balance essential for cellular and neuronal function.

key_concepts.concept: Role of mitophagy in maintaining neuronal health and brain homeostasis
key_concepts.description: Mitophagy supports synapse formation, axonal development, dopamine release, and long-term depression, thereby contributing to neuronal survival and proper brain function during aging.

key_concepts.concept: Defective mitophagy as a causal driver of aging and neurodegeneration
key_concepts.description: Impaired mitophagy leads to accumulation of damaged mitochondria, causing cellular dysfunction that contributes to normal aging processes and age-related neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews molecular pathways underlying mitophagy, links mitochondrial impairment to synaptic dysfunction in aging and neurodegeneration, and discusses therapeutic strategies including exercise and pharmacological compounds that induce mitophagy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining aging and neurodegeneration at the organismal level through mitochondrial quality control; it addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases; and it discusses underlying molecular pathways and evolutionary conservation.

results.title: Not wisely but too well: aging as a cost of neuroendocrine activity.

theories.name: Neuroendocrine theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that aging is driven by the activity of neuroendocrine signaling systems rather than their decline. Instead of neuroendocrine decline causing aging, it is the ongoing activity of these systems that contributes causally to the aging process.

Reduction in pituitary hormone secretion, such as through hypophysectomy or genetic interventions, can delay aging and extend lifespan, indicating that neuroendocrine signals have a causal role in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Insulin/IGF-1 signaling system as a key modulator
key_concepts.description: Decreased activity of the insulin/insulin-like growth factor-1 signaling pathway substantially increases lifespan, highlighting this neuroendocrine axis as a central mechanism linking neuroendocrine activity to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Reproductive and stress response systems impact aging
key_concepts.description: Activation of the reproductive system and stress responses can shorten lifespan, suggesting that neuroendocrine regulation of these systems modulates aging outcomes.

key_concepts.concept: Caloric restriction reduces neuroendocrine activity and extends lifespan
key_concepts.description: Caloric restriction lowers the activity of several neuroendocrine systems and is associated with increased lifespan, supporting the idea that reduced neuroendocrine signaling contributes to slower aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of hypophysectomy experiments, genetic studies reducing pituitary hormone secretion, lifespan extension via insulin/IGF-1 signaling reduction, and caloric restriction effects on neuroendocrine activity and lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging at the organism level, explaining how neuroendocrine activity drives aging broadly rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

results.title: Effects of accelerated biological age on depressive symptoms in a causal reasoning framework.
A multidimensional immunological perspective on long COVID.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation associated with aging
key_concepts.description: Inflammaging refers to a persistent, systemic, low-level inflammatory state that develops with advancing age and contributes to the decline in physiological function and increased susceptibility to age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Predisposition to immune dysregulation and chronic conditions
key_concepts.description: This chronic inflammatory state may predispose individuals to immune system imbalances, such as those observed in Long COVID, by amplifying persistent immune activation and impairing regulatory pathways.

key_concepts.concept: Interaction with immune tolerance breakdown and autonomic dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Inflammaging interacts with loss of immune tolerance and autonomic nervous system dysfunction to sustain chronic inflammation and autoimmunity, contributing to disease pathophysiology.

theories.evidence: Citations to emerging biomarkers including inflammatory cytokines, autoantibodies, immune cell phenotypes, epigenetic modifications, and heart rate variability; conceptual framework linking inflammaging to Long COVID pathophysiology.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging-associated chronic inflammation contributes to systemic immune dysregulation and disease susceptibility, applicable beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: Effects of stress and mindfulness on epigenetics.

theories.name: Epigenetic modulation of aging by stress and mindfulness

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic changes as mediators of environmental impact on aging
key_concepts.description: Epigenetics involves heritable changes in gene expression without DNA sequence alteration, influenced by environmental factors such as chronic stress. These changes can affect genomic health and aging processes at an organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Chronic psychological stress induces deleterious epigenetic modifications
key_concepts.description: Modern chronic mental stress, unlike acute survival-related stress responses, leads to harmful epigenetic alterations that may accelerate aging or impair biological functions related to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) can reverse or mitigate stress-induced epigenetic changes
key_concepts.description: MBIs influence epigenetic markers across multiple biological systems including the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, serotonergic pathways, and neurological biomarkers, potentially promoting healthier aging trajectories.

theories.evidence: The abstract references multiple pathways and biomarkers affected by stress and mindfulness, implying citation of empirical studies or data on epigenetic changes related to stress and MBIs, though no specific experiments are detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how environmental factors (stress and mindfulness) causally influence aging via epigenetic mechanisms, addressing aging broadly at the organismal level. It proposes mechanisms (epigenetic modifications) linking psychosocial factors to biological aging, thus meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: View Micronuclei in the Extent of Evolution: New Insight Into an Old Issue.
Beyond Peto's paradox: expanding the study of cancer resistance across species.
Reproductive endocrinology and aging in human males: An evolutionary perspective.
Aging, Sleep and Sleepiness Self-Assessment, and the Underlying Drives for Sleep and Wake.

theories.name: Sleep-Wake Regulatory Drive Interaction Theory

key_concepts.concept: Competing drives for sleep and wake
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that the regulation of circadian rhythms, including the sleep-wake cycle and diurnal variations in alertness and sleepiness, is fundamentally governed by the interaction between opposing drives promoting sleep and wakefulness. The balance and competition between these drives shape sleep timing, continuity, and duration.

The theory emphasizes that aging affects the regulatory mechanisms underlying circadian rhythmicity and sleep, leading to age-specific problems such as altered sleep timing, reduced sleep continuity, and changes in sleep duration. These changes are considered fundamental to understanding biological aging effects on sleep.

key_concepts.concept: Implications for geriatric and sleep disorders
key_concepts.description: By understanding the interaction of sleep and wake drives and their alteration with age, this framework suggests potential targets for novel treatments addressing sleep-related problems in elderly populations, linking mechanistic understanding to clinical applications.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews findings from a mini-issue published in 2016 and subsequent research over six years, highlighting new insights and ongoing questions related to aging and sleep regulatory mechanisms. It synthesizes prior and recent studies rather than presenting new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how aging affects fundamental regulatory processes of sleep and circadian rhythms at the organism level, proposing mechanisms (interaction of competing drives) that underlie age-related changes in sleep. It addresses general aging-related changes rather than narrow phenomena, thus meeting the criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Neonatal multimorbidity and the phenotype of premature aging in preterm infants.

theories.name: Maturational Vulnerability Framework of Neonatal Multimorbidity and Early Aging

key_concepts.description: Preterm birth imparts a vulnerability in the maturation process of infants, making them more susceptible to multiple chronic health conditions (multimorbidity) early in life. This vulnerability reflects an underlying biological susceptibility that predisposes to early physiological decline.

The framework incorporates the idea that preterm infants may experience accelerated or premature cellular aging processes, which contribute to the development of multimorbidities and functional decline, analogous to aging-related frailty observed in older adults.

Health trajectories are shaped by early life exposures and conditions, including neonatal intensive care interventions and post-discharge environmental factors, which can amplify or mitigate the biological vulnerability and influence long-term health outcomes.

theories.evidence: The framework draws on life course epidemiology and Developmental Origins of Health and Disease (DOHaD) models, supported by epidemiological observations of increased multimorbidity in preterm infants and associations with frailty and poor functional outcomes. No direct experimental evidence is presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for early aging phenomena linked to preterm birth, integrating biological and environmental mechanisms at the organism level. It addresses systemic aging-related multimorbidity rather than narrow disease or organ-specific issues.

results.title: Adding intrinsically disordered proteins to biological ageing clocks.

theories.name: Intrinsically Disordered Protein (IDP) Aggregation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Intrinsically disordered proteins tend to transform into β-sheet-rich aggregated states over time. These aggregates accumulate particularly in non-dividing or slowly dividing cells, potentially contributing to cellular aging.

key_concepts.concept: IDP aggregation as a molecular clock
key_concepts.description: The aggregation state of IDPs may serve as a biomarker reflecting the biological age or health age of cells. This concept proposes a protein-based molecular aging clock, termed the IDP clock, which could provide insight into cellular aging processes.

theories.evidence: Summary of established and emerging molecular clocks; hypothesis about IDP aggregation state correlating with cellular aging; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (IDP aggregation) underlying biological aging at the cellular and organismal level. It attempts to explain how aging occurs via protein aggregation dynamics and suggests a conceptual framework for measuring aging.

results.title: Targeting the microbiota-mitochondria crosstalk in neurodegeneration with senotherapeutics.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction-associated senescence (MiDAS) theory

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a driver of cellular senescence
