key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction leads to a specific form of cellular senescence characterized by irreversible cell cycle arrest and proinflammatory secretory phenotype, contributing to tissue dysfunction and aging.

Due to the evolutionary relationship between mitochondria and bacteria, dysbiosis in the gut microbiota can disrupt mitochondrial function, promoting MiDAS and thereby linking microbial imbalance to systemic aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) and senescent cell anti-apoptotic pathways (SCAPs)
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells resist apoptosis through SCAPs and secrete proinflammatory factors (SASP), creating a cytotoxic microenvironment that exacerbates inflammation, oxidative stress, and neurodegeneration.
A vicious cycle involving dysbiosis, mitochondrial dysfunction, inflammation, and oxidative stress perpetuates cellular senescence and neurodegeneration, suggesting a systemic aging mechanism.

theories.evidence: Accumulating evidence from early-phase research linking microbiota dysbiosis to mitochondrial dysfunction and senescence; references to known mechanisms of SCAPs and SASP; conceptual framework connecting these processes to neurodegeneration.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking mitochondrial dysfunction and cellular senescence to systemic aging processes, with evolutionary rationale and broad implications beyond a single disease.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as an onco-suppressive mechanism
key_concepts.description: Cells enter irreversible cell cycle arrest upon damage or stress to prevent cancer, but accumulation of senescent cells contributes to aging phenotypes.
Senescent cells secrete proinflammatory cytokines and factors that alter tissue microenvironment, promoting chronic inflammation and tissue dysfunction.
Mechanisms that allow senescent cells to resist programmed cell death, leading to their persistence and accumulation during aging.

theories.evidence: Established literature on senescence mechanisms and their role in aging; references to senotherapeutics targeting SCAPs and SASP.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as a well-established general aging theory explaining causal mechanisms of aging at the cellular and organismal level.

results.title: Telomere Dynamics in Human Health and Disease.

theories.name: Telomere attrition theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Telomere shortening leads to a G1/S cell-cycle arrest mediated by a functional TP53 response, inducing replicative senescence, which is proposed as a fundamental mechanism underpinning aging in long-lived species.

key_concepts.concept: Role of TP53 pathway in aging and cancer
key_concepts.description: When the TP53 pathway is abrogated, cells bypass senescence despite telomere erosion, leading to genomic instability, clonal evolution, and malignant progression, linking telomere dynamics to both aging and cancer.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length heterogeneity and disease risk
key_concepts.description: Variation in telomere length established at birth influences individual susceptibility to a broad range of diseases, including cardiovascular disease and cancer, suggesting telomere dynamics contribute to systemic aging and disease risk.

theories.evidence: References to established knowledge about telomere function, TP53 response, replicative senescence, and disease associations; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how telomere shortening drives cellular senescence and organismal aging, linking molecular events to systemic aging and disease risk.

results.title: Physiological aspects of hormesis.

theories.name: Hormesis as a general adaptive aging mechanism

key_concepts.description: Hormesis describes a biphasic dose-response where moderate, intermittent stress induces beneficial adaptive responses, while excessive or chronic stress causes damage and pathology. This inverted U-shaped curve explains how stress can be both beneficial and harmful depending on intensity and duration.

Hormetic interventions act through common molecular pathways involving key transcription factors such as NF-κB, CREB, and Nrf2. Activation of these factors leads to increased expression of neuroprotective genes like BDNF and heat shock proteins, which enhance cellular resilience and neuroplasticity.

key_concepts.concept: Hormesis linking homeostasis, neuroplasticity, and resilience
key_concepts.description: Hormesis bridges traditional homeostasis concepts with modern understanding of neuroplasticity and resilience, providing a mechanistic framework for how organisms adapt to stress at cellular and systemic levels, potentially influencing aging and age-related cognitive decline.

theories.evidence: Citations of hormetic interventions such as intermittent fasting, physical exercise, and environmental enrichment; molecular data on transcription factors and neuroprotective gene expression; conceptual framework linking stress dose-response to biological outcomes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses hormesis as a fundamental adaptive mechanism that can explain how moderate stress influences aging-related processes like neuroplasticity and cognitive function. It proposes underlying molecular mechanisms and connects these to organism-level outcomes, thus meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope criteria.

results.title: Epigenetics of Ribosomal RNA Genes.

theories.name: rRNA gene epigenetic regulation and genome stability theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic control of rRNA gene transcription
key_concepts.description: rRNA genes exist in multiple copies and are tightly regulated by epigenetic mechanisms to control their transcriptional activity, ensuring appropriate ribosome production according to cellular protein synthesis needs.

key_concepts.concept: Non-canonical regulatory roles of rRNA genes
key_concepts.description: Beyond producing rRNA, some rRNA gene copies form complexes with other nuclear genes, influencing their regulation, suggesting a broader role in nuclear gene expression control.

key_concepts.concept: rRNA gene copy number and genome stability
key_concepts.description: The number of rRNA gene copies contributes to maintaining genome stability; a reduced copy number may destabilize the genome, implicating rRNA genes in aging and chronic disease mechanisms.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses existing experimental evidence linking rRNA gene functions to genome stability and disease, citing studies on epigenetic regulation and gene complexes, but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain aging mechanisms at a general organismal level by proposing that epigenetic regulation and genome stability mediated by rRNA genes contribute causally to aging processes. It is not limited to a single organ or disease and proposes underlying mechanisms, thus meeting the criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: DNA methylation in mammalian development and disease.

theories.name: Epigenetic aging theory (DNA methylation-based aging)

key_concepts.concept: DNA methylation as an epigenetic modification
key_concepts.description: DNA methylation is a chemical modification of DNA that can regulate gene expression without altering the DNA sequence. It is evolutionarily ancient and forms part of robust epigenetic codes that influence genomic functions.

key_concepts.concept: Dynamic DNA methylation landscapes over lifespan
key_concepts.description: Distinct patterns of DNA methylation emerge and change throughout mammalian development and aging, reflecting shifts in cell physiology and developmental potential.

key_concepts.concept: Role of DNA methylation in cellular senescence and disease
key_concepts.description: Altered DNA methylation patterns are observed during cellular senescence and the transition to cancer, suggesting a mechanistic link between epigenetic changes and aging-related phenotypes and pathologies.

theories.evidence: Summary of recent mechanistic discoveries, references to advances in sequencing technologies (single-cell, long-read), and integration of findings across development, aging, senescence, and cancer fields.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses DNA methylation as a fundamental epigenetic mechanism influencing aging at the organismal level, addressing causal mechanisms linking epigenetic changes to aging and senescence. It is generalizable beyond specific diseases or organs and proposes underlying principles of aging related to epigenetic regulation.

results.title: Significance of mild thrombocytopenia in maintenance hemodialysis patients; a retrospective cohort study.

theories.name: Platelet activation-induced biological aging of hematopoiesis theory

key_concepts.description: Platelets become activated during the hemodialysis process, which leads to thrombocytopenia and altered platelet dynamics.

Activated platelets induce biological aging of hematopoiesis, potentially occurring extramedullary in the lung, where platelets deliver inflammatory cytokines and reactive oxygen species that affect hematopoietic cells.

key_concepts.concept: Vicious cycle of platelet aging and cardiovascular events
key_concepts.description: The process results in production of qualitatively altered, hyper-reactive platelets, which may perpetuate a cycle of thrombocytopenia and cardiovascular events in hemodialysis patients.

theories.evidence: Retrospective cohort study data showing platelet decrease independently associated with cardiovascular events; correlations with antiplatelet therapy disuse and macrocytosis; hypothesis based on recent knowledge of platelet dynamics and inflammatory mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism linking platelet activation and biological aging of hematopoiesis to systemic aging-related cardiovascular events in hemodialysis patients, addressing an organism-level process beyond a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: [Epigenetics, principles and examples of applications].
Adult telomere length is positively correlated with survival and lifetime reproductive success in a wild passerine.

theories.name: Telomere length as a biomarker and causal factor in aging and fitness

key_concepts.concept: Telomeres as biomarkers of physiological state and senescence
key_concepts.description: Telomeres are repetitive DNA sequences at chromosome ends that protect genomic integrity. Their length is considered indicative of cellular aging and organismal physiological condition, potentially reflecting cumulative damage or biological age.

key_concepts.concept: Correlation between telomere length and individual fitness
key_concepts.description: Longer telomeres are associated with higher short-term survival and greater lifetime reproductive success, suggesting that telomere length may influence or reflect organismal vitality and fitness outcomes.

Changes in telomere length over time (telomere attrition) are hypothesized to relate to aging processes, but in this study, the rate of telomere length change did not correlate with lifespan or reproductive success, indicating complexity in how telomere dynamics relate to aging.

theories.evidence: Longitudinal data from 16 years and 1225 individual house sparrows measuring telomere length, survival, lifespan, and reproductive output; statistical correlations between telomere length and fitness measures.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general biological aging mechanism (telomere attrition) with causal implications for organismal aging and fitness, beyond a narrow disease or organ-specific context. The study tests the relationship between telomere length and aging-related outcomes, providing mechanistic insight.

results.title: The Epigenetic Landscape: From Molecular Mechanisms to Biological Aging.

theories.name: Epigenetic Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that heritable changes in gene expression, such as DNA methylation, histone modifications, and chromatin remodeling, influence cellular function and contribute causally to the aging process at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic clocks as biomarkers of biological age
key_concepts.description: Epigenetic clocks use DNA methylation patterns to estimate biological age and predict health span, reflecting underlying aging mechanisms rather than merely correlating with chronological age.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic dysregulation impacts genomic stability and cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: Alterations in epigenetic regulation can lead to genomic instability and promote cellular senescence, which are key mechanisms driving systemic aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Reversibility of epigenetic changes as therapeutic target
key_concepts.description: Because epigenetic modifications are reversible, interventions such as lifestyle changes or pharmacological treatments may mitigate age acceleration and improve health span, suggesting a causal role of epigenetics in aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews multiple generations of epigenetic clocks (Horvath's clock, DNAGrimAge, DunedinPACE) and discusses their development and application; it also cites associations of epigenetic dysregulation with cancer, genetic disorders, neurodegenerative diseases, and cellular senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory attempts to explain aging as a fundamental biological process via epigenetic mechanisms; it proposes causal mechanisms (epigenetic changes driving aging and senescence); it addresses aging broadly at the organismal level; and it links molecular mechanisms to systemic aging and age-related diseases.

results.title: Neurotrophin regulation of energy homeostasis in the central nervous system.

theories.name: Neurotrophin-mediated oxidative homeostasis theory of neuronal aging

key_concepts.concept: Oxidant homeostasis failure as cause of neuronal aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that neuronal cell death and shrinkage in aging CNS result from an inability to maintain oxidant homeostasis amid increased reactive oxygen species, decreased antioxidants, and impaired energy metabolism.

key_concepts.concept: Neurotrophins as cell-sparing agents via antioxidant enzyme regulation
key_concepts.description: Neurotrophins such as nerve growth factor (NGF) and brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) protect neurons by stimulating synthesis of antioxidant enzymes (e.g., catalase, glutathione peroxidase) and supporting redox cycles, thereby mitigating oxidative damage.

key_concepts.concept: Link between neurotrophin signaling and energy metabolism in aging neurons
key_concepts.description: NGF enhances recovery from NAD+ losses caused by oxidative stress, suggesting neurotrophins support energy metabolism pathways critical for neuronal survival during aging.

theories.evidence: Behavioral improvements in aged rats treated with NGF, stimulation of cholinergic activity, protection of PC12 cells from H2O2 injury by NGF via upregulation of antioxidant enzymes, and biochemical pathways involving glutathione redox cycle enzymes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining neuronal aging at the organism level through oxidative stress and neurotrophin regulation, linking molecular pathways to systemic aging phenomena.

results.title: Sexual dimorphism, aging and immunity.
Resistance to glycation in the zebra finch: Mass spectrometry-based analysis and its perspectives for evolutionary studies of aging.
Cancer, type 2 diabetes, and ageing: news from flies and worms.

theories.name: Insulin/IGF Signalling (IIS) and Target of Rapamycin (TOR) Signalling Pathways in Aging

key_concepts.description: The IIS and TOR pathways regulate cellular and organismal growth in response to nutrient availability, linking metabolism and growth control to aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary conservation of growth and aging pathways
key_concepts.description: These signalling pathways are conserved across species, from model organisms like Drosophila and C. elegans to humans, suggesting a fundamental role in aging and disease.

key_concepts.concept: Connection between growth control and aging
key_concepts.description: Alterations in IIS and TOR signalling affect not only growth and cancer development but also influence lifespan and aging, indicating these pathways as central mechanisms in aging biology.

theories.evidence: Genetic studies in model organisms (Drosophila and C. elegans) dissecting tumour suppressor genes (PTEN, TSC1/2) and nutrient regulation pathways; evolutionary conservation highlighted; references to cancer and aging relevance.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general, evolutionarily conserved mechanism explaining how nutrient sensing and growth signalling pathways causally influence aging at the organismal level; it is not limited to specific organs or diseases but addresses fundamental aging processes.

results.title: Photoperiod and metabolic health: evidence, mechanism, and implications.

theories.name: Circadian disruption theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Circadian rhythms as programmed biological processes
key_concepts.description: Circadian rhythms are evolutionarily programmed biological rhythms primarily entrained by the light cycle, regulating various physiological processes.

key_concepts.concept: Photoperiod length as a disruptor of circadian rhythms
key_concepts.description: Extended exposure to light (long photoperiod), especially due to artificial light at night, disrupts circadian rhythms, leading to physiological dysregulation.

key_concepts.concept: Circadian disruption leading to premature aging and metabolic disorders
key_concepts.description: Disruption of circadian rhythms by long photoperiod exposure is linked to chronic health conditions including adiposity, altered hormonal signaling, metabolic dysfunction, premature aging, and poor psychological health.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing evidence linking long photoperiod exposure to circadian disruption and its downstream effects on metabolic health and aging, citing epidemiological and experimental studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (circadian rhythm disruption by photoperiod changes) explaining how aging and metabolic decline occur at an organismal level; it addresses aging broadly and discusses underlying biological mechanisms.

results.title: Evolutionary trade-offs between growth and survival: The delicate balance between reproductive success and longevity in bacteria.

theories.name: Evolutionary trade-off theory between reproduction and survival

key_concepts.description: Cells allocate limited resources between growth/reproduction and protection/survival to maximize evolutionary fitness. This trade-off represents a fundamental decision-making process balancing immediate reproductive success against long-term survival.

Sigma factors control transcriptional programs that determine whether cells prioritize growth or survival. Their activity is regulated by complex inputs integrating environmental signals to optimize cellular responses.
Biofilm development is associated with reduced growth rates but enhanced long-term survival, illustrating a developmental program that shifts cellular priorities from reproduction to persistence.

key_concepts.concept: Role of nucleotide second messengers and energy status
key_concepts.description: Molecules like nucleotide second messengers and cellular energy pools (ATP/ADP ratios) critically influence cell fate decisions between growth and survival modes.

key_concepts.concept: Regulatory small RNAs in decision making
key_concepts.description: Small RNAs contribute to the regulatory networks that mediate the balance between reproduction and persistence, adding layers of post-transcriptional control.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews recent advances and discusses regulatory mechanisms and molecular players involved in the trade-off, citing recent studies in bacterial systems. No new experimental data are presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable evolutionary theory explaining why aging-related trade-offs occur at the organismal level (here bacterial cells), provides causal mechanisms (resource allocation, regulatory control), and addresses broad aging-relevant processes (growth vs survival balance). Although focused on bacteria, the evolutionary trade-off concept is broadly applicable to aging.

results.title: Age-related micro-environmental changes as drivers of clonal hematopoiesis.

theories.name: Clonal Hematopoiesis as an Aging-Related Phenomenon Influenced by Microenvironmental Changes

key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with a reduction in the diversity of hematopoietic stem cells, which is a complex phenotype influenced by both genetic (germline) and environmental factors. This decline in diversity is linked to the emergence of clonal hematopoiesis.

With aging, there is an accumulation of fatty bone marrow, which alters the bone marrow microenvironment. FBM can influence clonal expansion of preleukemic mutations, particularly DNMT3A mutations, through inflammatory mediators such as IL-6.

key_concepts.concept: Sex Hormone Decline and Its Impact on HSC Function and Microenvironment
key_concepts.description: Age-related decline in sex hormones directly affects hematopoietic stem cell function and reshapes the bone marrow niche by promoting FBM accumulation. This hormonal change is linked to the prevalence of certain mutations in clonal hematopoiesis, especially in women with early menopause.

theories.evidence: The paper cites associations such as the higher prevalence of DNMT3A mutations in women, especially those with early menopause, and the role of IL-6 mediation in FBM-driven clonal expansion. It discusses recent findings on hormone decline and FBM accumulation affecting HSC dynamics.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses mechanisms (microenvironmental changes, hormone decline) that contribute to clonal hematopoiesis, which is an aging-related systemic phenomenon affecting blood cell populations. It attempts to explain why aging leads to reduced HSC diversity and clonal expansions, thus addressing causal mechanisms at an organismal level. Although focused on hematopoiesis, it connects these processes to general aging phenomena and raises broader questions about aging mechanisms.

results.title: A Hypothesis: Fructosamine-3-Kinase-Related-Protein (FN3KRP) Catalyzes Deglycation of Maillard Intermediates Directly Downstream from Fructosamines.
The Untapped Potential of Comparative Biology in Aging Research: Insights From the Extraordinary-Long-Lived Naked Mole-Rat.
MFN2 overexpression in skeletal muscles of young and old mice causes a mild hypertrophy without altering mitochondrial respiration and H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> emission.
The role of different physical exercises as an anti-aging factor in different stem cells.
Telomeres, telomerase, and the cell cycle.

theories.name: Telomere Shortening and Cellular Senescence Theory

key_concepts.description: Telomeres are specialized structures that protect chromosome ends from degradation and fusion. They are replicated by telomerase, a specialized polymerase that synthesizes one strand of the telomere, while conventional DNA polymerases synthesize the complementary strand.

key_concepts.concept: Telomerase activity regulation during cell cycle
key_concepts.description: Telomerase activity and RNA levels fluctuate as cells enter and exit the cell cycle, indicating a regulated mechanism of telomere maintenance linked to cell proliferation.

Gradual shortening of telomeres in the absence of telomerase does not immediately affect cell cycling; however, when telomeres become critically short, they are hypothesized to induce cellular senescence by triggering DNA damage checkpoints.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known biological processes of telomere replication and telomerase activity, as well as the hypothesis linking critically short telomeres to senescence and DNA damage checkpoint activation. No new experimental data is presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: This theory meets the criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism explaining how telomere shortening leads to cellular senescence, which is a fundamental aging process at the organismal level. It addresses a generalizable mechanism (telomere dynamics) linked to aging, not limited to a specific disease or organ.

results.title: Ageing and the gut-brain axis: lessons from the Drosophila model.
Phylogeny, regeneration, ageing and cancer: role of microenvironment and possibility of its therapeutic manipulation.

theories.name: Evolutionary trade-off theory of regeneration and cancer risk

key_concepts.concept: Inverse correlation between regeneration capacity and longevity
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that as organisms evolved greater complexity and longer lifespans, their capacity for tissue regeneration diminished. This reduction in regenerative ability is hypothesized to be an evolutionarily selected 'switch-off' mechanism in complex, long-living animals such as mammals and birds.

key_concepts.concept: Trade-off between regeneration and cancer incidence
key_concepts.description: The diminished regeneration capacity is linked to an increased occurrence of malignant tumors, suggesting a trade-off where reduced regeneration may protect against cancer or reflect evolutionary constraints balancing tissue maintenance and cancer risk.

key_concepts.concept: Role of microenvironment in aging, regeneration, and cancer
key_concepts.description: The tissue microenvironment is implicated as a key factor influencing healing, inflammation, and cancer development. Manipulating the microenvironment therapeutically is proposed as a novel approach to cancer treatment, linking aging processes to cancer risk via environmental context.

theories.evidence: Summary of comparative data across phylogeny from invertebrates to mammals; correlation observations between regeneration capacity, longevity, and cancer incidence; discussion of medical advances revealing cancer risk with increased longevity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable evolutionary mechanism explaining aging-related decline in regeneration and increased cancer risk, addressing causal explanations and organism-level processes; links aging to cancer risk via evolutionary and microenvironmental mechanisms.

results.title: Transcription-independent functions of p53 in DNA repair pathway selection.

theories.name: p53-mediated genome stability theory of aging

key_concepts.description: p53 has roles beyond its transcriptional activity, particularly in selecting DNA damage repair pathways after PARylation, which influences genome stability and tumor suppression.

key_concepts.concept: p53 and PI(4,5)P2 complex formation at DNA damage sites
key_concepts.description: p53 forms complexes with phosphoinositide lipids such as PI(4,5)P2 at DNA damage sites, which is critical for recruiting repair factors like ATR and directing the choice of DNA repair pathways.

key_concepts.concept: Correlation between p53 sequence homology, genome mutation rates, and lifespan
key_concepts.description: Across mammalian species, there is a strong correlation linking p53 sequence conservation with genome mutation rates and species lifespan, suggesting a role for p53 in longevity through genome maintenance.

theories.evidence: Experimental findings on p53 PARylation and complex formation with PI(4,5)P2 at DNA damage sites; observed correlations between p53 sequence homology, mutation rates, and lifespan across mammals.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism (p53's role in DNA repair pathway choice) that affects genome stability, tumor suppression, and longevity, thus addressing fundamental aging processes at the organism level with causal explanations.

results.title: Chronic age-related diseases share risk factors: do they share pathophysiological mechanisms and why does that matter?

theories.name: Inflammation and altered insulin/IGF signaling as mechanisms linking risk factors to aging and age-related diseases

key_concepts.description: Chronic, mild inflammation occurring throughout the body is proposed as a key mechanism linking exposures such as obesity and air pollution to multiple age-related diseases. This inflammation may contribute to the aging process and disease pathophysiology by promoting tissue damage and dysregulated immune responses.

key_concepts.concept: Alterations in insulin/insulin-like growth factor (IGF) signaling
key_concepts.description: Changes in insulin and IGF signaling pathways, which regulate metabolism, growth, and cell cycle control, are implicated as mechanisms connecting environmental and lifestyle risk factors to aging and longevity. Dysregulation of these pathways may accelerate aging and increase susceptibility to chronic diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Shared pathophysiological mechanisms underlying multiple chronic age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis that common molecular and cellular mechanisms, such as inflammation and altered signaling pathways, underlie diverse chronic diseases that increase with age, suggesting a unifying biological basis for aging-related morbidity.

theories.evidence: References to animal and some human studies associating inflammation and insulin/IGF signaling alterations with longevity and aging; epidemiological observations linking obesity and air pollution exposures to systemic inflammation and disease risk.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper proposes mechanisms (inflammation, insulin/IGF signaling) that may causally link environmental/lifestyle risk factors to aging and age-related diseases at a general organismal level. It attempts to explain why aging and multiple chronic diseases occur by shared biological pathways, thus meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: A uniformisation-driven algorithm for inference-related estimation of a phase-type ageing model.

Proteostasis and autophagy disruption by the aging-related VGVAPG hexapeptide - preliminary insights into a potential novel elastin-induced neurodegeneration pathway in an in vitro human cellular neuron model.
Botryllus humilis: A promising new ascidian model for aging, stem cell dynamics, and whole-body regeneration.
Cost of mating in Drosophila melanogaster females is mediated by male accessory gland products.
Studying Cellular Senescence Using the Model Organism Drosophila melanogaster.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is characterized by a permanent cessation of cell division, which prevents damaged or stressed cells from proliferating. This arrest contributes to tissue dysfunction and organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Contribution to Aging and Age-Related Diseases
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate with age and secrete pro-inflammatory factors that promote chronic inflammation and tissue degradation, thereby driving the progression of aging and related pathologies.

Drosophila melanogaster serves as a valuable model due to its genetic tractability, short lifespan, and conservation of key aging pathways, enabling in vivo study of cellular senescence mechanisms relevant to systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Overview of assays for detecting senescent cells in Drosophila tissues; references to conservation of age-related genes and pathways; emphasis on biomarker selection and challenges in organismal-level detection.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental biological aging process (cellular senescence) with causal implications for organismal aging, discusses mechanisms, and is generalizable beyond specific tissues or diseases.

results.title: Inoculation of lymphocytes from young mice prevents progression of age-related hearing loss in a senescence-associated mouse model.

theories.name: Immunosenescence as a causal driver of systemic aging and age-related hearing loss

key_concepts.description: The aging-related dysfunction of the immune system, characterized by reduced immune function and increased chronic inflammation and oxidative stress, which contributes to systemic aging and tissue damage.
The decline in immune system homeostasis leads to chronic inflammation and oxidative stress, which are proposed mechanisms driving aging processes in multiple organs, including the cochlea.

key_concepts.concept: Immune rejuvenation to prevent aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Rejuvenating the immune system by inoculating lymphocytes from young mice can inhibit progression of age-related hearing loss and prevent neuronal degeneration, suggesting a causal role of immune aging in systemic and organ-specific aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing that inoculation of young lymphocytes in a mouse model prevents progression of ARHL, maintains auditory thresholds, and avoids spinal ganglion degeneration and cellular immune aging markers.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (immune system aging) underlying systemic aging and a specific age-related phenotype (hearing loss), with experimental intervention testing the theory.

results.title: Shuttle craft Gene Affects Lifespan of Drosophila melanogaster by Controlling Early Development and Modifying Aging Program.

theories.name: Genetic regulation of aging via transcription factor control

key_concepts.concept: Role of stc gene in lifespan regulation
key_concepts.description: The stc gene encodes a transcription factor homologous to human NF-X1, which regulates neuronal development and other processes, and influences lifespan by controlling gene expression throughout life.

key_concepts.concept: Cell type and sex-dependent effects on lifespan
key_concepts.description: Knockdown of stc in embryonic and nerve cells leads to lifespan changes that vary depending on the specific cell type targeted and the sex of the organism, indicating complex regulation.

key_concepts.concept: Modification of cell death programs and phenoptosis
key_concepts.description: Reduction of stc expression in neurons can mitigate glutamate excitotoxicity, thereby altering cell death pathways and preventing premature death due to phenoptosis, linking genetic regulation to aging-related cell survival.

theories.evidence: Experimental knockdown of stc gene in Drosophila embryonic and nerve cells with observed effects on lifespan and neuronal glutamate toxicity
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a genetic regulatory mechanism affecting lifespan at the organismal level, offers causal explanations involving transcriptional control and cell death pathways, and addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow phenotype.

results.title: Particulate matter 2.5 accelerates aging: Exploring cellular senescence and age-related diseases.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the accumulation of senescent cells, which have ceased dividing and secrete pro-inflammatory factors, contributes causally to the decline in tissue and organ function observed in aging organisms.

Key mechanisms leading to cellular senescence include genomic instability, telomere attrition, epigenetic alterations, loss of proteostasis, and mitochondrial dysfunction. These cellular damages accumulate over time and promote systemic aging.

Exposure to environmental pollutants such as particulate matter 2.5 (PM2.5) acts as an exogenous factor accelerating the onset and progression of cellular senescence and thus systemic aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses known mechanisms of PM2.5-induced cellular senescence and links them to age-related diseases, citing established cellular damage pathways; no new experimental data is presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (cellular senescence) explaining how environmental factors accelerate fundamental aging processes affecting the organism broadly.

results.title: Game changer: Navigating between challenges and hopes in geropharmacology.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: The theory identifies twelve fundamental biological processes that characterize aging, such as genomic instability, telomere attrition, epigenetic alterations, and cellular senescence. These hallmarks provide a framework to understand the underlying mechanisms driving aging at the organismal level.

Aging is not a uniform process but exhibits variability among individuals and tissues, reflecting its multifaceted and dynamic nature. This concept emphasizes that aging mechanisms can differ in intensity and manifestation, influencing the effectiveness of interventions.

theories.evidence: References to extensive research establishing the twelve hallmarks; clinical studies demonstrating interventions targeting these hallmarks.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain aging as a fundamental biological process with underlying mechanisms applicable broadly across organisms; provides causal explanations through defined hallmarks.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Accumulation of senescent cells contributes causally to aging by impairing tissue function and promoting inflammation. The theory posits that senescent cells drive systemic aging and age-related diseases.
Targeting and removing senescent cells with senolytic drugs can mitigate aging effects and delay disease onset, supporting the causal role of senescence in aging.

theories.evidence: Clinical trials with senolytics showing heterogeneity in response linked to senescent cell burden; references to clinical studies testing senolytic efficacy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism for aging at the organismal level and is linked to general aging processes beyond specific diseases.

theories.name: Metabolic and Nutrient-Sensing Pathways Theory

key_concepts.description: Decline in NAD+ levels with age impairs cellular metabolism and repair processes; supplementation aims to restore metabolic homeostasis and delay aging.
Drugs like rapamycin and metformin modulate nutrient-sensing pathways (e.g., mTOR, AMPK) that regulate aging and longevity, providing mechanistic targets to slow aging.

theories.evidence: Clinical studies demonstrating potential of these interventions to mitigate aging and delay age-related diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses fundamental metabolic mechanisms causally linked to aging and organismal health span.

results.title: Role of mitochondrial potassium channels in ageing.
Mammals and Mutations, Life Span, Cancer Risk.

theories.name: Somatic Mutation Rate Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the rate at which somatic mutations accumulate in cells over time is a fundamental determinant of organismal life span. Higher mutation rates per year correlate with shorter life spans across mammalian species, suggesting a causal role of mutation burden in aging.
This concept suggests that the accumulation of DNA damage and mutations in somatic cells impairs cellular function and tissue homeostasis, thereby driving the aging process at the organismal level.

theories.evidence: Findings from the Wellcome Sanger Institute showing strong correlation between somatic mutation rates and life span across 16 mammalian species.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why aging occurs, applicable across species, addressing fundamental biological aging processes rather than specific diseases or organs.

theories.name: Peto's Paradox and Cancer Risk Theory

key_concepts.concept: Cancer risk independence from body mass and life span
key_concepts.description: Despite larger animals having more cells and longer life spans, their cancer mortality risk does not increase proportionally, indicating evolved mechanisms to suppress cancer risk that are independent of size and longevity.

Cancer mortality risk correlates with dietary factors rather than body mass or life span, suggesting environmental and lifestyle influences modulate cancer risk alongside intrinsic biological mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Study of 191 mammalian species led by the University of Montpellier confirming cancer mortality risk association with diet but independence from body mass and life span, supporting Peto's paradox.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it addresses an evolutionary and biological mechanism related to aging (cancer risk as an aging-related mortality factor) and discusses general principles across species, though focused on cancer rather than aging per se.

results.title: Harnessing the fundamental roles of vitamins: the potent anti-oxidants in longevity.

theories.name: Hormesis theory of aging mediated by vitamins

key_concepts.description: Certain vitamins induce mild cellular stress that activates adaptive stress responses, repair mechanisms, and homeostatic processes, which collectively promote cellular resilience and delay aging.

key_concepts.concept: Vitamins as modulators of aging mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Vitamins influence fundamental aging hallmarks such as telomere attrition, genomic instability, mitochondrial dysfunction, and nutrient sensing pathways, thereby impacting systemic aging and organ function.
By mitigating oxidative stress and supporting cellular repair, vitamins help prevent frailty and promote longevity, suggesting a causal role in modulating aging processes.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews recent advances and an increasing body of evidence linking vitamins’ hormetic effects to activation of cellular stress responses and repair mechanisms; it also discusses clinical implications of addressing vitamin deficiencies in elderly populations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how vitamins influence fundamental aging processes at the organism level, linking cellular stress responses to systemic aging and longevity.

results.title: Upregulated expression of lamin B receptor increases cell proliferation and suppresses genomic instability: implications for cellular immortalization.
SuperAgers and centenarians, dynamics of healthy ageing with cognitive resilience.

theories.name: Damage accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Accumulation of DNA damage over time leads to cellular dysfunction and contributes to aging.
Reactive oxygen species cause damage to biomolecules, promoting aging and age-related diseases.
Decline in mitochondrial function reduces cellular energy production and increases damage, accelerating aging.
Metabolic processes generate damaging byproducts that accumulate and impair cellular function.

theories.evidence: The abstract lists these factors as key aspects of aging to be discussed, implying a review of existing data and theories.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it explains aging through fundamental damage accumulation mechanisms applicable broadly across organisms.

theories.name: Cellular senescence as a causal driver of systemic aging

key_concepts.description: Cells enter a state of permanent growth arrest in response to damage or stress, contributing to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging through secretion of pro-inflammatory factors.
Age-related decline in immune system function that reduces the ability to clear senescent cells and pathogens, exacerbating aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: The abstract mentions cellular senescence and immunosenescence as aspects of aging discussed, likely referencing existing literature rather than new experiments.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general causal mechanism of aging at the organism level, proposing cellular senescence and immune decline as drivers of systemic aging.

theories.name: Genetic and lifestyle factors in healthy aging

key_concepts.description: Inheritance of favorable genetic traits can promote longevity and resistance to age-related decline.
Regular physical activity, balanced diet, and avoidance of harmful habits contribute to healthier aging and extended lifespan.
Access to education, healthcare, and positive environmental conditions synergize with genetics and lifestyle to enhance healthy aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references these factors as important contributors to longevity and cognitive resilience, likely based on epidemiological and observational studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it addresses broad aging influences but focuses more on modifiers of aging rather than fundamental causal mechanisms.

results.title: [Research progress on the epidemiological distribution and influencing factors of autosomal mosaic chromosomal alteration].

theories.name: Genomic instability theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Somatic mosaicism as an aging phenotype
key_concepts.description: Somatic mosaicism refers to the accumulation of somatic mutations in cells during an organism’s lifetime. Mosaic chromosomal alterations (mCA) represent a form of genomic instability that increases with age and is considered a hallmark or phenotype of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Impact of genomic instability on aging
key_concepts.description: Genomic instability, including mCA, compromises genome integrity, which is proposed to contribute causally to the biological mechanisms underlying aging and age-related diseases.

Understanding the prevalence and factors influencing autosomal mCA in peripheral blood can shed light on the biological basis of aging and help identify primary prevention strategies for age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Summary and synthesis of previous large-scale population-based epidemiological studies on autosomal mosaic chromosomal alterations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses genomic instability as a fundamental aging process, proposing mCA as a causal mechanism contributing to aging phenotypes. It addresses aging broadly at the organism level through genome integrity and is not limited to a specific disease or organ. Thus, it meets the criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: NSAIDs use history: impact on the genome-wide DNA methylation profile and possible mechanisms of action.
Age-related flexibility of energetic metabolism in the honey bee Apis mellifera.
Unveiling the Relation between Cellular Ageing, Epigenetics and Cancer.

theories.name: Epigenetic Drift Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: This concept involves heritable yet reversible modifications of the genome, such as DNA methylation changes, histone modification shifts, and chromatin remodeling, which accumulate with age and disrupt normal gene regulatory networks.
The accumulation of senescent cells is driven by epigenetic changes that foster a pro-inflammatory environment, contributing to tissue dysfunction and promoting tumorigenesis.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic landscape similarity between aged and cancerous tissues
key_concepts.description: The epigenetic state of aged tissues resembles that of cancerous tissues, suggesting that aging creates a permissive environment for malignant transformation.

theories.evidence: The abstract references fundamental principles of cellular aging, epigenetic changes, and their roles in tumorigenesis, citing the progressive decline in physiological functions with age, epigenetic drift, and the accumulation of senescent cells as mechanisms linking aging and cancer.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how epigenetic changes contribute to systemic aging and increased cancer risk, addressing fundamental aging processes beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: Running on empty: Exploring stem cell exhaustion in geriatric musculoskeletal disease.

theories.name: Stem Cell Exhaustion Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The progressive decline in the number and function of stem cells with age, leading to impaired tissue regeneration and maintenance. This exhaustion contributes to the deterioration of musculoskeletal tissues such as bone and muscle.

Age-associated chronic inflammation and oxidative stress create a damaging environment that induces progenitor cell senescence and shifts differentiation towards adipogenic lineages, reducing tissue quality and mass.

key_concepts.concept: Progenitor cell senescence and adipogenic differentiation
key_concepts.description: Senescence of progenitor cells limits their proliferative capacity, while increased adipogenic differentiation replaces functional muscle and bone cells with fat cells, contributing to musculoskeletal decline.

theories.evidence: Review of recent literature from PubMed/Medline, Science Direct, and Google Scholar databases summarizing biological processes linking stem cell exhaustion to musculoskeletal aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why biological aging occurs at the organism level, focusing on stem cell decline as a fundamental aging process affecting musculoskeletal system and potentially systemic aging.

results.title: Comparing anti-aging hallmark activities of Metformin and Nano-PSO in a mouse model of genetic Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease.

theories.name: Aging hallmarks theory

key_concepts.description: AMPK is a key cellular energy sensor that regulates metabolic homeostasis. Its activation is associated with aging processes and can influence longevity by modulating energy balance and stress responses.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress regulation via Nrf2 and mitochondrial activity
key_concepts.description: Nrf2 is a transcription factor that regulates antioxidant responses, while COX IV1 is involved in mitochondrial function. Both play roles in controlling oxidative damage, a hallmark of aging, by maintaining redox balance and mitochondrial health.
Chronic inflammation is a recognized hallmark of aging, contributing to tissue dysfunction. Increased stem cell production may counteract aging effects by promoting tissue regeneration and repair.

theories.evidence: Experimental data comparing effects of Metformin and Nano-PSO on aging hallmarks (AMPK activation, Nrf2, COX IV1), inflammation, stem cell production, and disease progression in a mouse model of genetic Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses fundamental aging hallmarks that are broadly implicated in systemic aging processes, proposes mechanisms (energy sensing, oxidative stress, inflammation) underlying aging, and tests interventions targeting these mechanisms. Although studied in a disease model, the focus is on general aging hallmarks rather than disease-specific pathology alone.

results.title: Pleiotropic Effects of Tocotrienols and Quercetin on Cellular Senescence: Introducing the Perspective of Senolytic Effects of Phytochemicals.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of senescent cells contributes causally to aging and age-related diseases by impairing tissue function and promoting chronic inflammation.
Targeting and eliminating senescent cells (senolysis) can delay aging phenotypes and prevent age-related diseases by removing apoptosis-resistant senescent cells.

key_concepts.concept: Dual role of senescence in cancer and aging
key_concepts.description: Senescence can suppress cancer by halting proliferation of damaged cells, but accumulation of senescent cells with age promotes tissue dysfunction; thus, modulating senescence has therapeutic potential.

theories.evidence: In vitro studies showing tocotrienols and quercetin induce senescence and apoptosis in cancer cells, delay senescence and rejuvenate primary cells, and quercetin’s senolytic effects linked to inhibition of anti-apoptotic genes such as PI3K.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging process (cellular senescence) with causal mechanisms (accumulation and removal of senescent cells), generalizable to organismal aging, and discusses therapeutic targeting as validation.

results.title: The role of historical change for adult development and aging: Towards a theoretical framework about the how and the why.
Ageing and disease.
Telomeres, oxidative stress, and timing for spontaneous term and preterm labor.

theories.name: Telomere-based biological clock theory of aging and gestational timing

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening as a biological clock
key_concepts.description: Telomeres progressively shorten throughout life in adults, contributing to physiological senescence, multiorgan dysfunction, and death. This shortening acts as a timing mechanism that regulates the length of gestation and the onset of labor.
Conditions that increase oxidative stress in the mother can accelerate telomere shortening in gestational tissues, potentially leading to earlier onset of labor and preterm birth.

key_concepts.concept: Racial disparities mediated by telomere shortening and weathering
key_concepts.description: The 'weathering effect' hypothesis suggests that chronic stressors such as systemic racism and socioeconomic marginalization cause accelerated telomere shortening in African-American women, explaining higher rates of preterm birth even among affluent individuals.

key_concepts.concept: Antioxidants mitigate telomere shortening and preterm birth
key_concepts.description: Antioxidant vitamins (E and C) can reduce oxidative stress, delay telomere shortening, and have been associated with reduced rates of preterm births in clinical trials.

theories.evidence: Multiple lines of evidence including observational data on telomere dynamics in gestational tissues, clinical trials with antioxidant vitamins, epidemiological data on racial disparities, and the conceptual framework of the weathering hypothesis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (telomere shortening as a biological clock) explaining aging-related processes (physiological senescence and timing of labor) at the organism level. It links oxidative stress and social determinants to telomere dynamics, addressing broad aging mechanisms beyond a single organ or disease.

results.title: RNA G-quadruplex (rG4) exacerbates cellular senescence by mediating ribosome pausing.

theories.name: RNA G-quadruplex (rG4)-mediated ribosome pausing theory of cellular senescence

key_concepts.description: rG4 structures within coding sequences can physically stall ribosomes during translation, leading to reduced translation efficiency of rG4-rich genes. This ribosome pausing contributes to the collapse of protein homeostasis, a hallmark of cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Increased abundance of rG4 structures in senescent cells
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells show a significant increase in rG4 structures, which exacerbates translation inefficiency and proteostasis imbalance, thereby promoting cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Role of RNA helicase DHX9 as a regulator of rG4 abundance
key_concepts.description: DHX9 helicase normally resolves rG4 structures to prevent ribosome stalling. Reduced expression of DHX9 in senescent cells leads to accumulation of rG4, increased ribosome pausing, and accelerated senescence.

Similar increases in rG4 abundance, protein homeostasis imbalance, and reduced DHX9 expression were observed in aged mice, suggesting this mechanism may contribute to aging beyond cellular senescence.

theories.evidence: Ribosome profiling and G-quadruplex RNA immunoprecipitation sequencing data showing reduced translation efficiency of rG4-rich genes; in vivo and in vitro experiments demonstrating translation impediment by rG4; observations of increased rG4 and reduced DHX9 in senescent cells and aged mice.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining how ribosome pausing mediated by rG4 structures contributes to cellular senescence and potentially organismal aging. It addresses a fundamental aging hallmark (loss of proteostasis) and links molecular mechanisms to systemic aging features.

results.title: Interventions Addressing the Telomere-Telomerase System.

theories.name: Telomere Shortening and Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening as a marker of cellular aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres shorten with repeated cell divisions, reflecting a cell's mitotic history. This shortening is influenced by cumulative exposure to inflammation and oxidative stress, which accelerates cellular aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of telomerase in telomere length maintenance
key_concepts.description: Telomerase is an enzyme that lengthens telomeres, counteracting shortening. Its availability and activity influence cellular aging and the potential for cells to avoid senescence or apoptosis.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence and apoptosis triggered by critically short telomeres
key_concepts.description: When telomeres become too short, cells may enter senescence, undergo apoptosis, or experience genomic instability, contributing to organismal aging and increased mortality risk.

key_concepts.concept: Link between telomere length and systemic health and mortality
key_concepts.description: Shorter leukocyte telomere length correlates with compromised general health and predicts mortality, suggesting telomere dynamics as a systemic aging mechanism.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews recent studies on leukocyte telomere length and telomerase activity in psychiatric disorders, citing clinical and preclinical data linking telomere shortening to accelerated cellular aging and mortality risk.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for biological aging at the cellular and organismal level, linking telomere dynamics to systemic aging processes beyond specific diseases.

results.title: Stress-induced failure of embodied cognition: A general model.
Designing Exercise to Improve Bone Health Among Individuals With Cerebral Palsy.

theories.name: Mechanostat theory

key_concepts.description: The mechanostat theory proposes that bone strength and density adapt to the mechanical loads placed upon them. Bone tissue senses strain and remodels accordingly to maintain optimal strength, with insufficient loading leading to bone loss and excessive loading stimulating bone formation.

The osteogenic index is a quantitative measure within the mechanostat framework that guides the design of exercise interventions by specifying the type, number of repetitions, and frequency of mechanical loading needed to stimulate bone growth or maintenance.

theories.evidence: Application of mechanostat theory principles to exercise program design for individuals with cerebral palsy, with recommendations on dosing of interventions based on osteogenic index; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how mechanical loading influences bone aging and strength, applicable broadly beyond cerebral palsy; provides a mechanistic explanation of bone adaptation as part of aging-related bone health.

results.title: Protein oxidation and aging. II. Difficulties in measuring alkaline protease activity in tissues using the fluorescamine procedure.

theories.name: Protein Oxidation Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging is driven by the buildup of oxidatively damaged proteins in tissues, which impairs cellular function and contributes to the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Age-dependent increase in protein carbonyl content
key_concepts.description: Protein carbonyl groups, markers of oxidative damage, increase with age, indicating progressive protein oxidation as a hallmark of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Decline in proteolytic degradation of oxidized proteins
key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with decreased activity of enzymes such as alkaline proteases that preferentially degrade oxidized proteins, leading to accumulation of damaged proteins.

theories.evidence: The paper critiques prior evidence supporting the theory by showing methodological difficulties in reliably measuring protein carbonyls and alkaline protease activity using certain assays. It presents experimental data demonstrating no age-dependent changes in protease activity in rat brain cortex using a more reliable assay.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging (oxidative damage accumulation and impaired clearance), addresses aging broadly at the organismal level, and discusses causal explanations rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Role of excitatory amino acid neurotransmission in synaptic plasticity and pathology. An integrative hypothesis concerning the pathogenesis and evolutionary advantages of schizophrenia-related genes.
The link between obesity and aging - insights into cardiac energy metabolism.

theories.name: Obesity-accelerated cardiac aging hypothesis

key_concepts.description: Both obesity and aging impair the heart's ability to switch between fuel sources efficiently, leading to reduced adaptability in energy metabolism.
Changes in the types of substrates (e.g., fatty acids, glucose) used for energy production in the heart occur similarly in obesity and aging, potentially contributing to cardiac dysfunction.
Mechanisms that detect and respond to nutrient availability become impaired, disrupting metabolic homeostasis and promoting aging-like changes in cardiac tissue.
Mitochondria in cardiac cells show reduced function and efficiency in both aging and obesity, leading to decreased energy production and increased oxidative stress.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review discussing existing hypotheses and data linking obesity-related metabolic changes to cardiac aging; no new experimental data are presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The hypothesis attempts to explain how obesity may causally accelerate cardiac aging by shared metabolic mechanisms, linking these changes to systemic aging processes. It proposes underlying mechanisms (metabolic inflexibility, mitochondrial dysfunction) relevant to organism-level aging, thus meeting the criteria for an aging theory-related hypothesis.

results.title: Calcium signaling hypothesis: A non-negligible pathogenesis in Alzheimer's disease.
Nicotinamide Mononucleotide in the Context of Myocardiocyte Longevity.

theories.name: Nicotinamide Mononucleotide (NMN)-Mediated Anti-Aging Mechanism in Myocardiocytes

key_concepts.description: NMN plays a critical role in maintaining intracellular homeostasis by regulating metabolic activities and signaling pathways essential for cell survival and function. Dysregulation of NMN metabolism is linked to impaired oxidative phosphorylation and cellular aging in myocardiocytes.

NMN influences autophagy, a key cellular process that manages intracellular detoxification, oxidative stress, and protein quality control. Proper autophagy regulation by NMN helps prevent accumulation of cellular damage, thereby promoting cell longevity.

NMN is fundamental for the functionality of sirtuins, a family of proteins known for their anti-senescent properties. Through supporting sirtuin activity, NMN contributes to delaying cellular senescence and enhancing myocardiocyte longevity.

NMN protects myocardiocytes from ischemic injury by modulating metabolism—reducing anabolic processes and enhancing catabolism—leading to a dormant cellular state that favors survival under stress conditions.

theories.evidence: The abstract references various hypotheses and known signaling pathways involving NMN, sirtuins, and autophagy, as well as pathophysiological observations in aged myocardiocytes, but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a general mechanism of cellular aging and longevity through NMN metabolism and its downstream effects on autophagy and sirtuins, which are broadly relevant to aging processes beyond just myocardiocytes. It proposes causal mechanisms linking metabolic regulation to aging and senescence, meeting the criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Funding Life-Extension Research.

theories.name: Geroscience Hypothesis

key_concepts.concept: Aging as a modifiable biological process
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis posits that aging processes within cells can be altered pharmacologically, potentially changing the trajectory of aging and delaying the onset of age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Common mechanisms underlying multiple chronic diseases
key_concepts.description: Geroscience suggests that many chronic comorbidities in aging populations share fundamental biological aging mechanisms, so targeting aging itself could broadly impact healthspan.
The hypothesis is entering a translational phase where laboratory findings on life extension are tested in humans through clinical trials to confirm or refute the ability of drugs to modify aging.

theories.evidence: References to accumulated insights into aging mechanisms, dramatic laboratory demonstrations of life extension in some organisms, and the ongoing/planned clinical trials testing drugs targeting aging processes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging at the cellular and organismal level, addressing aging broadly and not limited to specific diseases or organs.

results.title: When GETomics meets aging and exercise in COPD.
Genetic geroscience and Alzheimer's disease: The pleiotropy is the point!

theories.name: Genetic Geroscience Paradigm

key_concepts.description: Genetic variants can have pleiotropic effects, meaning they influence multiple traits or age-related conditions simultaneously. This concept suggests that some genes contribute broadly to aging processes and multiple age-related diseases rather than acting in isolation.

key_concepts.concept: Shared Genetic Basis of Age-Related Diseases
key_concepts.description: The paradigm posits that aging biology underlies a shared genetic architecture that contributes to various age-related health conditions, such as Alzheimer's disease, coronary heart disease, hyperlipidemia, and cancer. Identifying these shared genetic factors can illuminate fundamental aging mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Use of Statistical Models to Detect Pleiotropy
key_concepts.description: Modern statistical approaches can jointly assess genetic associations across multiple age-related diseases to identify variants with pleiotropic effects, providing a tool to uncover genes that may drive systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: Reference to the study by Pan and colleagues applying statistical models to identify pleiotropic genetic variants associated with Alzheimer's disease and other age-related comorbidities; conceptual commentary rather than new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging by focusing on genetic pleiotropy as an underlying mechanism linking multiple age-related diseases, thus addressing aging broadly at the organism level.

results.title: Role of sperm DNA damage in creating de-novo mutations in human offspring: the 'post-meiotic oocyte collusion' hypothesis.
The association between age and telomere length is age-dependent: Evidence for a threshold model of telomere length maintenance.

theories.name: Telomere length maintenance threshold model

key_concepts.concept: Age-dependent association between telomere length and aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that the relationship between telomere length and chronological age is not linear or uniform across the lifespan but varies depending on the age group considered. This dynamic association suggests that telomere shortening may be more pronounced or detectable in younger adults but less so or absent in older adults.

key_concepts.concept: Dynamic costs and benefits of telomere maintenance
key_concepts.description: The model suggests that the biological trade-offs involved in maintaining telomere length change throughout an individual's life course. This implies that telomere maintenance mechanisms may be regulated differently at various ages, influencing the observed telomere dynamics and their impact on aging.

key_concepts.concept: Threshold effect in telomere length dynamics
key_concepts.description: The theory implies a threshold or critical point in telomere length maintenance beyond which the association with aging changes or disappears. This threshold model may explain inconsistencies in empirical studies regarding telomere length as a biomarker of aging.

theories.evidence: Empirical data from telomere restriction fragment analysis in two groups of Japanese quail differing in age distribution; statistical analysis showing significant negative association in young adults but no association in all-age adults; exclusion of selective disappearance as a confounder.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining how telomere dynamics relate causally to aging processes at the organism level, addressing why telomere length associations with age vary. It attempts to explain a fundamental aging-related biomarker's behavior with implications for aging biology broadly.

results.title: "Best-Guess" MRAD Provides Robust Evidence for a Limit to Human Lifespan: Reply to de Grey (Rejuvenation Res. 2017;20:261-262).
β-hydroxybutyrate is a metabolic regulator of proteostasis in the aged and Alzheimer disease brain.

theories.name: Metabolically regulated proteostasis theory

key_concepts.concept: Proteostasis loss as hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Loss of proteostasis, the maintenance of protein folding and solubility, is a fundamental feature of biological aging and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer disease.
βHB, a ketone body produced during low glucose availability, regulates protein solubility and proteostasis by mechanisms independent of covalent protein modification, pH, or solute load.

βHB-induced protein insolubility selectively targets pathological proteins like amyloid-β, suggesting a mechanism by which metabolism influences protein aggregation and clearance relevant to aging and neurodegeneration.

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic control of proteostasis impacting aging
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that metabolic states, through molecules like βHB, causally regulate proteostasis mechanisms that underlie aging and age-related neurodegenerative pathology.

theories.evidence: In vivo mouse brain experiments with ketone ester delivery showing βHB-induced protein insolubility; nematode models demonstrating amelioration of amyloid-β aggregation toxicity; mass spectrometry proteomics identifying βHB target proteins enriched in neurodegeneration-related proteins; clearance of these targets from mouse brain.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking metabolism to proteostasis loss, a core aging hallmark, with organism-level implications and experimental evidence; addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases by focusing on proteostasis regulation.

results.title: Metabolic control of mitophagy.

theories.name: Mitophagy as a metabolic regulator of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction is recognized as a key feature of aging and related chronic diseases, implicating mitochondria in the fundamental processes that drive organismal aging.

Mitophagy is the selective autophagic removal of damaged mitochondria, essential for maintaining mitochondrial homeostasis and cell survival, thereby influencing aging at the cellular and organismal level.

Mitophagy is regulated by metabolic pathways and molecular switches such as AMP-dependent protein kinase, protein kinase A, mechanistic target of rapamycin, and sirtuins, linking cellular metabolic status to mitochondrial quality control and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of metabolic circuits to delay aging
key_concepts.description: Understanding and manipulating the metabolic regulatory circuits controlling mitophagy may provide therapeutic avenues to delay aging and treat mitochondria-associated chronic diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review discussing known molecular regulators of mitophagy and their metabolic integration, citing existing literature; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses mitophagy as a fundamental cellular process linked to aging, proposes metabolic regulation as a causal mechanism influencing aging, and connects mitochondrial quality control to systemic aging processes, thus meeting the criteria for an aging theory-related discussion.

results.title: Cross-sectional and longitudinal relationships among age, cognition, and processing speed.

theories.name: Processing Speed Theory of Cognitive Aging

key_concepts.concept: Processing Speed as a Mediator of Cognitive Decline
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that reductions in processing speed underlie age-related declines in cognitive performance. Slower processing speed leads to poorer cognitive function, making it a fundamental mechanism driving cognitive aging.

key_concepts.concept: Differential Effects in Cross-Sectional vs. Longitudinal Studies
key_concepts.description: The theory acknowledges that processing speed accounts for much of the age-related variance in cognitive performance in cross-sectional analyses but does not fully explain longitudinal cognitive decline, suggesting complexity in how processing speed relates to aging over time.

theories.evidence: Empirical data from 302 older adults followed longitudinally showing processing speed related to cognitive performance cross-sectionally and predicting within-person longitudinal cognitive decline; statistical analyses controlling for processing speed effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining why cognitive aging occurs at the organism level, addressing broad cognitive aging rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Good at Heart: Preserving Cardiac Metabolism during aging.

theories.name: Mitochondrial oxidative stress and quality control theory of aging

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that the accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced by mitochondria leads to cellular damage over time, contributing to aging and age-related decline in organ function, particularly in the heart.
Aging impairs mitochondrial energy production efficiency, which compromises cellular homeostasis and function, especially in energy-demanding tissues like cardiac muscle.

Mechanisms such as mitophagy and mitochondrial biogenesis maintain mitochondrial integrity; their dysregulation with age leads to accumulation of dysfunctional mitochondria, promoting cardiac aging and failure.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent research studies focusing on mitochondrial oxidative stress, energy production, and quality control mechanisms in aging hearts; references to human and animal models demonstrating cardiac aging phenotypes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining aging at the organismal level through mitochondrial dysfunction, addressing fundamental processes of cellular homeostasis and energy metabolism linked to systemic aging.

results.title: On Modeling Ovarian Aging and Menopause Timing.
Activated SKN-1 alters the aging trajectories of long-lived Caenorhabditis elegans mutants.
Cellular senescence in liver diseases: From molecular drivers to therapeutic targeting.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Senescent cells progressively accumulate in various hepatic cell types with aging and contribute to liver dysfunction. This accumulation is a hallmark of aging and is implicated as a central mechanism linking aging and metabolic insults to chronic liver disease.

Senescent cells secrete a complex mixture of pro-inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, growth factors, and proteases known as SASP, which influence local tissue environment and systemic health, promoting disease progression and chronic inflammation.

Senotherapeutic strategies such as senolytics (agents that selectively eliminate senescent cells) and senomorphics (agents that modulate SASP) are proposed to mitigate the detrimental effects of senescence. Advances in targeted therapies including PROTACs and CAR T-cell therapies offer precision intervention opportunities.

theories.evidence: The paper synthesizes recent advances including multi-omics profiling, multi-marker gene signatures, and emerging targeted therapeutic modalities. It discusses preclinical and clinical evidence supporting senescence as a driver of liver aging and disease.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes cellular senescence as a fundamental, generalizable mechanism driving aging-related liver dysfunction and systemic aging effects; it provides a causal explanation through senescent cell accumulation and SASP; and it addresses aging broadly beyond a single disease by linking senescence to systemic health and aging processes.

results.title: Histone modifications as molecular drivers of cardiac aging: Metabolic alterations, epigenetic mechanisms, and emerging therapeutic strategies.

theories.name: Epigenetic theory of aging via histone modifications

key_concepts.description: Histone modifications such as methylation, acetylation, and phosphorylation alter chromatin structure and gene expression patterns, thereby influencing cellular function during aging. These modifications dynamically regulate transcriptional activation and repression in cardiac tissue, contributing to age-related functional decline.

The theory posits that epigenetic changes in histone marks are closely linked with metabolic remodeling in aging cardiac cells, affecting mitochondrial function and energy homeostasis. This crosstalk between metabolism and epigenetics is proposed as a key mechanism driving cardiac aging.
