Histone modifications influence critical biological pathways such as DNA damage repair, inflammation, and fibrosis, which are central to the progression of cardiac aging. Altered epigenetic landscapes modulate these pathways, thereby contributing causally to age-associated cardiac dysfunction.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews current evidence from epigenomic studies showing dynamic changes in histone marks in aged cardiac tissue, including increased transcriptional activation markers and decreased repressive marks, with citations of studies linking these changes to mitochondrial dysfunction, DNA repair, inflammation, and fibrosis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (cardiac aging) through epigenetic mechanisms that have systemic implications for organismal aging. It proposes causal mechanisms (histone modifications altering gene expression and metabolic pathways) rather than merely describing patterns. Although focused on cardiac tissue, it connects to general aging mechanisms such as DNA damage and mitochondrial dysfunction, thus meeting the criteria for a generalizable aging theory.

results.title: Age-related brain-region-specific changes in diffusion anisotropy in subarachnoid space of young adults.

theories.name: Glymphatic system theory

key_concepts.concept: Waste clearance via cerebrospinal fluid flow
key_concepts.description: The glymphatic system theory proposes that brain waste products are removed through the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the subarachnoid space (SAS), which moves into perivascular spaces, mixes with interstitial fluid and waste, and is then flushed out via perivenous spaces.

key_concepts.concept: Role of subarachnoid space in glymphatic transport
key_concepts.description: The SAS, especially around arteries like the middle cerebral artery, is critical for glymphatic influx, facilitating the movement of CSF and waste clearance from the brain parenchyma.

key_concepts.concept: Age-related changes in diffusion anisotropy affecting glymphatic function
key_concepts.description: Diffusion tensor imaging measures such as fractional anisotropy (FA) in the SAS may reflect the efficiency of glymphatic transport, with age-related declines in FA indicating more isotropic diffusion and potentially altered waste clearance.

theories.evidence: The study used diffusion tensor imaging on 83 young adults to measure fractional anisotropy and mean diffusivity in the SAS across brain regions, demonstrating regional variations and an age-related decline in FA.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The glymphatic system theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological process—brain waste clearance linked to aging-related changes in CSF dynamics—thus addressing a causal mechanism relevant to brain aging. Although focused on brain-specific processes, it connects to systemic aging via waste clearance mechanisms, meeting generalizability and causal explanation criteria.

results.title: Non-equilibrium systems theory: some applications for gerontological nursing practice.

theories.name: Non-Equilibrium Systems Theory (NEST) of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Aging as formative change toward increasing disorder and order
key_concepts.description: Aging is conceptualized as a dynamic process involving both increasing disorder and the emergence of new order in form, pattern, or structure within the organism. This duality reflects the complex nature of aging as neither purely degenerative nor purely progressive.

key_concepts.concept: Self-organization processes leading to greater complexity
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that through self-organization, an individual develops increasing complexity over time. This process results in unique patterns of perception and behavior, making each older person distinct from others.

key_concepts.concept: Uniqueness of aging individuals as an outcome of self-organization
key_concepts.description: As aging progresses, self-organization drives differentiation among individuals, emphasizing that aging is not a uniform decline but a process of becoming more unique in behavior and perception.

theories.mode: discuss, apply as a practice framework
theories.evidence: The abstract does not present experimental data but discusses conceptual application of NEST to understand aging and guide nursing practice, focusing on interpreting behaviors as outcomes of self-organization.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging as a fundamental process involving self-organization and complexity changes at the organism level. It addresses aging broadly and provides an organizing principle rather than describing narrow phenomena.

results.title: Aging at the Crossroads of Organ Interactions: Implications for the Heart.

theories.name: Interorgan Crosstalk-Driven Accelerated Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Aging is accelerated by interactions between multiple organs and tissues, such as the heart, lungs, kidneys, liver, muscles, and brain. These interactions promote systemic aging processes rather than isolated organ decline.

Cellular senescence in various tissues contributes to aging by secreting pro-inflammatory factors (senescence-associated secretory phenotype) that propagate dysfunction and inflammation across organs.
Chronic inflammation, metabolic changes, mitochondrial dysfunction, and oxidative stress are mechanisms by which interorgan crosstalk accelerates aging-related tissue damage and organ remodeling.
The crosstalk leads to accelerated progression of cardiometabolic diseases and multiorgan failure, highlighting aging as a systemic process influenced by organ interactions.
Targeting the interorgan communication pathways offers new opportunities for early diagnosis, precision medicine, and interventions that may slow systemic aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known mechanisms such as cellular senescence, inflammation, oxidative stress, and metabolic dysfunction, and cites examples of organ interactions in cardiometabolic aging. It also discusses translational and therapeutic implications, but no new experimental data is presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging at the organism level through interorgan communication mechanisms. It addresses systemic aging processes rather than isolated organ pathology and links cellular mechanisms to organismal aging.

results.title: Living a Nonlinear Concept of Aging: Toward A Global Perspective.
Physiology, Pathophysiology and Clinical Relevance of D-Amino Acids Dynamics: From Neurochemistry to Pharmacotherapy.

theories.name: D-amino acid isomerization theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: D-amino acid incorporation in aged proteins
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that aging is associated with the isomerization of L-amino acids to D-amino acids within proteins, such as crystallin in the eye, teeth, bone, blood vessels, and brain. The accumulation of D-amino acids in primary protein sequences may contribute to structural and functional protein alterations linked to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Non-proteinogenic role of free D-amino acids
key_concepts.description: Free D-amino acids like D-aspartic acid and D-serine have been identified in specific brain nuclei and endocrine glands, suggesting they have biological roles beyond protein building blocks. Their dynamics may influence physiological and pathological processes relevant to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Altered D-amino acid levels in neurodegenerative and psychiatric diseases
key_concepts.description: Changes in plasma free D-amino acids and tissue levels are observed in conditions such as schizophrenia and neurodegenerative diseases, indicating a possible link between D-amino acid metabolism and aging-related pathologies.

theories.evidence: Historical identification of free D-amino acids in brain and glands; detection of D-amino acid incorporation in aged human proteins; observations of altered D-amino acid levels in disease states; references to experimental confirmations and therapeutic applications.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (protein isomerization by D-amino acids) underlying aging at the organism level, linking molecular changes to systemic aging processes. It goes beyond narrow phenomena by suggesting a fundamental biochemical aging mechanism and discusses its relevance to aging-related diseases.

results.title: Oxidative Stress Modulation Through Habitual Physical Activity.

theories.name: Hormesis theory

key_concepts.description: The hormesis theory posits that low doses of a stressor that is harmful at high doses can induce adaptive beneficial effects on cells or organisms. This means that mild oxidative stress from moderate exercise can upregulate protective mechanisms, whereas excessive stress from strenuous exercise can cause damage.

Reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated during moderate physical activity act as signaling molecules that stimulate the production of antioxidant molecules, such as glutathione reductase, enhancing the organism’s ability to counteract oxidative damage.

key_concepts.concept: Balance between beneficial and detrimental effects
key_concepts.description: The theory explains the complex relationship between exercise and oxidative stress, where habitual moderate exercise promotes health and reduces disease risk, but acute strenuous exercise can lead to excessive free radical production and potential harm.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews data on ROS generation during exercise, antioxidant molecule upregulation (e.g., glutathione reductase), and epidemiological associations between exercise intensity and cardiovascular outcomes; it also discusses emerging markers of mitochondrial and ER dysfunction.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The hormesis theory meets all criteria: it provides a generalizable causal explanation for aging-related oxidative stress modulation at the organism level, proposes mechanisms for how oxidative stress influences aging, and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on a single organ or disease.

results.title: The aging interactome: From cellular dysregulation to therapeutic frontiers in age-related diseases.

theories.name: Integrated cellular dysregulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by the progressive loss of cellular homeostasis, where cells fail to maintain stable internal conditions, leading to dysfunction.

Multiple interconnected biological pathways such as inflammaging (chronic low-grade inflammation), immune senescence (decline in immune function), mitochondrial dysfunction, and genomic instability collectively drive the aging process.
These cellular and molecular dysregulations contribute broadly to the development of multiple age-related diseases, indicating a generalizable mechanism underlying organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Citations and synthesis of current knowledge on mechanisms and their roles in various age-related diseases; references to multi-omics and AI-driven biomarker studies; discussion of clinical trials targeting these mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general, organism-level explanation of aging through interconnected cellular mechanisms, offers causal explanations, and links these to systemic aging and disease.

theories.name: Senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Accumulation of senescent cells contributes causally to aging and age-related pathologies by promoting inflammation and tissue dysfunction.
Senolytics, drugs that selectively eliminate senescent cells, represent a promising intervention to mitigate aging effects and extend healthspan.

theories.evidence: Mention of clinical trials using senolytics and other interventions targeting shared aging mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general causal mechanism of aging and discusses intervention strategies that test this theory.

theories.name: Epigenetic clock theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Epigenetic clocks use DNA methylation patterns to estimate biological age, reflecting the cumulative impact of aging processes.
These clocks may capture underlying programmed or damage-related mechanisms of aging, serving as biomarkers that link molecular changes to organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Reference to advancements in multi-omics and AI-driven biomarkers, particularly epigenetic clocks, for precise aging quantification and disease risk stratification.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it discusses a tool that reflects underlying aging mechanisms, though the abstract does not clarify if it proposes new causal mechanisms.

results.title: Gut microbiota and aging.

theories.name: Gut microbiota modulation theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Gut microbiota influence on physiological aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the composition and function of gut microbiota play a crucial role in maintaining physiological homeostasis in the gastrointestinal system, which in turn impacts the overall aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Link between microbiota disturbance and systemic inflammation
key_concepts.description: Alterations in gut microbiota are associated with changes in inflammatory states, which are implicated in neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, suggesting a systemic effect of microbiota on aging-related pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Interaction between microbiota products, immune system, and inflammation mediators
key_concepts.description: The mutual influence among microbial metabolites, immune responses, and inflammatory mediators is proposed to modulate aging processes, potentially facilitating healthier aging and counteracting degenerative mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Citations of several studies showing qualitative and quantitative alterations of intestinal flora in physiological and pathological conditions; observed correlations between microbiota disturbances and inflammatory states in neurodegenerative diseases; preliminary characterization of gut microbiota in elderly populations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking gut microbiota composition and systemic inflammation to the aging process at an organismal level. It addresses aging broadly, beyond specific diseases, by suggesting modulation of microbiota as a way to influence physiological aging and degenerative progression.

results.title: DNA methylation profile of a rural cohort exposed to early-adversity and malnutrition: An exploratory analysis.

theories.name: Developmental Origins of Health and Disease (DOHaD) / Barker's Hypothesis

key_concepts.description: This concept posits that nutritional deficits during fetal and early postnatal development cause lasting changes in metabolism that compromise organismal functions later in life, increasing susceptibility to age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic mechanisms as mediators between environment and genetic programming
key_concepts.description: Epigenetic modifications, such as DNA methylation, serve as the molecular link by which external environmental and social factors influence gene expression patterns, potentially programming aging trajectories.

key_concepts.concept: Environmental and social conditions shape aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Life course exposures, including trauma, famine, and chronic malnutrition, impact epigenetic markers and thereby influence the biological aging process and phenotypic outcomes in adulthood and old age.

theories.evidence: Exploratory epigenomic profiling of individuals from a rural Mexican cohort exposed to early adversity and malnutrition; observed differential methylation in pathways related to neuronal development, reproduction, learning, and memory.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (early-life environmental programming via epigenetics) explaining how aging phenotypes arise systemically; connects environmental exposures to organism-level aging outcomes through epigenetic reprogramming.

results.title: Predicting the prevalence of genetic trade-offs among adaptive substitutions.
Can DRYAD explain age-related associative memory deficits?

theories.name: DRYAD (Density of Representations Yields Age-Related Deficits) model

key_concepts.description: The DRYAD model proposes that aging leads to a broad, global decline in the fidelity of memory representations, affecting overall memory performance.

This global memory deficit is moderated by weaker representations of contextual information, which results in disproportionately larger age-related declines in memory for source, context, and associations.
The model suggests that the global decline in memory fidelity may be due to declines in attentional processes that affect how memories are encoded and retrieved.

theories.evidence: Comparison with associative deficit hypothesis (ADH) using two experiments manipulating attention and instructions; results supported ADH predictions and did not support DRYAD assumptions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (global memory fidelity decline moderated by attention and contextual representation) explaining why age-related associative memory deficits occur; it attempts to explain aging-related cognitive decline broadly rather than a narrow phenomenon.

theories.name: Associative Deficit Hypothesis (ADH)

key_concepts.description: ADH posits that aging specifically impairs the ability to form and retrieve associations between items, rather than causing a global memory decline.
The hypothesis emphasizes that attentional resources and encoding strategies are critical in associative memory performance and that these are selectively impaired with age.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from two studies manipulating attention and instructions supported ADH predictions over DRYAD.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a causal explanation for a general aging-related cognitive deficit (associative memory decline) with proposed mechanisms involving attention and encoding; it addresses a broad cognitive aging phenomenon.

results.title: Perinatal stress and epigenetics.

theories.name: Epigenetic Programming Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Epigenetic reprogramming involves modifications such as DNA methylation that alter genome function in response to early life experiences, leading to stable phenotypic outcomes that persist throughout life.

key_concepts.concept: DNA Methylation as a Mediator of Phenotypic Plasticity
key_concepts.description: DNA methylation profiles are dynamically rearranged during development, puberty, and aging, defining cell-type identity and enabling the genome to express multiple phenotypes based on environmental and experiential inputs.

key_concepts.concept: Programming of Stress Response via HPA Axis
key_concepts.description: Early life stress impacts lifelong behavioral and physical phenotypes through epigenetic modifications of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, which regulates stress responses.

Unlike genetic mutations, epigenetic marks such as DNA methylation are reversible through pharmacological or behavioral interventions, offering potential avenues for preventing or reversing aging-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper references data from the last 15 years on DNA methylation changes in the hippocampus and hypothalamus related to early life stress and lifelong phenotypic outcomes, including behavioral and physical health consequences.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how aging-related phenotypic changes occur via epigenetic mechanisms that are generalizable across the organism, proposes causal mechanisms (epigenetic modifications) for aging-related processes, and addresses broad aging phenomena including development, puberty, and aging itself.

results.title: Quadruplexes and aging: G4-binding proteins regulate the presence of miRNA in small extracellular vesicles (sEVs).

theories.name: G-quadruplex (G4) RNA-binding protein regulation of miRNA distribution theory

key_concepts.description: RNA molecules can form specific secondary structures called G-quadruplexes (G4s), which are stable four-stranded configurations formed by guanine-rich sequences. These structures influence RNA stability, localization, and interactions with proteins.

Certain proteins, such as Alyref and FUS, recognize and bind to RNA G4 structures via G-rich recognition motifs. This binding regulates the sorting and distribution of miRNAs into small extracellular vesicles (sEVs), which are important for intercellular communication.

key_concepts.concept: Link between G4-mediated miRNA regulation and aging/senescence
key_concepts.description: Imbalances in sEV production and miRNA distribution are associated with senescence and aging-related pathologies. The interaction between G4 structures and their binding proteins may thus influence aging processes by controlling miRNA-mediated signaling between cells.

theories.evidence: The abstract cites recent research identifying Alyref and FUS as RNA-binding proteins with G4 recognition motifs that regulate miRNA sorting into sEVs. It references associations between sEV imbalances and senescence but does not detail experimental data within the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory proposes a mechanistic explanation for how RNA structural motifs and their binding proteins influence miRNA distribution, which is linked to senescence and aging at a cellular communication level. It attempts to explain a fundamental biological process related to aging, not limited to a single organ or disease, and proposes a causal mechanism involving molecular interactions affecting aging-related pathways.

results.title: The effects of soluble Aβ oligomers on neurodegeneration in Alzheimer's disease.

theories.name: Aging Factor Cascade Hypothesis

key_concepts.concept: Integration of Aging and Disease Mechanisms
key_concepts.description: This newly proposed framework attempts to integrate recent data and concepts linking aging processes with Alzheimer's disease pathology, suggesting that aging factors cascade to influence disease progression.
The hypothesis aims to provide a novel conceptual basis for developing therapies that modify disease progression by targeting aging-related mechanisms rather than solely amyloid pathology.

theories.evidence: The proposal is based on recent research findings and the limitations of amyloid cascade hypothesis-based therapies, though specific experimental evidence is not detailed in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Appears to meet criteria as it proposes a general aging-related framework explaining how aging factors contribute causally to neurodegeneration and AD progression, with potential organism-level implications.

theories.name: Amyloid Cascade Hypothesis

key_concepts.concept: Soluble Amyloid-β Oligomers as Neurotoxic Agents
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that soluble low-molecular-weight amyloid-β (Aβ) oligomers trigger synaptic dysfunction and contribute to neurodegeneration in Alzheimer's disease. These oligomers impair synaptic function before neuronal death occurs, correlating with cognitive deficits.

key_concepts.concept: Progression from Synaptic Dysfunction to Neuronal Death
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis describes a cascade where synaptic alterations and loss precede and potentially cause neuronal death, particularly in brain regions critical for memory such as the entorhinal cortex and hippocampus.

key_concepts.concept: Amyloid Plaque Pathology and Its Limitations
key_concepts.description: While amyloid plaques are a hallmark of AD, transgenic mouse models overexpressing Aβ show plaques and early synaptic changes but fail to fully replicate the pattern of neuronal loss seen in human AD, suggesting limitations in the hypothesis or models.

theories.evidence: Citations of in vitro and in vivo studies showing synaptic dysfunction caused by soluble Aβ oligomers; transgenic mouse models with amyloid plaque pathology; novel animal model demonstrating neurodegenerative effects of soluble Aβ oligomers.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for neurodegeneration in AD linked to aging-related cognitive decline, addressing fundamental processes at organismal brain level, not limited to a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Task-Based Attentional Control: The Role of Anxiety and Age.
The quantum human central neural system.
Mitochondria and cell death.

theories.name: Non-lethal mitochondrial apoptotic signalling theory

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondria as central regulators of intrinsic apoptosis
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria release cytochrome c to initiate intrinsic apoptosis, which activates caspases to ensure programmed cell death without inflammation.

Beyond causing cell death, mitochondrial apoptotic signals can have diverse biological roles affecting processes such as cancer progression, innate immunity, and aging, implying a broader regulatory function.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondria as hubs for multiple cell death pathways
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria coordinate various cell death mechanisms including pyroptosis, ferroptosis, and necroptosis, integrating signals that determine cell fate and potentially influencing organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Discussion of mitochondrial roles in apoptosis and other cell death pathways, referencing BCL-2 family proteins and emerging literature on non-lethal signalling impacts on aging and immunity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how mitochondrial signalling influences aging at a general organismal level by linking cell death pathways to aging processes, proposing a causal mechanism beyond narrow phenomena.

results.title: Aging and associative recognition: A view from the DRYAD model of age-related memory deficits.
Aging and altruism: A meta-analysis.
Neuroprotective Effects of Intermittent Fasting in the Aging Brain.

theories.name: Calorie Restriction and Intermittent Fasting as Neuroprotective Aging Interventions

key_concepts.description: Calorie restriction (CR) and intermittent fasting (IF) are dietary strategies that alternate feeding and fasting periods, which have been shown in animal models to increase lifespan and slow age-related pathologies, suggesting a fundamental role in modulating aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Neuroprotection via metabolic and cellular pathways
key_concepts.description: IF may exert neuroprotective effects by influencing pathways that link nutrition and aging, potentially preserving brain function and delaying neurodegenerative disorders, indicating a mechanistic connection between dietary patterns and systemic aging of the brain.

Emerging evidence suggests that dietary interventions like IF could help maintain cognitive function in elderly individuals and offer a novel approach to prevent or treat dementia, implying a broader causal role of metabolic regulation in aging-related cognitive decline.

theories.evidence: Summary of animal model studies showing lifespan extension and delayed age-related diseases; references to recent research on dietary effects on dementia and brain function; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses general aging mechanisms via nutritional modulation, proposes causal pathways linking diet to aging and neurodegeneration, and discusses systemic effects beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Acarbose suppresses symptoms of mitochondrial disease in a mouse model of Leigh syndrome.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction is proposed as a fundamental molecular hallmark that contributes to the biological aging process, affecting organismal health and lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Shared mechanisms between mitochondrial disease and aging
key_concepts.description: Severe mitochondrial disorders and normative aging share underlying common mechanisms, suggesting that mitochondrial impairment drives systemic aging phenotypes.

Drugs like rapamycin and acarbose that extend lifespan and healthspan in normative aging models can also suppress symptoms and improve survival in mitochondrial disease models, implying a causal role of mitochondrial dysfunction in aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing that acarbose and rapamycin extend lifespan and delay neurological symptoms in Ndufs4-/- mice, a model of Leigh syndrome; microbiome remodeling and short-chain fatty acid supplementation experiments support mechanistic insights.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (mitochondrial dysfunction) underlying biological aging and severe mitochondrial disease, supported by mechanistic and intervention data; addresses aging broadly beyond a single disease.

results.title: Chromosome aneuploidy in Alzheimer's disease.

theories.name: Premature ageing hypothesis of Alzheimer's disease

key_concepts.concept: Chromosome aneuploidy as marker of aging
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis posits that increased chromosome aneuploidy, a condition where cells have abnormal numbers of chromosomes, is a hallmark of biological aging and is similarly elevated in Alzheimer's disease patients, suggesting a link between cellular aging processes and the disease.

This concept suggests that Alzheimer's disease represents a form of premature or accelerated aging, where the cellular and chromosomal changes typical of advanced age appear earlier and more prominently, rather than arising from a distinct biochemical defect specific to dementia.

The theory notes that no single chromosome is preferentially affected by aneuploidy in Alzheimer's disease, implying a generalized chromosomal instability associated with aging rather than a targeted genetic cause.

theories.evidence: Comparative cytogenetic analysis of lymphocyte chromosomes from Alzheimer's patients, age-matched controls, and older non-demented individuals showing similar patterns of chromosome aneuploidy in Alzheimer's patients and older controls.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation linking chromosome aneuploidy to systemic aging processes underlying Alzheimer's disease, addressing aging broadly rather than a narrow disease-specific mechanism.

results.title: Cellular senescence and neurodegeneration.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence refers to the state where cells irreversibly stop dividing and undergo distinctive phenotypic alterations. It is considered a fundamental aging hallmark that contributes to the decline in tissue function and organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells accumulation drives age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of senescent cells in tissues, including neurons and glial cells in the brain, promotes aging-associated pathologies such as Alzheimer's disease by disrupting tissue homeostasis and secreting pro-inflammatory factors.

key_concepts.concept: Selective elimination of senescent cells ameliorates aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Experimental removal of senescent cells in animal models reduces pathological features like amyloid beta and tau accumulation and improves cognitive function, supporting a causal role of senescence in aging and neurodegeneration.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies detecting senescent neurons and glial cells in AD patients and mouse models; experimental data showing that senescent cell clearance improves AD pathology and cognition in mice.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: generalizable to organism-level aging, proposes a causal mechanism (senescent cell accumulation causes aging and disease), and addresses aging broadly beyond a single disease by also discussing other neurodegenerative diseases.

results.title: Validation of the cumulative deficit theory in bariatric surgery: new bariatric frailty score is associated with non-home discharge, prolonged hospital stay and mortality in the era of fast-track bariatric surgery.

theories.name: Cumulative Deficit Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is explained as the progressive accumulation of health deficits, including diseases, disabilities, and physiological impairments, which collectively increase vulnerability and frailty.

key_concepts.concept: Frailty as a Measure of Biological Aging
key_concepts.description: Frailty is conceptualized as a syndrome reflecting biological aging, measurable by the cumulative deficit model, which aggregates multiple health variables into a single frailty index.
The theory posits that the combined effect of multiple co-morbidities on aging outcomes is greater than the simple sum of individual effects, indicating synergistic interactions among deficits.

theories.evidence: Analysis of 650,882 bariatric surgery patients using a newly developed Bariatric Frailty Score (BFS) mapped from the Canadian Study of Health and Aging-Frailty Index; statistical correlations and multivariate logistic regression showing BFS predicts postoperative adverse outcomes better than age or ASA score; propensity score matching confirming higher BFS associates with increased complications.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains why aging occurs via accumulation of deficits (generalizable to organism-level frailty), proposes causal mechanisms (deficit accumulation leading to vulnerability), and addresses aging broadly through frailty rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific focus.

results.title: Age-related neuronal damage by advanced glycation end products through altered proteostasis.

theories.name: Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) accumulation theory of brain aging

key_concepts.description: AGEs progressively accumulate in the brain with aging, contributing to neuronal damage. This accumulation is proposed as a fundamental aging-related process affecting brain function.

AGEs accumulation leads to disturbances in key cellular proteostasis systems including the ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS), unfolded protein response (UPR), and autophagy-lysosome system, which are critical for maintaining protein homeostasis in neurons.

An adaptive ER stress response occurs at mid-age (10 months), but maladaptive ER stress responses emerge at later ages (15-20 months), exacerbating cellular dysfunction and contributing to aging-related neuronal damage.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on neuronal growth factors and cell death
key_concepts.description: AGEs accumulation perturbs neurotrophic and presynaptic markers, leading to impaired neuronal growth and increased cell death, which are hallmarks of brain aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from immunoblotting analyses of brain tissues from WNIN rats at different ages (5, 10, 15, 20 months) showing progressive AGEs accumulation, ER stress markers, UPS and autophagy impairment, neuronal marker perturbations, histological staining indicating neuronal shrinkage and β-amyloid accumulation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining brain aging through AGEs accumulation affecting proteostasis and neuronal survival, addressing fundamental aging processes rather than a narrow disease focus.

results.title: Introduction: Historical Development and Progression of Clinical Research on Ageing.

theories.name: Evolutionary Theories of Aging

key_concepts.description: Proposes that aging results from evolutionary processes such as natural selection acting less strongly on traits expressed later in life, leading to accumulation of deleterious effects or trade-offs that impact organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Historical references to Darwin's contributions and the initiation of evolutionary explanations for aging; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain why aging occurs at an organismal level based on evolutionary logic, providing a causal framework beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Imagination and idealism in the medical sciences of an ageing world.

theories.name: Rate of Aging Control Paradigm

key_concepts.description: This concept prioritizes slowing down the biological aging process itself, rather than merely managing or eliminating diseases associated with old age. It emphasizes extending the human healthspan by targeting the fundamental mechanisms that drive aging.

The traditional medical paradigm focuses on controlling diseases, which has been effective in reducing early-life mortality from infectious diseases but is less successful in addressing chronic diseases of late life. This paradigm is considered myopic because it overlooks the intrinsic biological aging process that constrains health in late life.

The paradigm distinguishes between merely extending survival by managing multi-morbidities and frailty, and genuinely extending the period of healthy, functional life by controlling the rate of aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references the historical success of disease control in early-life mortality and its limitations in late-life chronic diseases, as well as the economic and disease burdens imposed by biological aging, but does not present new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paradigm attempts to explain why aging occurs at a biological level by focusing on the inborn aging process as a fundamental cause of late-life health decline. It proposes a causal mechanism (rate of aging) and addresses aging broadly at the organism level, meeting all core requirements of an aging theory.

results.title: Fine-tuning LLM hyperparameters to align semantic and physiological contexts of aging-related pathways.
Semaglutide as a possible therapy for healthy aging: Targeting the hallmarks of aging.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Chronic, low-grade inflammation is a key driver of aging and age-related functional decline. It contributes to tissue damage and systemic deterioration over time.
Accumulation of oxidative damage from reactive oxygen species leads to cellular and molecular dysfunction, promoting aging processes.
The decline in stem cell number and function reduces tissue regeneration capacity, contributing to organismal aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract mentions targeting these hallmarks with Semaglutide but does not present new experimental data; it is a conceptual discussion.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses general aging mechanisms (hallmarks) that are broadly applicable, proposes causal mechanisms (inflammation, oxidative stress, stem cell exhaustion), and is not limited to specific diseases or organs.

results.title: The African turquoise killifish (Nothobranchius furzeri): A model of age-related diseases and declining regenerative capability across multiple organs.
Deletion of Nrf1α exacerbates oxidative stress-induced cellular senescence by disrupting cell homeostasis.

theories.name: Cellular senescence as a causal driver of systemic aging

key_concepts.description: Cells enter a state of permanent growth arrest in response to stressors such as oxidative damage, contributing to organismal aging and age-related diseases.
Oxidative stress acts as a critical initiator of cellular senescence by damaging cellular components and disrupting homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Role of Nrf1α in maintaining cellular homeostasis
key_concepts.description: Nrf1α is a redox-regulating transcription factor essential for protecting cells against oxidative stress and preserving chromosomal stability and autophagy function, thereby preventing premature senescence.
Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory factors that exacerbate tissue dysfunction and aging processes.

theories.evidence: Experimental deletion of Nrf1α in cells leads to increased senescence markers (β-galactosidase activity, SASP), decreased vitality, cell cycle arrest, chromosomal instability, and autophagy dysfunction; also observed compensatory but insufficient Nrf2 accumulation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental aging process (cellular senescence) with mechanistic insights into oxidative stress and homeostasis disruption, proposing a causal role of Nrf1α in modulating senescence and thus aging.

results.title: A cross-sectional exploration of cognitive ability across age via stacked ensembles.
Effects of age on oxidative stress and locomotion in the pollinator, Megachile rotundata.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that aging results from the accumulation of oxidative damage caused by reactive oxygen species (free radicals) generated during metabolism, which impair cellular components over time.
Organisms possess antioxidant mechanisms to neutralize free radicals and mitigate damage; the balance between oxidative damage and antioxidant capacity influences the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Functional decline linked to oxidative stress
key_concepts.description: Age-related declines in physiological functions, such as locomotion, are hypothesized to be driven by increasing oxidative damage and insufficient antioxidant protection.

theories.evidence: Empirical data on age-related changes in oxidative damage and antioxidant capacity in Megachile rotundata, alongside measurements of locomotion (walking and flight) across lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process (oxidative damage accumulation), proposes causal mechanisms (free radicals causing damage leading to aging), and addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: Cardiac iron metabolism during aging - Role of inflammation and proteolysis.
Mitochondrial pathways and sarcopenia in the geroscience era.

theories.name: Mitochondrial quality control (MQC) theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial bioenergetics decline with age, leading to reduced muscle function and systemic physical performance. This dysfunction is proposed as a pivotal factor in muscle aging and sarcopenia.

MQC includes mitochondrial biogenesis, dynamics (fusion/fission), and mitophagy, which maintain mitochondrial and tissue health. Alterations in these processes contribute to aging phenotypes such as chronic inflammation, muscle atrophy, and dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: MQC as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Mitophagy and other MQC mechanisms have been recently recognized as hallmarks of aging, linking mitochondrial maintenance to systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: Correlative data from transcriptional profiling of muscle samples showing inverse correlations between autophagy/mitophagy gene expression and muscle volume/performance; associations of MQC alterations with inflammation and muscle dysfunction; citations of MQC as a hallmark of aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (mitochondrial dysfunction and MQC failure) underlying biological aging at the organism level, not limited to a single disease or organ but linked to systemic aging and physical decline.

results.title: Cancer-treatment-induced accelerated aging in older adult cancer survivors: A call for actions for future perspectives in geriatric oncology.

theories.name: Cancer-treatment-induced accelerated aging hypothesis

key_concepts.concept: Accelerated aging as a consequence of cancer treatment
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that cancer treatments can induce an accelerated aging process in older adult cancer survivors, leading to earlier onset of aging-related clinical and biological manifestations compared to cancer-free peers.

The hypothesis links cancer-treatment late effects such as frailty, sarcopenia, cognitive impairments, cellular senescence, telomere attrition, and chronic inflammation to established hallmarks of biological aging, suggesting a mechanistic overlap.
Older cancer survivors show increased levels of aging biomarkers and early onset of aging phenotypes, supporting the idea that cancer treatments may accelerate systemic aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Need for holistic and longitudinal research
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis emphasizes the importance of comprehensive geriatric assessments and large-scale longitudinal studies to understand mechanisms and health burdens of treatment-induced aging, aiming to improve interventions and care.

theories.evidence: Citations of clinical observations of early-onset frailty, sarcopenia, cognitive impairments, and elevated aging biomarkers in older cancer survivors compared to age-matched controls; references to parallels with hallmarks of aging; critique of current study limitations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for accelerated aging induced by cancer treatments, linking biological mechanisms (cellular senescence, telomere attrition, inflammation) to systemic aging processes in older adults; addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases.

results.title: Frailty biomarkers under the perspective of geroscience: A narrative review.

theories.name: Hallmarks of Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: Damage to mitochondrial DNA and overall genomic instability contribute to cellular aging and dysfunction, impacting organismal aging.
Progressive shortening of telomeres with cell division leads to cellular senescence and limits regenerative capacity, driving aging.
Changes in DNA methylation and other epigenetic marks alter gene expression patterns, contributing to aging phenotypes.
Impairment in protein folding and degradation systems leads to accumulation of damaged proteins, promoting cellular dysfunction.
Alterations in pathways sensing nutrients, such as IGF-1 and SIRT1 signaling, affect metabolism and aging processes.
Accumulation of senescent cells that secrete pro-inflammatory factors contributes to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging.
Decline in stem cell number and function reduces tissue regeneration and repair capacity during aging.
Changes in signaling between cells, including chronic inflammation, disrupt tissue homeostasis and accelerate aging.

theories.evidence: Narrative review of human studies associating biomarkers representing hallmarks of aging with frailty; mostly cross-sectional data from small samples; biomarkers include mitochondrial DNA copy number, telomere length, DNA methylation, Hsp70/72, IGF-1, SIRT1, GDF-15, inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, CRP, TNF-alpha), and immune cell markers.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses fundamental, general mechanisms of biological aging (hallmarks of aging) with causal explanations and broad organism-level relevance; connects biomarkers to frailty as a systemic aging phenotype.

results.title: Effects of Bacopa monnieri herbal supplement on aging and neurocognitive functions with relation to constitution (Prakriti) in healthy adults. Clinical trial protocol

theories.name: Programmed Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: This concept suggests that aging follows a predetermined biological schedule encoded in the genome, which regulates the timing of aging processes and lifespan.
Telomeres, protective caps at the ends of chromosomes, shorten with each cell division. When telomeres become critically short, cells enter senescence and stop dividing, contributing to aging.
Telomerase is an enzyme that maintains telomere length. Its activity decreases with age, leading to progressive telomere shortening and cellular senescence.

theories.evidence: The abstract references telomere shortening and telomerase activity as major elements of aging, and the study measures telomerase activity and telomere length as primary outcomes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism for aging applicable at the organism level, explaining why aging occurs via a programmed biological clock and cellular senescence.

theories.name: Error Theory of Aging (Damage Accumulation Theory)

key_concepts.description: Aging results from cumulative damage to cellular components caused by environmental factors such as oxidative stress, leading to functional decline.
Damage to DNA accumulates over time due to environmental insults and imperfect repair mechanisms, contributing to cellular dysfunction and aging.
With age, cells accumulate damaged proteins and other harmful substances that impair cellular function and promote aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract mentions environmental damage causing DNA damage and accumulation of harmful substances as a main theory of aging; the study aims to test an intervention that may stabilize aging-related changes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides a general causal explanation for aging based on damage accumulation affecting the organism broadly.

results.title: Football and Team Handball Training Postpone Cellular Aging in Women
Born to be young: prenatal thyroid hormones increase early-life telomere length

theories.name: Prenatal thyroid hormone regulation of biological aging theory

key_concepts.concept: Prenatal hormonal influence on aging markers
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that exposure to maternal thyroid hormones during embryogenesis can modulate molecular markers associated with aging, such as telomere length, thereby influencing the biological age set at birth.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length as a hallmark of aging
key_concepts.description: Telomere length decreases from early life to late adulthood, serving as a molecular marker of aging. The theory suggests that prenatal thyroid hormones can increase telomere length, potentially offsetting age-related telomere shortening.

The theory posits that prenatal environmental factors, specifically thyroid hormone levels, program the biological age of the organism at birth, which may have downstream effects on longevity and aging trajectories.

theories.evidence: Experimental manipulation of prenatal thyroid hormone levels in an avian model via egg injection; measurement of postnatal growth, mitochondrial DNA copy number, and telomere length at multiple life stages; observed significant increase in telomere length with elevated prenatal thyroid hormones.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism by which prenatal thyroid hormones influence aging at the organismal level through modulation of telomere length, a known aging hallmark; it addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific phenomenon.

results.title: Effects of prenatal testosterone on cumulative markers of oxidative damage to organs of young adult zebra finches (Taeniopygia guttata).

theories.name: Testosterone oxidative damage hypothesis

key_concepts.concept: Embryonic androgen exposure causes long-term oxidative damage
key_concepts.description: Exposure to elevated testosterone levels during embryonic development can lead to oxidative damage in vital organs later in life, suggesting a developmental origin of aging-related damage.

key_concepts.concept: Sex-specific effects on growth and oxidative damage
key_concepts.description: Testosterone exposure affects growth rates differently in males and females, which may translate into sex-specific patterns of oxidative damage accumulation in adulthood.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative damage as a mechanism linking early life conditions to aging
key_concepts.description: Oxidative damage to DNA and lipids in organs such as heart and liver serves as a mechanistic link between early developmental hormone exposure and aging-related cellular damage.

theories.evidence: Experimental injection of testosterone into zebra finch eggs, measurement of oxidative damage markers (8-oxo-2'-deoxyguanosine and isoprostanes) in heart and liver tissues at different ages, and monitoring of growth rates.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (oxidative damage induced by prenatal testosterone) explaining how early developmental factors influence aging processes at the organism level, with generalizable implications beyond the specific species studied.

results.title: Modulation of cGAS-STING Pathway by Nicotinamide Riboside in Alzheimer's Disease.

theories.name: cGAS-STING mediated inflammaging and senescence theory

key_concepts.concept: cGAS-STING pathway as a driver of neuroinflammation and senescence
key_concepts.description: The cyclic GMP-AMP synthase (cGAS) and stimulator of interferon genes (STING) pathway senses cytoplasmic DNA and triggers an interferon response that is characteristic of cellular senescence and chronic inflammation (inflammaging), particularly in brain tissue affected by Alzheimer's disease.

key_concepts.concept: Decline of NAD+ with aging contributes to impaired mitophagy and neuroinflammation
key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with a global decrease in nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+), which leads to reduced mitophagy (the selective degradation of mitochondria) and increased neuroinflammation, both hallmarks of aging that contribute to Alzheimer's disease progression.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation of NAD+ levels can attenuate aging-related cellular dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Augmentation of NAD+ through administration of nicotinamide riboside (NR) reduces cellular senescence, DNA damage, and neuroinflammation by normalizing cGAS-STING pathway activity, improving mitophagy, and enhancing cognitive and behavioral outcomes in an Alzheimer's disease mouse model.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from transgenic APP/PS1 murine model of Alzheimer's disease showing NR supplementation reduces senescence, DNA damage, neuroinflammation, normalizes elevated cGAS-STING signaling, increases mitophagy, and improves cognition and behavior; observations also include elevated cGAS-STING in human AD fibroblasts.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (cGAS-STING mediated inflammaging and senescence) underlying aging-related neurodegeneration, connects NAD+ decline to fundamental aging processes (mitophagy, inflammation), and addresses systemic aging features relevant beyond a single disease. The theory explains how aging processes cause cellular and organismal decline.

results.title: Hormetic Effects of Phytochemicals with Anti-Ageing Properties.
Emerging Pathophysiological Roles of Ketone Bodies.
Ion channel gene changes with inflammageing

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: This concept proposes that aging is associated with a persistent, low-level inflammatory state characterized by elevated cytokine levels, which contributes to the functional decline of multiple tissues and organs.

The theory suggests that increased inflammatory cytokines such as IL-1β and TNFα induce changes in gene expression, including ion channel genes, across diverse tissues, thereby linking inflammation to systemic aging processes.

theories.evidence: The paper uses two models: natural aging in rats examining ion channel gene expression changes in multiple tissues, and an in vitro inflammatory model exposing cells to IL-1β and TNFα to mimic inflammaging effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging (chronic inflammation) that affects multiple tissues and systems, explaining why aging occurs at an organismal level.

results.title: Hormetic Effect of 3-Bromopyruvate on Age-Induced Alterations in Erythrocyte Membrane Transporters and Oxidative Biomarkers in Rats.
Dietary Restriction, Cardiovascular Aging and Age-Related Cardiovascular Diseases: A Review of the Evidence.

theories.name: Dietary Restriction as a Modulator of Cardiovascular Aging

key_concepts.description: DR includes calorie restriction (CR) and alternate-day fasting (ADF), which are nutritional interventions shown to have anti-aging effects by modulating biological pathways involved in aging.

DR activates a network of cardiovascular protective signals including mTOR, AMP-activated kinase, sirtuins, and endothelial nitric oxide synthase, which interact through positive and negative feedback loops to mediate stress responses and potentially slow cardiovascular aging.

Cardiovascular aging contributes to increased morbidity and mortality from cardiovascular diseases, and DR is proposed as an intervention to control this aging process and manage cardiovascular health.

theories.evidence: The abstract references recent studies demonstrating DR's activation of protective cardiovascular signaling pathways and its anti-aging impacts, though specific experimental details are not provided in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how a fundamental intervention (dietary restriction) modulates aging processes at the organism level, specifically cardiovascular aging, by proposing underlying mechanisms involving key signaling pathways. It addresses aging broadly through cardiovascular aging as a driver of systemic aging and proposes causal mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Peptide location fingerprinting identifies species- and tissue-conserved structural remodelling of proteins as a consequence of ageing and disease.
Analysis of Different Strains of the Turquoise Killifish Identify Transcriptomic Signatures Associated With Heritable Lifespan Differences.
Calorie restriction mimetics against aging and inflammation.

theories.name: Calorie Restriction Mimetic Theory

key_concepts.description: Calorie restriction involves reducing calorie intake without malnutrition and has been shown to promote healthy aging and extend health span by ameliorating molecular, cellular, and physiological aging-related alterations.

key_concepts.concept: Mimicking CR Effects via Pharmacological Agents
key_concepts.description: Calorie Restriction Mimetics (CRMs) are compounds that replicate the beneficial effects of CR without requiring dietary changes, targeting key signaling pathways involved in aging such as insulin signaling, mTOR, AMPK activation, and stress response pathways.

CRMs act on pathways including insulin signaling (biguanides like metformin), mTOR signaling (rapamycin), stress signaling and mitochondrial metabolism (stilbenes like resveratrol), and modulation of free radical effects through glycolytic inhibitors, absorption blockers, polyamines, and polyphenols.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known compounds (metformin, rapamycin, resveratrol) and their molecular targets, summarizing existing knowledge about their mechanisms and potential geroprotective effects; no new experimental data is presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging by targeting fundamental aging pathways and mechanisms; it addresses aging broadly through molecular and physiological processes; it is not limited to a single organ or disease and discusses underlying mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: On the Paper by Leonid A. Gavrilov and Natalia S. Gavrilova entitled "Trends in Human Species-Specific Lifespan and Actuarial Aging Rate" Published in Biochemistry (Moscow), Vol. 87, Nos. 12-13, pp. 1622-1633 (2022).
Calorie restriction in nonhuman primates: mechanisms of reduced morbidity and mortality.

theories.name: Calorie Restriction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Sustained reduction in calorie intake without malnutrition leads to significant increases in median lifespan, as demonstrated in nonhuman primates. This suggests that calorie restriction slows fundamental aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Reduction of Morbidity via Metabolic Pathways
key_concepts.description: Calorie restriction prevents obesity and associated diseases such as diabetes by altering metabolic pathways, including glycogen synthesis and insulin signaling, which contribute to healthier aging.

The benefits of calorie restriction on morbidity and mortality do not require extreme leanness; maintaining body fat within a normal range is sufficient to achieve these effects, indicating a balanced metabolic state is key.

theories.evidence: Long-term study of adult-onset calorie restriction in nonhuman primates over 15 years, showing increased median lifespan, prevention of obesity and diabetes, and biochemical changes in glycogen synthesis and insulin response.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how reduced calorie intake slows aging and morbidity at the organismal level, supported by mechanistic insights and longitudinal data.

results.title: Age and Aging: Some Facts and a Lot of Hype.
Role of p66Shc gene in human longevity.

theories.name: p66Shc-mediated oxidative stress theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The p66Shc gene encodes a phosphotyrosine signal adapter protein that regulates reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels, influencing aging and lifespan. Genetic deficiency of p66Shc in mice extends lifespan by approximately 30%, indicating its role as a genetic determinant of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress as a causal mechanism in aging
key_concepts.description: p66Shc modulates oxidative stress, which is implicated in age-related dysfunctions and diseases such as high cholesterol, diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases. The theory posits that oxidative damage regulated by p66Shc contributes causally to the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: p66Shc as a target for intervention
key_concepts.description: Understanding the role of p66Shc could lead to novel therapeutic strategies aimed at slowing or curing age-related pathologies by modulating oxidative stress pathways.

theories.evidence: Genetic deficiency of p66Shc in murine models extends lifespan by 30%; involvement in regulation of ROS and age-related dysfunctions; references to oxidative stress involvement in human diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (oxidative stress regulation via p66Shc) underlying aging at the organismal level, supported by genetic and physiological evidence, and connects to systemic aging and age-related diseases.

results.title: Low-dose ionizing radiation increases the lifespan of Drosophila melanogaster under oxidative stress conditions through AKT/SOD regulation.

theories.name: Oxidative stress and AKT-mediated lifespan extension theory

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress as a major cause of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) leads to cellular damage contributing to aging. Managing oxidative stress is thus central to modulating lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Low-dose ionizing radiation (LDIR) induces protective responses
key_concepts.description: Exposure to low doses of ionizing radiation can activate cellular pathways that reduce oxidative damage, thereby extending lifespan and improving physiological functions under stress.

key_concepts.concept: AKT pathway activation mediates lifespan extension
key_concepts.description: Activation of the AKT signaling pathway by LDIR leads to increased activity of antioxidant enzymes such as superoxide dismutase (SOD), reducing ROS accumulation and promoting survival under oxidative stress.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing that 0.05 Gy LDIR extends lifespan and improves locomotion in Drosophila; decreased ROS levels and pro-apoptotic mRNA; increased SOD activity; AKT pathway activation; inhibition of AKT suppresses LDIR effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (AKT-mediated control of oxidative stress) explaining how aging can be modulated at the organism level, with generalizable concepts about oxidative damage and signaling pathways affecting lifespan.

results.title: Is Longevity a Heritable Trait? Evidence for Non-genomic Influence from an Extended Longevity Phenotype of Drosophila melanogaster.
Declining immunity with age in the wild.
Exploring the heterogeneous targets of metabolic aging at single-cell resolution.
D-amino acids in aging erythrocytes.
The Naked Mole-Rat as a Model for Healthy Aging.

theories.name: Delayed aging and resistance to age-related diseases in naked mole-rats

key_concepts.description: Naked mole-rats exhibit a delayed aging phenotype characterized by the absence of increased mortality with age and maintenance of physiological functions until near the end of their lifespan.
Naked mole-rats rarely develop common age-associated diseases such as cancer and Alzheimer's disease, suggesting mechanisms that protect against these pathologies.
Living in hypoxic underground environments, naked mole-rats have evolved high tolerance to low oxygen conditions, which may contribute to their longevity and healthy aging.
The paper discusses possible biological mechanisms underlying the naked mole-rats’ delayed aging and disease resistance, aiming to elucidate general principles of healthy aging.

theories.evidence: Summary of previous studies on ecology, hypoxia tolerance, longevity, delayed aging, and cancer resistance in naked mole-rats; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses aging broadly at the organism level, proposes mechanisms contributing to delayed aging and disease resistance, and discusses generalizable principles underlying healthy aging.

results.title: Developing a research agenda in biogerontology: physiological systems.
Relationship between antioxidants, lipid peroxidation and aging.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging (Oxidative Stress Theory)

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging is influenced by the balance between antioxidants and prooxidants (free radicals) in the body. Maintaining an appropriate balance is crucial for health during aging, as oxidative damage from free radicals can accumulate and contribute to aging and disease susceptibility.

A continuous presence of small amounts of free radicals in adult tissues leads to a progressive, rather than accelerated, aging process. This oxidative stress contributes to the gradual decline in physiological function over time.

The antioxidant defense system is under homeostatic regulation, similar to prokaryotes, which may explain why antioxidant capacity does not necessarily decrease with age. This control mechanism influences how antioxidant supplementation might affect endogenous antioxidant levels.

theories.evidence: Experimental results from multiple species (flies, rats, frogs) showing inconclusive changes in antioxidant defenses with age; physiological observations of aging rates; suggestion for controlled antioxidant supplementation studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general, organism-level causal mechanism explaining aging through oxidative damage and antioxidant balance. It addresses fundamental aging processes, not limited to specific organs or diseases, and discusses underlying mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Mitochondrial bioenergetics, aging, and aging-related disease.

theories.name: Mitochondrial bioenergetics theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: This concept posits that alterations in mitochondrial function, including impaired bioenergetics, contribute causally to the aging process by reducing cellular energy production and increasing cellular damage.

key_concepts.concept: Bioenergetic consequences linked to aging-related diseases
key_concepts.description: Changes in mitochondrial energy metabolism are hypothesized to underlie not only general aging but also the pathogenesis of aging-related diseases, especially neurodegenerative disorders.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses hypothesized associations between mitochondrial function alterations and human aging, with a special focus on neurodegenerative disease; no new experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain why aging occurs at an organismal level by proposing mitochondrial bioenergetic decline as a causal mechanism; it is generalizable beyond specific diseases and addresses broad aging processes.

results.title: Splice age: mTORC1-mediated RNA splicing in metabolism and ageing.

theories.name: mTORC1-mediated regulation of aging via RNA splicing

key_concepts.description: The mTORC1 complex is a central regulator of cell growth and metabolism, and its inhibition has been shown to delay aging processes. This positions mTORC1 as a key upstream modulator of longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Role of pre-mRNA splicing factors and alternative splicing
key_concepts.description: Modulation of pre-mRNA splicing factors and alternative splicing events are proposed as critical downstream mediators of mTORC1 signaling. Changes in RNA splicing patterns can influence gene expression programs that affect organismal lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Link between mTORC1, RNA splicing, and longevity
key_concepts.description: Recent evidence from Caenorhabditis elegans suggests that mTORC1 affects longevity by regulating RNA splicing machinery, implying a mechanistic pathway connecting metabolic signaling to aging through RNA processing.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent work by Ogawa et al. in C. elegans demonstrating that modulation of splicing factors and alternative splicing mediate mTORC1 signaling effects on longevity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process by proposing a causal mechanism (mTORC1 signaling modulating RNA splicing) that affects organismal aging and longevity. It is generalizable beyond a single tissue or disease, addressing systemic aging regulation.

results.title: Crosstalk between gut microbiota and cellular senescence: a vicious cycle leading to aging gut.

theories.name: Cellular senescence-gut microbiota vicious cycle theory

key_concepts.description: The buildup of senescent cells in tissues, which contributes to aging by impairing biological functions and promoting age-related diseases.
Age-associated changes in the composition and diversity of gut microbiota that disrupt gut homeostasis and immune function.

key_concepts.concept: Bidirectional crosstalk between gut microbiota and cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: Gut bacteria induce cellular senescence in ileal germinal center B cells, leading to decreased IgA production and diversity, which in turn causes an imbalance in gut microbiota, establishing a vicious cycle that exacerbates aging-related gut dysfunction.
The host immune system acts as a mediator in the interaction between gut microbiota and cellular senescence, influencing gut homeostasis and aging.

theories.evidence: Recent reports of gut bacteria inducing cellular senescence in ileal germinal center B cells with consequent effects on IgA production and microbiota imbalance; conceptual linkage of these phenomena into a vicious cycle contributing to aging gut homeostasis disruption.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking cellular senescence and gut microbiota changes to systemic aging processes via immune system interactions; explains how aging occurs at organismal level through gut homeostasis disruption; not limited to a single disease but addresses a fundamental aging-related decline.

results.title: Cellular senescence in normal physiology.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells as causal drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate with age and contribute to the decline in tissue function and organismal aging through secretion of pro-inflammatory factors and alteration of tissue microenvironments.

While traditionally associated with aging and age-related pathology, senescent cells also have beneficial physiological roles, such as in wound healing, development, and tumor suppression, indicating a complex role in organismal biology.

theories.evidence: The abstract references the association of senescent cells with aging and their physiological roles, implying a review or discussion of existing literature rather than new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process at the organismal level by proposing cellular senescence as a causal mechanism with systemic effects. It addresses general aging, not limited to specific organs or diseases, and discusses mechanisms underlying aging.

results.title: Help available--phenomenological models for research on aging.
Targeting Alternative Splicing for Reversal of Cellular Senescence in the Context of Aesthetic Aging.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is a state of stable cell cycle arrest that accumulates with age and contributes causally to cellular, tissue, and organismal aging. Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory factors and disrupt tissue function, thereby promoting aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Targeted removal or rejuvenation of senescent cells
key_concepts.description: Removing or reversing senescent cells can improve healthspan and lifespan, as demonstrated in animal models. This suggests senescence is not merely correlated with aging but causally involved.

key_concepts.concept: Dysregulation of alternative splicing as a molecular mechanism underpinning senescence
key_concepts.description: Emerging evidence indicates that altered regulation of alternative splicing may drive the senescent state. Restoring proper splicing regulation could represent a novel therapeutic avenue to reverse senescence and its aging effects.

theories.evidence: Citations of animal model studies showing benefits of senescent cell removal; in vitro and in vivo trials of senescent cell targeting strategies; emerging molecular data on alternative splicing dysregulation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental, organism-level aging process; proposes causal mechanisms (senescence and splicing dysregulation); addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Meeting report--44th Annual Drosophila Research Conference.
Mitochondria, Autophagy and Inflammation: Interconnected in Aging.

theories.name: Mitochondrial-autophagy-inflammation aging theory

key_concepts.description: Abnormalities in mitochondrial metabolism contribute to aging by disrupting cellular energy homeostasis and promoting harmful metabolic byproducts that affect cellular function.

Mitochondrial autophagy (mitophagy) and biogenesis are critical for maintaining mitochondrial quality control, and their dysregulation leads to accumulation of damaged mitochondria, which exacerbates aging processes.
Age-related changes in inflammatory signaling pathways, particularly involving cytosolic receptors such as NLRP3 and cGAS, drive chronic inflammation that contributes to systemic aging.

Expansion of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) and their production of methyl-glyoxal, an immunosuppressive metabolite, are negatively regulated by mitochondrial autophagy and metabolic pathways, linking immune dysfunction to aging.

theories.evidence: Discussion based on known molecular players (NLRP3, cGAS, MDSCs, methyl-glyoxal) and their regulation by mitochondrial autophagy and metabolism; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism linking mitochondrial dysfunction, autophagy, and inflammation to systemic aging processes; addresses fundamental aging mechanisms beyond specific diseases or organs.

results.title: Resetting the Aging Clock: Implications for Managing Age-Related Diseases.

theories.name: Circadian Dysfunction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: The endogenous circadian system orchestrates molecular, physiological, and behavioral rhythms that coordinate functions across tissues and organs, playing a fundamental role in maintaining organismal homeostasis and health.

key_concepts.concept: Circadian disruption accelerates aging and disease risk
key_concepts.description: Disruption or desynchronization of circadian oscillators increases the risk of diseases and appears to accelerate the aging process, suggesting a causal role of circadian dysfunction in systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Bidirectional interaction between aging and circadian function
key_concepts.description: Aging weakens circadian function, which in turn aggravates age-related diseases and pathologies, indicating a feedback loop where aging and circadian dysfunction exacerbate each other.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic potential of reinforcing circadian rhythms
key_concepts.description: Behavioral and pharmacological interventions aimed at reinforcing circadian rhythms may promote healthy aging and mitigate age-related diseases, highlighting the circadian system as a target for aging management.

theories.evidence: Summary of molecular and structural organization of circadian system in mammals and humans; examples from mammalian research models and humans; evaluation of technological and societal factors contributing to circadian disorders; discussion of behavioral and pharmacological interventions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging involving circadian system dysfunction affecting organism-level aging processes; addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases; discusses mechanisms and interventions linked to aging.

results.title: Restoring resident tissue macrophages to combat aging and cancer.

theories.name: Resident Tissue Macrophage Dysfunction Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Resident Tissue Macrophage (RTM) Loss and Dysfunction
key_concepts.description: With aging, there is a dysfunction and loss of RTMs in certain tissues, which leads to increased local inflammation, compromised tissue health, and contributes to tumorigenesis. This concept posits that RTM perturbations are a key driver of tissue aging and related disease.

key_concepts.concept: Abnormal RTM Genesis from Bone Marrow
