key_concepts.description: A defining hallmark of aging is the abnormal generation of RTMs from the bone marrow, which affects both healthy and unhealthy aging processes. This suggests that changes in myelopoiesis with age disrupt the maintenance and function of RTMs.

key_concepts.concept: Restoration of RTMs as Therapeutic Strategy
key_concepts.description: Restoring RTMs by reshaping their tissue niche to rescue local self-renewal or by rejuvenating aging-associated myelopoiesis in the bone marrow is proposed as a major intervention to promote healthy aging and combat aging-related diseases such as cancer.

theories.evidence: The paper summarizes existing work supporting the conceptual framework linking RTM dysfunction to aging and cancer, citing studies on RTM biology, aging-associated myelopoiesis, and inflammation; no new experimental data is presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging at the organismal level involving immune system aging, specifically RTM dysfunction and altered myelopoiesis, which affects tissue health and cancer risk. It addresses a fundamental aging process rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific phenomenon.

results.title: Risky moves.
Resistance training rejuvenates the mitochondrial methylome in aged human skeletal muscle.
Rpl13a snoRNAs-regulated NADPH oxidase 1-dependent ROS generation: A novel RBC pathway mediating complement C3a deposition and triggering thrombosis in aging and venous blood clotting disorders.
A systematic review of lifespan studies in rodents using stem cell transplantations.

theories.name: Stem cell aging theory

key_concepts.description: Aging involves the decline in the function of stem cell populations throughout the body, characterized by reduced self-renewal, differentiation capacity, and regenerative ability, which contributes to systemic organismal aging and functional decline.

key_concepts.concept: Stem cell dysfunction as a driver of organismal aging
key_concepts.description: The decreased ability of stem cells to maintain tissue homeostasis and repair damage leads to progressive organ dysfunction and increased susceptibility to age-related diseases, positioning stem cell aging as a causal mechanism in overall biological aging.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic potential of young stem cell transplantation
key_concepts.description: Supplementing aged organisms with young stem cells may delay tissue aging, reduce frailty, and extend healthspan and lifespan, suggesting that stem cell rejuvenation can modify the aging process.

theories.evidence: Systematic review of 21 rodent studies involving stem cell transplantation, with 18 studies showing significant lifespan extension and 7 showing reduced frailty and aging complications.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for organismal aging based on stem cell functional decline, addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases, and discusses interventions that test the theory.

results.title: Pivotal role of AGE-RAGE axis in brain aging with current interventions.

theories.name: AGE-RAGE axis theory of brain aging

key_concepts.description: AGEs are metabolic byproducts formed endogenously via non-enzymatic reactions or acquired from diet/exogenous sources. Their accumulation in brain tissue contributes to cellular damage, neurodegeneration, and cognitive decline.
AGEs bind to the receptor for advanced glycation end products (RAGE), triggering pro-inflammatory pathways, oxidative stress, and neuroinflammation, which impair neuronal function and cognition.

Activation of AGE-RAGE signaling induces programmed cell death, disrupts the blood-brain barrier, and promotes protein aggregation, all of which exacerbate brain aging and neurodegenerative processes.

theories.evidence: Citations of biochemical and molecular studies showing AGE accumulation, RAGE signaling effects, and interventions reducing AGE deposition; references to pharmacological, dietary, and lifestyle interventions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism explaining brain aging at the organism level via metabolic byproducts and receptor-mediated pathways; addresses fundamental processes like inflammation, oxidative stress, and cell death contributing to aging; not limited to a single disease but to brain aging broadly.

results.title: Role of the gut-muscle axis in mitochondrial function of ageing muscle under different exercise modes.
Reproductive Ageing: Unlocking the secrets of reproductive longevity: the potential of social insects.
Cell senescence in liver diseases: pathological mechanism and theranostic opportunity.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: A state of persistent proliferation arrest in cells accompanied by a specific secretory phenotype (senescence-associated secretory phenotype, SASP). Senescent cells accumulate with age and contribute to tissue dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells as drivers of aging and disease
key_concepts.description: While senescent cells have physiological roles, their accumulation due to aging or pathological conditions promotes damage and progression of chronic diseases, linking cellular senescence causally to organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on liver aging and disease
key_concepts.description: Senescence affects hepatic cells' phenotype and function, worsening liver disease prognosis and contributing to age-related hepatic deregulations.

theories.evidence: Summary of pathophysiological events involving hepatic senescent cells and their role in liver disease progression; discussion of geroscience therapies targeting senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (cellular senescence) explaining aging at the organismal level, generalizable beyond liver to systemic aging, and discusses underlying biological processes.

results.title: Liquid-liquid phase separation of RBM33 facilitates hippocampus aging by inducing microglial senescence by activating CDKN1A.

theories.name: Microglial senescence as a driver of hippocampal aging via RBM33 LLPS/p21cip1 axis

key_concepts.description: Microglia, the brain's resident immune cells, undergo senescence which contributes to aging of the hippocampus and associated cognitive decline. Senescent microglia exhibit functional impairments that negatively impact hippocampus-dependent memory.

RBM33 protein undergoes LLPS, a biophysical process forming membraneless condensates, which is essential for its function in regulating gene expression related to aging. This phase separation enables RBM33 to bind the promoter of CDKN1A (p21cip1) in a non-canonical transcriptional regulatory manner.

key_concepts.concept: Activation of CDKN1A (p21cip1) leading to senescence
key_concepts.description: RBM33 LLPS facilitates transcriptional activation of CDKN1A, a cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor known to induce cellular senescence. This activation promotes microglial senescence, thereby accelerating hippocampal aging and cognitive decline.

theories.evidence: Genetic deletion of RBM33 in hippocampus alleviates age-related cognitive decline in mice; overexpression exacerbates decline. In vitro and cellular assays demonstrate RBM33 LLPS and its binding to CDKN1A promoter. Behavioral and molecular data support the causal role of RBM33 LLPS/p21 axis in microglial senescence and hippocampal aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (RBM33 LLPS activating p21 to induce microglial senescence) explaining a fundamental aging process (hippocampal aging and cognitive decline) at the organismal level. It generalizes microglial senescence as a driver of brain aging, not limited to a narrow disease or organ-specific pathology.

results.title: Causal linkage of psoriasis with ageing: Mendelian randomization and enrichment analysis towards telomere length and psoriasis.

theories.name: Telomere Length Shortening as a Causal Mechanism of Aging and Disease

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length as a biomarker of biological aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres shorten with cell division and stress, reflecting biological age rather than chronological age. Shortened telomeres are linked to cellular senescence and organismal aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Causal relationship between telomere length and systemic disease
key_concepts.description: Shortened telomeres may causally increase risk for systemic diseases such as psoriasis, suggesting that telomere attrition contributes to disease pathogenesis and aging-related decline.

key_concepts.concept: Bidirectional genetic association between telomere length and psoriasis
key_concepts.description: Genetic predisposition to shorter telomeres increases psoriasis risk, and conversely, psoriasis genetic risk influences telomere length, indicating a feedback mechanism linking aging processes and immune-mediated disease.

theories.evidence: Mendelian randomization analyses showing statistically significant bidirectional causal associations between genetically predicted telomere length and psoriasis risk, controlling for confounders such as BMI, smoking, and alcohol consumption.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (telomere shortening) underlying biological aging and links it to systemic disease risk, with genetic evidence supporting causality and bidirectional effects. The theory is generalizable beyond psoriasis to aging and immune function.

results.title: Immunosenescence as a convergence pathway in neurodegeneration.

theories.name: Immunosenescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Immunosenescence refers to the gradual deterioration of the immune system associated with aging, characterized by remodeling of lymphoid organs and altered immune cell function, leading to increased susceptibility to infections, autoimmune diseases, and malignancies.

A chronic, low-grade systemic inflammatory state that develops with age, driven by persistent immune activation and senescent cell secretions, which contributes to tissue damage and age-related diseases.

The interaction between peripheral immunosenescence and central nervous system inflammation, where immune dysregulation promotes chronic neuroinflammation, contributing to neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's disease.

theories.evidence: Citations of contemporary experimental reports on senescent cell removal improving healthspan; references to cytokine-mediated glial activation and TNF-α elevation linked to cognitive decline; literature on immunosenescence's role in neurodegeneration.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging of the immune system contributes to systemic aging and neurodegeneration, addressing fundamental aging processes beyond specific diseases.

results.title: Repeated activation of Gαq has a detrimental impact on C. elegans in an age-dependent manner.
Epigenetic networks driving T cell identity and plasticity during immunosenescence.
Toward precision interventions and metrics of inflammaging.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Inflammaging is characterized by a persistent, systemic, low-level inflammatory state that increases with age and contributes causally to the development of multiple age-related diseases and aging processes.

The theory posits that inflammaging arises from an individual's unique lifelong exposures to inflammatory stimuli, influenced by genetics, lifestyle, socioeconomic status, infections, and environmental factors such as pollution, resulting in personalized aging trajectories.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammatory clocks as biomarkers of aging
key_concepts.description: Development of inflammatory clocks that quantify 'inflammatory age' provides a measurable metric that correlates strongly with age-related disease incidence and intersects with other biological aging clocks, linking inflammation mechanistically to systemic aging.

The theory supports that interventions such as nutritional changes, physical activity, and gerotherapies like senolytics can modulate inflammaging, potentially altering aging trajectories and improving healthspan.

theories.evidence: Discussion of inflammatory clocks with associations to age-related diseases, references to gerotherapies including senolytics, and consideration of environmental and genetic factors shaping inflammaging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging (chronic inflammation), addresses systemic aging rather than a single organ or disease, and links underlying causes (inflammatory stimuli, genetics, environment) to aging processes.

results.title: Stem Cell Aging in Lifespan and Disease: A State-of-the-Art Review.

theories.name: Stem Cell Exhaustion Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Stem cell role in tissue maintenance and regeneration
key_concepts.description: Adult stem cells replenish dying cells and regenerate injured tissues, maintaining normal tissue function and organ homeostasis, which is crucial for organismal health and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Age-related decline in stem cell function
key_concepts.description: With aging, stem cells undergo detrimental changes including alterations in their microenvironment, reduced regenerative capacity, and loss of function, contributing to the aging of organs and tissues.

key_concepts.concept: Stem cell exhaustion as a driver of systemic aging
key_concepts.description: The decline and dysfunction of adult stem cells with age is proposed as a fundamental mechanism underlying organismal aging and increased susceptibility to age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing age-related changes in stem cells across multiple tissues (skin, muscles, brain, heart, hair follicles, liver, lung) and links these changes to aging and disease risk, citing existing literature.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining how aging occurs at the organism level via stem cell decline; it addresses systemic aging rather than a narrow phenomenon; it discusses causal mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Multi-omics strategies to decode the molecular landscape of cellular senescence.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Senescent cells enter a stable, irreversible cell cycle arrest in response to various stressors, preventing their proliferation. This arrest is primarily regulated by the p53/p21 and p16INK4a/Rb pathways, which respond to DNA damage, oxidative stress, and oncogenic signals.

Senescent cells remain metabolically active and secrete a complex mixture of cytokines, growth factors, and proteases known as SASP. While SASP can promote tissue repair and regeneration, persistent SASP contributes to chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and tissue dysfunction, thereby driving age-related pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of Senescent Cells with Age
key_concepts.description: Over time, senescent cells accumulate in tissues, disrupting tissue homeostasis through their secretory activity. This accumulation is implicated as a causal driver of aging and age-related diseases, linking cellular senescence mechanistically to organismal aging.

theories.evidence: The paper integrates recent multi-omics data (metabolomics, proteomics, lipidomics) revealing molecular changes in senescent cells, highlighting biomarkers and therapeutic targets. It discusses regulatory pathways and functional consequences of senescence with citations to prior studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how cellular senescence contributes to organismal aging, discusses underlying pathways and systemic effects, and connects cellular processes to age-related dysfunction.

results.title: Aging: Disease or "natural" process? A glimpse from regenerative medicine.

theories.name: Aging as a treatable biological process distinct from disease

key_concepts.concept: Aging as a global multifactorial biological process
key_concepts.description: Aging is considered a complex, multifactorial process affecting the organism as a whole, involving various biological mechanisms rather than a single cause.
The paper debates whether aging should be classified as a disease or a natural process, emphasizing the difficulty in defining the boundary between normal aging and pathological states.

Despite aging not being labeled strictly as a disease, it is proposed as a treatable condition with emerging interventions such as Metformin, Rapamycin, and cellular therapies that may modulate aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: References to mechanistic explanations, blood-based biomarkers, inclusion of old age in disease classification, and examples of anti-aging interventions (Metformin, Rapamycin, cellular therapy).
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper addresses aging broadly as a fundamental biological process and discusses mechanistic explanations and interventions, meeting criteria for generalizability, causal explanation, and scope. However, it does not propose a new specific mechanistic theory but rather discusses the conceptual framing of aging.

results.title: Sirtuins: nodes connecting aging, metabolism and tumorigenesis.

theories.name: Sirtuin-mediated regulation of aging

key_concepts.description: Sirtuins, particularly Sir2 in yeast, function as NAD⁺-dependent histone deacetylases, which influence gene silencing mechanisms. This enzymatic activity is linked to lifespan extension by modulating chromatin structure and gene expression.

key_concepts.concept: Conservation and diversification of sirtuin functions
key_concepts.description: While Sir2 extends lifespan in yeast, mammals have seven sirtuin homologs (SIRT1-7) with diverse cellular locations and molecular functions. These proteins target a wide range of molecules for post-translational modifications, suggesting a broad regulatory role in physiology.

key_concepts.concept: Sirtuins as integrators of aging, metabolism, and tumorigenesis
key_concepts.description: Sirtuins are proposed as nodes connecting aging processes with metabolic regulation and cancer biology, indicating that their activity may influence systemic aging and disease states through multiple pathways.

theories.evidence: The paper summarizes prior research on sirtuins, including their enzymatic activity, roles in longevity in yeast, and functional diversity in mammals. It also discusses ambiguous roles in cancer, referencing existing studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging mechanism via sirtuin activity affecting gene regulation and metabolism, which is generalizable beyond specific diseases or organs. It proposes causal mechanisms (histone deacetylation, post-translational modifications) that influence aging and longevity, meeting the core criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Chronic kidney disease and aging: dissecting the p53/p21 pathway as a therapeutic target.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The p53 protein acts as a transcription factor and tumor suppressor that responds to cellular stress and damage. Persistent activation of p53 induces expression of p21, a cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor, which halts the cell cycle and triggers cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of tissue aging
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulate in aging tissues such as the kidney, altering the tissue microenvironment and impairing organ function. This accumulation reduces regenerative capacity and promotes fibrosis and inflammation, thereby accelerating age-related functional decline.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on organ-level aging and disease progression
key_concepts.description: In the aging kidney, increased senescence via the p53/p21 pathway diminishes recovery from injury and promotes progression of chronic kidney disease, linking cellular senescence mechanisms to systemic aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing literature on the role of the p53/p21 pathway in cellular senescence and its impact on kidney aging and chronic kidney disease progression. It also discusses emerging therapeutic strategies targeting this pathway.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory explains a fundamental biological aging process (cellular senescence) with generalizable mechanisms (p53/p21 pathway) that affect organ and organismal aging. It provides causal explanations linking molecular pathways to aging phenotypes and disease progression, meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Twins, Telomeres, and Aging-in Space!

theories.name: Telomere Attrition Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere Length as a Biomarker of Aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres are repetitive nucleotide sequences at chromosome ends that shorten with each cell division and due to various stresses, serving as a molecular clock reflecting cellular aging and organismal aging trajectories.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere Dynamics Influenced by Environmental Stressors
key_concepts.description: Environmental factors, including spaceflight-associated stresses such as radiation and microgravity, can alter telomere length dynamics, potentially accelerating or modulating aging processes at the cellular and systemic level.
Chromosomal aberrations and radiation-induced genomic instability contribute to aging by promoting cellular dysfunction and senescence, linking DNA damage responses to systemic aging mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Longitudinal telomere length and telomerase activity measurements in identical twins during and after spaceflight; chromosome aberration analyses indicating radiation exposure and genome instability.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper addresses a fundamental aging mechanism (telomere attrition) with generalizable implications beyond the specific context of spaceflight. It proposes causal mechanisms linking telomere dynamics and genome instability to aging, supported by empirical data. Although focused on a unique environment, the theory is applicable to organism-level aging processes.

results.title: Roles for SUMO modification during senescence.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence refers to the irreversible loss of cell replication potential, which accumulates with age and contributes to organismal aging by impairing tissue function and regeneration.

SUMOylation, a reversible post-translational modification, modulates protein activity, localization, and interactions, influencing the onset of cellular senescence by either promoting or hindering growth arrest.
Proteomic and transcriptomic analyses reveal increased global protein SUMOylation and decreased SUMO pathway components in aged tissues, suggesting a dynamic role of SUMOylation in the aging process.

theories.evidence: Preliminary comparative proteomics and mRNA data from young and old human and murine tissues showing altered SUMOylation levels with age; references to SUMO E3 ligase and SUMO-specific peptidase roles in senescence onset.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general mechanism (cellular senescence) causally linked to aging at the organismal level, discusses underlying molecular regulation (SUMOylation), and connects molecular changes to aging broadly rather than a specific disease or organ.

results.title: A new clinical age of aging research.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the buildup of senescent cells in tissues contributes causally to aging by impairing tissue function and promoting chronic inflammation.
Targeting and removing senescent cells (senolytics) can potentially alleviate aging phenotypes and improve healthspan, supporting the causal role of senescence in aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references research on senescent cell targeting as a key clinical area, implying discussion of experimental and translational studies in this field.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general causal mechanism of aging at the organism level, proposes underlying causes (senescent cells), and is discussed from a clinical translational perspective.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven in part by persistent, systemic inflammation that contributes to tissue dysfunction and age-related diseases.
Therapeutic strategies aimed at reducing inflammaging may slow aging processes and improve health outcomes.

theories.evidence: The abstract highlights alleviation of inflammaging as a clinical research area, suggesting discussion of evidence linking inflammation to aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general mechanism contributing to aging and is considered at the organismal level.

theories.name: Metabolic optimization theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is influenced by metabolic changes, and optimizing metabolism through endogenous metabolites or precursors can modulate aging processes.
Using metabolic interventions to restore or enhance metabolic homeostasis may attenuate aging and improve healthspan.

theories.evidence: The abstract mentions optimization of metabolism with endogenous metabolites or precursors as a clinical research focus, implying discussion of metabolic interventions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a broad mechanism of aging and proposes causal metabolic influences on aging.

results.title: Dysregulated Phenylalanine Catabolism Plays a Key Role in the Trajectory of Cardiac Aging.

theories.name: Dysregulated Phenylalanine Catabolism as a Driver of Cardiac Aging

key_concepts.concept: Elevated plasma phenylalanine levels with aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with a progressive increase in plasma phenylalanine levels, which correlates with cardiac dysfunction. This suggests that phenylalanine metabolism changes systemically during aging.

key_concepts.concept: Link between phenylalanine catabolism and cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: Dysregulated phenylalanine catabolism promotes cellular senescence in cardiac tissue, contributing to age-related cardiac deterioration. The study shows that phenylalanine treatment induces premature cardiac aging phenotypes and senescence markers.

Age-related decline in hepatic phenylalanine catabolism leads to elevated plasma phenylalanine, which in turn affects the heart. Increased myocardial PAH-mediated phenylalanine catabolism is identified as a novel signature of cardiac aging, indicating organ cross-talk in systemic aging.

Restoring phenylalanine catabolism pharmacologically or via dietary restriction reverses cardiac senescent alterations, suggesting a causal role of phenylalanine metabolism dysregulation in cardiac aging and a potential intervention strategy.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from wild-type and p21 knockout mice, phenylalanine treatment in young mice, pharmacological and dietary interventions, in vitro studies on cardiomyocytes and hepatocytes, and human sample observations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism linking systemic metabolic dysregulation (phenylalanine catabolism) to cellular senescence and organ-level aging (cardiac aging). It addresses a fundamental aging process beyond a single disease and includes mechanistic insights and intervention tests.

results.title: Inflammatory age and its impact on age-related health in older Chinese adults.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that persistent, systemic, low-level inflammation contributes causally to the aging process and age-related functional decline. This inflammation, termed 'inflammaging,' is thought to underlie multiple age-associated diseases and metabolic dysfunctions.

key_concepts.concept: Inflammatory biomarkers as indicators of biological aging
key_concepts.description: Specific inflammatory markers such as white blood cell count, neutrophils, monocytes, and albumin levels reflect the inflammatory burden that correlates with biological aging. These markers can be integrated into a composite measure to quantify the inflammatory component of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Link between inflammation and telomere length
key_concepts.description: Inflammation is associated with telomere shortening, which is a hallmark of cellular aging. The theory suggests that inflammatory processes may accelerate telomere attrition, thereby promoting systemic aging.

theories.evidence: The paper introduces a novel composite measure called inflammatory age (iAge) based on inflammatory markers and shows statistical associations between iAge and telomere length, metabolic dysfunctions, and risks of age-related diseases in an older Chinese cohort.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (inflammaging) with proposed causal mechanisms (inflammation driving aging), is generalizable to organism-level aging, and links inflammation to systemic aging phenotypes and telomere biology.

results.title: Aging and anti-aging strategies: A review of past and future therapeutics.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging involves the buildup of senescent cells that have ceased dividing but remain metabolically active, secreting pro-inflammatory factors that contribute to tissue dysfunction and systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Clearance of senescent cells as intervention
key_concepts.description: Removing senescent cells can alleviate age-related decline and diseases, suggesting senescence is a causal driver of aging.

theories.evidence: Summary of research progress on clearance of senescent cells as an anti-aging strategy, citing signaling pathways and targets related to senescence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general causal mechanism of aging applicable organism-wide, proposes a mechanism (senescent cell accumulation), and discusses interventions targeting this mechanism.

theories.name: NAD+ decline and metabolic dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with decreased levels of NAD+, a critical coenzyme in metabolic and DNA repair processes, leading to cellular dysfunction and aging phenotypes.

key_concepts.concept: Restoration of NAD+ levels to delay aging
key_concepts.description: Boosting NAD+ levels can improve mitochondrial function, enhance DNA repair, and promote cellular health, thereby delaying aging and age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: Review of signaling pathways and targets involving NAD+ metabolism and their role in aging and anti-aging interventions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a fundamental biochemical mechanism underlying aging applicable broadly and discusses interventions targeting this mechanism.

theories.name: Oxidative stress and inflammation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging results from the accumulation of oxidative damage caused by reactive oxygen species, impairing cellular components and functions.
Persistent low-grade inflammation exacerbates tissue damage and functional decline during aging.
Enhancing antioxidant capacity and reducing inflammation can mitigate aging-related damage and promote healthy aging.

theories.evidence: Summary of anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory strategies and their impact on aging and age-related diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes causal mechanisms (oxidative damage and inflammation) broadly applicable to aging and discusses therapeutic approaches.

theories.name: Proteostasis dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging involves the decline in the cellular ability to maintain protein homeostasis, leading to accumulation of damaged or misfolded proteins that impair cellular function.
Interventions aimed at restoring proteostasis, such as enhancing protein degradation pathways or chaperone activity, can mitigate aging-related decline.

theories.evidence: Summary of research progress on proteostasis dysfunction and related anti-aging agents.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general causal mechanism of aging and discusses therapeutic strategies targeting this mechanism.

theories.name: Telomerase activation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Progressive shortening of telomeres during cell division leads to cellular senescence and organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Activation of telomerase to delay aging
key_concepts.description: Reactivating telomerase can maintain telomere length, potentially delaying cellular senescence and extending lifespan.

theories.evidence: Review of telomerase activation as an anti-aging strategy and its role in aging mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a fundamental cellular mechanism contributing to aging and discusses interventions targeting it.

results.title: The expression of heat shock protein 70 decreases with age in lymphocytes from rats and rhesus monkeys.
Molecular Mechanisms of Cellular Senescence in Neurodegenerative Diseases.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a cell fate
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence is a stable cell state triggered by various stimuli, characterized by permanent cell cycle arrest and distinct phenotypic changes. It is proposed as a fundamental mechanism contributing to organismal aging by altering tissue homeostasis.

Senescent cells secrete a range of pro-inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, growth factors, and proteases collectively termed SASP. SASP factors can disrupt tissue microenvironments, promote chronic inflammation, and influence neighboring cells, thereby driving aging-related pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Role in brain aging and neurodegeneration
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence contributes to brain aging by promoting neuronal dysfunction and chronic inflammation, which are implicated in neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. The theory links senescence to protein aggregation and neuronal loss observed in these disorders.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews pathological features of neurodegenerative diseases, discusses cellular senescence phenotypes (metabolism changes, ROS, SASP), and cites potential therapeutic interventions like senolytics targeting senescent cells.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (cellular senescence) explaining aging at the organismal level, links cellular changes to systemic aging and disease, and discusses mechanisms rather than mere correlations.

results.title: Time and aging--mechanisms and meanings.
Outfielders playing in the infield: functions of aging-associated "nuclear" proteins in the mitochondria.
Two age-related accumulation profiles of toxic metals.

theories.name: Toxic Metal Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Certain toxic metals such as mercury, arsenic, and cadmium accumulate progressively in the body with age, showing significant correlations with aging and gender differences. This accumulation is proposed to be linked to the aging process itself.

key_concepts.concept: Classification of toxic metals by accumulation profiles
key_concepts.description: Toxic metals can be grouped into two families based on their accumulation patterns: one group (mercury, arsenic, cadmium) accumulates with age in adults, while another group (cadmium, lead, aluminium) shows highest burden in infants, indicating different biological dynamics and potential impacts on aging.

key_concepts.concept: Potential causal role of toxic metals in accelerating aging
key_concepts.description: The theory suggests that higher body burdens of certain toxic metals may contribute causally to the acceleration of aging processes, implying that toxic metal accumulation is not merely correlative but may be mechanistically involved in aging.

theories.evidence: Large-scale measurement of toxic metal concentrations in scalp hair samples from 28,424 Japanese subjects across a wide age range, showing statistically significant age and gender correlations in metal accumulation profiles.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (toxic metal accumulation) potentially underlying aging, offers causal explanation (toxic burden leading to accelerated aging), and addresses aging broadly rather than a specific disease or organ.

results.title: Metabolic remodeling in cancer and senescence and its therapeutic implications.

theories.name: Metabolic remodeling as a driver of cellular senescence and aging

key_concepts.description: Senescent cells, despite being in a stable growth arrest state, undergo significant metabolic changes that resemble those observed in cancer cells. This metabolic remodeling is proposed to be a critical component of the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: Shared metabolic pathways between cancer and senescence
key_concepts.description: There are similarities and differences in the metabolic reprogramming of cancer and senescent cells, suggesting that altered metabolism is a fundamental mechanism influencing both pathological states and aging.

Understanding the metabolic changes in senescent cells can reveal vulnerabilities that can be exploited therapeutically, potentially leading to new senotherapies aimed at promoting healthy aging by modulating cellular metabolism.

theories.evidence: Comparative analysis of metabolic features in cancer and senescent cells, referencing recent advances in cancer metabolism and emerging insights into senescence metabolism; no direct experimental data presented in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental biological aging process (senescence) through metabolic remodeling, proposes underlying mechanisms (metabolic plasticity and reprogramming), and connects these mechanisms to systemic aging and therapeutic interventions, thus meeting all core criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Changes in M6A methylation: A key factor in the vicious cycle of flora -gut aging.

theories.name: m6A methylation-mediated gut aging theory

key_concepts.concept: m6A methylation as an epigenetic driver of aging
key_concepts.description: m6A methylation is an epigenetic modification that influences gene expression and cellular function. It is proposed to play a pivotal role in driving the aging process, particularly in the gastrointestinal tract.

key_concepts.concept: Interdependence between intestinal flora and m6A methylation
key_concepts.description: The balance of intestinal microbes is maintained through mechanisms involving m6A methylation. Disruption in this epigenetic regulation contributes to an imbalance in gut flora, which in turn exacerbates gut aging.

key_concepts.concept: Vicious cycle of gut aging and flora imbalance
key_concepts.description: Gut aging and intestinal flora imbalance mutually reinforce each other, creating a vicious cycle. m6A methylation is central to this cycle, suggesting that targeting it could break the cycle and attenuate or reverse gut aging.

theories.evidence: The abstract references existing research correlating intestinal flora imbalance and gut aging, and highlights the role of m6A methylation based on prior studies. No direct experimental data is presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process at the organismal level (gut aging as part of systemic aging) through epigenetic mechanisms (m6A methylation) affecting intestinal flora balance. It proposes a causal mechanism (epigenetic regulation) underlying aging and its feedback with microbiota, thus meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: Recovery from spreading depolarization is slowed by aging and accelerated by antioxidant treatment in locusts.
Macrophages at the crossroads of cellular senescence and cancer development and progression: Therapeutic opportunities and challenges.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.description: A state of irreversible cell cycle arrest in cells that contributes to aging and disease pathogenesis by accumulating in tissues and secreting pro-inflammatory factors.
Senescent cells secrete a variety of pro-inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, and proteases that modulate the tissue environment and influence immune cell function.
Macrophages recognize and phagocytose senescent cells to maintain tissue integrity and prevent dysfunction, thereby influencing aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Impact of macrophage dysfunction on senescence-associated pathologies
key_concepts.description: Altered macrophage function can impair clearance of senescent cells, exacerbating inflammation and contributing to age-related diseases including cancer.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing literature on macrophage-senescent cell interactions, macrophage polarization states, and their roles in aging and cancer progression.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental biological aging mechanism (cellular senescence), proposes causal roles of senescent cells and macrophages in aging and disease, and discusses organism-level implications beyond specific diseases.

theories.name: Macrophage plasticity in aging and cancer

key_concepts.description: Macrophages exhibit plasticity by polarizing into M1 (pro-inflammatory) or M2 (anti-inflammatory) phenotypes, which differentially influence tissue homeostasis, inflammation, and disease progression.
Macrophages can suppress tumor growth via immune activation or promote tumor progression through angiogenesis, immune evasion, and metastasis, highlighting their complex role in aging-related cancer.
Factors secreted by senescent cells modulate macrophage phenotype and function, affecting inflammation and tumor microenvironment dynamics.

theories.evidence: Synthesizes studies on macrophage phenotypes, their interaction with senescent cells, and roles in cancer microenvironment.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria as it addresses macrophage roles in aging-related processes and cancer at a systemic level, proposing mechanisms of immune modulation relevant to aging.

results.title: Exploration of New Therapies for Heart Failure Targeting Age-Related Mechanisms.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a causal driver
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the accumulation of senescent cells contributes causally to systemic aging and age-related pathologies. Senescent cells secrete pro-inflammatory and tissue-remodeling factors that disrupt tissue homeostasis and promote disease.

Targeted removal of senescent cells (senolysis) via genetic, pharmacologic, or vaccination approaches can reverse aging phenotypes and mitigate age-related diseases, supporting the causal role of senescence in aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent studies showing reversal of aging and pathologies in age-related diseases through senolytic approaches.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains aging as a fundamental process via accumulation of senescent cells; proposes causal mechanisms; addresses systemic aging and multiple age-related diseases.

theories.name: Sync-Aging Theory via Senometabolites

key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that circulating molecules termed 'senometabolites' or 'senoproteins' mediate systemic synchronization of aging across tissues, coordinating age-related decline.

key_concepts.concept: Senometabolite-related disorders (SRDs) and age-related fibrotic disorders (A-FiDs)
key_concepts.description: New concepts introduced to describe diseases driven by these circulating pro-senescent molecules, linking molecular signaling to systemic aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: Conceptual introduction of senometabolites and related disorders; ongoing research efforts mentioned.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Potentially meets criteria as it proposes a systemic causal mechanism for aging synchronization, but evidence is preliminary and conceptual.

theories.name: Metabolic Remodeling Theory of Aging

key_concepts.description: Aging involves changes in metabolic processes, including insulin resistance and alterations in brown adipose tissue homeostasis, which contribute to systemic aging and age-related cardiovascular and metabolic disorders.

key_concepts.concept: Role of brown adipose tissue homeostasis
key_concepts.description: Maintaining brown adipose tissue function is crucial to suppress progression of obesity and heart failure, linking metabolic remodeling to aging-related pathologies.

theories.evidence: Studies cited on brown adipose tissue and systemic insulin resistance in age-related diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria by proposing metabolic changes as underlying mechanisms of systemic aging and disease progression.

results.title: Inflammaging, Epigenetic Damage, Mitochondrial Dysfunctions, and Macrophage Alterations are the Main Missing Pieces in the Complex Mosaic of Stem Cell Physiology.

theories.name: Inflammaging theory

key_concepts.description: Inflammaging refers to the progressive increase in chronic low-grade inflammation that occurs with aging. This persistent inflammatory state is thought to contribute to the development of multiple age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Causal role in aging and disease
key_concepts.description: Although inflammaging is associated with aging and age-related diseases, its exact causal mechanisms remain unclear. The theory posits that inflammaging may drive systemic aging processes by influencing cellular and tissue function.
Inflammaging affects mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) by altering their behavior and functionality, which may impair tissue maintenance and regeneration, thereby contributing to organismal aging.

theories.evidence: Narrative review of recent studies linking inflammaging to stem cell alterations and age-related chronic diseases; no new experimental data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (chronic inflammation) with causal implications for systemic aging and disease, discusses mechanisms affecting stem cells relevant to organismal aging.

theories.name: Epigenetic damage theory of aging

key_concepts.description: This theory suggests that aging results from the progressive accumulation of epigenetic damage, such as DNA methylation changes and histone modifications, which disrupt gene regulation and cellular function.
Epigenetic damage affects stem cell behavior and regenerative capacity, contributing to the decline in tissue maintenance and repair observed during aging.

theories.evidence: Discussion of recent advances linking epigenetic changes to stem cell dysfunction and aging; no direct experimental evidence provided in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism underlying aging at the organismal level, connecting molecular changes to systemic aging phenotypes.

theories.name: Mitochondrial dysfunction theory of aging

key_concepts.description: Aging is driven in part by mitochondrial dysfunction, which leads to impaired energy production, increased reactive oxygen species, and cellular damage.

key_concepts.concept: Influence on stem cells and immune cells
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial changes affect stem cell behavior and macrophage function, thereby impacting tissue homeostasis and inflammatory status during aging.

theories.evidence: Review of literature linking mitochondrial alterations to stem cell and macrophage changes in aging; no new data presented.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental biological mechanism with causal implications for systemic aging and cellular dysfunction.

theories.name: Macrophage alteration theory in aging

key_concepts.description: Macrophages undergo functional alterations with age, which may contribute to chronic inflammation and impaired tissue repair.
Altered macrophage behavior influences inflammaging and stem cell niches, thereby playing a role in organismal aging processes.

theories.evidence: Narrative discussion of macrophage changes in aging and their impact on inflammation and stem cell physiology; no experimental data in abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Potentially meets criteria as it links immune cell dysfunction to systemic aging mechanisms, but may be more narrowly focused on immune aging unless explicitly connected to general aging.

results.title: Unraveling the relationship between metabolic syndrome and epigenetic aging: evidence from NHANES 1999-2002 and Mendelian randomization study.
Operationally defining cognitive reserve genes.

theories.name: Cognitive Reserve as a Mechanism of Resilience to Brain Aging

key_concepts.description: Cognitive reserve refers to the brain's plastic properties that allow some individuals to maintain better-than-expected cognitive function despite brain aging or pathology. It is conceptualized as a resilience mechanism that counteracts the negative effects of aging stressors on cognition.
Genes associated with cognitive reserve may act as negative regulators of aging-related processes such as neuroinflammation and oxidative stress, thereby protecting cognitive function during aging.

Decreased expression of certain cognitive reserve genes linked to nervous system development and cation transport suggests that adaptive changes in neural circuits help preserve cognition in aging brains.

theories.evidence: Gene expression data from the CA1 hippocampal region of young and aged male rats, statistical filtering, and multiple regression analyses identifying genes predictive of better-than-expected cognition relative to brain aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining why some individuals maintain cognitive function despite brain aging, involves causal explanations related to gene regulation of aging processes, and addresses aging broadly at the organismal cognitive level rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific focus.

results.title: Role of branched chain amino acid metabolism on aging.
A conserved complex lipid signature marks human muscle aging and responds to short-term exercise.

theories.name: Complex lipid accumulation theory of aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging is associated with a conserved increase in specific complex lipids, particularly BMP, across multiple tissues. This lipid accumulation is proposed as a hallmark or driver of the aging process at the organismal level.

key_concepts.concept: Modifiability of lipid signature by healthy-aging interventions
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of BMP is not fixed but can be modulated by interventions such as moderate-to-vigorous exercise, suggesting a causal or regulatory role of lipid metabolism in aging and potential reversibility or mitigation of aging effects.
The lipid signature identified in aged mice is also observed in human muscle tissue, indicating a conserved biological aging mechanism involving complex lipid metabolism.

theories.evidence: Lipidomics profiling of over 1,200 unique lipids in ten mouse tissues comparing young and aged animals; validation of BMP accumulation in human muscle tissue from young and older individuals; intervention study showing exercise reduces BMP levels in postmenopausal women.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (complex lipid accumulation) underlying aging across tissues and species, offers a causal explanation by linking lipid changes to aging and intervention effects, and addresses aging broadly rather than a single organ or disease.

results.title: Telomere dynamics in adult hematological malignancies.

theories.name: Telomere Shortening Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening as a cellular aging clock
key_concepts.description: Telomeres are repetitive DNA sequences that protect chromosome ends but shorten with each cell division, limiting cellular lifespan and renewal capacity in somatic cells. This shortening acts as a molecular clock that regulates cellular senescence and organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of telomere dynamics in organismal aging and disease
key_concepts.description: Telomere length is associated with age-related diseases, suggesting that telomere attrition contributes to systemic aging processes and disease susceptibility. The theory posits that telomere shortening is a fundamental mechanism underlying biological aging.

Cancer cells can bypass the replicative limit imposed by telomere shortening, achieving immortality through mechanisms such as telomerase activation. This highlights the causal role of telomere dynamics in cellular aging and transformation.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews current knowledge and associations between telomere length and aging, including data from hematological malignancies and age-related diseases, citing existing literature.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging at the cellular and organismal level, explains why aging occurs via telomere attrition, and links to systemic aging beyond specific diseases.

results.title: Roles of hypoxia-inducible factor-prolyl hydroxylases in aging and disease.

theories.name: HIF-PHD signaling pathway as a modulator of aging and aging-related diseases

key_concepts.description: HIFs are transcription factors that respond to oxygen levels in cells. Their stabilization by inhibition of prolyl hydroxylase domain-containing enzymes (PHDs) activates transcriptional programs that promote adaptive processes such as angiogenesis and erythropoiesis.

key_concepts.concept: Role of PHD enzymes beyond hypoxia
key_concepts.description: While traditionally studied in the context of hypoxia, PHD enzymes have important functions under normal oxygen conditions (normoxia), influencing cellular and systemic processes relevant to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of PHD enzymes in aging-related diseases
key_concepts.description: Modulating the HIF-PHD axis through inhibitors has clinical applications, notably in anemia, and emerging evidence suggests potential benefits for a broader range of aging-associated diseases, implying a mechanistic link to aging processes.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews recent discoveries and clinical applications of HIF-PH inhibitors, citing advances in PHD biology and therapeutic strategies targeting this pathway in aging-related diseases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses a signaling pathway (HIF-PHD) that is implicated in fundamental cellular responses affecting organismal aging and age-related diseases, proposing mechanisms by which modulation of this pathway influences aging processes. It addresses general aging-related mechanisms rather than narrow disease-specific phenomena, thus meeting the criteria for an aging theory-related discussion.

results.title: The telomere connection between aging and cancer: The burden of replication stress and dysfunction.

theories.name: Telomere dysfunction theory of aging and cancer

key_concepts.description: Telomeres are protective caps at chromosome ends that maintain genome stability. Their length and integrity are crucial, as both excessively short and excessively long telomeres can disrupt cellular homeostasis and contribute to aging and cancer development.

Fragile telomeres arise due to abnormalities and replication stress during DNA replication. The accumulation of these fragile telomeres may represent a key mechanism linking cellular aging processes to increased cancer susceptibility.

key_concepts.concept: Dynamic nature of telomeres in aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres are dynamic structures whose length and stability change over time, influenced by replicative stress and repair mechanisms. Understanding their longitudinal changes is essential to elucidate their role in systemic aging and age-related cancer risk.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known molecular and cellular observations about telomere length, replication stress, and their association with aging and cancer. It calls for large longitudinal studies to further clarify these relationships, indicating reliance on existing literature and proposing future research directions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain aging and cancer as systemic processes linked by telomere dynamics, proposing causal mechanisms involving replication stress and telomere dysfunction. It is generalizable beyond a single organ or disease, addresses causal explanations, and connects molecular mechanisms to organism-level aging and cancer incidence.

results.title: From biological aging to functional decline: Insights into chronic inflammation and intrinsic capacity.

theories.name: Chronic inflammation as a mechanism of aging

key_concepts.concept: Chronic inflammation drives aging-related functional decline
key_concepts.description: Chronic inflammation is proposed as a fundamental mechanism contributing to the decrease in physiological reserves and functional abilities observed during aging. It is linked to intrinsic capacity decline, which reflects overall physical and mental capacities.

key_concepts.concept: Intrinsic capacity as a marker of aging-related functional ability
key_concepts.description: Intrinsic capacity, defined as the sum of an individual's physical and mental capacities, serves as an integrative measure of functional ability and health status in aging. Decline in intrinsic capacity is associated with adverse health outcomes and may be influenced by chronic inflammation.

Markers such as interleukin-6, C-reactive protein, and tumor necrosis factor-alpha are investigated as potential indicators of intrinsic capacity decline and aging-related inflammation, though their specificity and sensitivity remain inconsistent. A multi-analyte approach may improve monitoring.

theories.evidence: Review of current research on chronic inflammation, inflammation-related markers, and intrinsic capacity; discussion of inconsistent results regarding inflammatory markers and intrinsic capacity domains.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The paper discusses chronic inflammation as a general mechanism underlying aging-related functional decline, linking it to intrinsic capacity, which is a broad measure of organism-level aging. It proposes causal mechanisms (inflammation driving decline) and addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow disease or organ. Thus, it meets the criteria for an aging theory-related discussion.

results.title: The Emerging Role of Accelerated Cellular Senescence in Periodontitis.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a manifestation of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence refers to the state where cells cease to divide and undergo distinctive phenotypic alterations, representing aging at the cellular level. This process normally accumulates in aged tissues and contributes to tissue dysfunction.

Exposure to sublethal oxidative stress, persistent bacterial infection, chronic inflammation, diabetes, and smoking can cause premature DNA damage, leading to early onset or accelerated cellular senescence beyond normal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells exacerbate tissue damage and inflammation
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells contribute to chronic inflammation by secreting pro-inflammatory factors, limiting tissue regeneration, remodeling tissues, and transmitting senescence to neighboring healthy cells, creating a vicious cycle that worsens tissue deterioration.

The paper proposes the ALTER acronym to summarize key senescence-associated features implicated in tissue deterioration: Accumulate, Limit regeneration, Transmit senescence, Exacerbate inflammation, and Remodel tissues.

theories.evidence: The paper discusses recent technological advances and literature showing that sublethal oxidative stress and risk factors promote accelerated senescence, with references to DNA damage and inflammation mechanisms; it is a review article synthesizing current knowledge rather than presenting new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (accelerated cellular senescence) explaining how aging processes contribute to periodontitis progression, linking cellular-level aging to organism-level tissue deterioration and chronic inflammation. It addresses a fundamental aging process (cellular senescence) with broad implications beyond a single disease, thus generalizable.

results.title: Gut Microbiome as a Target for Anti-ageing Interventions.

theories.name: Gut Microbiome Dysbiosis as a Driver of Accelerated Aging

key_concepts.description: The gut microbiome consists of trillions of microorganisms that influence host metabolism, immune system function, nervous system regulation, and production of essential compounds such as vitamins and short-chain fatty acids.
An imbalance in the gut microbial community, termed dysbiosis, is linked to chronic low-grade inflammation, which is recognized as a hallmark of aging and a contributor to age-related pathologies.
The composition and function of the gut microbiome change with age, potentially triggering or accelerating systemic aging processes through inflammatory and metabolic pathways.

key_concepts.concept: Targeting the Microbiome for Anti-Aging Interventions
key_concepts.description: Interventions such as diet modification, probiotics, prebiotics, antioxidants, and exercise may modulate the gut microbiome to promote healthy longevity and counteract aging-related dysbiosis.

theories.evidence: The abstract references known associations between dysbiosis, inflammation, and aging, and discusses interventions affecting the microbiome; no new experimental data are presented in the abstract.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (chronic inflammation driven by gut microbiome imbalance) with causal mechanisms linking microbiome changes to systemic aging, thus meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: Enhanced branched-chain amino acid metabolism improves age-related reproduction in C. elegans.
Dividing to keep muscle together: the role of satellite cells in aging skeletal muscle.

theories.name: Satellite cell depletion theory of muscle aging

key_concepts.concept: Role of satellite cells in muscle maintenance
key_concepts.description: Satellite cells are a population of stem-like cells located on the surface of skeletal muscle fibers that contribute to the maintenance and repair of muscle tissue throughout life. Their function is critical for preserving muscle integrity and preventing atrophy during aging.

This concept involves the maintenance of a stable ratio between myonuclei number and cytoplasmic volume within muscle fibers. Satellite cells help sustain this ratio by providing new nuclei to muscle fibers, which is essential for muscle fiber function and size.

key_concepts.concept: Satellite cell depletion as a driver of sarcopenia
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that a decline in satellite cell number or function with age contributes causally to skeletal muscle atrophy (sarcopenia) by impairing the muscle's ability to maintain myonuclear domains and regenerate, leading to progressive muscle loss.

theories.evidence: The abstract references recent evidence and highlights a study by Brack and colleagues investigating satellite cells' role in maintaining myonuclear number to cytoplasmic volume ratio during aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal mechanism (satellite cell depletion) underlying a fundamental aging phenotype (muscle atrophy) with implications for organism-level aging. It attempts to explain why muscle aging occurs generally, not limited to a specific disease, and connects cellular mechanisms to systemic aging.

results.title: Autophagy-dependent splicing control directs translation toward inflammation during senescence.
Genetic Signatures of Centenarians: Implications for Achieving Successful Aging.

theories.name: Genetic Longevity Theory

key_concepts.description: Longevity, especially exceptional longevity as seen in centenarians, has a significant genetic component that increases with age, reaching up to 33% heritability in women and 48% in men over 90 years old. This suggests that genetic factors play a crucial role in determining lifespan.

Longevity is proposed to correlate with the presence of protective alleles that promote successful aging and the absence of detrimental alleles that contribute to age-related diseases. This genetic makeup influences the delay or avoidance of major age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Successful Aging as a Genetic Trait
key_concepts.description: Successful aging, characterized by extreme longevity and delayed onset of age-related diseases, is viewed as a complex, heritable trait that can be studied through the genetic signatures found in centenarians, providing insights into mechanisms underlying aging.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews genetic studies on centenarians showing heritability estimates and associations between longevity and specific genetic variants, citing growing evidence from population genetics.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging focused on genetic mechanisms influencing lifespan and disease resistance, addressing aging broadly at the organism level.

results.title: Transglutaminase 2-mediated glutamine deamidation enhances p21 stability during senescence.

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Replicative senescence as a driver of cellular aging
key_concepts.description: Cells have a limited capacity to divide, known as replicative senescence, which contributes to cellular aging. This process is triggered by telomere erosion that activates a DNA damage response, halting cell proliferation.

key_concepts.concept: p53-p21 pathway mediates cell cycle arrest during senescence
key_concepts.description: DNA damage activates p53, a transcriptional regulator that increases expression of p21, a cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor. p21 arrests cells at specific cell cycle stages, enforcing senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Post-translational stabilization of p21 by transglutaminase 2 (TGM2)
key_concepts.description: SerpinB2 upregulation activates TGM2, which enzymatically deamidates glutamine residues on p21, stabilizing the protein and maintaining cell cycle arrest in senescent cells.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation of senescence impacts aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Inhibition of TGM2-mediated deamidation accelerates p21 degradation and delays senescence onset, while pharmacological inhibition of TGM2 improves aging phenotypes in a chronic kidney disease accelerated aging model.

theories.evidence: Experimental data showing TGM2-mediated deamidation stabilizes p21; inhibition of TGM2 delays senescence in cells; pharmacological inhibition improves aging phenotypes in a CKD model.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental cellular aging process (cellular senescence) with causal mechanisms (p53-p21 pathway and TGM2-mediated stabilization) that impact organismal aging phenotypes; generalizable beyond specific disease; proposes mechanistic explanation of aging.

results.title: CT Biomarkers for Phenotypic Biological Aging: Emerging Concepts and Advantages.
Unraveling the complexity of chaperone-mediated autophagy in aging: insights into sex-specific and cell-type-specific regulation.
Extracellular Vesicles in Aging and Age-Related Diseases. How Important Are They?
Senescence: An Identity Crisis Originating from Deep Within the Nucleus.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Senescence as a causal driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence contributes causally to organismal aging and age-related diseases, not merely by loss of cell function but through active changes in cell behavior.
Senescent cells secrete a variety of factors that affect neighboring cells and tissues, leading to systemic impacts beyond the senescent cells themselves.

key_concepts.concept: Cell identity shift and gain-of-function phenotype
key_concepts.description: Senescence involves a shift in cell identity characterized by altered gene expression and epigenetic changes, resulting in a gain-of-function state rather than simple functional decline.
The epigenetic landscape is tightly linked to cell type-specific gene expression, causing heterogeneity in senescence phenotypes across different cell types.

theories.evidence: The abstract references broad physiological and pathological roles of senescence, the secretory phenotype, and epigenetic features, implying synthesis of existing literature rather than new experimental data.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It addresses aging as a fundamental process at the organism level, proposes causal mechanisms (senescence and SASP), and discusses generalizable principles (cell identity shifts and epigenetic regulation).

results.title: Genomic signatures of exceptional longevity and negligible aging in the long-lived red sea urchin.

theories.name: Genomic maintenance and homeostasis theory of negligible aging

key_concepts.description: The theory posits that enhanced genomic regulation and stability mechanisms, including chromosome rearrangements and gene family expansions, contribute to longevity by maintaining DNA integrity and proper gene expression over time.

Maintenance of protein quality and accurate mRNA processing are critical to prevent accumulation of damaged or misfolded proteins, which can drive aging; this theory highlights these processes as key to negligible senescence.
Optimized mitochondrial function supports cellular energy demands and reduces oxidative damage, thereby contributing to the organism’s ability to avoid age-related decline.
An expanded and effective innate immune system is proposed to protect long-lived organisms from infections and diseases that could otherwise accelerate aging.
The capacity for continuous tissue maintenance and reproduction without increased mortality suggests mechanisms that preserve organismal function and delay aging.

theories.evidence: Chromosome-level genome assembly and comparative genomics identifying gene family expansions, positive selection in genes related to genome regulation, mRNA fidelity, protein homeostasis, mitochondrial function, and innate immunity; comparative analysis with short-lived species.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes causal mechanisms underlying negligible aging at the organismal level, generalizable beyond a single tissue or disease, and explains how longevity is achieved through integrated genomic and cellular maintenance processes.

results.title: [Non-targeted renal metabolomics reveals multi-target effects of Dahuang Zhechong Pills on renal aging in rats].

theories.name: Cellular senescence theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that the accumulation of senescent cells, which cease to divide and secrete pro-inflammatory factors known as the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), contributes causally to tissue dysfunction and organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of cell cycle arrest proteins and SASP
key_concepts.description: Proteins associated with cell cycle arrest and SASP are markers and effectors of senescent cells that promote aging phenotypes by altering tissue microenvironments and impairing regenerative capacity.
Klotho is a protein with anti-aging properties; its decreased expression is linked to aging phenotypes, while upregulation is associated with improved tissue function and delayed aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from a D-galactose-induced rat renal aging model showing changes in SA-β-gal staining (a senescence marker), expression levels of Klotho, cell cycle arrest proteins, and SASP proteins; intervention with DHZCP and vitamin E modulated these markers and improved renal function and histopathology.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a general aging mechanism (cellular senescence) with causal explanations (cell cycle arrest, SASP), supported by experimental intervention, and is applicable to organismal aging beyond a single organ.

theories.name: AMPK signaling pathway in aging regulation

key_concepts.concept: AMPK as a metabolic sensor and regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) senses cellular energy status and regulates metabolic pathways to maintain energy homeostasis; activation of AMPK is linked to lifespan extension and mitigation of aging-related decline.
AMPK interacts with multiple signaling pathways including mTOR, PI3K-Akt, cAMP, and autophagy pathways, coordinating cellular responses that influence aging and longevity.

theories.evidence: The study shows DHZCP treatment upregulated key proteins in the AMPK signaling pathway in aged rat kidneys, alongside improvements in renal aging markers and metabolic profiles, suggesting AMPK pathway involvement in anti-aging effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a mechanistic pathway (AMPK signaling) that causally influences aging processes broadly, supported by experimental modulation and metabolic pathway analysis.

results.title: T cells and aging (update february 1999).

theories.name: Immunosenescence as a contributor to systemic aging

key_concepts.description: The immune system progressively loses function during aging, leading to increased susceptibility to infections, autoimmune phenomena, and cancer in elderly individuals.
Dysregulation of T cell function is a critical component of immunosenescence, affecting immune response and contributing to age-related morbidity.

key_concepts.concept: Multiple contributing factors to T cell immunosenescence
key_concepts.description: Factors include stem cell defects, thymus involution, defects in antigen presenting cells, aging of resting immune cells, disrupted activation pathways, and replicative senescence of clonally expanding cells, all of which collectively impair immune function.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing current knowledge and scientific basis of factors contributing to immunosenescence, citing existing research and clinical observations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation for aging-related immune decline, addressing systemic aging mechanisms rather than a narrow phenomenon. It discusses underlying causes and mechanisms of immune aging relevant to organism-level aging.

results.title: Aging in check.

theories.name: Spindle Checkpoint Dysfunction-Induced Premature Aging Theory

key_concepts.description: The spindle checkpoint ensures proper chromosome segregation during mitosis by delaying anaphase onset until all chromosomes are correctly attached to the spindle apparatus, preventing chromosomal instability.

key_concepts.concept: Role of Bub3 and Rae1 in aging
key_concepts.description: Bub3 and Rae1, components of the spindle checkpoint, have a newly identified role in regulating aging, where their deficiency leads to premature aging phenotypes linked to early cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The premature aging observed in mice with reduced Bub3 and Rae1 is associated with precocious activation of cellular senescence programs rather than apoptosis, suggesting senescence as a causal mechanism in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Link between spindle checkpoint compromise and organismal aging
key_concepts.description: Compromised spindle checkpoint activity predisposes to premature aging phenotypes in vivo, indicating that mitotic checkpoint integrity is important for maintaining organismal longevity.

theories.mode: discuss, cite recent study linking spindle checkpoint to aging
theories.evidence: Reference to a recent study showing mice haploinsufficient for Bub3 and Rae1 have shortened lifespan and early aging features linked to cellular senescence activation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a general causal mechanism (spindle checkpoint dysfunction leading to cellular senescence) explaining why aging occurs at the organismal level; it is not limited to a single organ or disease and connects mitotic regulation to systemic aging.

results.title: A cognitive-motor framework for spatial navigation in aging and early-stage Alzheimer's disease.

theories.name: Cognitive-Motor Integration Theory of Spatial Navigation Decline in Aging and Alzheimer's Disease

key_concepts.description: Spatial navigation decline in aging and early Alzheimer's disease arises from combined impairments in both cognitive functions and motor abilities such as gait and dynamic balance, rather than purely cognitive deficits.

key_concepts.concept: Overlap of sensory, cognitive, and motor systems
key_concepts.description: Spatial navigation and functional mobility share overlapping sensory systems, cognitive processes, and brain structures that are vulnerable to aging and neurodegeneration, indicating an integrated network underlying navigation.

key_concepts.concept: Early neuromodulatory and peripheral sensory changes
key_concepts.description: Deficits in spatial navigation may be driven initially by early alterations in neuromodulatory systems and peripheral sensory inputs, which precede the classical neurodegenerative changes in brain regions like the entorhinal cortex.

Spatial navigation is proposed as a meaningful phenotype that reflects combined cognitive and motor dysfunction in aging, providing a more comprehensive framework than models focusing solely on higher-order cognitive brain regions.

theories.evidence: Review of emerging evidence from neurobiological studies showing overlapping sensory and motor contributions to spatial navigation decline in aging and Alzheimer's disease; discussion of brain regions and systems involved.
