theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for aging-related decline in spatial navigation by integrating cognitive and motor mechanisms, addressing systemic aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: IL-1 in aging and pathologies of hematopoietic stem cells.

theories.name: Inflammaging-driven hematopoietic stem cell dysfunction theory

key_concepts.description: Continuous, low-grade activation of interleukin-1 (IL-1) cytokines creates a persistent inflammatory environment that impairs the function of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs) during aging.

The sustained inflammatory state driven by IL-1 acts as a selective pressure that promotes hematological alterations such as clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) and progression to hematopoietic malignancies.

IL-1 cytokines are essential for defense against infection and tissue damage at younger ages but become detrimental when chronically activated in aging, contributing to systemic aging-related pathologies.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing literature on IL-1 cytokines, their conserved role in inflammation, and their contribution to HSPC dysfunction and hematological diseases in aging; it also discusses potential therapeutic implications of IL-1 pathway inhibition.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (chronic IL-1-driven inflammation) explaining how aging-associated inflammatory processes impair stem cell function and drive systemic hematopoietic aging and disease; it addresses aging broadly at the organismal level through hematopoietic system aging and links inflammation to aging mechanisms.

results.title: Telomere length variations in aging and age-related diseases.

theories.name: Telomere attrition theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Telomere length as a biomarker of aging
key_concepts.description: Telomeres are repetitive gene sequences at chromosome ends that protect genome integrity. Their length is maximal at birth and progressively shortens with age, making telomere length a marker correlated with chronological aging.
Telomere shortening results from oxidative stress, inflammation, and repeated cell replication, which cumulatively damage telomeres and reduce their length over time.

key_concepts.concept: Link between telomere shortening and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: Shortened telomeres are associated with increased risk and progression of multiple age-related diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, Alzheimer's disease, and cancer, suggesting a causal role in systemic aging and disease susceptibility.

key_concepts.concept: Bidirectional relationship between aging, disease, and telomere length
key_concepts.description: Aging and age-related diseases not only synergistically affect telomere length but can also independently influence telomere dynamics, indicating complex interactions between biological aging processes and disease states.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews existing research linking telomere length dynamics with aging and age-related diseases, citing associations with oxidative stress, inflammation, cell replication, and disease correlations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The telomere attrition theory meets all criteria: it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging at the organism level, explaining why biological aging occurs via telomere shortening; it addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases; and it links molecular mechanisms to systemic aging.

results.title: Synergistic association of estimated glucose disposal rate and neutrophil-to-albumin ratio with accelerated biological aging.

theories.name: Metabolic-Inflammatory Axis Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Insulin resistance as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Insulin resistance, reflected by estimated glucose disposal rate (eGDR), is proposed as a hallmark linked to the aging process. Reduced insulin sensitivity is associated with accelerated biological aging, suggesting metabolic dysfunction contributes causally to systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Chronic inflammation as a causal factor in aging
key_concepts.description: Chronic systemic inflammation, measured by neutrophil-to-albumin ratio (NPAR), is implicated as a key mechanism accelerating biological aging. Inflammation affects metabolic processes and promotes aging-related functional decline.

key_concepts.concept: Synergistic interaction between metabolic dysfunction and inflammation
key_concepts.description: The combined effect of low insulin sensitivity and high systemic inflammation synergistically increases the risk of accelerated biological aging. This interplay highlights the metabolic-inflammatory axis as a pivotal mechanism underlying organism-level aging.

theories.evidence: Cross-sectional analysis of 35,169 U.S. adults from NHANES data using biological age acceleration metrics (KDM-BA and PhenoAge), multivariable regression, and dose-response modeling showing independent and combined associations of eGDR and NPAR with accelerated aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation for biological aging at the organism level through metabolic and inflammatory mechanisms, supported by population-level data linking these processes to biological age acceleration.

results.title: Long-lived cellular molecules in the brain.

theories.name: Long-lived cellular molecules theory of brain aging

key_concepts.description: Certain proteins and RNAs in brain cells do not turnover for months or years, suggesting that some cellular components are exceptionally long-lived compared to typical molecular turnover rates.
These long-lived molecules may be critical for preserving neuronal identity and plasticity, thereby supporting brain homeostasis and function throughout the lifespan.
Because these molecules persist for extended periods, they may accumulate damage or dysfunction over time, representing a convergent mechanism contributing to brain aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of recent evidence showing long-lived proteins and RNAs in brain cells; discussion of cellular homeostasis and molecular turnover studies
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism explaining how aging might occur at the cellular level in the brain, linking molecular longevity to functional decline; provides causal explanation by implicating long-lived molecules as potential aging drivers; scope is broad as it addresses brain aging as part of organismal aging.

results.title: Prevention of cardiovascular disease for healthy aging and longevity: A new scoring system and related "mechanisms-hallmarks-biomarkers".

theories.name: Healthy lifestyle intervention theory for aging and longevity

key_concepts.description: A composite lifestyle intervention encompassing environment, sleep, emotion, exercise, and diet aimed at improving human immunity and preventing cardiovascular diseases, thereby promoting healthy aging and longevity.
A series of cellular and molecular processes and indicators that mediate the beneficial effects of the E(e)SEEDi lifestyle on delaying aging and increasing life expectancy.

key_concepts.concept: Scoring system for life expectancy prediction
key_concepts.description: A novel quantitative system assigning points to core lifestyle factors (20 points each, total 120) to predict and evaluate healthy aging and longevity, linking lifestyle quality to biological aging outcomes.

theories.evidence: Review of associations between lifestyle factors and cardiovascular aging; development of a scoring system; conceptual linkage to cellular and molecular mechanisms (no direct experimental data presented in abstract).
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal explanation linking lifestyle interventions to systemic aging processes via immunity and cardiovascular health, addressing aging broadly and proposing mechanisms and biomarkers.

results.title: Retrotransposon SINEs in age-related diseases: Mechanisms and therapeutic implications.

theories.name: SINE Retrotransposon Involvement in Aging and Age-Related Diseases

key_concepts.concept: Retrotransposon Activity as a Driver of Aging
key_concepts.description: SINEs are self-replicating genomic elements that can move within the genome via RNA intermediates, potentially causing genomic instability or dysregulation that contributes to aging processes and age-related diseases.

SINEs are implicated in multiple age-related diseases including neurodegenerative disorders, cardiovascular diseases, metabolic diseases, osteoporosis, visual dysfunctions, and cancer, suggesting a broad role in systemic aging pathology.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic Targeting of SINEs for Anti-Aging
key_concepts.description: Targeting SINEs, particularly through antisense RNA approaches, may mitigate cellular and molecular age-related alterations, offering a potential intervention strategy to promote healthy aging and treat age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper is a review summarizing current knowledge and recent investigations including experimental and clinical studies on SINEs in aging and age-related diseases, as well as therapeutic interventions targeting SINEs.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism (retrotransposon activity) contributing to aging and age-related diseases broadly, discusses causal mechanisms (genomic instability and molecular alterations), and connects to systemic aging rather than narrow disease focus.

results.title: Unraveling the functional and molecular interplay between cellular senescence and the unfolded protein response.

theories.name: Cellular senescence as a causal driver of systemic aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a stress response phenotype
key_concepts.description: Senescence is described as a complex cellular state triggered by stress, leading to a stable cell cycle arrest and altered cellular functions that contribute to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Unfolded Protein Response (UPR) involvement in senescence
key_concepts.description: The UPR, a cellular stress response related to protein folding in the endoplasmic reticulum, is intricately connected to the development and regulation of the senescent phenotype.

key_concepts.concept: UPR's role in biological processes linked to aging
key_concepts.description: UPR signaling influences oxidative stress and autophagy, processes that are implicated in aging and age-related pathologies, suggesting a mechanistic link between protein homeostasis and senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic targeting of UPR components to mitigate senescence effects
key_concepts.description: Modulating specific elements of the UPR pathway may provide novel interventions to reduce the detrimental impacts of senescent cells on organismal aging and related diseases.

theories.evidence: Summary of advances over the past decade, including new insights into UPR and senescence interplay; references to biological processes such as oxidative stress and autophagy; proposal of therapeutic strategies based on these mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses cellular senescence as a fundamental aging mechanism with causal explanations involving UPR signaling; proposes underlying mechanisms relevant to organismal aging and potential interventions; not limited to a narrow phenomenon.

results.title: CRISPR-Cas9 mediated d3GHR knockout in HEK293 cells: Revealing the longevity associated isoform stress resilience.

theories.name: Growth Hormone Receptor Isoform Longevity Theory

key_concepts.description: A specific genetic variation of the Growth Hormone Receptor gene, termed d3GHR, which lacks exon 3, is associated with increased longevity. This isoform alters the structure and potentially the function of the GHR protein, influencing lifespan.

Cells expressing the d3GHR isoform show increased survival under environmental stressors such as UV radiation and fasting, suggesting that this isoform confers enhanced cellular stress resistance, a factor linked to aging processes.

The d3GHR isoform affects downstream signaling pathways, notably IGF1 and JAK/STAT, with homozygous d3GHR cells showing significantly reduced baseline expression of these genes, which may relate to mechanisms underlying aging and longevity.

theories.evidence: CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing was used to create d3GHR isoform cell lines (homozygous and heterozygous) in HEK293 cells. Viability assays under UV radiation and fasting conditions showed increased survival for d3GHR cells compared to wild type. Gene expression analysis revealed significant changes in IGF1 and JAK/STAT signaling pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable mechanism linking a genetic variation in a key hormonal receptor to fundamental aging processes (stress resilience and signaling pathways) that affect organismal lifespan. It provides causal explanations through altered signaling and stress response, addressing aging broadly rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific phenomenon.

results.title: Genes of human longevity: an endless quest?

theories.name: IGF-I/insulin signaling pathway theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Genetic variants in IGF1R affecting longevity
key_concepts.description: Specific polymorphisms in the Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 Receptor gene are correlated with longevity, particularly in centenarians, suggesting that genetic modulation of IGF1 signaling influences lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Low plasma IGF1 levels linked to increased lifespan
key_concepts.description: Lower circulating levels of IGF1, associated with certain IGF1R variants, may contribute to longevity by modulating growth and metabolic pathways that impact aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: IGF-I/insulin pathway as a conserved regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: This pathway is implicated as a key regulator of aging across species, influencing cellular growth, metabolism, and stress resistance, thus providing a mechanistic explanation for aging at the organismal level.

theories.evidence: Genetic association studies identifying SNPs in IGF1R correlated with longevity in centenarians; plasma IGF1 level measurements; references to prior research on IGF-I/insulin pathway in aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism underlying aging at the organism level, supported by genetic and biochemical data, and linked to a fundamental biological pathway.

theories.name: mTOR signaling pathway theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: mTOR as a central regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: The mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway integrates nutrient and growth signals to regulate cellular metabolism, growth, and autophagy, thereby influencing aging and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Modulation of mTOR activity affects lifespan
key_concepts.description: Inhibition or modulation of mTOR signaling has been shown to extend lifespan in multiple model organisms, suggesting its role as a conserved aging mechanism.

theories.evidence: Citations of studies linking mTOR pathway activity to longevity; discussion of mTOR as a promising target for longevity interventions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it addresses a fundamental, organism-level aging mechanism with causal implications, supported by experimental data from various species.

theories.name: Genetic variants in APOE and longevity

key_concepts.description: Different alleles of the apolipoprotein E gene are associated with variations in human longevity, possibly through effects on lipid metabolism, cardiovascular health, and neurodegeneration.

key_concepts.concept: APOE as a genetic locus linked to healthy aging
key_concepts.description: Large-scale genetic studies, such as the GEHA project, have identified APOE among key chromosomal regions associated with extended lifespan and healthy aging phenotypes.

theories.evidence: Data from the GEHA project and other genetic association studies linking APOE variants to longevity outcomes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Partially meets criteria; while APOE variants are linked to longevity, the abstract does not elaborate a mechanistic causal theory of aging but rather an association; however, it is connected to general aging processes.
